title: Address by Member of the Presidency of BiH Dr Denis Bećirović on the Occasion of the Unveiling of the Monument “Flower of Srebrenica” at the United Nations Square in Vienna
content:
Honourable Mothers of Srebrenica, esteemed families of the victims of genocide, Excellencies, Eminences, lLadies and gentlemen, it is my honour to address you on behalf of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with sincere gratitude for demonstrating solidarity and profound respect for the victims of genocide here in the capital of the Republic of Austria.
Today is an important day for Bosnia and Herzegovina, for Europe, and for the world.
Today, in the friendly Republic of Austria — in one of Europe’s and the world’s cultural capitals, the city of Vienna — we are unveiling a monument to the victims of genocide.
The genocide against Bosniaks was committed in and around Srebrenica, within a United Nations (UN) safe area. Therefore, it carries deep symbolism that this monument is being unveiled at the UN Square and on the UN Day.
From Vienna, we are sending a global message that the victims of genocide are not forgotten — and that the deniers of truth will not prevail.
This monument stands in the service of truth, justice, and the prevention of future evil.
I extend special respect to the “Mothers of Srebrenica,” who have been fighting for truth and justice for decades.
The Mothers of Srebrenica are Bosnian and European heroines.
Their courage and unbreakable spirit serve as an inspiration to all of us.
The strength of the heroines of Srebrenica and Podrinje reminds us that even in the darkest moments, love is stronger than hatred, and truth is stronger than lies.
I thank the Republic of Austria for its support in the adoption of the Resolution on the International Day of Remembrance and Commemoration of the Genocide in Srebrenica at the UN General Assembly.
As a person who led the complex process of adopting that Resolution, I feel both a human and political obligation to express my gratitude to the friendly Republic of Austria for its support in this historic achievement.
I also thank President Dr Alexander Van der Bellen and the friendly people of the Republic of Austria for the comprehensive assistance their country has provided to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I express my deep gratitude to the Mayor of Vienna, Dr Michael Ludwig, without whose help we would not be unveiling this monument today.
I am also grateful to the Bosnian and Herzegovinian diaspora in Austria, which continues to strengthen the bonds of friendship between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Austria — particularly to the members of associations within the Consilium Bosniacum Alliance.
I thank everyone who, in any way, contributed to the realization of this important project.
Thank you for helping to embed the truth about the genocide against Bosniaks into Austria’s and Europe’s collective memory.
Between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Republic of Austria, there exists deep historical, cultural, and other ties — written into our architecture, art, education, and many other fields.
During the aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Republic of Austria opened its doors to many refugees and displaced citizens of our country.
Bosnia and Herzegovina deeply values the selfless assistance of the Republic of Austria.
Ladies and gentlemen,
The monument we are unveiling today stands as a warning to future generations — never to accept lies instead of truth,
and always to respect the final judgments of UN courts.
I call on the democratic world to support Bosnia and Herzegovina more decisively on its Euro-Atlantic and European path.
This is a geopolitical investment in collective European security.
It is a shared interest of both Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Republic of Austria.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Through the culture of remembrance, we defend the idea of a democratic Europe.
I thank the friendly Republic of Austria for preserving the truth about the genocide committed against the Bosniaks.
May the friendship between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Republic of Austria live forever!
Thank you for your attention!

title: The Chair of the Presidency of BiH, Željko Komšić, attended the unveiling ceremony of the monument "Flower of Srebrenica" in front of the UN building in Vienna, on the occasion of United Nations Day
content:
The monument, symbolizing remembrance, truth, and a warning to humanity, was erected with the support of the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Austria, and organized by the Alliance of Bosnian Associations in Austria "Consilium Bosniacum."
In his address to those gathered, the Chair of the Presidency of BiH, Željko Komšić, emphasized that the United Nations Square is the most fitting place for a monument to the victims of the Srebrenica genocide, and that it is the duty of all to preserve the memory of the victims and ensure that such crimes never happen again.
"Dear citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina in Austria,
Ladies and gentlemen,
It is an honour to be here with you today in Vienna, as you unveil the monument ‘Flower of Srebrenica.’
The United Nations Square in Vienna is the most appropriate place in this city for such a monument to be built — for many reasons, both positive and negative. Let us begin with the positive ones.
The fact is that the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) was established by a decision of the United Nations, and that it both de facto and de jure represented a Court of the United Nations.
That Court established judicial truth about a number of facts and events that occurred in July 1995 within the so-called UN "safe area" of Srebrenica — events that were legally qualified as genocide against the Bosniaks of the Srebrenica enclave.
The UN Court also determined, based on facts, the nature of the crimes that preceded the genocide — crimes that had been continuously committed from 1992 until the final genocidal operation in July 1995.
This judicially established truth, through verdicts for genocide and for crimes against humanity, is now known worldwide. In many countries, genocide denial in Srebrenica is not only socially unacceptable but also punishable by law.
The genocide in Srebrenica has become a historical precedent in Bosnian history, as it marks the first time that an attempt to annihilate a people on such a scale has been documented and institutionally memorialized.
Even earlier in our history, similar crimes and massacres occurred — but this is the first time that those who were direct victims of genocide in Bosnia and Herzegovina have been able, in their own country and their own state, to record what was done to them and to remember it in different ways.
The role and assistance of the United Nations Court in this was enormous — I would even say decisive.
Unfortunately, there is also the negative, darker side of the overall role of the United Nations in the genocide in Srebrenica, which we must never forget. That is one of the main reasons why we are unveiling this monument here today.
It is also a fact that the United Nations, as the leading international institution, bears direct responsibility for the genocide in Srebrenica.
By proclaiming Srebrenica a protected zone under its authority, and declaring demilitarization that in practice meant disarming only the Army of Bosnia and Herzegovina — but not the forces of the Army of Republika Srpska — the United Nations enabled the genocidal operation of July 1995.
The Dutch UN battalion served as an assistant in carrying out the genocide against the Bosniaks of Srebrenica and Podrinje, just as the Ukrainian UN contingent was responsible for the death of Commander Avdo Palić in Žepa.
That act of cowardice, the weakness of the UN forces, and their alignment with the perpetrators faithfully reflect the role of the UN military presence — demonstrating that their attitude toward the Bosniaks of Srebrenica was not an exception, but rather the rule.
As a Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and as a Bosnian and Herzegovinian, I am proud that my country did not stand on the side of crimes and genocide taking place in the world today.
One often hears, from many sides, that it is neither wise nor prudent to take sides in international conflicts.
But where conflicts go beyond military clashes and become attacks on the unarmed and the innocent, then taking sides is not a question of wisdom — it is a question of character, morality, and human dignity.
That is why I am proud that we condemned the genocide against the Palestinians, as well as the Russian aggression against Ukraine.
We do not believe we can correct all the world’s injustices — we are not that naïve.
We must, above all, look after our own interests — the security and stability of our state — but our clear stance toward injustice committed against others gives us the moral right to stand here today with our heads held high, remembering Srebrenica and all that was done to Srebrenica and to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We are also here to send a clear message: never again will we allow the fate of the people of our country to be placed in the hands of anyone outside of ourselves.
We will build good relations with all states that are friendly toward our homeland.
With those that are not, we will strive to maintain correct relations — but never again will we trust in foreign guarantees or foreign protection.
Our bloody history has taught us that lesson.
Thank you for your attention."

title: The Chairman of the Presidency of BiH, Željko Komšić, is participating in the Brdo
content:
The theme of this summit is “Common Interests, Common Commitment for a Common Future: Together Towards the EU.”
The Chairman of the Presidency of BiH, Željko Komšić, addressed the participants of the Summit.
"Thank you for the invitation to another gathering of the Brdo Brijuni Process, this time in Durres.
We have more or less permanent topics for our discussions: European integration, Growth Plan, youth and brain drain, regional cooperation and regional security.
I want to repet again that European integration is still our path and our goal, regardless of various disappointments. Disappointments that are mutual, both European and ours.
For some time now, it seems that the EU and we from the Western Balkans often operate on "different frequencies". The EU says it wants us to join, we say we want the same, but in reality it all looks like we are talking and thinking about completely different things.
The generation from our region that embarked on European integration with hope at the beginning of this century is already approaching to the end of its working life.
Two and a half decades later, enthusiasm has been replaced by the fatigue of an entire generation.
Those who have long since stopped accepting small steps in social reforms as normality, reforms that are necessary and that are happening slowly or not at all, are caught up in, so called, the 'brain drain'.
And it cannot be stopped by anything other than changing policies, implementing reforms and changing relations among ourselves, but also by creating a stable region.
A stable region, dedicated to social change and reform, reform wich can create security.
A region without territorial claims, without rattling weapons, without interfering in the internal affairs of other states, without cheap populism.
An unstable region is a source of insecurity, and as such necessarily leads to depopulation and economic decline.
It is pointless to talk about declarative aspirations towards regional cooperation and European integration without a real political consensus on regional cooperation, finding some common economic denominators and leaving the political practices of the past, which lead nowhere.
The declaration proposed at this meeting is good for adoption at this time.
Finally, the declaration does not touch on any issue on which there is no consensus.
But the time is coming when we will have to start answering difficult questions in this format as well.
I suggest that we consider that, to begin with, we can open discussions about possible joint economic projects that cross the borders of our countries. Projects in the field of energy, needed by all of us, can be the beginning of such a practice.
There is interest, both, ours and the interest of potential partners outside our region.
And finally,
Honorable presidents, thank you for your attention and thank you to our host today too!"

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of BiH Dr Denis Bećirović at the Summit of Leaders of the Brdo - Brioni Process Countries
content:
Distinguished President Begaj, honourable colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, I extend my gratitude to our esteemed hosts from the Republic of Albania for their warm hospitality and excellent organization.
Dialogue, cooperation, and mutual respect in our region are more important today than ever before.
Through active participation in regional initiatives, Bosnia and Herzegovina demonstrates that it is a proactive and constructive partner.
In this context, we will continue to actively support regional cooperation, including the Brdo – Brioni Process initiative.
Let me remind you that the foreign policy of Bosnia and Herzegovina toward neighbouring and other countries is based, above all, on respect for independence, sovereignty, and territorial integrity, as well as on adherence to the fundamental principles of international law.
In the years following the Second World War, only a few believed that the unification of our continent was possible.
European visionaries such as Schuman, Adenauer, and Spinelli showed that the vision of a united Europe is stronger than fear, prejudice, and hatred.
The political wisdom of European leaders turned former enemies into allies who built a unique European project — a symbol of lasting cooperation and strategic vision for Europe.
This important lesson must be understood and applied in our region as well.
We in the Western Balkans must not forget that the process of European integration is a "two-way street."
Why a "two-way street"? Because the path toward the European Union (EU) does not mean only taking money from European funds and development projects. Above all, it means embracing the core European values and standards.
Unfortunately, we are witnessing trends in some countries of the region where European values are being pushed aside, and practices incompatible with modern democracy are being promoted instead. Such a trend must be stopped.
Ladies and gentlemen,
there can be no genuine peace and progress in Southeast Europe without abandoning the idea of creating "greater states."
The dangerous idea of redrawing state borders is a threat to both the present and the future. It is high time that all countries in the region understand this.
Our future lies in establishing inter-state relations modelled on those of the EU member states. That must become a genuine commitment. Only in this way can we build peace,
security, and development in our common interest.
The Scandinavian model of cooperation may not be something we can fully replicate in our region, but we can certainly draw positive lessons from it.
The Scandinavian countries recognized the advantages of cooperation and found ways to create an environment for accelerated economic development.
Let us learn from this and similar examples. Let us not repeat the dangerous politics of the 1990s, whose catastrophic consequences we still feel today.
Mutual respect among states is the path that leads toward a stable and prosperous region.
Ladies and gentlemen,
the intensification of the Berlin Process and the implementation of signed agreements bring visible benefits to all countries in the region.
It is time, through concrete action, to open the path toward progress and enable the final remaining ratification of the Agreement on Freedom of Movement with Identity Cards in the Western Balkans. The ratification of this important agreement would facilitate the implementation of other agreements under the Berlin Process as well. It is time to put an end to obstruction and blockade.
We believe that in the period ahead, it is important for all of us to focus on:
- Infrastructure, energy, digital, and economic connectivity between the Western Balkan countries and the EU;
- Improving energy efficiency and capacity building as a response to climate change;
- Accelerating the energy transition toward green sources of energy;
- Intensifying work on the development of the transport network;
- Facilitating access to the EU’s structural and cohesion funds for countries in the enlargement process;
- Creating new jobs and reducing the emigration of young people.

title: Chairman of the Presidency of BiH Željko Komšić attended the ceremony marking September 28 – the Day of Formation of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina Brigades in the Municipality of
content:
In his address before former soldiers and numerous representatives of all levels of government in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Chairman of BiH Presidency Komšić emphasized the greatness and importance of the Bosnian and Herzegovinian resistance and underlined the importance of nurturing the culture of remembrance.
"When you look back from this distance and try to explain to your child what happened, you come to the conclusion that the saying about the miracle of Bosnian and Herzegovinian resistance holds true. I believe there are two miracles of the Bosnian and Herzegovinian resistance. The first miracle is the youth who accepted the fight against a far superior enemy. Without hesitation, they were ready to give their lives – that is a remarkable thing. The second miracle is the organization of the units. When you start to build an army, it is serious work, and we managed to create one. The miracle of resistance in BiH exists; it happened. It marked our generation, and we carry it with pride.
This is about a culture of remembrance, but also about lessons for the new children who have arrived and those who will come. The games around BiH are not over. It is our duty to pass on to our children at least part of the sense of responsibility toward our homeland. What we have is great – we have a state, and we must not allow it to slip through our fingers like sand. That is why it is important for children to learn, to go and see all the places of suffering,'' said Chairman of the Presidency of BiH Željko Komšić.

title: The Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Željko Komšić, attended the Fifth Crimea Platform Summit, which was held in New York, at the invitation of the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr
content:
Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Komšić addressed numerous world officials with clear messages, emphasizing the importance of respecting the United Nations Charter and universal principles of international law, and supported the New York Declaration, which, among other things, confirms the commitment of the UN member states to the goals and principles set out in the UN Charter, in particular respect for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of states, non-use of force and peaceful resolution of international disputes.
"President Zelenskyy,
fellow Heads of state,
Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen,
President Zelenskyy, thank you for inviting me to take part in the Fifth Crimea Platform Summit.
As you noted in your letter, this is a symbolic year – the 80th anniversary of the United Nations – and we must show that the United Nations is not a symbolic institution and that the Charter of the United Nations is not a symbolic document.
It has never been more important than now to show that we stand behind the elementary political achievements of a civilized society that the Charter of the United Nations has represented for eight decades.
The International Crimea Platform is a platform based on multilateralism, aimed at preserving the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine, including Crimea and the city of Sevastopol.
The Charter of the United Nations obliges us, as civilized societies, to uphold these timeless, universal principles, which you rightly emphasized in the proposed declaration.
Article 2 of the Charter clearly obliges civilized States Parties to refrain from the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any State, or in any other manner inconsistent with the purposes of the United Nations, and to settle their international disputes by peaceful means.
The taking of land from others, the killing of civilians, children, the carrying out of ethnic cleansing or genocide, for any political purpose, national interest or, worse, for business profit, can bring neither happiness nor prosperity anywhere in the world.
I fully support the proposed declaration, which affirms that no territorial acquisition resulting from the threat or use of force can be recognized as legal anywhere in the world.
Finally, coming from Bosnia and Herzegovina, which became a member of the United Nations despite the aggression, ethnic cleansing and genocide we have suffered, we reaffirm our commitment to the sovereignty, independence, unity and territorial integrity of Ukraine within its internationally recognized borders, including its territorial waters.
Never lose hope. Good will always triumph over the forces of evil and destruction.
Thank you!"

title: The Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Željko Komšić, attended the high-level side event of the United Nations General Assembly entitled "Nizami Ganjavi: Multilateralism at the Cros
content:
On that occasion, Chairman Komšić addressed the officials and participants in the gathering, emphasizing the importance of multilateralism, dialogue and solidarity in overcoming global challenges, and conveyed clear messages of support for the idea of international cooperation based on justice and humanism.
"Dear guests, excellencies, ladies and gentlemen,
It is my pleasure to address this gathering at the Harvard Club, among distinguished leaders committed to peace and cooperation.
Today, as we reflect on multilateralism, we draw inspiration from the timeless wisdom of Nizami – a legacy based on dialogue, compassion and justice.
In a world marked by complexity, multilateralism is at a critical crossroads.
We face challenges that no nation can solve alone: ​​resurgences of genocide and conflict that destroy societies, economic inequalities that cause instability, and crises of democracy.
These challenges test the very foundations of international cooperation and require a renewed commitment to collective action.
Bosnia and Herzegovina knows very well the price of division and the value of dialogue.
Our history teaches us to advocate dialogue in a world of multilateralism, not as an abstract idea, but as a practical necessity – a framework through which peace, security and sustainable development can be achieved.
Our generation has entered a dark era, an era of collapsed values ​​of humanism.
It is almost unthinkable that genocide and the deliberate starvation of entire peoples have become part of our daily reality – a "normality" that we risk passing on to future generations.
The least we can do is to pass on to these generations the values ​​of empathy and solidarity with all those who suffer. Without this foundation, new generations will not be able to take even the first step towards improving the world we leave them.
Gathered here in New York, a city that symbolizes diplomacy and diversity, let us reaffirm our commitment to the idea of ​​multilateralism that Nizami Ganjavi so powerfully embodied.
As Nizami reminds us: "In a world filled with harmony, the music of life is sweet." We must keep in mind the power of this virtue so that we can respond to the challenges of today and build a future in which peace will not be a fleeting hope, but a lasting reality.
Finally, I call on leaders, my colleagues, to remain united at this crossroads. Together, through dialogue, respect, and determination, we can chart a path toward a world with less chaos and more stability and justice.
Thank you."

title: Chairman of BiH Presidency Željko Komšić attended the event "Days of Victory, Days of Pride
content:
On that occasion, he addressed those present, emphasizing the importance of the defense of Bosnia and Herzegovina and recalling the heroism of the fighters who laid down their lives for the freedom of the homeland in those regions:
"First of all, thank you for the invitation to be with you today, on Vlašić, on the Galice plateau, with the people who won an almost incredible military victory, led primarily by General Alagić. The military significance of that operation, and what it meant in the offensive operations, primarily in Krajina, in the liberation of that part of our country, should be spoken about by those who participated in it, and it is my duty to express my respect for that.
Yesterday I attended the 30th anniversary of the liberation of Ključ. It is certain that even that would have been questionable had it not been for the liberation of the Vlašić plateau. The moral meaning of the liberation of Vlašić at that moment, because of that image when our flag is raised on top of Vlašić, is really difficult to describe to someone who does not belong to that generation. In these thirty years since the end of the war, it seems to me that I understood some things in the correct way only now, and at the age of twenty-eight, when the war started, I did not understand that. I realized that peace is important, that freedom is more important, but that the homeland is the most important. Because without a homeland, you can hardly talk about freedom, and then peace. In the gradation of those values, peace, freedom and homeland, peace can also be sacrificed for the homeland. And a person can sacrifice freedom for the homeland, but he must never sacrifice the homeland, because without it we don't exist.
I like this symbolic handover of war flags. As a generation, we can be proud that we did our best to stand here today, but we haven't done anything if we don't pass on what we know to our children, and that's our duty as elders, as parents, as more experienced and wiser. To point out what kind of place they live in, what kind of beauty, after all, they live in, and what this generation has done means, not so that they would respect it, not so that they would admire us, but only so that they would learn something. That is why this symbolism of the handing over of war flags by veterans to our future should be a kind of process of passing on knowledge, experiences and our expectations. It is our obligation to leave these children as a legacy, to tell them that BiH, when it has existed for a thousand years as our homeland, must continue to exist forever, while it is of this world."

title: The Chairman of the Presidency of BiH, Željko Komšić, addressed the opening ceremony of the Third Congress of Endoscopic Surgeons of BiH in the Sarajevo City Hall (Vijećnica), organized by the Associa
content:
On that occasion, he highlighted the importance of this professional and scientific gathering for the development of the medical profession and the improvement of health care in Bosnia and Herzegovina, stressing that the citizens of our country will benefit the most from the knowledge and experiences that will be exchanged in the coming days by the best experts in this field from around the world.
“Esteemed conference organizers, esteemed participants, ladies and gentlemen, respected members of the academic and professional community,
It is my pleasure to greet you tonight and address you at the Third Congress of Endoscopic Surgeons of Bosnia and Herzegovina with international participation.
I am pleased that Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina are hosting this exceptional professional gathering, which brings together the best experts in endoscopic surgery from the country, the region and the world.
Today, in a time of rapid technological progress, it is important that Bosnia and Herzegovina also keeps pace with global standards – not only through professional and scientific gatherings like this one, but also through systemic support for education, research and development of the healthcare sector.
Unfortunately, we are aware that our healthcare system, like many other sectors, is going through challenging transitions.
In this regard, your profession – highly specialized and demanding – plays a key role in laying the foundation for the modernization and improvement of healthcare in our country, where endoscopic surgery should be the gold standard, recognizing its benefits for the patient, but also for the healthcare system in general.
I believe that your work and this conference, in addition to the exchange of professional knowledge and experiences, will be an incentive for new initiatives, cooperation and ideas that will improve both endoscopic surgery and the entire healthcare system of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I wish you successful work and a pleasant stay in Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Furthermore, I am glad to see some of the doyens of laparoscopic surgery in Bosnia and Herzegovina here among you. Please do not hold it against me, but I must single out a man whom I greatly respect when we talk about work in this field - primarius doctor Mirsad Granov, and from this place I would like to express special respect and gratitude, both to him and to all of you, for everything you do for the benefit, primarily of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also of the profession and science. Thank you once again.

title: Member of the Presidency of BiH Dr Denis Bećirović addressed the closing ceremony in Bužim marking the 33rd anniversary of the 505th Knights' Mountain Brigade
content:
In front of more than 10,000 citizens of Bužim and Krajina, Dr Bećirović, among other things, said: "At the beginning of my address, I congratulate all members of the 105th/505th Knights' Mountain Brigade on the 33rd anniversary of their founding and the beginning of the heroic and glorious path of defending the homeland of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The heroic Bužim raised famous Bosnian knights. Among them is the hardened Krajina and Bosnian warrior, our hero of the defence and liberation war, the Golden Lily and General Izet Nanić. He is one of the greatest heroes in the millennial history of the Bosnian state. We will forever remember General Nanić and all Bosnian heroes. Their war heroism is a lasting role model for current and future generations. We are proud of the soldiers of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We do not allow anyone to question the honourable fight for Bosnia and Herzegovina. There is no discussion, no bargaining about that. Never!
Greater-state protagonists are trying to deprive Bosnia and Herzegovina of its right to exist. However, they fail to break the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It has not been permanently subdued even by much stronger forces in the last 1,000 years. Bosnia and Herzegovina has always had its sons and daughters who will protect it. That's how it was and that's how it will stay.
Our task is to strengthen the foreign policy position of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We must strengthen alliances around the world. Let's strengthen old friendships and build new ones wherever we can. The General Assembly of the United Nations (UN) adopted the Resolution on July 11 as the International Day of Remembrance and Commemoration of the Genocide in Srebrenica. Many thought that we would never see the adoption of this resolution. Although we were in a completely unequal position, we showed that we know how to win. Bosnia and Herzegovina can win. This is one of the most important diplomatic and political victories of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the 21st century. In order to continue winning, we must be serious, hardworking, united and determined.
Because of the adoption of the Resolution and the policy of protecting our country, I am exposed to attacks by the leaders of Serbia and their regime media. They are bothered by the truth and arguments. They would prefer us to remain silent. We will not remain silent. We will fight for truth and justice. We will not justify ourselves to those who are trying to undermine Bosnia and Herzegovina. And let them remember that well!
Regime political and media circles from Serbia say that I initiated the adoption of the Resolution on the Genocide in Srebrenica. I admit it, I did. They say that I am responsible because I led the process of adopting the Resolution on the Genocide in Srebrenica. That is right, I led that process. The President of Serbia publicly says that "cooperation with Bećirović is impossible". I am telling him from Bužim: equal cooperation is possible with me, but it is not possible to humiliate Bosnia and Herzegovina with me. It cannot be! Period!
The best sons and daughters have been guarding our country for centuries. We will guard what is ours in the times to come. Some ask us: What is ours? Ours is what the whole world has recognized and what was permanently sealed in the UN on May 22, 1992. The planetary certificate of statehood, independence and sovereignty has not been issued to any entity, district, canton, city or municipality. There is only one certificate in the UN, only one address, only one name – that is the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We serve it. We fight for it.

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of BiH, Željko Komšić, at the opening ceremony of the Eastern European Machine Learning (EEML) summer school, at the Holiday Hotel in Sarajevo
content:
Dear participants, dear guests, ladies and gentlemen!
It is my sincere pleasure to welcome you to the opening of the Eastern European Summer School on Machine Learning here in Sarajevo.
I am especially pleased that this prestigious educational program, which brings together more than 350 participants from over 50 countries around the world, will be held for the first time in Bosnia and Herzegovina, after several countries in the region.
The fact that the Eastern European Summer School on Machine Learning is being held right here in Sarajevo this year is a strong recognition of our country and its growing potential in science, technology and education. Your presence in Sarajevo sends a strong message of support for the development of science, research and new technologies in our country and the region.
Artificial intelligence represents one of the key development points of modern society, and for Bosnia and Herzegovina it opens up the possibility of building a more sustainable and competitive future through knowledge and innovation. In this context, events like this do not only mean the exchange of knowledge – they create a new generation of leaders and experts ready to shape the world we live in.
For Bosnia and Herzegovina - a country rich in talented, educated and creative young people, this is an opportunity to keep up with global trends and build a more sustainable, modern and competitive future through knowledge, innovation and cooperation.
A summer school like this one does not only serve to transfer knowledge - it creates a space for networking, inspiration and development of future leaders in the field of technology. Therefore, I would like to especially thank the organizers, lecturers, partners and everyone who made it possible for this exceptional initiative to be held right here.
To you, dear participants, I wish successful work, useful knowledge and that you ultimately take away beautiful memories from Sarajevo and our Bosnia and Herzegovina. Take advantage of this unique opportunity to learn from each other, build bridges of friendship and together shape a future in which knowledge will be the driving force, and you, the bearers of progress and innovation - ready to use your expertise and vision to improve the quality of life and respond to the challenges of that future.
Once again - welcome to Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of BiH, Dr Denis Bećirović, on the occasion of the 33rd anniversary of the commemoration of the victims of serious war crimes with elements of genocide in Prijedor
content:
Respected families of victims, surviving camp inmates, representatives of victims' associations, esteemed Reisu-l-ulema Kavazović, representatives of the executive and legislative branches, citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, today, in Kozarac, we pay tribute to the civilian victims of serious war crimes committed in Prijedor and the Sana Valley.
We are here to pay our respects and to bow to the shadows of more than 3,176 innocently murdered civilians, including 102 murdered children.
Crimes against humanity and other war crimes committed in this part of Bosnia and Herzegovina are among the most serious war crimes in Europe since World War II.
War crimes were committed as part of a large-scale project of aggression against the independent, sovereign and internationally recognized state of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We remember and have an obligation to speak about it, write about it, but also to take actions that will lead to the punishment of all war criminals.
The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia has proven that serious war crimes, characterized as crimes against humanity, were committed against civilians in Prijedor and the surrounding area.
In its verdict against Radovan Karadžić, the Hague Tribunal clearly established that Prijedor was "one of the centres of ethnic cleansing in Bosnia and Herzegovina". I quote: "The municipality of Prijedor was a place where Bosniaks and Croats were systematically killed, imprisoned and persecuted with the aim of their permanent removal."
To the whole world, on the 33rd anniversary of the crimes against humanity in Prijedor, we want to say: We will never give up on searching for our missing! We will never stop prosecuting war crimes.
In Prijedor and its surroundings, the non-Serb population was forced to wear white armbands.
They marked this population as in the darkest days of European history.
This must not be forgotten.
The criminal ideology cantered on blood, soil, and the idea of a heavenly people has always brought unprecedented suffering and misery.
Where the ideology of a greater Serbia has prevailed, death has also prevailed.
Evil must not be forgotten or underestimated.
On November 20, 1945, the famous American prosecutor Robert H. Jackson gave one of the most important courtroom speeches in history in Nuremberg.
On that occasion, he said, among other things: "The crimes we are trying to condemn and punish were so evil and with such devastating effects that human civilization could not tolerate them, leave them unnoticed, otherwise it could not survive such a repetition."
Even today, well-intentioned people are obliged to say, like Prosecutor Jackson, that we mus not forget the war crimes committed in Prijedor and the Sana River Valley, because the path from oblivion to their repetition is short.
It is our duty to be the voice of those who are no longer here and to fight for their dignity.
We have the strength to speak without hatred, knowing that hatred is the most obvious sign of powerlessness.
People of good will must fight against hatred, prejudice and stigmatization of other people just because they are of different religious, ethnic or other affiliations.
Dear all,
In the next 100 years, the vast archive of the courts in The Hague will be one of our most important books of collective memory.
In this archive there are millions of printed pages, audio and video recordings that are important not only for preserving the truth, but also for understanding our reality.
That is why, for more than two years, I have been working intensively to ensure that the United Nations (UN) reaches a just solution and that the original archive of the Tribunal is stored in Sarajevo - the capital of our state.
We need long-term strategies, policies and actions that have long-term value for the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We must all be guardians of the truth!
The fight for truth does not last one day a year. It is continuous and is conducted in various areas: passing and enforcing laws, in education, in institutions, in every memorial, every textbook, every classroom...
By advocating the truth, we make the best contribution to the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Let's not forget, killing the truth is killing both the past and the future.
We are against hatred, we advocate peace and tolerance.
We are against forgetting, we affirm memory.
We remember, because if we stop remembering, evil can happen to us again.
Our memory is not a matter of simple choice, it is fatefully important for us.
Dear all,
it is our moral obligation to remember all those killed and to honour them in a dignified manner.
Civilized countries learn and draw long-term lessons.
We must never stop telling the truth about the innocent victims of Prijedor and the Sana Valley!

title: Member of the Presidency of BiH Željko Komšić attended today the celebration of July 15 - the Day of Democracy and National Unity of the Republic of Turkey, and the 9th anniversary of the failed coup
content:
BiH Presidency member Željko Komšić said in his opening address to those present that the date July 15 defined and determined the future of the Republic of Turkey and its people. He also pointed out that Turkish people then showed their will to defend their choice, and therefore defended their right to decide who will work on their behalf in the Republic of Turkey.
"No force, no matter what it was, could change their will. And we in Bosnia and Herzegovina can learn a lot from the Turkish people, that no one can cancel or change our democratically made decision. The question is what would Turkey be like today and what would the Islamic world be like today, and what would its attitudes be if the coup had succeeded. That's why I want to congratulate Turkish people and wish them a lot of success in the future," said BiH Presidency member Željko Komšić at the end of his address.

title: Address by the Member of the Presidency of BiH, Dr. Denis Bećirović, on the occasion of the commemoration of the 30th anniversary of the genocide against Bosniaks of the “United Nations Safe Area Sreb
content:
Esteemed families of the victims of the genocide, Respected Mothers of Srebrenica, Excellencies, Eminences, dear friends, today, in Potočari, we mark the 30th anniversary of the genocide committed against Bosniaks in and around Srebrenica.
With sorrow and respect, we lay to eternal rest the remains of seven more innocent victims of the genocide against the Bosniaks, and we express our deep sympathy with the families of the victims of the genocide.
Three days ago, in New York, for the first time under the organization of the United Nations (UN) General Assembly, the International Day of Reflection and Commemoration of the Srebrenica Genocide was observed.
I thank all the states that supported the adoption of the Resolution, which is important not only for Bosnia and Herzegovina but also for the entire world.
The implementation of the Resolution has begun. In the period ahead, for as long as human civilization exists, the 11th of July will be the International Day of Reflection of the Srebrenica Genocide.
Thirty years have passed since the genocide was committed. It was the culmination of a barbaric aggression against the internationally recognized state of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Thirty years since the conclusion of the joint criminal enterprises against the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as established by the judgments of the United Nations court.
Thirty years since unprecedented mass killings, torture, persecution, extermination, deportations and forced transfers, violations of the laws and customs of war, and the spreading of terror among the civilian population.
Thirty years of searching for the remains and exhuming the mass graves of genocide victims.
Thirty years of confronting the horrifying consequences of genocide.
Thirty years of pain, sorrow and suffering.
Thirty years of the fight for truth and justice.
Thirty years of fighting denial and relativization of genocide.
Thirty years of brave and unwavering struggle of the Mothers of Srebrenica.
Thirty years of struggle for a safer future for all people.
Respected guests,
The genocide against the Bosniaks was comprehensively and meticulously planned over many years.
Serbian regime media, for years before the genocide, labeled Bosniaks as “fundamentalists,” “extremists,” “terrorists,” “traitors,” and other derogatory names. Milošević’s regime disseminated poisonous content through mass media. The degree of indoctrination was such that even one member of the Serbian Parliament publicly declared: “For one Serb, a hundred Muslims will be killed.”
A specific objective of the genocidal propaganda was to demonize and compromise Bosniaks in the eyes of the West.
This dirty aim of discrediting the Bosniaks in the West has once again been activated. That is why the West and Bosnia and Herzegovina must this time, seriously and in a timely manner, understand the intentions behind the renewed manipulative and dangerous propaganda, which in the 1990s led to catastrophic consequences.
Unfortunately, in the year when we mark the 30th anniversary of the genocide against Bosniaks, we are once again witnessing monstrous and frightening propaganda against Bosnia and Herzegovina - a state that is an important and reliable part of the Global Anti-Terrorism Coalition.
Let us not forget, it was precisely the savage political and media campaign that served as the prelude to the only genocide in Europe after the Second World War - the genocide against the Bosniaks.
The crime of genocide against the Bosniaks was not a historical accident. It was planned, organized, financed, and brutally carried out.
Respected guests,
I know that even today there are those who do not wish to hear the truth about the role of the leadership of the Republic of Serbia, led by Slobodan Milošević, in committing genocide.
My duty is to speak about this publicly.
Therefore, I particularly draw attention to the following facts:
- The aggression against the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was launched from Belgrade;
- Without military, logistical, financial and other support from Belgrade, the genocide in and around Srebrenica would not have been possible;
- The personnel policy and activities of the paramilitary so-called Republika Srpska, from 1992 until the end of 1995, were directed from Belgrade, from the General Staff of the Yugoslav Army (VJ);
- The original transcripts of the Supreme Defence Council of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia testify that the then-President of Serbia was aware of the genocide being committed against the Bosniaks;
- At a meeting of the Supreme Defence Council in Belgrade, on the 25th of August 1995, the President of Serbia welcomed war criminal Ratko Mladić as a hero and congratulated him on his “military success”.

title: Address by Serb Member and Chairwoman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željka Cvijanović at 4th International Conference on Financing for Development in Seville, Kingdom of Spain
content:
Excellencies, distinguished delegates, ladies and gentlemen, it is a great honor to address you today in my capacity as the Serb Member and Chairwoman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina - a country that, despite enduring and various challenges, remains fully committed to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.
For us, achieving the Sustainable Development Goals is not merely a policy ambition—it is an imperative for the prosperity, stability, and dignity of our citizens.
At the core of this agenda lies a fundamental question: How do we finance our shared ambitions?
For Bosnia and Herzegovina, this question has become a central tenet of the strategic planning processes within the country, especially in both entities.
Although classified as an upper-middle-income country, we continue to face significant fiscal and structural constraints.
Our per capita investment in the SDGs remains 62 per cent below the average for our income group, while domestic savings hover at approximately 8 per cent of GDP - far from the levels necessary to drive transformative development from within.
Yet, despite these limitations, we have acted decisively.
Over the past three years, the Governments of Republika Srpska, the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Brčko District, and the Council of Ministers have adopted Bosnia and Herzegovina’s first-ever Sustainable Development Goals Financing Framework.
This is a landmark strategic document that articulates a shared vision for mobilizing new and innovative financial resources in alignment with priorities of different governments in the country.
Developed with support from the United Nations system, this Framework lays out concrete pathways to expand fiscal space and attract sustainable investment, particularly in three priority sectors: clean and affordable energy and infrastructure, digital transformation, and research and development.
It introduces a range of new instruments - green and SDG bonds, strategic investment funds, and energy performance contracting through ESCO models.
It also anticipates the greater deployment of blended finance mechanisms, social impact bonds, and apex financing facilities to unlock the full potential of both domestic and international capital markets.
Beyond proposing tools, the Framework integrates policy, budget, and investment incentives to drive our long-term development goals.
I pleased to report that the Framework is already being translated into action. Feasibility studies for SDG bonds are underway at the entity level. Interest-free loan schemes, co-financed by development partners, are supporting small and medium-sized enterprises in adopting green technologies.
Plans for biodiversity financing and digital transition schemes are being developed to improve our readiness for a sustainable future.
However, let me be clear: financing development is not the sole responsibility of governments. Our success will hinge upon enduring partnerships - with international financial institutions, development partners, and, crucially, the private sector. In this regard, it is essential that our partners understand the unique constitutional architecture of Bosnia and Herzegovina – one that is highly decentralized and shaped by the principles of our peace framework.
We seek cooperation that respects this structure and supports our development goals without the intention of altering the constitutional foundation of the country.
We view this conference as an opportunity not only to reaffirm our engagement, but to declare our readiness to lead – constructively, cooperatively and credibly.
Ladies and gentlemen,
The journey to 2030 is not a race between nations. It is a test of our shared resolve, solidarity and vision. Bosnia and Herzegovina may be modest in scale, but is resolute in action. We stand ready to walk this path with all of you - side by side - with purpose and ambition.
Thank you.

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of BiH, Dr Denis Bećirović, at the commemoration on the occasion of the National Day of Remembrance of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland for
content:
Honourable Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom Ms Rayner, Honourable Minister of State for Europe Mr Doughty, Honourable Minister for Religion, Communities and Displaced Lord Khan, Honourable representatives of His Royal Majesty's Government and Parliament, Honourable Mayor of London Mr Khan, Honourable Chairman of the "Remembering Srebrenica" Foundation Dr Azmi, dear mothers of Srebrenica, respected Reisu-l-ulema Kavazović, ladies and gentlemen, it is my honour to address you on behalf of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with expressions of sincere gratitude that this year in London you show solidarity and deep respect for the victims of the genocide committed against Bosniaks in and around Srebrenica.
Your continued support is proof that truth, justice and the memory of Srebrenica have their enduring allies in the international community.
Thank you to the United Kingdom for the proposed resolution on Srebrenica in 2015, and especially for the great help in preparing and adopting the Resolution on the International Day of Remembrance and Commemoration of the Srebrenica Genocide at the United Nations (UN) General Assembly in May 2024.
The adopted Resolution has planetary significance. It represents a moral, historical and civilizational act by the UN.
I would like to emphasize that Bosnia and Herzegovina has many friends in the United Kingdom.
I would like to thank them all for their tremendous support. I would like to express my deepest gratitude to the Chairman of the Remembering Srebrenica Foundation, Waqar Azmi, and to our friends from this foundation.
One great man will forever be etched in the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina. His name is Lord Paddy Ashdown. On behalf of the citizens of my country, I express my deep respect for this just man.
The United Kingdom has recognized that spreading the truth about the genocide against Bosniaks is not only important for Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region.
In times of complex global relations, it is important to know that the truth has its guardians.
Therefore, it is important that together we:
- strengthen the culture of peace,
- encourage advocates of justice,
- institutionally protect the legacy of the UN courts;
- affirm dialogue;
- condemn the policy of glorifying war criminals;
- and strengthen education systems in the function of genocide prevention.
Unfortunately, as we mark the 30th anniversary of the genocide against Bosniaks, we are facing new threats to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Eleven months ago, here in London, I said that continued tolerance of the anti-Dayton and pro-Russian policies of the leadership of Republika Srpska entity could lead to the destabilization of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Unfortunately, these words of mine have proven true.
For almost four months, a brutal attack has been going on against the constitutional order of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Dayton Peace Agreement.
Ladies and gentlemen,
The current security crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot be understood without knowing the bigger picture.
Moscow has long been working to destabilize the Western Balkans, with the aim of diverting attention from Ukraine. Russia is concretely and strongly supporting its proxies in the region, and in particular the leadership of Republika Srpska entity.
It is no coincidence that Putin has received the president of the Republika Srpska entity twenty-six times. Putin does not receive anyone by chance.
Russia has exploited every weakness of the West. If the danger in Bosnia and Herzegovina is underestimated, Russia will seize this opportunity as well.
The democratic world and Bosnia and Herzegovina must not allow the argument of force to prevail over the argument of law.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Thirty years after the genocide, crimes against humanity and other war crimes in Bosnia and Herzegovina, my country is once again under serious threat.
The evil that we do not stop at the beginning becomes greater and more dangerous later. Together, let us stop the new evil in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
With a culture of remembrance, we fight for democracy and human rights.
Thank you to the United Kingdom for preserving the truth about the genocide in Srebrenica.
We are a country that remembers and values ​​its friends and allies.
Long live the friendship between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the United Kingdom!

title: BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić attended the commemoration on the occasion of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland National Srebrenica Memorial Day to mark the 30th anniversary
content:
On the eve of the marking of the 30th anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide, in addition to BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić, the commemoration was attended by numerous guests from Bosnia and Herzegovina and from around the world.
Adress:
Your Eminences,
excellencies,
ladies and gentlemen…
Today, we are standing together in this space of prayer and remembrance, to pay tribute to the innocent victims of the Srebrenica genocide from 30 years ago.
The Srebrenica genocide remains an open wound in the souls of the people, of a generation, of every decent and honest person.
Srebrenica has been reminding us for 30 years that peace is not just the absence of war - peace requires justice and truth, as well as human dignity. That reminder stays put for the generations that will come after us as well.
Today, more than ever, in this world we live in, we must be aware that peace without justice is very often not even peace, but an expectation of new war and suffering.
In this spirit, please allow me to recall the words of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr: “Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.”
The following message must become our pledge - denial of crimes committed shall never be allowed. Victims shall never be forgotten! The peace shall be built, above all, on the basis of truth, empathy, dignity, and reconciliation!
Here, in the peace of St. Paul’s Cathedral, let us pay tribute to the innocent victims and their families.
Let us wish for the vision of a world in which no one remains silent in the face of injustice, nor surrenders to silence. Let us raise our voice against everything that destroys and degrades human dignity, and causes suffering.

title: Member of the Presidency of BiH Željko Komšić spoke tonight at the ceremonial opening of the 12th Gastroenterology Conference dedicated to Dr Mehmed Gribajčević, in the Sarajevo City Hall
content:
Dear conference organizers, esteemed participants, ladies and gentlemen...
It is my pleasure to greet you tonight and address you on the occasion of the opening of the 12th Gastroenterology Conference, which is dedicated to the great name of BiH medicine, our esteemed Dr Mehmed Gribajčević.
I am glad that Bosnia and Herzegovina and Sarajevo are the hosts of this important event that brought together top experts, health workers, researchers and representatives of the academic community, dedicated to one of the most important areas of modern medicine.
This conference once again confirms that Bosnia and Herzegovina, despite the challenges we face, when it comes to gastroenterology, has knowledge, proven experts and a long tradition, and proof of this are many experts such as our esteemed Dr Mehmed Gribajčević.
Today's medicine, as you know best, increasingly relies on innovation and the application of modern technologies, which makes treatment more efficient, faster, more accessible and more comfortable for patients.
These technological advances and their application in modern medicine are not a luxury but a necessity, therefore it is important that Bosnia and Herzegovina continues to move with global trends.
I firmly believe that your work over the next few days, in addition to the exchange of new scientific knowledge and professional experiences, will bring new opportunities and new momentum in the development of medicine in Bosnia and Herzegovina, following and applying the latest world standards, and positioning our country as the centre of the region in the application of modern technologies in this branch of internal medicine.
I wish you a pleasant stay in Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović, at the NATO Parliamentary Assembly Gala Dinner on the occasion of the 30th anniversary of the signing of the Dayton P
content:
Honourable Congressman Turner, honourable NATO Secretary General Rutte, esteemed Excellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen, I thank the organizers for the invitation and the opportunity to address you on the occasion of the thirty years since the signing of the General Framework Agreement for Peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina (Dayton Peace Agreement).
On behalf of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I express my gratitude to the NATO member states for their concrete assistance, support and decades of friendship.
Following the dissolution of the former Yugoslavia, Bosnia and Herzegovina restored its independence in 1992 and became a full member of the United Nations.
During the brutal aggression from 1992 to 1995, the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was the only subject of international law.
The independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of our state were also confirmed by the Dayton Peace Agreement in 1995.
Since the end of the aggression until today, Bosnia and Herzegovina has made significant progress.
Today, Bosnia and Herzegovina stands at the doorstep of the EU and NATO. These are strategic foreign policy goals, which were unanimously adopted by the state authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Unfortunately, the current implementation of the Dayton Peace Agreement has not eliminated the threat of large-state projects and separatist aspirations aimed at the territorial, political, economic and cultural division of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Ladies and gentlemen,
the leadership of the Bosnian and Herzegovinian entity Republika Srpska (RS) does not respect the Dayton Peace Agreement.
It is a paradox that destructive anti-Dayton activity is reaching its peak precisely at the time of marking the 30th anniversary of the Dayton Peace Agreement.
The leadership of the RS entity, supported by Moscow and Belgrade, launched a brutal attack on the constitutional order of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the end of February this year.
This attack on the fundamental provisions of the Dayton Peace Agreement is still ongoing and poses a serious threat to peace and stability.
The current problem in Bosnia and Herzegovina is primarily of a security nature.
The Dayton Peace Agreement brought us peace and thank you for that.
Help us defend your legacy and do not allow Russia to open a second front in the Western Balkans.
The security crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina is not a local problem. It is the result of aggressive actions by Moscow through its proxies in the Republika Srpska entity.
Ladies and gentlemen,
In conclusion, I would like to emphasize that Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot count on long-term stabilization and faster development without changing the constitution.
The following principles should be taken into account in the future process of constitutional transformation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:
Our state needs a comprehensive democratic reform of the entire state, social and economic system, with a goal to make an individual, as a free citizen, the fundamental political subject.
The Constitution of BiH should be based on the principles of civil democracy, with mandatory respect for the multiethnic character of the state.
The priority of all state bodies of Bosnia and Herzegovina must be the implementation of the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights.
Finally, it is necessary to strongly oppose any ethnic federalization of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as additional ethnic divisions.
Our vision is Bosnia and Herzegovina as a single, unified, democratic and legal state, a member of the Euro-Atlantic family of states.
Thank you for your attention!

title: Address by Chairwoman and Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željka Cvijanović at the Parliamentary Assembly formal dinner marking the 30th anniversary of the signing of the Dayton Pea
content:
Mr. President, esteemed members of the NATO Parliamentary Assembly, dear colleagues heads of state, distinguished guests, it is with deep appreciation—and a sense of responsibility—that I join you here in Dayton, a city that changed our history.
Thirty years ago, the Dayton Peace Agreement ended a devastating war and created a constitutional framework for Bosnia and Herzegovina that reflected the realities of our society. It gave each of its three constituent peoples and two entities the right to self-govern within one state.
Dayton did not erase our differences. It organized them. It did not impose unity. It structured it.
Today, however, that balance is slowly unraveling—not by democratic mandate, but through the actions of unelected international actors who treat Dayton not as a binding agreement, but as a living document to be stretched, reinterpreted, and rewritten—without consent.
The truth is that in the past 30 years Bosnia has been treated as a radical nation building project and this experimental approach has led the country from one crisis to another. Almost all foreign interventions have been carried out without negotiation, without parliamentary process, and without constitutional legitimacy.
And it is fair and suitable to reiterate here in the very city of Dayton that the Dayton agreement never gave the right to any unelected foreign bureaucrat under the title of high representative to impose or amend our laws, to suspend our entity constitutions, to weaponize our legal system to silence and remove from office our democratically elected leaders such as Republika Srpska president Milorad Dodik or to punish our political parties. But all this has been done by Mr. Christian Schmidt and many of his predecessors in the past 3 decades.
The most troubling is the turn toward lawfare—where legitimate political disagreement is answered with criminal charges, indictments, and threats of arrest. I have listened carefully what President Trump, Vice President Vance, Secretary Rubio and just two days ago Deputy Secretary of State Landau have stated. And it is quite clear that the nation building pattern promoted in Bosnia for 3 decades is in contravention with the policy of the new President Trump- led administration. And I want to believe that this administration will help us save democracy in BiH where its future will be written not by decree and foreign dictate but by law and our constitution.
I come from Republika Srpska, and let me emphasize that we are not undermining the Dayton Agreement; we are upholding it. But we do not want to be told how to govern by people who do not vote in our elections, do not speak our languages, and do not bear the consequences of their decrees. One example of our dedication is that November 21st, the day the Dayton Agreement was initialed, is a public holiday in Republika Srpska, but in the other entity, it is a normal working day.
What we do want is to restore Dayton—to return to the agreement as it was signed, not as it is now imagined. That is why Republika Srpska is asking to go back to basics. We are ready to engage in structured dialogue with all parties. If the agreement is to evolve, it must evolve lawfully—through amendment and mutual consent.
We also believe in strategic partnership with the US regarding investment in energy sector, as well as exploitation of the reserves of the critical minerals, grounded in transparency and constitutional law.
In closing, let me emphasize: Peace was possible in 1995 because all the parties were respected and heard. Peace in 2025 will require the same.
Let us recommit - on this anniversary — to what Dayton truly meant: consent, constitutionality, and cooperation among equals. Let us go back to basics—so the next thirty years are better than the last thirty.
Thank you.

title: Address by the Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Željko Komšić, at the NATO Parliamentary Assembly formal dinner marking the 30th anniversary of the signing of the Dayton Peace Agree
content:
Taking into account my position and the established foreign policy goals of my country, I can only speak about Bosnia and Herzegovina and my constitutional and legal obligations as a member of the BiH Presidency.
I shall not comment on the situation and goals of other countries in the region.
I expect the same attitude towards Bosnia and Herzegovina from the other participants of this gathering.
It needs to be mentioned that today we are in a place that is historically linked to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Once again, I wish to express my gratitude to our hosts, as well as to the people and the government of the United States, for their overall engagement with Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1995 until today!
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country that knows how to appreciate the importance of peace. The majority of people in BiH will do everything to preserve the peace and ensure that future generations of Bosnians and Herzegovinians never learn the horrors that my generation was exposed to.
It seems to me that we in Bosnia and Herzegovina are very much aware that "the gates of hell are easy to open, but to close that door is very difficult, sometimes even impossible".
On the other hand, peace, a stable state and a strong society are not granted and not forever.
We need to work on those goals daily. We need to fight for them and protect them.
The Dayton Peace Agreement should also be viewed in this context. It is certain that the DPA can be considered the basis of peace and stability in Bosnia and Herzegovina and, indirectly, in the entire region.
From a 30 years' distance, I think we can now correctly estimate the positive achievements of the Dayton Peace Agreement.
However, we also have the right to ask ourselves, whether it’s time to move on.
I know this is a difficult question, full of dilemmas. But, for the sake of the future, we have to ask ourselves this very question. We must try to find an honest answer, an answer beneficial for the future.
Is the constitutional framework provided by the DPA sufficient for our country to move forward?
To be clear, by saying this, I am not implying the opening of the issues of the administrative organization of the country. I know that we cannot reach an agreement on that now, or in the future.
What I am primarily referring to, is the issue of human rights, but also the closely related issue of the rule of law.
The fact is that Bosnia and Herzegovina discriminates against its citizens on identity issues and violates the human rights of its people.
This has been repeatedly established by the Strasbourg Court of Human Rights.
There is no acceptable answer to the question of why this is the case. The simple and logical truth is that correcting this injustice towards the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina will certainly not break and destroy the Dayton Constitution and the constitutional and administrative structure of BiH as regulated by the DPA.
For this reason, I emphasize the need to urgently work on correcting this injustice towards the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This is conditio sine qua non for further progress in BiH.
I fear that, without resolving this issue, we will remain permanently turned towards the past and various interpretations of it, without the strength and capacity to leave it behind and turn to the future.
With due respect to the limited presentation time at this session, I will stop here. Thank you, once again, for the invitation and the opportunity to be here today and to speak in this place of great importance for Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Address by Serbian member and Chairwoman of the Presidency of BiH Željka Cvijanović in New York at the United Nations Security Council biannual debate on Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Mr. President, distinguished members of the Council, I thank you for the opportunity to address you at this decisive moment for Bosnia and Herzegovina and, indeed, for the credibility of the international system we all rely on.
Although I currently chair the tripartite Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I speak to you today in my constitutional capacity as the Serb member of that Presidency—elected by the citizens of Republika Srpska, one of two constituent entities that comprise BiH.
The Dayton agreement was not a perfect solution, but it was an act of courageous diplomacy that balanced three peoples and two entities in one state. It was - and remains, a legally binding treaty, lodged in the annals of this Council, whose Annex 4 is our Constitution and whose Annex 10 defines the mandate of the High Representative.
It created a decentralized, consensus-based system precisely so, that no single actor—domestic or foreign—could dominate the others. Yet today, that balance is being hollowed out by unaccountable foreign intervention either through the actions of various high representatives or foreign judges in the Constitutional Court of BiH.
Allow me to begin where Dayton begins: with the rule of law. Annex 10 is clear when requiring that the High Representative shall be approved by the UN Security Council. This has never happened in Mr’ Schmidt’s case. He was selected by the self-appointed Peace Implementation Council—an informal assemblage with no charter basis, no treaty or legal authority, and no power to override this body. And he has acted based on the so-called Bonn powers that are not codified in any legally binding international instrument.
Some claim that because the PIC “informed” the Council of its selection, confirmation became unnecessary. But if this Council’s vote were unnecessary, Annex 10 would never have required it.
Annex 10 is also clear about the mandate of the High representative. The Dayton Agreement did not authorize the High Representative to legislate, to suspend constitutions, to criminalize elected officials and political parties, or rule by decree.
Yet, that is precisely what Mr. Christian Schmidt and some of his predecessors have done many times.
Here lies the heart of a continual crisis in Bosnia whose culmination we are witnessing today. Everything that flows from that irregularity – lack of UN Security Council confirmation and unlawful impositions beyond the mandate set forth in Annex 10, is infected with the same defect. No legal system—domestic or international—can survive if the interpreters of the rules exempt themselves from the rules.
Let me briefly mention only some of numerous edicts Mr. Schmidt unlawfully issued since arriving in BiH.
1.He unilaterally suspended the Constitution of the Federation of BiH to impose a government he preferred, ignoring the election results.
2. He altered the electoral law bypassing democratic parliamentary procedures,
3. As well, he extended the mandate of the Central Election Commission without legislative approval.
4. He amended the criminal code to criminalize non-compliance with his own decrees—a move to primarily eliminate from political life a democratically elected president of Republika Srpska for fulfilling his constitutional duties to sign laws passed by the National Assembly of Republika Srpska, but also to intimidate any dissenting officials who would dare challenge his illegitimate rule.
5. He cut public funding to the democratically elected political parties in Republika Srpska cancelling the political will of the vast majority of its voters.
Esteemed members of the Council,
This is neither the Dayton Agreement, nor a democracy, and certainly not the rule of law. It is dictatorship—government by decree, unchecked by courts, devoid of appeal. What started as mere overreach has now solidified into a system of repression.
Each action was justified in the name of “functionality.” Yet the result is not a more cohesive Bosnia; it is a deeply polarized country which can hardly survive this form and extent of foreign intervention.
When Republika Srpska protests such violations, we are unjustly labeled as separatists. However, demanding adherence to international treaties is not separatism.
Contrary to some narratives, Republika Srpska is not undermining the Dayton Agreement—it is upholding it. Our demands do not seek to dismantle Bosnia and Herzegovina but rather to restore the legality and balance originally enshrined in the Dayton framework.
For this reason, the National Assembly of Republika Srpska has enacted legislation to defend its rights within Dayton. These measures are not provocations; they are lawful responses to persistent violations of international law.
The ongoing crisis is neither of Republika Srpska’s making nor in its interest. It has been triggered by Mr. Schmidt’s most expansive and authoritarian use of power, burdening the country with a series of unlawful impositions
Therefore, condemning Republika Srpska’s actions without first addressing Mr. Schmidt’s unlawful interventions is not only misleading but dangerously one-sided.
Allow me to state our position plainly:
1.We remain fully committed to the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina as defined by Dayton.
2. As for the mandate of the High Representative, we seek to place it back on its legal foundation, which is Annex 10, and prepare for the closure of the OHR’s
3. We reject unilateral decrees that rewrite the treaty, criminalize debate, persecute political opponents through a weaponized judicial system, discriminate political parties or suspend the will of voters.
A legal reset in Bosnia is a logical next step if we want to prevent escalation or successive future crises.
Therefore, I respectfully call on this Council to take some immediate steps:
1. Schedule a formal vote on Mr. Schmidt’s confirmation. If he cannot pass the vote, let us find another candidate who can and who will be appointed in accordance with annex 10.
2. Establish an independent legal review, under Security Council auspices, of the conformity of the so-called “Bonn powers” with Annex 10 and the UN Charter.
3. Encourage all BiH stakeholders to engage in a dialogue aimed at preventing further crises and revitalizing functional governance.
We are prepared to participate constructively, transparently, and in good faith.
Mr President, members of the Council,
The Dayton Agreement ended a devastating war and laid the foundation for our constitutional system. It deserves respect, not manipulation and breach of its procedures.
Let us together ensure that Bosnia’s future is written not by decree, but by law.
On a separate but critical note, I want to clarify an issue. As a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I have been forced to engage directly with your missions due to obstruction by the BiH Ministry of Foreign Affairs. This ministry selectively restricts my diplomatic correspondence while granting unrestricted access to my Bosniak colleague. This bias extends even to Bosnia’s Permanent Mission to the United Nations.
Such actions demonstrate the reality of the state we are being asked to accept—a system where power is centralized, constitutional rights are disregarded, and even the fundamental ability to communicate is manipulated for political ends.
I thank you for your attention and remain at your disposal for any questions.

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović, at the meeting of the North Atlantic Council (NAC) and Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Dear Deputy Secretary General of NATO, distinguished ambassadors, ladies and gentlemen, as a member of the Presidency of BiH, I would like to express my gratitude to NATO for its continued support to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Today's meeting, at the highest level, once again demonstrates that Bosnia and Herzegovina is important to the Alliance and that it is very important to accelerate the Euro-Atlantic path of our country.
Bosnia and Herzegovina and NATO are inextricably linked.
NATO has established and maintained peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina are eternally grateful to NATO.
The Dayton Peace Agreement, Annex 1-A, clearly stipulates the role of NATO.
