According to this international agreement, NATO has a mandate and a duty, when necessary, to establish its forces with the aim of protecting peace and the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. No country outside the Alliance has such strong ties with NATO as Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The positions of the last NATO summits in Madrid (2022), Vilnius (2023), Washington (2024) are particularly important for Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Of particular importance is the Alliance's approach, which implies that the security of Bosnia and Herzegovina is incorporated into the security of NATO, as well as the importance of joint action to strengthen the defence capabilities of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We particularly welcome NATO's decision to develop a new Defence Capacity Building (DCB) package for Bosnia and Herzegovina. The package includes projects that are very important for strengthening defence capabilities, resilience and interoperability with NATO.
The state authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina unanimously defined the legal framework and opted for the membership of our country in NATO.
Our country has adopted all key legal, strategic and other documents in the field of defence and security. This is evidenced, among other things, by the following acts:
- Law on Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina;
- Review of Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina;
- Defence Policy of Bosnia and Herzegovina;
- Security Policy of Bosnia and Herzegovina;
- Statements of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina on the commitment of Bosnia and Herzegovina to join NATO;
- Resolution of the Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which clearly states that the goal is to become a member of NATO.
The Law on Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Article 84, clearly stipulates: “The Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and all defence entities, within their own constitutional and legal jurisdiction, shall carry out the necessary activities for the admission of Bosnia and Herzegovina to NATO membership.”
If someone within Bosnia and Herzegovina wants to change the adopted laws and strategic documents, they can only try to do so in accordance with the legal procedure and in the manner in which these acts were adopted.
Until the aforementioned laws and documents are changed, they must be implemented and are binding on everyone. I remind you, they were unanimously adopted by state bodies, with the votes of Bosniaks, Serbs, Croats, and Others.
On the path towards full NATO membership, Bosnia and Herzegovina has achieved concrete results.
Among other things, the state authorities have:
- adopted five annual reform programs of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which were submitted to Brussels, and the sixth is in preparation;
- agreed with NATO on the Individual Tailored Partnership Program for the period 2025-2028;
- adopted more than 70 decisions in the field of defence at the sessions of the Presidency of BiH in the last two years;
- declared and evaluated the Light Infantry Battalion Battle Group of the Armed Forces of BiH, which was successfully assessed by NATO;
- realized an important visit of the NAC to Bosnia and Herzegovina in 2024;
- successfully organized the NATO Partnership 360 Symposium 2024 as hosts;
- allocated more funds for defence in this mandate;
- adopted a new structure of the General Staff, after two years of blockade;
- appointed new generals in the Armed Forces of BiH;
- approved at the sessions of the Presidency of BiH the participation of the Armed Forces of BiH (AFBiH) in peace support missions and operations (Ethiopia and Eritrea, Iraq, Afghanistan, Congo, Mali, Central African Republic), thereby contributing to collective security;
- enabled the participation of members of the AFBiH in NATO structures;
- and ensured that Bosnia and Herzegovina, for the first time, was invited to contribute to the NATO Response Force, i.e. high-readiness forces, which are capable of rapid deployment at short notice.
Ladies and gentlemen,
the results achieved would have been better if it were not for the destructive actions of pro-Russian politicians in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Unfortunately, the leadership of BiH entity of Republika Srpska (RS) brutally attacked the constitutional order of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the beginning of March this year. Let us not forget that the leadership of this entity has been undermining the Dayton Peace Agreement for years and is openly working against the Euro-Atlantic integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The competent judicial institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina (the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Prosecutor's Office of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina) have, in accordance with the laws of Bosnia and Herzegovina, adopted appropriate measures and decisions that have rendered the illegal acts of BiH entity of RS legally invalid.
I would like to remind you that Milorad Dodik was sentenced in the first instance to one year in prison and a six-year ban on political activity for attacking the constitutional order of the state.
Due to the denial of court decisions and the continuation of anti-constitutional actions, the Court of BiH, in accordance with the law, issued a central arrest warrant for Milorad Dodik, Nenad Stevandić and Radovan Višković.
Given these facts, the aforementioned leaders of BiH entity of RS are no longer relevant interlocutors, they are the subject of justice.
Due to the violation of the Dayton Peace Agreement and the threat to peace by the President of BiH entity of RS and his closest associates, justified sanctions were imposed by the United States of America, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the Federal Republic of Germany and the Republic of Austria, and the anti-Dayton policy was condemned by almost all NATO members and the entire democratic world.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Bosnia and Herzegovina and NATO have many common interests in our country becoming a member of the Alliance as soon as possible.
Among other things, I will list the following reasons:
Bosnia and Herzegovina's NATO and EU paths are complementary. It is evident that progress on the NATO path simultaneously brings Bosnia and Herzegovina closer to the EU membership.
Security and military reasons are reflected in the fact that it would be much more efficient to integrate Bosnia and Herzegovina into NATO than to deploy NATO forces to establish peace and security in the country and the region.
Bosnia and Herzegovina's membership in NATO is the best solution in terms of ensuring a quality security environment.
NATO membership is also important for political reasons. As a NATO member, Bosnia and Herzegovina would strengthen its democratic path and development.
NATO membership would strengthen regional cooperation, as good neighbourly relations contribute to reducing security threats.
NATO membership creates the conditions for economic stability and growth of foreign investment.
As one of the members of the Presidency of BiH, I express my full commitment to dynamizing reform processes and assuming responsibility, in accordance with my competences.
This includes, among other things: consistent respect for the Constitution and laws of Bosnia and Herzegovina, strengthening the efficiency of state institutions, respecting decisions of judicial institutions, more efficient implementation of BiH Reform Program, and increasing defence spending.
Finally, I have a few concrete suggestions.
I believe that it is extremely important for NATO to act proactively in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including through deterrence.
It is very important to ensure the long-term presence of NATO forces in military bases in Bosnia and Herzegovina. This would be the best prevention of the disruption of peace and security in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region.
In the event that the UN Security Council vetoes the extension of the EUFOR mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is essential to have a ready NATO response, in accordance with Annex 1-A of the Dayton Peace Agreement. A security vacuum in Bosnia and Herzegovina could have catastrophic consequences.
Bosnia and Herzegovina should be even more firmly institutionally incorporated into the Alliance's security framework. This includes an increased NATO presence in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the adoption of a strategic concept that strengthens security guarantees for Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the development of concrete plans for political and military action in crisis situations.
I propose the adoption of a joint action plan, with the aim of inviting Bosnia and Herzegovina to NATO membership as soon as possible.
Finally, I propose that such a meeting, in the format of NAC and Bosnia and Herzegovina, be held at least once a year.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željko Komšić addressed the members of the North Atlantic Council
content:
During his address to the NAC members, BiH Presidency member Željko Komšić presented his view of the current political situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, with an emphasis on Bosnia and Herzegovina's path towards full membership in NATO.
“Esteemed members of the North Atlantic Council,
It is my pleasure and honour to address you briefly and present my view of the current political situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, with an emphasis on my country’s path towards full membership in NATO.
In a few sentences, allow me to briefly recall that Bosnia and Herzegovina’s path towards NATO membership began in 2001, with the adoption of the relevant Declaration in the Parliamentary Assembly, which resulted in the Law on the Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which prescribed the obligation of all state institutions to work towards fulfilling the criteria for NATO membership.
We submitted our official request for participation in the MAP (Membership Action Plan) back in 2009, and in 2018 the NAC invited Bosnia and Herzegovina to participate in the MAP.
In 2019, we only drafted and submitted the first Annual National Program (ANP), which we renamed the Reform Program in agreement with the allies, and four Reform Programs were submitted in the previous period, and the fifth is expected to be submitted very soon.
What we can jointly assess is that all Reform Programs after 2019 are, in fact, the same versions of the one from 2019, and I expect that this will be clearly stated and concrete tasks set for Bosnia and Herzegovina from each subsequent NATO evaluation.
In addition, Bosnia and Herzegovina has participated in two NATO missions, in Afghanistan and Iraq, then several United Nations missions, and finally a series of military exercises with NATO forces at home and abroad, where the interoperability of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina was rated very highly.
On the other hand, the current political situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, initiated by the first-instance verdict against Milorad Dodik, the President of Republika Srpska entity, is very complex and may pose a direct threat to the security of the country and the entire region.
We have a judicial procedure on the one hand, conducted by domestic judicial institutions, which on the other hand is attempted to be turned into a political issue and some kind of internal dialogue, although in its essence it is not because it is not a political issue but, above all, a security issue.
We even have such signals that an attempt is being made to negotiate and agree on a solution through internal dialogue, which is actually impossible, because there is no political agreement or treaty that can or should devalue the decisions of judicial bodies, because that would be the final blow to the rule of law in our country.
We are fully aware that this is a matter for the domestic judicial and police institutions, which must resolve it themselves and which can be assisted by the EUFOR forces, and even NATO, as equal legal successors of the former SFOR, as already decided in Resolution 1575 of the United Nations Security Council from 2004.
I would like to take this opportunity to remind you how quickly SFOR forces reacted in 2001 in the "Hercegovacka Banka" case and prevented the then-attack on the constitutional order that was taking place under the name of "Hrvatska samouprava" ("Croatian self-government").
In a short conclusion, I would like to emphasize that Bosnia and Herzegovina allocates 0.95% of its GDP for defence, which is insufficient and, unfortunately, limited by the existence of the Fiscal Framework, which limits the state budget to 500 million euros, although in reality it should be around 15 billion euros.
If we were to abolish the existence of the Fiscal Framework, then we would have enough funds to fulfil our obligation under the NATO criteria to allocate 2% of GDP for defence.
Because of all the above, I call on NATO allies to pay additional attention to fulfilling the political criteria, especially those related to the rule of law and democracy, in the upcoming period regarding Bosnia and Herzegovina's participation in the MAP and its 5 chapters.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, the rule of law is currently being attacked by those political actors who use the current poor political system to achieve a series of blockades, thereby attacking democracy itself and the democratic processes in the country.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, there is a positive sentiment among around 70% of citizens who want NATO membership, which can be politically blocked by only one member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, or only 3 delegates in the legislative body of government called the House of Peoples.
It is therefore essential that our NATO allies focus their attention, in addition to military criteria, on political criteria, in order to unblock the processes that lead Bosnia and Herzegovina towards NATO membership, as well as a country where the rule of law and full democracy prevail.
Thank you for your attention. "

title: Speech by Serb member and Chair of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željka Cvijanović at the Global Baku Forum
content:
There is a large number of crisis areas and negative developments in the world, so it is logical to ask whether these challenges can be turned into opportunities.
I come from a country that, unfortunately, is going through the biggest political and constitutional crisis in its thirty-year history.
I must admit that I have a very bad feeling about the possible outcome of the thoughtless decision of an unelected foreigner, confirmed by instrumentalized judicial institutions.
Generally speaking, everyone is now waiting to see what international relations will look like after the arrival of the new administration, led by President Trump.
The American deep state, together with globalist and bureaucratic elites in Europe, is using Bosnia and Herzegovina as an experiment for radical nation-building with the aim of creating a centralized state, completely different from the one envisaged and established by the Dayton Agreement – ​​with a decentralized structure.
The fact is that this experiment, after three decades, has resulted in a failed state and has failed to impose a common national identity that would turn Serbs, Croats and Bosniaks into one nation.
Their main tool is the instrumentalized judicial institutions, where, in the case of the Constitutional Court of BiH, three foreign judges are actually helping to change the Dayton Peace Agreement and our constitution in order to illegally create a unitary state.
In practice, the Constitutional Court of BiH is used to change the Constitution, instead of protecting it. Another example of abuse of judicial institutions is the Court of BiH, which, incidentally, was not provided for in the Dayton Agreement at all, and before which a political trial ended ingloriously with a verdict that could plunge BiH into a vortex of violence and disintegration.
The legally and democratically elected President of Republika Srpska was convicted for fulfilling his constitutional obligation and signing laws passed by the National Assembly of Republika Srpska; the verdict in the first instance is – one year in prison and a ban on candidacy for the office of President or any other political office for a period of six years.
All this happened because an unelected foreigner, who falsely claims to be the High Representative – a German pretender to absolute power – in contradiction to international law, the Dayton Agreement, the Constitution of BiH and the Constitution of Republika Srpska, imposed amendments to the Criminal Code, according to which disrespect for his illegitimate and autocratic decisions is a criminal offense.
This trial is a classic example of violence by legal means – where the judicial system is used as a tool to eliminate political dissenters under the guise of administering justice. This is a deliberate attempt to weaken a democratically elected leader for protecting the sovereignty of his people and traditional values.
This abuse of the judiciary forces the legal and legitimate institutions and elected representatives of Republika Srpska to wage an existential struggle to preserve the Dayton Agreement and the constitutional autonomy and powers guaranteed to our Republika and our people.
In all likelihood, the response of this uncrowned ruler from Germany and the instrumentalized judiciary will be additional repression, threats of violence, retaliation, and further abuse of the judiciary for political purposes.
I believe that Bosnia and Herzegovina must move away from these politically motivated moves and turn to building a truly democratic system, in which elected leaders will have the power to make decisions, where the judiciary will not be a tool of political war, and the law will serve the people, not the interests of a few unelected officials who are not accountable to anyone, but still impose their will.

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović, on the occasion of the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina at home and abroad, distinguished excellencies, eminences, distinguished guests! I would like to extend a special greeting to the High Representative in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Mr Schmidt, the Head of the EU Delegation, Mr Soreca, as well as numerous ambassadors and international representatives. Their arrival tonight is an important message.
Today, with pride and dignity, we celebrate our great holiday - the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
This holiday symbolizes freedom, unity and the right of citizens to express their democratic will. The results of the legal and democratic referendum for an independent, sovereign and united Bosnia and Herzegovina were recognized by the entire world, and on May 22, 1992, our country became a full member of the United Nations. This is an epochal result, which cannot be erased.
The vast majority of the citizens of our country decided to preserve the thousand-year-old past on March 1st and open the door to the future for our country. The citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina did not allow the history of our country to be trampled and the future to be in division and occupation.
The democratically expressed will of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina was defended by brave and honorable patriots during the brutal aggression against the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We owe them boundless respect and gratitude.
Millions of people who love Bosnia and Herzegovina, both at home and abroad, follow the noblest idea - the idea of ​​freedom. It is the strongest idea that man has ever had and will have, as long as human society exists.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a long-lived and resistant state.
The centuries behind us undoubtedly confirm this. Bosnia and Herzegovina is a permanent international legal, historical and political fact. No one can dispute that.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has been a coherent whole for centuries.
Prominent American historians Robert Donia and John Fine rightly stated: Bosnia and Herzegovina has been a unique entity for centuries. Our country is a centuries-old plural society that proves that pluralism can successfully exist. Bosnia and Herzegovina has built a special cultural and spiritual value.
Ladies and gentlemen,
we live in a brutal world.
The world we knew until February 2022 was not fair, but this new one that is being born is much more unfair and cruel. We need to be careful.
We must face the truth: There are destructive individuals who, out of personal interest, threaten the collective interest of Bosniaks, Serbs, Croats and other citizens to live in peace and a secure environment.
In order to realize this dark plan, they are trying to devastate the constitutional order of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The attacks on the institutions of the High Representative and the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina are not accidental. This is part of a dangerous plan to destroy the constitutional order and institutions that have the mandate and authority to stop anti-Dayton and anti-constitutional activities.
How to respond to challenges and temptations?
Let us not forget that, based on the provisions of the UN Charter and the Declaration on Principles of International Law Concerning Friendly Relations and Cooperation among States, in accordance with the 1970 United Nations Charter, the right to self-defence is a fundamental right of every state. This right is an inseparable part of its sovereignty.
The state institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina are obliged to activate all available resources when necessary, for the purpose of protecting the state and all its citizens and peoples.
On the foreign policy front, let us continue to diligently and daily develop and strengthen our strategic alliances. Let us work in an organized and united manner.
On the domestic political front, we must be much more cautious and prepared. We all have an obligation to preserve constitutionality, legality and fight for the human rights of all citizens and peoples. This is our common interest.
We face great trials and challenges. The competent state institutions, as well as the responsible representatives and military forces of the international community in Bosnia and Herzegovina, have a clear mandate, duty and mechanisms to stop and sanction all those who threaten peace, stability and constitutional order.
Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
Any attempt to destroy the constitutional order of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina is an act of endangering peace.
All those who try to endanger the Dayton Peace Agreement will be responsible for opening Pandora's box and for consequences that could be unforeseeable. My message to all people in our country is that we should not allow a collective catastrophe to be caused by protecting the interests of privileged individuals.
I publicly call on all political parties in Bosnia and Herzegovina to act responsibly.
In defending peace, people and the state, no one should be calculating. We must resolutely and together safeguard the principles of constitutionality and legality, with all available state mechanisms and means.
Let us together and resolutely stop the targeted spread of apathy, defeatism and any possible incidents.
Ladies and gentlemen!
In these complex moments for the whole of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I would like to address each and every person in our country in particular.
I would like to address Bosniaks, Serbs, Croats and all other citizens.
Together, let us preserve peace, stability and the constitutional order that guarantees it.
Together, let us not allow the tragedy of the 1990s to repeat itself.
Together, let us not allow irresponsible politicians to lead us into a collective tragedy.
Together, let us prevent any incident that will be a cover for the forces of darkness to destabilize the situation.
Let's take care of our children together, Bosniak, Serb, Croat and every other child.
Let the 33rd anniversary of the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina be an additional motivation for us to continue building our country for all its inhabitants.
Long live our homeland Bosnia and Herzegovina!
She always had sons and daughters to defend her.
That's how it has been and that's how it will stay.
This year, we celebrate our national holiday on the eve of the beginning of the month of Ramadan. On this occasion, I congratulate Muslims in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the region and around the world on the coming month of Ramadan.
And finally, to all citizens I proudly wish happy March 1 - Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željko Komšić on the occasion of the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Dear citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, at the end of the last century, faced with the new political reality that arose after the collapse of communism and the reality of the disintegration of the former common state, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, through their political representatives elected in the first democratic elections, on March 1, 1992, set out on the then only possible path, the path of voting for the independence of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the path of independence and sovereignty.
Historical circumstances and the age-old desire for independence came together in a successfully held referendum on independence that laid the foundation for the international recognition of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
A recognition that had to be defended with weapons since our neighbours turned into aggressors who were not ready to accept the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a political and international fact.
International recognition was preceded by our, let's call it that, our own civic self-recognition, or the acquired awareness that in the fight for the independence of our state we can and must rely primarily on ourselves and our own forces.
This awareness in practical terms was manifested immediately at the beginning of the aggression when the available republican institutions, and most of all the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, reacted decisively to the moves of the secessionists and aggressors in the defence of vital state institutions and in the protection of the lives of citizens.
The further development of events and the course of the aggression gave the right to such a belief. Our own forces concentrated in and around the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, under the supreme command the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, remained our only support in the fight for independence.
Not only could we not rely on international forces, but the international factor was most often on the side of the aggressor, which was seen through the offered peace plans that did not presuppose Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state, but sometimes as a union of states, sometimes as a confederation, sometimes as anything else but never as a unified state.
Such an attitude of the international factor towards Bosnia and Herzegovina lasted until we formed, organized and structured the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina into a military force capable of carrying out the most complex military operations and achieving both tactical and strategic victories.
Only after that, when it became clear that Bosnia and Herzegovina would not disappear, and when it became clear that the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was an invincible factor, only after that could we count on some form of assistance from international forces.
But, let's not lie to ourselves, that assistance was not the result of their international will or favour, but the result of our demonstrated strength in the fight for our homeland.
All this points us to a conclusion based on great collective experience, which says that whenever we have relied on our own strength, the result of our struggle has been visible and concrete, and whenever we have, sometimes in numerous illusions, relied on another in the defence of our lives and homeland, the result has been devastating.
And that is why today there must be no dilemma about who we can rely on in the upcoming challenges.
We must rely on ourselves, but also talk to everyone from both the East and the West. Let us talk and cooperate with everyone if it will be beneficial to the homeland.
Let us reject all those frequent and malicious objections to our attempts to cooperate or establish contacts with countries that are undoubtedly friendly to our homeland.
We are not obliged to justify and explain ourselves to anyone. We owe that only to our country and our children, and the only guarantee of our independence are our duties towards Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Every day we witness again and again that the world that existed yesterday, the relations that until yesterday were the foundations of such and such an international order no longer exist.
If we do not change to such an extent, and if there is still in us the same thread that united us in the defence of the homeland thirty years ago, today we must be equally aware that global circumstances are changing, just as they were changing at the time of the fall of the Berlin Wall.
The echo of these global changes can be felt here in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Therefore, we are welcoming this Independence Day with an ever smaller political presence of a foreign factor in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It must be said loud and clear that the international community and its role in BiH, as a concrete and effective mechanism, no longer exists.
Let's throw it out of our political, academic and every other vocabulary, so that at least at the level of language and thought we can catch the last train with contemporary events.
The reality that follows will be completely different from this post-Dayton era that we have survived.
If we want to catch that last train of reality, we will have to simultaneously find the strength and our own capacities to defend the integrity of the decisions of domestic institutions, both when we like those decisions and when we don't like them.
We will have to ensure the functioning of the state, systems and institutions, as we know and can.
Therefore, when I speak of relying on one's own strength and capacities, I do not mean merely taking up arms in an absent moment, but rather taking responsibility for one's own country.
The time has passed when, due to the malfunctioning of this or that institution, one turned to a foreign ambassador. Until now, seeking such a nanny was ridiculous, but from now on it could be disastrous.
However, we in Bosnia and Herzegovina are no exception.
The whole of Europe is currently trying to consolidate itself, precisely for similar reasons.
We are not the only ones who must now primarily rely on our own strength.
The whole of Europe is facing this challenge, and if it wants its own freedom, it will have to pay dearly for it or fight for it, since the great tutor has cancelled unconditional support.
Therefore, our and European challenges are almost the same, and if there is still something called the European path of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is precisely in the imperative that both Europe and Bosnia and Herzegovina must deal with themselves.
In this sense, we should be clear that Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europe, whatever we mean when we say Europe, share the same future, not to say fatalistically, destiny.
That should be our most important foreign policy landmark in the future.
In this, after all, I see an opportunity for the healing of both Europe and Bosnia and Herzegovina and the social relations that prevail in it.
Whatever challenges await us, and it is clear that they will not be easy, I am sure that Bosnia and Herzegovina will overcome them because we passed our most difficult tests of state self-affirmation long ago, and showed the world who we are and what we are.
This country has a reason for its existence and survival.
It is a natural and social entity and not any ideological or political construct imposed by anyone.
That whole, in itself, is characteristically and mentally specific, indivisible and indestructible, like the love of the Bosnian man for his homeland, which has lasted for centuries and will last as long as there are us.
Dear citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Happy Independence Day!

title: Address by the Serb member and Chair of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željka Cvijanović at the World Summit of Governments in Dubai at the forum "Innovative governance for a resilient futur
content:
Dear Excellencies, Dear guests, ladies and gentlemen, it is a great honour for me that for the first time I have the opportunity to participate in this prestigious summit and to speak about a topic that is of fundamental importance for the future of all of us.
At the very beginning, I want to thank the hosts for the invitation and congratulate them on the excellent organization of this very important event.
In a time of unpredictable global processes and tectonic geopolitical upheavals, we face serious challenges that call into question the resilience of our institutions, economies and societies.
In such circumstances, responsible, efficient and innovative management becomes not only imperative, but also a basic prerequisite for preserving stability, sustainable growth and development, as well as the progress of society as a whole.
The resilience of any community depends to the greatest extent on the strength of its institutions, which implies their ability to successfully meet the various needs of citizens.
In the era of the digital revolution, which has fundamentally transformed the way we live, communicate and do business, there is no effective management without the application of new, modern technologies.
Galloping technological changes are setting new standards for public administration, giving it the opportunity to become more agile, transparent and closer to citizens than ever in the past through the process of digitization.
From e-government to artificial intelligence, digital tools already represent indispensable segments of every modern administration, and their role will be even more significant and pronounced in the future.
Countries which recognize the importance of technological innovation in this area have made significant progress in terms of raising the quality of public services.
A great example of this is the host country of this summit - the United Arab Emirates, whose programs to improve the efficiency of the administration through the digitalization process show really impressive results.
We are very interested in strengthening cooperation with the UAE in this sector, as well as in the application of modern digital solutions, with the aim of improving the quality of public services, preserving public order and peace, and raising the level of security of our citizens and property.
There is no doubt that there is a clear correlation between the adoption of innovative approaches and technological modernization on the one hand, and faster and more sustainable economic growth on the other.
In the 21st century, it is almost impossible to build a competitive economy without digital transformation in administration and economy and without strategic investments in education and scientific research.
That is why different levels of government in Bosnia and Herzegovina are implementing numerous reforms, with the aim of strengthening competitiveness through the process of modernizing the economy and introducing innovations in areas such as education and public administration.
However, we are aware that it is a continuous and extremely demanding process in which we must constantly catch up with very dynamic contemporary trends.
The key players in the digital transformation of our society are young people who successfully use the most advanced digital tools in their daily lives, education and work, just like their peers in the most developed countries of the world.
We must pay extra attention to young people, their education and training and offer them appropriate conditions, so that they can use their modern technological knowledge and skills for the development and progress of the entire society.
The world we live in is becoming more and more connected, and the challenges we face have long gone beyond the borders between countries and peoples.
Economic crises, migration, various security challenges require joint efforts and collective responses from us, because none of us can overcome them individually.
That is why the improvement of cooperation is imperative, both at the bilateral and regional, as well as at the global level.
I am sure that the future belongs to those who are ready to build bridges of fruitful cooperation, constructive dialogue, mutual understanding and sincere partnership on equal grounds with others.
I am strongly in favour of strengthening regional cooperation within the Western Balkans, because it is the best way to build a more stable and prosperous environment for all of us in the region.
Joint economic initiatives, energy and infrastructure projects can bring enormous benefits to all of us and significantly accelerate the economic development of both the region as a whole and all individual countries.
Ladies and gentlemen,
I am convinced that we can learn a lot from each other in different areas, including the ones we discussed today.
That is why I see gatherings like this prestigious summit as very important and precious in the context of mutual exchange of knowledge, contacts, information and experiences.
Some claim that the world has changed more in the last 40 years than it has in the previous thousand years. At first it seems unreal, but not unfounded.
What is certain is that the world we live in today is drastically different from the one just a decade ago, and that in ten years this world will seem like a distant past.
This means only one thing - that we have to keep up with the times, to strengthen institutions and modernize management, to invest in education and innovation, to improve cooperation and partnerships, in order to preserve stability, ensure sustainable growth and development and be able to cope with all upcoming challenges.
The coming future is not entirely predictable, just like the challenges that will be in front of us in the coming period, but I believe that we will have at our disposal enough modern tools to overcome them, as well as the knowledge to use them in the best possible way.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by the Serb member and Chair of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Željka Cvijanović, at the traditional Christmas reception
content:
Distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen, brothers and sisters, Peace of God, Christ is born!
With this traditional greeting, Orthodox Christians convey to one another, and to the entire world, the most joyous message in the history of humankind.
In the language of modern media, the headline of this news might read: 'The Son of God descended among humanity and became one of us'.
The light of this magnificent and unparalleled event continues to illuminate our hearts and homes to this day, just as the bright star illuminated the Bethlehem cave at the moment of Christ's birth.
In honor and celebration of the Christ Child and His arrival in the world, we observe Christmas as a holiday of true joy - a joy that grows only greater when shared.
That is why, as in previous years, I am immensely happy and deeply grateful to all of you for gathering here today for this wonderful occasion.
During this festive season, I would like us to reflect on the values that are universal and shared by all of us, regardless of faith, nationality, or skin color.
Our traditional Christmas greeting, with which I began this address, starts with the word 'peace'.
Peace, like love, is one of the fundamental universal values inherent in various cultures and religions.
As human beings, we are all called to live in peace with one another, and an essential prerequisite for peace is mutual respect and understanding.
The diversity within Bosnia and Herzegovina underscores the necessity for greater tolerance, helping to prevent misunderstandings and conflicts.
While it is natural to love and preserve our own heritage, we must equally respect and value the heritage of others.
We should nurture our identity, uphold our traditions, and celebrate our holidays, but never deny others the right to do the same.
Through dialogue and open communication, we must address and resolve any outstanding issues, without expecting someone else to wave a magic wand and impose a solution at the expense of any one party.
I deeply believe that any agreement reached domestically, no matter how imperfect or time-consuming, is far better than any solution imposed externally.
Everything foreign and forcibly imposed in this region has historically had a limited lifespan.
In contrast, the only sustainable solution for Bosnia and Herzegovina lies in an agreement reached by its constituent peoples - through compromise, their own will, and their own wisdom.
Dear friends, distinguished guests,
Thank you for honoring this event, which is especially dear and important to me, with your presence.
I wish you, above all, good health, joy, and happiness in your homes, as well as success in your personal and professional endeavors.
To all of us, I wish serenity and peace within ourselves, and naturally, with one another.
With these sincere wishes, I once again warmly greet you with our most beautiful Christmas greeting: Peace of God, Christ is born!
Thank you.

title: Speech by the Serb member and Chair of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Željka Cvijanović, at the ceremony on the occasion of the Day of Republika Srpska
content:
Your Holiness and Your Eminences, Esteemed President of the National Assembly of Republika Srpska, Esteemed President of the Government of the Republic of Serbia and President of the Government of Republika Srpska, Esteemed Deputies and Delegates of Srpska and Serbia, Ministers in the Governments of Serbia and Republika Srpska and in the Council of Ministers, Dear Chief of the General Staff of the Army of Serbia, Esteemed members of the Senate, Esteemed officers, soldiers, fighters and representatives of associations and organizations stemming from the Defence-Fatherland War, Your Excellencies, ambassadors and representatives of the diplomatic corps,
Dear guests,
Dear citizens of Republika Srpska,
May there be peace in the year that we will walk through together for the next 12 months.
I wish that the strength of the family protects us in this and all the years to come, that the strength of institutions protects us, and that this year also strengthens our faith in a better future.
Today, the entire Republika Srpska is celebrating in the colours of our most beautiful tri-colour in honour of its birthday, in the spirit of freedom, love, the desire for progress and all those values ​​that every community and every individual naturally aspires to.
Celebrating Christmas gives a special dimension to every other holiday, and I sincerely hope that the warmth of Christmas will shine on every family and everyone who celebrates it.
Equally, I hope that words of friendship and solidarity will touch every neighbour or fellow citizen who celebrates other holidays and gathers their family on other dates.
As every year, Republika Srpska celebrates its holidays with solemnity and dignity.
From the hills and mountains of unconquerable Herzegovina, through freedom-loving Romanija and heroic Krajina, the beautiful banks and canyons of the Drina, all the way to the fertile plains of Semberija, Lijevče and Posavina.
It is easy to understand why the Day of Republika is one of the most important holidays in the national calendar of the Serb people.
Because it's the day we chose survival, instead of the extinction that others intended for us.
It is the day when we clearly announced that we will proudly walk the path of freedom, and never again bow our heads on the road of no return, in the columns of death.
On that day, we chose unity over division, harmony over strife, union over partition.
And that is exactly why it was and remains so important to us, and for some others, subsequently, in the process of political reckoning with everything that belongs to someone else, it became a subject of dispute, although previously, together with us, they marked it for years.
Dear citizens, esteemed guests,
Usually during the holidays, with the desire to build a better and more certain future, we also look back at the world in which we live and the environment in which we fulfil our role as a society.
We live in an area that has experienced many historical adversities, but still, as a community or a people, we have not succumbed to merciless historical processes, although almost none of them have bypassed or spared us.
We can rightly say that Republika Srpska has been exposed to pressures throughout its entire development.
From the time of its creation to the time when it defended its freedom and even today, when it defends its constitutional capacity.
And although no period has been easy, we owe the greatest gratitude to those without whose selfless sacrifice today we would have nothing to protect or anything to fight for.
To those who left their lives, body parts and health, defending their families and friends, houses and fields, churches and graves.
And therefore we owe the greatest respect and special gratitude to the soldiers of the Army of Republika Srpska, members of the police of Republika Srpska and the families of the fallen and missing soldiers.
Because of their sacrifice, Republika Srpska is also a covenant community and that is why today none of us has the right to trade with it, regardless of all pressures, sanctions, blackmail and threats.
Our forests, rivers and meadows are soaked with the blood of the best sons of Republika Srpska and the tears of their mothers and fathers, brothers and sisters, wives and orphans.
Such a thing is not handed over to someone else, nor is it handed over to oblivion.
Republika Srpska is a stable society today, it functions as a successful political community, financially sustainable and capable of dealing with all problems.
We are grateful to the institutions of Srpska that have remained strong and that have brought us through many politically and economically difficult times with far fewer scars than would otherwise have been the case if we had allowed them to be weakened by various external or internal shocks.
It is enough to recall that several hundred million marks that have belonged to Republika Srpska for years, and out of pure political whim, have been sitting unallocated in various accounts in BiH, which could have served the additional development of Republika.
This is hard to understand for anyone in any other country, but in BiH everything that is abnormal anywhere in the developed, democratic world has become the standard.
Thus, in BiH it has become the standard that the Constitutional Court does not protect its own constitution, but rather creates new unconstitutional solutions.
That it is served by foreign judges instead of domestic judges, and that judges continue their professional engagement even after the prescribed retirement age.
It has become the standard for unelected foreign individuals to impose new and change existing laws instead of having them passed by parliament in a democratic procedure, and for ambassadors to address members of parliament via video link, dictating to them how to vote.
However, the height of political absurdity and democratic collapse is that, with the use of foreign force, respect for domestic constitutions and laws is incriminated, and the judiciary is consequently used for a political showdown with the elected president of Republika Srpska, with the absurd accusation that, in carrying out his constitutional obligation, he violated the decision of Christian Schmidt.
The fate of BiH and its health will depend solely on the extent and duration of such deviations in its institutional life.
The sooner BiH emerges from the vortex of legal uncertainty, voluntarism, interventionism, and the usurpation of domestic institutions by foreign individuals, the greater the chances it has of embarking on the path of healing.
Dear guests, dear citizens,
I also feel the need to say how important it is that hatred and intolerance should never be the driving force behind any activity or reaction in Republika Srpska, but that awareness of other people's hatred should always be a call for increased caution.
I would like to stress in particular that it is extremely important that Republika preserves its democratic capacity and that every resident, regardless of religion or nationality, feels safe and protected in it, treated equally and without barriers in exercising their rights.
It should also be said that, despite the combined destructive actions of individuals from political Sarajevo and foreign circles, Republika Srpska today has more friends in the world than it has ever had in the past.
There are, therefore, foreign addresses, both in the West and in the East, where our friends or our partners or our good acquaintances who understand the position of Republika Srpska live.
Who understand that the picture in BiH is not black and white and that the only things that are healing for BiH are domestic dialogue, the engagement of domestic institutions and an environment in which every nation feels comfortable and protected, and every individual is treated in the same way.
Of particular importance for Republika Srpska is the cooperation we have with Serbia, to which, led by President Aleksandar Vučić, we owe immense gratitude for constant care, attention and support.
When it comes to the EU, it should also be recalled that our representatives at various levels of government have made a significant contribution to the implementation of several important reforms on the European path, but it should also be said that the movement towards the EU has been burdened, and often stopped, by numerous crises that have arisen as a result of the OHR interventions.
This process will become credible only when it is implemented in accordance with the basic postulates of the EU and when it is based on the activities of democratically elected domestic institutions, as is already the case with all EU member states and those aspiring to join it.
Republika Srpska remains open and committed to cooperation with all, based on mutual respect and understanding.
We are aware that the world is currently in great and dangerous disorder, and it is important for us to preserve peace and stability, and in this historical vortex, to preserve primarily ourselves, Republika Srpska, as well as its constitutional position.
Ladies and gentlemen, dear citizens of Republika Srpska,
As someone who has had the honour of performing many important duties on its behalf for almost a decade and a half, I am unspeakably proud of our Republika.
In that period, as before, many winds have been breaking Republika Srpska, but none brought it to its knees, thanks to its strong immunity woven from the love and will of our people.
It remained, survived and emerged from every natural, economic or political disaster, perhaps not always stronger, but certainly wiser and more experienced.
That is why even today I firmly believe that no challenge is so great and insurmountable when we are united and gathered around Republika Srpska and its vital interests.
That this is indeed so is perhaps best evidenced by this holiday and the day when Republika Srpska was born for eternity.
Dear citizens, distinguished guests, it is my honour to once again, on behalf of the President of Republika Srpska, Mr Milorad Dodik, with holiday greetings, wish you a peaceful, stable and serene Republika Srpska, and to you and your loved ones all the best on a personal and professional level.
Peace of God, the Christ is born!
Long live Republika Srpska!
Long live Serbia!

title: Speech by Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović, at the "Athlete of the Year" event, organized by the Olympic Committee of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Dear President of the Olympic Committee of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Mr. Rađo, respected Vice-Presidents and members of the Executive Committee of the Olympic Committee of Bosnia and Herzegovina, respected representatives of the executive and legislative authorities at all levels, dear athletes, sports workers, ladies and gentlemen, tonight we have gathered at this important sports event to pay tribute to exceptional individuals who, with their effort, talent, dedication and results, inspire and encourage the entire society.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has a rich sports tradition.
The Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo left an indelible mark in the hearts of our people and became an important part of the sports and cultural identity of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This event also inspires new generations, positively promoting our capital and Bosnia and Herzegovina on the world stage.
Our strategic interest is to bring back the former sports spirit and to become a sports-oriented nation again, in full capacity.
As the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in Paris this year, I supported the Olympic team of Bosnia and Herzegovina represented by Lana Pudar, Aleksandra Samardžić, Larisa Cerić, Mesud Pezer and Jovan Lekić.
In the building of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, after the end of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, I organized receptions for the Olympic and Paralympic Committee of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I am glad that I was able to help our athletes in a concrete way, within the available funds.
It is time for the entire country to understand the importance of sports.
In the modern world, sport and sports diplomacy are among the key factors in the redistribution of political and economic power.
Modern sport, due to its popularity and media ubiquity, has become an instrument through which countries attract investments, thus strengthening their international reputation and influence.
We should be aware that in recent decades, in addition to classical diplomacy, sports, cultural, economic and other types of diplomacy have played an increasingly important role.
In the context of the above changes, we in Bosnia and Herzegovina should also recognize the positive effects of sport and sports diplomacy on creating a positive image of our country.
I would like to express special recognition to the athletes for their contribution to strengthening the atmosphere of trust and rapprochement.
The past testifies that sport has often played a positive role in spreading tolerance, peace, understanding and friendship between different peoples.
Sport is a universal phenomenon that transcends national, ethnic, religious and other borders.
Dear friends,
It is extremely important that we also develop inclusive sports programs.
Let us enable people with disabilities, as well as people from minority and marginalized groups, to actively participate, develop their talents and feel a sense of belonging to the community.
There are no impossible goals in sports.
Our swimmer Ismail Barlov is the best example of this. He brought the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina its first Olympic medal in its history, in the individual competition. Our brave boy, our Ismail, pushed the boundaries of what is possible, he is a true sports hero and the pride of our country.
I also express great respect to our sitting volleyball players, who have been winning Olympic and other medals for decades. They represent Bosnia and Herzegovina with honour and dignity.
We should all be proud of our sports heroine Lana Pudar. Thank you for her enormous effort and sacrifice, as well as for all the medals.
I also express my gratitude to all Olympians who represented Bosnia and Herzegovina at the Olympic and Paralympic Games in Paris. They met the Olympic standards and represented our homeland with dignity among 206 countries.
Our men's senior national team in basketball brought tears of joy to our people with their recent victory over Croatia in Skenderija. Our basketball players leave their hearts on the court in every game and show everyone how to fight under the flag of their homeland.
Due to limited time, I have only highlighted a few successful individuals and teams, although there are many more athletes who deserve respect. You will be awarding some of them tonight. I congratulate them all on their successes and achievements.
These are our sports heroes, whom the entire society can look up to.
Dear friends,
we can all be proud of our athletes.
They give strength and positive energy to the entire country.
Please give them a big round of applause.
One of the universal moral authorities and Nobel Peace Prize winner Nelson Mandela said, "Sport can create hope where once there was only despair. "
In the wake of these words, let's awaken hope wherever we can.
Regardless of all the challenges, we do not lose hope.
Our sportsmen and women give hope and inspiration to all of us.
Let's be proud of them.
Let's support them.
Let's develop optimism together.
Let's invest more in sports and young people.
Let's testify with our actions that we can do better.
And let's not forget: Bosnia and Herzegovina is the country of the future.

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović, at the ceremony marking the 19th anniversary and the Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Ladies and gentlemen,
let us not forget to express our gratitude to our friends from NATO.
Therefore, I express special respect and gratitude to NATO member states that are concretely helping to equip and strengthen the unified Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I would also like to point out the important role of the NATO headquarters in Sarajevo, as well as the contribution of the EUFOR in maintaining a safe and stable environment in our country.
As a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I would especially like to emphasize that the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina have demonstrated:
- enormous motivation, commitment and patriotism;
- superior professionalism;
- an enviable level of readiness and dedication in saving human lives;
- the ability to work together and coordinate with the armed forces of NATO countries;
- readiness to meet NATO standards;
- and increased interoperability, as one of the most important parameters of cooperation and achieving NATO standards.
These are not just my personal assessments, these were also recognized by the highest officials of NATO. During a series of talks, at the NATO headquarters in Brussels, with the Secretary General of NATO, the President of the NATO Military Committee and other top officials of this alliance, I witnessed how respected our Armed Forces are.
The Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina must remain above and beyond political and individual aspirations. They must remain a positive example, which other institutions should emulate.
The military must remain professional, responsible and in the function of realizing its legally defined mission.
Our Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina have shown that they serve the citizens.
Despite limited resources, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina have proven to be a reliable institution that assists citizens and civilian structures in responding to natural disasters and other emergencies.
The Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as the Supreme Command of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, has acted responsibly and in a timely manner in situations of natural and other disasters, has unanimously adopted the necessary decisions on the engagement of our military forces.
Based on more than thirty decisions of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, this year alone, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina have proven through dedicated and courageous action that they are ready and capable of providing assistance to all endangered local communities in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina have successfully completed all their tasks. I congratulate you on that. Your professionalism, courage and dedication deserve the highest praise.
Together, we can all be proud of the multi-ethnic Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which belong to and truly serve all citizens throughout the state territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In addition to the country, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina have proven their professionalism beyond the borders of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
They have made an immeasurable contribution to the affirmation of our state on the international stage.
In less than three decades, Bosnia and Herzegovina has transformed from a recipient to a provider of international military assistance. The credit for this primarily belongs to the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina. History after World War II does not remember such rapid progress of a single state.
The ten-year successful participation of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina in international peace support operations around the world is the best confirmation that our country can be a reliable partner and contribute to world peace and security. High marks on NATO-led operations, the UN and EU missions are the best confirmation of the high level of training and professionalism of our Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Our soldiers have shown how to protect the image of a country and gain the trust of allies.
Ladies and gentlemen,
We must never take our eyes off our future.
Let us continue to achieve NATO standards because they are the guarantee that together we will all have more security, economic progress and justice.
The state of Bosnia and Herzegovina does not need threats.
We must all finally understand that in our state we share both good and evil.
Let us strengthen peace, security and good neighbourly relations.
Let us work for more good and progress.
For all of us together.
Let us contribute together to make the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina even stronger and more efficient.
Ladies and gentlemen,
we live in a dangerous and cruel world.
Let the suffering of civilians in Ukraine, Gaza and other parts of the world be an additional reminder of how important it is to uphold the principles of constitutionalism and legality, because they are the fundamental prerequisites for peace and stability.
At the end of my address, I have a message for all citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina:
We cannot change the fate of our ancestors, but we can influence the fate of our descendants.
Let us work together so that our children and grandchildren have a peaceful, secure and stable future.
Let us protect together the Bosniak, Serbian, Croat and all other children in our homeland.
Let us strengthen the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina as the main factor in protecting peace and stability.
Dear officers, non-commissioned officers and soldiers,
your mission is not only military, it is moral and social, and all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina can be proud of you.
Thank you for being who you are - brave, loyal, professional and honest.
Thank you for serving Bosnia and Herzegovina and all its people.
Happy the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina Day!

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željko Komšić at the ceremony marking the Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina and 19 years since their establishment, at the
content:
“Dear soldiers, non-commissioned officers, officers and civilians serving in the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina…
I express my pleasure that, on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as the Supreme Commander, and on my own behalf, I can address you on the occasion of the 19th Anniversary of the Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The formation of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina was a very complex task, requiring patience, compromise, determination, knowledge and will, so even today, 19 years after its establishment, we can say that the establishment of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina is the best example of successful reform in our country. It is important to emphasize that this was our domestic agreement, with the assistance and help of friends from the international community, and that December 1 was not imposed by representatives of the international community.
I would like to remind you once again that the Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina, at the session of the House of Representatives held on 28 September 2005 and the session of the House of Peoples held on 5 October 2005, adopted the Law on Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Law on Service in the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with only one vote against. These laws regulate that the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina assumes command and control over the Armed Forces.
Today, 19 years later, we can say that our armed forces represent a factor of stability and security throughout the country. They are a reliable partner, first and foremost, to all citizens of our homeland, which you recently proved in the disaster management in Konjic, Jablanica, Kreševo, Fojnica, Kiseljak, Buturović-polje. When everyone left those areas, the Armed Forces remained in certain locations where it was necessary.
You also confirm the credibility and importance of the Armed Forces in international missions, where you have repeatedly proven yourself as a reliable partner to our allies on the international level, which I have personally witnessed.
And during this year, by participating in international exercises, you have proven the tradition of successful cooperation with soldiers from NATO countries, according to NATO standards. Unfortunately, in the current year we have not fulfilled our obligations to the NATO alliance because we have not submitted the Reform Program to Brussels, but you are not responsible for that.
I cannot promise you what is logical – that politics will be aware of your role and importance in the country and that it will repay you adequately, by improving your status, purchasing better and more modern equipment, and so that you will be safer in carrying out regular and extraordinary tasks.
Given the unhealthy political environment in which we live, as well as the fact that this may be accompanied by some demands that have nothing to do with improving the status of members of the Armed Forces, let us hope that the responsible authorities will not pay attention to petty politics and that these disagreements will be overcome.
In a time when, unfortunately, wars are being waged in Europe and when some countries are once again, violating international law, committing aggression, the importance of the Armed Forces is paramount. That is why the training of soldiers, non-commissioned officers, and officers must be a priority! Without a strong Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the state itself cannot count on the protection of territorial integrity and sovereignty. Stable and strong Armed Forces are the main guarantee of the survival and stability of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and a lever that must never be called into question by anything.
The citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina can find support in our armed forces, but also a tool for deterring any form of potential violence against the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Therefore, all together, for the sake of our future, we must and will be committed to strengthening the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina and personally, I congratulate all members of the Armed Forces on Armed Forces Day, and I wish you all the best, good health and much success in your future work and private life. Thank you for your attention”.

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović, on the occasion of November 25 - Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Why does ZAVNOBiH still bother the greater-state protagonists today?
Because the Bosnian and Herzegovinian anti-fascists at the ZAVNOBiH sessions opted for a unified and indivisible Bosnia and Herzegovina as opposed to the Chetnik project of a greater Serbia and the Ustasha project of a greater Croatia.
ZAVNOBiH is a historical turning point and an epochal defeat of destructive policies that intended to divide Bosnia and Herzegovina.
ZAVNOBiH deserves a new reading, evaluation and contextualization of this historical event.
It is our authentic Bosnian and Herzegovinian product, our great torch of freedom that carries light. Let us illuminate our present and future with the light of ZAVNOBiH.
November 25th should be discussed with new scientific insights, new scientific elaborations, with a new scientific and political understanding of ZAVNOBiH.
In this context, I particularly emphasize the positive role of our state Academy of Sciences and Arts of Bosnia and Herzegovina (ANUBiH), which contributes in all respects to the study and affirmation of the values ​​of ZAVNOBiH.
Ladies and gentlemen,
one of the symbols of the statehood of our homeland is ANUBiH.
ANUBiH was founded on June 22, 1965, and since 2006 it has been a member of the International Union of Academies with headquarters in Brussels.
It is a fundamental national institution, which continuously inherits the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina. That is why ANUBiH stands in the path of destructive forces that do not recognize the sovereignty and independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina has adopted a decision ordering the Ministry of Justice of Bosnia and Herzegovina to decide, in accordance with the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, on the entering of ANUBiH in the Register of Legal Entities of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Regardless of the obstructions, ANUBiH will sooner or later be registered as a single state academy.
Science and art cannot be nationalistic. Science and art are universal and must not be reduced to ethnic boundaries.
Our role is to connect the past and the future with knowledge.
We must balance what comes from our past with what the future brings. Bosnia and Herzegovina must find the strength to reject illusions and populism.
In this difficult and complex time, there are no simple and quick solutions. Responsible people know that real political choices rarely involve just one variable. Good decisions require a mix of political, diplomatic, sociological, economic, psychological, historical and other insights.
The adopted Resolution on the genocide in Srebrenica showed us that we need knowledge, courage and character.
The knowledge to design, evaluate and successfully conduct diplomatic activities.
Courage to, despite all obstacles and threats, enter the battle against very strong political, diplomatic, media, intelligence and other structures.
The character to endure in a consistent fight for truth and justice, even when the media attacks were violent and the situation uncertain.
The resolution on the genocide in Srebrenica, as well as some other foreign policy activities, have shown that we do not need to be on the defensive.
We have shown that we have the knowledge, people, capacity and strength. We have proven that we can win even the most difficult diplomatic battles. We confirmed this in New York on May 23 of this year, more than 7,000 kilometres away from Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Let us be optimistic. Now it is up to us to awaken the spirit that drove the best generations before us.
Dear friends,
our message from Bosnia and Herzegovina is universal: instead of destroying, we build bridges.
Just as our glorious ancestors built bridges, so must we. We are about to complete the construction of the two most important bridges of the 21st century - towards the European and Euro-Atlantic alliances.
Let us not allow anyone to undermine and obstruct the construction of these two bridges. Let us complete their construction in the interests of our people.
In addition to these two bridges, we are simultaneously building many other bilateral bridges of cooperation and friendship, with our numerous friends around the world.
Never in the history of mankind has it been more difficult for an honest man.
We live in a world where we witness the immense suffering of people in Gaza, Ukraine and some other parts of the world.
It is us in Bosnia and Herzegovina who understand the vulnerable and disenfranchised, because we ourselves experienced the suffering during the 1990s.
To us, all human lives are equally valuable.
In ancient Greece and Rome there was a special philosophical school of Hellenistic philosophy called Stoicism.
The Stoic philosopher Epictetus wrote a long time ago: "We cannot choose external circumstances, but we can always choose how we respond to them."
Our role is to design and offer the best answers in the given circumstances, and to inspire people in their implementation.
Responsibly.
Bravely.
With character.
And with the vision of a better and more advanced Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Happy Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina to all people in their homeland, throughout Europe and the world!

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željko Komšić at the Reception on the occasion of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the City Hall on November 25, 2024
content:
Dear all, before I say a few sentences about the very reason for our gathering tonight, I want to greet everyone present, especially - members of the Mountain Rescue Service and members of the Federal Administration of Civil Protection, and athletes Ismail Barlov and Lejla Njemčević, who are here with us tonight. By all means, greetings and congratulations to the basketball team of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
On November 25, 1943, under conditions of Nazi occupation and quisling terror, the citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina, led by the National Liberation Movement, which consisted of various groups of democratically oriented citizens, succeeded at restoring the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It was a historic success which many who fell in the fight against occupiers and traitors were not fortunate enough to experience, as were those who, in the decades preceding it, made a significant contribution to preserving the idea of ​​Bosnia and Herzegovina as an independent and sovereign state, through the political struggle for the autonomy of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Their dreams of an autonomous status for Bosnia and Herzegovina, both in relation to the empires of the East and the empires of the West, as well as in relation to political Belgrade and political Zagreb, were fulfilled by the fighters of the National Liberation Movement by constituting the Republic with ZAVNOBiH, with Sarajevo as its capital.
The historical step forward that was thus made was not only the fulfillment of the idea of ​​an autonomous position for Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also a pledge for the future and a signpost on the path to independence and sovereignty.
November 25th is nothing but the birthplace of March 1st. These are the foundations of the statehood and independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Although sometimes it seems and perhaps, too often, a dilemma arises as to whether these foundations are sufficient for the survival and progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina, today, in this solemn hour, it should be pointed out that many empires, states and para-states have disappeared, and Bosnia and Herzegovina survived!
It has not been blown away by numerous geopolitical storms precisely because of the foundations that make up its framework. Therefore, we must appreciate more what we have, because nothing we have is by chance.
Some new geopolitical storms will surely blow, and it is us who love this country or the generations which come after us will have some kind of shelter here.
It depends on us whether, how and in what way, on these foundations, we will fortify it for what the future holds.
We cannot and should not expect anyone other than us here to establish and fix the state framework we have. We must be the ones who will strengthen the supporting pillars of our statehood in the face of challenges that will certainly not bypass us.
Appreciating what we have, with awareness of the reality in which we live, I am convinced that we will continue to think about the idea of ​​Bosnia and Herzegovina in a way that we will never give up on the fact that this country should be a state for all its citizens, that we will continue to fight for this idea that is not decades old, but centuries old.
Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina today carry the same flag of freedom before the European courts that was carried by the partisans in 1943 and that was carried by the fighters of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the MUP (The Ministry of Internal Affairs) of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. And that fight itself is like that again, I would say partisan.
We do not have any funds or bags of money with which to buy justice, although, in the world as it is, we should have them too. We have none of that political corruption and unprincipledness which subordinates all morality to self-interest, although, in the world as it is, we should have such too.
Generally speaking, as citizens who want a normal state, we have very little that makes us strong, but I am convinced that no matter how some processes end in which the possibility of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a normal civil state is called into question, there will always be someone who will continue the fight until the final victory.
Finally, I would like to emphasize that any future struggle for Bosnia and Herzegovina will depend on how much of our own strength and knowledge we gather. Bosnia and Herzegovina can be proud of the people it has produced over the past 81 years from ZAVNOBiH. These people, with their strength and acquired knowledge, have preserved the state framework that we possess. And one more message. A message to those who deny the statehood, but also the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is all in vain!
On November 25, 1943, after several centuries, this country restored its statehood.
On March 1, 1992, it gained its independence.
For centuries, they trampled on it, burned it, destroyed it, devastated it, both the country and our way of life, but they didn't succeed.
At one time it seemed that they had caused us irreparable damage. It seemed that every generation of our people, at least once in their life, had to collide with evil and that they had no other choice but to oppose it with all their might.
There is no doubt, as things now stand, that both our enemies and our false friends will continue to try.
Our country, in the emerging world, will be exposed to pressures and challenges, they will break us, they will ask us to bend our backs, they will blackmail us arrogantly and conceitedly, they will use everything they can only to divide us, but we will not give up our statehood and independence.
There is no giving up on Bosnia and Herzegovina!
Long live our only, Bosnia and Herzegovina!
I wish all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina a happy Statehood Day.

title: Address by the Chairman of BiH Presidency, Dr Denis Bećirović at the final plenary session of the Summit of the European Political Community in Budapest
content:
