The Serb people are an integral part of the unity of Bosnia and Herzegovina in diversity and an equal people with other peoples. That is how it has been and that is how it will stay.
The resolution on the genocide in Srebrenica is not a threat to the Serb people. There are no genocidal nations.
This Resolution should be understood as a great chance for catharsis and charting a path to a safer future.
I also wish to send a message to the citizens of the neighbouring Republic of Serbia.
Serbia is not mentioned in this resolution. I want us to develop good relations between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia, with mutual appreciation and respect.
It is time for the president of Serbia to understand that he is the president of the Republic of Serbia, not the president of the Serbs. There are no presidents of Serbs, Bosniaks, Croats and other nations, there are internationally recognized states and legal authorities of those states. We should not invent Serbian, Bosniak and Croat parliaments, we should respect the Parliament of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the National Assembly of Serbia and the Parliament of the Republic of Croatia. We do not need medieval logic, but respect for international law.
Inclusiveness, economic growth, regional cooperation and Euro-Atlantic integration should be the direction of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the coming years.
I think we have the capacity and partners with whom we can achieve these goals.
Like never before, I am convinced that Bosnia and Herzegovina will be a country of successful people.
Finally, thank you once again to all the UN member states who voted for the Resolution and who preserve the truth about the Srebrenica genocide and give hope for a more just future.

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović at the session of the United Nations Security Council in New York on the occasion of the High Representative's R
content:
Mister President, First of all, I wish you a successful presidency of the United Nations (UN) Security Council in these turbulent times. I also welcome all distinguished ambassadors, as well as Mr. Christian Schmidt, High Representative of the International Community in Bosnia and Herzegovina, whose report contributes to the overview of the current situation in our country.
I especially emphasize that the High Representative is the only one authorized to submit a report to the UN Security Council.
Entities and other, lower levels of government do not have that right within the sovereign state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. That is why the so-called reports coming from Republika Srpska entity are legally unfounded. The UN Charter stipulates that states address UN organs and bodies. The only subject of international law is the independent and sovereign state of Bosnia and Herzegovina
Esteemed President,
Allow me to present the key problems, challenges and dangers in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as possible directions for overcoming the current crisis.
I am addressing you on behalf of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, whose millennial historical roots are strong and unbreakable.
In the last twenty-nine post-Dayton years, Bosnia and Herzegovina has once again confirmed its strength and resilience.
Despite numerous blockades, obstructions and pressures, the development of our country continued, showing both in war and in peace that the destruction of Bosnia and Herzegovina is not possible.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a full member of the UN, the Council of Europe and a country which is at the door of the European Union (EU) and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
In March of this year, an important step towards membership in the European Union (EU) was made. The European Council made a decision to open EU negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is a huge encouragement for the citizens of our country. I use this opportunity to express my gratitude to the EU and NATO for their commitment and support to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The world needs to know the truth. The key problems of Bosnia and Herzegovina did not arise in our country, but outside its borders.
This was determined by the highest courts of the UN. Last year, the Hague Tribunal defined the legal nature of the war waged against the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina in its verdict against the leaders of the State Security of Serbia.
The final judgments of this UN court confirmed that in Bosnia and Herzegovina there was not a civil war but an international armed conflict.
These judgments of the UN courts are of great importance because they tell what the essential problem was and remains. These are attempts from outside to weaken and destroy our country. This is the essence of all the problems in Bosnia and Herzegovina in the last four decades.
In July this year, we are marking the 29th anniversary of the genocide committed against Bosniaks in and around Srebrenica.
It is a terrible reminder of the recent past of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also a warning that we must be careful. Verdicts on committed genocide were determined by the highest courts of the UN. That is a legal fact.
Unfortunately, the leaders of Republika Srpska entity do not respect the judgments of the UN courts. Moreover, they glorify convicted war criminals and say they want to continue the policy of war criminals. This can be understood as a threat of a new genocide.
It is important for humanity that the UN General Assembly adopts a resolution on the remembrance and commemoration of the genocide in Srebrenica in 1995.
This resolution is of great importance for spreading the truth and awareness about the committed genocide against Bosniaks. It is an important civilizational step forward in the fight for truth and justice.
The authorities of Republika Srpska entity do not respect the entirety of the Dayton Agreement and its annexes.
They selectively interpret the Dayton Agreement and undermine the independence, sovereignty and statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina. With such an irresponsible policy, they threaten peace and stability.
The latest report of the High Representative highlights this.
A dangerous attack on the constitutional order and the Dayton Agreement is underway. The peace and stability of Bosnia and Herzegovina is seriously threatened by the anti-Dayton policy of Republika Srpska entity. For years, they have been trying to use legal violence to change the fundamental provisions of the Dayton Agreement.
Two key institutions of the Dayton Agreement were openly attacked: the Office of the High Representative and the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The entity of Republika Srpska is trying to block these two institutions. They do not hide that they want to become the supreme interpreters of the Dayton Agreement. It is an attempt to unilaterally destroy this international agreement.
The international community has clearly defined obligations and responsibilities in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It has all the necessary instruments, including executive powers, to guarantee peace and stability. In the first post-Dayton decade, high representatives helped the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina to live in peace with decisive and justified interventions. Those decisions did not threaten the sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but preserved peace.
That is why it is essential to strengthen the institution of the High Representative.
The decisions of the High Representative must be implemented on the entire state territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This must be ensured de jure and de facto.
The authorities of Republika Srpska entity are advocating dangerous deceptions.
The first deception of the political leaders of Republika Srpska entity relates to sovereignty. There is no sovereignty of entities within a sovereign state, but only the sovereignty of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Allow me to underline, sovereignty is mentioned nine times in the Dayton Agreement and exclusively refers to the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The second deception concerns the issue of continuity. This is precisely resolved in Article 1 of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Only Bosnia and Herzegovina has continuity. Entities in the country have only existed since the signing of the Dayton Agreement.
The third deception of the authorities of Republika Srpska entity relates to the issue of resolving constitutional disputes. They cannot be resolved by entities. The Constitution of BiH stipulates that this is the competence of the Constitutional Court of BiH and that its decisions are final and binding.
The fourth deception concerns the final interpretation of the Dayton Agreement. This was resolved by Annex 10 of the Dayton Agreement and that role was assigned to the High Representative.
The fifth deception refers to the anti-Dayton attempt to present neighbouring Serbia as a guarantor of the Dayton Agreement. Serbia is not the guarantor of this agreement, but one of the three parties.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a peaceful country, committed to strengthening regional cooperation.
We want good relations with our neighbours, based on mutual appreciation and respect. That is why we actively participate in a series of regional initiatives, with the aim of improving cooperation in the region.
Unfortunately, we have intense militarization in the neighbourhood. That is why I want to emphasize that it is very important to preserve the balance of military forces in the region, as determined by Annex 1-B of the Dayton Agreement.
For peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is important that the UN Security Council extends the mandate of the Althea mission in November 2024.
The presence of the EUFOR is important for the preservation of peace and stability. This particularly refers to the protection of returnees in Republika Srpska entity, who are exposed to numerous attacks.
The future of our country is connected with the implementation of the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights.
The judgments order Bosnia and Herzegovina to change the entire political paradigm and harmonize it with democratic standards. Bosnia and Herzegovina is obliged to ensure the individual rights of citizens, not only the collective rights of the people..
It is particularly important to emphasize the legal fact that state property belongs to the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Article 1 of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina defines that the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina is the sole successor of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which includes the continuity of ownership of state property.
Also, Bosnia and Herzegovina is the owner of the property that belongs to it based on the Agreement on Succession Matters. This international multilateral agreement established the sovereign equality of Bosnia and Herzegovina and other successor states of the former Yugoslavia. According to the principle of pacta sunt servanda, all successor states, including Bosnia and Herzegovina, must respect and implement the agreement. Entities are not even mentioned in this international agreement.
Bosnia and Herzegovina's ownership of state property was confirmed by final and binding judgments of the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Therefore, Bosnia and Herzegovina's argumentation is based on international and national law.
Let us not forget, one of the key demands of the then president of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, in Dayton was to divide the state property between the entities.
Milošević did not achieve that goal in Dayton. Today, some politicians from Republika Srpska entity would like to get in peace what Milošević did not get during the aggression. The international community must not allow this.
In particular, we should warn about the danger of politics which advocates changing state borders in Southeast Europe.
The president of the entity Republika Srpska publicly advocates the unification with Serbia of the entity Republika Srpska and Montenegro. Thus, he directly calls for the destruction of several member states of the United Nations. It is a serious threat to European peace and the members of the UN.
Finally, on behalf of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I sincerely thank the friends of our country.
We have not forgotten the help we received from many UN member countries. Bosnia and Herzegovina appreciates it and does not forget it.
That is why I invite you to preserve peace and stability in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region together. I am convinced that this is in the interest of both Bosnia and Herzegovina and the UN.
Thank you for your attention!

title: Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željko Komšić opened tonight the exhibition " Mario’s 100 years" in the Collegium Artisticum in Sarajevo, on the occasion of the hundredth anniversar
content:
The Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina member Komšić is also the patron of this important exhibition.
The Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina member Komšić is also the patron of this important exhibition.
Address by the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina member Željko Komšić:
Dear ladies and gentlemen,
Goran, organizers of the exhibition...
It is a privilege, and certainly a pleasure, to open tonight's exhibition and to be part of the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of a great painter such as Mario Mikulić, from Sarajevo, not by place of birth, but by choice.
This event represents, not only an opportunity to remember his extraordinary contribution to art, but also to remember a great man, his interesting life that "smells" irresistibly of Sarajevo.
You, his family, and us with you, both can be proud of everything he did during his lifetime, and of the legacy he left to Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
This exhibition is precisely the opportunity to become a part of his world through his masterpieces, to explore the different phases of his creativity and to enrich ourselves with his work and art. Watching his paintings tonight is not only an aesthetic pleasure, but also a deep reflection of the human spirit and emotions.
I congratulate the organizers of the exhibition, which gives us a glimpse into the distant past, but at the same time gives us an insight into universal themes that are still relevant in Bosnian society today.
I thank Goran, not only for this exhibition, but for everything he does, sometimes painstakingly, for culture in Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
At the end of the day, this exhibition is not only a memory of his father, this is a precious gift of both Mario and Goran Mikulić to Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić at the solemn session of the Municipal council Stari Grad Sarajevo on the occasion of the Day of the Stari Grad Municipality, at the Gazi Husrev-bey libr
content:
Dear Stari Grad citizens, citizens of Sarajevo, esteemed Mayor Čengić,
Right at the beginning, I would like to congratulate all of you on the Day of the Municipality of Stari Grad. I congratulate in advance all the winners of the awards that will be presented today, both to collectives and to individuals for their general contribution, not only to the municipality of Stari Grad, but also to the whole of Sarajevo, and to the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The municipality of Stari Grad, historically and symbolically, is one of the most prominent municipalities in our city, because it is in this area that our capital was founded.
For centuries, this part of the city symbolized, in a certain way, the center of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
This is evidenced by this space where today's event is held. In other words, the area of ​​Gazi Husrev Bey's endowment, which again has existed for centuries as one of the spiritual and educational centers of Sarajevo.
Today, the Old Town, if not always, then certainly often, is the first image about us, the image of the City of Sarajevo that goes to the world through the photos of numerous tourists visiting Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Therefore, the responsibility of the people who lead the Municipality of Stari Grad is of particular importance, and I am convinced that they are aware of this responsibility.
This is especially important when it is known that we live in a time where there is no room for repeating someone's mistakes and when those in power are expected to offer citizens and the state something new and better.
In this regard, I am encouraged by the projects implemented by the Municipality of Stari Grad with the aim of improving the overall status and reputation of the municipality, and I hope that a positive energy will be maintained in the future.
Finally, given that the 2nd of May is celebrated as the day of the Municipality of Stari Grad, and we all know what happened 32 years ago on that day and in the days that followed, we are obliged to remember all the fallen fighters and martyrs who laid down their lives for the freedom of this city and for the beauty that we enjoy in peace today.
Eternal glory and thanks be to them, and once again I congratulate all of you on the Day of the Municipality of Stari Grad!

title: Address by Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Denis Bećirović at the headquarters of the United Nations in New York, on the occasion of the resolution on the International Day of Rem
content:
Dear ambassadors, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, thank you for your time and the opportunity to point out important facts that are significant, not only for Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also for all of humanity.
Allow me to briefly state the context, reasons and significance of the adoption of the resolution on July 11 as an International Day of Remembrance and Commemoration of the g=Genocide in Srebrenica, committed in 1995.
The final judgments of the highest UN courts (the International Court of Justice and the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia) confirmed that genocide was committed against Bosniaks in the UN safe zone of Srebrenica.
These are court judgments that cannot be erased from the history of mankind. The highest UN courts proved what happened in Srebrenica in 1995.
No genocide after the Second World War has been documented in such detail as the genocide in Srebrenica.
I would like to remind you that the Hague Tribunal left behind a huge archive of the genocide, crimes against humanity and other crimes.
Among other things, the legacy of The Hague consists of:
· 2.5 million transcripts of court proceedings;
· 422,000 documents;
· 30,000 videos.
10,800 trial days were held at the Hague Tribunal, and over 4,600 witnesses testified. In total, almost 1,500 years of imprisonment were imposed. The tribunal did not judge nations, but determined individual responsibility.
Former UN Secretary General and Nobel Peace Prize winner Kofi Annan wrote in his 2000 report on the fall of Srebrenica that the UN made a "mistake in Srebrenica by miscalculating and failing to recognize the extent of the evil they were facing."
He also said that what happened in the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda is a shame for the UN, because these terrible crimes happened right in front of the UN troops.
The United Nations made a mistake in 1995, but they must not make another mistake in 2024. Genocide victims and their families deserve even a small piece of justice.
The proposed text of the resolution on July 11, as the International Day of Remembrance and Commemoration of the Genocide in Srebrenica committed in 1995, refers to civilizational values.
Among other things, the text of the resolution emphasizes:
to declare July 11 as the International Day of Remembrance and Commemoration of the Genocide in Srebrenica in 1995, which will be marked every year;
· to unreservedly condemn any denial of the genocide in Srebrenica and call on the member states to preserve the established facts;
· that it is necessary, through educational systems, to develop appropriate programs, also as a mark of remembrance and with the aim of preventing revisionism and genocide in the future;
· that glorification of persons convicted of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide should be unreservedly condemned, including those responsible for the genocide in Srebrenica;
· to establish appropriate education and activities to raise public awareness of the committed genocide.
What are the key objectives of this resolution? I will list, among others, nine key arguments for its adoption:
1. Strengthening the culture of peace and encouraging justice
The fundamental goal of this resolution is to build sustainable peace, and encourage the process of justice, truth and trust in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Western Balkans region.
The process of reconciliation must consist of the overall recovery of society, recognition of genocide and crimes, acknowledgement of victims, and punishment of criminals, but with a focus on an outcome that would promote peace and justice.
2. Turning to the future, not the past
We cannot change the past, but we can influence the future.
The aim of this resolution is not to rewrite the past, as that is simply impossible. The purpose of this resolution is to emphasize the importance of building a safer future for new generations.
3. The resolution serves the purpose of reconciliation in the Western Balkans region
The adoption of this resolution would undoubtedly help and encourage the reconciliation process in the long run, within Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as in the region as a whole.
4. Institutional protection of the heritage of the UN courts
Institutional protection of the heritage of UN tribunals and courts simultaneously protects civilizational values and the fundamental principles on which the UN rests, but also contributes to ensuring that the crime of genocide is never repeated.
For the sake of the future work of the UN and the preservation of the credibility of this most important international organization, it is extremely important to learn from the failure of the UN to prevent the genocide in Srebrenica.
5. An important message and warning to mankind
By adopting this resolution, we would send an important message to humanity. The United Nations should be reminded of the final verdicts of its courts on the genocides committed in Rwanda and Srebrenica, because they should serve as a constant warning to humanity.
It is, therefore, necessary for the UN General Assembly to adopt a resolution on the International Day of Remembrance and Commemoration of the Genocide in Srebrenica, as it
did in the Resolution on the International Day of Remembrance of the Genocide in Rwanda against the Tutsi.
Rwanda and Srebrenica must never be erased from the collective memory of humanity.
6. Solidarity with victims, conviction of criminals and prevention of genocide denial
By denying the genocide committed in and around Srebrenica, as well as by glorifying legally convicted war criminals, the surviving witnesses of the genocide are exposed to attacks on their dignity every day.
By adopting this resolution, we would support the families of genocide victims in their fight for truth and justice.
7. Affirmation of the culture of remembrance
Cultivating the culture of remembrance should serve the purpose of stimulating the process of critically confronting the past.
By critically dealing with the past, we want to emphasize the importance of preserving the human rights and freedoms of each individual, and encourage empathy towards the victims of genocide. That is why this resolution is extremely important.
The culture of remembering the victims of the genocide in Srebrenica is not and must not be a culture of denial, but a culture of remembrance, so that the genocide is never repeated.
8. The resolution serves the purpose of dialogue and building an inclusive society
Public education, along with encouraging critical reflection and public dialogue, is the fundamental basis for building socially conscious citizens, ready to oppose ideologies and policies that lead to genocide.
With the resolution, we want to contribute to the construction of an inclusive society based on civilizational values.
9. The resolution has global significance because it encourages educational systems to be in the function of genocide prevention
The resolution should encourage UN member states to adopt teaching and educational programs based on which future generations will be educated about the prevention and consequences of genocide.
The adoption of the UN General Assembly resolution is an important civilizational step forward in the fight for truth and justice.
We are convinced that this resolution is as important for all of us together, for the world, as it is for Bosnia and Herzegovina, because it unequivocally expresses, on a global level, the condemnation of genocide, support for the victims, prevention of denial of genocide and willingness to work together to prevent genocide.
As the chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I especially want to point out important legal arguments, because this resolution is based on international and national law.
In that respect, I emphasize the following legal facts:
·Bosnia and Herzegovina is a full member of the UN and it is our obligation to respect and implement legally binding judgments of permanent and ad hoc established courts (and tribunals) of the UN;
· The General Framework Agreement for Peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina (Dayton Peace Agreement) was signed in 1995. In Article 9 of this agreement, the parties undertook to respect their obligations and cooperate "in the investigation and prosecution of war criminals and other violations of international humanitarian law";
· In the preamble of the BiH Constitution, which is an integral part of the Dayton Peace Agreement, the determination of the contracting parties to ensure "full respect of international humanitarian law" is expressly emphasized, which, among other things, implies the implementation of legally binding court rulings;
· In the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Article II. 8. it is also a standardized obligation of all relevant authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina to cooperate with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and any other international organization authorized by the UN Security Council, with a mandate concerning human rights or humanitarian law;
· The Criminal Code of Bosnia and Herzegovina prohibits public approval, denial or justification of the crime of genocide. Therefore, any action contrary to the Criminal Code of Bosnia and Herzegovina is a criminal offense in Bosnia and Herzegovina;
· Finally, I would like to remind you of the extremely important provisions of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties from 1969, according to which concluded international agreements must be respected and executed in good faith. Bosnia and Herzegovina has undertaken obligations to act in accordance with the principles of the UN Charter, as well as numerous other international agreements, relevant to the adoption and implementation of the resolution in question.
It is very important that we break the false propaganda that tries to present this resolution as an attack on a nation.
Serbs, Bosniaks, Croats and Others, as well as all citizens of our country, are an integral part of Bosnian-Herzegovinian unity in diversity. That's how it was and that's how it will remain.
The resolution on the genocide in Srebrenica is not a threat to the Serbian people. There are no genocidal nations. There are criminals who are responsible for genocide.
There is not a single sentence in this resolution that talks about the collective responsibility of a nation. It is a truth that must be spoken publicly.
There is no justifiable reason for any country in the world not to support the proposed resolution on Srebrenica in the UN General Assembly.
I call on those who are lobbying against the adoption of this resolution to stop doing so and to support the adoption of this resolution.
The genocide in Srebrenica, in the heart of Europe, must not be forgotten or denied.
We must not allow this for the sake of the future of humanity.
By remembering, we preserve the dignity of the victims.
With memory, we fight for a safe future for new generations.
This is a big test for the United Nations as well.
This is also a question of protecting the credibility of this highest international organization, whose highest courts have already passed the final verdicts on the genocide in Srebrenica.
I hope that UN members will protect international law and send a global message that there is hope for a more just future for humanity.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina member Željko Komšić at the UN regarding the consideration of the resolution on Srebrenica at the UN General Assembly scheduled for May 2
content:
"If you look in detail, and even superficially, at the text of this resolution, even the most malicious person will not be able to find the argument that we see circulating in the media, which is that this resolution is directed against any country, people and nations. It does not exist in the text of this resolution. Only the malicious can extract such messages.
This resolution tries to prevent and stop the denial of the facts established by international courts, namely that the genocide was committed in Srebrenica.
Another thing worth taking out of the resolution as a universal message is commitment to the future. Dedication to our children, to the generations that come after us, which I hope will be better than us. That future generations know what happened, that they can draw the right conclusions that will not be burdened with hatred towards anyone. Denying genocide, denying that evil and accepting that denial is actually sowing new seeds of evil for a new genocide.
What I have heard in recent days in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the countries of the Western Balkans, and even here in New York from those who attack and criticize the resolution, is, in fact, the denial and negation of the genocide in Srebrenica.
We can wrap it in any kind of cellophane, but under that cover is the fact that refusing to support the resolution is denying the genocide in Srebrenica, despite the international courts!
Does this mean that not accepting the fact that genocide was committed in Srebrenica means that we are ready to accept some new genocides and the results of genocide? I hope we are aware of that. Only the truth is healing, a lie does not help, only the truth heals. The harsh truth, whether someone likes it or not, is that genocide was committed in Srebrenica! These people were systematically killed because of their religion and ethnicity.
I thank all of you for your support and for listening to us these days, and I hope that the resolution will receive support at the UN General Assembly.
I thank all those who have so far expressed their public support for this act, not as a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but as a Bosnian and Herzegovinian and on behalf of my child".

title: Address by the Chairman of BiH Presidency, Dr Denis Bećirović on the occasion of the adoption of the decision of the European Council on the opening of negotiations of the European Union with Bosnia a
content:
Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the country and abroad, The European Council adopted the Decision on the opening of negotiations between the European Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
After a long time, we made it!
This victory belongs to the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The country of Bosnia and Herzegovina won.
The European Union won.
The future won.
The work and effort paid off.
At this moment, there is no room for celebration and euphoria of politicians because we all have to prepare for the huge work that follows.
Before us is the process of transformation of the state in which the legislation of Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to be harmonized with the acquis of the EU.
This is one of the most important moments for Bosnia and Herzegovina in the 21st century. We brought the country closer to the EU and strengthened the foreign policy position of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a full member of the United Nations, the Council of Europe, the OSCE, and a country that is at the door of NATO.
As of today, we are a country that is officially entering the final phase of integration into the EU, with which we are opening negotiations on full membership.
Thank you to everyone who contributed to making today's decision of the European Council a positive one.
First of all, I would like to thank the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Without their patience and support we could not have achieved this result.
Thanks to our friends in the EU, especially the President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, and the President of the European Council, Charles Michel.
We also had enormous support from the head of the EU Delegation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Johann Sattler, and his associates.
I would also like to thank my colleagues in the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
An important contribution was provided by the media, as well as representatives of civil society in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina have common interests and aspirations. The multicultural EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina are inseparably connected and complementary.
Just as Bosnia and Herzegovina, due to economic, legal, political, security and other reasons, decided to be a part of the EU, I believe that for the EU, for geopolitical and other reasons, it is important to dynamize the process of integration of the countries of the Western Balkans.
The potential of the EU membership provides a significant incentive for changes within Bosnia and Herzegovina that are necessary for:
§ strengthening of BiH economy and attracting investments,
§ building a true democratic society,
§ strengthening the rule of law,
§ promoting media freedom,
§ creating an appropriate climate for the strengthening of civil society.
The opening of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina represents the demonstration of the ability and strength of the EU to be an effective community, based on the values of unity in diversity.
For the sake of peace and stability in this part of Europe, it is necessary to introduce zero tolerance towards individuals who threaten the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The European path of Bosnia and Herzegovina does not exist for certain individuals to weaken our country. The movement towards the EU membership must be in the function of building a modern, European and functional state. The opening of negotiations with the EU should mark the end of anti-Dayton and separatist politics.
It is also in the EU's interest to support civil society in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Our country in Europe can only be what Europe is, a civil society in which ethnic, religious and other rights are part of the overall set of human rights.
The Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina contains the European Convention on Human Rights, which is an integral part of our constitutional system. According to the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, this convention and its protocols are directly applicable in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It has priority over any other law.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, there is no more room for anti-European, irrational, discriminatory and asymmetric solutions. Our country needs a true and consistent implementation of European principles and democratic standards.
What awaits us after the opening of negotiations?
After the European Council adopted the Decision on the opening of negotiations, the following steps are ahead of us:
- The EU adopts the negotiation framework;
- Beginning of negotiations - First intergovernmental conference between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU;
- Screening - explanatory bilateral reports;
- Preparation of positions in the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina;
- Adoption of positions in the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina;
- Opening of negotiations in clusters (6 clusters);
- Conducting negotiations and temporarily closing negotiations in chapters (33 chapters);
- EU decision on temporary closure of negotiations and preparation of the draft accession agreement;
- Signing and ratification of the EU accession agreement.
It is about over 120,000 documents and more than a million pages of text.
We have a huge work ahead of us to harmonize our legal system with the EU acquis.
The process of legal harmonization implies that the legal regulations of our country are harmonized with the legal regulations of the EU, that is, with the legal acquis - a set of rights and obligations that binds the EU members.
This process of harmonizing regulations with the EU regulations is a continuous and permanent process that implies constant monitoring of changes and harmonization of domestic regulations with the EU acquis.
To conclude, we have opened the front gate of the EU courtyard.
We are expected to arrange our house Bosnia and Herzegovina in the same way as 27 other houses in the common European yard.
So, before us is the work of tidying up, adjusting and harmonizing.
The result should be a democratic, legal and economically developed Bosnia and Herzegovina.
A country that serves people.
A country of arrival, not the country of departure.
Thank you for your attention!

title: Address by Serb member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željka Cvijanović on the panel entitled "On War and Peace: The Return of "Realpolitik"" at the Global Baku Forum in Azerbaijan
content:
Esteemed Excellencies, Dear Friends, Let me first, and once again, thank our hosts for the invitation and the opportunity to address this distinguished gathering. I am honoured to share my insights on this highly significant matter.
There are many elements we need to take into consideration as we explore the theme of the panel. The first one implies the theory of the return of Realpolitik to international relations and global security.
Here we have to bear in mind that Realpolitik, by definition, views international relations primarily through the lens of hard power, predominantly military, and subsequently economic strength.
It is seen as a fundamental instrument for attaining projected interests and goals, offering a rather bare worldview stripped of deeper value elements, except those associated with preserving stability and the power of the state itself.
Despite the fact that some new developments such as, for instance, the conflicts in Ukraine and Gaza or the new geopolitical circumstances, warn us, as suggested by the title of this panel, of the ‘return’ of Realpolitik, I believe that Realpolitik and its fundamental categories are constantly present in international political or security arena, where only the intensity of their manifestation varies from phase to phase in specific historical epochs.
And we, who come from the Western Balkan countries, which not too long ago witnessed war and destruction, and who still live with a high-level interference and involvement of certain foreign actors in our domestic issues, are always aware that it takes very little for ‘Realpolitik’ to reveal its ugliest face, where force and power become the sole tool in political processes and relations.
This leads us to another, also relevant issue, which is to understand the circumstances in which Realpolitik manifests as the dominant behavioural matrix but also to understand where our shared responsibility lies when it comes to the current state of affairs in international relations.
It is obvious that Realpolitik and its essence come to the forefront primarily when the key instruments, designed to cushion the impulses originating from the categories of force and power in international relations, fail.
Unfortunately, what we can see nowadays is a complete functional atrophy of multilateral international structures. In other words, their failure in fulfilling their main mission is so evident that we almost do not believe any more in their capacity to bridge the gaps and help the opposed sides to reach agreements or to assist the global community in identifying a common denominator on all relevant or burdening issues in international relations.
We also live in a world marked by profound distrust among key global actors, their direct struggle for more and more power, deep divisions, and ‘taking sides’ in conflicts and inter-state relations that could and should have been avoided.
Therefore, responsibility for the current state of international relations lies with all of us, primarily those who, with their capacities and resources, predominantly shape not only the current global environment but also our near and distant global future.
Those who believe that Realpolitik instruments represent the right way to achieve proclaimed interests and goals neglect the fact that Realpolitik, by its nature, is not only destructive but also self-destructive and that it cannot bring stability and prosperity in the long run.
I am convinced that it is high time for all of us to ‘wake up’ and to start thinking in a serious and responsible manner of how to revive the collapsing international structures, starting from the UN, and how to adapt them to the new circumstances and expectations of those who genuinely promote peace and stability.
Of course, it would sound too ambitions to say that we expect or demand from the big players to reduce their appetites and ambitions but we can still insist on all of us being gathered in an effort to renew mutual trust and to ensure common ‘rules of the game’ that everyone would equally respect, regardless of their strength and power.
Esteemed Excellencies,
Paradoxically, despite the overall civilizational, technological, scientific, and social development, today's world is facing the most complex security challenges in its history.
In a globalised world based on integration and interdependence, each and every one of us will suffer the consequences of our negative individual or collective choices and behaviours.
Therefore, with a certain concern for future developments, we should appeal to all, especially to key players on the international scene, to replace Realpolitik instruments with a negotiating process and diplomatic means.
Otherwise, the world will end up in deeper divisions and uncertainties and I am confident that this is what we want to avoid and that this forum firmly stands for a just and a more peaceful world.
Thank you.

title: Address by the member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović on the occasion of the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Distinguished excellencies, eminences, esteemed guests, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, At the beginning of my address, I express my particular gratitude to the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina who, in a legal and internationally recognized referendum, decided that our country should be independent, sovereign and united, as well as to the anti-fascists of the last century who restored statehood and defended the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The long and glorious past of our country is behind us.
Let us be proud of the first 1075 years since the country of Bosnia was mentioned in historical sources. After this millennial journey, we cannot go back.
We just have to move forward. Before us is the Euro-Atlantic and European future of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Deviating from that path would have fatal consequences.
Therefore, I consistently and everywhere insist on the implementation of the adopted strategic foreign policy goals. I do not do it by accident. This is how we protect the safety of our people and country in the best way!
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a full member of the United Nations, the Council of Europe, the OSCE, and a country that is at the door of the EU and NATO.
These are indisputable facts of international law that separatists must be aware of. Likewise, they must finally understand that the entities have never had and will never have international subjectivity.
According to the provisions of international and national law, Bosnia and Herzegovina is a state. Its constitutive elements are state territory, population and sovereign power. They are contained in the term "state", the term used to define Bosnia and Herzegovina in the international and national order.
Those who thought they could, in spite of all democratic principles, create a state within the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina ended up as legally convicted criminals, most of them are still in prison or have left this world branded.
This is how it will end for all those who eventually try to walk again in the paths of convicted war criminals.
Public holidays are an opportunity to initiate concrete steps aimed at strengthening the statehood and independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Tonight is an opportunity for me to initiate two specific proposals. First, as there is a Bosnian Language House in Tuzla, I suggest that we open Bosnian language houses in every municipality or city, wherever possible.
Secondly, let us follow the positive example from Cazin, where the Museum of the Bosnian Kingdom was opened. I suggest that in every municipality or city, where possible, we open museums dedicated to the Bosnian and Bosnian and Herzegovinian state.
Let us do everything in our power to make our country stronger and safer.
We tell well-intentioned people that together we should protect Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We tell the malicious ones who have not given up on the illusory large-state projects that they will have an impenetrable wall in us.
So, with friends amicably, with enemies as they deserve.
Why do separatist-oriented politicians mind the presence of the international community in our country?
Why are they against foreigners in the Commission for National Monuments appointed by the Director General of UNESCO? Why are they against the judges of the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina appointed by the President of the European Court of Human Rights? Why are they against the institution of the High Representative of the International Community? Why are they attacking the ambassadors of Western and other countries who respect Bosnia and Herzegovina?
Nothing is accidental. Those who advocate it have dangerous intentions towards Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is not true that the presence of foreigners bothers the leaders of BiH's entity of RS. The truth is that they wish to strengthen the influence of Russia and weaken the influence of the West and the free democratic world.
That is why the president of Bosnia and Herzegovina's entity of RS said that "the whole world needs Putin's humane approach", in order to "restrain the freakish liberal West and the EU, which has fallen into cultural regression".
There is no dilemma, the leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina's entity of RS are working according to the instructions of Moscow and their common goal is to remove the Euro-Atlantic influence from Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as to block everything that leads our country towards a functional liberal democracy.
What would happen if the international community withdrew from Bosnia and Herzegovina?
We all know the answer, the same policies would attack Bosnia and Herzegovina, and again threaten the peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region.
That is why we must openly and argumentatively expose this hypocritical and dangerous policy.
We must use arguments to break falsehoods and hoaxes.
We became a candidate country for the EU membership in December 2022. Soon we expect the opening of negotiations with the EU on full EU membership. We are in the heart of Europe and our place is in the EU.
We are also at the door of membership in NATO. This is our national legal, strategic and political commitment. We have a full consensus on NATO and it has been reached in the competent state bodies. That consensus can only be changed where it has been established and unanimously voted for. So, in competent state bodies, not in non-competent entity bodies.
NATO is a safe haven that guarantees peace, security and economic development to all people in our country.
Finally, I would like to emphasize that there is no more important issue than the issue of preserving the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Let us work for the benefit of the country and people and protect the country and people.
Let loyalty and devotion to the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina be the first.
Happy Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: Address by the Chairman of BiH Presidency Željko Komšić at the International Conference entitled "Members of Parliament and Religious Leaders for Peace and Coexistence"
content:
Your Excellencies, distinguished guests, members of parliament, respected organizers of the Conference!
I wish you a warm welcome on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina and personally, and I welcome guests from abroad to Bosnia and Herzegovina and Sarajevo.
I am glad to have the opportunity to open today's International Conference "Members of Parliament and Religious Leaders for Peace and Coexistence", and to discuss the topic of peace and life (I prefer this word and term to the word coexistence) here in the Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina, especially since I think that we in Bosnia and Herzegovina have something to say about that topic, regardless of the angle from which anyone looked at it.
The question of life and peace or living in peace, current even today, is the main question that was posed to us as a society after the signing of the Dayton Agreement in November 1995.
Given that it was also a peace agreement, the maintenance of the entire constitutional and social structure within Bosnia and Herzegovina, which was established through difficult compromises, depended on the state of peace.
Peace was therefore at the centre of what, after the aggression and the bloody war, was our general, that is, common interest. Numerous security and other challenges, including tensions in this post-Dayton period of Bosnia and Herzegovina's history, could not overcome the basic civil need for peace and stability.
That basic civil need for peace won a sort of victory in the Bosnian society and enabled, at least partially, social integration, not only in the institutional, but also in the economic, cultural and sports sense.
Although Bosnia and Herzegovina remained administratively divided into entities, cantons and districts, the movement of people, goods and capital could not be stopped, just as numerous other encounters in different social disciplines could not be stopped. Peace gained meaning every day and it was increasingly clear that it was the greatest value of a political agreement with which, let us be honest, no one was satisfied.
For the peace, of course, we can thank ourselves as citizens, and we can also thank our friends from the international community who, wholeheartedly, made a solid contribution to its maintenance.
All this, in almost three decades of post-Dayton history, created the preconditions for a stable state of life in peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which I am convinced can turn into a permanent peace if Bosnia and Herzegovina is not threatened from the outside, as it is has been the case so far. The perspective of permanent peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina depends exclusively on this, because unrest and conflicts in Bosnia and Herzegovina did not arise by themselves, but were always and as a rule initiated and brought about from outside.
The state of peaceful life in Bosnia and Herzegovina is most visible right here, in Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Although it has not yet healed all wounds, and the question is whether this is even possible, the fact is that Sarajevo can be considered one of the freest and most liberal cities, not only in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also in the entire Western Balkans.
By its character and nature, Sarajevo has always been like that! In Sarajevo, it is considered quite normal, almost natural, that people from all over Bosnia and Herzegovina, people of all ethnic and religious identities, live, work, cooperate, hang out, and more than that. It is simply our way of life and we see it as normality, not some spectacular fact and something new.
No matter how hard some political actors try to emphasize the existence of administrative lines, practical life testifies to the fact that people rely on each other in their daily activities. This speaks in the best way in favour of a pleasant and peaceful life. This, if nothing else, is evidenced by the thousands of people from all over Bosnia and Herzegovina who come to work in Sarajevo every day and work in peace and harmony with their colleagues, as well as by the many people who leave Sarajevo for other parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The image of life and the perspective of lasting peace can be especially strengthened by religious communities and their leaders. I am saying this for a reason that is well known to all of us, whether some like it or not, the role of religious communities and religious leaders in our country is, after all, the role of spiritual and generally moral authority for a good part of Bosnians and Herzegovinians. This makes the role more important, but the responsibility is also greater!
I would like to hear religious officials talk more often about peace, living in peace and cooperation, as the actor Aleksandar Stojković spoke in response to the accusations, and in connection with the hosting of the Sarajevo War Theatre in Banja Luka.
I will end my address with his words because they are for me, without being pretentious and declaring them important for everyone, one of the most important thoughts that were expressed after the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I quote:
"Do you think that I, Aleksandar Stojković, a soldier of the Republika Srpska army and a disabled war veteran, should be banned from participating in any festival in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina because I was a member of the Republika Srpska army, lost my best friends and lost hometown, lost the most beautiful youth ... that I need someone to justify myself because we invited our colleagues to come and do a play here, 30 years after the war. The two governments, the Government of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Government of Republika Srpska, met together the other day, did anyone ask them that question? Maybe there was a Golden Lily there, maybe there was someone who wounded me in 1992, so what? Should I live in that world? Should I say to my son Marko: 'Don't cross over to Sanski Most even by accident, should I do that?'", end of quote.
Thank you for your attention. I wish everyone successful work and the Conference.

title: Address by the Chairman of BiH Presidency, Željko Komšić, at the Central Ceremony at the National Theatre in Sarajevo on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of the XIV Winter Olympic Games in Sarajev
content:
Your Excellencies, Dear friends, Ladies and Gentlemen… welcome to Olympic Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I want to start by thanking all the athletes for their presence here tonight, especially those who participated in the competitions within the Olympic Games in Sarajevo. I am particularly pleased with the fact that the president of the friendly Republic of Slovenia is with us tonight, whom I hereby greet and once again welcome to Sarajevo. Welcome to Sarajevo, which exactly 40 years ago, according to the then president of the International Olympic Committee, Juan Antonio Samaran, organized the best Winter Olympic Games until then.
Why were these, until then, the best organized games? There are many answers to this question, and many of us may have different answers to it, but I would venture to say that the main reason it was the best organized Winter Olympics was that we were among the best organized societies in the world at the time, no matter how it sounds to someone today.
Without any unnecessary pathos and excessive nostalgia for the times that have passed, which always and almost as a rule seem beautiful even when they are not, let alone when they are; I claim that the Bosnian society of that time was in every sense at its zenith, that is, at the peak of its creative, work and moral potential.
When I say that, I also feel a kind of deep gratitude towards the generation of people who dared to engage in the project of organizing the Winter Olympic Games. Gratitude not only to the people who had a clear vision of the importance of the Olympic Games for Bosnia and Herzegovina and Sarajevo, but also to a working generation of people who, in their enthusiasm and faith, for the general and common good, were ready to take and contribute from their own income in order to present ourselves to the world in the best light.
That generation succeeded in this and thus proved to themselves and others that the decades of work and effort that had preceded it were not in vain. Bosnia and Herzegovina has gone from a small and underdeveloped Republic to a Republic that is able to organize events at the highest level, a journey from the backwoods to the centre of the world.
Of course, neither Sarajevo nor Bosnia and Herzegovina were alone in this. And that is why I want to thank all those from the former Yugoslavia, from Triglav to Vardar, who helped organize the Olympic Games in Sarajevo, and those who participated in the organization and maintenance of them. Without their contribution, the organization itself would not be the same and at such a high level. The Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, in addition to everything else in terms of organization and sport, are also a triumph of the spirit. It was the victory of our common idea that we can be the best at anything that we accept with true enthusiasm and passion.
The feeling of collective pride that permeated us in those days left a deep mark on all of us who were witnesses of that time and those events.
We were proud because the world came to us and proud that we are the world, that is, our better side that lives on the principles of humanism, solidarity, friendship and equality.
Unfortunately, just when we believed that only the sky was our limit, it was as if all the hatred of the world fell on this city and country, and within a few years what had been built for decades disappeared and was burned. The aggressor against our country destroyed during the war all the Olympic stadiums and competition grounds, and worst of all, wounded the soul of this City, from which we are still recovering today, with more or less success.
The organization of the 2019 Youth Olympic Festival brought back hope and reminded of the days of the Winter Olympics, and it is also one of the most beautiful events in recent years.
That event leads us to think about the underutilization of our potential, but at the same time it represents the possibility that a new generation of our people will set before themselves the challenge of organizing the Winter Olympic Games, and once again make what is apparently difficult, complicated and demanding a part of our reality. I believe that those who are just entering sports and other fields today can succeed in this.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Speech by the Serb member of the BiH Presidency, Željka Cvijanović, at the 19th Summit of Heads of State and Government of the Non
content:
Esteemed ladies and gentlemen, It is an honour for me, as a representative of the observer country, to address this esteemed assembly at the 19th summit of the Non-Aligned Movement. It is a true privilege for me to be in Kampala and Uganda for the first time, rightfully acclaimed as the pearl of Africa.
This gathering provides a unique opportunity to forge new partnerships, strengthen cooperation, and engage in discussions about the most important global issues.
I am confident that this conference will contribute significantly to enhancing bilateral and multilateral cooperation, fostering a deeper understanding of global processes, and addressing prevailing challenges.
Though originating from an observer nation rather than a full member, I hold the principles of non-alignment and the Movement itself in high regard.
This sentiment is partly rooted in the fact that my home country, the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, where I was born and spent a significant part of my life, was one of the founding members of the Non-Aligned Movement, with its capital, Belgrade, hosting the inaugural conference in 1961.
The policy of non-alignment has obviously endured the test of time and its principles and values are needed today just as they were 60 years ago.
Regrettably, it appears that the lessons of the past have not been fully embraced. The language of force, weapons, and conflict continues to overshadow the language of peace, dialogue, and diplomacy.
Striking similarities exist between the perilous Cold War era and the current state of global affairs, where fires are extinguished with gasoline rather than rational discourse and diplomatic efforts.
Just as in the past, the dominance of power over international law persists, with the latter holding significance for the big powers only when it aligns with their interests.
Otherwise, international law remains a mere symbol on paper - an unrealised beacon of justice for the small who always suffer when their interests do not overlap with those of the big and powerful.
But we all know that rules will be effective only if they are universal - collectively and individually accepted by all relevant actors.
If the international law is selectively respected or adhered to and if standards vary from case to case, the result is a breeding ground for double standards and a perilous descent into chaos and disorder.
The consequence of the breakdown of the global order based on international law is instability and anarchy, where, in the long run, no one emerges victorious, and all, to varying degrees, suffer losses.
Regrettably, we observe this scenario in the Balkans, particularly in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which has become a victim of contemporary neocolonialism and a laboratory for various political experiments, causing a destructive impact on all its peoples and citizens.
It is crucial to emphasize that Bosnia and Herzegovina bears the disreputable label of being the ‘sole colony in Europe’ where a German national Christian Schmidt, disregarding the procedures of the international law, assumes the role of a high representative, behaving akin to a colonial governor from the 19th century.
Unlike former high representatives appointed in adherence to proper procedures and confirmed by the United Nations Security Council, Schmidt lacks UNSC confirmation, making his formal election to this position non-existent.
His unlawful presence in Bosnia and Herzegovina relies exclusively on force and the influence of powerful Western nations that back him, disregarding the fact that his appointment does not align with the Dayton Peace Agreement.
Still, this individual enforces laws in lieu of democratically elected domestic institutions and confronts democratically elected local representatives, seeking to politically eliminate those who oppose his arbitrary rule.
In front of the the eyes of the world, through his illegal actions, Christian Schmidt directly undermines the Dayton Peace Agreement, the rule of law, sovereignty, and the institutional and democratic capacity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
As one of the three members of the collective Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I strongly believe that the fate of peoples should be determined through domestic institutions, not by self-proclaimed protectors, ambassadors, or any foreign entities.
The will of any individual or the stroke of a pen, regardless of its origin, should never override the collective will of the people. Unfortunately, what we see in BiH is that certain foreign actors promote the concept where the will of an individual should prevail over the collective will of our institutions.
I firmly assert that all political challenges, both in Bosnia and Herzegovina and across the globe, should be resolved through peaceful and civilised means - through compromise and dialogue - rather than by force or the unilateral imposition of solutions.
The scenes of war, violence, and destruction in Eastern Europe or the Middle East deeply affect me, as I recognise the pain, suffering, and personal and familial tragedies that accompany every armed conflict.
The tragic conflict that the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina experienced, the consequences we still feel nearly 30 years after its conclusion, obligates us to approach global conflicts not from a partisan perspective but exclusively from a human and humanitarian standpoint.
It urges us to consistently emphasise, on every occasion, the paramount importance of peace, understanding that it is better to negotiate for a thousand days than to engage in war for a single day.
I am confident that there is a high level of consensus at this forum regarding the fundamental values and principles that should underpin the international order and interstate or intergovernmental relations.
Without peaceful coexistence between states and peoples, mutual respect for sovereignty and the essential decolonisation of the world, there can be no stable international order.
Therefore, it is crucial to make additional efforts to reaffirm these values globally, given that challenges arising from their absence are shared by many.
It brings me great joy to have the opportunity to attend the Non-Aligned Movement Conference for the first time, right here in the heart of Africa.
I am convinced that our tradition of non-alignment and the shared values we inherit can be a powerful catalyst for better understanding and the strengthening of bilateral and multilateral cooperation with member countries of the Movement.
I am confident that this conference will proceed in a positive and constructive atmosphere, fostering open dialogue on all current challenges and exploring possibilities for overcoming them.
Congratulations to President Museveni on assuming the presidency of the Non-Aligned Movement, and to President Aliyev for successfully leading the organisation during the past challenging and complex period.
I extend my congratulations to the hosts for the excellent and successful organisation of this year's conference, expressing gratitude for the attention and the opportunity to address you.
Thank you.

title: Address by the Chairman of BiH Presidency Željko Komšić at the European Union
content:
Dear President of the European Council,
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I am grateful for the invitation to another summit of the European Union and the countries of the Western Balkans. I think it is very important to maintain the continuity of talks at the highest political level.
We are still in a very complex geopolitical moment for Europe, caused by Russia's aggression against Ukraine. The situation is further complicated by Israel's disproportionate military response to Hamas' terrorist attack on Israeli civilians.
The level of indiscriminate destruction and killing of Palestinian civilians in Gaza has caused great turbulence in Europe and the world, and has also affected relations in the United Nations and the functioning of its institutions.
Emotions capable of raising tensions cannot be localized to regions of conflict. Media and social networks transmit emotions to other parts of the world with uncertain outcomes.
In this geopolitical context, we are discussing today, here in Brussels, the further direction of the integration of the Western Balkans into the European Union.
This is good, because the active role of the European Union and its political presence can thwart potential intentions to provoke conflict situations that could lead to escalation in our region as well.
I think that escalation does not suit anyone reasonable in the region. Therefore, let us start talking about revitalizing the perspective offered to the Western Balkans by bringing it closer to the European Union.
From the perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is clear to us that our candidate status, acquired a year ago, as well as the recent conditional recommendation of the European Commission for the opening of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, is the result of the tense geopolitical situation on the borders of the European Union and that obtaining candidate status has absolutely nothing to do with meeting the standards and realizing the assumed obligations.
Nevertheless, I certainly want to thank the Commission and the Council for their positive attitude towards Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I would like to be able to say that the progress in the EU integration status of Bosnia and Herzegovina is the merit of the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Unfortunately, the effort to adopt legislation and build the professional capacities of the state administration is not satisfactory.
Our public opinion is aware of this. The survey from 2023 shows that 73.3% of citizens still support the European integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is 4.1% less than in 2022, while the survey from 2022 shows that only 42% believe that BiH will become part of the EU by 2030, and 13% believe that it will never happen.
I still believe that the fulfilment of 14 key priorities from the Opinion of the European Commission from May 2019 is crucial for further progress of our country in the direction of harmonization with the EU acquis.
I appeal to all EU institutions, as well as to the member states that the so-called 14 priorities from the European Commission Opinion from 2019, which concern Bosnia and Herzegovina, still remain a kind of official policy of the European institutions towards Bosnia and Herzegovina. That relationship and that policy must be freed from any kind of hypocrisy on all sides.
The last intensive dialogue of the European Commission with representatives of the legislative and executive authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina, entity and cantonal governments, in accordance with the established coordination mechanism within BiH, which the Commission also accepted as a working method, caused, to put it mildly, ridicule in BiH public.
The public of Bosnia and Herzegovina saw that meeting as an obvious proof of the dysfunctionality of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state, but also as proof of the dysfunctionality of the coordination mechanism itself and the relationship to the EU integrations of both the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Nevertheless, that method of work is officially and mutually accepted, and because of this, the legislative and executive bodies of all levels of government in Bosnia and Herzegovina are obliged to play an active role in the implementation of reform processes.
In this regard, the "Growth Plan" for the Western Balkans can be an important support for reform processes, but also for the preservation of pro-European commitment in the circumstances of a pronounced propaganda war aimed at destroying "European values", not only in the Western Balkans but also in the European Union itself.
I am aware that the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted the draft "Reform Plan" for Bosnia and Herzegovina to the Commission last week. The document briefly includes: green and digital agenda, development of the private sector and business environment, preservation and development of human resources and the rule of law.
In the next month or two, governments and legislative bodies of all levels of government in Bosnia and Herzegovina should show concrete progress in this direction.
In this regard, I expect the responsible officials to fulfil the obligations they have assumed, including the obligations that the leaders of the political parties assumed at the meeting with you, President Michel, exactly 18 months ago, in this same place.
Finally, concrete regulations, standards and procedures are, at first glance, far from their sphere of interest. I would therefore recommend that the European Union pay attention to the preservation of "European values" as a type of emotional aspect of integration that is often neglected, but turns out to be very important.
Underestimating the subjective attitude of citizens towards the value system on which the EU is based can lead to those citizens giving up on the European Union. Ultimately, the value system that we believe still exists in the EU makes us in Bosnia and Herzegovina determined to be part of the EU.
Giving up those values will turn BiH society away from the EU itself, and the EU will gain another source of instability on its borders.
Here, above all, I mean support for the elimination of discrimination based on religious, ethnic, racial, political or any other affiliation, which is guaranteed by the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, which is an integral part of our Constitution.
Therefore, in the context of the rule of law, as one of the reform priorities from the draft "Reform Plan" of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I believe that the implementation of the six judgments of the European Court of Human Rights in the cases of Sejdić-Finci, Pilav, Zornić, Šlaku, Pudarić and Kovačević is pivotal.
The geopolitical moment does not allow further procrastination and avoiding the truth, that the actual implementation of these judgments is inevitable. Only if the European Union, clearly and unequivocally, stands behind the necessity of realizing "European values" and the rule of law in Bosnia and Herzegovina, we can get a synergy of "emotional" support for European values, practical visibility of the "Plan for Growth" and a real will for reforms that will further direct Bosnia and Herzegovina towards her European goal.

title: Address by the member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović on the occasion of the 25th of November
content:
Ladies and Gentlemen citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, respected excellencies, appreciated guests! Today we mark and celebrate the national holiday - Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and express deep respect to the anti-fascists of the 20th century who restored statehood and defended the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina. A great number of ambassadors from friendly countries are with us, whom I warmly greet, and whom I sincerely thank for celebrating our national holiday with us.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of the oldest European countries.
Today there are 49 countries in Europe. At the time when the medieval Bosnian state became a kingdom in 1377, there were only fifteen kingdoms in Europe, and the Bosnian Kingdom was the sixteenth. So, when most European states did not even exist, we were in the "elite club" of sixteen European states - kingdoms.
This fact too shows that Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of the oldest European countries. The roots of our country are extremely strong and deep. They cannot be uprooted by small and fleeting politicians, because forces much bigger and stronger than them could not do that either.
In the coming period, we must strengthen the national identity.
In the last three decades, we emphasized numerous identities, but we did the least work on strengthening the state identity of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It's time for a turnaround. Let's all gather around the state and strengthen the state identity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In particular, we must take care of the equality of all languages and, in this context, protect the Bosnian language from denial.
The Bosnian language has centuries of continuity. The following facts testify to this:
- Ban Kulin's charter dated 29.08.1189, as the oldest preserved Bosnian state document, undoubtedly confirms the historical continuity of the Bosnian language and its centuries-old written tradition.
- Constantine of Kostenets (the Philospoher) in his work Writing on Language and Spelling, written at the end of the 14th and beginning of the 15th century, writes that the Bosnian language is an equal member of the community of Slavic languages.
- After the fall of the Bosnian kingdom, the Bosnian language acquired the status of a diplomatic language in the Ottoman Empire.
- Matija Divković in Venice in 1611 published Nauk Krstjanski in the Bosnian language.
- Stjepan Matijević published the Confessions in 1630 and wrote that it was translated from Latin into the Bosnian language.
- Muhamed Hevai Uskufi publishes the Bosnian dictionary in 1631. It was the first dictionary of the Bosnian language and the entire Štokavian dialect.
- After the Ottoman Empire, Austria-Hungary also recognized its centuries-old name and called it the "terrestrial Bosnian language", and in 1890 the Grammar of the Bosnian language was published.
- Under pressure from the neighbourhood, in 1907, it was announced that the use of the previous name Bosnian language would cease.
- Nevertheless, despite all negations, in the last decade of the XX century, the Bosnian language was given back its centuries-old name.
For the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is extremely important to preserve and respect the equality of all languages. We must invest much more in education, science, culture and art. This is where the inexhaustible strength of Bosnia and Herzegovina lies.
Millions of us in the country and outside it, can and should be proud of our country, its statehood, stability, history and heroes.
Bosnia and Herzegovina and its defenders have never been convicted of attacking anyone or committing genocide. That is why, among other things, it is unacceptable that Bosnia and Herzegovina is attacked by those who glorify convicted war criminals for the committed genocide.
We are legalists and we do not threaten anyone. That is why we can freely say that it is absolutely unacceptable that the leaders of BiH entity of RS threaten the independent, sovereign and indivisible state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Bosnia has existed for more than 1,000 years. Our country existed even without entities, and entities have never existed and will never exist outside the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The people of Bosnia and Herzegovina have character and pride. We best understand those who are threatened and disenfranchised because we went through the calvary of the 1990s.
That is why I once again strongly condemn the killing of innocent civilians in the Middle East and Ukraine. There are no more or less valuable human lives. Civilized people sincerely sympathize with the families of the victims, regardless of their religious, ethnic or other affiliation.
If only the law of the stronger applies on our planet, then the human species is no different from other living beings. If anyone on the globe thinks that the main rule is the law of the stronger, he is doing harm to himself and others. We are all on this planet just a small and fleeting grain in an endless universe and we should defend the values of civilization together.
Let us protect our country when it is threatened, build a persistently more positive social environment whenever we can.
Let us develop and build relations with all friendly countries, on all meridians and parallels, and never endanger the Euro-Atlantic path of our country.
Moving towards full membership in NATO and the EU is our strategic commitment. There is no serious alternative to that decision.
If I had to be the last man in our country to say that, I would do it again.
