Bringing the presidents, general, camp manager and other responsible persons before the Hague Tribunal exceeded the initial expectations from the beginning of the work of this international ad hoc court. With the decisions concerning the genocide committed against Bosniaks, crimes against humanity and other war crimes, the ICTY showed that the high position of an individual can no longer be a protection against criminal prosecution.
The tribunal also confirmed the legal nature of the war waged against the internationally recognized state of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The final verdicts of the Hague Tribunal, including the verdicts on joint criminal enterprises, proved that it was an international armed conflict. Neighbouring states fought a war for territories with the aim of creating a greater Serbia, and in one period of the war, a greater Croatia. These facts were established in eight final judgments of the ICTY.
Today's verdict against Stanišić and Simatović is important because the two former heads of the Serbian security service were sentenced with final force of law, thus confirming Milošević's commanding role, considering that this verdict refers to the Serbian State Security Service and its crimes in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as in Croatia.
The special importance of this verdict lies in the fact that the top leaders of the Serbian security service were legally convicted of crimes and involvement in aggression against the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Stanišić and Simatović acted under the direct orders of Milošević, who managed his secret police and its secret combat unit. Let us not forget, the secret units were also designed to hide the responsibility of the Serbian government for some of the worst crimes committed against civilians outside of Serbia.
The appeals panel found, among other things, "that there was a joint criminal enterprise and that its common goal was the forcible and permanent removal of the majority of non-Serbs from large parts of Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina by committing murder, deportation, inhumane acts (forced relocation) and persecution, as charged in the indictment. (...) The appeals panel found that Mr. Stanišić and Mr. Simatović responsible as members of a joint criminal enterprise for crimes committed by various Serbian forces in 1992 in Bosnia and Herzegovina, in Bijeljina, Zvornik, Bosanski Šamac, Doboj and Sanski Most, and for crimes committed in 1995 in Trnovo and Sanski Most" (...).
Transcripts from the Hague Tribunal trials, as well as documented digital evidence, provide much more detailed information about the role of Slobodan Milošević and Serbia than the verdict itself.
The huge archives of the Hague Tribunal await researchers. At the trial of Slobodan Milošević, Serbia's aggressor role was comprehensively discussed. Although it was widely assumed that, under the Milošević regime, Serbia supported Serbian parastatals in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, the full extent of that support and the mechanisms by which it was provided were not revealed to the public until this trial. The death of Slobodan Milošević prevented a verdict against him, but it did not erase the facts.
Considering the aforementioned facts, as a member of BiH Presidency, I emphasize the following:
1. Judgments of the Hague Tribunal are of capital importance for the entire international law and order. The judgments of the highest courts of the UN established that genocide was committed against Bosniaks. At the same time, they are verdicts on the policies of the big states that tried to divide and destroy Bosnia and Herzegovina as an independent, sovereign, indivisible and internationally recognized state with a joint criminal enterprise.
2. The verdicts of the Hague Tribunal, including today's verdict in the case Prosecutor v. Stanišić and Simatović, established not only individual, but also institutional responsibility of high-ranking political, military and police leaders of Serbia for crimes against humanity and violations of the laws or customs of war.
3. The international community and the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina have a legal, political, moral and historical obligation towards the victims and future generations to demand:
- revision of history and other textbooks in the countries of the region with the aim of incorporating legally binding judgments of the highest United Nations’ courts;
- revision of the criminal legislation in the countries of the region in order to adequately prosecute and punish all those who glorify convicted war criminals;
- prosecuting and punishing those remaining responsible for the committed genocide, crimes against humanity and other war crimes;
- justice and truth for thousands of people who are still searching for the truth about the fate of their loved ones;
- implementation of mechanisms of transitional justice.
4. On the occasion of the thirtieth anniversary of the establishment of the Hague Tribunal, I again request that the UN bring a just solution and that the complete original archives of the Hague Tribunal be stored in Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Namely, as a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, at the beginning of this year I asked the UN Secretary General, the President of the UN General Assembly and the President of the Residual Mechanism for Criminal Courts to store the archives of the Hague Tribunal in the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Millions of printed pages, audio recordings, videos, photographs, political agreements and secret data, which clearly depict what happened during the aggression against the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1992 to 1995, should be stored in Sarajevo.
5. The international community should not allow final court judgments to be archived and then forgotten. Bosnia and Herzegovina has the right to demand that:
- the international community, in the interest of all humanity, sends a message that the results of committed genocide, crimes against humanity and other crimes cannot and must not be permanently recognized;
- representatives of the international community insist and encourage member states to fulfil their international obligations in good faith. It is necessary to take all necessary measures against countries that refuse to do so, provided for by the UN Charter and other relevant international acts.
- The UN, and especially the countries of the European Union, sanction all politicians who threaten and work to break up the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina and glorify legally recognized war criminals as a precondition that such evils never happen again to anyone.
6. It is in the best interest of preserving peace, stability and good-neighbourly cooperation that the highest authorities and officials of the Republic of Serbia:
- responsibly face the consequences of the actions of their highest officials and institutions in the 1990s;
- stop denying the court-judged genocide against Bosniaks. No genocide after the Second World War has been so extensively and factually documented as the genocide against Bosniaks committed during the aggression against the internationally recognized state of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina;
- provide access to key archives, remove the secrecy mark and ensure complete access to documents of the Supreme Defence Council of the FRY that have not yet been published;
- condemn the criminal project of Greater Serbia and permanently stop threatening the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina;
- draw a long-term lesson from the fact that Serbia is the only country that has been judged to have violated the UN Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide;
- stop with the policy of undermining and disrespecting Bosnia and Herzegovina, and especially with denying the final and binding decisions of the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina;
- normatively and factually decide to establish good neighbourly relations between independent and sovereign states in accordance with the principles of international law;
- condemn and excommunicate perpetrators of genocide, crimes against humanity and other crimes, and not glorify them;
7. Today's verdict is a new opportunity for Serbia to clearly distance itself from the architects, organizers and perpetrators of genocide, crimes against humanity and other crimes, so that we can turn to building a prosperous future together.
The future of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, and wider areas is not in hegemonic policies, conflicts and quarrels. The conviction of criminals and their policies is an important prerequisite for strengthening good neighbourly relations, stability and sustainable development. It is time to decisively start the process of raising awareness and conducting a reasonable and peaceful policy.
Finally, citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, let us turn to the future, but with constant vigilance and caution, because genocide is repeatable. Let us not forget, the planners, order givers and perpetrators of genocide and only have respect for those who are trained for defence and who show a desire for defence. It us a lesson we all need to learn well.
Long live our proud and indomitable country Bosnia and Herzegovina!
- stop the practice of providing refuge to convicted war criminals.

title: Address by the member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović at the 12th Sarajevo Business Forum
content:
Dear organisers, Excellencies, respected businessmen and entrepreneurs, Ladies and Gentlemen, dear guests!
It is my pleasure to welcome you to the 12th Sarajevo Business Forum. Sarajevo is an open and cosmopolitan city, where well-intentioned people from all over the world always receive a warm welcome.
Sarajevo Business Forum has established itself as one of the most important business and investment events in this part of Europe. I am particularly glad that the importance of this forum grows year by year and confirms the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a strategically important destination that increasingly attracts investors from all over the world.
I believe that it is the duty of state officials to provide full support to gathering and connecting business people and investors from our country and the whole world, respecting our unique position at the crossroads of roads that connect East and West, both geographically and in terms of civilization.
Europe and the world have experienced tectonic changes in a short time, especially in the past two years. The world is at a geopolitical, security, economic, cultural and historical turning point. We must adapt to the new circumstances and do everything we can so that we do not become victims of global earthquakes again.
Paradigms which have existed for decades, once even for centuries, are changing or disappearing before our eyes. We no longer have to wait for decades for capital accumulation to push the limits of production possibilities. We must not continuously be a "developing country" without clear prospects and deadlines for overcoming such a position. Gone are the days of "big" and "small" economies and businesses. We are living the reality of rapid and innovative changes.
The certain European and Euro-Atlantic future of our country is an additional incentive for strengthening our economy. It is our obligation to rapidly harmonise our economic and administrative system with the standards of the European Union. Our ambition is to deepen regional cooperation as well. This helps us to be more competitive and attractive for companies from abroad that want to have their springboard in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region towards the EU market.
Politics and people in it must understand what our tasks and role in the economy of the new times are. We are in a merciless global game in which literally everyone is competing for the key resources, and through market share and influence, they strive to win or maintain relevance and their citizens' living standard. This does not mean that we are necessarily confronted with each other and that conflict is our destiny. If our competitors are global, then we have to look for partners all over the world, but not to forget those who are there with us. These insights must be at the core of the state's new approach to the economy, and we must define its role and tasks based on them.
I wish to be very clear here. On the one hand, the state must be actively involved in the economy by defining our interests and properly evaluating the existing structure of our economy, and then create the appropriate strategy and policies to realize them. On the other hand, the state must abandon the idea and practice of being omnipresent in the economy and get out of the positions that belong to private initiative.
It is time to bring the public sector closer to the standards and rules of the private sector in terms of efficiency and effectiveness. We must relieve the private sector of excessively high levies and tax burdens on labour, as well as the burden of unfair competition. We will continue to open space for our companies abroad and protect their interests, but also show confidence in our companies and business people in the country.
Stable energy supply and energy security, as well as internal and external security in general, can only be ensured by states. It must be at the top of our priorities. We must have control over key energy resources and use them responsibly, always keeping in mind the need to protect energy sovereignty and future generations. We are part of Europe, and soon we will become part of Green Europe.
Let us support our businessmen, entrepreneurs and employers. They bear the burden of responsibility for shared success. We want to see even more domestic initiatives and investments. Employers should better organise, unite, define their priorities and promote them in dialogue with government representatives.
We must jointly invest more in the most valuable resources we have - the human resources. For too long, we have based our GDP growth on short-term consumption incentives, neglecting production capacity in the medium term and the development of growth factors in the long term, such as education and capacity for innovation.
It is important to continue and intensify investments in our economy, invest in the development of employees, increase their incomes and improve working conditions. Investing implies anticipating the future, but also an active work on its shaping and realisation. It involves the allocation of certain resources and their use in the most efficient way possible. It requires that we plan, monitor, redefine when necessary and constantly improve the entire process. We should not forget other important variables such as: the ideas and passion of investors, outcomes and opportunities that not everyone sees, and especially the willingness and commitment to turn good ideas into reality.
United around positive ideas and projects we have a chance, divided we don't. If others perceive us as divided, quarrelsome and weak, and our resources as prey, they will try to treat us that way.
We are hard-working people who badly need results, victories and self-confidence. The youth of this country should know that there are countries with comparable resources and a starting position as Bosnia and Herzegovina today; e.g. Singapore and South Korea in the mid-20th century, or Ireland at the end of the last century, managed to reach the very top of the developed countries of their regions and the world in less than a lifetime of a single generation. These are just some of the examples that nothing is permanently given and that positive changes are possible if we all work dedicatedly to make them happen.
Our specificity lies in the fact that our human resources are scattered all over the world. Of course, I am talking about Bosnia and Herzegovina's diaspora that emerged from the tragedy and civilizational injustice of the 1990s into a force that has great potential to transform our country. In politics, science, business, culture and sports, we individually have a number of successful individuals, families and companies around the world. The task of this generation is to bind those great soloists into a strong BiH orchestra and help them to transfer the acquired knowledge and understanding, and only then the material resources, to the country where they derive from.
To everyone who is considering investing in Bosnia and Herzegovina today, I wish to say that you are in the right place. This is a country that offers hard-working, educated, warm-hearted and good people, workers and experts. In addition to human resources, we also have natural resources that are largely unused. Wind, sun, hydro potential, ores, biomass, sea and Olympic mountains and forests are inputs that we want to develop on a sustainable basis and with responsible partners. Industries and sectors from primary to tertiary are developing and ready for investment momentum. In addition, let us not forget, our country has a stable monetary and financial sector.
Dear guests,
I want you to exchange business experiences and ideas, create new partnerships, conclude successful projects and build new visions.
I invite all those present, as well as our citizens in the country and diaspora, friends and partners around the world, to invest in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is an investment in the future.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is the country of the future.

title: Address by the Serb member and BiH Presidency Chairwoman Željka Cvijanović at the session of the United Nations Security Council as part of the debate on the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
I thank you, Madam President, for this opportunity to address the Security Council.
I am encouraged to hear so many statements indicating that the governments represented in this meeting all share the same objective—a Bosnia and Herzegovina that is sovereign, independent, stable, functional, and prosperous.
With this shared goal in mind, I would like to emphasize three points that any informed observer must agree are key to accomplishing it.
First, and most important: the only realistic path toward this shared objective is adherence to the Dayton Accords, including the BiH Constitution, which incorporated a formula for power-sharing among the three major constituent peoples in BiH that share a long history of conflict.
The BiH Constitution was carefully designed based on a recognition of this simple reality and established a system with decentralized authority and important power-sharing mechanisms in order to give each of the groups confidence that it will not come under the rule of the other groups. This carefully crafted system has successfully preserved peace in BiH for more than 27 years.
Since the Republic of Srpska, the Entity that has elected me to the BiH Presidency, has been mentioned so many times here, I would like to note that at Dayton the RS agreed with the other parties to be part of a highly decentralized BiH in which all competences belong to the two Entities except for those few competences that the Constitution expressly assigns to BiH-level institutions.
In the decades since the Dayton Accords were signed, BiH has been contorted into a much more centralized system, due almost entirely to foreign interventions, rather than legal, democratic actions.
If we all share the common goal of a sovereign, independent, stable, functional, and prosperous BiH, then the most important thing that the Security Council and its members can do is to support the Dayton Accords by word and deed, and condemn actions that would undo the carefully crafted system of checks and balances guaranteed in the BiH Constitution.
My second point is that, despite some heated rhetoric, the security situation in BiH is, in fact, quite stable, as EUFOR has recently confirmed. BiH is not at all the powder keg it is alleged to be by some who seek more foreign intervention and control over BiH.
It is true that BiH often finds itself in a state of political tension, but that condition is typical among most democracies, including many of those represented here today.
And this brings me to my third point. The primary threat to BiH’s stability does not come from charged political statements, but from the failure to faithfully implement the Dayton Accords. Quite simply, if the deal struck at Dayton is not honored, then there is no hope for BiH’s success.
There are two particularly pernicious ways in which there has been a failure to adhere to Dayton. The first is the illegal transformation of the role of the High Representative from a facilitator into an autocrat with unlimited powers, vastly exceeding the strictly limited mandate agreed in Annex 10 of the Dayton Accords.
The despotic powers claimed by the High Representative are even more expansive than those of a foreign viceroy, as they are asserted to be completely immune from any limitations or oversight whatsoever.
Successive High Representatives, having almost no relevant experience in the region and few relevant credentials for the position, have ruled by decree with no local hearings, no consultation with elected bodies or officials in BiH, and no due process whatsoever—and they have done so with no authority granted by this Council or by any valid legal instrument or international organization.
These dictatorial actions have resulted in a flood of rash, ill-considered, humiliating decrees— more than 460 pieces of legislation and regulations, 110 amendments to Entity constitutions, and 249 extrajudicial punishments of individuals—all with no legal authority or oversight.
Despite widespread agreement—even among former High Representatives—that the High Representative’s claim to rule by decree is utterly illegal, Mr. Christian Schmidt has rashly announced additional disruptive decrees that have infuriated large segments of BiH’s population.
His latest edicts, which purport to amend the criminal codes of both of BiH’s Entities, yet again make a mockery of the rule of law, and represent just the latest brazen usurpation of the democratic rights of the citizens of BiH to rule themselves—rights that this Council is pledged to protect.
Furthermore, shortly before my travels to participate in this meeting, Mr. Schmidt, whose appointment this Council failed to approve, threatened that if I had the nerve to question his legitimacy before this Council, I would receive an answer I would not like. The attitude that Mr. Schmidt has shown toward the elected officials in BiH is, unfortunately, typical of the attitude of too many foreign officials who come and go in BiH.
Their arrogant, dismissive, and disdainful attitude toward legally elected and broadly supported domestic officials and institutions in BiH is, to say the least, unhelpful, and becomes particularly absurd when these officials sharply criticize the Entities for proposing laws mirroring those that have long been in place in these diplomats’ own home countries.
Remarkably, these officials, who work to usurp the constitutional authority of democratically elected officials in BiH on a daily basis, complain when local officials do not bend the knee and honor their illegal assertions of authority, and so we are accused of a “failure to communicate.”
The High Representative’s dictatorial rule is not just patently illegal, but it is also very counterproductive, as has been attested in recent years by former High Representatives.
The OHR’s looming presence and constant attempts to micromanage BiH suffocate the democratic process and hinder the unfettered internal dialogue and reconciliation essential to BiH’s future success.
Indeed, the OHR’s ill-advised interference more often creates rather than solves problems, as demonstrated by the way it has generated and enflamed the controversy regarding ownership of public property.
Initially it was widely accepted that the Constitution left public property to the Entities, an understanding used as the basis for various BiH laws still in force, and upheld by the Constitutional Court. Even statements made or supported by influential foreign officials in 2008 also demonstrated acknowledgement of Entity ownership of public property.
The issue was never in dispute until former High Representative Paddy Ashdown, with his typical imperial attitude, intervened to create the entire controversy. Years later, in 2012, when the parties in BiH agreed to a resolution of the public property issue, the deal was quashed by then-High Representative Valentin Inzko, simply because it was not driven by the OHR and crafted to his liking.
Uncertainty regarding public property, caused solely by OHR meddling, now hinders cooperation and progress in BiH, as the issue has been seized upon by those seeking to further centralize BiH in contravention of the Constitution.
If BiH is ever to be sovereign, independent, stable, functional, and prosperous, then BiH needs to be governed not by unelected foreigners issuing despotic decrees according to their own preferences and prejudices, but by its own Constitution, and its own citizens, in accordance with democratic principles and the rule of law.
The truth of this statement must, I think, be obvious to all members of the Council, but it is perhaps particularly clear to the many countries represented here that have proud histories of freeing themselves from despotic imperial rule by certain foreign powers.
And it must also be acknowledged by the members of this Council that the rule of law needs to be honored not just by local leaders in BiH, but also by those foreign officials that have long been ignoring or even actively subverting the BiH Constitution agreed at Dayton; that have been routinely and cavalierly violating the Vienna Convention’s prohibition against foreign diplomats meddling in local politics, and that have been influencing judicial cases that should be decided only in accordance with the Constitution and proper judicial integrity.
This points to a second important threat to the constitutional order in BiH. Unfortunately, some of the greatest distortions to the constitutional structure of BiH have been caused by the very institution established to uphold it—the BiH Constitutional Court.
The OHR frequently complains that the Court’s rulings are not being respected by the Entities. Тhis same OHR has hypocritically decreed that its own edicts are totally untouchable by the rulings of any court in BiH. Remarkably, the OHR never addresses the reasons why the Court’s decisions are met with skepticism, which is due to the corruption of the judicial process by the interference and influence of the OHR itself, along with that of certain foreign powers, as well as the effective control of the Court by its three foreign judges.
These foreign judges, who were meant to be a part of the Court only for the first five years of its operation, do not live in BiH, have no educational background in the laws of our country, do not speak the local languages, and issue contorted rulings that many agree read like political acts meant to please certain foreign powers rather than soundly reasoned legal determinations.
When a court ignores judicial propriety and the constitutional limits of its own authority, and issues decisions that are ultra vires, that court naturally squanders the respect of the citizens and the other branches of government. And when such decisions are the product of a voting bloc of foreign judges subject to outside influences, it is clear why such decisions lack credibility.
It is in the context of this total usurpation of the democratic process in BiH by outside powers, and the corruption of our judiciary, that so-called “secessionist rhetoric” and other political expressions of extreme frustration in BiH must be understood.
As for the RS, its official policy remains what it has always been: The RS is committed to BiH’s sovereignty and territorial integrity, and to the constitutional order established in the Dayton Accords, and it is committed to peace above all. But it is not ready to accept illegal, despotic rule by high representatives and unconstitutional decisions of the Constitutional court, nor to have its constitutional, democratic rights trampled and be treated as a colonial possession of certain foreign powers.
Somehow the RS has ended up in a sort of Orwellian position where complaints about the distortion and degradation of the Dayton Constitution are said to be anti-Dayton. The hypocrisy of such allegations, coming from some who actively subvert the Constitution agreed at Dayton, is astonishing.
If members of this Council will read the latest report from the OHR in this context, then they may understand that, to many of us in BiH, the report reads like that of a colonial viceroy to the home office, complaining that the locals, who are too ignorant and uncivilized to rule themselves in a constitutional democracy, do not respect and appreciate the benevolent despotism of the viceroy’s overlordship.
And if Council members will read the latest report from the RS, they will see that the RS cannot be accused of being some “renegade state” simply because it calls upon foreign officials to respect international law and the constitutional democratic rights of BiH citizens.
I again thank the members of the Council for their concern about the future of my country. I ask the Council to support BiH by advocating the full implementation of the Dayton Accords as written, and condemn foreign meddling in BiH that undermines the Accords, violates the rule of law, corrupts our judicial system, and hinders political cooperation within BiH.
As the most important concrete steps in this direction, this Council should make clear once and for all that the High Representative does not possess the despotic authority to rule BiH by decree and to confirm that our institutions at all levels of administration are entitled to make decisions in accordance with our Constitution.
I am convinced that BiH can have a successful future if the Dayton Accords are faithfully implemented with the support of this Council.

title: BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić attended the gathering of patriots and citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, organized by the Union of Veterans' Associations of the Patriotic League of Bosnia and He
content:
The theme of the gathering held in the multimedia hall of the Kovači Memorial Centre, where BiH Presidency Member Komšić spoke as the keynote speaker, was "The future of Bosnia and Herzegovina through the prism of the current political and security situation".
Address:
"Ladies and gentlemen, respected comrades, generals, professors,
Thank you for organizing this gathering, it was about time. If nothing else, let's look each other in the eye and, in popular terms, bear our souls. Let's not lie to ourselves, where we are and what we are at this moment.
At the moment, all kinds of things are happening in and around Bosnia and Herzegovina, it's not that it wasn't like that before, but it was in a milder form. Everything was leading to a climax and surely this whole situation will also reach that peak.
I, as a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, will respect this constitution that is currently in force, and as a lawyer I believe that constitutions and laws must be respected, there is no other way. Otherwise, any state and society cannot function. So, this constitution is the framework of our behavior and everything we think we should and everything we plan to do.
This kind of constitutional solution represents a kind of, as people have already said, straitjacket for all those who care about Bosnia and Herzegovina. One should ask what can be done in the given circumstances, and how. The key thing at this moment is to protect our institutions, because that ensures what we had in 1992, when the aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina began, the international legitimacy.
We must not be the ones who'd be degrading or destroying those institutions, regardless of who is at the head of those institutions.
Do you think you can rely on the international community and foreigners? I argue that you cannot. I claim that they act according to the principle of might makes right, that is, whoever is stronger that is the factor being talked with. If you are weak, you are just a dish on the table, you are not a subject of conversation but an object. If you don't believe it, ask the Palestinians. Do not expect from the international community, I will not say miracles, I will say, do not expect anything.
The moment I saw it with my own eyes during the war, when the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Ministry of Interior of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina grew to the point that we were a serious military force, when we started conducting serious offensive combat activities, then we became a factor that is when they wanted to listen to us. When we showed that we were willing to make sacrifices to get what we wanted, then we became a factor whose opinion mattered.
When the Washington Agreement was created, what was happening in the military field? Remember Dayton and what was happening on the military field then. I'm not advocating any military action, I'm just saying how things are going. You have to be strong enough for anyone to respect you.
Why not tell people that we want Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state of equal people? Someone in Washington doesn't like it! I can only be equal if I am within the pack, I want to be human. What should I stand for, that we are an eternally divided society, that they sell me the story of the constituent peoples as a saving solution? Not true! That is what is now proving to be the basis for the disintegration of Bosnia and Herzegovina! That kind of structure provides foundation for the talk of secession and self-determination. Bosnia and Herzegovina existed many, many years before Yugoslavia. Yugoslavia fell apart, Bosnia and Herzegovina survived.
For now, we have to rely entirely on the legal responses to the current situation. Now Dodik has started to raise tension, now he is speaking in front of the president of the neighbouring country, who is smiling at the announcements that he would annex part of the country. He should startle these foreigners, who are urging - don't fight. If he manages to work out some negotiations regarding state assets, he has already climbed a step higher.
What separates Dodik today from the secession of RS? What divides it? One session of the National Assembly of the RS government, one order to the Ministry of Interior of the RS entity, the media that he completely controls anyhow... What are we going to do?
The decision on the use of police units at the cantonal level can be made, but at the FBiH level would be difficult. According to the BiH Constitution, the decision on the use of the BiH Armed Forces cannot be made without the consent of all three members of the BiH Presidency.
What are we going to do, go to the entity line and shoot clay pigeons with shotguns? Don't be ridiculous. What is the answer? I refer again to the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Here, let the Bosnia and Herzegovina's Prosecutor's Office say - he did nothing, that everything is politically legitimate, or arrest him. Just give the prosecutors freedom to practice law freely, and we'll know if we're wrong or if they're wrong. Again, we are being asked to practice false political correctness, not to waver, not to raise our heads, to be silent, to be hypocritical towards ourselves and to say - it's fine, at least there is no shooting. Ask the Palestinians if it's okay when there's no shooting! Why do these foreigners and part of the media see us as a problem?
There is a lot of anti-Islamism in such a relationship towards Bosnia and Herzegovina, and that is why this is the story of the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Hungary. His boss thinks the same, half of Europe thinks the same, at least 30 to 40% of Washington thinks the same. Let's be aware of that. Anyone who says otherwise is lying.
Do you want to know what the big plan is for the Balkans, for Bosnia and Herzegovina? What is Open Balkans, what is the story about changes to the Election Law in BiH? So Tirana, Belgrade, Zagreb. Division of the zone of influence between Albanians and Serbs, i.e. Belgrade and Belgrade. And that's what Rama and Vučić carry. This latter one calls it the 'Serbian world'. It's all the same. Where does that affect us? Through RS. What is the West's response to that? Pull in our ally NATO member and EU member Croatia and fulfill their wish. Give them that Election Law. Why? So that they manage the rest of the country. Why? So if Mile starts to secede, let Croatia defend the Bosniaks in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Why is Vučić arming Serbia? Today, Croatia is acquiring new weapons. Where are our new weapons? Do you think we can get it? When you start that story, they cut you like a sledgehammer. We want to arm ourselves too, but you can't! So it appears we present the danger with what we have, but those countries are not a danger given the fact they are arming themselves.
I am telling you this from the position of one who has been bitten once and is twice shy. I don't want any of this to remain unsaid so that we are in a situation tomorrow to be saying „what are they doing to us?!“ I just want us to be aware of the situation we are in. The answer to that situation at the moment is - we will not make the first wrong step. No, no, no! You will not provoke us to make the first wrong step. We have the wisdom and patience, but you won't make fools of us either. Protect the institutions, demand that the institutions do their job.
And tell them - that fascism that you are carrying out in Europe. Which, because of false political correctness you will not call by its real name, and the real name for fascism in Europe now is actually anti-Islamism, although anti-Semitism has not died either, but fascism in Europe has taken on a new form. Why not tell them that? What's the secret? What do I need, to wait for someone again to come to my front door and take me into the night because of the wrong name and surname? This almost happened to me in 1992 and never again. I will not put myself in that situation again; whoever wants to – be my guest.
This, dear friends, is what Bosnia and Herzegovina is all about. If we show them and tell them that they cannnot, while respecting all the standards that apply in the democratic world, because we are not the ones who will burn down our country. Showing them that we are both wise and smart and that we are aware that they and their policies will pass, but we are also determined to defend this country because we have no other, I have no other! For now, this is a political battle for Bosnia and Herzegovina, there is no retreat, the only way is forward!"

title: BiH Presidency Member Dr Denis Bećirović's speech in Ahmići on the occasion of commemorating the 30th anniversary of the HVO's crimes against the Bosniak population of Ahmići, Donja Večeriska and othe
content:
Honoured families of the martyrs, dear citizens of Ahmići, esteemed reisu-l-ulema of the Islamic community in Bosnia and Herzegovina Husein ef. Kavazovic, distinguished guests from abroad,
Today, we remember with sadness and deep respect the victims of the crime against humanity committed against civilians in Ahmići.
We have no right to forget 116 innocent Bosniak victims, killed in a bloody and criminal campaign by members of the Croatian Defence Council (HVO). Among the innocent victims were 32 women and 11 children under the age of 18. The youngest victim was a three-month-old baby.
The International Tribunal for War Crimes Committed in the Territory of the Former Yugoslavia ruled that the murders in Ahmići were a crime against humanity. One of the organizers and commanders of this crime, convicted war criminal Dario Kordić, was sentenced to 25 years in prison. Unfortunately, not all perpetrators of this heinous crime in Ahmići have been convicted yet.
A crime against humanity has no statute of limitations. We will continue to bear witness to the broken human lives, broken childhoods and stolen hopes of the victims. It is our constant responsibility to convey and preserve the facts about the brutally murdered, but also to ensure a dignified life, truth and justice for the surviving residents of Ahmići.
Final judgments of the highest international courts cannot be obliterated or annulled. The world's highest courts have determined that Bosnia and Herzegovina was attacked and that genocide was committed against Bosniaks. Unfortunately, the threat of repeated crimes and genocide has not been eliminated. Politicians who openly threaten Bosnia and Herzegovina are still on the scene. We have no right to ignore and underestimate these threats.
British soldiers from UNPROFOR played an important role in uncovering the truth about Ahmići. One of the first people to arrive at the scene of the horrific crime was Colonel Bob Stewart. The contribution of this virtuous British officer was important in presenting to the international public the barbarity and brutality of this crime against humanity. Even today, Colonel Stuart is one of the sincere friends of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In the Parliament of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, he advocates a policy of support for the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We send a clear message to Colonel Stuart and other friends around the world: We never forget our friends, we will teach new generations to respect the truth about great and humane people.
It is our permanent obligation to speak the truth and seek justice. Equally, it is our duty to fight for every criminal to be brought to justice. We have no right to give up on conveying and preserving the truth about the suffering of Bosniaks in Ahmići. We will never stop seeking punishment for those who have committed crimes. At the same time, we want to build a life together with all well-intentioned people who are fighting for peace and progress.
The defenders of Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot be equated with those who attacked our country. We were not the same in the 1990s, and we are not the same today. Because we are not the same, we have the human, moral, and civilizational strength to condemn every crime. We are obliged to show respect to every innocent victim, we are obliged to demand the strictest punishment for every criminal.
Evil must not be forgotten nor underestimated.
On 20th of November, 1945, in Nuremberg, the famous American Prosecutor Robert H. Jackson gave one of the most important courtroom speeches in history. On that occasion, he said, inter alia, : "The crimes that we are trying to condemn and punish were so evil and with such a devastating effect that human civilization could not tolerate them, leave them unnoticed, otherwise it would not be able to survive such a repetition".
Even today, in Ahmići, well-intentioned people are obliged to say, like prosecutor Jackson, that we must not forget the evil acts committed in Ahmići because the path from oblivion to repeating the crime is not long.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, we must build a culture of remembrance. It is not a culture of revenge. It is a culture of educating about policies that bring about evil and violence. The purpose of the culture of remembrance is not to create discord and hatred, but to prevent evil and misfortune.
We must affirm the culture of remembrance as a strategy of fighting against forgetfulness. We do not retract with the culture of remembrance. Memory helps us find meaning in the present and answers for the future. That is why the culture of remembrance must never be erased, with its existence we remember all the innocent victims and protect new generations from repeating evil.
The culture of remembrance helps us fight for a democratic society in which there will be no denial, revisionism and negationist rhetoric. Let's not forget, with memory we preserve the dignity of those who are no longer among the living.
Well-meaning people ask the legitimate question: When will we achieve justice and true peace?
Without a statesman like Willy Brandt, there is no real peace in this region. We need leaders who have the strength like Brant who had knelt in the Warsaw Ghetto, to knee down in every place where any innocent person was killed.
Brant's "falling to his knees" should someday be an inspiration for responsible politicians in the former Yugoslavia, for whom, unfortunately, moral lapses are a frequent occurrence, and humane and responsible actions are rare.
We must understand the times in which we live. This is the time of tectonic geopolitical earthquakes, which also greatly affect our country.
Only by being aware and gathered around strategic topics for the future of our homeland, aware of the historical, cultural, moral, spiritual and other values of our country, can we build a society of freedom and equality for all citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Regardless of all the suffering, I believe in the safe future of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We have a future if we teach our children to be smarter and stronger, to love their own and respect others. We must create a democratic and civilized society in which people will be judged on the basis of the human virtues. Building such a society is an obligation and moral-historical debt of both us in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the representatives of the international community.

title: BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić attended tonight the Ceremonial Academy on the occasion of the 31st anniversary of the founding of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the 18th
content:
The member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina addressed a large number of guests at the National Theatre in Sarajevo.
"The times in Bosnia and Herzegovina are the way they are. This day falls at a politically turbulent time. And when we start thinking it can get better, things start going other way round. This day is dedicated to people who have a connection with the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and who today serve in the Second Ranger Regiment.
Everything that the Army, I will say it with immense pride, the magnificent Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina did in the defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina is certainly not only the merit of the fighters. We should not forget the units of the Ministry of Interior of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, all those people who were doing their job, like the medical staff, like the people who worked in the military industry, the people who made sure we had something to eat during the aggression. They can also be seen in that image of the defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina bore the brunt of that fight to the greatest extent possible. When one looks at that time, and how it all came about, from this distance, one wonders if it was possible? That in such a ratio of forces without any structure, except for one part in the Territorial Defence, that such an Army was created and became a political factor. The Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was a magnificent accomplishment of the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The Second Ranger Regiment that inherits the tradition of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina has every reason to be proud of everything it inherits. The function of that regiment within the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina is a guarantee of peace and any stability in Bosnia and Herzegovina. In terms of their numbers, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina are small, in terms of their equipment, they are not up to par with neighbouring countries, but as long as they exist, they are a guarantee of peace. If the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina were to disintegrate, the question is what would happen in Bosnia and Herzegovina. That's why they should be preserved, and lessons from 92-95 should be learned. One of the most important experiences that can be gained from the existence of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina is that you can only rely on yourself. Rely only on yourself. Stay alert, follow what's happening. The history of this country teaches us that almost every generation gets stuck in some conflict, whether it is world conflicts or conflicts that do not have the character of world conflicts. What the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina did, believe it or not, still serves as a basis when we talk about the defence of the country. I wish for you to just read about this experience, learn it, and wish for you to never have to use it.
I know there are those who are disappointed in everything they see today. Back at the end of 1995 and at the beginning of 1996, we had imagined our country to be different to what it is like today. We have reason to be proud of all that we have done. We did our best to defend this country. This is what a living man can be proud of, and the generations after will be able to say that their ancestors managed to defend this small, yet large, suffering, yet rich country that did not deserve all that history, neighbours and the big world players serve it .
Happy anniversary to all of us of the founding of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the Day of the 2nd Infantry Ranger Regiment of the Armed Forces of BiH.

title: Address of the member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dr Denis Bećirović on the occasion of marking the 31st anniversary of the founding of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegov
content:
Respected families of martyrs and fallen members of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina (Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina), respected representatives of veterans' associations, war disabled soldiers, veterans, honourable fighters and war commanders of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, gentlemen soldiers, non-commissioned officers, officers and generals of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, respected representatives of the military-diplomatic corps
I congratulate you on the 31st anniversary of the formation of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina Army and the Day of the 2nd Infantry-Ranger Regiment of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
As a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I express my deep gratitude to those who sacrificed their lives and their health for the defence of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and especially to disabled war veterans, families of martyrs and fallen soldiers, golden lilies and all fighters for their selfless contribution to the defence and building of our state of Bosnia. and Herzegovina.
Thirty-one years ago, the legal Presidency of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina passed the Decree on the formation of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina Army. It is one of the most important decisions in the long history of our country. It turned out that the Freedom Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was the most important historical fact in the centuries-long history of our country.
In the time of the most difficult challenges and temptations, the Army defended the country and freedom. We proudly preserve the tradition of the Freedom Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which defended the multi-ethnic, democratic and indivisible state of Bosnia and Herzegovina of equal citizens and peoples.
The Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina is most deserving of the fact that they defended the results of the legal and internationally recognized referendum for the independent, sovereign and indivisible state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Also, it is most responsible for the fact that our country's admission to the United Nations did not remain a dead letter.
The Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was essentially different from those who attacked Bosnia and Herzegovina. It led a defence-liberation struggle and did not wage war on the territories of other countries, nor for the interests of other countries. With respect for the highest moral and military rules, the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina first achieved a moral and civilizational victory, and then military victories.
The Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina defended universal human values - freedom, equality, equity and independence of the internationally recognized state of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which was subjected to brutal aggression. It protected the vulnerable and the powerless, prevented even greater genocide, guarded and defended kindergardens, hospitals, schools, mosques, churches, synagogues, museums, libraries... People who love Bosnia and Herzegovina can be proud of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The entire democratic world recognized the heroic and righteous struggle of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
On the 9th of May 1995, for the first time in its history, Bosnia and Herzegovina received an invitation to participate in the military parade in Paris on the occasion of the Victory over Fascism Day. The only armed force from our country that received an invitation to participate in the parade was the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is an indelible and permanent recognition of an honorable struggle. It was a global expression of respect for the heroic struggle of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which defended the statehood and freedom of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina in almost impossible conditions. The aforementioned international support is still important in the process of Euro-Atlantic and European integration of our country.
Today, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina are the only legal military force in our country. They are, among other things, in charge and ready to provide military defence to Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as assistance to civil authorities and the population throughout the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina represent the guarantor of security for every human being. The state authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina have clearly defined that our strategic goals are full membership in NATO and the EU.
I would like to thank NATO and our allies for their help and support in strengthening the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the entire security and defence system.
Members of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina also participate in peace support missions. Thanks to the constant progress on this front, today Bosnia and Herzegovina is no longer only a recipient, but also a provider of international military aid. And the units of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina are especially responsible for that.
In the previous months, as a member of the Presidency of the State of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I visited Brussels twice and spoke with the highest NATO and EU officials. Among others, I spoke with NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg, Chairman of the NATO Military Committee, Admiral Rob Bauer and Quinta ambassadors in NATO. Also, in Brussels I spoke with the highest officials of the European Union. It is encouraging that at these meetings the willingness to help Bosnia and Herzegovina on its accelerated path to Euro-Atlantic and European integration was expressed.
At all these meetings, I clearly indicated that NATO and the EU are the strategic goals of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Strategic goals can only be changed in the state institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina. As long as state laws and strategies are in force, all state authorities are obliged to respect them.
Full NATO membership is a guarantee of security for all people. It is the best possible legacy we can leave to our children and future generations. Bosnia and Herzegovina is the only NATO aspiring country that has activated its Action Plan for NATO membership. In addition, our country received candidate status for EU membership.
No destructive rhetoric, no media and political hoaxes, no decisions of any lower level of government in Bosnia and Herzegovina can stop the path of Bosnia and Herzegovina towards NATO and the EU.
Unfortunately, we are once more witnessing anti-Dayton threats to the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Our answer is clear: we will respect the Dayton Peace Agreement, the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the laws of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the final and binding decisions of the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We benevolently recommend destructive politicians who attack the legal order of the country to come to their senses.
Those who may start to unilaterally destroy the constitutional order of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina must be ready to take full responsibility for this kind of destruction.
The message to the separatist politicians is the following: We will never bend the knee. Never! We will fight for the human rights of every person in our country. We will strengthen state institutions. We will strengthen our Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We will protect our country Bosnia and Herzegovina and we will continue our European and Euro-Atlantic path.
Our commitment is peace and security for all people. We will build peace and always be ready to defend the country, identity, honour and dignity. We must be alert and careful.
Let loyalty and devotion to Bosnia and Herzegovina be stronger than personal vanity and party animosities.
The preservation and development of Bosnia and Herzegovina is our debt to those who laid down their lives in defence of our only homeland, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Finally, once again I congratulate one of the greatest dates in our history - the Day of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
May the invincible state of Bosnia and Herzegovina live forever!

title: Address by the Serb member and BiH Presidency Chairwoman Željka Cvijanović at the UN Conference on the Midterm Comprehensive Review of the Implementation of the Objectives of the International Decade
content:
Your excellencies, Distinguished colleagues and guests, It is a privilege to be here today and discuss the topic that is fundamentally important for the whole world, and, one can easily say, for the future of humanity.
I would first like to thank the organizers for the invitation and the opportunity to speak on this occasion.
This is especially because the topic in question, considering its immense importance, can never be given the amount of attention it actually deserves.
The limits of natural resources and their accelerated consumption represent one of the biggest challenges today.
In a world inhabited by more than eight billion people as of the end of last year, the question of resources, their efficient use and equal distribution, emerges as a priority and requires quick responses and sustainable solutions from states, international organizations and other subjects.
The need to find a sustainable solution is all the greater when it comes to a vital, essential and irreplaceable resource such as water—a resource on which human life depends.
To illustrate this, if the entire supply of the world's water were placed in a four liter jug, the drinking water available to us would fit in one spoon.
This additionally points to the obligation of responsible and rational use of water, even in those parts of the world that do not have issues with water shortages.
Water has always been a multidimensional resource, and its utility value has greatly exceeded the role of satisfying basic human needs.
The importance of water for preserving our environment, regulating climate conditions, as well as for sustainable economic development, especially in areas such as agriculture, industry and energy, is immeasurable.
The modernization of the Water Services Sector is a strategic priority of Bosnia and Herzegovina for the environmental sector and an essential step towards the country’s EU integration.
Fundamentally, it is helping the implementation of the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda. In addition, modernization needs of the water sector in BIH require extremely heavy investment. That is also the case with poorer countries, which will need substantive international funding support from the richer countries.
In an effort to ensure the long-term sustainability of supporting activities, in particular infrastructure investments in the sector, major international development partners in the country established the Water Alliance BiH in 2020.
These international development partners are committed to use the Water Alliance BIH as a consultation and coordination platform with a goal to support both entities of BIH in the Modernization of the Water Services Sector.
Through this collective approach, the Water Alliance BIH continues to engage with the authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina and support their commitment to implement the necessary reforms and systemic changes in the Water Services Sector in further alignment with the EU water related legislation.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, in particular, hydropower represents a huge development opportunity, and one of the strategic and still underutilized branches of the economy.
In accordance with this, our development plans for the future are largely based on investments in the energy sector, the importance of which in the global framework is greater today than ever before.
Unfortunately, in Bosnia and Herzegovina, short-sighted political interests sometimes take precedence over elementary economic logic.
That is why many important hydropower projects, that we in Republic of Srpska intend to carry out together with Serbia, are subject to pointless obstructions and blockades by certain political actors.
However, this will not impede our determination to use the hydro potentials which are our great development opportunity and a competitive advantage to the maximum extent, for the common good.
Certainly, the use of hydro potential for development purposes also implies a high level of awareness of the necessity for preserving the environment.
On the path of development, we are obliged to strive to preserve natural resources, because if we endanger our planet, damage the climate and the ecosystems, pollute our seas, rivers and lakes, we will endanger our own existence.
The scarcity of water, its pollution and floods in many parts of the world contribute to the fact that water-related risks have been at the top of the list of the biggest global challenges for years.
About one fourth of the world's population still does not have access to safely managed drinking water services, while almost four billion people, or virtually half of our population, do not have safely managed sanitation services.
The data from UNICEF, according to which in 2015 around three hundred thousand children under the age of five died from poor sanitary conditions, poor hygiene and inadequate drinking water. This is devastating and terrible!
We cannot ignore such horrible tragedies that happen throughout the world every day.
This is not a challenge that individual countries can overcome independently.
It is thus necessary to make additional joint efforts so that in the coming years all people have access to drinking water, as well as appropriate sanitary conditions.
It is very important that today, on World Water Day, we also have the opportunity to discuss these challenges, because I am aware that numerous human lives, and in the long term, the fate of our planet, rest on overcoming them.
If there is a goal that should unite us, regardless of all other global challenges, differences and rivalries, it is the provision of a sufficient amount of water, as well as adequate sanitary conditions for all people in the world.
Thank you for your attention and for all you do on this issue!

title: The speech given by the Serb member and BiH Presidency Chairwoman Željka Cvijanović at the Summit of the Non-aligned Movement Contact Group in Azerbaijan on the subject “The Non-aligned Movement in th
content:
Honorable representatives and distinguished colleagues, I am honored to have the opportunity to address you at this important gathering. First, I would like to express my gratitude for the invitation to the President of Azerbaijan and the Chairman of the Non-Aligned Movement, Mr. Aliyev.
It is a true privilege to be here today and discuss many important issues, not only at a symbolic level, but concretely, through the idea of partnership and solidarity.
This gathering is happening at a time, just like in the period when the Movement was formed, when the world desperately needs peace, relaxation, dialogue, and restraint from the intent to make an existing problem bigger.
The global challenges we currently face point to the importance of respecting the timeless and universal values and principles based on which the Non-Aligned Movement was founded and rests today.
The world we live in is changing at a dramatic pace and, unfortunately, not in a positive direction.
The corona virus pandemic has left serious and long-term consequences throughout the world.
They primarily include lost human lives, and besides in medicine and health care, they are visible in almost every other segment of society, too.
Due to the pandemic, economic challenges have become even more complex and multiplied, both globally and in individual countries, especially in the poor ones.
At the height of the pandemic, the differences between developed and underdeveloped countries were especially pronounced, in terms of access and distribution of medical supplies, such as respirators and medical protection equipment, or the vaccines in the later phase.
The principles of solidarity and mutual assistance retreated before the fear of an invisible enemy that spread at a tremendous speed, defying all the restrictive measures introduced by the authorities throughout the world to preserve their populations.
However, there were also positive examples, such as the actions of those countries and international organizations that offered their assistance to the most vulnerable.
As a representative of an observer country, I want to praise the role of the Non-Aligned Movement, which was then, and still is, at the center of multilateral efforts aimed at overcoming the negative effects of the corona virus.
Unfortunately, the period of gradual recovery, which followed the stabilization of the epidemiological situation in the world, was marked by new global security challenges, armed conflicts, and the dramatic sharpening of geopolitical rivalries.
So it sometimes seems that the post-covid recovery, like many other important topics in the previous year, has gone to the background, at least as far as the media and their focus are concerned.
Yet, the lack of media interest does not mean that these challenges have disappeared or diminished.
That is why I consider it very important that within this summit we have the opportunity to draw the attention of the international public to the problem of post-covid recovery, as well as to the importance of making additional efforts to overcoming negative effects of the pandemic.
That task is not easy at all, considering the complex circumstances and the huge mess the world is in at this moment.
War, sanctions and terrorist attacks demonstrate that the language of force and weapons has prevailed over diplomacy and dialogue, and sometimes, it seems, over reason itself.
And while people get killed, a huge part of the world has turned into cheerleader camps that are putting out a fire with gasoline.
In the spiral of violence and war hysteria, those who appeal for peace and dialogue, refusing to align themselves with one of the opposing camps, are viewed with suspicion, almost with hostility.
As you know, three decades ago a bloody civil war raged in the territory of the former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, one of the founders of the Non-Aligned Movement.
Especially tragic was the conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina in which almost 100,000 people died.
Unfortunately, we know very well what war is and what sanctions are and what consequences they bring, because we still feel them today, 28 years after the end of the armed conflict.
That is why we sincerely sympathize with and mourn every lost life in Ukraine and in other parts of the world because we know that they are not numerical data but human beings whose lost lives caused deep wounds to their forever forlorn families.
The tragedy we went through compels us to talk about it from a human and humanitarian point of view, with the full awareness that the price of war is enormous, just like the importance of peace.
And especially at this very place, because the principles on which the Non-Aligned Movement was founded are the only possible path to peace and long term stabilization of the current geopolitical and security challenges.
The world urgently needs a reaffirmation of the principles of peaceful coexistence between countries and peoples, mutual respect for sovereignty and territorial integrity, and non-interference in the internal affairs of other countries.
Within the collective three-partite Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I strongly advocate these values, as well as the consistent respect for the domestic and international rule of law.
International law was not established to be a dead letter or a buffet from which everyone, on a case-by-case basis, takes what suits them.
It was defined as universal, with the clear intent that it should be respected equally by all entities, regardless of size, population, and their military or economic power.
The consequences of the collapse of the global order based on international law are instability and anarchy, in which no one wins in the long term, and everyone loses, to a greater or lesser extent.
I am convinced that, among us here, there is a high degree of agreement regarding the fundamental values on which the international order should stand, among which peace, stability and cooperation are among the most important.
I am pleased that, as a representative of an observer country, I am attending, for the first time, the gathering of the countries of the Movement that has shown the ability to survive and maintain its importance in spite all global changes.
The fact is that the circumstances - in which it arose in 1961 in Belgrade, the capital of the SFRY, and today the capital of Serbia - are different, but not entirely incomparable to the current ones.
It is also the fact that many non-aligned countries, then poor, have managed to change from undeveloped into developed, modern countries.
This is exactly why the countries of the Movement represent an excellent framework for a new economic cooperation, and thus it is important to rehabilitate economic and business contacts between them.
Both then and today, the Non-Aligned Movement strives to preserve the international balance, affirm cooperation and mutual respect in the bilateral relations of its members, but also in the global order.
That is why I am convinced that our tradition of non-alignment, founded on the legacy of SFRY foreign policy, can be a strong bridge of cooperation and understanding in the future, both through strengthening of bilateral relations with the member countries of the Non-Aligned Movement, and through participating in multilateral initiatives of general, global importance.
We have many common challenges, whether it is the post-covid recovery or the current insecurity and geopolitical turbulence.
Therefore, I believe that we can also jointly reach certain conclusions that could contribute to overcoming these challenges.
Thank you.

title: The address by Dr. Denis Bećirović on the occasion of the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Esteemed excellencies, eminences, distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen, First of all, at the beginning of my address, I would like to express my special gratitude to the anti-fascists of Bosnia and Herzegovina from the last two wars, who are most responsible for the fact that we have a state today and that we can celebrate the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The first of March is among the five most significant dates in the millennial history of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The first such date is the year 949, when the Byzantine emperor Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus published his famous work "De administrando imperio" (On the Administration of the Empire), in which the existence of the "land of Bosnia" is mentioned for the first time in a written historical source.
The second date is 29th of August, 1189, the day when the famous ruler of Bosnia, Ban Kulin, issued a charter guaranteeing Dubrovnik merchants freedom of movement and trade in Bosnia. It is the oldest preserved Bosnian state diplomatic document found, written in the Old Bosnian language and in the Bosnian script, “bosančica”. From a legal point of view, it can be stated that Kulin's charter is the "birth certificate" of Bosnian statehood and irrefutable proof that Bosnia had an organized state and the institution of a sovereign ruler in the 12th century.
The third date is the 25th of November, 1943, when Bosnian statehood was restored at the First Session of ZAVNOBiH.
The fourth date is the 1st of March, 1992, when, in a legal and democratic referendum, over 64% of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina voted for an independent, sovereign and unified Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The fifth date is the 22nd of May, 1992, when the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was admitted to full membership of the United Nations.
These five dates in the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina should be written in capital and golden letters, for children to learn in schools, for important cultural and public institutions and other important objects to be named after them, and for every citizen of Bosnia and Herzegovina to be proud of, regardless of ethnic, religious, political or ideological affiliation.
Unfortunately, the big-state protagonists are trying to deprive our state of Bosnia and Herzegovina of its right to exist.
They are trying to steal and reshape our history and literature. They do not respect our national sovereignty. They deny our ethnic and linguistic identity, and abuse our right to religious identity. They are stealing Bosnia and Herzegovina's talents in sports, science and many other fields.
Despite all that, they fail to break the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It has not been permanently subdued by much stronger forces in the last thousand years. Bosnia and Herzegovina has always had its sons and daughters, who protected it. That's how it was and that's how it will stay.
Because of irresponsible individuals who interpret the principle of self-determination without arguments, we must clearly answer the question: what is the "right to self-determination of the people" and how is it realized?
Even Slobodan Milošević did not know the answer to it when in 1991 he appointed the so-called Badinter's commission. His question then read: "Does the Serbian population in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, as one of the constituent nations of Yugoslavia, have the right to self-determination?" The arbitration commission gave its answer in the form of an "opinion". It was difficult for the followers of big-state politics to learn that all international instruments related to the principle of equality and self-determination of peoples should be understood first of all in a territorial sense and not in a strictly ethnic sense.
Unfortunately, once again on the political scene we have followers of Slobodan Milošević's big-state politics.
They still do not accept the fact that the principle of self-determination is in permanent conflict with the principle of political independence of existing states in the world. Namely, if all "nations" resorted to this right, the territorial integrity and borders of many states would be called into question.
The General Assembly of the United Nations has precisely determined that the right to self-determination must never be understood as approving or encouraging activities that would threaten, in whole or in part, the territorial integrity or political unity of states. That is why, among other things, the secession of Bosnia and Herzegovina's entity of RS is impossible. because the population of one part of the independent, sovereign and indivisible state of Bosnia and Herzegovina will never be able to decide the fate of the entire population of our state.
Never! Let separatist-oriented politicians remember that well.
The Dayton Peace Agreement confirmed the independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity and state continuity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Today, Bosnia and Herzegovina is a candidate for membership in the European Union and a country about to join NATO.
Before our country are important and demanding stages of the process of European and Euro-Atlantic integration. Bosnia and Herzegovina should be helped to build functional state institutions, capable of taking responsibility for the accelerated movement of our country towards membership in the EU and NATO.
Unfortunately, the continuous and systematic attempts to weaken and destroy the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina have not stopped.
During the period of aggression, it was carried out by mass killings, expulsions, crimes against humanity and genocide. Today, that goal is being implemented through a systematic blockade of the state, attempts to weaken and collapse state institutions.
The ultimate goal of the destructive forces is the division of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state. The direction of those projects will not change in the coming years either. There are no serious arguments or assumptions that this can change in a short period of time.
It is no secret that in our country there are destructive politicians who openly advocate the destruction of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the peace process.
I deliberately connect the preservation of the state and the peace process because only the malicious and naive can even think that it is possible to destroy the legal order of our country and not threaten stability and peace in the entire region.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is not an isolated island. We are inextricably linked to the democratic and free world.
Today, when we celebrate our national holiday, we should also remember our friends who are going through difficult times.
Today, as we celebrate our national holiday, we should also remember our friends who are going through difficult times.
Once again, I express my deepest condolences and solidarity with the brotherly people of the Republic of Turkey, which was hit by devastating earthquakes. I also express my condolences and solidarity to the people of Syria. I am especially proud of our rescue teams who saved twenty-six lives. They are the pride and mirror of the brave and charitable Bosnia and Herzegovina. I am also proud of all Bosnians and Herzegovinans who once again showed that they have big charitable hearts.
Tonight I also express solidarity with the brave President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky and the freedom-loving people of Ukraine. We are on the side of Ukraine and the free world. We are not neutral and indifferent to the sufferings of the people of Ukraine because neutrality is another name for supporting Putin's regime.
Ladies and gentlemen,
