at the end of the address, I would like to emphasize that there is no issue that is politically, morally and existentially more important than the issue of preserving the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Let's suppress party and local politics in favour of state politics.
Let loyalty and attachment to Bosnia and Herzegovina be stronger than personal vanity and animosity.
Let's determine a red line below which one cannot go at the state level.
We are not silent in the face of injustice.
Let's not agree to division and discrimination.
Let's not respond to provocations with hatred and destruction.
Let us respond with love and by building kindergartens, schools, colleges, factories, libraries and apartments for young married couples.
It is the best answer to the politics of destruction and division.
Bosnians and Herzegovinans, in the country and abroad,
Happy Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: The speech by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić at the reception marking the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
At the beginning of tonight's address, I would like to greet our brave Bosnians and Herzegovinians who are here with us tonight.
These are the people who, with their charitableness, self-sacrifice and kind heart, extended a hand of salvation to the unfortunate population of the Republic of Turkey, who suffered in the catastrophic earthquakes.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is proud of you. All of us together showed solidarity with the affected population of the Republic of Turkey, but those of you who went to the scene did the hardest job.
Thank you! Thank you for selflessly contributing to Bosnian-Herzegovinian society with your daily activities in solving difficult and unforeseen situations.
Dear Excellencies,
ladies and gentlemen, citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina...
Exactly thirty-one years ago, with the declaration of citizens in a referendum, Bosnia and Herzegovina began its struggle for independence and sovereignty, which is still ongoing.
Opponents of the independence and existence of Bosnia and Herzegovina did not achieve their goals even with armed aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina, an internationally recognized state. Bosnia and Herzegovina has survived in its recognized international borders, despite everything, and even despite the so-called the international community.
The armed aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina did stop with the signing of the Dayton Peace Agreement, but the political one is still ongoing. From this follows the logical conclusion that the struggle for independence and sovereignty is still ongoing.
The outlines of that struggle in the last years, and even in the last months, are particularly visible. Unfortunately, our country is now faced not only with the big-state aspirations of its neighbours and their, I would say, traditional attempts to divide Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also with inappropriate foreign interventionism that may have seemed confusing, strange, almost unbelievable to us at first. So confusing, strange and unbelievable that even many did not want to believe their eyes. Then the logical questions appeared, all of a sudden, although it is not really all of a sudden, because let’s remember the experience of the war, where did the human rights, equality, democratic standards, democracy in general disappear? Where did the international support for the sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina disappear, to now allow those false friends to be taking a measured cut with our neighbours.
The nature of that interventionism and the solutions that are trying to be imposed are contrary to all democratic standards, but also contrary to the March 1 determination of Bosnians and Herzegovinans on the equality of all citizens and peoples living in this country. The manner in which these solutions are being imposed, despite the will of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, is brazen and rude.
Basically, they deny the assumption of any independence and sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state. The citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina for the most part view such treatment of Bosnia and Herzegovina with displeasure. Such political activity will no doubt one day find itself on the wall of shame and judged by history. Unfortunately, sometimes things in Bosnia and Herzegovina look like a slightly dressed up, made-up replay of the cruel and bloody reality and events that we have already gone through in the war!
Let's just remember the arms embargo against the defenders of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the cowardly instigation of the division of the country through the so-called peace plans and negotiations. Today, they offer us an embargo on democracy and respect for basic human rights, supposedly conciliatory agreements and plans that ultimately lead to the complete dismantling of Bosnian-Herzegovinian society with a certain division of the country as the end result. However, this is not at all a reason for any kind of pessimism, let alone defeatism.
The struggle for independence and sovereignty in the period from 1992 to 1995 was a general struggle of people who have no other homelands, people who only defend their own, and do not reach out for other people's homeland. That struggle was brought forward by the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, members of all its ethnic, religious or other identities, and not by our false friends.
Even today's sincere advocacy for the independence and sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina is above all a matter of conviction and awareness of Bosnians and Herzegovinians, who have no dilemma as to what and whose Bosnia and Herzegovina is.
Only those who identify with Bosnia and Herzegovina participated in the armed struggle, that is, the defence of the independence and sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and those who do not identify with Bosnia and Herzegovina attacked it.
Of course, even today we cannot rely on those who do not identify with Bosnia and Herzegovina, but neither can we rely on those who put the sign of equality between these two categories, justifying such a position with alleged political correctness, as they like to call it. This sign of equality is also put by some foreign officials who tell us that for the survival and vitality of Bosnia and Herzegovina it is of crucial importance that they manage the places of decision-making, and that we should believe that they care more about Bosnia and Herzegovina than ourselves.
This is exactly the kind of order that has been established in Bosnia and Herzegovina today. Such an order is directed against the independence and sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is such that it cannot be called by other words than the ones that I will not utter for the sake of the solemnity of this moment.
However, as I have already said, this is certainly not the reason for any kind of defeatism and pessimism, but quite the opposite, the reason for struggle. It is good that certain illusions have finally been lifted. It is good that we finally know who is in favour of real independence and sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and who thinks that our legislation should be decided by foreigners and the governments of neighbouring countries. It's good that we finally determined the place where we meet, but also the place where we diverge.
Therefore, freed from those illusions, we should not and cannot be sad nor depressed, but rather joyful. Glad that the fog has cleared and we can see clearly who is who. Joyful because we finally know who, in the current and future struggles for independence and sovereignty, we can count on and who we can't count on, and finally joyful because we know that it is not the mass of undecideds who waver that wins, but those who are determined and who know what they want.
We will continue to fight for independence both legally as we do, and politically, but also in every other way because we no longer have a choice. Once we step in, there is no going back.
No one who has won freedom gives it up voluntarily. Sometimes it seems to us that they would leave us alone if we gave up our independence. They wouldn't, they would just persecute us even worse. Those who think today that they will leave them alone, if they submit to them, are seriously mistaken, they will be persecuted even more.
Those who know whose Bosnia and Herzegovina is will win, and it is ours and only ours. Those who are determined, not those who find themselves in the sea of false dilemmas. Those who fully identify with Bosnia and Herzegovina will win, because they know what kind of Bosnia and Herzegovina they want. Free and democratic, country of equal people, country of order and human rights!

title: Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željko Komšić gave a pertinent speech tonight at the central ceremony on the occasion of celebrating the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina,
content:
Dear Bosnians and Herzegovinans! Thirty-one years ago, due to the dissolution of the former common state, a referendum on the independence of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was organized in the Socialist Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The referendum was preceded by numerous political events both internationally and domestically. And while the separatists were already trying to create a political and legal basis for separatism through illegal and legally void plebiscites, the forces loyal to the Republic, on the international level, were trying to gain support for the organization of the referendum. They succeeded in that, so the referendum was called based on the findings of the Badinter Commission.
At the referendum on independence, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina overwhelmingly chose the path of independence, exercising their democratic right. Immediately after the announcement of the results, Chetnik separatists organized through paramilitary formations began obstructing normal and everyday life in the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and soon they were joined by the Yugoslav People's Army and the formed para-institutions that were created by the division of the security agencies of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Many times, better armed separatist forces together with the Yugoslav National Army, realizing that they cannot prevent the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which was already officially recognized by the leading countries of the world at the beginning of April, embark on an armed aggression against the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This aggression began with mass crimes in Eastern Bosnia, the attempt to seize the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina in early May 1992, and a series of massacres of the civilian population in cities throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina.
However, Bosnia and Herzegovina was admitted to the United Nations on 22nd of May. That act put an end to the issue of international recognition of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bosnia and Herzegovina gained international recognition as a member of the United Nations, but at the same time Bosnia and Herzegovina was punished by the same United Nations by introduction of an embargo on the import of weapons, which made it difficult, almost impossible, for the defenders of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina to defend the Republic, and the perpetrators of genocide and those who committed ethnic cleansing with the help of neighbouring Serbia, and a year later Croatia, were given an additional wind at the back.
This put the aggressors against Bosnia and Herzegovina in such a better position militarily, that it is simply unbelievable from a military point of view that they did not manage to completely destroy Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state, considering the advantage they had in weapons, but also the support they received by a significant part of the international community, which viewed the extermination of an entire nation and the destruction of an internationally recognized state quite favourably. All the hypocrisy of politics, as well as false sympathy for the weak, came to the fore in that first year of aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Instead of, as is the case with Ukraine today, the defenders of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina were provided with weapons in order to be able to defend themselves against aggression, we were forced not only to deal with the consequences of the introduction of the embargo, but we were also forced to negotiate numerous ostensibly peace plans that were nothing more than proposals to divide the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with the prospect of its complete shutdown.
We should never forget that the most shells fell on the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina on the very day when the so-called Owen - Stoltenberg's plan to divide Bosnia and Herzegovina into three republics was negotiated in Geneva. All this was by no means accidental. They wanted to force us to capitulate in that way as well. We were about to be faced with a choice, either we will sign what is completely acceptable to the aggressor, or we will pay with our lives for rejecting that dishonourable offer. It is understandable that it was not easy for those who made those decisions. It was also not easy for us who, with a rifle in our hand, asked for the fight to continue, but we persevered. We did not capitulate.
Of course, we should not forget, especially when we see what is happening today on the political level, the following. It must not be forgotten that Lord Owen, in that most difficult time in 1993 when he was trying to gain support for his plan to divide Bosnia and Herzegovina, was the one who took Fikret Abdić with him during the negotiations and showed him as a cooperative and good boy who is ready to agree to many concessions that the legal representatives of the authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina could not agree to.
Unfortunately, even today, some new "Lord Ovens" are looking for new Fikret Abdić. Their political methodology is the same. Their targets are the same, and even those behind them are the same. Where did they come from and why do they still exist? They exist because the aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina has never stopped. The forces that attacked Bosnia and Herzegovina did not come to terms with its independence and sovereignty. They will still continue to attack. We can defend ourselves only if we defend ourselves with the courage with which we defended ourselves in the period from 1992 to 1995.
In this fight, we can and must rely on ourselves first. If we hope for the help of others, and if we are passive, we ourselves will question the survival of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I am convinced that we will not be passive, and that we will not idly wait for the situation to unfold. Bosnia and Herzegovina is the country of those who identify with it. Anyone who does not identify with Bosnia and Herzegovina is not someone who can be relied on. We don't need to beg anyone for love for our country anymore, because we have enough of that. And this gathering here shows us that love for the homeland is not lacking at all. The enemies of Bosnia and Herzegovina must know and will know that we will never lack the courage to defend Bosnia and Herzegovina from all attempts to threaten it. That is why we recommend to them the peace which we sincerely desire and which we now enjoy.
However, peace can only be preserved by those who are ready to fight for what they consider their greatest value at any moment. Bosnia and Herzegovina is our greatest value and measure of things.
Cheers, and a warm welcome to you all. Happy Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: The speech given by the Serb member and BiH Presidency Chairwoman Željka Cvijanović at the Christmas reception
content:
Dear attendees, Ladies and gentlemen, Brothers and sisters, I am immensely happy that we are gathered tonight on the occasion of the most joyous Christian holiday - Christmas.
The light of the birth of Jesus Christ has illuminated our homes and the hearts of all Orthodox believers, both here and in the world.
That's why I want us to share the joy and light of Christmas together this year and also, from this place, to send messages of peace, love and goodwill.
Peace and love are the fundamental messages of Christmas, but also universal and timeless values on which social communities and human civilization as a whole rest.
Their absence is the cause of many misunderstandings, conflicts and wars, some of which, unfortunately, we are still witnessing today.
The impressive technological development of humanity in recent decades, unfortunately, has not been accompanied by an equivalent moral maturity.
Lasting peace remained an ideal and an unattainable dream that was denied in practice by harsh reality.
Just like in families, the lack of dialogue and conversation between peoples and countries around the world leads to misunderstandings and rising of tensions.
Conversely, where there is honest and open dialogue, regardless of mutual disagreements, peace will never be questioned.
It is a clear signpost for everyone, but especially for us in this region, who well remember the tragic period when words fell silent and weapons spoke.
That is why there is no greater duty, individual and collective, secular and religious, than preserving peace in international and interpersonal relations.
It is necessary for us in Bosnia and Herzegovina also to talk and conduct a dialogue about all the open issues that weigh on our everyday life.
To respect each other, respect the diversity of identities and interests, looking for common ones on the basis of which we will build a better and more successful future.
The common obligation of all of us is to provide the generations to come with a safe and stimulating environment for development and prosperity.
And that they are never faced with the existential challenges faced by ours, as well as many previous generations in these areas.
We live in a country of diversity, but we still cannot say that we are, as the slogan of the European Union promotes, "United in Diversity".
In order to achieve that goal, we need peace and stability, as well as more orderly relations at the level of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is necessary that, instead of international interventionism, national institutions at all levels of government take full responsibility for the processes in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We are not against the constitutional BiH, as foreseen by the Dayton Peace Agreement.
We are legalists and we believe that without full respect for the Constitution, the highest legal and political act, the rule of law remains just a dead letter on paper.
This is why we think that BiH can be possible to the extent that everyone respects the letter of the Constitution, and then also each other.
We do not wish to live in a country of blockades and obstructions, but in a country where every nation and every entity will be able to express its full capacity and its ability to progress, because no one has the right to block economic development, energy stability and new jobs.
Especially in today's world where every megawatt of electricity, barrel of oil and cubic meter of gas is vital.
"Glory to God in the highest heaven, and on earth peace among those whom he favours!" (Luke 2:14)
Nothing so simple, divine and human illustrates the essence of Christmas as the words of this angelic song.
With immense gratitude that you graced tonight's reception with your presence on the occasion of the most joyous Christian holiday, I greet you all with a traditional Christmas greeting:
Peace of God! Christ is born!
Thank you!

title: The speech by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić at the event “The January 9 - the path to Genocide”
content:
Dear citizens, professors, scientists, It is my pleasure to have the opportunity to be the keynote speaker at the scientific meeting " January 9 - the road to genocide".
The January 9 1992 cannot be viewed outside of two contexts, legal and political, which are unified in the idea of the genocidal intent of the Greater Serb policy in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The road to genocide is precisely the unity of attempts to undermine the constitutional and legal order of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and attempts to completely exterminate Bosniaks, Croats and others who do not belong to the Serb people from the most of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Of course, here I will leave it to historians to clarify the historical context of what preceded that January 9, 1992. I will use the opportunity to briefly refer to the political goal of what was proclaimed through the declaration on the proclamation of the so-called Republic of the Serb people in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Although that declaration on the proclamation was, even at that moment, a legally void document, which failed to prevent the legal authorities of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina from calling a referendum on independence, it has political significance, precisely from the aspect of the political goal that was not realized, even with the use of genocidal violence.
Namely, on January 9, 1992 in Sarajevo, the so-called Assembly of the Serb People proclaimed the Republic of the Serb People of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which according to that proclamation is part of the Federal State of Yugoslavia, as its federal unit.
We all know that the declaration of this illegal and unconstitutional assembly did not receive any international support, and that the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina voted for the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina in a referendum.
The only way for part of Bosnia and Herzegovina to remain part of the Federal State of Yugoslavia, as its federal unit, was for the advocates of that policy, faced with legal defeat, to use genocidal violence.
That process, which had as its goal the destruction of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina and its entire peoples, began on January 9, but did not result in parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina belonging to another state, i.e. Serbia.
When the authorities of the RS entity today mark the anniversary of January 9, they simultaneously cover up the fact that the Great Serbian regime of Milosevic and Karadzic, even with the help of genocide, did not succeed in making part of Bosnia and Herzegovina part of Serbia. The RS is an entity in the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, not a federal unit within Serbia. That part of Bosnia and Herzegovina will never become part of Serbia, because the actors of that policy in the period from 1992 to 1995, when they had absolute military superiority, especially when it comes to resources, I would say, missed the opportunity to seize part of Bosnia and Herzegovina. They were stopped in this, with the great sacrifices and heroism of the members of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the MUP (Ministry of Internal Affairs) of the RBiH, as well as the people who stood by them.
Nevertheless, we are witnesses that the continuation of the genocidal policy, cherishing what is the spirit of January 9, and its spirit is nothing but crime, are parading again today and trying to send a message that they have not given up on seizing a part of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The way they do it and the place where they do it do not allow me to agree with the assessments of certain levels of government and responsible persons who claim that such events do not threaten the security situation.
A satisfactory security situation is not an expression of the cessation of hostilities, but of the overall political and social environment, which is far from satisfactory, and therefore I use this opportunity to call for caution when it comes to assessing the security situation.
The goal of the January 9 parade by the authorities of the smaller BiH. entities is evoking memories of committing genocide, which they are proud of, intimidating the people, but also raising their own prices, first of all with foreigners, who are always in such and similar situations, ready to run to us who are for the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, regardless of who at that moment is in the government, and always with the same question, with the question of what we can give to Dodik and the separatists in order to preserve stability and peace.
However, in this regard, I think it is finally time for us all to say together that we cannot and will not give anything to Dodik and the separatists, because they have too much anyway.
Dodik does not have the Yugoslav People's Army and its arsenal behind him, he does not have the numerous paramilitary formations that his ideological and political predecessor Radovan Karadžić had, and it is not wise for him to provoke a conflict in which the loss of what was gained through genocide is possible.
I am convinced that the authorities of the RS entity are also aware of these facts, just as it is clear that Dodik must not gamble. That what he is allowed to do is to provoke in the hope that we will forever seek protection from the non-existent international community, which will then do everything to calm down the separatists in RS.
That is why I stand by the fact that in the future we should not ask for any help from foreigners in curbing Dodik's separatism, because so far it has proved to be a complete failure, and we have usually received their rhetorical condemnations, in the form of demands that on some other issues from of state importance be lenient.
We are already a bit tired of empty declarative condemnations, and hypocritical announcements in which all parties are called to lower tensions, while it is clear that not all parties raise tensions, and we do not place any hope in empty rhetoric that equates those who attack the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all others.
However, what we are sure of is that we will defend this country at all costs in the event of a secession attempt. The goals from the declaration of January 9, according to which part of Bosnia and Herzegovina should have been annexed to Serbia, will never be realized. We will never give up on Bosnia and Herzegovina. We didn't give up even when the arms embargo was introduced, and we are not giving up even today when the democracy embargo is being introduced.

title: Speech by BiH Presidency Member Dr. Denis Bećirović at the Panel of Experts "January 9
content:
Ladies and gentlemen, Respected families of victims of genocide, Dear guests, Esteemed colleague Komšić,
At a time when separatist political circles are sending out various and numerous untruths, falsifications and hoaxes, it is very important to use science and scientific facts to oppose genocide deniers. I believe that Panel of Experts, such as this one today, are very important because they provide a scientific valorization of undeniable facts and contribute to a comprehensive overview of our past from historical, legal, sociological, psychological, demographic and other aspects.
In 1992, the highest legal act of Bosnia and Herzegovina did not prescribe any right to self-determination for ethnic communities in Bosnia and Herzegovina. That is why the anti-constitutional gathering of part of the renegade members of the Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina on January 9, 1992 was an act of lawlessness and violence against the legal order. The Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in its decision of September 15, 1992, evaluated the proclamation of the so-called of Republic of Serb Bosnia and Herzegovina as an anti-constitutional act. The same position was adopted by the Badinter Commission of the European Union in 1992.
The criminal policy of separating the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina and creating a parastate on the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, designed and led from Belgrade, was in contradiction with the domestic legal system and international law. That is why the so-called Republic of Serb People in Bosnia and Herzegovina/Republika Srpska was a dead creation and the international community never accepted it as an independent international subject.
Today's marking of January 9 in the BiH entity RS represents a violation of the Dayton Peace Agreement, the Constitution of BiH, the final and binding decisions of the legal Constitutional Court of BiH.
At the 96th plenary session of October 11 and 12, 2013, the Venice Commission adopted an opinion on the compliance of the elections of the BiH entity RS with the anti-discriminatory standards of the Council of Europe, ie the European Convention on the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. The commission concluded that the celebration of January 9 as the day of BiH entity of RS, is a discriminatory act against other peoples in that part of Bosnia and Herzegovina and that it is not in accordance with the basic democratic values and postulates. Such a policy is not in line with values such as dialogue, tolerance, mutual understanding and equality, which should be the basis for choosing the entity day, the Venice Commission assessed.
In its final and binding decisions, the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina ruled that the celebration of RS Day is unconstitutional and contrary to Article II/4 of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the norms of a constitutional nature: Article 14 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, Article 1. Protocol No. 12 to the Convention, and the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.
It is high time that the officials of the BiH entities of RS and Serbia stop their anti-Dayton activities, as well as their immoral and anti-civilizational policy of denying the judicially and scientifically proven genocide against Bosniaks. It is time for them to start respecting the judgments of international and domestic courts.
Let's not forget, the planners and performers of the criminal policy of destroying the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina were sentenced to more than a thousand years in prison at the Hague Tribunal and courts in Bosnia and Herzegovina and abroad. Therefore, the glorification of the dark politics that committed the only genocide in Europe after the Second World War represents an unacceptable act of insult and provocation for the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the European Union and the United Nations.
The genocide against Bosniaks is not a historical accident. It is the result of planned and organized actions of Greater Serbia ideology, politics, media, army, police and other factors. The crime of genocide against Bosniak population could not have been carried out without genocidal intent, system and planning engagement of numerous institutions.
We have to be careful. Genocide is repeatable. Ideology, politics, media and other factors that led to the genocide of Bosniaks are still active and dangerous. The threat of a new genocide has not been eliminated. The planners and perpetrators of genocide have only respect for those who are trained to defend themselves and who show a desire to defend themselves. It is a lesson we must learn well.
In the interest of peace and a secure future, court rulings must not be archived and forgotten. The international community, in the interest of all humanity, should and must send a global message that the results of genocide, crimes against humanity and other crimes cannot and must not be recognized permanently. It is high time for the international community to stop destructive policies that glorify legally convicted war criminals.
The Hague Tribunal is not a political court but a legal court of the United Nations. Only political advocates of criminal politics can be against the courts of the United Nations. If it were not for the Hague Tribunal, no one in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region would be held accountable for the genocide and the most terrible crimes committed in Europe after the Second World War.
Permanent and indelible international court rulings cannot be hidden or denied. Important lessons for the future must be drawn from these judgments. Denial and futile running away from the truth will not help anyone. That's why everyone should face the truth and turn a new page in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region.
Today we express our solidarity with Ukraine's just fight against brutal Russian aggression. We belong to a free and democratic part of the world. The award given by the president of Bosnia and Herzegovina of RS entity to Russian President Vladimir Putin represents an unprecedented civilizational shame. It is not a mirror of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is another stone in the mosaic of the destructive entity politics of RS.
In the end, if we should say two key words from this panel of experts today, they are: truth and future. Those two words are inextricably linked because without truth there is no better future. The future of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region is not in hegemonic policies, conflicts and quarrels. It is time to decisively and thoroughly cross paths with criminal policies and start the process of raising awareness and conducting a reasonable and peaceful policy.
Let's tell the new generations to never emulate convicted war criminals. Young people should emulate the great and world-renowned Bosnian humanists, scientists, cultural workers, writers, painters, athletes... Bosnia and Herzegovina is the country of the future. In the state of the future, there is no place for the glorification of convicted war criminals.
Thank you for your attention!
Long live the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: The speech by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić at the official reception in Vienna organised to mark the Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Honorable Excellencies, Minister Podžić, Ambassador Kozarić, Ambassador Bencun, Brigadier Bajramović! Respected representatives of the military, ladies and gentlemen! It was a particular pleasure for me to respond to the invitation to celebrate the Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina here in Vienna to send clear and strong messages together.
Seventeen years ago, with the adoption of the Law on Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Law on Service in the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the process of establishing a professional Armed Forces of our homeland, trained for various types of operations and activities, began.
Those regulations carried with them a powerful message at the time, namely that anyone can be a part of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, regardless of ethnic, religious or any other affiliation. The only essential condition was to be able to handle the challenges that are an integral part of doing this job.
I have already said this once, but I will say it again, the 1st of December - the Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina - is the day to remember the contribution of those who, investing a lot of knowledge, effort and sacrifice, created the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina of today.
Although it was a very complex process, which required determination and patience, today we can safely say that the process of establishing the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of the best examples of a successful reform in our society and country.
Despite the difficulties, which are mainly reflected in the lack of financial resources, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina are unconditionally available to all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, assisting civil authorities in responding to natural and other disasters that, unfortunately, have befallen us in recent years. They are a significant guarantor of state stability and protection of the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
As a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is the Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I have had the opportunity to see the courage of our soldiers many times. Those young men and women had an adequate and courageous response to the challenges they faced. One of those occasions was a meeting with members of our Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the NATO mission "Resolute Support" for 2020 in Afghanistan, where they showed readiness and an exceptional level of ability to react in emergency situations, rivalling the largest military forces in the world. Our soldiers, for their participation in peacekeeping missions around the world, continuously receive the praises in which their professionalism and dedication are highlighted, which we should all be proud of because they represent us and our country Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The foreign policy strategy of Bosnia and Herzegovina, adopted by the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, is very clear. In that document, it was pointed out that in the continuation of activities on reform processes in our country, NATO remains the priority of the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I am not saying that it will be easy to bring this process to an end, there is a lot of work ahead of us, but all our diplomatic activities will lead to full membership in the NATO alliance, which is of great importance for the security, stability and overall progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
For the overall development of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the strengthening of personal capacities through the training of soldiers, non-commissioned officers and officers, as well as education of military personnel abroad, is of particular importance. That is why I use this opportunity to welcome the successful cooperation between the Federal Ministry of Defence of Austria and the Ministry of Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is reflected in the project of training our cadets at the Theresian Military Academy here in Austria.
I congratulate the cadets who graduated this year and became lieutenants, and now work as platoon commanders in our units. To the cadets of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina who are currently attending training and are here with us tonight, I wish good health, happiness and success during their education and work.
Without a strong Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the country itself cannot count on the protection of territorial integrity and sovereignty. The stable and strong Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina are the main guarantee of the survival and stability of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and a lever that must never be called into question. At a time when, unfortunately, wars are again being waged in Europe and the world, and when certain countries, in violation of international law, are once again carrying out aggression, the importance of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina is absolutely crucial for our homeland.
Let's acknowledge everything we have done to date, and what we will do in the future so that the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina remain a strong and unassailable pillar of our society. I am sure that the Ministry of Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, based on the democratic principles of openness and cooperation, regardless of the challenges they will face, will do everything to make Bosnia and Herzegovina an equal member of the Euro-Atlantic family in the future. I can promise you that I will do whatever I can.
Once again, on behalf of the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina and in my own name, I congratulate all the members of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina the Armed Forces Day and the 17th anniversary of its establishment.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Speech by the member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željko Komšić at the Ceremonial Academy on the occasion of the 17th anniversary and Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Honourable Excellencies, generals, officers and non-commissioned officers, soldiers, dear guests. It is my honour and pleasure to be able to address you on the 17th anniversary of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and in my own name.
December 1 - Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina is the day to remember the contribution of many who invested a lot of knowledge, will and effort in the process of establishing the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Although it was a very complex process, which required determination and patience, today, 17 years after its establishment, we can safely say that the process of establishing the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of the best examples of successful reform in our society and country.
The Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina today, in 2022, represent a factor of stability and security in the entire state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. They are a reliable partner, first of all to all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the state institutions, but they also prove to be a reliable partner to our allies at the international level
The credibility and importance of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina grows stronger every year, and the leadership and members of the Armed Forces represent the Armed Forces with dignity both domestically and internationally. This year alone, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina successfully participated in six international military exercises. In doing so, they continued the tradition of successful cooperation with allies, which was reflected in previous years through successful participation in peacekeeping missions.
No less important is the cooperation of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina when it comes to carrying out tasks to help the population of Bosnia and Herzegovina and civil authorities in responding to natural disasters and similar challenges, whereby the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a rule, show a high degree of responsibility and readiness to act on the orders of its Supreme Command.
And during this year, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina proved to be one of the most vital state institutions that successfully perform their tasks. Of exceptional importance for the overall process of NATO integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina is the fact that the Light Infantry Battalion Battle Group of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a few months ago, successfully completed a NEL 2 evaluation during exercises held ON the Manjača training range.
This not only continued good cooperation with our NATO allies, but also confirmed that our units are able to achieve excellent results according to NATO standards. We can be proud to have a reinforced battalion level unit ready and available in the NATO basin of force for future NATO operations, European Union and United Nations peace support operations, as well as for participation in NATO exercises.
It is important to know that this was preceded by the participation of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the NATO Summit in Madrid, where Bosnia and Herzegovina was the only country that participated as a pretender, a country that is in the process of Euro-Atlantic aspirations.
A few months before that, at an extraordinary NATO summit, on March 25 this year, NATO made a decision to strengthen forces on the eastern front and provide additional equipment to NATO members. It is of great importance that Bosnia and Herzegovina, as the only member of the MAP, is included in this additional equipment. All these activities, as well as the continuation of cooperation between the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Armed Forces of the United Kingdom, are encouraging from the aspect of strengthening the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina through the exchange of experiences and close cooperation with allies.
Ultimately, the submission of the Reform Program for 2022 by the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina, together with the previously mentioned military-diplomatic activities, testifies to the acceleration of Bosnia and Herzegovina's path towards full membership in the NATO alliance. In this sense, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina definitely represent the main engine of NATO integration.
I would like to take this opportunity to point out that in the current year we finally managed to increase the salary of the soldiers of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina. True, that this increase is insufficient, but finally, after a long time, the ice was broken, and the trend of stagnation and reduction of income for members of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina was stopped. I hope that the trend of increasing the salary of members of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina will continue. Therefore, I call on the future holders of executive and legislative power at BiH level to include exactly this at the top of their priorities.
I am aware that bringing about a new and more significant increase entails difficulties given the unhealthy political environment in which we live, as well as the fact that it may be accompanied by some demands that have nothing to do with improving the status of members of the Armed Forces, but the responsible government must not pay attention to small details politicking if the end result will be the improvement of the financial status of the members of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Of particular importance for the overall development of the Armed Forces of BiH is certainly the strengthening of personal capacities through the training of soldiers, non-commissioned officers and officers, and the education of military personnel abroad. It is possible to be done in a better scope only by including the issue of better and more significant financing of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the top of the state priorities.
Without a strong Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the country itself cannot count on the protection of territorial integrity and sovereignty. The stable and strong Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina are the main guarantee of the survival and stability of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and a lever that must never be called into question by anything. At a time when, unfortunately, wars are again being waged in Europe, and when certain countries are once again committing aggression in violation of international law, the importance of the Armed Forces is absolutely first-rate.
Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina can find support in our Armed Forces as well as a tool to deter any form of possible violence against the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Therefore, all of us together, for the sake of our future, must and will be committed to strengthening the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina and in my own name, I congratulate all members of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I wish you all happiness and success in your future work and life.
Thank you.

title: Speech by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić on the occasion of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina, City Hall Vijećnica, 24.11.2022.
content:
Dear citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, dear guests
This year marks the 79th anniversary of the formation of the First Republic in the history of the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina. After two years of joint struggle against fascism and occupation, through the National Liberation Movement, the citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina formed a people's government in 1943 and proclaimed a Republic based on the values of anti-fascism.
Thus, the foundations of the modern statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina were set, without which today's Bosnia and Herzegovina would not have been possible, nor would any future be possible without those fundamental values on which the country itself was built.
On the day when we celebrate the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is our duty, therefore, to remember with much respect all those great men who imbraided their lives and their life's deeds into the struggle for Bosnia and Herzegovina and its statehood. We are also obliged to know that in that time of darkness and fascism, the Bosnia and Herzegovina’s man rose far above many others who had neither the strength nor the courage to do such an act, all the while putting himself on the right side of history.
It is thanks to all of them, both great and ordinary folk of our Bosnian-Herzegovinian peoples, that we still have our state today.
Continuing the tradition of one of the best generations of Bosnian people, we carry on the fight for Bosnia and Herzegovina, both nationally and abroad, the country in which there is a place for all its citizens.
ZAVNOBiH confirmed and established the borders of the Republic, defined its territorial integrity and formed the government as a republic. All of these are elements of state sovereignty, which decades later are being attacked and threatened, and for which we are fighting today.
However, unfortunately, it seems that we often forget some of the basic lessons of ZAVNOBIH. It is, therefore, worth reminding of them on this day.
We must know that it is precisely ZAVNOBIH that teaches us that it is not possible to receive a state as a gift, just like that, by referring to a historical right, centuries-old continuity, etc. One must fight for the country and fight continuously!
It cannot be obtained with the help of strong allies, and even when you share civilizational values with them, and without the struggle of an internal factor, as was the struggle of the People's Liberation Movement.
If the citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the period from 1941 to 1945 waited for the final stages of the Second World War, and had they not only formed a government but also defined the goals of their political struggle in Mrkonjić Grad in 1943, no support of any allies would have helped in the formation of the Republic. And dare I say, there wouldn't be one.
The most progressive elements of the society at that time succeeded in politically and militarily overpowering those forces that wanted to tie the fate of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the outcome of political undertakings of other states, as well as ideologies.
They did not allow anyone else, besides themselves, to form a government for them, nor to form the principles of such a government's operation, nor the key state priorities.
That is why the brave enterprise of the generation 1943 is monumental, and from a historical point of view, their efforts can be compared to the Bosnian-Herzegovinian people who, in the period from 1992 to 1995, managed to preserve the state its legal continuity.
Today, it seems that we have two versions on stage, or rather two visions of Bosnia and Herzegovina, very similar to those of 1943.
That proud, defiant and brave Bosnia and Herzegovina is not afraid to say that it cannot be made into an ethnically divided country, that citizens cannot be forced into ethnic ghettos with some self-proclaimed leaders of those ethnic communities.
We are not afraid to say that we strive for a state system in which every citizen has equal rights and where every vote in elections is equally valid. We are not afraid to say that we are advocating for a system of values as is present in all the countries of the European Union. This is the centuries-old, proud, defiant, brave and never conquered Bosnia and Herzegovina.
However, we also have another version of our country, one that is anti-ZAVNOBIH, a subservient state that is afraid to fight for all the values of the modern democratic world and for the values on which this country was founded.
That subservient mindset of some is built on personal interests and a system that generates corruption and nepotism on the widest scale, from which their fear of the international community also springs. It is a system that protects itself, through its submissive expression and servile attitude towards all those who do not want any progress in this country, but the maintenance of the existing status quo situation, which cannot, and will not, lead us to membership in the European Union nor the NATO Alliance.
Such people, in moments when we are fighting for fundamental human rights in our country, tell us that we should not actually fight for the idea of Bosnia and Herzegovina - a state and society of equal people. They tell us that such a society and state will be built by others.
Such people tell us and lead us to build partnership with different parts of the international community on a basis of servient mentality and to unconditionally accept everything that comes from that international community, regardless of us being aware of what terrible, even disastrous solutions we are getting into. That's how slaves, if you'll excuse the expression, behave, not free citizens.
That's why I invite you today, on this festive day, so that we can all be part of the proud, defiant and brave ZAVNOBIH’s Bosnia and Herzegovina, which knows what it wants and how to realize its ideas of the state of equal citizens, with equal rights and equal freedoms.
I invite you to show what we have been showing for centuries: that we are a proud nation of Bosnians and Herzegovinans, that we are a defiant and brave country with which no one can play various political and geopolitical games.
Regardless of all the agreements and solutions at play currently, I am convinced that this proud country can achieve full democracy and protect the rights of every citizen.
The centuries-old history of our Bosnia and Herzegovina obliges us to do so, and that's why I want to say - Bosnia and Herzegovina has no price and is not for sale!
Once again, Happy renewed Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Speech by BiH Presidency Member Dr. Denis Bećirović on the occasion of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Vijećnica, November 24, 2022.
content:
Distinguished Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, esteemed guests, dear friends,
We gathered to celebrate the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina or, to be more precise, the day of renewal of the Bosnian statehood. There is no reason why any citizen or people should not experience this date as their holiday. This is not a holiday that discriminates, endangers or excludes anyone. On the contrary, this is a national holiday that connects and affirms the human rights of all citizens and nations.
Unfortunately, in the post-Dayton period, it became common for one member of BiH Presidency not to attend the marking of the 25th of November. This is not good practice. Representatives of all citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina participated in the creation of far-reaching decisions of ZAVNOBiH. It is the immortal work of the most advanced people of that time. It is the indestructible legacy of Bosnian anti-fascists who were globally recognized and a deserving part of the world anti-fascist coalition. For these reasons, as well as numerous other, we are working sincerely and patiently to ensure that one day all three members of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina jointly organize the celebration of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Denying the value of ZAVNOBiH is pointless and useless. Imagine that the Republic of France does not celebrate the 14th of July as a national holiday with the explanation that it refers to some other France. Or for the United States of America to erase the 4th of July from its memory. It is, of course, impossible to imagine. That is why current irrationalities and unsustainable reductionisms need to be explained to the new generations in our country as well. We must find the strength to bring the positive memory of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the surface and show people that the situation in the country does not have to be the way it is today.
We need to stop misinterpreting the term anti-fascism and reducing it from a civilizational level to an ideological level of meaning and use. Party and ideological disputes must not affect the importance of affirming anti-fascism. Anti-fascism is a civilizational, humanistic, and not an ideological category. It is one of the key postulates of modern society and is embedded in the foundations of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Union.
Let's not forget to acknowledge and express gratitude to all anti-fascists in the 20th century that contributed to the restoration of statehood and the defence of the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Thanks to them, today we have the privilege of living in our own country, whose sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity are unquestionable. Thanks to them, Bosnia and Herzegovina is today a full member of the United Nations.
The ideas of ZAVNOBiH point to peace and tolerance. That is why these ideas are more relevant today than ever. The first session of ZAVNOBiH is a bright example of protest against hatred, fratricide and division. With its philosophy and spirit of peace and unity, ZAVNOBiH still designs the geopolitical space of Bosnia and Herzegovina today.
The messages of ZAVNOBiH are strong and inexhaustible. ZAVNOBiH is more than just a conference, more than one politically significant event. It is a date and an event of the highest order, an event that changed the course of history and brought new social forces and new political ideas onto the historical stage.
It would be incomplete to talk about ZAVNOBiH and not mention the importance of the Second Session of ZAVNOBiH. At this session, in the spirit of the libertarian political tradition of authentic national movements, such as the French Civil Revolution (1789) and the American Uprising for Independence (1776), which brought their declarations on the freedoms and rights of citizens, the "Declaration of ZAVNOBiH" was adopted on the rights of citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is about one of the brightest documents adopted in the long history of our country. The declaration represents an inexhaustible source of inspiration in the fight for human rights and civil liberties.
The ideas and principles of ZAVNOBiH survive all attempts to destroy and disintegrate Bosnia and Herzegovina. The great historical significance of ZAVNOBiH lies in the fact that in BiH conglomerate of ethnic, religious, social and other elements found a point of synthesis and all-Bosnian integration. It is time to understand the essential message of ZAVNOBiH and find a point of synthesis in the XXI century.
Challenging the continuity of Bosnia and Herzegovina is a Sisyphean task. In the last thousand years, our country has survived what no other country could. And, despite everything, she survived. Bosnia and Herzegovina has always had the strength to withstand even the heaviest attacks and to defiantly and proudly stand tall. Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of the most stable and durable European countries.
It's time to ask some serious questions: What are we doing in the communities where we can to truly affirm the messages and values of ZAVNOBiH? What are we doing within the educational system and cultural reproduction to promote ZAVNOBiH? We should not talk about ZAVNOBiH in an inert, uninspiring and inertial way. The 25th of November should be talked about with new scientific achievements, new scientific elaborations and serious political understanding of ZAVNOBiH.
Unfortunately, we often waste energy and scarce resources on secondary historical phenomena and events. It is time to start dealing with essential issues of importance for the past, present and future. It's time for new ideas and serious projects. Among other things, we should seriously consider establishing the ZAVNOBiH Institute. It is time to raise ZAVNOBiH to the top of the value pyramid because it has a huge untapped potential to be the Bosnian Piedmont that gathers new generations with the idea of living together.
In order for a peaceful and successful Bosnia and Herzegovina to develop, it is necessary that integrative aspirations and policies become dominant in our homeland. Integrity cannot be imposed; it can only be established by the political will of all citizens and nations. Democracy and integration in Bosnia and Herzegovina are inseparable. They are two sides of the same process.
A country made up of different ethnic groups cannot be integrated by one ethnic group. Such a situation can exist in a mono-ethnic country, but it cannot exist in a historically formed state of multi-ethnic composition and character.
Progressive forces must persistently and patiently build a more positive social environment in our country that will bring forth good for all people. Let's act responsibly with a view to the future. People all over our beautiful country are looking for peace, economic development and a better standard of living. In order to meet their expectations, we must speed up Bosnia and Herzegovina's path to full membership in the EU and NATO. We are working together to build a more favourable business environment that will attract foreign investors and encourage domestic investors to invest capital in our country.
Our homeland needs statesmen who are ready to fight for the realization of the dream, the vision of a European and democratic Bosnia and Herzegovina, eager for the future, aware of their past. We need brave leaders who will have the strength to tell society the truth and fight against injustice. Determined and organized people do not complain but change the environment as tireless initiators of positive changes.
Let us believe in Bosnia and Herzegovina. We work diligently to make our country a source of good ideas and positive projects. Bosnia and Herzegovina can be a point of convergence and rapprochement, a driver of peace and development projects. Let the positive achievements of the past be an additional inspiration for us to build the Bosnia and Herzegovina of the future.
Let's tell the new generations that there are no impossible goals. There are those who believe in positive ideas and those who do not. There are optimists and pessimists. We believe, we are optimists.
Happy Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: The speech delivered by Chairwoman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željka Cvijanović at the constitutive session of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Respected members of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the old and new convocations, Dear President of the Republika Srpska, Respected presidents of the governments of Republika Srpska and Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina Chairman of the Council of Ministers, the House of Representatives and the House of Peoples, Representatives of institutions at state, entity and other levels of government, Respected representatives of religious communities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Your Excellencies, ambassadors, representatives of the diplomatic corps and international organizations in Bosnia and Herzegovina Dear citizens, Ladies and gentlemen,
It is an honour to have the opportunity to address you, for the first time as a Serb member, and at the same time as the Chairwoman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I have been elected to this responsible position, as is a well-known fact, by the citizens of Republika Srpska, to whom I would firstly like to express my gratitude for their enormous support and trust.
In the last elections, they gave me the mandate to represent their interests in the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina and defend the constitutional position of both Republika Srpska and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I come to the Presidency with open arms, with good intentions. I wish for us to work together, in accordance with our constitutional competences, for the benefit of both entities and all peoples in BiH, as well as other citizens, and not to anyone's detriment.
We desperately need dialogue on all the open issues that weigh on our daily lives. Both within the Presidency and other state institutions, as well as with legislative and executive governments at the level of the Republika Srpska and the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and I believe that, in these globally complex circumstances, each of us will contribute to the search for solutions to existing problems.
I believe that we are politically mature enough to determine our own priorities, and not have solutions imposed on us by anyone from the outside. That's why I want us to be subjects of decision-making, and not mere objects or recipients of interventions, because we live in a country that belongs equally to all of us and in which we, elected by the people, are accountable to the people for what has been done or not done. Because if we want to be respected by others, then we primarily must have more respect for ourselves.
There are many things on which we disagree within Bosnia and Herzegovina and this is nothing new. But the measure of our success will be precisely in finding the lowest common denominator and directing our forces towards those goals that are equally important for everyone.
I am an advocate of discussing all important issues, but in practice that we primarily deal with common priorities, and those issues that we know in advance that there is no agreement of everyone in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I believe that it is necessary to improve our relations and build bridges of cooperation both within Bosnia and Herzegovina and with countries in the region. Primarily with Serbia, Croatia and Montenegro, with whom we share a border, but also with North Macedonia, Slovenia and others in the region and beyond.
It is important that in these challenging times we accept every development opportunity that presents itself to us, that together with neighbouring countries we participate in all regional initiatives that can bring benefits to our economy and citizens.
That is why I will strongly advocate for additional strengthening of regional cooperation within the Berlin process, but also for full participation in the Open Balkans initiative. In this sense, I am ready to clarify everything that is necessary, but also to listen to the explanations of other participants who are competent to decide on these issues, in order to reach a harmonized position.
One of the strategic commitments is the continuation on the European path, and the first task of institutions at all levels is certainly to obtain candidate status for EU membership. It is not possible to implement this work without close coordination of different levels of government, therefore I believe that it is necessary to rehabilitate the coordination system that would enable us to move forward in a systematic and organized manner.
I particulary wish to highlight that in the context of European integration, but also in all other processes that we will implement, it is of crucial importance that we consistently respect the Dayton Peace Agreement and the constitutional structure of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is a framework that provided us with peace, but also clearly determined the position and responsibilities of different levels of government in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The assumption of the rule of law is respect for the highest legal and political act of a country, without which there is neither a functional legal state nor an orderly system.
And that is exactly what we should primarily strive for, both in the BiH Presidency and in other institutions at all levels of government, because otherwise we would only have disorder, divergence and separation.
At this point, I am obliged to clarify my position regarding the participation of a foreign factor in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Carrying out important functions for many years and taking into account all the stages this country has gone through, I understand that good cooperation between national institutions and foreign representatives is necessary. However, democracy will come to life in its full capacity, and internal dialogue and mutual trust will strengthen only when national institutions fully take responsibility for all processes.
It is no secret, nor is it unknown, that I do not believe in the benefits of forcible interventionism by a foreign factor, but that I exclusively believe in dialogue and cooperation.
Just as I do not believe that the abuse or usurpation of constitutional powers on the foreign policy front can help Bosnia and Herzegovina, I also do not believe that foreign judges in the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina, high representatives or foreign micro-managers can help us live in a more successful country.
But, on the other hand, I believe that internal dialogue can help us overcome problems both internally and externally, and as a member of the BiH Presidency, I am ready to contribute to building such a dialogue.
I congratulate my colleagues in the Presidency and all the newly elected representatives of the people in both entities and at the state level, with a wish to, in the next four years, justify the trust that has been given to us.
Thank you!

title: The speech delivered by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić at the constitutive session of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Dear citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, esteemed guests from the country and abroad, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends,
I am addressing you with a sense of sincere pride, gratitude and responsibility for the high duty I am assuming. I understand the trust of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which was given to me during the elections, as an obligation to represent all those democratic values that we inherit as citizens and that we preserve as a state.
I would like to use this opportunity to thank my colleagues for their cooperation in the previous mandate of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Mr. Šefik Džaferović and Mr. Milorad Dodik.
The conduct of the duties of a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina entrusted to me will be devoid of partial party or any individual or group interests. The election to this position, and the Constitution of the State of Bosnia and Herzegovina, obliges me to treat all citizens of our country equally. This is also my personal committment not only a constitutional obligation.
All activities that I undertake as a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina will be directed towards the unity of the state and in accordance with the priorities defined by the decisions of the institutions of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The feeling of belonging to this country as our common good, its difficult but glorious past, faith in its future, faith in the generations to come, is my motive. By working in the general interest of all citizens and in the interest of the state, I wish to, together with everyone, try to make the country offer better living conditions, the country of hope and the country that can fulfil the dreams of the best among us.
The citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina can be sure that I will not spare either myself or those whom I have chosen to work with, to work towards this goal every day.
In this same place four years ago, taking the oath for the past mandate, I said that I would not miss an opportunity that might arise, to unblock the process of NATO integration through the activation of MAP.
That opportunity presented itself, and the Reform Program was delivered to the NATO headquarters in Brussels, first by the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina and then by the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I am pround of that fact.
I, therefore, would like to use this address to higlight that I will not miss the opportunity to do everything in my power, even beyond, to take the last step towards Bosnia and Herzegovina's full membership in the NATO alliance, if such a possibility presents itself because the membership of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the NATO alliance is a primary foreign political priority.
The destruction of the implementation of 14 priorities from the European Commission Opinion on the candidate status for membership of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the European Union, and the gross ignorance of the European Court of Human Rights' judgements, unfortunately threatens to make Bosnia and Herzegovina's European path a secondary foreign policy priority, given the extent of violations of the European standards and principles, especially regarding the equality of citizens before the law and the Constitution.
For my part, I will make all the necessary efforts, and use all the mechanisms provided by the Constitution, so that the perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina's membership in the European Union is not permanently destroyed.
In this, I will need the support of all well-intentioned citizens and political options in Bosnia and Herzegovina who still believe that the membership of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the European Union is one of the primary foreign policy priorities.
While respecting the Constitution of the State of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I use the opportunity to remind you of its evolutionary nature, that is, the fact that the Constitution itself foresees the possibility of upgrading to a system of complete democracy and all its values.
The fulfilment of the European Commission Opinion obligations urges us to do precisely that. The fullfiment of obligations are teh best tool in achieving equality of all citizens.
No one can take away the right to democracy from the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and I will resolutely oppose all such attempts because I am obliged to do so by the trust shown by all those people who believe in a democratic Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In terms of foreign policy withing the United Nations, as a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I will strive to keep Bosnia and Herzegovina on the side of those countries that respect international law and the principle of the inviolability of internationally recognized borders, in other words, on the side of the democratic and civilized order opposed to any form of aggression and violence.
Taught by its own historical experience, Bosnia and Herzegovina will continue, through the United Nations, the Council of Europe and other international associations, to be the state that will not take a neutral position in matters of the conflict between civilization and anti-civilization.
I have only one but simple message for our neighbours. We will respect you as much as you respect the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, its sovereignty and territorial integrity. Bosnia and Herzegovina owes nothing to anyone, and many owe a lot to it. The days of all kinds of justifications just because we want and want to live in our normal, peaceful and prosperous country are long gone.
The state of Bosnia and Herzegovina and its institutions will certainly be a reliable regional partner for all those who want peace, economic and any other social development through the relevant international agreements that we have signed in the past period.
Personally, as an official who has been entrusted by the citizens to represent them in the highest state institution, I will remain committed to the idea of ​​equality for all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, regardless of their ethnic, religious or other identity origin, as well as the values ​​of anti-fascism on which the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina was built.
All citizens can find in me, as a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a faithful ally in advocating for such values, as well as an ally in the fight against all forms of corruption and nepotism.
My intention is to finally free the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina from the choice between the feeling of love for the homeland and the feeling of systematic injustice. I will invest all my energy and integrity in building a just state in which there is room for all its citizens.
Thank you.

title: The speech delivered by BiH Presidency Member Dr. Denis Bećirović at the constitutive session of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Dear citizens, People of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Members of the BiH Presidency, Excellencies, Eminencies, Honored guests, Ladies and gentlemen,
I want to thank the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina for the trust you have given me. On October 2, more than 330.000 people voted in my favor of becoming a member of the Presidency of BiH. I feel an enormous responsibility toward the people of this country, and to the country itself, and it is a great honor as well.
We took an oath that we will conscientiously perform the duty entrusted to us, as well as protect the human rights of all nations and citizens. Let's protect and strengthen the values of a democratic society and social solidarity. Let’s defend the freedom and dignity of every person in our country. Let's respect and implement the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, as well as the decisions of international and domestic courts. Let’s change what is bad, what divides and discriminates all of us. Let's do everything in our power to help people live better lives.
Deep roots and strong anti-fascist foundations of Bosnia and Herzegovina
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country with deep medieval roots and strong anti-fascist foundations. To this day, anti-fascist values mean advocacy for democracy, human rights, and social justice. A concise assessment of our country's past can be expressed in one sentence that reads: All the great deeds in the long history of this country were done together, all the great tragedies were committed by those who tried to break us apart.
United on life's great questions and the future
We cannot change the past, but we can learn from it. We must direct our energy towards fixing the substandard present and building the foundation for a more secure future. For a better quality of life, all levels of the government should be focused on solving the existential issues.
All of us in Bosnia and Herzegovina have common opponents such as poverty, unemployment, injustice, and mass departure of people from our country, especially the youth. These opponents do not know political, ethnic, religious, and other differences and they endanger all people equally. It is crucial that we act responsibly together in order to confront the actual problems.
The vision of Bosnia and Herzegovina
My vision of Bosnia and Herzegovina is that of a democratic, legal, and European country. A country where ethnic, religious, regional, social, and other identities are freely developed and respected, which altogether build the common identity of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is a vision of a free, open, multi-ethnic, European, creative, and an attractive country for investment.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has a secure future
Let's build the future together and strengthen the security of the country of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Drawn from experience: for peace and economic development, we need everyone in our country, for conflict and destabilization we don't need all. Let us strive to the politics of peace, cooperation, and strengthen the economic foundations.
Politicians in Bosnia and Herzegovina must turn from selfishness and investment in their own popularity and benefit. Let's work for the interests of impoverished and disenfranchised ones. Let's not build political popularity on quarrels and conflicts. Only the seeds of misery and unhappiness can sprout from inflicting threats and tensions.
People dream about a peaceful life and growth
People dream of their children building the future of our country. They wonder how it is that young people from our country can work and live together in the West whereas here, the politicians teach them the opposite. Let us help people get closer to their dreams. Those dreams are reachable if we collectively become better than we used to be.
Cooperation and decisiveness policy
