I am holding out a cooperation hand to all who wish well for the people of our country. At the same time, I will be determined to defend the democratic, legal, European and multi-ethnic country of Bosnia and Herzegovina. There is no legal, political, moral, historical, or civilizational basis for contesting the country of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Responsible and courageous statesmen build peace and stability
What people need today are responsible and brave statesmen. Nowadays, courage is shown by standing up for peace and the human rights of every human being. Strength is expressed through cooperation and dialogue, not insults and threats. It is time to draw the line and admit that strife and division are the roads to poverty and isolation. It is time to rise above quarrels and anger to make the most of the present and build a better future.
Accelerate the path toward EU and NATO membership
Our strategic goals are full membership in the European Union (EU) and NATO. National competent authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina unanimously adopted these objectives. Legally adopted decisions and laws of competent state authorities must be respected as in any other country. The rule of law and respect for the continuity of the decisions made are fundamental requirements for stability and development.
EU membership is a great challenge. We must demonstrate the ability to succeed in the large and demanding European market, thereby fully embracing the democratic values of a united Europe. It is of great importance to prepare our economy on this path by improving knowledge, science and implementing new technologies while respecting the sustainable development goals.
The new parliamentary majority at the national level should rapidly implement the recommendations of the European Commission. Let us do everything we can in the upcoming weeks so that Bosnia and Herzegovina moves closer to becoming the candidate for EU membership in December this year. I believe that granting candidate status would be a powerful message and an additional initiative to intensify our European path.
Let's coordinate the foreign policy of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU
Let's be persistent in fulfilling the undertaken contractual obligations between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU, and let's continue and improve the alignment of Bosnia and Herzegovina's foreign policy with the statements, declarations, and common positions of the European Union. We are part of the free and democratic world and are committed to the values on which it is based. Accordingly, we undoubtedly contribute to security and stability, both in Europe and the whole world.
Our historical experience brings forward a great amount of empathy for the suffering of others. Today, people in Ukraine and elsewhere are suffering. Let's show our full solidarity with them.
Let’s work to ensure that, with increased cooperation with EU and NATO member states, Bosnia and Herzegovina continues to develop good relations and all-around ties with numerous friendly countries on all meridians and parallels.
Regional cooperation has no other alternative
Regional cooperation is one of the primary interests of the country of Bosnia and Herzegovina and an important prerequisite for EU integration. Good relations with neighbors guarantee peace, stability, the opening of trade relations, investments, growth of tourism, culture, sports, education, and any other kind of cooperation with the neighbouring countries. Respect for international law, equal cooperation, and partnership in the region can result in the prosperity of the entire region.
I say to the benevolent people in the region that they have sincere friends and reliable partners in the citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Today, from Sarajevo, I am sending a special message to the people of Serbia, Croatia, Montenegro, and the entire region, which states: let's declare together the 21st century an era of peace and development by engaging into the finest economic cooperation as well as any other form of cooperation.
Let's continue with the reforms of the defense system under the NATO standards
An efficient and qualified defense system must serve the general, personal as well as property rights and security of people in our country. We must continue to reform the defense system under NATO standards. We are bound by international agreements and the adopted Law on the Defense of BiH, as well as the decisions of responsible state institutions. In the period ahead, even greater challenges will be faced, including the continuation of reforms, and their implementation, but also the realization of expected obligations and defined tasks. To achieve this, a high degree of functionality, efficiency, and professionalism of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina is necessary, which should be interoperable with NATO and capable of realizing the statutory mission.
Let's connect Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Diaspora
Millions of our fellow citizens live and work all around the world. They haven't forgotten Bosnia and Herzegovina and we must not forget them. They are a massive involving force and genuine partners in building the future of our country. Let's make a deeper connection between our people in the homeland and the diaspora.
Let's strengthen the connective tissue of our multi-ethnic state
We live in a multi-ethnic and multi-religious country. It is a treasure. Let's strengthen the connective tissue of Bosnia and Herzegovina, connect nations and citizens, and work for the benefit of our country. Let's come up with a policy of returning all citizens and people to their homeland. Bosnia and Herzegovina must be a house where the rule of law, democracy, and human rights reside.
Let's bring back optimism and positive energy
Let's leave apathy and pessimism in the past, and bring optimism and determination in the present. Let's bring back some positive energy to our society and open up to positive changes. None of us can do it alone. Therefore, let's affirm the joint work of authorities at all levels. By working together, we can build a better world for all.
Let’s build the Bosnia and Herzegovina of the future
Let's break new ground and build Bosnia and Herzegovina of the future. Let’s work for our country and every benevolent person. Let's reject monologue and arguments, let's affirm dialogue and cooperation. Let’s serve the people and our country. We are all sons and daughters of Bosnia and Herzegovina. May our mother Bosnia and Herzegovina live forever! A country of equal nations and citizens. The country of the future.
Thank you for your attention!

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Šefik Džaferović, at the commemoration of the anniversary of the death of the first President of the Presidency of the Republic of
content:
Dear members of Alija Izetbegović's family, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, I feel honored and proud to have known the late Alija Izetbegović. I feel honored and proud to have been his collaborator. Because I was and remain his follower. I feel an exceptional moral duty and social privilege, that today, in the capacity of Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in this place, I speak about Alija Izetbegović.
Dear friends,
Alija Izetbegović's name evokes an inexhaustible number of topics, because of his peculiar personality and he is one of the most significant people in the history of this country. Certainly the most significant personality in the recent history of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Alija Izetbegović's name evokes an inexhaustible number of topics, but today I will talk about three.
About his character. About his fight for the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. About his fight for the Bosniak people.
First, about character. I knew late President Izetbegović personally and I cannot but be personal when I talk about him. As a young man, I was his associate. I had the opportunity to talk with him day after day, closely observe his actions and his attitude towards people.
What I knew about Alija Izetbegović as a Bosniak and an ordinary citizen, I further confirmed by working alongside him.
Alija Izetbegović was a president, thinker, writer, humanist, lawyer.
However, one word best sums up the impressions we all felt before the late president.
Alija Izetbegović was a statesman. In the true sense of the word.
Although he was also a politician, Alija Izetbegović is not remembered as a politician, but as a statesman.
Politicians dream of power. Statesmen watch over the fate of the country and people.
Politicians only think about the next election. Statesmen think about future generations.
For politicians, power is the goal. For statesmen, it is only a tool.
Alija Izetbegović was a statesman. Because power for him was a means to do something good. Because he watched over the fate of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Bosniak people. Because he was thinking about the generations to come.
Alija Izetbegović was a statesman, because he was a man of thought, but also of action. There are politicians who think a lot, but do not act. There are also those who act a lot, but without much thought. Alija Izetbegović was a statesman, because he thought and acted.
Dear friends,
Now I will say something more about the second and third topic - about the fight of President Izetbegović for the state and for the Bosniak people.
He was a statesman, because he shared the fate of Bosnia and Herzegovina and his people.
He was 65 years old when he was elected president of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
He remembered the division of Bosnia and Herzegovina, through the Cvetković-Maček agreement.
He survived the Second World War, which Bosniaks faced without their own state. He remembered the crimes against Bosniaks and the attempts to assimilate us.
He fought on the side of the Partisans, although he was not a communist, like many other Bosniaks.
He truly believed that Bosnia and Herzegovina belonged to all its peoples. That's why he protested when the new authorities betrayed the formula of ZAVNOBiH and pushed aside the Bosniaks, who were then named after their religion.
He always emphasized that this country belongs to all its nations and people. He emphasized that everyone has the right to love her, even when they didn't.
He knew that Bosniaks, due to their historical destiny, are tied to the destiny of Bosnia and Herzegovina by an umbilical cord. But he never, I repeat - he never denied Serbs and Croats the right to feel Bosnia and Herzegovina as their own.
He fought so that no one would be uncomfortable in this country and in his own skin.
Convinced that different peoples can and should live together, he fought for different opinions to be confronted in public. He was a staunch democrat to the end. He said that the right of the stronger is not a right, but a fact. He said that true law was created to protect the weak. He said that freedom of thought is primarily the freedom to think differently.
And then a paradox happened. He who fought for coexistence was accused of doing the opposite. He who fought for freedom of thought was accused of doing the opposite.
He was sentenced twice, for words and thoughts. The first time as a young man, and the second time as a mature man. Both times he preserved his dignity, knowing that there are times when a free man has no choice but to be a prisoner.
The people understood that, after the Sarajevo process. Despite the regime's intentions, the process turned into its opposite. The intention was to convince the Bosniak people not to follow Alija Izetbegović. And the opposite happened.
The people always followed Alija Izetbegović. Even during the communism. As a manager of large construction sites, he led projects on which half a thousand workers worked. It is known how much influence his articles in Preporod had on Bosniak intellectuals and ulema of that time.
When he came to power, there was no revanchism. Even some of his interrogators testified about this. He knew that the motive of his persecutors was to divide the people and therefore he did not want to follow their path.
He followed another path. His thought, which was formed primarily on the Holy Qur'an, and then on the highest achievements of Western philosophy, refined by folk wisdom and experience, was a light and a guide for the Bosniak people, who were facing the most turbulent period in modern history.
Dear friends,
As I said, Alija Izetbegović was 65 years old when he became the president of independent Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Up to that point, he had lived through almost everything a man can live through in his lifetime. But in the following ten years he lived more and more.
Independence and international recognition of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Siege of Sarajevo and genocide throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Double aggression. Embargo.
Creation and strengthening of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Various peace negotiations.
The solidarity of friends in the world, and the cynicism of those who were not.
Liberation actions of the RBiH Army.
July 11, which he said was the greatest calamity that could happen in our lifetimes.
The intervention of the international community.
And finally – the Dayton Peace Agreement.
Throughout the entire period of aggression, and especially at the very beginning and end, he bore the greatest burden of responsibility. But he was always up to the task. He always questioned his views, listened to others, consulted, but defended what he believed in with great strength. We should never forget that this is a man who paid for his beliefs with his freedom.
Explaining the responsibility of statesmen, he once said: "History is not a laboratory, so try out several possibilities and monitor the results. You can only do what you're about to do once."
The decision to start gaining independence passed the test of history.
Acceptance of the Dayton Peace Accords – passed the test of history.
Both of these decisions were historically correct and necessary. The violent destruction of Yugoslavia was not the will of Alija Izetbegović, but the will of others. And the will of others is an objective circumstance. After becoming the head of a country that was attacked from outside and inside, he made the best decision - Bosnia and Herzegovina started the path of independence.
The ultimate goal of the aggressors was to overturn this decision. Alija Izetbegović never agreed to it. From the Carrington and Cutilier plans, through the Vance-Owen and Owen-Stoltenberg plans, until the Dayton Agreement, he never agreed to annul the independence and integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
He did not consider the Dayton Peace just, but he considered it more just than the continuation of the war. In the world as it is, with power relations as they are, a better peace could not be achieved. Our problem was not that we accepted the American peace initiative, but that it did not happen earlier and that it was not fairer. With the imposed embargo, the cynicism of the world and the double aggression of our neighbors, we did not have enough strength for a complete victory. But we didn't even lose. We got a chance to win in peace, which we did by strengthening and building state institutions.
Dear friends,
The strategy of the anti-state forces, after reluctantly accepting the Dayton Peace, was to tire us and the world. But they tired themselves. First, because we, with the support of our friends, were stronger. Second, because the destruction of Bosnia and Herzegovina is not in the interest of any nation.
Not shying away from telling hard truths, the late president once said that Bosnia and Herzegovina is what the Bosniak people want most at this moment. But he added that it should not be imagined without the Serbian and Croatian people. The same as without other peoples, who have been living here for centuries.
On another occasion, the late president said that the solution to all our problems is a complete and democratic Bosnia and Herzegovina. "Comprehensive" - means to reduce ethnic divisions, and "democratic" - to develop a division of opinion within each nation, instead of between them.
Dear friends,
I was recently in the Czech Republic, at the summit of the European Political Community. Our people, who live in the Czech Republic, reminded me of one detail, with which I will end.
What Alija Izetbegović is for us, Vaclav Havel is for the Czechs.
A month before the signing of the Dayton Agreement, Vaclav Havel gave unconditional support to the legal authorities and the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, comparing the fate of our country with that of Czechoslovakia in 1938 and strongly condemning attempts to equalize the parties in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Asked what he thought about the political views of Alija Izetbegović, Havel said that he hardly saw the difference between his and Izetbegović's views, adding that in conversations with him he became convinced that the Bosnian side wants democracy, civil coexistence of different peoples and religions, which is the cornerstone of modern civilization .
I heard an almost identical assessment of the late president from numerous other statesmen in all corners of the world.
Alija Izetbegović, his thought, as well as the fate of Bosnia and Herzegovina, were one of the rare issues on which both West and East agreed, and that is no small matter.
Let us be aware of it forever.
Let's be grateful to God for the country and the freedom we have, and work hard to make our situation better.
Let us be forever proud that we had Alija Izetbegović and that we follow his path.
Thank you for your attention!
4 PHOTO GALLERY

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Šefik Džaferović, at the general debate of the 77th session of the United Nations General Assembly, New York, 21st September, 2022
content:
Mr. Speaker,
Secretary General,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my honor to address this respected body, as the chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I congratulate Mr. Shahid on successfully presiding over the 76th session of the United Nations General Assembly. Together with the Secretary General of the UN, Mr. Guterres, he worked dedicatedly so that this body of the United Nations could carry out its duties, despite the difficult conditions caused by the pandemic.
I also congratulate Mr. Kőrösi on his election as the chairman of the 77th session of the General Assembly. You can count on the support and cooperation of Bosnia and Herzegovina in ensuring the productive work of this body.
Dear President,
In recent years, at the sessions of the General Assembly and other international forums, we have regularly assessed that the global order is experiencing tectonic changes. Today, however, we can conclude that the world has been irreversibly changed. Relations, on which rested the security architecture of Europe as well as the wider international framework, have become a thing of the past.
At a time when towns and villages in Ukraine are facing the terrifying reality of war, the least we can do is not to be silent about it. We must not be silent, especially in this building. In the United Nations, which was established with the aim of preventing and stopping what is currently happening in Ukraine. Finally, we in Bosnia and Herzegovina, who ourselves have a vivid memory of the horrors of war and aggression, must not be silent.
As in the case of my country, in the period between 1992 and 1995, the United Nations system, unfortunately, was again unable to prevent or stop the war in Ukraine. I am primarily referring to the Security Council, as a body responsible for the protection of international peace and security, in light of the principles defined by the Charter of the United Nations.
Unlike the Security Council, which, due to internal relations and blockades, is evidently unable to fulfill its obligations, the General Assembly of the United Nations, by an overwhelming majority, adopted a resolution on aggression against Ukraine.
The aforementioned resolution of this body confirmed the unquestionable principles of the Charter of the United Nations and other acts of international law, which prohibit the use of armed force and order states to resolve disagreements by peaceful means.
Support for the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine was expressed, and the actions of the Russian Federation were unequivocally called aggression, and a request was made to stop it. The secessionist moves of certain regions within Ukraine directed against its territorial integrity were also rejected.
Bosnia and Herzegovina supported this resolution and stood on the right side of history, together with 140 other countries, and in accordance with the obligations from the UN Charter, our previously held positions and our obligation, according to the Stabilization and Association Agreement, to follow the foreign policy of the European Union.
Although this resolution does not have the power to stop the war, it does have the power to stop lies. The clear and unambiguous language of this highest international forum reduces the space to the extreme for all those who try to twist the truth. The first step towards any solution is to tell the truth and respect it.
I express my hope that there will be peace as soon as possible, so that people in Ukraine can live normally and so that the displaced can return to their homes.
Dear President,
The war in Ukraine, as well as the consequences of the pandemic, led to enormous changes in all spheres of life. At the current moment, this is mostly expressed through a deep energy crisis, inflation, a general recession and the threat to supplies, especially when it comes to food. We all have a very difficult and challenging winter ahead of us.
The global market and international free trade have enabled enormous progress in all corners of the world. The eradication of hunger, the availability of consumer goods, continuous economic growth in all corners of the world, these are all unquestionable benefits of global economic liberalization.
By tightly connecting various parts of the globe, globalization has made us interdependent. Strong economic, security and political interrelations have produced an increasingly integrated global framework, in which everyone relies on each other, in various spheres, ranging from the economy to security.
At the same time, the interdependence of different parts of the world is the source of the vulnerability of the global community. This was shown by the pandemic, when traffic and supply channels were blocked. This is also shown by the current crisis, related to the war in Ukraine, when due to the blockade of wheat exports from Ukrainian ports, hunger threatens developing countries on the African and Asian continents. Or, as it is the case today when most of the European continent is facing an energy crisis due to dependence on Russian gas.
Due to some difficulties caused by the process of political and economic integration, in the past years we have often witnessed the advocacy of political sovereignty and economic protectionism. The consequences of the transformation of developed countries from industrial to post-industrial, then migration and finally pandemics, were the reason for many to advocate for the erection of economic and even literal walls and wire fences.
It's a stray path. The solution to the mentioned problems is not to close, but to open. The solution is not to cooperate less, but cooperate more. The solution to the energy crisis in Europe, caused by dependence on one source, is not only relying on one's own force, but in diversification, finding new, multiple channels of supply of gas and other energy sources.
No one in the modern world has enough resources to be able to rely only on themselves, and the past crises show that even dependence on individual external sources is not enough. Both of these difficulties can only be overcome through even greater international cooperation.
Dear President,
We live in unstable times, unprecedented in recent history. While we await an extremely difficult winter, we are aware of the destabilizing potential of the economic and energy crisis.
The 20th century provides extremely valuable lessons about the connection between economic crisis and right-wing populism. It was on the wave of great economic depression that the Nazi movement came to power, which led to the greatest cataclysm in the history of mankind, after which the United Nations was established, and the UN Charter was adopted, and then the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the Convention on preventing and punishing genocide, as well as other UN acts.
The essential idea of the United Nations, on which all these fundamental acts of international law rest, is the idea of the equality of all people, regardless of their origin, skin color, religious, national or other affiliation. This is the idea on which modern civilization is built.
Now, almost eight decades later, we can hear voices openly or implicitly denying those fundamental tenets. More and more often, right-wing populists say that all people and nations do not have equal rights, that some are more valuable than others. More and more often, they openly advocate the ideas of ethnic and racial supremacy, as well as that domination and bare force is the only principle on which interpersonal and international relations can and should be structured. From these ideas to violence is only one step away.
From this place, from the United Nations building, I call for caution and action. In the coming period, we will face huge challenges. We must fulfil our duty, and fight for civilized ideas. We must defend them, at all costs.
Dear President,
Bosnia and Herzegovina has been home to many peoples, cultures and religions for centuries. We are proud of our long tradition of multiculturalism. We are proud of our Muslim, Christian, Jewish, Roma and other communities, as well as the culture of living together and mutual respect that we have developed over the centuries. All these communities are individually and collectively part of the Bosnian state mosaic and will remain being so.
At the same time, Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a meeting place of cultures, was a thorn in the side of politics, which are based on the idea of the impossibility of living together and the necessity of confrontation. Such policies led to a terrifying war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, from 1992 to 1995, which culminated in the genocide in Srebrenica.
In the resolutions of the General Assembly and the Security Council of the United Nations from the mentioned period, as well as in the reports of the UN Secretary General, and finally in the judgments of the International Criminal Court based in The Hague, the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina is qualified as an international armed conflict, with the participation of neighbouring countries.
In the judgments of the Hague Criminal Tribunal, it was concluded that joint criminal enterprises were conducted, with the aim of eliminating certain ethnic groups from parts of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, so that these territories would ultimately be annexed to neighbouring countries, which committed the most serious violation of international general and humanitarian law.
Since the conclusion of the Dayton Peace Agreement, Bosnia and Herzegovina has gone through an arduous path in building peace. However, there are still numerous challenges, the biggest of which are the policies in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the neighbourhood, which have not given up on the war goals of dividing the country.
As part of a broader wave of right-wing populism in Europe, there are politicians in Bosnia and Herzegovina who openly claim that Bosnia and Herzegovina is not possible, because, as they point out, it is not possible for Muslims and Christians to live together.
Muslims and Christians live and can live together. And such life has a perspective. And what certainly has no perspective are the retrograde policies that oppose it.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, with its centuries-old history, is a living example and proof of the civilized idea that people of different religions, nations and cultures can live together. The fact that Bosnia and Herzegovina, even despite the war that was aimed at its destruction, managed to survive shows its exceptional resilience.
The majority of people in Bosnia and Herzegovina want to live in peace with their differences, and there is enough strength for such a Bosnia and Herzegovina to win. I am convinced that it will be so.
Dear President,
The experience of Bosnia and Herzegovina shows that the rule of law is a crucial factor for building peace. The work of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, which was formed by the UN, provided victims with a minimum of justice, and sent a message to criminals that their actions will not go unpunished, and that they will be brought to justice and bear the consequences for their actions.
Furthermore, other bodies of the international community, primarily the Office of the High Representative and the Peace Implementation Council, made a huge contribution to peace building and protection.
Both bodies were established on the basis of Chapter 7 of the Charter of the United Nations, which mandates the intervention of the international community for the purpose of protecting peace, and their establishment was also confirmed by relevant resolutions of the Security Council. Accordingly, their closure is possible only with a new decision of the Security Council, and it is not yet time for that.
Allow me to remind you that in significantly developed countries, such as Germany, there was international supervision, with much greater executive powers than the Office of the High Representative in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and it was extinguished after 45 years of existence, when the prerequisites for it were created.
Over the past 27 years, the Office of the High Representative and the Peace Implementation Council have assisted domestic political actors in implementing reforms. Thanks to joint efforts, we managed to unite the three once warring armies into a single Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We also united the three intelligence services, the tax system, the judiciary, etc.
Thanks to these reforms, that is, the existence of the Armed Forces and other state institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina, even after the gradual withdrawal of 60,000 international troops, peace has been preserved.
In the past little more than a year, in Bosnia and Herzegovina there was an attack on the 27 years of implementation of the Dayton Peace Agreement, through an attempt to dissolve the state institutions that were established based on the clear provisions of the Dayton Agreement.
Thanks to the action of the Office of the High Representative and the member states of the Peace Implementation Council, led by the United States of America, the attack on state institutions was stopped and peace was preserved, which demonstrated the expediency and efficiency of the institutions of the international community in BiH.
In the past period, in addition to requests for the closure of the OHR, requests for the High Representative to take steps that would weaken the unity of Bosnia and Herzegovina and introduce additional ethnic divisions are becoming more frequent. The obligation of the High Representative, according to the Dayton Agreement and the UN Charter, is to protect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and not to contribute to its disintegration.
Dear president,
In addition to the civilian presence, in Bosnia and Herzegovina also there is an international military presence, in the form of the EUFOR mission and the NATO headquarters, with a total of 1,100 members. Bosnia and Herzegovina is not specific in that respect either, because many, much more developed, also sovereign states have a need for the presence of international military forces, in a much larger number than is the case in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The international military presence was established by the Dayton Peace Agreement, and the Security Council confirms EUFOR's mandate every year.
In less than a month, there will be a new vote in the Security Council on the EUFOR mandate. It is very important for peace and stability in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region that this resolution is adopted, but it is worth emphasizing that in any case, according to the Dayton Agreement, the NATO alliance has the right and obligation to deploy its forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Also, there are decisions of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina which give consent to the presence of EUFOR and NATO forces, without a time limit, and these decisions are a sufficient legal basis for the presence of an international military mission in BiH, until the Presidency of BiH takes a different position.
Dear President,
Bosnia and Herzegovina's foreign policy goals are membership in the European Union and the NATO alliance.
At the session of the European Council in June of this year, space was opened for granting Bosnia and Herzegovina the status of a candidate for membership in the European Union, subject to the fulfilment of certain conditions. In the past period, Bosnia and Herzegovina made some progress in fulfilling 14 priorities from the European Commission's Opinion on Bosnia and Herzegovina's application for EU membership. We achieved some priorities in full, and others partially. It is good news that, in the past weeks, we have continued to fulfil those priorities.
I expect that, after the general elections that will be held on October 2 of this year, BiH will continue on this path even more strongly and get the status of a candidate for EU membership as soon as possible.
When it comes to relations with the NATO alliance, Bosnia and Herzegovina is part of the Action Plan for membership. The Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina adopted the Program of Reforms, with which Bosnia and Herzegovina fulfils its obligations, on an annual level, when it comes to the reforms that the NATO alliance expects from us, as an aspirant state.
Dear President,
The foreign policy goal of Bosnia and Herzegovina is also regional cooperation. Bosnia and Herzegovina wants good relations with its neighbours, with mutual appreciation, respect and the principle of reciprocity. And that is the only way to build good relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Everyone in the region must understand that the geostrategic and geopolitical configuration of the region is complete, and that the path to security and prosperity is a path of mutual cooperation and solving open issues, in accordance with the principles of international law.
Everyone in the region is equal, no one can dominate anyone, and everyone needs peace and stability.
Dear Chairman,
The whole world needs peace and stability. All current disputes in the world should be resolved on the principles of international law and with the participation of international justice institutions. That is why it is very important to strengthen multilateral mechanisms and institutions. In this sense, I believe that the strength and authority of the UN as a key multilateral mechanism must be strengthened.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by the Chairman of BiH Presidency, Šefik Džaferović, at the ceremonial academy on the occasion of the 30th anniversary of the formation of the First Corps of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia
content:
Respected heroes of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, respected members of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Respected families of shaheeds and fallen soldiers, representatives of veterans' associations, members of the Organizing Committee for the celebration of the 30th anniversary of the formation of the First Corps of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, respected representatives of the executive and legislative authorities at all levels in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Excellences, respected attendees,
I express my gratitude to the Organizing Committee of today's manifestation for their perseverance and efforts to preserve the memory of the heroic journey of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the achievements of the defense and liberation war 1992 – 1995.
Celebrating the 30th anniversary of the First Corps of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina is another confirmation of such efforts, which should be an honor to each of your members, as well as to all of us.
I send special thanks and respect to the families of the shaheeds and fallen fighters of the First Corps of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Today we remember them with the wish that the goals of their struggle remain permanently recorded. We will not forget them. We will not forget their sacrifice and that time of the greatest trial for our homeland.
It was not only the defense of human lives and territory, but a battle for the existence and idea of this country. They preserved it with their lives. And that will remain permanently recorded.
Dear attendees,
The latest aggression against the statehood and integrity of our homeland is the freshest testimony of the sacrifice that the citizens of Sarajevo and all of Bosnia and Herzegovina were ready to make.
In the complete political, informational and economic blockade to which the capital of our country was exposed throughout the aggression, in an extremely difficult and complex military-political situation, thanks to the members of the First Corps of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of BiH, Sarajevo was defended, and with it the belief that we will preserve the integrity of this country.
In the most difficult moments of the fight for the defense of the capital and the survival of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the First Corps of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina led by Generals Mustafa Hajrulahović, Vahid Karavelić and Nedžad Ajnadžić gave their best sons. Among them are the late Safet Hadžić, Enver Šehović and Safet Zajko, heroes of the defense and liberation war. At the time of the most difficult moments for Sarajevo and the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, they believed in its survival and final victory.
We will not and cannot forget our heroes who laid down their lives for the homeland we have today and in which there must be no more room for uncertainty and repetition of the sufferings we went through.
It is up to us and the generations to come to preserve the truth about their righteous struggle and not to allow that truth to ever be endangered by deliberate distortion of facts.
Dear attendees,
The intention of the perpetrators of genocide and the joint criminal enterprise was to destroy the multi-ethnic fabric of our society through mass slaughter, torture, rape, expulsion and robbery. Their followers still dream of ending the political project that brought bloodshed to the entire region.
We witness almost daily threats to secede a part of Bosnia and Herzegovina or abuse of the Dayton constitution with various blockades, in order to force us to agree to a policy of division, exclusivity and inequality for all citizens.
We are witnessing the increasingly open support of our neighbors for such policies in Bosnia and Herzegovina, their lobbying and pressure in the institutions of the European Union in order to comply with such policies. We will not give in to such demands.
Those who want better relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina will have to face the truth, prevent the questioning of the sovereignty and territorial integrity of our country, stop insulting the victims and those who survived the genocide and the joint criminal enterprise, as well as denying the facts confirmed by the courts.
You cannot deny genocide, provide shelter to war criminals, arrest defenders of Bosnia and Herzegovina, reward Hague convicts and then declaratively demand better relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina.
You cannot bypass the official highest institutions in Bosnia and Herzegovina by visiting parts of another entity or only cantons with a majority of one nation. That's not how friendships are made with Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I wish to emphasize this in particular:
Every part of Bosnia and Herzegovina belongs equally to all citizens. To those who think differently, who seek to maintain and deepen divisions in our society under the guise of legitimacy, I am telling them from this place: you will not achieve it. No one wants such a Bosnia and Herzegovina anymore. The majority of our citizens want a modern, democratic, European state where everyone will have the same rights. Neither does the European Union. The messages of European officials are clear and unequivocal and reject the politics of division and ethnic exclusivity.
Dear attendees,
Regardless of everything, the progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot be stopped any longer. The vast majority of our citizens want peace, stability and prosperity, they want to build a common and safe future for themselves and their children.
Time is on the side of those who want a stable Bosnia and Herzegovina, who work for its progress and who want to see it safe and prosperous as a member of the European Union and NATO. And we will make it happen. There is no longer any doubt about that.
Bosnia and Herzegovina will gradually return to what it has always been - a place where people of different religions, cultures and identities live together in security and progress. But with a bitter experience in which there will be no more room for forgetting and tragic mistakes that lead to some new genocide or joint criminal enterprise. Be sure of that.
Thank you.

title: Address by Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Šefik Džaferović, at the Summit of the Crimea Platform
content:
"Dear President Zelensky, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your invitation and the opportunity to speak at this event.
Bosnia and Herzegovina's foreign policy towards international partners, which includes friendly Ukraine, is based on openness and equality, mutual respect for sovereignty and territorial integrity, the principle of peaceful cooperation, respect for international law and respect for mutual interests, which is expressly stated in the Foreign Policy Strategy of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is fully in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations.
On 6th of March, 2014, the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina adopted a special statement on the situation in Ukraine. With that statement, the Presidency expressed its expectation that the newly emerging crisis will be resolved through peaceful and democratic means, dialogue and political negotiations between all relevant parties, with the constructive support of the entire international community, based on globally accepted principles of international law.
On that occasion, the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina also expressed its full support for the efforts aimed at overcoming the current situation and maintaining peace and the necessary security, and called on all parties to the dispute to refrain from the use of force and urgently start a political dialogue for a solution to the emerging situation, in the interest of peace , regional and global stability.
One year after the holding of the illegal and illegitimate referendum, and the consequent illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol by the Russian Federation on 16th of March, 2015 Bosnia and Herzegovina joined the declaration of the high representative on behalf of the EU on Crimea, which confirmed the firm commitment to the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine.
The same declaration continued with the condemnation of that act of violation of international law, and it was pointed out that the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol is a direct challenge to international security, with serious implications on the international legal order that protects the unity and sovereignty of all states.
Also, the commitment to the full implementation of the non-recognition policy, including restrictive measures, was highlighted. Deep concern was reaffirmed over the continued military build-up and deterioration of the human rights situation in the Crimean Peninsula, including the denial of freedom of speech and the persecution of minorities.
The call was repeated to allow international actors in the field of human rights full, free and unrestricted access to the entire territory of Ukraine, including Crimea and Sevastopol.
I repeat, Bosnia and Herzegovina joined this declaration of the high representative on behalf of the European Union on Crimea.
After the Russian Federation's invasion of Ukraine on 24th of February, 2022, Bosnia and Herzegovina, following the aforementioned, joined numerous international documents, such as:
the resolution of the General Assembly of the United Nations "Aggression against Ukraine";
the decision of the Council of Europe on the suspension of the representative office of the Russian Federation from the Council of Europe;
declaration of the high representative on behalf of the European Union on the invasion of the armed forces of the Russian Federation on Ukraine and a series of accompanying declarations, as well as a series of decisions of other international institutions and organizations;
The previously stated positions of Bosnia and Herzegovina were adopted following the decisions of institutions, as well as the international obligations, including the Agreement on Stabilization and Association of BiH with the European Union and other acts.
In the end, despite external and internal pressures, as the chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I can say that the stated official positions of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina on support for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine and on the condemnation of actions that violate the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine have not changed.
Thank you for your attention".

title: BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić attended the event marking the 30th anniversary of arrival of the First Independent Sokolac Battalion to the Olovo warzone in Kruševo, Olovo municipality
content:
Address by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić: "Thank you for the opportunity and giving me the honour to spend some time together today. I remember this unit from the war, from the moments that were great for Bosnia and Herzegovina, from the moments when the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina set out to liberate its territory. What I saw and witnessed when it comes to you is something that is worthy of great respect. In the Army of Bosnia and Herzegovina, each unit was important in its own way and each had its own role, and there were also units such as the Independent Sokolac Battalion, such as the Ilijaš Brigade, which were units composed of people who were expelled from their homes.
What I had the opportunity to see, and I do not wish to offend anyone, was that those units were often orphan-like, but it seems to me that the more they were treated with injustice, the bigger and braver they were, and that is the size of this battalion.
The moment when we met here on the Nišići plateau and when the First Sokolac Battalion came to our zone of responsibility, what I saw when it comes to a battle is worth it for anyone who is honest to oneself and with others to say: kudos people and thank you for being the way you are!
I want to thank you for telling people who you are, what you are, and what you've been like. This place is not cherished just because we can gather and have a chat, this place is cherished because we can remember those who gave their lives for Bosnia and Herzegovina and to thank them. To thank their families and mothers for giving birth to such sons and daughters, and it is up to us to educate our children as much as we can about the value of our fight in that period.
You are the people who did right, and have held your head high. In fact, you are the people who, together with others from the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Police Force of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, saved this country. It is because of your bravery and sacrifice that we walk freely in our country today. It may not be the country we had envisaged, but, whatever its structure, it is still ours. We can proudly say that we did the right thing for our families and for the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and for our homeland.
We did not give up when it was more difficult than it is today. Therefore, this is an opportunity to say that we will never surrender and that we will never give up the fight for this country."

title: Address of the Chairman of BiH Presidency Šefik Džaferović at the solemn ceremony on the occasion of the "Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Respected soldiers of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, respected relatives of shaheeds and fallen soldiers, representatives of veterans' associations, the management of the Sarajevo Canton Memorial Fund, members of the Organizing Committee of the event "Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina-Igman 2022", respected attendees!
It is a particular honor to be at Kovači today. Freedom, honor, pride and homeland are the most important words here. White shaheed's nishaans (tombstones) are the clearest testimony of our fight for Bosnia and Herzegovina, freedom and dignity.
When, in the first post-war days, answers and explanations were sought as to how we managed to defend the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, our president and commander-in-chief, the late Alija Izetbegović, said: "When the miracle of the Bosnian resistance is unraveled from some historical distance, it will be found that the secret was somewhere in the souls or character of people".
Our heroic resistance rests on the sacrifice of those who were ready to stand up against evil and injustice at the cost of their lives and oppose the far superior force of the aggressor. Only such determination, the determination of people who defend the right to survival and citizens who defend the right to freedom and equality, can bear fruit. Such resistance cannot be broken.
Dear attendees,
on this day, we remember one of the most important battles for the defence of Sarajevo and the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the battle of Igman. It is one of the greatest military victories won by the soldiers of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also by our policy, led by the Wartime Presidency of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Commander-in-Chief Alija Izetbegović, which were based on just goals and civilizational achievements.
We were attacked from all sides on Igman. The aggressor was convinced that crushing our resistance was only a matter of time. The soldiers of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina offered unexpected resistance. Despite all expectations and military logic, that resistance continued to grow stronger after the victory at Igman. The army then grew into a superior and victorious military force.
I want to emphasize this in particular: That victory was not only a military one, but also a civilizational one. We chose democracy. We defended the idea and the being of this country. And that is enormous.
Respected warriors of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina,
all peoples who turned their struggle into a healthy and functional state, built it on the heritage of values won by people like you. Sometimes it seems that in the arduous political everyday life, in the difficult political efforts we undertake, under the force of obligations and pressures to which we are exposed, we forget how expensive every piece of Bosnia and Herzegovina that you defended was.
But we will not get tired, rest assured, we will not agree to forget. Because of every hero of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina that we lost. For every innocent victim that has fallen.
With the depth of the tragedy that happened to us, we can measure our obligation to future generations, with the goal of preserving peace and never letting evil repeat itself again.
Dear attendees,
unfortunately, there are still those who openly attack the sovereignty and territorial integrity of our country, question its sustainability, threaten divisions, undermine its institutions and international subjectivity, try to undo the progress that we have painstakingly achieved through joint efforts.
The ideological and political followers of those who were the main organizers of the genocide and the joint criminal enterprise, hinder our progress towards achieving full stability, prosperity and membership in the European Union and NATO.
But it seems that the end of these destructions is getting closer. No one wants to open new wounds in Bosnia and Herzegovina. All significant international factors are decisively opposed to such a policy. Our persistent action and pointing out the perniciousness of such policies, at home and abroad, has helped spark the new resolve we are witnessing. The ideological and political followers of the organizers of the genocide and the joint criminal enterprise are slowly being left alone.
During my mandate, as a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I clearly warned and called on international officials to stop such actions and pointed out its disastrous impact on positive processes in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Amendments to the Criminal Code of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which prohibit the denial of genocide and other war crimes and the glorification of war criminals, confirm that the international community has finally seen this.
Dear attendees,
Allow me to conclude by underlining the following: It is our duty to complete the construction of the nation for which the best among us have given their lives. Let's forget about ideological divisions, party or personal interests, because the interest of the state is above all these individual interests.
We will succeed only if we create an environment in which young people will continue to live with dignity of their work and start families, because that is the only guarantee of the future. We have to keep that in mind every day and work dedicatedly towards that goal.
Thank you.

title: The Chairman of BiH Presidency Šefik Džaferović and Speaker of the House of Commons of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland Lindsay Hoyle spoke at the commemoration on the occasion
content:
The United Kingdom's Equal Development Minister Greg Clark, Shadow Secretary of State David Lammy, Director of the Srebrenica Memorial Center Emir Suljagić, Member of Parliament and former commander of the British UNPROFOR Battalion Bob Stewart, MPs Ian Blackford and Fleur Anderson, Baroness Sayee Warsi also spoke as well as Chairman of the "Remembering Srebrenica" Foundation Waqar Azmi.
Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Šefik Džaferović, at the commemoration "Remembering Srebrenica", London.
Honorable representatives of Her Royal Majesty's Parliament and Government, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen,
I thank Mr. Waqar Azmi and "Remembering Srebrenica" for organizing this gathering, as well as the United Kingdom for supporting this commemoration program. Thank you to everyone who contributes to preserving the memory of the genocide.
The genocide in Srebrenica is the biggest crime on European soil after World War II. In less than seven days, after July 11, 1995, units of the Republika Srpska Army and Police killed more than eight thousand Bosniak men and boys. The executions were carried out in the manner of Einsatzgruppen squads: the victims were taken out in small groups of five to ten people, blindfolded, shot in the back or the back of the head, and then buried in mass graves.
After the authorities of the United States of America, in the summer of 1995, published satellite images of mass graves, the authorities of Republika Srpska launched an operation to move mass graves from primary locations to secondary and tertiary locations in order to cover up the crimes. This led to the fact that the remains were buried in two, and often in three different mass graves, which are tens of kilometers apart.
This crime represents one of the darkest pages in the history of the 20th century, among other things, because it was committed in the presence of United Nations military forces. The passivity of the United Nations in Srebrenica was only the culmination of their passive and neutral attitude during more than three years of war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, from 1992 to 1995.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The lessons of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and especially the mistakes of the United Nations in Srebrenica, must be an eternal guide for the international community, especially today, when we are witnessing the aggression against Ukraine, followed by a criminal campaign.
One of the reasons that led to the genocide in Srebrenica was the unjust introduction of an embargo on the import of weapons, which deprived Bosnia and Herzegovina of the right to self-defense, guaranteed by the Charter of the United Nations, at the very beginning of the war in 1992. We were exposed to the brutal aggression of neighboring Serbia, which inherited all the weapons of the Yugoslav People's Army, and by committing systematic and mass crimes, tried to change the demographic picture of a large part of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in order to annex it and incorporate it into the so-called "great Serbia".
Another tendency that led to the genocide was the neutral and relativizing attitude of some international officials, primarily United Nations officials such as Boutros Ghali and Yasushi Akashi, who constantly relativized the crimes committed, equated victims and criminals, and opposed the intervention of international forces.
Some of the rare voices of common sense in those dark years were former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Lord Paddy Ashdown, to whom I would like to give recognition and respect on this occasion, because they recognized from the very beginning who was the victim and who was the aggressor, and demanded the action of the international community in order for crimes to be stopped. Later developments confirmed the correctness of their views.
Today, when Ukraine is faced with the aggression of a neighboring country and when crimes are committed against the civilian population in Ukraine, the lessons from Bosnia and Herzegovina have never been more important. Instead of an embargo, the attacked state must be allowed to defend itself, and the international public must not be allowed to find justifications for aggression and crimes. There must be a clear distinction between criminals and victims, because anything else leads us to darkness and the moral collapse of humanity.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I am grateful to the authorities of the United Kingdom for their contribution to the intervention of the NATO alliance, which stopped the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina and concluded the Dayton Peace Agreement.
I am also grateful for the support that the United Kingdom has given in the past 27 years of the implementation of the peace agreement, primarily when it comes to the integration path of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the strengthening of state institutions. In this sense, we owe special thanks to the late Lord Paddy Ashdown, who served as a high representative of the international community in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Lord Ashdown will remain forever in the memory of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina as an unwavering fighter for justice, and the time of his mandate will be remembered as a golden age of reforms, strengthening the state and prosecution of war criminals. With his activities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Lord Ashdown continued the brightest British tradition of fighting for freedom and against tyranny
Of special importance, in the context of preserving the memory of the genocide, was his decision from 2003, by which the building of the former battery factory in Potočari was handed over to the Memorial Center, which laid the material basis for the formation of the Memorial Center as a state institution in charge of preserving the memory of the genocide in Srebrenica.
I am grateful to the Parliament and the current government of the United Kingdom for their decisive action over the past year, when it comes to suppressing the crisis caused by the secessionist actions of the authorities of Republika Srpska entity. It was thanks to the sanctions imposed by the British authorities on the officials of Republika Srpska, as well as the support that the British government, together with the rest of the Euro-Atlantic community, gave to the High Representative Christian Schmidt in applying the Bonn powers, that the situation stabilized.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The fight for the protection of the victims of the genocide in Srebrenica is not something that only concerns Bosniaks. This really primarily concerns Bosniaks, because the genocide in Srebrenica was a crime against Bosniaks. But punishing the genocide in Srebrenica also concerns the overall international security. We have seen from the example of the shootings in the Syrian Tadamon or the Ukrainian Bucha that crimes are not a thing of the past. We also saw it in the example of the attacks in Norway's Utoya and New Zealand's Christchurch
The outcome of the fight for justice in Bosnia and Herzegovina is monitored not only by civilized people in the world, but also by villains. Whether the crime will be punished or rewarded is something they are also interested in. That is why the fight for justice in Srebrenica is a fight for justice on the whole globe and beyond. That is why the fight for the safety and future of Srebrenica children is a fight for the safety and future of every child.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić at the unveiling of the "Flower of Srebrenica" memorial in Rogno, Italy, which he attended at the invitation of the Association of Bosnian-Herzegovina’s
content:
Dear Mayor of Rogno, representatives of Bosnia and Herzegovina associations, respected ladies and gentlemen It is an honor to be here with you today.
Unfortunately, the occasion is sad and today we remember the thousands of men and boys who were brutally murdered in Srebrenica 27 years ago. We remember the interrupted youth, hope, we remember the interrupted dreams.
Remembrance of all that happened is necessary for the sake of the whole world, to which, unfortunately, it was not enough that what we went through on the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I say, it was not enough because we are still witnessing the forces of evil that reign around us and the suffering of the innocent. After the genocide in Srebrenica, nothing is the same, and our fight for justice and truth is still ongoing. And it will continue until the politicians and individuals who deny what they did, while belittling the innocent victims and their families, go to the dustbin of history.
All of us, who are witnesses to our painful past, have a duty for the sake of new generations and their future not to forget and not to allow such evil to ever happen again.
On the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the genocide in Srebrenica, the Italian Prime Minister said that what happened in Srebrenica was a defeat of our common values. I wish to remind of that important message, which was delivered on behalf of the state and citizens of Italy, especially because, unfortunately, we are still witnessing crimes and violations of basic human rights and international law in Ukraine, which is exposed to Russian aggression.
Europe and humanity must finally learn from the genocide in Srebrenica so that the violence, which innocent people are again exposed to today, can be stopped.
We are reminded of crimes in vain if new crimes are happening before our eyes, and that is why we must all unite in defense of common values, and peace and tolerance among people are the basic values on which the European Union itself is founded.
This "Flower of Srebrenica" here from Rogno, a memorial that was created thanks to your help, empathy and compassion, will send a loud message to the whole world. It will be a silent reminder of innocence, pain and suffering, but at the same time the hope that not a single person should ever again be a victim of a criminal hand.
On behalf of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina who want peace and in my own name, I want to thank you for this expression of respect for the victims of genocide. It is a strong message that the evil committed against one group of people because of their name and origin is evil against the whole of humanity, but at the same time it is also a message that we can resist crime and genocidal intentions only by being united.
It is a pre-requisite for building a better world, based on the values of humanism and cooperation between peoples and countries.

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Šefik Džaferović, at the commemoration of the 27th anniversary of the genocide in Srebrenica, Potočari, 11 July 2022
content:
Dear mothers of Srebrenica, survivors, families of the victims, your excellencies, ladies and gentlemen,
There is no sadder place in the world today than this place right here. Twenty-seven years is enough for the whole world to change, but in one man's life it is not much. At the age of twenty-seven, a man is just entering the mature age, in which he should experience his most important experiences.
Hajrudin Halilović was twenty-seven years old when he was killed in July 1995. In one of the fifty coffins, which we will lay in the cold Potočari soil, there are also his remains. Hajrudin was killed together with his father Alaga. Until the beginning of the war, they lived in the village of Osat, and they came to Srebrenica, like others, because they thought they would find salvation there, after it was declared a "protected zone by the United Nations".
Of Hajrudin, only "right hand, right leg, other arm, some parts of his jaw and very little of his chest bones" were found. He and his father were captured on the fateful July 11 here, in Potočari, in the presence of United Nations military forces, and after that, like thousands of others, they were taken to the vicinity of Zvornik, where they were shot and buried in mass graves.
Twenty-seven years is not much time, but it is an eternity for the families of Hajrudin Halilović and other victims, who spent all those years waiting for the bodies of their loved ones to be found and at least buried. Unfortunately, numerous families still have not found their fathers and sons, brothers and cousins. Hundreds of mothers died before finding even a single bone of their children, which testifies the monstrosity of the crime committed here.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The mass executions committed in July 1995 were not the result of some spontaneous and uncontrolled hatred. On the contrary, the genocide in Srebrenica was a consciously and carefully planned crime, with political motives. It was, namely, the final act of "establishing a corridor in the Drina valley and eliminating the Drina as a border", which Radovan Karadzic had already in May 1992, at the Assembly of Bosnian Serbs, determined as one of the six strategic goals of the war.
The Srebrenica genocide is neither a temporally nor a spatially isolated crime. The men and boys who were captured after the fall of the enclave, in July 1995, were Bosniaks from Podrinje - from Srebrenica, but also from Zvornik, Vlasenica, Bratunac, Višegrad, Rogatica, Han Pijeska and Milići, from where they fled in 1992 before the first wave of crimes and flowed into the "UN protected zone".
After being captured in Potočari and the surrounding forests, they were mostly not killed here, on the spot, but in a well-organized operation they were taken to the broader area of Bratunac and Zvornik, where they were killed, at locations approximately seventy kilometers away from this place. Some were transported as far as Kalinovik or Trnovo, not far from Sarajevo, and were killed there.
The genocide operation was directed by the President of Republika Srpska and the Commander of the General Headquarters of the Army of Republika Srpska. The operation involved the commands and personnel of the Drina Corps, the Zvornik and Bratunac Brigades, then the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Srpska, additional military and police units from Bijeljina, Doboj, Višegrad, and the special police forces of neighboring Serbia, the so-called "Scorpions".
In order to kill thousands of people, thousands of people were needed, those who had clear responsibilities and orders. The genocide was not committed by the Serbian people, nor by any alienated unit, but by the institutional structure of the Republika Srpska, supported by Serbia. The authorities of Serbia and the Republika Srpska entity know all this very well, but they will not admit it.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Denial of crime is not an expression of the denialist's inability to learn and accept the truth. Denying a crime, like covering it up, is just a continuation of its commission. It speaks of a perverted continuity.
We must never forget that Ratko Mladić himself, after the fall of Srebrenica, denied that murders were being planned, assuring the captured Bosniaks themselves, as well as representatives of the international community, that all prisoners would be evacuated. He claimed this after, at a meeting at the Fontana Hotel, he had already given orders to kill all the prisoners. From the beginning to the end of the operation, he denied that the murders were taking place, although he personally visited the execution sites and supervised them.
When the authorities of the United States of America published satellite images of mass graves, the authorities of the Republika Srpska, in the fall of 1995, launched a huge operation of moving corpses from primary to secondary and tertiary mass graves, in order to cover up the traces of the crime.
Not long after that, the authorities of Republika Srpska formed the so-called the "mixed commission", which was supposed to make the first report on the murders of the people of Srebrenica. All the cynicism was reflected in the fact that among the members of the commission was Milorad Trbić, one of the officers of the Zvornik Brigade who organized the executions and relocation of the graves, for which he was later convicted.
In the past years, we have continued to witness the efforts of the Government of Republika Srpska to deny the genocide in Srebrenica, through commission reports and in other ways.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
However, we are attending this commemoration under special conditions. It will soon be a year since the former high representative of the international community, Valentin Inzko, passed the law, after which genocide denial and hate speech based on it almost completely disappeared from the public space.
Mr. Inzko is not here, but I wish to send him a message. Mr. Inzko, thank you for what you have done, because you have not only fulfilled the duty prescribed by your mandate and your conscience, but you have also saved the restoration of trust among the people of this country. History will remember your act as protective towards victims and justice, but also one that protects the peace, because it was your law that stopped the swelling wave of negationism, which retrograde politicians used to poison relations between nations and undermine sensitively built peace.
Thanks also to the member states of the PIC for the support they have given to this law. The experience with the adoption and implementation of this law has shown that more justice means more peace and more hope for a better future. This should be a lesson for the future activities of the international community in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In two days, the mothers of Srebrenica will visit the places of mass murders: Kravica, Orahovac, Petkovce, Branjevo, Kozluk and Pilica. In these small towns, the largest mass murders on the European continent took place after the Second World War. But at none of these execution sites, there is not even a letter about what happened. The local authorities of Zvornik and Bratunac are preventing the installation of signs, because they want to hide the truth.
In the past, the local authorities of these municipalities, through the engagement of their civil protection and utility companies, helped to hide the traces of crimes, and now they do so through the banning of placing signs or renovating a building in Kravica.
If local authorities continue to blatantly prevent the commemoration of the genocide, then, Mr Schmidt, you must do what the late Paddy Ashdown did in 2003 when, as High Representative, he dedicated this building to the Memorial Centre. The warehouse in Kravica and the House of Culture in Pilica, as the places where the genocide was committed, cannot be anything but the genocide monuments. I call on the local authorities to respect the victims and the pain of their families.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
This year, for the first time, the Srebrenica Inferno will be performed by a choir of children from Srebrenica. The terribly sad verses will be even sadder this year, because they are performed by the descendants of the murdered. At the same time, they will also give us hope, because these children are proof that, despite the crime in which entire lineages and surnames were exterminated, Bosniaks survived in Podrinje.
It is the duty of all of us to insist on truth and justice. The obligation of all of us is to do everything necessary for the new generations in Srebrenica, so that they can live and work here. Each of us has to think throughout the year how it is for the Bosniaks in Srebrenica; each of us must come and visit the returnees, help the economic perspective, especially young people. Because the fight against genocidal intent will be successful only if young people decide to stay and live here.
Thank you.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Šefik Džaferović at the 9th Global Baku Forum, Baku, 16th of June 2022
content:
Dear President Aliyev, dear management of the International Centre ”Nizami Ganjavi”, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen! It is a special honour for me to be with you today, at the opening of the Global Baku Forum, which this year is entitled "Challenges to the Global Order". I thank the Nizami Ganjavi International Centre for the invitation and warm hospitality in Baku.
President Aliyev, I wish you success in the reconstruction and rebuilding of Karabakh, success in the implementation of the post-World War II agreement and success in protecting the territorial integrity of Azerbaijan in accordance with international law, as you yourself have said.
What are the challenges to the global world order? To answer this question, we must consider our behaviour in global world crises, such as migration, pandemic, aggression against Ukraine. We all bear the consequences of global crises, although we are not all equally responsible for them.
What can be done to prevent crises or to avoid or mitigate the harmful consequences?
The answer is logical and simple, but, unfortunately, because of the world as it is today, it is difficult to achieve. We all know that the answer lies in greater justice, unity, solidarity, international law, strong and effective multilateral mechanisms. However, we do not seem to be able to achieve that. We say never again after every crisis, and yet the crises keep happening, and these are the crises a man is responsible for. Therefore, using the authority of the Baku Forum, we must constantly emphasize these things and be persistent in the fight for a better world.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
this part of the world is similar to the part of the world I come from. Both the Caucasus and the Balkans are crossroads - places where different worlds meet. Often these places, being at the crossroads of the great empires, were the places of conflict. But at the same time they have been the meeting places of civilizations and cultures. It is thanks to these meetings that new paradigms have been created in these places.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is one such paradigm. My country is not one of the great countries of the world, but it is an extremely important country, even in a global context, precisely because of its paradigm.
For centuries, communities belonging to different cultural and civilizational circles have lived in Bosnia and Herzegovina: Islamic, Roman Catholic and Orthodox, Jewish, etc.
Throughout its history, Bosnia and Herzegovina has been built as a community of diversity, developing special social practices and institutes, unknown to mono-ethnic societies. Knowledge and respect for other people's religious and traditional customs, then cultural syncretism and other practices, have over time become an integral part of the Bosnian-Herzegovinian identity that people in Bosnia and Herzegovina are proud of.
In the last few decades, through globalization, major economic migrations and other processes, something unexpected happened. Multi-ethnicity, which to many seemed like a deviation specific to Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Balkans, has become a feature of developed modern societies. It is now quite normal for people of all races and many cultures to live in one society. The whole world has become a crossroads.
It is no longer a question - whether our societies can and should be multi-ethnic, because they already are. The only question is how to organize life in them, for the benefit of all their members. What is applicable to a society anywhere in the world, is applicable for the world as a whole, as a global society.
Dear friends,
the global order, as we have known it for decades, was founded after the end of World War II, as a counterbalance to the Nazi project aimed at destroying multi-ethnic societies, eradicating or enslaving entire nations, and regulating international relations on the principle of force and domination.
Awareness that all parts of the world are interdependent, and that regional crises can turn into world fires, has prompted the international community to establish global institutions and a rule-based order. The mission of the United Nations, defined in the founding acts, is to ensure international peace, with dialogue, tolerance and pluralistic awareness.
Today, when, after the experiences of the pandemic and aggression against Ukraine, we talk about the challenges to the global order, we state the impossibility of multilateral institutions to respond to the challenges of the era. We are witnessing a violation of international law.
What we should not forget is that this process has not started now. The greatest collapse, after the Second World War, the United Nations experienced in Bosnia and Herzegovina, in the period from 1992 to 1995.
For the first time since the founding of the UN, a war was launched on European soil aimed at forcibly seizing part of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina and exterminating the Bosniak people, as a community that was to be protected by the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of Genocide.
At the very start of the war, the United Nations Security Council imposed an unjust embargo on arms imports to Bosnia and Herzegovina, preventing us from exercising our right to self-defense under the Charter of the United Nations.
