At the same time, the United Nations failed to protect Bosnia and Herzegovina, its member, which was subjected to brutal aggression from its neighbourhood.
The fact that for more than three and a half years, mass crimes in Bosnia and Herzegovina were committed in the presence of the United Nations military force, UNPROFOR, has ruined the credibility of this world's largest organization. Finally, in July 1995, despite the presence of UNPROFOR, the genocide was committed in Srebrenica, the largest massacre on European soil since World War II, in which more than 8,000 people were killed in just a few days.
The fact that the institutions of the international order, primarily the Security Council, had the opportunity to prevent the genocide in Srebrenica, but did not do so, due to indecision, left lasting consequences on the credibility of the UN.
I see the biggest defeat of the United Nations today in the fact that none of them even expects to stop the aggression against Ukraine and crimes against the civilian population. The adoption of the UN General Assembly resolution condemning the aggression against Ukraine is a significant act, but if it exhausts the possibilities of the UN, then there is no doubt that the system must be reformed. International peace and the inviolability of the borders of sovereign states cannot be held hostage by the vetoes of privileged states.
Dear friends,
in anticipation of the reform of the United Nations system, as a long-term and comprehensive solution, we must also think of current solutions. In this regard, I will refer again to the experience of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The Dayton Peace Agreement, which ended the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, was signed after NATO intervention, based on a Security Council resolution, and was implemented thanks to the presence of NATO troops and the international civilian community, primarily through the Office of High Representative as an institution which was given the right to annul acts contrary to the Dayton Agreement and to sanction officials who violate this agreement.
During the 27 years of implementation of the Dayton Agreement, High Representative acts with the support of the Peace Implementation Council, which elects him, and reports to the Security Council, fulfilling the obligations of Chapter 7 of the UN Charter on International Peacekeeping Actions.
The effectiveness of the international community in BiH has been demonstrated in recent months, when the Republika Srpska entity launched a series of secessionist activities, seeking to overthrow state institutions required by the Constitution to preserve sovereignty and territorial integrity, such as a unified armed forces, judiciary, tax system and others.
Members of the Peace Implementation Council imposed sanctions on those responsible for secessionist activities, and High Representative used his powers to repeal acts contrary to the Dayton Accords, making a crucial contribution to stabilizing the situation.
Thanks to multilateral action and the action of the international community system, the worst-case scenario was prevented - the spillover of war from Ukraine to Bosnia and Herzegovina, but to ensure long-term stability we will need much more caution, wisdom and, above all, determination.
Dear friends,
I spoke about the challenges to the global order mainly through the example of my country, because the example of Bosnia and Herzegovina clearly shows that when multilateral mechanisms fulfil their mission, things move forward and peace can be protected.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Šefik Džaferović at the South East European Cooperation Process Summit, 10th of June 2022
content:
Ladies and Gentlemen, I am pleased to see you again, a year after the last summit in Antalya. I wish to thank Prime Minister Mitsotakis for the cordial hospitality and organization of the Summit.
We have often heard, at similar gatherings in recent years, that the world is changing rapidly, and these changes have been elucidated in detail. Today, after the pandemic and the aggression against Ukraine, it has become more than obvious that the world is no longer the same. The entire security architecture of the European continent has changed.
At this moment, it is of the utmost importance to help Ukraine defend itself from aggression. The lesson we need to know is that peace will be increasingly closer, as the aggressor becomes more aware that with time, the aggressor will have to pay the higher price.
Unlike Bosnia and Herzegovina, which had an unfair embargo on arms imports imposed during the 1992-1995 aggression, Ukraine was provided with timely defense weapons. This shows that, although history repeats itself, the international community has leart some lessons. The most important thing is to preserve European and Euro-Atlantic unity. Were it not for that unity and support for Ukraine, the question would be where would the aggression have ended.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
the war in Ukraine has not yet spread to other countries, but its implications are enormous. This can be seen in the Western Balkans, and we in Bosnia and Herzegovina are feeling the consequences.
For more than a year now, a severe political crisis has been going on in my country, which has intensified especially just before and after the aggression against Ukraine.
It is no secret that there are actors in Bosnia and Herzegovina who are under the Russian influence. It was they who, through their actions, called into question the Dayton Agreement and 27 years of its implementation, threatening secession and taking concrete anti-constitutional steps leading towards that goal. This seems to be a threat to the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which our Constitution defines as necessary to preserve the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina, such as the unified Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the tax system, judiciary and others.
Thanks to the support of the international community, led by the United States, the European Union and the United Kingdom, we are managing to keep things under control, even though the situation is still very fragile. It is essential that the international community re-strengthen the mechanisms established in Bosnia and Herzegovina, based on Chapter 7 of the UN Charter, which calls for international action to preserve peace. I am thinking primarily of the Office of the High Representative and the international military mission - EUFOR.
The High Representative, in fulfilling his obligations under the Dayton Accords and using the powers deriving from that agreement, has annulled some secessionist moves by the government of the Bosnian-Herzegovinian entity of Republika Srpska, which threaten the constitutional order and peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina. At the same time, the High Representative thwarted the attempt of some ministers, who, abusing the right of ethnic veto, tried to suspend democracy in Bosnia and Herzegovina, making the elections conditional on changes to the Election Law.
The Dayton Peace Accords aimed to stop the war. That is why the system it established remained unfinished. Opportunities for blockades and abuses remain, especially when it comes to using ethnic and entity vetoes.
Simply put, national actors have been given the opportunity to block almost every decision and paralyze the entire system with impunity. The only instance that could sanction them and unblock the system is the Office of the High Representative, which is why it had been formed.
We need to build national accountability mechanisms and complete the system, so that we could function without Office of High Representative (OHR). Our goal is not for the OHR to remain forever, but to complete the construction of a functional system, so that, even when the OHR leaves one day, the state can function independently. Until then, we will need international supervision, just as it was extremely useful in the form of Allied control councils to other countries, such as Germany and Austria, after the Second World War. Thanks to that supervision and international support, and not in spite of it, these countries have become among the most organized countries in Europe.
Dear friends,
Bosnia and Herzegovina's strategic goals are membership in the European Union and NATO. We have made remarkable progress since the Stability Pact held in Sarajevo in 1999, when the countries of South East Europe were promised a Euro-Atlantic perspective, and through the Thessaloniki Summit in 2003, when the European Union opened its doors. We have implemented a number of reforms and significantly improved relations in the region.
It is clear to us that there are a number of problems within the EU that have resulted in fears of enlargement. But we should never forget that the European Union, despite all the difficulties, became stronger, better and safer with the addition of new members than it would have been without them. I have no dilemma that this would be the case with the inclusion of Bosnia and Herzegovina and other countries in this part of Europe.
That is why I expect that Bosnia and Herzegovina's European path will be strongly supported and furthered at the upcoming European Union-Western Balkans Summit this month.
I support the initiative presented here by President Pahor to grant Bosnia and Herzegovina candidate status. This would repay the debt to Bosnia and Herzegovina by the international community.
In 2004, Bosnia and Herzegovina was shoulder to shoulder with Croatia on the EU path, but due to the failure of the international community to meet the obligations foresighted by the Dayton Agreement, it eventually lost pace.
I also expect that at the next NATO summit, the NATO integration path of Bosnia and Herzegovina will be strongly supported and improved.
Bosnia and Herzegovina supports regional cooperation. We want to build good relations with our neighbours, resolve open questions through dialogue, and if that is not possible, then through the institutions of international law.
We have confirmed our commitment to regional cooperation by joining the Common Regional Market, within the Berlin Process. We are extremely interested in the implementation of this initiative, in cooperation with the EU, in order to enable our citizens to consume the four basic freedoms of movement (people, goods, services and capital) throughout the Western Balkans. That is why I am extremely pleased that the resolution of this summit supports the Berlin Process as well as the Common Regional Market.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a credible partner for regional cooperation, and we want to make a strong contribution to these processes in order to ensure a peaceful, stable and prosperous future for our citizens.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Šefik Džaferović at the meeting with ambassadors of the North Atlantic Council in Brussels, 25th of May 2022
content:
Dear ambassadors of the member states, and NATO Deputy Secretary General! It is a great honour and pleasure for me to address this esteemed body of the North Atlantic Alliance and acquaint you with the situation in my country.
In the past few years, and especially the last one, Bosnia and Herzegovina has been experiencing a deep crisis, which has called into question 27 years of painstakingly built peace. Irresponsible actors within Bosnia and Herzegovina, motivated by malignant influence from abroad, set out to unilaterally violate the Dayton Peace Agreement and 27 years of results of its implementation. The sense of security of the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina has been seriously undermined.
The situation in my country has further complicated the consequences of the Russian aggression on Ukraine and the disruption of the overall security architecture that has been the foundation of European security for decades. The horror scenes we are witnessing in Ukraine these days remind us of the bloody scenes that came from Bosnia and Herzegovina, before the conclusion of the Dayton Peace Agreement.
The fact that the Dayton Agreement, as a cornerstone of security in the Balkans and overall European security, has been called into question deserves the full attention of this esteemed body.
Dear ambassadors and NATO Deputy Secretary General,
NATO played a crucial role in ending the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. During more than three and a half years of aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina, the United Nations and the then European Community failed to bring peace and stop crimes.
The passivity and artificial neutrality with which the UN acceded, especially encouraged those who tried to destroy and divide Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the culmination resulted with the genocide in Srebrenica, which was committed in the presence of United Nations military forces.
The essential change came only with the inclusion of NATO, which, with its intervention, did what the United Nations should have done. NATO stopped the war and brutal aggression against an internationally recognized state, and stopped horrific crimes and partially punished their perpetrators. Although the intervention came with a delay, thanks to it, the hope survived that there is still a civilization and the belief that the principles of the United Nations Charter and the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of Genocide are not meaningless.
The conclusion of the Dayton Peace Agreement ensured long-term peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which until then had looked impossible. Thanks to the decision of the North Atlantic Council, and based on the provisions of the Dayton Agreement and the Security Council resolution, the presence of NATO military forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina, within the international peacekeeping missions IFOR and SFOR, was enabled.
In the most critical period of the implementation of the Dayton Agreement, from 1996 to 2004, NATO military forces made a crucial contribution to maintaining peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It was one of the most successful international military missions in recent history. No attacks were reported on members of the international force, who successfully overcame all security challenges and provided the civilian authorities with the necessary conditions to implement the Dayton Accords.
Dear ambassadors and NATO Deputy Secretary General,
thanks to the support of the international community, as well as our national efforts, we have made significant progress in the past 27 years of implementing the Dayton Accords.
The clear provisions of the Dayton Peace Agreement and the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina provide the possibility for the state to establish additional state institutions and take over the competencies it needs to preserve its sovereignty and territorial integrity.
Implementing this provision, as well as realizing the obligations from our EU and NATO path, we have established one army, intelligence service, judiciary, tax system and numerous other institutions, which are necessary for preserving sovereignty and territorial integrity. Thanks to these institutions, Bosnia and Herzegovina has increasingly become able to function independently.
Thanks to the strengthening of Bosnia and Herzegovina's state institutions, things have progressed to such an extent that peace and stability could be preserved, even after the initial 60,000 international troops were reduced to just 600, which was unthinkable after the end of the war when the three warring sides were still very wary of each other.
Unfortunately, in the past ten months, we have witnessed a brutal attack on these state institutions. Authorities in the Republika Srpska entity, an administrative unit within Bosnia and Herzegovina established by the Dayton Peace Accords, have threatened to unilaterally disband state institutions.
Threats of secession, as well as an attempt by the authorities of the lower administrative unit to take over the powers of the state needed to preserve its sovereignty and territorial integrity, are an open attack on the constitutional order.
Considering NATO's role in concluding and implementing the Dayton Peace Agreement, as well as its overall mandate when it comes to protecting European security, let me warn this esteemed body of the dangers of these secessionist activities, which threaten the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina and undermine European security.
Dear ambassadors and NATO Deputy Secretary General,
Bosnia and Herzegovina should not go backwards, through the annulment of 27 years of progress. We need to turn to the future, reforms and economic development, with full respect for the constitutional and legal system, which we have created through the implementation of the Dayton Agreement. Bosnia and Herzegovina should continue its path towards the European Union and NATO, in accordance with the assumed international obligations and decisions of its institutions.
When we talk about the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina, we often hear calls for internal dialogue and consensus. The problem in Bosnia and Herzegovina is not the lack of dialogue and consensus at all. The problem is that the actors from the Republika Srpska entity do not adhere to the existing solutions that we came to precisely through painstaking dialogue and consensus.
The best such example is the NATO path of Bosnia and Herzegovina. As a country, we paved our NATO path many years ago. With the consent of everyone in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including representatives from the Republika Srpska entity, we adopted the Law on Defence in the Parliamentary Assembly, which clearly states that the goal of Bosnia and Herzegovina is membership in the NATO Alliance.
Thereafter, the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, based on consensus, submitted an application for membership in NATO, which provided Bosnia and Herzegovina with the Membership Action Plan (MAP).
When, acting on these decisions, the NATO Secretary General requested from Bosnia and Herzegovina to submit the first Annual National Program in December 2018, based on the obligations arising from the MAP, there was a problem because the Republika Srpska representatives, contrary to the laws and the decisions made, said that everything we had achieved was no longer valid.
After a year of painstaking efforts, we finally managed to resolve this by submitting a Reform Program to NATO. Two years later, the Republika Srpska entity representatives in the Council of Ministers are obstructing the adoption and submission of a new cycle of reform programs, slowing Bosnia and Herzegovina's compliance with the NATO's commitments.
Personally, I believe that the Republika Srpska representatives did not independently deviate from the realization of the agreement, but did so at the request of the Russian Federation, which openly expressed interest in stopping our NATO path. It is obvious that the blockade of institutions and the lack of realization of adopted decisions has become a means of blocking NATO's path.
In any case, we cannot talk about dialogue and consensus, if the authorities of the RS entity obstruct what came about as a result of dialogue and consensus, whether it is the Reform Program, the BiH Armed Forces or something else. The basic precondition for a dialogue and consensus is that the established solutions are respected.
I therefore call on this esteemed body to insist on the actors in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region to respect the achieved solutions and hold accountable all those who unilaterally deviate from them. This will best protect the Dayton Agreement, stability within Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the degree of integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina into NATO.
I call on the Allies to send strong signals and support furthering of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s NATO path at the upcoming Strategic Concept part of the NATO Summit in Madrid, in order to send a clear message to those who want to stop this process.
In recent times, we have been hearing messages from NATO that, in addition to protecting its members, it will also provide support to aspiring countries in response to the widening of aggression against Ukraine. We thank you for that, but we believe that it is not enough when it comes to Bosnia and Herzegovina. According to the Dayton Peace Agreement, NATO has an obligation to protect the peace, stability, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which should be clearly stated at the Madrid Summit.
Dear ambassadors and NATO Deputy Secretary General,
Bosnia and Herzegovina aspires to join NATO and we support the integration of other aspiring countries. We reject any conditioning of anyone's path with the changes to the Election Law in Bosnia and Herzegovina that we have been recently hearing in the public space.
Reform of the Election Law has been a problem that Bosnia and Herzegovina has been facing since 2009, when the European Court of Human Rights ruled in Sejdić-Finci case and determined that our electoral system needs to be improved. Members of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina are currently elected according to the system established by the Dayton Peace Agreement. Our obligation is to harmonize the Election Law with the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights and to ensure the rights of those citizens who do not belong to any of the constituent peoples.
Dear ambassadors and NATO Deputy Secretary General,
given that Bosnia and Herzegovina, due to the complex decision-making system established in Dayton, does not have fully developed own mechanisms for the timely prevention of secessionist activities, we need the support of the international community. Experience with the implementation of the Dayton Agreement shows that such support has always proved useful and effective.
This was shown at the beginning of this year, when we had security incidents in January. Simultaneously, in several cities in the Republika Srpska entity, people who returned to their homes after the war were intimidated. This introduced a sense of insecurity, which culminated after the Russian aggression on Ukraine.
The deployment of additional EUFOR troops has helped increase the sense of security. Given that NATO member states are participating in the EUFOR mission, I take this opportunity to welcome the decision to deploy additional forces, while remaining convinced that it is better to prevent a fire than to extinguish it.
What is most worrying at the moment is that, after the Russian aggression in Ukraine, the extension of EUFOR's mandate in the Security Council has been called into question. This is the result of the joint action of the authorities of the Republika Srpska entity and the Russian Federation, which has recently started discrediting the EUFOR mission, questioning the scope of its executive mandate.
After the possibility of renewing the NATO mission instead of EUFOR was opened, the Republika Srpska government softened their stance on EUFOR, and a few days ago openly supported the EUFOR mission, suggesting that its status should no longer be determined by the international community, but that there should be a new agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU put in place.
There should be no new decisions made with regards to the presence of international military forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina. This is a proposal, which carries with it the danger that those who threaten secession, block state institutions and question our NATO path and the Dayton Peace Agreement would play a decisive role in the duration and scope of EUFOR's mandate. In order to implement the military aspects of the Dayton Agreement, EUFOR forces must not be politically dependent on these political actors.
I believe that the EUFOR mandate will not be challenged in the Security Council in November this year. Should any of the permanent members of the Security Council veto it, I would like to make it clear that the international military force nevertheless has the right and obligation to continue its mandate in Bosnia and Herzegovina, based on the Dayton Peace Agreement and other acts earlier institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina had agreed to the presence of an international military mission.
Bearing in mind that, in addition to EUFOR, NATO Headquarters in Sarajevo is the legal successor to the original missions, I call on the North Atlantic Council to contribute to ensuring the smooth continuation of the military mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina, in accordance with its obligations under Annex 1 of the Dayton Peace Agreement.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Šefik Džaferović at the main event in Sarajevo marking the 30th anniversary of the membership of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the United Nations
content:
Ladies and Gentlemen, Resident Coordinator Macdonald, Your excellences! It is a great pleasure to address you on the occasion of this important jubilee. On this day, 30 years ago, Bosnia and Herzegovina became a member of the United Nations. The flag of Bosnia and Herzegovina was raised in front of the East River building, along with the flags of Slovenia and Croatia.
That was one of the most significant moments in our history, it was solemn, but we did not celebrate. We could not. We were forced to fight for freedom, independence, but also for democracy as we were facing huge sacrifices already.
The international community had accepted the fact that international law is at the foundation of our statehood. Admission to the United Nations was the final stamp on that viewpoint. The highest standards of international law determined the path that had been consistently and transparently met in declaring our independence. Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, almost two-thirds of them, of all ethnicities, showed political maturity, responsibility in the face of history and generations to come and voted for independence on February 29 and March 1, 1992.
The international community accepted this, and the whole world recognized Bosnia and Herzegovina. The government of Bosnia and Herzegovina, under unimaginably difficult circumstances, ensured that, in addition to individual recognitions, Bosnia and Herzegovina was affirmed at the multilateral and global level. We entered the world stage on May 22, 1992, with the UN Resolution No. 757, and since then our intensive and meaningful relationship with the UN Organization and its agencies has continued. Thirty years of membership deserves a much more detailed and meaningful review, but allow me to iterate the following in the shortest terms.
The international recognition of Bosnia and Herzegovina and simultaneous admission to the UN was an important and irreversible diplomatic act. The symbolic message of the international community and the UN that it stood with Bosnia and Herzegovina's independence, however, was brutally tested on the ground in Bosnia and Herzegovina itself, but also in international forums where the act of international recognition and admission to the UN would become an important capital of the war-torn state. The UN membership was of key significance. There are only a few countries in the world that have had such a historic disaster as Bosnia and Herzegovina that their mere survival depended on the UN, and to be among those who experienced the consequences of the inefficiency of the UN system on the ground.
Although the UN has had many successes and failures in peacekeeping operations during its existence, only the tragic scale of crimes and genocide in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and also in Rwanda, would affect changes in the institutional culture of "peacekeeping" developed by the UN Secretariat and which had not recognized the possibility of humanitarian intervention to protect civilians from crimes against humanity.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, in a specific international context, can be described as a victim of the passivity of the international community, but by no means only as an object but a state that has shown exceptional, even unprecedented intensity of diplomatic activity. We have failed to reform the UN, or to change the post-Cold War state of relations in the international community, and, unfortunately, this is a process that still remains to be completed.
However, even the subtle changes in the course of this cumbersome global mechanism, reflected in the consideration and introduction of new concepts of protection of civilians in war conflicts, international punishment of crimes and, in particular, sexual crimes against women, can be considered significant global diplomatic successes of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Countries with much greater foreign policy capacity would have found it difficult to accomplish such changes.
Allow me also to point out the fact that each of the 55 UNSC resolutions from this period, which refer to Bosnia and Herzegovina and the situation in the former Yugoslavia, was very clear and precise in terms of describing the situation and events on the ground. This would prove extremely important for determining the character of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which at that time was interpreted differencly.
The diplomatic mission of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the UN was, of course, among the first and most important diplomatic missions of Bosnia and Herzegovina and, let me highlight, the contribution of the mission had in the formation of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. The Hague tribunal and its attitude towards it, even after its formal closure in November 2017, remained a measure of political decency and emancipation from the aggressive nationalism of the 1990s for all countries of the former Yugoslavia. Based on that experience, Bosnia and Herzegovina was an active participant in the establishment of the International Criminal Court.
Global visibility and experience gained by Bosnia and Herzegovina in the early 1990s would prove to be a very important political and diplomatic resource even in years when Bosnia and Herzegovina was no longer high on the agenda of international issues, and when faced with a different position in the UN - the one all other countries enjoy, and whereby, given the size and capacity of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is very difficult to be noticed.
Although the intensity of diplomatic activities has been reduced to a regular, peacetime level, Bosnia and Herzegovina has remained, for a country of its size and foreign policy capacity, a very visible, committed and active member of the United Nations. One part of these activities is still related to cooperation with the UN and UN agencies in the implementation of the Dayton Peace Agreement, and the impact and shaping of the UN engagement, because Bosnia and Herzegovina has remained, to this day, one of the topics at UN Security Council meetings.
The second part of our diplomatic activities is dedicated to sharing experiences in conflict and post-conflict situations. In the UN environment, I can convey this to you first hand, and the BiH ambassadors present at the UN can confirm this, the fact that is especially appreciated is that in less than ten years since the end of the war, Bosnia and Herzegovina moved from a country which hosted international military forces to the category of a state participating in peacekeeping missions.
Bosnian-Herzegovinian troops were part of peacekeeping missions in Afghanistan, Congo and Mali, and police officers in Cyprus, and in Liberia, South Sudan, Afghanistan, Somalia and the Central African Republic. So far, more than 2,000 troops and several hundred police officers have participated in UN peacekeeping missions.
Our engagement in the UN and the attitudes we have promoted have best confirmed that we share the principles and values of the UN Charter.
This was recognized and rewarded with the greatest diplomatic success of BiH - membership in the UN Security Council in the period 2010-2011 as a non-permanent member. It is a source of great pride for Bosnia and Herzegovina that 174 UN members voted FOR its non-permanent membership in the UN Security Council.
Furthermore, perhaps more importantly, the two-year term in this "global government" meant that Bosnia and Herzegovina experienced new foreign policy and diplomatic challenges, to which we, united as rarely we were, successfully responded. The intensity and content of our diplomatic activities confirmed Bosnia and Herzegovina as an equal and competent partner in the international community, and an actor whose diplomatic performance is often well above objective foreign policy capacities. We can also thank our outstanding ambassadors and mission staff for this.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
We have shown visibility and commitment in many other UN bodies, as well as in Bosnia and Herzegovina itself, through active and successful cooperation with UN agencies. Our view of the UN is realistic and balanced - we understand and see the difficulties and global challenges facing the UN, but we also recognize the value of these goals and the need for humanity to make this organization a success. That is why we remain committed to these principles and goals and we want to share our experience and offer our full contribution.
Our position in the United Nations is determined by universal trends of intensifying globalization and interdependence, realistic foreign policy capacities of Bosnia and Herzegovina, harmonized foreign policy goals of BiH, sustainable development goals, and high intensity of diplomatic activities of our missions in the United Nations. Therefore, I firmly believe that Bosnia and Herzegovina will continue to consistently fulfill its obligations and exercise its rights as a full member of the United Nations.
Finally, on the occasion of the 30th anniversary of Bosnia and Herzegovina's accession to the United Nations, allow me extend my words of gratitude and sincere congratulations to all officials and international officials of the UN and its agencies, international and local staff of the UN and UN agencies in Bosnia and Herzegovina, UN volunteers, as well as Bosnian-Herzegovinian ambassadors and diplomats who, with their professional and personal engagement, have contributed to successful membership in these 30 years.
I invite you to continue working daily with the younger generations to the benefit of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to promote peace, cooperation and sustainable development in the United Nations community.
8 PHOTO GALLERY

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić on the occasion of marking the 30th anniversary of the formation of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina in Mostar
content:
Dear comrades-in-arms, citizens of Mostar, Herzegovina, it is my great pleasure to be here with you today, on the day when we mark the 30th anniversary of the formation of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
From this time distance of thirty years, and when we take into account the existing political and security context, we can say with certainty that the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, together with the Ministry of Interior of the Republic of BiH, is most deserving for the survival of Bosnia and Herzegovina. No one is more deserving than members of the Army of the Republic of BiH and the Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of BiH for the fact that the admission of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the United Nations in May 1992 did not remain a dead letter.
Left by the United Nations at the mercy of the aggressor, members of the Republic of BiH Army, at first, with almost no means to fight and defend the state, made superhuman efforts to preserve their homeland, and they succeeded. There were moments, especially during the difficult 1993, when, due to the double aggression on the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, everything seemed to be lost, but even then we did not give up nor did we lose hope.
The negotiating table was never sat at in circumstances when the forces of the Army of the Republic of BiH were in an unfavourable position, but the opposite. I want to note here that the Washington and Dayton Accords were preceded by the defeats of the aggressor forces. So, the peace agreements were signed only after the Army of the Republic of BiH crushed the attacks of the aggressors, and that is what must not be lost sight of today, because I have a feeling, like, I believe, many of us here, that we would not be in the end allowed to be victorious. Because it was just enough that the embargo was imposed on us, we were supposed to be prevented from liberating our homeland with the weapons we took from the aggressors.
Each of the seven corps of the Army of the Republic of BiH has made a huge contribution to the defence of the homeland, however, here today I want to emphasize the importance of the Fourth Corps of the Army of the Republic of BiH, which during the aggression, almost the entire time fought against two enemies. Members of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina felt the burden on their shoulders the most in this city, where they poured into, after they fled and were expelled from the south and southeast of our country. The heroic deeds of the people of Mostar who, as one of the Mostar commanders said, fought to the end, regardless of the price, saved not only this city, but also the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina in this area. We should certainly never forget the struggle of the people of Konjic and Jablanica, which was of exceptional strategic importance for communication with Sarajevo. If the aggressor had managed to hijack the military industry in Konjic, the question is how this war would have ended. Maybe we would look at the same pictures like those from Srebrenica or the pictures we see today in Ukraine. Therefore, the importance of the Fourth Corps for the defense of the state is immeasurable, and I use this opportunity to congratulate my comrades on everything that has been done.
However, even thirty years later, the attacks on the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina have not stopped, they are only being conducted by other means. The judgments of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia continue to be rejected, and on the basis of what has been ruled, the policies of some parties in the country are still being pursued and implemented, supported by policies from outside the country.
The "Six" verdict established that there was an international armed conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the state of occupation, in a way that neighbouring Croatia carried out control through local bodies in the so-called Herzeg-Bosna.
According to the verdict, the goal of this joint criminal enterprise was to establish an ethnically pure entity, at least partly within the 1939 Banovina of Croatia borders, and its annexation to Croatia, in order to re-establish the alleged unification of the Croat people in the event of disintegration of Bosnia and Herzegovina or it becomes an independent state within Bosnia and Herzegovina, closely connected with Croatia.
In that regard, the verdict established, among other things, that the HVO and the so-called The Croat community of Herzeg-Bosna was in the function of achieving various aspects of the joint criminal enterprise of establishing an ethnically homogeneous space. It was especially established that Croatia, i.e. its then leadership, committed aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina, and that Franjo Tuđman, Gojko Šušak and others were part of a joint criminal enterprise.
If we compare this with today's HDZ policies in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and especially with the views we hear from official Zagreb, we can clearly conclude that these are the same policies today, i.e. the continuation of the joint criminal enterprise in peacetime, through limited reform of the Constitution and electoral legislation of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
How else to understand such an aspiration for ethnically pure constituencies, related to the parts of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina from which the so-called legitimate political representatives of the constituent peoples should be arriving. The involvement of neighbouring Croatia in the internal affairs of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is realized through their satellites from the HDZ, can easily be shown by examples of undetermined interstate border, the problem around the border in Kostajnica, the issue of Trgovska gora, and unauthorized use of hydro potential from the Lake of Buško neighbouring Croatia benefits from on the basis of an agreement made with the so-called Herzeg-Bosna. And, finally, the issue of the interstate border at sea, where we are visibly faulted against, which HDZ representatives in the government structures of Bosnia and Herzegovina obstruct and do not allow these issues to be resolved. They are clearly working for the benefit and interest of neighbouring Croatia, and almost never in the interest of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Aren't these sufficient indicators of the continued realization of the goals of the joint criminal enterprise?
Let us add to that the story about the reform of the election legislation, which can only be done if European standards are fully applied, i.e. in accordance with what is ordered in the Opinion of the European Commission and the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights. And you know what the problem is? Those who would further ethnically divide this country and deliver our state sovereignty to neighboring Croatia and Serbia, giving them unlimited political power to govern our Bosnia and Herzegovina, will not accept something like that.
You will easily recognize which political actors are involved, and who directs their entire political activity towards the realization of the political interests of neighboring countries. That is absolutely unacceptable. This devalues our heroic struggle for Bosnia and Herzegovina. We must say a resounding NO to such people and stop any further ethnic and territorial division of the country, in order to preserve the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The country can be preserved and even improved in only one way, and that is that all its citizens have the same rights, that we organize the country as a state of equal citizens, regardless of their ethnic, religious or cultural affiliation. This is the ideal of a civil Bosnia and Herzegovina in which we are all equal, and thus it does not annul, usurp, or touch anyone's ethnic or religious identity.
Some may say that it is the idealism, that it is impossible, a utopia, but I think it is possible.
If in 1993 we did not believe that it was possible to defend the state, today we would not have a state like this, which is not perfect, but it is still ours and we do not have a better one. It is worth fighting for, and it is worth trusting the people who are sincerely fighting for it today. There are enough of them, and there will be as long as there are states. These may be the quietest among us, but therefore the most faithful ones.
4 PHOTO GALLERY

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of BiH Šefik Džaferović on the occasion of marking the 30th anniversary of forming of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the 17th annivers
content:
"Respected families of shaheeds and fallen heroes of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina! Disabled war veterans, war veterans! Gentlemen soldiers, non-commissioned officers and officers! Generals! Congratulations on the 30th anniversary of the formation of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
I also congratulate you on the Day of the 2nd Infantry - Ranger Regiment of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Through its formation and work, we preserve the tradition of our Army, its true achievements, courage, justice, multi-ethnicity and universality of the goals for which the Army fought.
The Second Infantry Ranger Regiment has been cherishing the heritage and the highest values and goals for which the Army of the Republic of BiH fought for and won for years, as the legal army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina! That is Bosnia and Herzegovina, a state of equal peoples and all its citizens.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
This is an opportunity for all of us to remember the historical role of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina in defending our homeland, to confirm and emphasize once again that we will continue to defend the values for which our best sons gave their lives and health, and that we must care for the families of shaheeds , fallen heroes and disabled veterans.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a state whose obligation and goal is to achieve the lofty idea of a free, independent and prosperous Bosnia and Herzegovina, free and prosperous for all its peoples and citizens, and the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina have significantly given, give and will continue to contribute to that, primarily through its professional execution of legally defined missions and tasks.
Our Armed Forces are the only legitimate military force of our state, made up of the people and citizens who live in it, ready to act and help on the entire territory. They are the only guarantor of peace and security both in the country and when it comes to taking part in the security structure of Europe and the Euro-Atlantic area. The process of reforms, in which the Armed Forces are still present today, is a process of their continuous advance towards NATO and the EU and in which they are growing into a respectable factor of stability and security in the region and beyond.
I must reiterate that defense reform is the most successful reform Bosnia and Herzegovina has made since the Dayton. The path is not the dismantling of what has been done, but the path is the further construction and strengthening of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This is in the interest of everyone in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The Dayton Peace Agreement and 27 years of patiently built reforms are the framework within which Bosnia and Herzegovina and its Armed Forces can and must act. All this needs to be further improved and we need to especially fight for better technical equipment of the Armed Forces, as well as for a better financial status of members of the Armed Forces.
This is also an opportunity to thank NATO and the international community for their help and support in strengthening the unified Armed Forces of BiH, as well as their readiness to help us in the process of implementing the upcoming reform laws and decisions. What is especially worth emphasizing is that by engaging members of the AFBiH in peacekeeping and peace support missions and thanks to the constant progress in that field, today Bosnia and Herzegovina is no longer just a recipient, but also a provider of international military assistance. And the units of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina are particularly responsible for that.
Gentlemen soldiers, non-commissioned officers and officers,
We are proud of all of you, all of you who inherit the tradition of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which you carry in your heart every day, because you inherit pure, moral and universal values that are valid in all modern democratic societies.
Therefore, we expect you to continue the professional execution of tasks, because in that way you show military responsibility and loyalty to your homeland Bosnia and Herzegovina.
All of us together, the army and the state as one, are committed to a common goal. On this occasion, I would like to emphasize that our ultimate goal is admission and full membership in NATO and the European Union, and that only within Euro-Atlantic democratic institutions can we ensure economic prosperity and security of all citizens throughout BiH.
Once again, I congratulate you on the 30th birthday of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the 17th anniversary of the 2nd Infantry - Ranger Regiment of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina! "

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Šefik Džaferović at the Delphi Economic Forum VII, April 6, 2022, Delphi
content:
Dear President Sakellaropoulou, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, It gives me special pleasure to be here with you, at the Economic Forum VII in Delphi, which is being held under the auspices of the President of Greece.
I thank the Delphi Economic Forum, the Nizami Ganjavi International Center and the Marianna Vardinoyannis Foundation for organizing this eminent event, as well as for inviting me to participate.
Ladies and gentlemen,
we are living in a special historical moment. In recent years, there have been global movements which have resulted in an entirely new reality. This is a reality that is drastically different from the world we knew after the end of World War II, and especially after the fall of the Berlin Wall.
Instead of the bloc division of the Cold War-era world, or the unipolar world of previous decades, a multipolar world has come to the fore. This world is characterized by a never larger number of relevant geopolitical actors, which puts to the test multilateral institutions a s well as traditional modes of action.
The state of geopolitical change, which began during the past decade, has escalated with Russian aggression against Ukraine. This event de facto moved the limits of geopolitical imagination on European soil in the 21st century. What seemed unthinkable became a reality.
There is a direct military aggression on the scene against a sovereign and independent state, a member of the United Nations. Civilians in Ukraine are being victims of atrocities. The horror scenes in Mariupol and the last scenes of the Bucha massacre are disturbing the conscience of humanity, as was the case with the siege of Sarajevo in the 1990s and the massacre of civilians in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which we thought would not happen again, at least not on European soil.
The issue of Russian aggression against Ukraine is not just a geopolitical issue. It is primarily a human question. It is a question of the struggle of Ukrainians for a bare life and survival. At the time when civilians are being killed and cities are being destroyed, much more important than analysis is raising the voice and awareness of what is happening. At the same time, it is completely unquestionable that this event has consequences primarily on the global security architecture, and then on all other sectors, from the economy, through energy and international transport, all the way to culture and sports.
The economic consequences of the war are already being devastating. The trends are relentless. As a large producer and a significant market, Ukraine has been an important link in the chain of the European economy. Consequently, the contours of the great crisis in food supply and the energy crisis are being outlined. The Russian Federation, which has brought down its capacity to be a reliable partner through this aggression, has also been an important link in the chain, as a large market and supplier of energy.
The adoption of an unprecedented set of sanctions, in response to the attack on Ukraine, raises some new questions. What is the potential of our common economy to transform and adapt, in the appropriate time frame, in order to avoid the most severe consequences. Furthermore, the diversification of energy supply chains in Europe is becoming a fateful process on the outcome of which much will depend.
Ladies and gentlemen,
One of the crucial issues after the aggression against Ukraine is if a spillover to other regions in Europe is possible, including the Western Balkans. It is a risk assessment made by the addresses with the highest degree of seriousness, primarily NATO and the European Union. This assessment is in line with the concerns of the public, including the population in the Western Balkans and Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a central point in the security structure of the Western Balkans.
The biggest problem with the security of the Western Balkans and Bosnia and Herzegovina is that some political structures are still dreaming of changing borders. Despite the horrific experience of the 1990s, they have not yet given up on their intentions to change borders, with the aim of increasing the current size of the territory of certain states and reducing other states, such as Bosnia and Herzegovina.
This is an ideology that is primarily manifested in Bosnia and Herzegovina through secessionist tendencies. The bearers of these secessionist tendencies openly say that they are just waiting for a favorable geopolitical moment in order to start the final implementation of their intentions. Until then, they have been working on "preparing the ground", and we have seen this for more than half a year, when Republika Srpska entity embarked on a project to unilaterally annul 27 years of implementing the Dayton Accords, undermining the very foundations of peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
These actors, who are striving to secede certain parts from Bosnia and Herzegovina, will tactfully deny their intentions when faced with condemnation and pressure from the international community. But it is necessary to look at their actions more than their words, and it is clear that Republika Srpska authorities have not yet withdrawn unconstitutional laws and other measures, which they passed during the past six months, and which have been unequivocally declared secessionist in international institutions and the public.
Another dimension of the problem is the strong Russian influence on these political actors. The Russian Federation has been a political protector of these actors for years, and they in turn are working in favor of some of Russia's strategic interests, such as blocking NATO integration and creating permanent instability in the soft belly of the European Union and NATO.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has joined the international community in condemning Russian aggression, and pro-Russian political forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina are currently blocking Bosnia and Herzegovina from implementing identical sanctions imposed on the Russian Federation by the European Union. Although it is our obligation, under the Stabilization and Association Agreement, to join these sanctions, it is evident that Russian influence is so strong that it prevents this.
That is why it is extremely important to maintain the continuous focus of the entire international public, and primarily NATO and the European Union, on the processes within Bosnia and Herzegovina. Because, these processes are important not only for Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also for the overall European security and stability.
One of the topics of this forum is the future of the European Union. As the largest peace project in history, the European Union has an exceptional role to play in the new situation. The European unity that was demonstrated on the occasion of Ukraine gave new energy to the European Union itself. Undermining the European and overall global security architecture has created awareness of the geopolitical importance of the functioning of the European Union and its enlargement.
The Ukrainian crisis has demonstrated that saturation with enlargement must be overcome, because enlargement is not a one-sided process, in which only new members would gain a lot and the old ones would lose. Enlargement is of mutual interest for both the European Union and the new members, especially when it comes to the Western Balkans. We need the European Union, but the European Union also needs the Western Balkans.
The biggest risk for the members of the European Union, in terms of security and new social problems, would be to leave the Western Balkans to third actors, who could destabilize the European Union itself through the Western Balkans. Therefore, enlargement must be seen as a geopolitical and strategic issue, not an administrative one. That is why the tangible progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina and other countries in the region towards the European Union would be crucial for European security.
In particular, granting candidate status to Bosnia and Herzegovina would be extremely important for overcoming the internal political crisis, and it would be a clear message, at an exceptional moment, that Bosnia and Herzegovina, like the entire Western Balkans, is part of the European system and will not fall under a new Iron Curtain, but will have a clear European and Euro-Atlantic perspective.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of BiH Šefik Džaferović at the opening of the exhibition "National Treasures of Bosnia and Herzegovina" in the City Hall, (Vijećnica) 21 March, 2022
content:
Respected management of the Alija Izetbegović Foundation, esteemed representatives of the National and University Library of Bosnia and Herzegovina, distinguished guests from the Republic of North Macedonia, the Republic of Serbia, the Republic of Montenegro and the Republic of Croatia, distinguished representatives of judicial, legislative and executive authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Your Excellences, Eminences, Ladies and Gentlemen,
Before us is one of the most important exhibitions of the written cultural heritage of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the last half century: "National Treasures of Bosnia and Herzegovina", organized on the occasion of the 30th anniversary of Bosnia and Herzegovina's independence, which represents a kaleidoscope of our rich cultural past, stored in special collections of the National and University Library of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which were rightly included in the list of national monuments of BiH in 2020.
This is the first time that the National and University Library of Bosnia and Herzegovina opens its special collections for the public on this scale and with such a wide domestic and international outreach. On the path leading to this exhibition, this core institution of culture in Bosnia and Herzegovina has gone through difficult trials. The most difficult event that would mark the last three decades of the Library's work and existence happened on 25 and 26 August, 1992, when a large part of the Library's fund burned down in an aggressor's attack on the City Hall (Vijećnica), the seat of the Library. The exhibition holds special significance for the National and University Library of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as this is the return of valuable documentary materials to the renovated City Hall.
The National and University Library of Bosnia and Herzegovina is the synonymous with a hard and persistent struggle for the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is time to find a solution for a sustained functioning of this institution.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
By organizing this event, the "Alija Izetbegović" Foundation, which bears the honorable name of the first president of the independent state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the late Alija Izetbegović, reaffirms its commitment to preserving and improving the fundamental processes in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which culture and cultural heritage surely are. The path taken by the "Alija Izetbegović" Foundation and the way it is managed can be a source of pride to all of us.
In terms of authorship, the exhibition is a real refreshment in the field of promoting cultural heritage in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The choice of material and the way it is presented shows erudition and breadth in understanding both the culture and the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Only true dedication and knowledge can lead us to an exhibition such as this one.
Congratulations to the author and contributors who participated in the realization.
Someone nicely noticed: valuable documentary material stored in our libraries, archives and museums, should no longer be stored in a way that is accessible only to researchers and scientists. Just the opposite. The public at large is unaware of the value of the documents stored there. How are we going to protect our values if we have no knowledge of them? In this lies the additional significance of this exhibition, which will also soon be presented to the international public.
Dear Ladies and Gentlemen,
the intellectual achievements of the people who overcame barbarism and ignorance, as Dr. Safvet-beg Bašagić once said, cannot be destroyed by the most vicious enemy even. The restored City Hall and the written cultural heritage that was preserved and exhibited tonight are a testament to this. That is my message to future generations.
In that name, I am opening the exhibition "National Treasures of Bosnia and Herzegovina“.

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Željko Komšić at the reception held in the Sarajevo City Hall (Vijećnica) on the occasion of Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegov
content:
Dear citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina! On this day, 30 years ago, and by the will of the majority of the citizens of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, we decided on the path of independence, sovereignty, freedom and democracy. The vote at the referendum on independence was an act of freedom, and the very independence, as experience has shown, is not just an act, but a process as well.
On 1 March 1992, the process of gaining our independence began. It was a painful and a difficult one, and, at the same time, as many times before in our history, which relies on the tradition of anti-fascist struggle, it was necessary and indispensable.
In that process for independence of our state, we fought in a sublime and dignified way, unfortunately with great sacrifices and help of the world that was, truth be told, usually lacking.
I often remember my fallen comrades. Yes, they would have been here with us today if they had had anything but their hearts to defend their homeland with. They lacked neither courage nor determination, nor love for the homeland. They had no dilemmas about what and for what they fought for. The only thing we lacked were means of deterrence from the oppressors and those to whom no rules, no honour, or anything belonging to the values of civilization applied to.
And yet, even with all of that, they did not defeat us, and did not destroy us, or the State of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
That is why, today, enemies of our state know that we are not, as the old saying goes, a “rootless turnip”, and that we are even more prepared and determined to fight for the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity, if we have to.
The last thing we want is to have to fight again, but both are enemies and our friends should know that an honourable fight for freedom, democracy and human rights, for us, is an ideal more important than an undignified peace.
It is better to live for one day in freedom in your own state, than to live an eternity in someone else’s state or in humiliation.
As the shocking and disturbing example of Ukraine teaches us, independence of a state is not understood as a permanent category if you are surrounded by dishonest and malicious neighbours. And that is why I claim that independence is both a state and a process. The degree of independence also depends on the attitude towards one's country. Thirty years of attacks on our country, both from the inside and from the outside, are not only a sign of vulnerability, but a sign of strength and endurance. From this duality of strength and vulnerability comes the reality we live in.
The reality we live in forces us today, when the whole world recognizes and accepts the division into those who respect international law and the sovereignty of other states, and those who aggressively interfere in the internal affairs of other countries, that we in Bosnia and Herzegovina clearly detect who is on which side - who respects the sanctity of borders and the inviolability of sovereignty, and who considers it normal to support secessionist and destructive forces in other countries.
Who gives himself the right to attack another country without cause just because he is stronger or because he doesn't like something there, and who resolves misunderstandings within the framework of the international law and civilizational mechanisms? Who supports a state of free citizens, individuals, and who enables the corruption terror of narrow circles that feed on the concept of constitutiveness and group rights? Who is for the rule of law, and who is for the rule of force and crime? Who stands for the force of law, and who for the law of force?
Among these aforementioned contradictions, I am convinced that we recognize the dominant policies in Bosnia and Herzegovina. According to the politics and aggressive intentions of these politics, which are obviously outside of the democratic - civilizational circle, there must be no indulgence. We are the first ones that must oppose such politics.
That is why today, as we mark the 30th Anniversary of Independence, I would like us, as citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, to forget all our internal and ideological political differences and to be proud of what we have. Only if we appreciate what we currently have, and we have a State, will we be able to build a state tailored to all its citizens in the future. A state that is sovereign, independent, and I emphasize, secure.
At the moment, our country is not what some of its loyal fighters imagined it to be 30 years ago, but it is also not what its enemies imagined, nor will it ever be. They assumed that we do not exist, but we did not consider it our duty to respect their assumptions.
That is why, above all, we need to respect ourselves more, at least for the sake of the generations of people who are growing and maturing. Generations that have no intention of going anywhere, even though they are being lured by more powerful people than us, because the love for our homeland is stronger than any mockery of it, because the truth is stronger than lies, and justice is superior than injustice. Let us remain persistent and proud of what we live for and what we believe in.
To all of us, happy Independence Day of our homeland, Bosnia and Herzegovina!
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by the Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Šefik Džaferović at the reception in the City Hall on the occasion of the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Distinguished Chairman of the Presidency, Your Excellencies, dear friends, dear guests, Today we have gathered here for a special jubilee. Exactly three decades ago, Bosnia and Herzegovina embarked on the path to its independence. That is a big, I would say - epochal thing. Almost two thirds of the citizens, in a free referendum, chose to live in a sovereign and democratic Bosnia and Herzegovina. It was a vote for a state of equal citizens and peoples, Bosniaks, Croats, Serbs and everyone else. It was a voice for the freedom and survival of Bosnia and Herzegovina, at a time when plans were forged for division and destruction of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The referendum of the 29th of February and 1st of March 1992 was conducted in accordance with the rules of domestic and international law. Therefore, the democratic will of the citizens is expressed in a legal and transparent way, with full cooperation with the international community.
The act of the independence declaration was performed in accordance with all necessary procedures. This was confirmed by the fact that immediately after the declaration of independence, Bosnia and Herzegovina was recognized by the international community and admitted to the United Nations as an equal member. It should not be forgotten that those who wanted to divide Bosnia and Herzegovina also held some of their own referendums, but they were illegal, they were never recognized and from a legal point of view they remained null and void.
Those who did not have the law and justice on their side tried to achieve their goals - by means of ruthless force. When the brutal aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina began, it turned out that the only guarantor of its survival were the defenders. International law was indispensable for gaining independence, but it alone proved insufficient. It took strength to stand behind that law. That force was the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The freedom we won was paid dearly. We must never forget that. The truth about the period of aggression is written on the pages of the international courts. According to the verdicts of the International Court of Justice and the Hague Tribunal, the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina was unequivocally characterized as an international armed conflict, in which Serbia and Croatia participated. Leading civilian and military officials of Serbia and Croatia have been identified in these verdicts as members of joint criminal enterprises, with the aim of dividing Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Dear friends,
On the 1st of March 1992, Bosnia and Herzegovina did not gain independence for the first time, but restored it, after a century of foreign rule.
As one of the oldest countries in Europe, Bosnia and Herzegovina has never lost its identity, even in times when it was without political independence. The restoration of the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the first session of ZAVNOBiH in 1943, and then the restoration of independence on the 1st of March 1992, was a natural consequence of the aspirations of the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina for freedom.
Today's Bosnia and Herzegovina is organized on the foundations of the Dayton Peace Agreement, but it is in a relationship of continuity with the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina from the 1st of March 1992. The first article of the Dayton Constitution unequivocally speaks about the continuity of the existence of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which includes the continuity of its regulations, as well as the law on the basis of which we celebrate today's holiday.
Resistance to the 1st of March is contrary to the foundations of the Dayton Accord, because according to the Dayton Agreement, as well as in accordance with the 1st of March, Bosnia and Herzegovina is an independent state, a member of the United Nations, with its internationally recognized borders. Therefore, all those who accepted the Dayton Accords also accepted the results of the 1st of March. Or, in fact, they never sincerely accepted the Dayton Accords.
Dear friends,
We are in a particular historical moment. The crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina has been going on for more than half a year. The work of the institutions has been blocked and secessionist activities against the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina are gradually being conducted. The 27 years of the implementation of the Dayton Peace Agreement have been openly attacked, and the reactions of the Euro-Atlantic community are still mild and insufficient to stop the secessionist project of the RS entity authorities.
At the international level, the aggression of the Russian Federation against Ukraine changed everything. The relationships that were implied are now brought into question. The Charter of the United Nations and international law have been ruthlessly violated. The situation indicates the need for the highest degree of vigilance, seriousness and responsibility.
The only way to preserve stability in Bosnia and Herzegovina is for everyone to unconditionally respect the Dayton Peace Agreement and 27 years of its implementation. Anyone who wants to take us back to 1995 has dangerous intentions. The international community, and above all the Euro-Atlantic community, must understand the seriousness of the moment and react preventively. By using political and defense-military mechanisms, the Euro-Atlantic community must protect the Dayton Peace Agreement, because that is their obligation even under that agreement.
The European Union and NATO must provide everything the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina need to protect their sovereignty and territorial integrity. I hope that there will be enough common sense within Bosnia and Herzegovina by those who are already attacking the constitutional order of Bosnia and Herzegovina to stop in time, return to a constructive dialogue within the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina and continue our development normally. Otherwise, they will be the biggest losers. They will not be able to harm Bosnia and Herzegovina. They can only harm peace and stability, and they will end up in the courts and in the dustbins of history.
The current crisis in Ukraine and the aggression of the Russian Federation against Ukraine, and everything that is happening in that regard, should be a great warning to them.
The absolute interest of all citizens and all peoples in Bosnia and Herzegovina is to preserve the independent and democratic state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as defined by the referendum question. It is a state of equal peoples and citizens, in which everyone will feel comfortable in their own skin, on every inch of this country. We need a modern, democratic, functional state, a member of the European Union and NATO, which will be able to respond to the challenges of the modern age and human needs in it, because only in this way will new generations be able to plan their future in their own country.
On that behalf, to all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I wish happy Independence Day.
Long live our Homeland – Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Šefik Džaferović at the opening of the exhibition “Three Decades of Bosnia and Herzegovina's Independence”
content:
Ladies and gentlemen, Dear friends! It is my pleasure to attend the opening of the exhibition "Three Decades of Independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina" and the round table that follows.
I thank the Archives of the Federation for the organization as these are extremely valuable testimonies, needed even today. This exhibition, as well as the testimonies of the actors of the events of 30 years ago, help us today too, as we continue to respond to the challenges, and attempts at revision and relativization of historical events.
Needless to say, the role of the Archives is greatly important, as is the work you do. In your hands are the facts about what we were yesterday, what we are today, and what will make us known to and judged by the generations that come after us. That what is written remains, that what is not, as if it never existed. I respect your work, I support it and I support continuous investments in scientific research and its public orientation.
A little more than 30 years ago, at a time when black clouds rolled over Bosnia and Herzegovina, we chose the path to freedom. Our ideals, then and today, are the same. We were forced to fight for freedom, independence, but also democracy, and we made huge sacrifices. In addition to honourable defence against brutal aggression, international law is also at the foundation of our statehood. Its highest standards set the path, prescribed a standard that was consistently and transparently met. The citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, almost two thirds of them, of all ethnicities, showed political maturity, responsibility in the face of history and generations to come, and voted for the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It was an exam without a resit. And we passed it.
In an answer to the question that determined our political destiny, every vote was important. Even today, every vote counts. We fight for every vote to be equally valuable. Equality is a fundamental value that we have not given up and which is now recommended and protected by international judgments. We respected international law norms in the period of calling the referendum, we respected them even during the brutal war, we respect them even today and we are guided by them.
All documents of the authorities of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina testify to that. In the whirlwind of war, chaos, despair and pain, and in the cities under siege, order, civilization, and the rule of law was preserved. Bosnia and Herzegovina will always, and I repeat always, respect the international legal norms and the highest standards of our civilization. That is built in the foundation of our statehood. The rule of law is also the basis of the functioning of the state, and that is the essence of the crisis we are currently in.
The Dayton Peace Accords, signed in Paris, ended brutal aggression in late 1995. Bosnia and Herzegovina won because it survived. Internationally recognized, the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina has continued its path as Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I will repeat once again: on the 1st of March 1992, the proclaimed and immediately afterwards the internationally recognized Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina continued its path as Bosnia and Herzegovina! I repeat, I will repeat, and we will repeat this fact until everyone understands it. And there are those who need to be educated about Bosnia and Herzegovina, in legal, political and every other sense. We will always be in the mood to talk about it and spread the truth.
In the context of the challenges that continue to come from the same great-state positions in our neighbourhood, I will reiterate that there are no guarantors of the Dayton Peace Agreement. Our neighbours are signatories to the Dayton Accords because they were participants in the international conflict, but that does not give them any special rights over Bosnia and Herzegovina or allow them to interfere in internal affairs. In addition to the signatories, there are mechanisms of the international community that help implement the Agreement.
The system established by the Dayton Peace Accords was not fair, but it was better than continuing the war. Also today, for all of us in BiH, for all peoples and citizens and every part of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is better to adhere to the existing system that includes the Dayton Peace Agreement and the reforms we have achieved by consensus over the past 27 years then to go down the path of destabilization. Our system is expensive and irrational, and it works harder. It needs to be changed. But only with the consent of all.
The Euro-Atlantic path, on which we have reached a consensus in a legal way and in accordance with the prescribed procedures, is our geopolitical framework. Full NATO and the EU membership is the medium-term goal of our policies and focused reforms, and the standards and norms that these memberships bring are the best political practices and experiences that both citizens and constructive and authentic BiH policies accept as their ideals. There where life is better, safer and more prosperous, that system is better. That's why the EU and that's why NATO! Hence their values, and not some others.
We have been on that path for 30 years. The circumstances which we find ourselves under, fighting against very powerful and established enemies of both the state and the ideas of Bosnia and Herzegovina, we have made difficult and slow progress. Success and our victory lie in the fact that we have remained on the same path and that difficulties and challenges have not changed or distracted us from the civilized values and norms. We see today, unfortunately, that the forces of darkness have raised their heads and are roaring fire again. Now those shocking images are coming from the other side of Europe, but poison arrows are being fired at us as well.
Our painful experiences have made us wary and sensitive to such tendencies. We were concerned and we warned in time about any policy that puts one country ahead of another, considers one nation more important than another, one's faith better than another, justifies force and violence, and does not respect borders and sovereign will. Both in our region and beyond.
