This city, as well as the whole of Bosnia and Herzegovina, has always been purely multi-ethnic, which we can be proud of. That is why we must reject lies which are come from those ideological kitchens that actually had wanted pure Serb municipalities and pure Serb Sarajevo, but did not succeed.
It is a lie that the Serbs lost Sarajevo. It is the truth that Karadžić's and Mladić's hordes failed to subdue this city, primarily thanks to the magnificent resistance of the First Corps, which included many Sarajevo and Bosnian Serbs, true and sincere patriots, who recognized and chose the right side of history.
It is often forgotten how much victory for the whole of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and I would say for the whole civilization, was the defence of Sarajevo and how fierce the defeat was for the aggressor forces, whose followers still cannot get over not conquering Sarajevo.
The glorious and honourable defence of the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina must be kept from oblivion, because only thanks to that struggle is Sarajevo today a free, European, open city, the capital of a sovereign and independent state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the state that will sooner or later be a state of equal citizens and peoples.
We must remember this well and constantly highlight it. And we have to take care of those who are most deserving - fighters. This is what this state is doing and will continue to do.
Finally, I would like to extend best wishes to all members of the First Corps, on the occasion of this anniversary, with expressions of gratitude for all the sacrifices they have made.
Thank you.

title: An Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Šefik Džaferović at the official event “Defence of BiH - Igman 2020”
content:
Dear members of the Shaheed families and the fallen soldiers, dear injured veterans, dear members of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
We are here today to remember the Battle of Igman, one of the most significant battles during the defence against aggression, which the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina magnificently fought and won.
In the summer of 1993, the aggressor forces had a plan to completely close the ring around Sarajevo and cut off the last connection of the capital with the rest of the country. Had they succeeded, the military, strategic and political consequences would have been disastrous for the defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Although many times more technically superior, the aggressor forces failed in their intention. They failed because they had to face the heroic Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, an army of honorable people who fought for the right goals, for their homeland, for freedom, for dignity, for the truth, for the idea of independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, a state of equal people.
That was the greatest strength of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is the only armed force in the wars in the former Yugoslavia without a stain in its existence and its fight. This army was mostly composed of Bosniaks, but it had members of all Bosnia and Herzegovina’s peoples in its ranks. This army, unlike the aggressor forces, did not commit mass organized crimes, did not undertake joint criminal enterprises, ethnic cleansing, killings and torture of civilians ...
While others committed crimes systematically and in an organised manner, in the territory under the control of the Army of the Republic of BiH and the only legitimate government led by the late Alija Izetbegović, the crimes were prevented and systematically punished. And that is the key difference between us and them.
Yes, there were individual crimes committed by members of the Army of the Republic of BiH. We have condemned these crimes and we will always condemn them. We have no problem with that.
What we will not allow are the fabricated indictments against honorable people, officers of the Army of the Republic of BiH, which are trying to equalize the guilt at all cost. Some of these indictments have already been dropped in court. Some of our bravest soldiers, such as Ahmet Sejdić and Naser Orić, proved their honor and innocence. I am convinced that the other defendants will come out of the ongoing process free, with honour and with their heads held high.
Dear friends,
just as we were not the same in the war, we are not the same today. We have witnessed this in recent days, when we see that war crimes indictees are being rewarded in the neighbourhood, fugitives from justice, and that the criminal who ordered the establishment of the Sušica camp in Vlasenica is becoming a member of the state assembly.
Over the years in Bosnia and Herzegovina, we have been witnessing the contenstation of final judgments of the international court on joint criminal enterprise on the one hand, and on the other, the even more difficult and disastrous practice of rewarding convicted criminals and celebrating their crime.
Policies which direct this cannot change the truth about what happened during the aggression against our country, they cannot change a single verdict of any court, nor will they ever be able to erase from our collective memory the images of evil we have survived and remember those as a warning not to allow it to ever happen again.
These policies, by such actions, in fact, speak most about themselves. They are persisting in these endevours. We all need to be aware of this.
In that sense, a new hoax has been attempted lately, in linking the solution for Kosovo to Bosnia and Herzegovina. My message to them is - give it up, because there is no possible link between the situations in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo, nor will there ever be. The only link between BiH and Kosovo is the crimes and ethnic cleansing committed by Milosević's Greater Serbia regime and its followers.
Other messages are sent to us, both rhetorical and practical. This will not frighten us, but it will strengthen our caution and our determination to protect the interests of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Dear friends,
it is clear to all of us that the struggle for Bosnia and Herzegovina continues. Fortunately, instead of bullets and grenades, the fight is being waged by political means.
On one side are the forces that want the disintegration of the state and division among its peoples and citizens, on the other are those that want the reintegration and equality of every man on every inch of our homeland.
On one side are those who think that they can link their destiny and interests with neighbouring countries, and on the other are those of us whom Bosnia and Herzegovina is the only home, and who do not have another motherland.
On the one side, there are those who, through various blockades and blackmail, want to make the functioning of the state meaningless, and on the other, there are those of us who, despite that and in spite of them, manage to patiently move things in favour of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
On one side are those who want to slow down or stop Bosnia and Herzegovina's path towards the European Union and NATO, on the other are those of us who are leading the country step by step in that direction.
And rest assured, they will fail, we will succeed.
They will not succeed because they failed even when they were much stronger than they are today - nor are they as strong now as they would like to think of themselves.
We want to succeed, because the people who love this country are much stronger and more determined to preserve it than those who want to destroy it may think.
I call on them again to abandon secessionist and nationalist policies, because the result will never be the division of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but the result will be a waste of precious time, a slowdown in the progress of the state and its economy, the departure of youth. It is not in anyone's interest.
Throughout history, Bosnia and Herzegovina has outlived all those who had attacked it.
It will outlive those negative forces of today.
Thank you.

title: The Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Šefik Džaferović at the marking of the 25th anniversary of the Genocide against the Bosniaks of Srebrenica
content:
Dear mothers of Srebrenica, dear survivors, dear families of the victims of genocide, dear friends from Bosnia and Herzegovina and the world! Today, here in the Potočari Valley of sorrow and pain, we are together to see off the remains of nine innocent victims, some of whom were young men, killed only because they belonged to one people - because they were Bosniaks.
Today, in the Potočari valley which is soaked in tears and sorrow, we bury the youth who will be laid to rest alongside hundreds of their peers, Salko Ibišević who was killed age 23, and only a few years older Sead Hasanović, Alija Suljić, Hasib Hasanović and Kemal Musić. We will also bury people who were killed in their middle age: Zuhdija Avdagić, Bajro Salihović, Ibrahim Zukanović, but also Hasan Pezić, killed at the age of 70.
Their white tombstones will be next to the tombstones of other innocently killed Srebrenica men, boys, women, next to the tombstone of the youngest victim, newborn Fatima Muhić, and the oldest victim, Šaha Izmirlić, killed at the age of 94. All absolutely innocent.
We are here to express our sympathy for their families and to remember with due reverence all the victims of the Srebrenica genocide, but also to remind that more than 1,000 people, whose bodies have been moved from one mass grave to another to cover up the crimes, are still to be found.
We are marking this 25th anniversary of genocide against the Bosniaks of the "UN Safe Haven Srebrenica", in special circumstances caused by the coronavirus pandemic. However, that did not prevent us from marking this saddest anniversary in the history of our people here, in our Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also around the world.
And nothing will ever stop us from continuing to do so. It is our duty to remember, to preserve the truth about genocide and to warn: for our own sake and for the sake of the whole world. It will remain our duty until the Day of Judgment.
Everything is known about the genocide of the Bosniaks in Srebrenica, the truth is clear and complete and it is sealed by final judgments of international and domestic courts.
It is clear from these verdicts that the genocide in Srebrenica was a planned and systematically committed crime committed by Karadžić's and Mladić's death squads, the Army and Police of Republika Srpska, aided by units from Serbia, in order to completely wipe out the existence of one people in this area. Serbia and the then regime were declared responsible because they could but did not prevent genocide.
The genocide, which took place in front of the eyes of the whole world, could, but unfortunately was not prevented by the then leading world leaders, including the United Nations. Despite the resolution declaring Srebrenica a "UN Safe Haven", no concrete steps were taken to stop the brutal killings of innocent men, children, women, pregnant women, and the elderly.
The result of the lack of concrete action to stop the ideology of evil and its horde of murderers are white tombstones here in Potočari. They will forever be a reminder to humanity that there must be no calculations in opposing evil.
The UN officials themselves have acknowledged that Srebrenica will forever remain a black stain on the conscience of all those who could and did not prevent the genocide. In its report on Srebrenica, the United Nations stated:
''Through error, misjudgement and the inability to recognize the scope of evil confronting us we failed to do our part to save the people of Srebrenica from the Serb campaign of mass murder. No one regrets more than us for the chances for peace and justice that were missed. No one condemns more than us the failure of the international community to take decisive steps to stop the suffering and war that has produced so many casualties."
Today, 25 years later, there is a growing awareness throughout the civilized world about the scale of the crime committed and the mistakes made. Srebrenica has become a synonym for the suffering of innocent people, and the crime that was committed then is called the only applicable name for it – Genocide.
The anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide is now being marked around the world. People across all meridians sympathize with the families of the victims and our people. Today you could also hear messages from the leaders of the modern world, where there is no dilemma as to what happened in those July days of 1995 and who is responsible for it.
Those messages mean a lot to us and I take this opportunity to thank all the presidents, prime ministers and other officials who have expressed their sympathy for the families of the victims of genocide and who have contributed to our fight for the truth.
At the same time, I take this opportunity to warn all our friends around the world to show, in addition to words and deeds, that they do not accept attempts to deny genocide and to celebrate and glorify the organizers and perpetrators of this horrific crime.
And, unfortunately, we are witness to that.
Instead of the expected catharsis, confession of genocide, apology, arrest and prosecution of many direct perpetrators who are still at large, we are witnessing the same planned and systematic denial of genocide.
Instead of the acknowledgement, a sincere apology and condemnation, the ideology that planned and realized genocide is very much still alive in both Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia. This ideology today attacks the truth by minimizing and denying genocide. The science says this is the last stage of genocide.
It’s not just an insult to the families of the victims, it’s much more than that. The deniers of genocide, in fact, speak the most about themselves and send us a clear message that they have not given up.
That is why we and the whole world must resolutely oppose them. There is no room for mistakes and indecision.
It is high time we were helped and the international community, which has a mandate to do so, immediately imposes the law banning genocide denial.
The issue of banning genocide denial does not only concern Srebrenica, Bosniaks and Bosnia and Herzegovina, but it concerns the entire world. It is a universal question of the struggle of good and evil.
Dear friends,
in recent years, the words truth and justice have been uttered many times from this and other places.
These are not just ordinary words, they are also our message.
Acceptance of the truth and just punishment of perpetrators of genocide, as well as perpetrators of other crimes wherever they were committed and whoever committed them, are the first and basic preconditions for restoring trust in this region.
There can be no trust as long as attacks on the truth, denial of genocide, and glorification and rewarding of perpetrators continue.
That is why today, as it has been done many times before, I call on the political, religious and intellectual elites of the Serb people, who have suffered a lot throughout history, to gather strength and face the truth honestly and to, without hesitation, refrain from the ideology and regime that committed genocide against Bosniaks in their name.
Let them do it for the families of the victims, for us, but mostly for themselves. Let them not leave that heavy burden as a burden to the generations to come.
Those generations, from both peoples, deserve better lives than the lives we live. It is the duty of our generation to provide better lives for them.
We have always lived together in this region. And we should continue to live together.
We will remember our pains, our sorrows, our misfortunes and our sufferings and live with them, but we are obliged to think of both the present and the future.
As we wait for the day when our neighbours will have the strength to face the truth and thus enable the process of restoring trust, it is up to us to make daily efforts to build a society and a state in which every man will be equal on every inch of this land, regardless of ethnicity or religious affiliation.
It is up to us to build a modern, democratic and prosperious state with the help of our friends, and despite obstacles; the state that will be part of the European family and in which people will be able to peacefully build a future for themselves and their children, but also a state that will guarantee that no similar crimes are ever committed against anyone, ever again.
We have a special duty towards Srebrenica and the whole Podrinje area, which must be the places of sustainable return, where people will live peacefully, from their work. A lot of things have been done in that area, but a lot more remains to be done.
We will remember the victims forever, preserve the truth about the genocide, and it is up to each of us to show special responsibility and help Srebrenica become a place of living again.
It is our debt to the innocent victims and their families. Thanks.

title: Speech by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić in the Memorial Church in Berlin to mark the 25th anniversary of the Genocide in Srebrenica
content:
Esteemed priests, ladies and gentlemen, dear citizens of Berlin and the Federal Republic of Germany!
I feel extremely honoured that I can address you in a few sentences, in this city and in this place of significant meaning and name, in the Memorial Church, and on the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the genocide committed in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Srebrenica.
Before I start, I would like to take this opportunity, bearing in mind that the notion of remembrance is what brought us together here today, to remember the victims of the horrific terrorist attack which happened during a Christmas fair four years ago, not far from of this place, when twelve innocent people were killed.
Such a horrible manifestation of a crime committed out of insanity and hatred, for us who come from Bosnia and Herzegovina can never go unnoticed, and cannot be easily forgotten, because we felt insanity and hatred as citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the end of the last century. It was, unfortunately, proof that evil is not so fleeting, and that it returns, even when you least expect it.
The very nature of a good man finds it difficult to accept evil as an objective possibility. The good nature wants to suppress such thoughts and exclude it as a reality, however despite the belief of the good ones, evil has happened numerous times in the history of mankind. Because forgetting is the first precondition for evil to return, and remembering evil, is the first precondition for it never to happen again.
If all the evils and sufferings that happened in the Second World War, which left unforeseeable consequences, had not been repeated in my country at the end of the last century, I would have said that it is easy to remember. I cannot say that today, given what I have experienced and survived. Remember, that is hard. Therefore, although it is difficult, it is paramount.
We in Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot, will not, nor do we want to forget what happened to us. If we’d agreed to that, we would give approve of those who wanted to destroy our state and at the same time to destroy an entire nation from the face of the earth.
Srebrenica is in fact only the focal point of the Bosnian genocide, i.e. criminal operations conducted against the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens, from the beginning to the end of the aggression, from 1992 to 1995, because the same or similar crimes were committed in other cities of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with the same intent and with the same or similar genocidal consequences.
Yet Srebrenica is the one that has been remembered by the world as a black stain in modern history, the stain on the conscience of the most advanced part of the world and civilization. For Bosnia and Herzegovina and most of its citizens, Srebrenica is a fundamental determination of its present, and a determination of the lives of several generations of people.
The relevant verdicts of international and domestic courts have only partially satisfied justice, although these verdicts can hardly be a particular mental satisfaction for victims of genocide. However, they are only a scientific contribution to history and the truth about the facts that cannot and must not be a topic of any negotiations today, because one does not negotiate about the facts.
However, some, even in our neighborhood, who bear responsibility for genocide, still seem to expect the victim to lend a hand to the criminal in the name of a more pleasant future - instead of the criminal kneeling before the victim in the name of a just and peaceful future.
We do not have the right to order things that way today, we do not have the right to do so as human beings, because we cannot forgive in the name of the victims and their families; we have no right as an advanced society either, because violence must not be a value and a path that pays off.
The victims of genocide have so many times shown willingness to reconcile, that this willingness is simply fascinating, which is especially evident in those who have suffered the greatest and heaviest losses. They are glad to reconcile, but they prefer the truth, and I appreciate that they are completely right, because reconciliation without the truth is a false reconciliation, and an interlude to new tragedies.
We need a partnership based on a common interest, and we believe that peace is the common interest of all. The people in Bosnia and Herzegovina want peace more than anyone, and that is why we insist more than others in the region on suppressing any signs of the emergence of ideologies that can repeat or try to repeat the genocide. We will never stop insisting on that, because it is not only a political but also a moral responsibility. We want to be responsible to ourselves and to others. We want to break once and for all the chain of suffering that permeates our common history.

title: Address by Šefik Džaferović, Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina delivered at the European Union - Western Balkans Summit
content:
Dear President of the European Council, Dear President of the European Commission, Dear High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Ladies and gentlemen presidents and prime ministers, dear colleagues,
First of all, let me express my sincerer condolences to the families of the victims in your countries. In our prayers and thoughts, we remain close to those who are facing the most difficult situations, as well as to those who are fighting the coronavirus in the first lines.
The situation which all of us have been facing is one of the biggest challenges of our time. COVID-19 has known no borders, regions, or nations. However, despite the physical isolation, the current misfortune has brought us closer together, and stressed the need for "n enhanced mutual cooperation and solidarity alike.
In regards to this, let me point out the following three issues:
On behalf of BiH and its citizens, I extend our thanks to the European Union and its member states for the assistance and support they provided to us in this difficult period. We know that this was not easy for them, we know that most members of the European Union have also been facing very difficult situations. Therefore, the assistance of the European Union is all the more important and symbolic.
The assistance provided by the European Union to our country in these difficult times also represents a very important political message that Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Western Balkans remain one of the main geopolitical priorities of the European Union, and that the future of the Western Balkans lies in the European Union.
In this context, I would like to express our contentment for BiH's participation in the Joint EU Procurement Agreement of Medical Countermeasures, as well as for the European Union's decision to exempt the Western Balkans from the obligation to obtain export permits for medical equipment.
Further, let me express out contentment for the organization of today's video meeting, which offers us a possibility to continue the high-level political dialogue with the European Union and its member states. The mere fact that the European Union decided to hold this meeting, despite the very difficult situation it is in, enhances the political message on the importance that the European Union attaches to the Western Balkans as its natural part.
On behalf of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I hereby avail myself of the opportunity to extend our thanks to the Croatian Chairmanship over the European Union for including the Western Balkans in the top priorities, which enabled the present Summit to take place.
Today's Summit is a great opportunity for us to re-iterate how much we appreciate the European Union's approach aimed at including its neighbourhood, with a special place reserved for the Western Balkans, in its strategy of economic recovery.
Bosnia and Herzegovina believes that, within the implementation of the strategy of economic recovery of our region's portfolio, a special focus should be put on the sectors which will have most significant positive impact on the economic revival, including a an enhanced implementation of the Connectivity Agenda through continuing and intensifying the infrastructure works, the energy sector, with a special focus on energy transformation and the so-called "Green Agenda“, digitization of the society, as well as the support for small and medium enterprises.
The competent institutions in BiH have been working hard on the preparation of the project proposals, which we will submit to the European Commission in the forthcoming period.
Moreover, Bosnia and Herzegovina is looking forward to the publication of the new enlargement package in June. We are certain that the new enlargement package, following the European Union's decisions on opening the negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia, will be a new important incentive for the accelerated progress of the whole region along the European Union's path.
More than ever before, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina need a concrete indicator of their European perspective, i.e. of the candidate status. Our ultimate goal is membership in the European Union, and the candidate status is one of the steps to be taken on that path. It is time for the European Union to enable us to make that next step, so that we can see that the membership in the European Union is both achievable and realistic, that the efforts invested are meaningful, and that we can be encouraged to continue to carry out the necessary reforms.
It is necessary that the competent institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina double their efforts aimed at the implementation of the key priorities. One should take into consideration that some of the key priorities demand a comprehensive elaboration and wider discussions aimed at reaching a possible agreement on the way in which their implementation would be approached.
In view of this, the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina initiated (last week, on April 28, 2020) the process of the implementation of the 14 key priorities by establishment of an ad hoc Political Working Group, and tasked the Chairman of the Council of Ministers to initiate a process of drafting the Action Plan for the Implementation of the 14 Priorities set out in the European Commission's Opinion, along with precisely defined deadlines, mandates and indicators.
I avail myself of this opportunity to re-iterate that the most important strategic priority of Bosnia and Herzegovina is to become a member of the European Union.
Certainly, Bosnia and Herzegovina is fully aware of the fact that the speed of our progress along the European Union's path depends primarily on ourselves, on how efficiently we will manage to meet the necessary conditions and transform our society in accordance with the EU standards.
Thirdly, the regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is, in our opinion, an integral part of the whole region's European path. Connected with the shared strategic goal – the membership in the European Union – the countries of our region have had to mutually cooperate.
Good regional cooperation is also the best way for all of us in the region to show in a concrete way our readiness for the respect and application of the standards and principles the European Union is based on. I believe that all of us are fully aware that the path to Brussels leads though its regional cooperation section.
A need for a further enhancement of the regional cooperation in the forthcoming period of economic recovery will be even more emphasized through defining and implementing of large joint projects, as this is the best way to revive our economies.
Despite the well-known problems, our region has achieved an enviable progress in the area of regional cooperation in the previous period. The Regional Economic Area (MAP REA) project will end this year. We implemented it within the Berlin Process. This is an opportunity for all of us to see which direction we should proceed in, and further intensify our cooperation, so that we can bring our economies closer to the joint European Union's market.
Of course, all of us agree that our region should continue to implement the social and economic reforms. However, I am also certain that the Western Balkans should and can benefit greatly from a better cooperation in the areas of internal affairs, the rule of law, security, and a better coordination in the joint responses to crisis situations.
Finally, I wold like to express hereafter my belief that all of us will grow stronger and more united out of the current crisis. Bosnia and Herzegovina appreciates it very much that in these difficult moments it can count on the strong support of the European Union and its member states, which are our strategic partners.
Thank you.

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Šefik Džaferović participated at the EPP Summit shortly before the European Union - Western Balkan Summit
content:
President Donald Tusk, President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, Croatian Prime Minister Andrej Plenković as host, Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov, Serbian President Aleksandar Vučić and others attended the European People's Party (EPP) Summit, held in the form of a video conference.
In his address Chairman Džaferović said:
Dear President Tusk, esteemed ladies and gentlemen!
Allow me to greet you as the chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also on behalf of the Party of Democratic Action of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Although the extraordinary circumstances have sadly not allowed for us to meet in person, I am glad that there is this opportunity for us to exchange views and experiences.
The health crisis, which is still in force in Europe, has prevented many established contacts, from international traffic to the most ordinary human encounters. But this crisis has also shown us how interconnected people, nations and states are and how dependent they are on each other.
The coronavirus pandemic has shown what a destructive power it has not only for human health, but also for the entire economic, institutional and social system. But the outcome of a crisis situation ultimately depends on how we approach it.
Solidarity and togetherness should be the key things we will remember about this crisis, one day when it passes.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has so far successfully responded to the health aspect of the pandemic crisis, taking timely and appropriate protection measures.
We face serious challenges regarding the inevitable negative economic consequences.
I thank the European Union, which has provided BiH with important assistance in overcoming both the health and economic crisis. This is incomparably the most significant support that Bosnia and Herzegovina has received.
Like any other crisis, this one can be a chance to strengthen European unity. Common trouble can bring us even closer and unite us. This time again, it was made clear that we can successfully take on the challenges we face only by undertaking joint action.
I believe that in this way, the situation regarding the pandemic should be viewed by all of us who are supporters of a united Europe, a strong European Union and the continuation of European and Euro-Atlantic integration.
The absence of a unified and solidary action of the European Union, or even the very indications of that, open room for involvement of some other and different policies and influences, both in the European Union itself and in the Western Balkans in particular.
We are part of Europe, but we also want to be part of the European Union and its institutions. That is the main foreign policy priority and strategic interest of my country. There is a consensus on this in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The other countries in the Western Balkans are also committed to membership in the European Union.
For all the reasons I have stated, it is very important that Bosnia and Herzegovina and the entire Western Balkans receive very clear messages about the foreseeable prospect of full membership in the European Union. Certainly, it is up to us to take concrete steps in order to speed up the implementation of reforms and fulfill the required conditions.
It would be extremely important for Bosnia and Herzegovina to receive the candidate status and open negotiations later this year. After the political, and now the pandemic crisis, I believe that the time has come to dedicate ourselves to the accelerated implementation of the recommendations from the European Commission Opinion. The first steps, in cooperation with the Delegation of the European Union to BiH and our other partners, have already been made.
A credible European perspective represents the strongest mechanism for advancing human rights, the rule of law and establishing internal political cohesion in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and one of the most important factors in socio-economic progress. That is why I emphasize once again that the European path remains our permanent and strategic commitment, for the benefit of our citizens and in accordance with the mutual interests of the European Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The Party of Democratic Action, as a member of the European People's Party, has always nurtured a commitment to European integration, and there are no dilemmas for us in that sense.
Thank you.

title: Address delivered by Šefik Džaferović, BiH Presidency member at the event marking the Day of the Brčko District and the 20th anniversary of establishment of the Brčko District
content:
It was exactly two decades ago that the International Arbitrage Court passed its decision to establish the Brčko District. This was done after the negotiating parties in Dayton failed to find a solution which all sides would be satisfied with.
Esteemed representatives of the Brčko District’s institutions,
Esteemed representatives of the international community,
Esteemed representatives of all administrative levels in BiH,
Ladies and gentlemen,
Esteemed representatives of the Brčko District’s institutions,
Esteemed representatives of the international community,
Esteemed representatives of all administrative levels in BiH,
Ladies and gentlemen,
It is with great pleasure that I attend this celebration, and I hereby extend my thanks to you for inviting me to do so.
I extend my congratulations to all female and male citizens of Brčko on the Day of the Brčko District and the 20th anniversary of its establishment.
It was exactly two decades ago that the International Arbitrage Court passed its decision to establish the Brčko District. This was done after the negotiating parties in Dayton failed to find a solution which all sides would be satisfied with.
During the Dayton negotiations, it even seemed impossible to find a solution that all parties would agree to. However, the solution was found after all.
It was still uncertain pursuant to the Arbitration Court’s decision whether the solution achieved would be sustainable or only temporary. Today, twenty years later, it has turned out that it was a satisfactory one, which has not been disputed by anyone. Moreover, during the last 20 years, the Brčko District has been positioned as a successful multiethnic community, with both functional and sustainable institutional frameworks.
While marking the 20th anniversary of establishment of the Brčko District, we need to remind ourselves of the key lessons learnt from that event.
First of all, the case of Brčko District has demonstrated that we can, in both peaceful and civilized way, resolve even such issues that could not be resolved during the peace negotiations in Dayton.
This was made possible as it represented a compromise, by which no one was fully satisfied, and yet no one had any reason to be fully dissatisfied. This is the essence of a compromise – that everyone rejects their unilateral demands and any accompanying ultimatums. Such path of a compromise as the only efficient way of moving things forward, in which there is no winners and no defeated ones, has been demonstrated not only in the case of Brčko District but in many other cases, too.
Further, the Arbitrage Agreement is the solution for the Brčko District, and it is not a part of the original Dayton arrangement. The solution for Brčko District represents a natural course of the implementation of the Dayton Peace Agreement, which includes international mediation.
This is yet another key lesson from establishment of the Brčko District. It illustrates the essence of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the post-Dayton period.
The solutions reached once with everyone’s give respective consent granted must be respected unconditionally, as long as we reach some different solutions. None of us has the right to dispute unilaterally the solutions established by the Dayton Agreement or reached through its implementation.
Dayton means all this.
One such solution is certainly the Brčko District, without which it is impossible to talk about the constitutional structure of Bosnia and Herzegovina today.
Ladies and gentlemen,
In the last two decades, the Brčko District has undergone a very important phase of its political and institutional stabilization alike. I wish from the bottom of my heart that the next two decades be marked with an enhanced economic development and prosperity, to the benefit of all citizens of the Brčko District.
The Brčko District is a symbol of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is my main message to you today to guard good relations, respect and acknowledge each other, as it is only in that way that you can create an environment worth living in, in which no one will be restricted and everyone will feel comfortable.
The Brčko District, the same as Bosnia and Herzegovina, is large enough to be comfortable for all its residents. It is our homework to arrange our relations in such a way that will allow for a country in which the new generations will be able to plan their future peacefully.
Thank you for your attention.

title: The address by BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić at the reception marking the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Your excellences, eminences, ladies and gentlemen, dear guests, It is with pride that we remind ourselves tonight of the first of March as the day when Bosnia and Herzegovina gained independence, the day when the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, by using referendum as a democratic instrument, expressed their citizen will to have a sovereign and independent state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The result of their vote created preconditions for Bosnia and Herzegovina’s international recognition.
In the ensuing period, just like numerous times in its history, Bosnia and Herzegovina has shown yet again its indestructibility. Those who love her, her citizens, led by the love of their homeland, have done their best to preserve her international legal personality, and they have succeeded in doing so. No one could kill neither the hope nor the belief of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina in what they stood for, and we stood up for the same values we stand up for today: for the state of equal citizens, the state in which has always, and there always will be a place for everyone.
Such a state was desired and is desired now by the vast majority of citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Today, however, we must maturely oppose all attempts at partition, whether on the political, party or ideological basis. We also give and should extend our hand to those who did not vote for the independence of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, or are still opposed to independence and sovereignty. My message, to those fellow citizens, is honest, short and clear. This is your country too. Nobody wants to, nor will they take her away from you. She belongs to all of us, so let’s make her better than she is today, if not for ourselves, then at least for the sake of our children. We must not allow for our children to start hating their home, so they seek their happiness and life chances away from this country. We must give them hope that this country can be the best place in the world for them.
We can only succeed in doing so if we, as responsible people, refrain from expressing disrespect and misunderstanding towards one another, refrain from spreading unnecessary fears, bypassing the law and undermining the institutions that are our state, and must be at service to everyone equally. It is easy to break trust, respect, and unfortunately even institutions, but this is an act of folly, and folly always has tragic consequences.
After all, I still somewhat hope that everything we have witnessed in recent days which was not directed towards building a better society but was focused on destruction, that all of that is just one bad act, one poor choice of methods in political action. I believe that a belligerent person, in times of peace, primarily attacks himself. Therefore, instead of destruction and strife, let the race for peace and prosperity be a major challenge and one in which we will compete.
We, as citizens, society and the state, face the fulfilment of numerous conditions in order to move closer to a safer living environment within broader international associations, which is outlined in our foreign policy priorities. However, we should know that no one outside this country has more interest or benefit than us who share the same skies. We will not find greater friends in the world unless we find them among ourselves, and I believe we can do that. Finally, without shying away from our hot Balkan blood and temperament, we still just want to be a normal, peaceful, and a safe country.

title: Address by Željko Komšić, Chairman of BiH Presidency at the ceremony held on the occasion of marking the Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
During the last fourteen years, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina have proven themselves as a powerful and reliable support pole to the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens alike. The Armed Forces of BiH are, beyond doubt, a better part of our society, as well as an indicator that the reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina can be conducted successfully indeed.
Esteemed excellences, dear generals, officers and lieutenants, dear soldiers, dear guests!
On behalf of BiH Presidency, which is commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces, and on my own behalf, it is my pleasure to address you today on the occasion of the 14th anniversary of the Armed Forces of BiH.
During the last fourteen years, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina have proven themselves as a powerful and reliable support pole to the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens alike. The Armed Forces of BiH are, beyond doubt, a better part of our society, as well as an indicator that the reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina can be conducted successfully indeed.
The primary purpose of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina is the protection of sovereignty and territorial integrity of our country. At the same time, this is a basic precondition for the integration of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina into the wider defence and security systems, such as the NATO Alliance, under whose framework, while relying on our own forces, we can be not only safe but also prosperous as a state and a society alike.
The Armed Forces of BiH have not only taken care of the security of our society, but, through their active participation in the peace missions, especially the one in Afghanistan, have demonstrated that they have been a reliable partner to all the countries and societies striving to achieve global peace and security. The readiness and determination of the AFBiH to participate in the peace missions in order to keep or establish peace in the world have deserved nothing but praise. The engagement of our soldiers in these noble missions has made us proud. However, it has also imposed an obligation on us to ensure that the overall status of the Armed Forces' members should be raised to a higher level.
I avail myself of this opportunity to express my satisfaction over the activities conducted by the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Let me take as an example the successfully completed military exercise held in September this year at Manjača. Over a thousand AFBiH soldiers participated in it. This exercise was organized with the assistance provided by NATO. As well as many other military exercises, this one shows the readiness of the Armed Forces to achieve the necessary NATO standards, and represents the AFBiH's longest step forward to raising the level of interoperability, which is, in many ways, the key factor of cooperation and achievement of NATO standards respectively. All these activities have been recognized as significant by our partner countries. Therefore, I am not surprised in the least by the statements in this regard given at my bilateral meetings with the representatives of the ministries of defence of our friendly countries.
The fact is, and I believe it is necessary to underline it today, that, for the first time since it was established, the marking was made of the Light Infantry Battalion Group. Namely, the group was marked as “combat ready“. The credits for such successes certainly go also to the Joint Command of the Armed Forces of BiH, which established an excellent cooperation with the Allied Forces in Europe.
For the Armed Forces to be enabled to continue to achieve good results, the decisions of the state institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina are needed in order to create the necessary preconditions enabling such progress.
Last year, at this very same place, on the occasion of marking the thirteenth anniversary of the AFBiH, we talked about the need of meeting the conditions for The Membership Action Plan (MAP).
Now, a year later, we are glad to stablish that Bosnia and Herzegovina has been in MAP since 5 December 2018, and that, in accordance with the decision made by the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Annual National Program of reforms is being submitted to the NATO headquarters. This program will create a new dynamics of the integration processes towards NATO.
The process, for which we were waiting for years to start unfolding, has now been unblocked, which certainly represents an additional encouragement for all members of the Armed Forces of BiH, as well as for all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Nowadays, it is unlikely that it can seem easy to anyone in Bosnia and Herzegovina to try to degrade the role or importance of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina again by any political machination. We witnessed such attempts indeed. However, they failed ultimately. Nevertheless, I am glad that I remain assured that there will be no such attempts made in the future. The ones who dare trying to do that must know that they by doing so they will be risking everything and gaining nothing in the process.
Hoping that, in the course of the next year, when we will be marking the fifteenth anniversary since the Armed Forces of BiH were established, we will again be in a position to acknowledge further advances and progress achieved, especially in the area of integration processes, I hereby extend my congratulations to all members of the Armed Forces on the anniversary of the day when the AFBiH were established.
Thank you.

title: Željko Komšić, Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, upon invitation of the Chicago-based Bosnian and Herzegovinian community, attended the Solemn Academy held on the occasion of marki
content:
Chairman Komšić delivered a speech on this occasion: My dear Bosnians and Herzegovinians, Excellences, Ladies and gentlemen, dear friends... I am both honoured and grateful to be here with you tonight, once again. Thank you for the invitation and such a warm welcome here in the United States of America, our friend and ally, where we gathered to mark the most important date in the modern history of Bosnia and Herzegovina – the Statehood Day, i.e. to mark the anniversary of the first session of the State Anti-Fascist Council for the National Liberation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (ZAVNOBiH).
We must never forget that it is our permanent obligation to underline the civilizational significance of ZAVNOBiH as the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We both can and must be proud of the fact that 76 years ago the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, regardless of their national or ideological orientations, while occupied by the fascists, constituted their state's authorities on the basis of the anti-fascist principles, i.e. the principles of the free and democratic world. They were determined, while opposing the evil, to defend and preserve their homeland and organize it as a country of equal citizens and peoples.
The historical documents talk about this to a certain extent only. The resolutions and declarations of ZAVNOBiH are just a sum of efforts invested on the path to freedom and a united country. That path was marked for us by those who cleared the snow and mud on it, while shedding their own blood and sweat. Their endeavour could not be stopped by the fascist tanks, planes or cannons.
The atrocities perpetrated by the domestic quislings could not stop them either. Those quislings will always remain inseparable from the pillar of shame, from which no revisionists or forgers of history will be able to remove them because such position was defined for them by the civilized part of the world.
The ZAVNOBiH delegates, members of the National Liberation Movement, i.e. the nationals of Bosnia and Herzegovina were all on that civilized side of the world. There were a few countries in Europe of that time, which the fascists managed to occupy, and which, nevertheless, managed to constitute the anti-fascist rule under the fascist occupation.
The citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina gathered their strength, wits, and knowledge for such an endeavour. Therefore, I dare to say here tonight that Bosnia and Herzegovina, historically speaking, cannot be lectured by anyone on the issue of civilizational values. While our ancestors bled and sacrificed their lives, many gentlemen in Europe bowed their heads and lowered their eyes cowardly before Hitler and the ghosts of fascism.
Therefore, we will not allow anyone, regardless of what their names are, or the influence they currently have, to offend or undermine the dignity of our citizens today.
The one who is not willing to invest efforts to preserve the dignity of the citizens of our country cannot preserve our country either. That is how it has always been like, that is how it is now, and that is how it will always be.
The citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina, by constituting the anti-fascist rule on the 25th of November, demonstrated their social and political maturity alike. At the same time, the delegates of ZAVNOBiH demonstrated their political courage and readiness to take responsibility for making big decisions. The history has confirmed the magnitude and importance of these decisions of theirs.
Those who made such decisions were maybe not aware of their colossal importance. However, they were courageous, determined and united at that time. They knew where they were, where they were going to, and where they wanted to arrive. All that was recognized at a wider international plan. That is why Bosnia and Herzegovina was, and still is, a part of the wider anti-fascist alliance.
The current geopolitical orientation of Bosnia and Herzegovina was predetermined back then. If that were not the case, the First of March 1992 would not have neem possible as the Independence Day, nor would the 22nd of May be possible as the day of admission of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the United Nations.
Thus, we were indeed at the right side of history at the right time, together with the United States of America that, for all these years since, and until now, have remained a true friend of our state and her citizens.
Bosnia and Herzegovina survived thanks to the awareness of her citizens on where they belong, and thanks to her friends who knew how to recognize it.
Big decisions are being made again in Bosnia and Herzegovina now. These current decisions are certainly not as courageous as were the decisions of November 1943. However, they are important as indicators of our state's continuity. Again, those states which were at the side of Bosnia and Herzegovina in 1943 are on her side now as well. Such decisions are based on the agreement and consensus. It is never easy to reach them. However, despite everything, we have been reaching them, thus strengthening our state.
On the other hand, what is encouraging is the fact that most citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina truly understand the importance of such decisions, as well as that it is not easy to reach them, that a lot of patience and perseverance is needed in the course of the decision making processes.
If you want to know if you made a right decision, listen to the pulse of the people, and everything will become clear.
The people of Bosnia and Herzegovina recognize what is important for our country. I would dare to say that this is the same level of recognition of the important issues as it was the case back in November 1943.
The decisions of ZAVNOBiH, which correspond to the values endorsed by the civilized world, have lived through the awareness of the citizens on the interests of their state - Bosnia and Herzegovina. Therefore, I hereby extend my congratulations on the Statehood Day to all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Happy Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: Address of the Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina H.E. Šefik Džaferović at the Reception on the Occasion of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina Sarajevo, November 21, 2019
content:
By celebrating the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina we mark the first session held by the Anti-fascist Council for the National Liberation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (ZAVNOBIH) on 25 November 1943, at which its participants restored and reaffirmed the statehood of our country and its territorial integrity.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Excellencies
Dear friends
It is a great honor to welcome you tonight at the reception on the occasion of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
By celebrating the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina we mark the first session held by the Anti-fascist Council for the National Liberation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (ZAVNOBIH) on 25 November 1943, at which its participants restored and reaffirmed the statehood of our country and its territorial integrity.
With pride and due respect, we remember the generation of Bosnia and Herzegovinian patriots who not only had the courage to oppose fascism, but also the resolve, vison, and wisdom to confirm the historical and legal continuity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In such difficult circumstances, in a war-affected Europe and the world, not only were the foundations for the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina laid anew, but also - which is equally important - the unity and equality of all its peoples and citizens was affirmed as well.
People of various ethnic and religious backgrounds have lived here side by side for centuries. Ideas of community and equality represent the very essence of Bosnia and Hercegovina.
Greater-state aspirations that have caused the aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina during the 1990s have attacked the very postulates of ZAVNOBIH: statehood, territorial integrity and our unity. They wanted to destroy Bosnia and Herzegovina, they wanted supremacy of one people over the others, or for one people to simply disappear.
But we fought them back.
Together.
We had defended the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We had defended its territorial integrity.
With the same reverence and gratitude with which we remember the generation that gave us ZAVNOBIH, today we also express our gratitude to the generation of the BiH patriots who defended this country form the last aggression. And they keep defending it today.
The forces that had attacked BiH have not been fully defeated, therefore, we are left with rebuilding and strengthening our community, and fight for the equality of all people in every inch of BiH.
It is a gruesome fight filled with difficult challenges. Yet, despite all the resistance, obstructions and obstacles we witness every day, BiH is moving forward even though it does it slowly one step at the time and it will continue to move forward.
Our goal is clear- BiH as a modern, prosperous state where all people are equal, member of the EU and NATO.
Rest assured, we will surely reach that goal.
Dear friends,
In the 24 post Dayton years of BiH a lot has been done, numerous reforms have been implemented and progress was achieved. Sometimes these processes went at a faster and sometimes at a slower pace.
We made a faster progress while we had a pronounced presence of our friend s form the international community in BiH. The weakening of their interests has resulted in a strengthening of destructive politics which are trying to refute the existing solutions, laws and decisions. Such politics are trying to demote BiH and pull it into new ethnic and even territorial division.
To all of them I would like to state again that it is a futile waste of time, for in this they cannot succeed. It is demonstrated to them clearly every day.
The only thing that can be result of such politics is the exodus of young people from this country, the weakening of the economy and political instability turning investors away. Nobody needs this, nor can it be of use to anybody in this country.
What people of this country need are peace, jobs, economic stability, progress, justice a system guaranteeing equal rights to everyone and a clear perspective offering the hope that they will be able to provide a decent life for themselves and their children.
People are tired from crisis and political disputes.
Therefore it is high time to cease with the irrational obstructions, blockage and attempts to unilaterally change the existing constitutional and legal framework. Too many times we have witnessed, particularly during the last year, that crisis brings nothing good to anyone and that ultimate and unilateral approach achieves nothing.
Instead, we should all together turn to constructive dialogue based on truth and justice, mutual respect, respect of the rule of law, European standards and cooperation for the benefit of all of our people.
We have demonstrated many times that we can agree upon matters and reach compromise; find solutions in the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina that harm no one and benefit all.
I wish to believe that the agreement that we have achieved two days ago here in the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina can be a turning point beyond which this country will strongly move forward.
We all need to step out of the dangerous matrix according to which, once an agreement is reached, someone always needs to be a winner, and someone needs to be defeated. A compromise, an agreement between all of us in Bosnia and Herzegovina is not, and can never be anyone’s defeat.
On the contrary, it can only be a victory for all of us, a victory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, each and every one of its parts and each and every one of its citizens.
With hope that there shall be many such agreements and victories for all of us in Bosnia and Herzegovina in the upcoming period, to all of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina I congratulate the Statehood Day of our homeland, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Thank you.

title: Address by Željko Komšić, Chairman of the Presidency of BiH to the Global Convention of the UN Trust Fund to End Violence against Women
content:
Dear Ms Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, Esteemed representatives of UN Women and UN trust Fund, Esteemed participants of the Convention, Ladies and gentlemen, media representatives, I am glad that I was granted an opportunity to address this important Global Convention of the UN Trust Fund to End Violence against Women.
The Bosnian and Herzegovinian society has faced a lot of challenges in the last decades, including the burning issue of violence against women. According to the statistics provided by the competent institutions, there are over 50% of women in Bosnia and Herzegovina who, since their age of 15, have experienced some form of violence.
These figures are devastating and alarming facts for all of us in Bosnia and Herzegovina, urging us to address the problem and get actively involved in suppressing it.
Violence against women and girls is not and should not be a problem which concerns individuals only. I as an individual and you as parts of the society you live in are responsible of recognizing the features and forms of violence taking place around us. We are obliged to act towards supporting harassed women and girls, while working actively towards creating an environment which will prevent such harassment.
By providing selfless support we will encourage the victims to report the violence they suffered to the competent institutions, while sending a clear message to the perpetrators that they will be punished.
Any form of violence against women or girls represents a violation of the fundamental human rights. In addition to offending a victim, it also has immense consequences to the surroundings in which the victim lives, as well as the consequences to the persons close to the victim, i.e. her family members.
Being a part of the contemporary and civilized society, we are obliged to prevent violence. We are obliged to speak out publicly about this problem, and support the institutions which are ready to undertake measures aimed at suppressing it.
It is important to underline that Bosnia and Herzegovina has undertaken a number of steps so far on achieving a significant progress in creating the preconditions for prevention of violence against women and girls, as well as on ensuring gender equality.
It is the achievement of such objectives that is a priority in promoting, protecting and ensuring the rights of women and girls, and mitigating all forms of violence against them.
The adopted Gender Equality Act in BiH, the legal standards defined by the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, and the objectives defined by the Beijing Declaration and its Platform for Action have been integrated in the legislative system of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In order to achieve the gender equality objectives, Bosnia and Herzegovina adopted its third Gender Action Plan for the period from 2018 to 2022. Bosnia and Herzegovina was the sixth member of the Council of Europe that ratified the Council of Europe’s Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence (The Istanbul Convention).
The laws on protection from domestic violence were adopted, too, and the significant efforts were invested in ensuring protection and support services for the victims of violence, whereas the relevant laws and bylaws have been harmonized with the Istanbul Convention standards. Bosnia and Herzegovina was the first country in the region to adopt and successfully implement the Action Plan for the Implementation of the UN Resolution 1325 “Women, Peace, and Security”.
The Third Action plan for the implementation of the UN Resolution 1325 in Bosnia and Herzegovina for the period from 2018 to 2022 was adopted by the Council of Ministers, with the aim of consistent, high quality and effective implementation of the UN Security Council’s Resolution concerned.
The fact that at the meeting of G7 ministers of foreign affairs in 2018 the European Union selected Bosnia and Herzegovina for its partner within the “G7 Partner Initiative Women, Peace, and Security” supports the claim on the successful implementation of the UN Resolution 1325 in Bosnia and Herzegovina. This is yet another instance of recognition of the positive experience of our country on the issue concerned.
The experience and specific results achieved by Bosnia and Herzegovina have been recognized at the international level, too. Thus, the national action plans of Finland, Moldova, and Albania were created following the model of the Action Plan on the UN Resolution 1325 in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The implementation of the UN Resolution 1325 is just one segment of the regional cooperation between the institutional mechanisms for gender equality in the Western Balkans’ countries. In 2005, Bosnia and Herzegovina started its regional cooperation in the area of gender equality by signing the Regional Declaration on Cooperation of Institutional Mechanisms for Gender Issues in the Western Balkans. At that time, the Regional Coordination Board of Institutional Mechanisms for Gender Equality was established. In this way, Bosnia and Herzegovina took a leadership role in the implementation of a continued regional cooperation.
All data provided by the relevant institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and continuous adoption of the policy and necessary strategies have indicated that our country has expressed commitment to the improvement of a position of women and girls in the society, to their empowerment, as well as to gender equality in all areas of our society. Bosnia and Herzegovina’s cooperation with UN Women and with the UN Trust Fund alike have opened up the path leading to a systemic resolution of the issue of gender-based violence.
A continued support the UN Women and the UNN Trust Fund have provided to us is of a huge importance for Bosnia and Herzegovina, for a continuation of both the good practice and cooperation between the countries in the region, as well as for a contribution to the preservation of peace and good partnership relations alike.
The fact is that there is still a lot of work that we need to do. Bosnia and Herzegovina will have to undergo a process of maturing and implementing the specific reforms in order to address adequately all the challenges it faces. The prejudices faced by the Bosnian and Herzegovinian society should not be an obstacle to a further progress and harmonization of our standards with the international ones, or to a necessary harmonization with the Gender Equality Act.
We should all strive to achieve equality of all our male and female citizens through affirming the values of democratic societies. Although there are examples of women who have significantly contributed to our social spheres, including politics, education, economics or the armed forces, the representation quota of women at the leadership positions has remained low. We have to change that. It is necessary to include as many women as possible in the social and political spheres of the Bosnian and Herzegovinian society, as well as in the reform-focused processes in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is a shared responsibility for all of us to work more intensively on the gender equality in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as on creating an environment which will be as conductive as possible for all to be equal and enjoy equal rights.
Finally, let me point out that the activities related to the process of Euro-Atlantic integrations of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the harmonization of the Bosnian and Herzegovinian social and political system with the European legal tradition should be in the focus of our attention. The implementation of the strategically important reforms and measures will, ultimately, lead to creating a more conductive environment for the implementation of progress in all spheres of our society.
I am convinced that this Global Convention session, which gathered a significant number of participants from the East European and other countries, will contribute to experience sharing and enhancement of mechanisms needed for a more successful fight against violence against women and girls.,
I hereby extend my welcome to all of you to Sarajevo and to Bosnia and Herzegovina, and I wish the Convention a successful work.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by Željko Komšić, Chairman of BiH Presidency at the event marking the 830th anniversary of the Charter of Kulin Ban
content:
Dear representatives of the Bosnian and Herzegovinian academic community in Austria,
Dear Mayor Skaka, and Ambassador Kozarić,
Esteemed ladies and gentlemen!
First of all, let me extend my thanks to the organizer for the invitation to this discussion about our Bosnia and Herzegovina tonight in Vienna, the discussion about those parts of history from which it can be seen that Bosnia and Herzegovina is not some new creation established, thanks to the great powers' will, at the end of the previous century in Dayton, but that it was a state indeed even when most of today's states did not exist.
The colleagues who already delivered their speeches tonight referred to the past and the historical facts. To know and respect the past of one's country is often one of the key conditions for discussing adequately the present, and even the future, or a mechanism necessary for making correct estimates of current, as well as future relations in a certain country.
I do not refer here to the political relations only, which have often been both shaped and channelled by our history in our regions. I also refer hereby to the wider societal relations and processes which unfold in the society itself, sometimes completely independently from the political relations. While appreciating the importance of history and historical facts, I would, however, want to avail myself of this opportunity to share my standpoints on a few issues which are related to the present, as well as to the future of our homeland.
Let me be honest with you: it is not easy to say what is the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina if that future is turned over to others, while expecting that they will take better care of us and of Bosnia and Herzegovina than we ourselves should do, if we expect that others do care more about Bosnia and Herzegovina, that they love or respect it more than we do.
No one knows what tomorrow brings. However, we can at least be certain on what we wish, what we want, and what we are trying to do with our lives and with our country.
I believe that the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the future of us - Bosnians and Herzegovinians will be exactly the one we stand up for. It will be such future we stand up for, and not the one someone else does so.
Personally, I do not believe that effort invested or commitments made can be in vain, that they are futile, that they do not cause any effect.
Let us just remember the effort, commitment, hopes, sacrifice, belief in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the self-confidence of those who gave their lives for our homeland, the state we have today.
It is not perfect, not ideal, not as we imagined it. However, we have it and it is ours, no matter how it is like.
I would not want this brief address to turn into various phrases on integration processes, the phrases you listened to way too often yourselves. I believe that all of us know too well what our key state-focused priorities are, what our desired direction is, and which memberships we want to be granted.
It is my opinion that, while taking our history into consideration, and I already said that it was necessary to be familiar with one's history in order to be able to make correct decisions in today's world, i.e. such decisions which will be beneficial to the future generations in our country, too, and while having in mind elementary and basic human need for security and stability, it is most important now for both ourselves individually and thus for our country BiH to ensure a full membership in the NATO Alliance.
If it is necessary to explain this logic in detail to anyone, and how one reaches such conclusion, I remain available to elaborate on it.
While talking about effort, sacrifice, belief in oneself, hopes, let me mention one of us - Bosnians and Herzegovinians. He showed to us that all this pays off, that efforts invested bring about results relatively quickly, that effort, sacrifice, and belief in oneself are predestined to succeed. Let me, therefore, mention Amel Tuka hereafter. The success of this young athlete, who possesses all these features, made all of us extremely happy some ten days ago.
Imagine, then, how many more people like Amel are there in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the people who do not think about quitting after the first or the second obstacle. They are our future, and it is for them that we must fight. We should not lose hope that everyone who want to live a decent life and earn for living by their work can achieve great success like the one achieved by our Amel Tuka. We live amongst such people. I do believe in such people, and really think that there are many more of them than it may seem to us.
The fact is that a high number of young people left our country, and it sometimes projects a gloomy image of the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina. However, we cannot just mourn over such facts on departures. I do not accept that we lost the people who left the country. In fact, if it was true that they were lost for our country then I would not have been standing before you here today. You have not disconnected yourselves from your homeland, nor will you, I am sure of it, disconnect from it ever.
There is a lot we can do together. All that we do through cooperation, primarily in the area of economics, is the highest possible form of loyalty to our Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Therefore, I believe that the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina lies in ever more intense cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Bosnians and Herzegovinians in any place where they may be today, including Austria.
In this way we will neither lose our identity nor culture. Instead, we will enhance both our identity and culture further.
We knew 830 years ago how to trade and make bilateral agreements, and the Charter of Kulin Ban is an evidence that we did so indeed. Consequently, we will know how to do trade and make bilateral agreements in the future, too.
As long as there are Bosnians and Herzegovinians who love their homeland and wish to advance it, the future of this country cannot be taken away from us by anyone.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Željko Komšić, at the General Debate of the 74th Session of the United Nations General Assembly
content:
Mr. President, Mr. Secretary-General, Excellencies, Ladies and gentlemen, Mr. President Muhammad-Bande, please allow me to first of all congratulate you on your election as the President of the United Nations General Assembly. I will also take the opportunity to thank Mrs. Maria Fernanda Espinosa Garcia, the previous President of the General Assembly.
I would like to emphasize the importance of the current moment. Amidst quite complex political and geopolitical circumstances, we will next year celebrate the 75th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations. This organization has faced numerous challenges in the past. I believe that United Nations General Assembly sessions have always been an opportunity to bring together leaders of different countries and share opinions and views on the world situation and, in particular, to find optimal solutions to contemporary global challenges and problems.
In that respect, the United Nations have also faced escalation of conflicts in different areas in 2019, including a major migrant and refugee crisis, followed by terrorism and violent extremism, as well as other forms of violence perpetrated by various extremist groups. There is also the issue of implementation of the Agenda for Sustainable Economic Growth and Sustainable Development, which will be discussed at this session as well.
Mr. President,
United Nations established the High-level Political Forum on Sustainable Development as a platform where political leaders agree on recommendations regarding the sustainable development matters. This year’s Forum session was held in July 2019, where my country, Bosnia and Herzegovina, for the first time presented the Voluntary National Review (VNR) as part of monitoring of the implementation of sustainable development goals in the country, thus sharing our experiences in accelerating the implementation of the 2030 Agenda.
By adopting the 2030 Agenda, Bosnia and Herzegovina has committed itself to initiating a systematic monitoring and supervision process for the implementation of this global agenda that integrates the social, economic and environmental dimensions of development. Bosnia and Herzegovina takes the view that the successful implementation of the 2030 Agenda requires an agreement on foreseeable, coherent and sufficient funding to achieve sustainable development goals.
For these reasons, we believe that the achievement of the 2030 Agenda goals should strongly and qualitatively contribute to eradication of poverty, reduction of world hunger, protection of the environment, and handling of the evident climate changes. Bosnia and Herzegovina sees the United Nations Agenda for Sustainable Development and its transformative nature as an opportunity and a mechanism of change aiming to comprehensively promote the social, economic and environmental aspects of the life of population. We therefore hope that the Review of Implementation Activities for the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development in Bosnia and Herzegovina will be finalized by the end of 2019 and submitted to the High-level Political Forum to be held in the coming years.
Mr. President,
Bosnia and Herzegovina believes that the present time offers a special opportunity to change the course of development by creating a self-sustaining environment that will benefit everyone. It is a great honor for Bosnia and Herzegovina to be a part of this transformational Agenda as a sovereign country and provide our contribution within the worldwide countries family. Successful cooperation with the United Nations encourages our implementation of the 2030 Agenda, which presents an opportunity for Bosnia and Herzegovina to share our own experience, lessons learned, as well as challenges and practices on important life issues with the other United Nations member states and contribute towards strengthening of the international cooperation.
Mr. President,
Activities related to the Euro-Atlantic integration process in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the alignment of the BiH socio-political system with the EU acquis communautaire, are at the center of political developments in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as the country is committed to continuing its activities to stabilize the situation and accelerate the initiated reform processes.
