The European Commission’s Opinion on Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU membership application is a very accurate record of all the reforms required. Some of the reforms require the voidance and annulment of the existing systemic discrimination against the citizens of my country, which, unfortunately, is set out in certain provisions of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as provisions of various legislative acts. Bosnia and Herzegovina will have to undergo a process of maturation in order to reach such a political level that those necessary reforms can be implemented without major socio-political strains.
Furthermore, Bosnia and Herzegovina is actively contributing to regional security efforts in our region. In that respect, I would like to assure you that Bosnia and Herzegovina is a reliable, serious and determined partner to the United Nations, the European Union and NATO. We are particularly determined to strengthen the European security area, committed to fight organized crime, combat terrorism and violent extremism, as well as illegal migration, and to protect the security of national borders in terms of migration management. With regard to international challenges of the modern times, Bosnia and Herzegovina particularly emphasizes its commitment to global efforts to combat terrorism and violent extremism.
Mr. President,
In addition to internal reforms, Bosnia and Herzegovina also focuses on strengthening regional co-operation, especially when it comes to infrastructure projects in the communications, transport and energy sectors. Internationally, Bosnia and Herzegovina is active within the United Nations and organizations such as the OSCE, the Council of Europe, CEFTA, and other various regional initiatives. We would like to emphasize that Bosnia and Herzegovina in the previous period had a prominent and active chairmanship of the SEECP regional initiative and MARRI, where it invested additional efforts and provided an active impetus to the regional approach to facing current challenges.
Bilateral relations between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the neighboring countries are at the top of our foreign policy priorities. That should be the foundation for continuous improvement of cooperation based on mutual interest and the principle of equality, respect for one another and respect for state sovereignty and territorial integrity. The above might lead to conclusion that the relations between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the neighboring countries are good and intensive. However, due to particular policies of our neighbors, we occasionally witness their activities aimed at realization of their own political interests within Bosnia and Herzegovina. That causes unrest and produces a degree of destabilization in my country, which is neither good, nor does it contribute to development of the desired good neighborly relations.
Mr. President,
The United Nations has primary responsibility for world peace and security. One should not lose sight of the interactive interdependence and complexity of the relationship between peace and security, development and cooperation and especially the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. With the increasing number of conflicts becoming progressively more complex, we are aware that the United Nations is facing a number of challenges, especially on the African continent and the Middle East. In order to find an adequate solution to numerous crises, Bosnia and Herzegovina supports the United Nations efforts to strengthen the preventive diplomacy sector within the political affairs department. It is of particular importance that all disputes be resolved peacefully, as stated in Article 33 of the Charter of the United Nations, which expressly requires that disputes be resolved peacefully and with good will to resolve them. United Nations and Security Council resolutions represent one form of support for such peaceful settlement of various disputes between the countries.
Bosnia and Herzegovina continuously monitors these phenomena and, to the best of its ability, strengthens its capacities in the fight against terrorism, international crime and narcotics production and trafficking, as well as trafficking in human beings occurring within the framework of migration movements. Bosnia and Herzegovina strongly condemns violent extremism and terrorism in all its forms, and finds all acts of extremism and terrorism, regardless of their form, motivation and perpetrators, to be criminal and unjustifiable. Bosnia and Herzegovina is committed to the full implementation of all UN Security Council resolutions aimed at bringing persons involved in the financing, planning, preparation or commission of terrorist acts to justice.
Mr. President,
Bearing in mind the direct correlation between security and sustainable development and the central role the United Nations has in the process of peacebuilding and the creation of basic conditions for the development of post-conflict societies, I would like to emphasize that Bosnia and Herzegovina supports the United Nations’ direct activities in stabilizing post-conflict societies by building and strengthening institutions, especially those in the field of the rule of law, protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms, security, reintegration and reconciliation processes.
Bosnia and Herzegovina expresses its concern about the ongoing escalation of violence in the world, especially in the Middle East, and I take this opportunity to call for an end of combat activities and for the finding of peaceful solutions. Bosnia and Herzegovina has a principled view that the protection of civilians, respect for human rights and humanitarian law are a necessary priority in international relations.
Bosnia and Herzegovina's foreign policy is focused on maintaining and promoting lasting peace and security in all parts of the world. The activities of Bosnia and Herzegovina in terms of international relations are based on the principles enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations, the Helsinki Final Act and other Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe documents, as well as generally accepted principles of international law. Bosnia and Herzegovina has either ratified or successively taken on the most significant international documents in this field and is ready for full cooperation with other countries, both within relevant multilateral organizations and initiatives, as well as bilaterally, in order to effectively combat proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and their means of deployment.
Bosnia and Herzegovina also advocates all general positions in terms of promoting and supporting all realistic and effective ideas that will lead to the ultimate goal, which is the world without nuclear weapons.
In accordance with the obligations arising from the provisions of the United Nations Security Council Resolution 1540, regarding the prevention of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and their means of transport, Bosnia and Herzegovina is focused on fulfilling its commitments with an emphasis on strengthening dialogue and non-proliferation cooperation on mass destruction as well as various forms of regional cooperation.
Bosnia and Herzegovina explicitly opposes provision of any support to non-state actors and entities seeking to develop, procure, produce, possess, transport, transfer or use nuclear, chemical or biological weapons and their means of transfer. Furthermore, we actively and directly contribute to the United Nations peacekeeping missions, one of the most visible components of the United Nations. As a sovereign country that attaches particular importance to peacekeeping missions, Bosnia and Herzegovina best demonstrates its participation and commitment to peacekeeping through its involvement in United Nations and NATO peacekeeping missions. Bosnia and Herzegovina welcomes the commitment of the United Nations to support the participation of women in peacekeeping missions. I would like to point out with particular pleasure that we are one of the few countries that has been fulfilling its stated goals for a long time, that is, over 20% of women participating in peacekeeping missions.
Mr. President,
I would particularly like to point out that the Agreement on Suppression of Sexual Exploitation and Abuse was signed on January 10, 2019 between the United Nations and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which obliged my country to hold everyone responsible, whether civilian or uniformed, for all forms of sexual exploitation and abuse in United Nations peacekeeping or other humanitarian operations, including support for a zero tolerance policy towards this type of deviant behavior.
International legal framework is the starting point to exercise the rights of a child, and the International Convention on the Rights of the Child is the fundamental instrument to determine the legal framework and policies of the countries that are the Parties to the Convention, which focus on addressing the issues of the rights of a child. The Country Programme 2015 - 2019 between UNICEF and Bosnia and Herzegovina is particularly important as it further contributes to the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the Convention on Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, and the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as well as the Development Agenda for the period after 2015.
Racial discrimination, as well as other forms of discrimination, is insufficiently regulated by the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Still, these deviant phenomena are referenced through several features of criminal offenses within the criminal legislation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as lower levels of government. That clearly expresses the commitment of the authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina to respect the human rights of all citizens who live there, as well as permanently resident aliens or aliens granted temporary residence on the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with respect to all principles of mutual tolerance. However, as I said earlier, certain provisions providing for systemic discrimination remain in the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as established in the four judgments of the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, in the Sejdić-Finci, Zornić, Pilav and Šlak cases, as well as the European Commission’s Opinion on Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU membership application. Bosnia and Herzegovina must provide for constitutional reforms as well as reforms of various laws in order to meet the European standard, which is the equality of all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in all aspects of life. Such action will require the agreement of domestic political actors to remove obstacles to the continuation of the process of integration into the European Union.
In the area of ​​trafficking in human beings, a comprehensive and multidisciplinary Action Plan to Combat Trafficking in Human Beings in Bosnia and Herzegovina for the period 2016-2019 aims to improve the support system for combating trafficking in human beings in Bosnia and Herzegovina. We will further modernize this plan and prepare a new one for the coming period.
Mr. President,
The rule of law and international law are firmly established in the provisions of the Charter of the United Nations, which is the very foundation of this organization. Bosnia and Herzegovina is committed to promoting the rule of law at all levels - national, regional and international, and firmly committed to contributing towards the building, strengthening and full respect of international law, including human rights and international humanitarian law. Therefore, I would like to assure you that Bosnia and Herzegovina is committed to respecting its international obligations. That is very important for our contribution to the comprehensive development, preservation and maintenance of peace, and the promotion of human rights, fundamental freedoms and sustainable development.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is fully cooperating with the International Criminal Tribunal Residual Mechanism, which has taken over functions from the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, including judicial functions, enforcement of sanctions, relocation of released individuals and protection of victims and witnesses. The authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina remain committed to ensuring that all persons suspected of war crimes on the territory of the former Yugoslavia must be brought to justice.
Bosnia and Herzegovina hereby reaffirms its commitment to continue negotiations on United Nations reform in accordance with the final document of the 2005 New York World Summit of Heads of State and Government. Reform of the United Nations system is necessary, but such reform must be carried out with extreme care and broadest consensus of the Member States. Bosnia and Herzegovina shares the view that developing countries are underrepresented in the Security Council, which is an appropriate point to hear and discuss the specific issues and problems of developing countries.
Given the sensitivity of the issue, Bosnia and Herzegovina is committed to reaching a compromise solution. Given that the number of Eastern European countries has more than doubled, we expect that the reformed Security Council will be expanded with additional seats for non-permanent members of the Eastern European group of countries. Bosnia and Herzegovina also supports greater representation of African countries, as well as small and medium-developed countries, including the small island countries.
Thank you Mr. President.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić during the award ceremony “The Honorary Citizen of the Bosanska Krupa Municipality “
content:
Dear citizens of Bosanska Krupa, dear Mayor! I am honoured that on the occasion of the Bosanska Krupa Municipality Day, I can receive the “Honorary Citizen of Bosanska Krupa Municipality” award. I take the opportunity to thank you all for this honour.
It is my particular pleasure to receive recognition on the day of the liberation of Bosanska Krupa from the aggressor. To this day, members of the Fifth Corps, or members of the 511st Famous Brigade, liberated this city through a masterful action as part of the Operation Sana 95 and made the enemy of the state panic.
The enemy left a devastated and looted city behind. However, the town's citizens who love the town and who love this country raised Bosanska Krupa to its feet again. That is why I am glad to see that Bosanska Krupa lives its life, and not the one intended by its aggressor.
Therefore, the aggressor failed in his goal. His goal will remain unfathomable permanently, but our goals are still alive. More alive than ever. Just in this town, last year, during the election campaign, I spoke about the goals of us who love and fight for the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and at the time I said that we must maintain faith in the idea of ​​the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Now I will repeat the same thing I said then.
The day we stop believing in the idea of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina is the day we will lose this kind of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Do not let them kill our idea of a Republic, a democracy we cherished amongst ourselves, even when political parties did not exist. We politicians need to constantly be highlighting it as the fundamental value of politics and our Bosnian-Herzegovinian society. Let's stop just talking in our own and the name of our close ones, let's stop listening just to ourselves and our close ones. Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a republic, will again be a society in which we are open to everyone, as we once were. I believe in this and that is why I am in politics.
The idea of ​​the Republic is not one's private or party property, but the first-of-its-kind legacy of the vision of the civil state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It does not belong to one people, nation or religion, but to all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina who feel this country their own, as well as those who are no longer among us.
This idea is worth advocating in every possible way, and we show our best commitment by preserving peace. Peace is, in fact, our only weapon. It is the weapon which those who seek to undermine the sovereignty of the State of Bosnia and Herzegovina, inventing some other sovereignties, will succumb to. We are not in a hurry as much as they were to tear down the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. There's a common saying: All things come to those who wait.
We are facing a struggle through peaceful political means to advance Bosnia and Herzegovina through the necessary reforms and make it a modern state for all its citizens, by joining the larger security, political and economic systems.
Allow me once again to thank you for this honour.
Thank you.

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić gave speech at the (Royal College of Defence Studies as part of the working visit to the United Kingdom
content:
Dear Soldiers, Officers, Government Officers, Ladies and Gentlemen! It is a special honour for me to address you today as Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina and as a former soldier of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. There is almost no greater honour in public engagement than to serve your country militarily, and when you have noble and civil intentions, that honour is even greater. Indeed, it is a nice feeling to know that you have fought for justice, freedom and peace, against injustice, tyranny and terror. When you pursue such noble goals, no one can take away that feeling.
I am particularly pleased to say this here before you, who are proudly serving our friendly country, the United Kingdom, a NATO member state, the same alliance of countries in the interest of maintaining peace and stability in the world, and to whom we in Bosnia and Herzegovina, despite numerous resistances, we strive. Among those present here are also people who come from other countries in order to deepen the knowledge in this elite institution. I believe that your goals are the same as ours, namely collective security, the rule of law, democracy, freedom.
I wish to highlight on this occasion that the friendship between the peoples and citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the United Kingdom is not recent. It was built a long time ago, through a common struggle and commitment to what are true civic and democratic values, through the struggle between civilization and anti-civilization, through the glorious struggle and sacrifices our citizens endured in the fight against fascism in World War II.
Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens do not forget their friends easily especially since though they had not done any harm to anyone, they have had many enemies throughout their history.
All of us in Bosnia and Herzegovina know very well how the support of the United Kingdom has been in the moments of statehood and global fascism. Brigadier General Fitzroy Maclean did not randomly fall from the sky in the small town of Drvar in September 1943, but, at Churchill's request, descended a parachute to Tito's headquarters near Drvar, to help, on behalf of your country, the heroic struggle of our partisans who fought for our state, and against our then common enemy. Together they planned coordinated actions by the partisan army and allied aviation to prevent the enemy from regrouping in Central and Western Europe, which would further prolong the war.
It is no wonder, therefore, that Britain was the first to see who in our region fought for the same goals and against the same enemy. For this reason, but not only for this reason, the friendship between our countries is a permanent category. We were on the same, or on the right side of history, and that, I am convinced, will remain so in the future.
Bosnia and Herzegovina wants to be part of a community of states and security systems that want peace in the world. I've said it before, but just because of the importance of it, I keep saying it. We are grateful to the United Kingdom for the efforts made since the signing of the Dayton Peace Agreement. These peacekeeping efforts in Bosnia and Herzegovina have not failed. Thanks to British troops coming to the BiH peacekeeping mission, our country is stable today. However, we want it to be even more stable. That is why we greatly appreciate the support the United Kingdom is providing to Bosnia and Herzegovina on its path to NATO integration.
We will not be distracted from this path by troublemakers whose goals are not in the interest of peace, who spread unrest even in Britain, regardless how hard they may be trying. I will not mention their names, because we in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the UK know very well who they are. We are on the threshold of the 70th anniversary of the NATO Pact, which has brought lasting peace, security and prosperity to much of Europe. It is time for the process to be completed and rounded by incorporating the remaining countries that have publically declared for NATO membership, including Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is therefore necessary to further strengthen the bilateral ties of our countries in the coming period. The foundation for that, as I said, is long overdue. In the changed geopolitical circumstances in the world, cooperation between our countries, both political and economic as well as military, is both essential, necessary and mutually beneficial. For my part, I will do my utmost to strengthen this cooperation and further expand it at each of the levels mentioned. In this context, I take this opportunity to express my satisfaction with the engagement of the United Kingdom Ambassador to Bosnia and Herzegovina, His Excellency Matthew Field, who is a true friend of the State of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all its citizens.
Finally, dear attendees, I would like to say the following; Only the names of heroes, whether soldiers, officers, diplomats or statesmen, remain written in history. I want you to be honoured with the merit of peace, because peace is the most sacred thing we need to protect today, in the name of the future. That is the victory we must strive for.
Thank you.

title: Speech by Željko Komšić, Chairman of BiH Presidency within the central programme of the “Defence of BiH - Igman 2019” event
content:
Esteemed families of the shaheeds and the fallen soldiers, Disabled military veterans, Veterans of the Army and the Ministry of Interior of the Republic of BiH, the defenders of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
Dear President Džaferović, Minister Bukvarević, Minister Jusko, ladies and gentlemen!
Today, at this place, the place which was essential for the defence of Sarajevo and out entire homeland, we remember those who, by superhuman efforts, by their hearts and souls, went to the battle and laid down their lives for our country’s freedom.
Today we remember the heroic times.
This territory was crucial for the defence of Sarajevo, and we all know all too well what would have happened if Igman fell. Namely, it is questionable how the war would have ended in that case.
Thanks to the courageous people who were fighting back then at this territory, Igman was defended, Sarajevo was defended, and Bosnia and Herzegovina was defended.
The enemies did not succeed in killing the heart of this state which was already wounded. They knew that the one who held Sarajevo controlled the entire Bosnia and Herzegovina. However, they failed in fulfilling their intentions.
Those who are not with us today sacrificed themselves and prevented them in such an endeavour.
We should never forget it!
Therefore, we need to tell the truth on what happened in BiH. Actually, it was indeed the conflict between the civilization and the anti-civilization.
We, the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, defended the true civilizational values and democratic norms, whereas all others, and let this statement be understood in any way anyone wants to understand it, discarded and rejected such values, and the history is yet to give its judgment on it.
Therefore, we do send a message to them from this place that they should not be threatening us. We defended the state with not much more than our bare hands, while they had at their disposal the facilities built up for fifty years in the military industry.
Bosnia and Herzegovina and her citizens have their past, their present, and will have their future, and that future will be without false compromises, without divisions, false policies, and without those who have acted openly against Bosnia and Herzegovina and her citizens.
Ensuring such a future is the obligation of all of us!
Our young generations have not carried the burden of the past as we have done so. Despite the evil which befell us, we should teach them not to hate. However, we also must tell them the truth on what happened during the past war in BiH.
The truth which has been confirmed by the whole world, that very world which witnessed the horrors which befell BiH. We should not allow any Yutel-like delusions re-occur, nor should we allow that it is believed again that our destiny is in the hands of others, that it depends on the good will of others. No, it does not! Our destiny depends upon ourselves, and ourselves only, as well as on the past lessons we learnt.
Therefore, I am, once again, inviting those who have been trying to forge the truth: do not do it! Do not do it for the sake of these young people to whom we are obligated to ensure both peaceful and safe future.
Let us not conduct mutual battles when we already won one, which we did not ask for in the first place.
Do not let your own or the interests of others lead you in your endeavours. Do work instead in the interest of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all her citizens. The interests of all the citizens include peace, stability and prosperity. Do not think that there is no war conducted nowadays against BiH. That current war is silent, treacherous, and ruthless.
The more quiet, treacherous or ruthless that war is, the firmer our obligation is to be as loud as possible. And let us tell them: “Listen, ladies and gentlemen, in this country or outside it, no generation of Bosnians and Herzegovinians has been born or lived, nor shall it be born, who would be ready to let this country die, either with the roar of canons and army tanks or quietly and voicelessly.
Thank you.

title: Address by Šefik Džaferović, BiH Presidency member at the opening ceremony of “The Defence of BiH - Igman 2019“ event
content:
Dear BiH Presidency Chairman, Esteemed members of the shaheed families and the families of the fallen soldiers, Esteemed disabled military veterans, Esteemed members of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Esteemed representatives of all administrative levels!
A two-day event “The Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina – Igman 2019“ starts today, marking our memory of the battle of Igman, one of the most important battles during the defence against the aggression.
These are the days when we recall the glorious victory of the soldiers of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which took place in the summer of 1993 on the Igman mountain. This victory was of essential importance for the defence of the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as for the defence and survival of the entire country.
The aim of the aggressor forces was to take Igman and cut off the final landline which was connecting Sarajevo with the rest of the free territories, and, ultimately, with the rest of the world. If the aggressor succeeded in this intention, then the siege which curtailed and strangled the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina from the beginning of the aggression would have been fully rounded. That would have had huge, probably substantial consequences as eventual cutting off of the communication by land between Sarajevo and the rest of the country would have been irrecoverable from both military and strategic perspectives.
Thanks to the heroic efforts of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina's soldiers, the aggressor was brought to its knees and prevented from achieving its objectives. With many times more arms and supplies, the Greater Serbian aggressor tried to break the backbone of defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina on the Igman Mountain. However, in the end, the aggressor broke its own teeth instead. The Army of RBiH demonstrated its glorious strength.
In the course of these days back then, the history re-confirmed that there is nothing stronger than an army of honourable people who are fighting for a right cause.
The aggressor forces had both infamous and criminal aims. Their goal was to break down Bosnia and Herzegovina, while destroying the Bosniak people and all BiH patriots respectively. It was established by the judgments passed by the highest instances of international justice that their fight was marked with the breaches of the international law, as well as of the rules and customs of warfare. It was, to put it simply, the joint criminal enterprise.
On the other hand, the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was fighting for the noblest aims, which included defending and preserving Bosnia and Herzegovina, and defending of the Bosniak people against the genocide. From 1992 to 1995, the Army of the Republic of BiH, as the only legal military formation in the territory of BiH, was defending the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the right of the Bosniak people and all BiH patriots to survival.
Parallel to this, the RBiH Army, in the mountains of Igman and other fierce battlefields throughout BiH, was the only one in the period from 1992 to 1995 that defended the basic values of the free, democratic world and elementary civilizational principles, including the idea woven into the core of Bosnia and Herzegovina – the idea that the people of different ethnic or religious affiliations can live together.
Thanks to our aim being the righteous one, Bosnia and Herzegovina was preserved and defended. If they managed to convince us, and then the rest of the world as well, that Bosnia and Herzegovina was a land of hatred, and that her peoples could not live together, this country would not have had a chance to survive. The crime perpetrators failed in destroying the civilizational idea of Bosnia and Herzegovina. They will never be able to succeed in their cause because we will never allow them to do that.
All those who, during the aggression, tried to destroy Bosnia and Herzegovina, have been trying to do the same now with their followers and successors, this time hidden under various disguise, in a perfidious way, not by the military means any more, but by the political ones.
The options we were faced with had never been choosing between war and peace, confrontation or cooperation, but between fight and surrender, between freedom and slavery. It was like that in 1992. It is like that now, too. We have always chosen to fight, and today it is a political fight on which the destiny of this country depends. Therefore, it is important to create and strengthen the awareness on the need of defending the country because a unity of this country's patriots is the only guarantee of its preservation.
Tomorrow is the day when the veterans of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina from all parts of the country will gather on Igman to recall the memories from the summer of 1993, and inform the young generations on the most difficult times in the history of our country, when both the state and the freedom were defended.
“The Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina – Igman 2019“ event starts here, in this special place, with the shaheeds.
We are here today to pay respects to all fallen soldiers of the Army of the Republic of BiH, to the best sons of this country. If it were not for their sacrifice and readiness to, at all costs, including the cost of their own lives, defend Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bosnia and Herzegovina would not have existed now.
Therefore, we will never forget the sacrifice of the shaheeds and the fallen soldiers of the Army of the Republic of BIH, and we will teach the new generations about it because it is by studying the truth on the period of aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina that one can understand most fully the essence of the current political processes in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
A special message that I would like to send from this place today is the one on the importance of caring for the families of the shaheeds and the fallen soldiers. The debt with which our shaheeds and the fallen soldiers of the Army of RBiH indebted us is not reimbursable ever because their sacrifice is that huge. However, we need to keep returning that debt all the time, while working on protecting the rights of the families of the shaheeds and the fallen soldiers. We have done that all these years since the war ended, in accordance with our possibilities. We will continue doing this in the future, too.
The representatives of the state, the holders of office at all administrative levels, must have this in mind every day as their obligation and homework, and they should never fail in availing themselves of the opportunity to provide support and assistance to the families of the best sons of this country.
Thank you.

title: Željko Komšić, BiH Presidency Chairman attends marking the 27th anniversary of Čedomir Čedo Domuz' and Smajo Soma's deaths. On this occasion the BiH Presidency Chairman laid wreaths on the Brezovača m
content:
“Dear family members, friends, fellow soldiers, and all who respect Čedomir Domuz and Smajo Soma and their deeds,
We have gathered here in Igman today to pay respects at the Brezovača memorial to our Golden Lilies Čedo and Smajo. Unfortunately, they have not been with us for 27 years now. We have all missed them, and those who have missed them most are, I know, their children and families.
It is precisely because of their children and other family members that we must not forget what Čedo and Smajo did for the defense of Igman from the key moments of organising defense until their premature and tragic death in the operation of liberation of Trnovo and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
They were both uncomplicated and good people who loved their city, their homeland, and its people. When the war started, they disregarded any consequences and fought, together with their fellow soldiers, for Bosnia and Herzegovina's freedom, for the freedom of all of us living in this country.
I find it painful when no sufficient credit is given to the people like Čedomir and Smajo for what they did. We should not allow their sacrifice, or the sacrifice of all courageous people who lost their lives during the past war, to become futile.
Insufficient attention has been paid to their families, their children. Their children, such as Čedo's ones, are adults. Today, by their knowledge, efforts and work they contribute to a better Bosnia and Herzegovina, thus defying those who would still it to be different from that.
Therefore, we must not forget Čedo and Smajo. We should not forget the people who laid down their lives to defend Bosnia and Herzegovina, to the people who enabled us to live in peace today. They are heroes of both difficult and critical times in the history of our country, and for that we are indebted and will be eternally grateful to them.“

title: BiH Presidency Member Šefik Džaferović attended the opening of the shaheed memorial in Žepa and marking the fall of the UN “Safe Area” 24 years ago
content:
Esteemed members of the shaheed families, Esteemed members of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dear all originating from Žepa,
We are marking today the completion of the construction of the shaheed memorial in Žepa, which will always remind us of the most difficult days in the history of this area, and of the entire Bosnia and Herzegovina. We are also paying respects today to the best sons of this country because Bosnia and Herzegovina would not have existed today if it were not for them. We will never forget what happened to this country and to our people during the aggression from 1992 to 1995. We will teach the future generations about it because oblivion is dangerous. The one who forgets takes a risk that evil will be done against him again.
It is with sadness that we remember the 453 Bosniaks, who were killed by the aggressor forces during the three and a half years of the siege of Žepa, and in the last days of July 1995. We also remember more than one thousand people who were taken from Žepa to the detention camps back then. They were taken to the camps in the occupied territory, as well as in the territory of the neighbouring Serbia, where they were held in detention even long after the Dayton Peace Agreement was signed.
On July 27, 1995, which was precisely 24 years ago, there was not a single Bosniak left in Žepa. The death squads of Ratko Mladić started the systemic looting and destruction of the Bosniak houses on that day, and, at the end of it, they also destroyed the mosque. They wanted to remove the traces of our existence in this area, in the Podrinje region of ours, which was one of the goals of the Greater Serbian aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina.
There is also an opportunity today to recall the shameful role of the UN Ukrainian battalion which, without any resistance, handed over the “protected area“ to the Mladić' units. By doing so, they betrayed the people of Žepa, and blatantly deceived their own mandate, which had been given to them by the United Nations.
By handing over the “protected area“ which was declared safe by the Security Council, the highest ranking body in charge of international security, the international community and the United Nations lost their credibility in the eyes of many around the world, and have not managed to restore it to date.
One of the numerous activities which contributed to this was the UN approval to Mladić' army first to kidnap, within the UNPROFOR base in Žepa, and then shoot dead Avdo Palić, Commander of the Žepa Brigade of the Army of RBiH, as well as the members of the war leadership of Žepa, including Mehmed Hajrić, and Amir Imamović. The fact that the UN forces handed over the delegation consisting of legitimate authorities to the hands of the war criminals, and the fact that they did it during the peace negotiations, will remain an unprecedented act, and a permanent shame of the UN.
Žepa is a symbol of suffering in our collective memory. However, Žepa is also a symbol of resistance. From the very start of the aggression, the people of this area resisted and opposed heroically against the fierce attacks of the aggressor armada, and they were doing so throughout the three years of the siege.
Žepa was the last refuge to thousands of refugees from the surrounding areas, and it was only thanks to Žepa that thousands of people managed to survive. The heroes of the Žepa Brigade of the Army of the Republic of BiH, led by their commander Avdo Palić, are those who who deserve credit for this, and we will never forget their deeds.
The restored houses and the returnee community in Žepa have testified that the aggressor, although committing the most horrific crimes, has not succeeded after all. The perpetrators of crime dreamed about it that there would be no Bosnia and Herzegovina. However, it survived and has grown stronger despite such aspirations. They also dreamt about removing Bosniaks altogether. However, the Bosniaks survived and have grown stronger.
Every day, since the Dayton agreement was signed, there has been more and more of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which has contributed to the anti-state forces' panicking. By their ongoing attempts to erode this country, to undermine its foundations, or at least obstruct its development, they have constantly reminded us of their intentions. However, they should know that they will never succeed in their endeavours.
We will never give in under the pressure of those who do not wish well to this country and its citizens, and we will continue to fight for the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in which each person should have equal rights at each inch of its territory.
You, the returnees, are amongst the greatest heroes in the fight for the state in the times of peace. The process of return has a crucial importance in reconstruction and restoration of the state. The policy of division of Bosnia and Herzegovina was marked with the expulsion of people from their homes. Therefore, there is no better way to oppose such policy than by return of the people to their homes.
Both economic and financial state resources have increased constantly. Investment in returnee communities and support to returnees, particularly the young ones, must be a strategic commitment of all administrative levels. All returnees deserve to have access to security, housing, as well as to jobs in order to ensure a decent life to themselves and their families. I will continue to advocate strongly, through the institution of the Presidency of BiH, and urge for intensifying the programmes which will be directed to further enhancement of the status and the rights of returnees in all parts of BiH.
A united and democratic state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, member of the European Union and NATO Alliance alike, has remained our goal. I have no doubt that we will reach that goal by committed work. However, our development will not only be measured by the results we manage to achieve in the area of economics or through large construction projects. Our success will primarily be measured by and depending on the quality of life of those who live in the borderline, returnee places, most remote from the centres. We must have this in mind every day, while working devotedly and sincerely in order to ensure a peaceful and prosperous future to the state and the new generations alike.
Thank you.

title: Address by Šefik Džaferović, BiH Presidency member at the commemoration marking the 24th anniversary of the genocide committed in Srebrenica, July 11th, 2019
content:
Dear mothers of Srebrenica, esteemed families of the victims of genocide, dear friends from Bosnia and Herzegovina and the world, who have shared pain and sorrow with us, while demonstrating piety in remembering the innocent victims of the genocide committed in Srebrenica,
We gathered here today to lay to rest the mortal remains of 33 people, the 33 people who were innocent!
To whom and of what the 16-year old boy Osman Cvrk can be guilty? We will bury his mortal remains here today. To whom and of what all other children can be guilty? The white gravestones mark their graves in Potočari. What was the nature of quilt of Asim and Kasim Isakovic, the boys who were just coming of age? What was the guilt of Zaim Pilav and his son Fuad? What was the guilt of the 82-year old Šaha Cvrk, and all other old men and women who got killed? What wrong and to whom did all these victims do? These women, including the pregnant ones, the new-borns, the boys, the old men, the men who defended their families and bare lives were all killed in an excruciating way.
The reason for which they were killed was only one – they were Muslims, Bosniaks. That indeed was the sole and sufficient reason for the RS Army and RS Police death squadrons of Karadžić and Mladić, supported by the paramilitary units from Serbia to, in just a couple of days in July, in an organized and monstrous way, kill over 8.300 people. More than 1.000 people were killed daily. One innocent, helpless human being was killed almost each minute.
The goal was to exterminate one ethnic group in this area. The crime unfolded before the eyes of the whole world. By its resolution, the United Nations declared Srebrenica a safe zone. However, they did not, when they should have done so, make steps to prevent the gravest crime committed in Europe since the Second World War.
Srebrenica will always remain a dark stain on the conscience of all those who could have and but failed to prevent the genocide committed there. The UN officials recognized it years later. Unfortunately, the representatives of the international community still lack a more decisive reaction, this time to the genocide denial and glorification of the war crimes.
By failing to prevent genocide in the area the UN Security Council declared “a safe UN zone” the international community lost its credibility in the eyes of many around the world. The only chance for the United Nations and the international community to restore a part of its lost credibility is to decisively oppose those who deny the truth about the crime, and glorify its perpetrators.
In various forms, the crime unfolded against the victims of the genocide even after their death. In order to attempt to hide the crime, the victims’ bodies were additionally affected by the acts of acts of sacrilege for months after the genocide was committed. This was done by moving the mortal remains from one grave to another in order to hide them. The mortal remains of one person were sometimes found in two, three, even in four different graves. As the genocide was committed in an organized and systemic way, an attempt was made to hide the crime in a systemic and organized way subsequently.
A continuation of the crime against the victims, or at least complicity, we can indeed consider the silence due to which, even 24 years after the genocide, we have not found the bodies of all who were killed can be considered a continuation of the crime against the victims, or complicity to say the least. Over 1,700 victims have not been found or identified yet, they have not found their eternal peace, and they were not buried yet in a decent way worthy of human beings.
Therefore, I hereby re-iterate, as many did already in this context, an appeal to our neighbours: do disclose the locations of the mass graves, and thus ease the pain and suffering to the victims’ families! Help yourselves, find a grain of goodness in yourselves, and, at least partly, ease your conscience! Do not go around living with the thoughts that, around you, there are the hidden graves with the bodies of innocent people who were killed, while you remain silent. Do have in mind that, until their souls find peace, you will not be at peace with yourselves either.
We consider genocide denial and glorification of its perpetrators responsible for the crime special kinds of posthumous crimes committed against the victims. It was established scientifically that denial is the final phase of genocide.
Genocide has been denied despite the judgments passed by the International Court of Justice and The Hague Tribunal respectively. Having in mind the evidence on brutal killings, while clearly recognizing the aim to which the mass executions were committed, and faced with a distorted ideology which was driving the systemic and organized perpetration of the crimes, both international and domestic courts established, in the only way which is possible and correct, that the events of July 1995 constituted the crime of genocide.
Unfortunately, the political and religious elites of the Serb people have not wanted to accept these facts, they have refused to face the truth or distance themselves clearly from the ideology which created the genocide. They have not wanted to distance themselves from the specific perpetrators either, who were mainly sentenced to life or many years of imprisonment. They have done exactly the contrary – they have glorified them.
By genocide denial and glorification of the convicted war criminals they have not only insulted the victims and the victims’ families, but defied all civilized world, which knows what the truth is, and understands the meaning of the judgments passed by the international courts. Although they may not be aware of it, it is by such attitude that they have caused most harm to their own people, onto whom they have projected the guilt for the crimes driven by Milosevic’ and Karadzic’ policy.
The path they have followed is wrong. The right path would be to recognize the genocide was committed, accept the court judgments, clearly and unequivocally distance themselves from its creators and perpetrators alike, as well as from the ideology which created it. Further, they should support, together with us, passing of the law on banning genocide denial and glorification of war crimes. It is only in this way, on the basis of truth and by accepting the court judgments, that trust can be restored. We need such trust not only for our own sake, but for the sake of the future generations.
As for ourselves, we know our path indeed. We will keep insisting on justice to be done as long as it takes for the final perpetrator to get punished. And we will guard the truth. Nobody will be able to overpower that truth. In addition to the fact that it was written in the court judgments, which are historical facts, that truth is carved deeply into our collective consciousness.
It is carved in indeed as a warning!
The truth about the genocide committed in Srebrenica has been carved in permanently in the collective consciousness of the civilized world. Numerous commemorative events on genocide in many cities around the world, on all continents, have bear witness to that. Remembering Srebrenica has become a global event. Year after year, the Peace March is joined not only by the people originating from Bosnia and Herzegovina, but by those from all other parts of the world.
All of them are the guardians of the truth. I hereby extend my thanks to all of them for guarding the truth.
Dear friends,
The white gravestones in the Potočari valley, and this memorial centre have also bear witness to this. I hope that time will come shortly when we will find, identify, and bury all 8,372 victims, so that they and their families can find peace.
The years will follow when there will be no collective funerals in Potočari. This fact obligates us additionally to equip this memorial centre in terms of infrastructure, supplies, technical support, scientific capacity, and in all other necessary ways, so that it can continue its mission of guarding the truth on genocide.
We will keep visiting Potočari always. We will always remember the victims of genocide. However, it is our obligation to take care of restoration of life in this area, of the returnees who have lived in Srebrenica and throughout the entire Podrinje region.
They need to have security, housing, as well as jobs, which will enable them to provide for themselves and their children and live decently thanks to their own honourable work. The return to the Podrinje region, to the banks of the beautiful Drina river of ours, where we have always been residing on our own land, must be sustainable.
Much has been done already. More remains to be done. There have been some weaknesses, mainly when we were not united. However, it is up to all of us to contribute our maximum to committing ourselves with even more determination and focus, through special programmes, to enhancement of the status and the rights of the returnees in all parts of our country, and here in particular – in Srebrenica and the Podrinje region.
That is our debt to the innocent victims of the genocide committed in Srebrenica.
Thank you.

title: Address delivered by Šefik Džaferović, BiH Presidency member at SEECP Summit
content:
Bosnia and Herzegovina has been strongly committed to the regional cooperation and policy of good neighbourly relations. It is committed to resolving inter-state disputes in a peaceful way, based on the respect for the international law. In addition to this, Bosnia and Herzegovina advocates dialogue as a means of identifying mutually acceptable solutions to all open issues. This kind of dialogue is one of Bosnia and Herzegovina's key foreign policy priorities.
Dear Mr Chairman,
Your excellences, presidents, and prime ministers,
Ladies and gentlemen,
It is both my honour and pleasure indeed that we can host you in Bosnia and Herzegovina at this year's Summit of the South-European Cooperation Process.
This platform was established 23 years ago in order to enhance the regional cooperation, security, and stability. In the previous period, all SEECP members achieved a significant progress in reaching their objectives. The processes of integration into the European Union and NATO alike have been of key importance for the future of our region, as well as for its security and progress. An improvement of relations in the region is necessary for joint actions on migration flows, the fight against terrorism and violent extremism, the fight against organized crime and illegal arms trade, the fight against cyber threats, as well as for the joint regional energy and transport policies respectively.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has been strongly committed to the regional cooperation and policy of good neighbourly relations. It is committed to resolving inter-state disputes in a peaceful way, based on the respect for the international law. In addition to this, Bosnia and Herzegovina advocates dialogue as a means of identifying mutually acceptable solutions to all open issues. This kind of dialogue is one of Bosnia and Herzegovina's key foreign policy priorities.
Our region is still faced with a number of challenges, including the ongoing migration crisis as the priority area of concern. The migration crisis has escalated in the last two years in the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Facing the problem of migration crisis has indicated the weaknesses of both institutional capacities and regional cooperation. If we have in mind the fact that the migrants have arrived to this region, including Bosnia and Herzegovina, from the territory of the European Union, then it is clear that the focus of this issue cannot be put on the border between the EU and BiH only. Bosnia and Herzegovina has not caused such intensified migration processes, and thus cannot be solely responsible of resolving this issue. We expect the EU to provide both strategic and organizational support to the institutions of BiH, so that all challenges brought about by the migration crisis can be addressed efficiently.
The spread of organized crime and human trafficking respectively have made the situation even worse. The Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina has considered the issue of cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the neighbouring Montenegro and Serbia, aimed at supressing the ongoing human trafficking.
Inevitably, the jeopardized stability has reflected itself on the socio-economic situation, as well as on the overall social environment. Both political instability and disputes, as well as legal insecurity, have created the environment which is not conductive to economic growth.
Faced with an insufficient improvement of living standards, and with an uncertainty caused by the political instability, a significant portion of the young population have left to the Western European countries, which, have been faced with a demographic deficit and a need for a new labour force.
The challenges in the areas of security, economic development, migration crisis, or emigration of the young have been shared problems which can be overcome by joint solutions and regional initiatives only, aimed at enhancement of stability and economic cooperation alike.
One of the objectives of the South-East Europe Cooperation Process is improvement in the areas of judiciary and the rule of law, which are the bases of modern and developed societies.
In this context, let me avail myself of the opportunity to draw your attention to the regional problem which has seriously challenged the rule of law, as well as security. Namely. we have witnessed the practice that the convicts with dual citizenship, who are sentenced in one state for the gravest forms of war crimes, get changed sentences / considerably reduced sanctions in another country for the same criminal charges, and get released subsequently.
It is unacceptable that a person who committed mass crimes can avoid justice so easily. The states must invest additional efforts in preventing such practice, so that all who committed criminal offences can be held accountable accordingly.
In regards to the Western Balkans region, it is necessary to establish that no necessary progress has been achieved yet on facing the truth about the past, or a need to restore trust between the states and between various ethnic groups respectively.
In the previous period, some positive processes on this aspect of regional cooperation have been disputed, and even halted. A lack of respect for the judgments passed by the international courts, negative and inflammatory rhetoric, or intensified arming have been most serious factors which have challenged both security and stability.
Having in mind all challenges and internal debates the European Union itself has been faced with, it is necessary to underline the crucial importance of preserving a credible European perspective of the Western Balkans. It is beyond doubt that the European perspective remains the main driver of reforms in the Western Balkans. Therefore, it is of key importance that the accession of all states of this region remains one of the European Union's priorities.
Steps forward which were made, such as the accession of Montenegro to NATO, or signing of the Prespa agreement, have added new energy to the Euro-Atlantic integration in the region. Such momentum needs to be retained in the forthcoming period, too, and that is what we expect from the new European Commission to do.
Bosnia and Herzegovina received the European Commission's opinion, containing a series of reform-focused measures. These measures need to be fulfilled in order to ensure that Bosnia and Herzegovina is granted a candidate status, and then opens its accession negotiations with the European Union.
The regional cooperation has a huge potential, including development opportunities, and the latest example indicating this is the project of construction of the Sarajevo – Belgrade motorway. This project was initiated through a joint initiative of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Turkey, and Serbia. Although it was created upon the initiative of these three countries, this project has a huge importance for the entire region, and beyond.
The regional cooperation, founded on the principles of mutual respect, trust, our shared values and intersection of interests, has remained a key framework for advancement of the entire region, and of its people.
I wish a successful chairmanship to Kosovo as the next chairman of SECEEP. I am sorry that their delegation does not participate in this summit.
Thank you.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić at the SEECP Summit
content:
Excellences, Ladies and Gentlemen, Dear guests and media representatives, I wish you a warm welcome to Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is our honour to be the country that chairs the South East European Cooperation Process, because, as we know, this Process was initiated at the Sofia Summit in 1996 with the intention of creating an environment of trust, good neighbourly relations and stability in the region.
Today, we can proudly state that Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of the founders of this international regional forum, which in the previous period produced a number of good results and has had positive effects for the entire region.
Let me express my pleasure that Bosnia and Herzegovina has had the opportunity to chair the SEECP for the second time. The first chairmanship was in the period 2003-2004, which I hope had left a number of positive effects, especially in the area of regional cooperation, which is one of the more important principles of the European Union.
By developing regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations, we send a clear message that this region, that is, South-East Europe, also called the Western Balkans, can be part of integration processes. Especially those processes that lead Bosnia and Herzegovina towards NATO and the European Union, into which each SEECP member state can be incorporated.
Let us remind ourselves of several SEECP goals, such as:
• development of stability, security and good neighbourly relations
• Intensifying multilateral, economic and trade cooperation in the region, especially cross-border cooperation, improving transport, communication and energy infrastructure, investing and promoting trade
• promoting cooperation in the humanitarian, social and cultural fields
• cooperation in the field of justice and home affairs, for the fight against organised crime, illegal drug trafficking, arms and terrorism.
When we look at these goals, then we can conclude that the cooperation of SEECP member countries is very good in these areas.
Certainly there is room for us to work more together in solving many open issues we have, which will further enhance our neighbourly relations. In this regard, I invite you all to make additional efforts together and find ways to resolve these open issues, in the interests of all our citizens. It is necessary to maintain the stability of the region, and through our mutual cooperation and common mechanisms, to maintain and more easily control the illegal migration flows that our countries have encountered. Only together can we more easily and effectively face the challenges ahead of us.
In this way, we will show that the area of South-East Europe certainly belongs to the European Union, and that each of the countries that have not yet got the status of a member of the European Union can certainly pass all the challenges imposed by the membership procedure.
Therefore, we all need to work harder, especially in harmonizing our local legal systems with the European acquis, in order to show that we are ready to accept and apply European standards in all required areas.
I urge all SEECP member states to respect the judgments of the International Tribunal for Genocide, War Crimes and Crimes against Humanity, and thus pay tribute to all victims of genocide as one of the prerequisites for building lasting reconciliation and trust among the countries of the Western Balkans.
Once again, I wish you a warm welcome and a pleasant stay in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by the Serb member and BiH Presidency Chairman Milorad Dodik at the plenary session of delegation chiefs of the South
content:
It is a great honour to welcome you on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina here on Jahorina at the final Summit of our chairmanship over the South-East European Cooperation Process. I wish to thank you for your participation here today, noting that today's gathering represents yet another confirmation that cooperation in South-East Europe is not only diplomatic, but also very correct and content-full activity.
Dear Sirs, Madams, Presidents and Prime Ministers,
Honourable ministers and ambassadors,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I am pleased to welcome you here at the Olympic mountain Jahorina, our famous tourist center. I hope your stay here will remain a very nice memory. This is the final meeting during Bosnia and Herzegovina's chairmanship over the SEECP, and I am pleased to be chairing the meeting today. I am also pleased that you responded to the invitation to participate in today's summit. This is yet another opportunity to exchange views on the most important issues we are facing in the region, and in particular the state of European and Euro-Atlantic integrations.
You will find a draft agenda for our meeting today in front of you. Do you have any complaints or comments? If not, can I state that you have accepted and agreed on the proposed agenda? Therefore, the agenda is adopted.
Dear Mr Tayyip Erdogan, dear Mr Mile Đukanović, dear Mr Stevo Pendarovski, dear Mr Iljire Meta, dear Ms Ana Brnabić, dear Mr Bojko Borisov, dear Mr Nikolae Hurduk, dear Ms Zdravka Bušić, dear Mr Georgios Iliopulos, dear Mr Oleg Culea and dear Ms Zorica Bukinac, ladies and gentlemen,
It is a great honour to welcome you on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina here on Jahorina at the final Summit of our chairmanship over the South-East European Cooperation Process. I wish to thank you for your participation here today, noting that today's gathering represents yet another confirmation that cooperation in South-East Europe is not only diplomatic, but also very correct and content-full activity.
Many will remark today that the state in South-East Europe is not as we would wish, and not the one we have been trying to establish in the last 20 years. Maybe that is the case.
I would generally agree with such an assessment. We founded this process 23 years ago in order to be a forum where we will solve problems or at least create conditions in which these problems can be solved by some other mechanisms. If the Process serves it, use it then, let's do it today and here, to start some things and agree on things. You know, as well as me, that there is talk about the so-called. rationalization of regional initiatives. It of course makes sense. It is clear that circumstances change, but it is not always easy to respond to a call for participation at the appropriate level.
I am not sure that this process should be rationalized or quashed. This is an initiative we consider as an autochthon to the region of South-East Europe. When it is already so, I would use, for the benefit of our countries and the region as a whole, the support provided by the European Union in this process. In addition, the countries of South-East Europe, as we know, are either members of the European Union or aspire towards the membership. That is why the countries which are not members of the Union will contribute to the process of solving the problems that largely relate to the European path within the Process.
I do not want to interfere in anyone's bilateral problems, although I believe that we can talk about everything at the meetings within the Process. However, I think that it is not right that we waste our time today by exchanging pleasantries, and then we part without any results, and that our citizens continue to expect and, of course, suffer the consequences of not being able to agree on some important issues here.
I'll start with Bosnia and Herzegovina. Some say that there are problems with effective functioning and that is now manifested by the fact that even after nine months after the election, we have not been able to form all the government institutions. I can tell you that the process of talks and the agreement on forming government has long been considered complete. I believe that we will be able to do it quickly and that we will be able to inform you all about it. In fact, it is only necessary to apply what we have already agreed on within BiH. Therefore, the agreement and compromise which we had reached. When everyone accepts it, and when I say all, I mean inside and outside of this country, the path towards further outputs will be open. What about the so-called foreign affairs problems of Bosnia and Herzegovina? As those foreign policy issues, border issues with Croatia and Serbia are often mentioned. We have a standstill there, and almost nothing is happening. I propose that we make a statement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croatia, and the one between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia, in which we establish joint commissions that could continue and actualize these issues.
We know that it is very important to resolve the issue of the border and that we must not allow time and waiting for that to happen by itself. We could begin by confirming the agreement from the year of 1999 with Croatia, which is considered as the agreement that settled the problem on an interim basis. I suggest that today we also agree on the formation of joint commissions that will deal with all open issues, such as the issue that arises here in BiH, regarding the issue of the Neum Bay, but also the issue of the assets of companies from Bosnia and Herzegovina, who are prevented from using these by the decisions made by Croatia. That's why we need to work together to jointly work on the issues in question, rather than simply leave it to the media and some other processes. I also suggest that we today agree on the way of resolving the environmental issues between BiH and Croatia. Not only Trgovinska gora, but also Oil Refinery, which Croatia, quite justifiably, is concerned about.
I suggest that we today agree on the establishment of an expert commission between BiH and Serbia, which will solve a bizarre problem of the order in the steps of what comes first; whether the agreement of the borders according to the current cadastral status will first be concluded, and then the border will be corrected where necessary or vice versa. This is a trivial problem and of course no one should be afraid to be deceived, especially no one here in BiH. Furthermore, there is our problem with Kosovo regarding export taxes. We understand that Kosovo wants to resolve the issue of travel with BiH. We expected this issue to be addressed at the regional level, within regional economic areas. But we can talk about it. I see no reason for BiH to accept what Serbia has already accepted in relations with Kosovo. But the abolition of taxes is an international legal obligation accepted by Kosovo within CEFTA. International legal obligations must be implemented while in force. Imagine if we did something like that. And with regard to the request that Bosnia and Herzegovina first recognizes the Republic of Kosovo, and that would be followed by the abolishion of taxes, I think we should not waste words on that. Despite all, we regret that the Prishtina delegation is not here, because of missed opportunities for further cooperation on the regional level. What was the reason for this? They explained that they were not satisfied with the treatment by the host. However, had we not fully complied with the arrangement regarding regional representation which Prishtina had agreed on, and was involved in this process before? We think there was no reason to cancel it. If I am allowed to notice, Prishtina seems to be trying not to leave the center of international attention lately. I do not think this is the way to go, and that they need to let go of such a stance.
In the end, the current migration problem. We do not need explanations here of what the problem is, everyone knows it, but we need to know what options there are for solving this problem. Can we solve it by simply hermetically closing the borders between non-members and members of the European Union, and not vice versa, and not between the non-member states?
If we keep an open flow from one member to another, as well as between two non-members, and at the same time seal off the flow from each non-member to each member, the number of migrants will grow in non-EU countries to the number under which they will explode, and then there would be regional and EU interventions to solve this problem in all countries in the region. That is why I have reservations about projects that the European Border Service assists the Border Police of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the idea that the border between BiH and Croatia is hermetically sealed off. At the same time, migrants continue to arrive in BiH by known routes. Also, I am not in favour of the Armed Forces of BiH to be deployed to the border with Montenegro and Serbia, it would not send a good message for the region. I suggest finding a sustainable solution, a solution that will be regional in character and in cooperation with the EU. I suggest that European experts meet as soon as possible with representatives of relevant ministries within this Western Balkans forum in order to discuss the situation and propose a solution.
Certainly, a regional body that will deal with the issue of migration should be created. One thing we surely must do, and we all share the same stance on this, is to prevent the trafficking of these people whose fate is already very hard. What we should certainly have, and we all share common attitudes about it, is to prevent the smuggling of those people whose fate is very difficult.
There, I have given a few ideas and I do not know if I was in focus. Later, I will ask my colleagues from the Presidency to also address you.
I invite you to be open, as I have tried to be.
I invite you to make suggestions and for us to not only discuss these, but also to reach at least some solutions.
Last night we attended a joint dinner and I thank you for contributing to creating a constructive atmosphere for the program today.
Thank you for your attention. We will continue as per agenda.
I would like to give the floor to Mr Komšić, a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, who will address you.

title: Address by Šefik Džaferović, BiH Presidency member at the Brdo
content:
The respective processes of integration into the European Union and NATO still have the key importance in shaping the future of our region. These processes represent the best framework for the implementation of our shared aspirations for the lasting security, stability, and prosperity.
Tirana, May 9th, 2019
Esteemed colleagues,
It is my great pleasure to participate for the first time at the Brdo-Brijuni Process leaders' meeting.
I extend my thanks to President Meta, President Grabar – Kitarović, and President Pahor for their invitation.
In particular, let me extend my thanks to President Meta for his warm welcome here in Tirana.
I am very glad that our friends Andrzej Duda, President of the Republic of Poland, and Federica Mogherini, High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy are with us today. We appreciate very much indeed their support to the European perspective of the Western Balkans, and to strengthening relations between our region and the European Union.
Since it was established in 2013, the Brdo-Brijuni Process has represented an important platform for enhancement of the regional dialogue and cooperation, as well as for resolving of open issues and promoting the European future of the Western Balkans.
Slovenia and Croatia, as initiators of this process, have demonstrated their firm commitment respectively to the European perspective of our region. Having in mind the European Union's internal debates on the issue of enlargement, it is of particular importance to have advocates of the idea of enlargement amongst the members of the European Union. Therefore, we have to use today's meeting to send together the messages which are important for the European future of our region, thus helping our friends within the European Union who have been advocating for the enlargement.
The situation in our region is much more complex now than it was the case six years ago, when the Brdo-Brijuni Process was launched. Namely, there are more tensions indeed, as well as political instability, and security challenges in the region now. The important changes at the international level have strongly reflected themselves to the relations within our region, too. A lot has changed since 2013. However, some issues have remained the same.
The respective processes of integration into the European Union and NATO still have the key importance in shaping the future of our region. These processes represent the best framework for the implementation of our shared aspirations for the lasting security, stability, and prosperity.
The regional cooperation, based on mutual respect, equality, trust, shared values and cross-section of interests has remained the key to resolving numerous challenges we have been faced with, and for achieving progress in the process of integration into the European Union and NATO.
Although, in the past six years, the countries in our region have not fully achieved the planned progress, the processes of integration into the European Union and NATO have had a significant impact to the development of democracy, the rule of law, and the respect for human rights.
Furthermore, the integration processes have provided a decisive contribution to resolution of the open bilateral issues between the countries in our region.
Accession of Montenegro to NATO Alliance, and signing of the Prespa Agreement between Greece and North Macedonia are particularly important moments for the overall relations in the region. These two milestone events boosted new optimism of all of us in the region.
Such moves forward have indicated that, through the mechanisms of dialogue and cooperation, and with credible European and Euro-Atlantic perspective, our region can indeed resist the negative external influences, as well as resolve successfully the open issues and disputes which were lasting for a number of decades.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has also made important moves forward in its integration- focused processes. In December last year the ministers of foreign affairs of the NATO Alliance member countries approved that Bosnia and Herzegovina could submit its first Annual National Programme within the NATO MAP Programme. The NATO MAP is a framework for continuation and enhancement of the current cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the NATO Alliance, which would represent a significant contribution not only to peace, security and stability in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also in the entire Western Balkans region. All states in our region have had very strong cooperation with the NATO Alliance, and most of them were already granted full membership in that organization.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has achieved progress in the process of integration into the European Union. We submitted the replies to the European Commission's Questionnaire, and we have expected the opinion of the European Commission on our application for membership, followed by a decision of the European Council on granting the candidate status to BiH. There are a number of reforms which lie ahead of Bosnia and Herzegovina within the process of its accession to the European Union. We already undertook one such reform, particularly in the period until the year 2015. We are determined to continue to implement all the remaining reforms which are necessary for us to meet the Copenhagen and Madrid criteria alike for accession to the European Union. The reforms are necessary in order to harmonize our system with the values, regulations and standards of the European Union. A positive opinion of the European Commission on Bosnia and Herzegovina's application for membership, and a decision of the European Council on granting Bosnia and Herzegovina a candidate status would provide us with a powerful incentive to speed up the implementation of all the necessary reforms, and to achieve an even greater and faster progress within the accession process.
Being fully aware of the debates conducted within the European Union on the issue of enlargement, I would like to emphasize a crucial importance of the credible European perspective for the Western Balkans. The integration of the Western Balkans into the European Union has an indispensable importance for the overall European security and stability, and it brings about the mutual benefit to both the Western Balkans and the European Union.
The migration crisis has demonstrated interdependence between various regions, and, in particular, the connection between the European Union and the Western Balkans as its immediate neighbourhood. There is a strong consensus within the European Union concerning the protection of the external borders, and the fight against illegal migration. It is important to underline that there can be no successful protection of the external borders or migration control without stability and security in the Western Balkans, and without the latter's credible European perspective.
