The European Council will soon adopt the Strategic Agenda of the European Union for the period from 2019 to 2024. An order of priorities which will represent the framework of the European policy in the next five years will be established by this agenda. It is hugely important to provide clear and unequivocal guidelines for a credible perspective of the Western Balkans countries' integration into the European Union in the agenda concerned.
The process of integration into the European Union has been proven as the most efficient mechanism of transforming our states, societies, and economies into modern democratic states, into the societies of European values, and into competitive market economies, achieving lasting stability, security and overall social and economic development. It is for this reason that we need to maintain the current momentum in the process of our region's integration into the European Union.
It is up to us to take responsibility for ourselves and, by means of the concrete reform-focused activities in our countries, as well as through an enhanced regional cooperation and networking, send the best message in favour of the accession to the European Union.
Thank you.

title: Address by Šefik Džaferović, BiH Presidency member on the occasion of marking the anniversary of the crime committed in Ahmići
content:
Esteemed families of the shaheeds, dear residents of Ahmići, honorable guests, We gathered here today to mark the 26th anniversary of the horrific crime committed in Ahmići, and to remember, once again, with both dignity and sorrow, the 116 innocent victims killed in a bloody and insane campaign carried out by the perpetrators.
It was on today’s date that members of the Croatian Council of Defense (HVO), led by the sentenced war criminal Dario Kordić, committed the gravest crime against the civilian population during the conflict between the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina (ARBiH) and HVO.
During the massacre in Ahmići, the darkened criminal minds demonstrated the darkest side that human beings can demonstrate, if at all one can call a human being someone who is capable of killing a three-month old baby, a four-year old boy, to burn a mother with her four children, to kill women and elderly people.
We will remember the victims forever indeed as it is our obligation and duty alike to do so. At the same time, we have to take care of the families, the surviving residents of Ahmići. It is our obligation to ensure their peaceful and dignified life, as well as to ensure both truth and justice for them.
Six crime perpetrators were sentenced for the crimes committed in Ahmići. They were sentenced to 95 years in prison in total. That is less than one year of imprisonment per victim!
It is obvious that these crimes were not committed by the six perpetrators only. There will be no justice for the residents of Ahmići until the very final perpetrator is brought to justice. We hereby re-iterate our pledge in Ahmići today that we will not cease from pursuing such outcome.
I have initiated that within the Institute for Research of Crimes against Humanity and International Law, which has been operating for over two decades now, a special center should be established, with the aim to document each individual and mass crime. The task of such center will be to report the crimes to the competent judicial institutions, and to follow up closely what will happen further with each particular case.
Such center will become operational soon, and its task, in addition to what I already stated, will be to oppose, together with all of us, the attempts aimed at equalizing the victim and the aggressor, as well as the attempts of changing the character of the war in BiH. Unfortunately, the latter is exactly what one part of judiciary system in our country has been supporting.
We have witnessed to the judiciary prosecution of honorable defenders of BiH, our generals, due to the crimes committed by individuals. The aim of such prosecution is to create a virtual joint criminal enterprise which would be assigned to the Army of RBiH. For individual, less grave crimes which were committed by the members of the Army of RBiH, the draconian sentences have been passed, and such sentences have been almost the same as those made for the mass crimes committed by the aggressors’ armies.
At the same time, next to no perpetrators have been found responsible before the domestic judiciary system for the planned and organized crimes, mass killings, persecution, destruction of entire residential areas, a four-year brutal siege of Sarajevo, the crimes committed in Prijedor, across the Krajina region, the crimes committed in Goražde, and in other parts of the Podrinje region, as well as for other crimes committed throughout BiH.
They are trying to present that we were all the same.
We were not the same.
The crimes committed by the aggressors were planned and organized, fueled by the political decisions and backed by the whole system.
There were crimes committed by some irresponsible members of the Army of BiH, too, but these were individual cases which we tried to sanction even during the most difficult conditions in the course of the aggression.
Today is the anniversary of the crime committed against the Croat civilians in Trusina, and it is with sadness that we have remembered these victims, too.
Therefore, we are not the same even now as we have no objections that each perpetrator should be brought to justice for his crime. It is only in this way – by truth and justice – that we can work successfully on restoring trust among the peoples in BiH.
Truth and justice are the two words which are very important for successful restoration of trust. Everyone must face it, both our neighbors who committed the aggression and ourselves within Bosnia and Herzegovina. All that is needed by our country and its entire well-intended people is the truth on what was happening here during the aggression. Nothing less, and nothing more than that. All of us know all too well what happened here, and the minimum all of us must gather around is the truth established by the international courts, including the International Court of Justice in the Hague, and the International Criminal Tribunal for former Yugoslavia in the Hague. These two courts established that there was an aggression made against Bosnia and Herzegovina, and that mass crimes and genocide were committed by the aggressor forces in this country. Two joint criminal enterprises were established in the judgements concerned – i.e. one driven from Belgrade, and another one driven from Zagreb.
Unfortunately, on the one hand we are responded by negating of the judgements made by the international courts, by negating the genocide which was established by the court, by glorifying and awarding the perpetrators, by naming student dormitories after the perpetrators who were found guilty by the final and binding court decisions.
On the other hand, we have also seen negating of the Hague sentence on the joint criminal enterprise committed by the leaders of Herzeg-Bosnia, as well as a lecture, organized by the Church and the University of Zagreb, delivered to students by the war criminal found guilty for the massacre in Ahmići. These are horrible messages, which have been sent to the victims’ families, to all of us, and to the entire civilized world.
However, there was an encouraging message from the young people and one part of the public in Croatia, who opposed the glorification of the war criminal concerned. Such attitude raises hope in the possibility that civilized values condemning crime and protecting the victims will prevail. We expect that such an attitude should start being promoted, too, and without hesitation, by the political, religious, and intellectual elites of the Croats, both in BiH and in Croatia.
We do live together, we share the same living space, we are directed towards one another, and that is the only path towards restoring trust and building a shared future in our homeland Bosnia and Herzegovina.
This is our obligation to future generations.
Thank you.

title: Address by Šefik Džaferović, member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the VII Global Baku Forum opening ceremony
content:
We should not accept a vision of global reality being a hostile environment lacking regulations and trust. International competition, as a part of the new global constellation, cannot and should not be ignored. A great global match brings about serious challenges and fears. However, it does not necessarily have to mean a confrontation. A faith in cooperation lost in advance means entering a battle for sustainable global peace, security, stability, and prosperity which is lost in advance.
Baku, 14 March 2019
Excellences,
Ladies and gentlemen!
I extend my congratulations to the International Centre “Nizami Ganjavi” for organizing this forum, which is gathering leaders from the countries around the world to address the issues of global importance. It is my great honour and pleasure to participate in this event and discuss the issues of our shared interest with all of you.
We have lived in the times of great changes. International relations have become more and more complex and unstable, while becoming less and less predictable and while bringing about more insecurity. Global and regional challenges, crisis and conflict have continued to grow more complex and deeper. The phenomena and processes we are witnessing have not been limited to the places of their origin only or to their direct agents. To the contrary, such phenomena and processes have caused the fundamental changes in the architecture of international order.
We have witnessed the deep crises of arms control agreements, the international security used to be based on for decades. We have witnessed the changes of trade agreements, which used to be the framework for international economic cooperation for decades. The huge migration waves, climate changes, terrorist threats, as well as the rise of extremism, international crime and discrimination have remained the burning issues The impact of information technologies and development of artificial intelligence on all spheres of social life, as well as the phenomena such as cyber-crime fall within such challenges for which joint responses are yet to be found.
While the old and the new challenges have multiplied, the international mechanisms and institutions which should address them have been weakened.
No single country can remain focused on its internal issues only, nor can it resolve them in isolation or independently from the processes unfolding in its immediate surroundings, as well as those unfolding globally. Contemporary challenges have surpassed both state borders and individual capacities and capabilities of any country to address them on its own. The processes of rapid globalization and integration have more and more cancelled and made meaningless the traditional firm division between internal and foreign issues, relations, tasks and policies. Security, stability, development and prosperity of each country are more and more dependent on security, development, prosperity of other countries in its immediate surroundings, as well as at the global plan.
This is exactly why we need joint solutions based on shared values and intersection of interest, which can be implemented by joint forces and capacities of all states only.
In this regard, the international cooperation is of essential importance.
Efficient responses to contemporary global challenges demand both shared vision and action, which are based on democratic pluralism, mutual trust, respect for the international law, as well as on a new, more progressive understanding of state sovereignty.
Invitations to joint steps are credible as much as they are honest, and can only succeed if we understand seriously the messages on dangers of alternatives to cooperation. Namely, such alternatives represent a path leading to conflicts.
We should not accept a vision of global reality being a hostile environment lacking regulations and trust. International competition, as a part of the new global constellation, cannot and should not be ignored. A great global match brings about serious challenges and fears. However, it does not necessarily have to mean a confrontation. A faith in cooperation lost in advance means entering a battle for sustainable global peace, security, stability, and prosperity which is lost in advance.
Multilateralism and international order based on the generally accepted rules continue to remain the best platform and the best framework for addressing the global issues. International dialogue, cooperation, respect for the human rights and the generally accepted rules of international law are the key mechanisms for ensuring stability, security, and sustainable development. We must preserve, promote, and keep developing such universal values, principles, rights and regulations.
I represent a country which knows all too well what failure means of such international mechanisms and institutions whose obligation and task is to protect and ensure the respect for such universal international values, rules and rights, but which also knows what it means when such mechanisms and institutions start to implement their obligations and tasks, which are the reasons of their existence.
The countries which share similar experience with that of Bosnia and Herzegovina are firmly committed to respect, protect and promote the international law and global order, based on the universal values and generally accepted regulations of the international law. Bosnia and Herzegovina is committed to multilateralism and dedicated to act in accordance with the obligations driven from the international conventions and membership in the international institutions alike.
I firmly believe that the commitment to multilateralism, the respect for the international law, and the adherence to the shared values and global order based on the accepted regulations are the best way of addressing the complex challenges we have been faced with. This is indeed the right path to a safer world.
Thank you.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Šefik Džaferović at the reception marking Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
It is particularly important that the referendum on independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina was conducted in accordance with all domestic and international legal norms, i.e. in a legal, transparent and peaceful way, and under a comprehensive international monitoring. This was a democratic decision by which, centuries after the foreign-run governance operated within various state communities, Bosnia and Herzegovina proudly renewed its full independence and sovereignty.
Esteemed excellences, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, dear guests!
There are many important dates in the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina. However, one of these dates – the 1st of March - holds a special place in our hearts.
It was 27 years ago that almost two thirds of the citizens of all ethnic affiliations in this country voted in both decisive and dignified way in the referendum FOR a sovereign and independent Bosnia and Herzegovina. This was the vote FOR a state of equal citizens and peoples, Bosniaks, Serbs, and Croats, as well as members of all other peoples living in it. At the same time, this was the vote AGAINST the greater states' policies clearly aimed at dividing Bosnia and Herzegovina. Such policies were already active at the time.
It is particularly important that the referendum on independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina was conducted in accordance with all domestic and international legal norms, i.e. in a legal, transparent and peaceful way, and under a comprehensive international monitoring. This was a democratic decision by which, centuries after the foreign-run governance operated within various state communities, Bosnia and Herzegovina proudly renewed its full independence and sovereignty.
It is by voting in favour of independence that the people of this country defined fatefully both the path of our homeland and its future.
There have been many difficult situations and challenges along the path towards an independent, sovereign, modern European state of equal people. We overcome successfully the gravest of all such challenges – the aggression launched against our country after the declaration of independence. We bore numerous victims in order to preserve an integral and independent Bosnia and Herzegovina.
These victims have made heavier the burden of responsibility which we have carried over before the next generations. The victims we bore in the name of our homeland, the victims who paid for our current freedom very expensively, have obligated us to persevere in both preserving and building Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Furthermore, this is our responsibility to the most honourable, most courageous and best Bosnian sons who succeeded in defending this country, while not hesitating to contribute their lives into its foundations. We must never forget these people.
In the meantime, after the aggression against it ended, Bosnia and Herzegovina has faced both graver and lesser challenges. All such challenges have been overcome successfully.
There are new challenges ahead of us. Destructive political forces, including those who have tried to achieve unattained war objectives by other means, have been louder and louder.
I will not focus on such destructive forces too much today, but will only send a message to them that their efforts have been in vain, and that they will never succeed in carrying out their intentions.
Unfortunately, the permanent crises resulting in a lack of desirable economic growth has been caused by such destructive policies because it is political instability indeed which has frightened the investors off. In addition to this, some, often utterly irrational, political disputes have contributed to an increased volume of departures of the young people from this country towards the countries which have operated ordered and stable systems.
Such behaviour of the destructive political forces has not brought about anything good to anyone in this country, and particularly not to those on whose behalf they have been allegedly carried out. If we want to achieve progress for all, it is high time to root out discrimination and inequality from the BiH society in the whole territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and ensure that each person feels at home at each square inch of this country. This is the only way in which each individual in BiH will be guaranteed a better and safer life. Furthermore, we are obliged to ensure a discrimination-free context for the future generations.
Therefore, it is necessary for all political actors to stop with negative rhetoric and destructive activities, and that all of us turn together to a constructive dialogue based on truth and justice, mutual respect, respect for the rule of law, the European standards, and the cooperation aimed at wellbeing of all our people.
There are many examples throughout history, as well as nowadays, which have indicated that we can do much for our country in a way which benefits all when we work together and in unity. I believe that there will be even more of such examples in the time ahead of us.
Our goal is clear: Bosnia and Herzegovina as member of both the European Union and NATO Alliance. Despite the obstacles and destructive policies imposed, we have progressed towards that goal. It is true that our progress has been slow and full of obstacles, but we will indeed – let me assure you – achieve our goal.
This beautiful country is abundant with everything, which is sufficient for all its citizens to have decent lives in dignity, earn for living in a fair way, and raise their children in peace. They do deserve such life indeed.
Finally, I extend my heartfelt congratulations on the Independence Day to all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
May long live our homeland Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić at the reception marking Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
On 1st March 1992, we did not divide ourselves between those on the left and those on the right, between liberal and conservative, between urban and rural, but we, together with the will of most of the citizens, opted for an independent and sovereign Bosnia and Herzegovina, for a civil Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Dear Excellences,
Eminencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
friends of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
Allow me firstly to greet the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and all the Bosnians and Herzegovinians in the Diaspora, and congratulate them on the occasion of marking a significant day for Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Happy 1st March - Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Throughout the centuries, our country has always been recognizable by its historical struggle for the preservation of independence, sovereignty and integrity, and for the good people who lived and live here today. The dates of 29th February and 1st March will remain written in our history forever, because on those days most of the citizens of our country clearly gave their vote for independent Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The question put to them then is well known, and it read: "Are for you sovereign and independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, the state of equal citizens, the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina - Muslims, Serbs, Croats and members of other peoples who live in it? "
It does not hurt to constantly repeat this question, because it is a reminder of what kind of a state its citizens wanted, and I believe they want the same today.
Although we paid a high price for the affirmative answer to this question, and, unfortunately, suffered huge losses, together we managed to defend ourselves from those who tried to violate the independence, integrity and sovereignty of our country. Unfortunately, this battle for the country by the measure of the referendum lasts to this day, and as it seems even with a higher intensity than ever.
On 1st March 1992, we did not divide ourselves between those on the left and those on the right, between liberal and conservative, between urban and rural, but we, together with the will of most of the citizens, opted for an independent and sovereign Bosnia and Herzegovina, for a civil Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We should not be divided into ideological camps today either, with regards to the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. All of us must work together to strengthen Bosnia and Herzegovina as a civil state, a state of equal individuals and equal collectivities. Bosnia and Herzegovina is composed of different identities, but above all, Bosnia and Herzegovina is an identity. The identity of the century-old tolerance and the joint life of all its inhabitants. That's the way it used to be, that is the way today, and that is the way it will, despite everything, remain.
Today, 27 years later, when there are intents and attempts of individuals to again violate this independence, we must actively work and fight against their controversial ideas of division on any basis. This homeland is ours, we do not have other, and therefore we have a duty to work for its benefit, to work for the benefit of its citizens, to ensure dignified life and equal rights to all. We need this because of our youth, and because of the future generations who will be born and who will live in this country. We should use the potential we have and together create a different country - a country for all of us.
I am aware, as I believe most of you are, that we cannot solve all the problems overnight. We need, and we are all obliged, to take the opportunity to finally bring Bosnia and Herzegovina into NATO and the European Union. This is a path that allows a civil state, a safe state in which all human beings are guaranteed basic human rights. Bosnia and Herzegovina is undoubtedly a part of the European space and it deserves to be part of a large European family. It is European due to geography, but it must become so in practical terms too, respecting all Eurpean standards and democratic values. I am convinced that we have enough energy and potential to achieve this, together.
Dear friends, I thank you for being with us tonight. Once again, I congratulate Independence Day to all, with a wish for this holiday to soon be marked in the whole territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Thank you for your attention.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić at the commemorative academy dedicated to the 27th January - International Holocaust Remembrance Day
content:
We have gathered here today to mark a significant historical date and pay tribute to the victims of the Holocaust, the largest and most brutal atrocity of the past century remembered by the human civilization. The date January 27th is marked throughout Europe, and today, seventy-four years later, it reminds us of the day in 1945 when the Red Army freed seven and a half thousand prisoners left by the Nazis in the concentration camp Auschwitz.
Dear members of the Jewish community,
Esteemed President of the Jewish community, Mister Jakob Finci,
Eminencies and Excellencies, representatives of the international community,
Dear friends,
Ladies and gentlemen!
We have gathered here today to mark a significant historical date and pay tribute to the victims of the Holocaust, the largest and most brutal atrocity of the past century remembered by the human civilization. The date January 27th is marked throughout Europe, and today, seventy-four years later, it reminds us of the day in 1945 when the Red Army freed seven and a half thousand prisoners left by the Nazis in the concentration camp Auschwitz.
Allow me to greet and show deep respect for the Holocaust survivors who are here with us today. To those who were witnesses to the dark side of history that has left them with deep wounds, and all of us with an obligation to confront all forms of evil and violence. The obligation not to let something like this happen ever again.
Unfortunately, what happened during the Nazi regime in the Second World War was not a lesson for some. We have witnessed that in recent history, genocides and grave atrocities were committed. They are still happening today; the genocide was committed here in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Furthermore, the disastrous fact is that seventy-four years after the Holocaust, there are still certain political forces in our country that do not give up the Nazi heritage. Thus, due to such political forces, the streets in Mostar are named after those who took part in committing the Holocaust.
Therefore, out of respect for the victims, I wish to believe that the memory of the sufferings of the Auschwitz victims, and all other victims of monstrous minds, will be a reminder to the new generations to reject the ideologies that are based on segregation, intolerance, disrespect and lack of care for those who may be different.
As part of the modern civilization, we must not forget what happened, on the contrary, we have an even greater obligation to work on improving mutual relations and building a future in which the rule of law, moral values, the freedom of each individual and empathy will be the imperative. The future which will not allow for war, extremism, inter-conflicts and where every person will have a chance to lead a dignified life.
Thank you.

title: BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić held the lecture on the topic “Future of Bosnia and Herzegovina: How to step up integration process to EU and NATO”
content:
It is my both pleasure and honour to be here today. Thank you for the opportunity to say something about two topics that may seem like a classic foreign policy question for one country, in this case for Bosnia and Herzegovina. However, many things that are not only political are permeated in these two topics; it is not just an administrative or media issue, but it is about certain deep, social and sociological processes that are taking place in BiH. This is not the place, nor do we have much time to reflect on all the developments in the region that are related to what is happening in our country, and even to touch on the role of the great powers and multilateral processes that are also taking place in the European Union, and which subsequently reflect on the whole region, and with that on Bosnia and Herzegovina too.
Allow me to greet all those present and thank you for inviting me to speak at this eminent conference organised by the International Institute for Middle East and Balkan Studies (IFIMES).
The presentation on the European and NATO perspectives of Bosnia and Herzegovina should begin with a brief reminder of what the European Union is and how it originated. So, please, let us briefly return to the time after the end of the Second World War, when the idea of a united Europe was born. The idea originated from Winston Churchill, who dreamed of the United States of Europe, which, prior to the creation of the European Union, were articulated in a series of steps towards the European Union of today by the historical political authorities such as Adenauer, Bech, Beyen, Da Gasperi, Hallastein, Mansholt, Monnet, Spaak, Spinelli and Schuman.
The first form of association can be seen in 1952 in the creation of the European Coal and Steel Community, which later assumed a new form in the organisation of the European Atomic Energy Community in 1958, as well as the creation of the European Economic Community, also in 1958.
All these were steps towards the formation of the present European Union, which was founded by the signing of the Maastricht Treaty which came into force on November 1, 1993, which created today's Union as an inclusive community with its criteria for accession. The original European Union was formed by six countries: Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands. Later this number grew to ten, twelve, fifteen, to today's twenty-eight countries.
EUROPEAN ACCESSION CRITERIA
Accession to the European Union was defined back in 1993, within the Copenhagen criteria, consisting of three elements: political, economic and administrative-institutional. Every state aspiring to become the member of the European Union must also fulfil the fourth, administrative criterion, which requires adjustment to a whole series of its own regulations in order to become a successful candidate.
The political criterion represents several further elements, such as the stability of institutions that must be able to guarantee democracy, the rule of law, the protection of fundamental human rights and the protection of minority rights.
The economic criterion concerns the functional market economy in the country in the sense that it is sufficiently capable to cope with the competitive challenges of a major marketplace such as the European Union.
The administrative-institutional criterion states that there must be such an ability of the EU candidate country to fully accept the European acquis communautaire.
These criteria are strengthened by the Madrid Criteria, which clearly state that the country must have a reformed administration and the judiciary in a way that it is able to immediately accept the entire European acquis.
For the countries of the Western Balkans, these criteria are somewhat modified, in the way that the first step is to enter the Stabilisation and Association Process, and then the following criteria are applied:
• political criterion - which has remained unchanged
• economic criterion - which has been changed in the need to strengthen regional cooperation in the Western Balkans and
• administrative-institutional - which has remained the same and relates to the ability of each country to fully accept the complete European acquis communautaire.
In order for the European Commission to see all of these elements, the EU Questionnaire is applied, in which each country that aims to get a candidate status offers a cross-section of the situation in the country through different chapters. There are now 35 of these chapters. We are at this stage - we provide answers to the Questionnaire sent to us from Brussels. We completed some of the answers and sent them to Brussels, and then they returned them with additional questions and our institutions are dealing with these additional issues. We have a kind of promise from the competent institutions in BiH that this will be completed as soon as possible, so that we can complete answers to these additional questions.
Answers to the Questionnaire, which often include additional questions, such as in our case, serve the European Commission to draw up an Opinion, which it delivers to the Council of the European Union, followed by a decision reached by consensus which determines whether a country can be awarded a candidate status. This candidate status may have three variations: direct candidate status, conditional candidate status and conditional candidate status with the deadline for the fulfilment of conditions, in order to formalise the candidate status.
Once the country obtains candidate status, screening of all chapters is done, when together with the candidate country, the compatibility of domestic legislation with the European regulations is observed. In case of a discrepancy, negotiations are opened for each chapter separately.
Prior to the start of the negotiations, a negotiating position of the candidate country is determined, and then the negotiations begin. Chapters 23 (judiciary and human rights) are very often those that are opened first, which is for us, now I speak on behalf of Bosnia and Herzegovina, of crucial importance, and 24 (justice, freedom and security), which ranks as high as Chapter 23 in terms of importance. The issues in these chapters are not solved by negotiations but rather with an ACTION PLAN, that is, the candidate country receives very concrete tasks which must be fulfilled in these chapters within a given time frame.
Upon completion of the verification of all negotiation chapters, it is proposed that the candidate country be admitted to membership in the European Union. This is approximately a phase in which we are now, that is, we aim to complete that phase.
WHERE IS BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA IN THAT?
We can present our short overview in the following few sentences, because the situation is very simple, and the European Commission in its report on BiH for 2018 pointed out that the current situation is still not sufficiently good.
If we start from the political criteria, it is clear that BiH has no institutions that can guarantee democracy, the rule of law, the protection of fundamental human rights and the protection of minority rights. Through this theatrical play regarding the changes in the Election Law of BiH, which we witnessed in the period immediately prior to the elections in BiH, we could see the unpreparedness of the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina to implement the fundamental democratic principles, because the discussion about this boiled down to the construct "legitimate political representation of the peoples" which is not the part of the European acquis, nor is it part of the European principles and standards, and in fact represents a clear indication that democracy in BiH wants to be sacrificed by certain political parties in order for them to have a better position in forming of the government (the fear of anyone being outvoted in the European institutions simply does not stick). Something like that is not a democracy founded in the European Union, thus it is quite clear why Mr Johannes Hahn, European Commissioner for Neighbourhood Policy and Enlargement Negotiations, said that Bosnia and Herzegovina with the Dayton political model cannot become a candidate for the European Union, because that model differs from the European acquis. This is, in fact, an essential question because the Dayton political model has been abused by loose interpretations that ethnic political elites should be granted rights greater than individual rights of citizens. In order to strengthen such argumentation, comparisons with Belgium, the Netherlands and similar countries (and some even make comparisons with Switzerland which does not intend to become part of the European Union) are used, which is completely wrong since the historical context how these countries originated compared to Bosnia and Herzegovina is starkly different. However, these countries have certainly aligned their socio-political system with the European acquis, whereby there exists protection of fundamental human rights at an individual level, while in Bosnia and Herzegovina, unfortunately, it is not the case.
Frightening the people of our country that the civic concept means a unitarian state, which then in turn means the principle of one man - one vote, which results in somebody being outvoted by someone else - these are stories for young children because the European Union is based on the protection of civil rights at the individual level, and that is what we need to do in BiH, to strengthen this principle, not to protect the collective rights as it wants to be presented. The European Union is based on this, and it has confirmed it already two times in the conclusion of the Council of the European Union. Bearing in mind where I am at this moment, the function I perform, and the fact that I am currently staying in a friendly country, I do not wish to mention even certain interventions by the neighbouring states of Bosnia and Herzegovina whose representatives went so far as to attempt to establish a new principle for EU candidate member states, so they called BiH a sui generis case in the whole story. There are no sui generis cases regarding the accession to the European Union. There is no sui generis case with regards to Belgium, where the principle of respect of basic human rights is the founding principle of the organisation of the state. Therefore, Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot be a sui generis case with regards to the basic principles upon which the European Union functions.
The situation regarding the rule of law, which in its essence means the existence of a legal state that must guarantee all rights, freedoms and equality to its citizens on an individual level, is completely the same- which immediately differs from the policy of a significant part of the political scene in BiH whose remaining in power is made easy by the Dayton model, even though it is not within the framework of the European democratic principles. Likewise, the rule of law means that there must be a system that will effectively fight against corruption and organised crime, which, again, is not the case in BiH.
An example of this is the recent lack of political support for changes to the Criminal Law of BiH, where political parties are trying to make amendments which will result in protecting certain actors of criminal activities coming from their ranks. Therefore, there are many political structures in BiH wishing to actually move BiH further away from the key principle of the functioning of the EU, such as the rule of law, for one simple reason-to maintain its political position, influence and power and ultimately, I have to say, suspiciously acquired material assets.
Who is the promoter of EU values in BiH, who wants what? Who really wants the European Union? What are the motives behind politicians in BiH who opt for the EU? -that is a special issue. There are those who really and frankly want to join the EU, and I think that there are those who want the EU, naively thinking the European Union will agree to gamble with the principles upon which it functions.
The economic system in Bosnia and Herzegovina is a deviation of the free market, where there are different oligopolies, which negotiate and agree on the market behaviour (for example, petroleum products distributors). Therefore, Bosnia and Herzegovina as a sovereign country does not fulfil the initial condition, and it particularly does not fulfil the requisite of having the necessary competitive ability in challenges offered by the large market place of the European Union.
There is no need to speak of an administrative-institutional criterion, as there are no political statements by various political actors or political parties that would undoubtedly say that they will do everything possible for Bosnia and Herzegovina to adopt a complete European acquis.
How will they accept such a degree of change in socio-political reality that would surely diminish their political power, currently given to them by constructs of the type of "constituent peoples" or "legitimate political representatives of the peoples" that completely neglect democracy, to such an extent that they offer systematic discrimination which, as a consequence, gives greater political power to those same opponents of European values.
WHAT IS, THEN, THE WAY OUT OF THIS SITUATION?
The first element would be the search for those political structures, parties, concepts and personnel that can convince us in their public appearances that they know the procedures for accession to the European Union for start, and the second part, and that they are really doing it. Unfortunately, there are many public declarations claiming the commitment to the EU, as well as NATO, but essentially, this is the case of mere demagoguery. “We will strive to join the EU” is one of the most common sentences you can hear in public speeches of politicians or political elites. This gets forgotten very soon and we return to the functioning so typical for our region, that some call the Balkans, some call it the Western Balkans, while others refer to it as Southeast Europe.
What is to be done? We need help, sincere help from the European institutions. We need clear and precise positions, we know the standards, if we wish to know them. But we need, not just the message from all European officials, diplomats, but we need to see the messages in action in BiH. There should be no double standards, especially those applied by EU officials. I have been in this business for too long, and I have, unfortunately, had such experience with some EU officials, from the European Commission as well as the diplomatic corps. On the one hand, there is the general story and message and, on the other, it is the case of a classic Balkan political game. I have too often been in such situations to see it; we have often been witnesses to double standards coming from EU officials. With such a policy, the EU will not get a reliable partner in BiH, nor will BiH make any progress. I expect the EU institutions and member states to be able to recognize those forces in BiH, because it is really not difficult, that are really devoted to the European path of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to refrain from repeating to us constantly "well, you know, it is your reality". We need to adapt, but with such political action, with such philosophy, we will not get far. We had the opportunity to see this stance in the negotiations regarding the changing of the Election Law. Fortunately, such stance failed to win. We also had such an example when adopting the Excise Law in BiH. I have to say that I was shocked by what some EU officials are doing on behalf of the European Commission. You will not believe what happened. I cannot comprehend politically nor legally - that we have adopted two laws whose very important Articles clash with each other. And this has happened under the patronage of the European Union officials. In the aftermath, those officials come and state that BiH has suffered a decline. Therefore, if we are going to talk frankly, it is necessary to find BiH forces which sincerely wish, not only to formally fulfil criteria and requirements set out by the EU, but which see in those criteria the opportunity for a recovery of a whole society. Not only administration, political life and public discourse, but the recovery of the society in Bosnia and Herzegovina. We need standard criteria of the EU because of us, because they change us as people in BiH and create conditions to move away from the mud in which we live and create something out of this country which will resemble an orderly country, a democratic country in which people will be able to see their future and prosperity.
LET US SAY SOMETHING ABOUT NATO
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization or the North Atlantic Treaty, better known as NATO, is an international organization of military and political nature, founded in 1949 by signing the North Atlantic Treaty (Washington Agreement) between the twelve states of the then Western bloc. The basis of the North Atlantic Alliance is the Agreement between Member States, which in its nature is an international treaty. The Agreement recognises and supports the states' individual rights as well as their international obligations under the United Nations Charter. It obliges each Member State to take part in the risks and responsibilities, establish a joint defence system and requires each not to accept any international obligations that might be in contravention of the Agreement.
The idea of NATO formation, besides its security nature, was the creation of a military bloc to counter the spread of ideological communism to the Western world, as a response to the historical circumstances of the time after the end of World War II. As an opposition to this military alliance, the Warsaw Pact was formed at the time, creating the then bipolar world order, and the Cold War began, which lasted until December 1989 when the US President George Bush and the then USSR President Mikhail Gorbachev announced at a conference in Malta that the Cold War was over. Regarding the Cold War, it is important to say two more things. First, it was a conflict based on ideological differences, led by all the means other than military. Second, it had its own reference terms, such as détente or peaceful coexistence between 1968 and 1975, which worked through mechanisms of the specially formed CSCE organization, at a conference in Helsinki in 1973, which served as a channel or space for communication between the West and the East. After the ending of the Cold War, this organisation was transformed into OSCE at the Summit in Budapest in 1994. This organisation represents the largest international organisation which promotes security and cooperation, ensures assistance with initiating political negotiations and decision making, and acts as support in recognising early warnings, conflict prevention, crises management and rehabilitation after conflicts. It has its six permanent missions (one is in Bosnia and Herzegovina), and several observation missions.
NATO ENLARGEMENTS
During its existence, NATO had seven enlargements, that is, acceptances of new states to its membership. Here it would be good to say one thing in terms of the enlargement, and it refers to the idea initiated by Zbigniew Brzezinski, as the then member of John F. Kennedy's Electoral Staff at the beginning of the 1960s, when he proposed, as a solution to the Cold War, that NATO expands as eastwards as possible, primarily thinking of his native Poland. Nearly 40 years later, or more precisely in 1999, NATO began enlargements to Eastern European countries, within its fourth enlargement (Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary), followed by the fifth and the largest enlargement in 2004 (Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Romania, Latvia, Slovakia and Slovenia), then the sixth expansion in 2009 (Croatia and Albania) and last, hopefully not final enlargement in 2017 (Montenegro). By observing the geopolitical idea of Zbigniew Brzezinski from the early 1960s, it is obvious that NATO expanded to the east of Europe, towards Russia, as close as it was possible. This provokes Russia's opposing reaction, because any new NATO enlargement to countries in the Eastern and South-Eastern parts of Europe causes a security imbalance. It uses all means at its disposal, apart from the military for now, to fiercely oppose this. This is also the reason why Serbia is positioning itself in such a way, because of its political connection with Russia, and BiH entity, Republika Srpska, is following suite by declaring its military neutrality despite this act being completely unconstitutional. Why unconstitutional? Because Article III of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina clearly states that entities do not have jurisdiction over membership in international organisations, if this is not approved by the Parliament of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Moreover, entities cannot prevent Bosnia and Herzegovina as an internationally recognised state and subject to international law, to enter into international agreements and international organisations.
Article III / 5 of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina is particularly important, as it deals with the competencies to be taken over by the state authorities for the protection of sovereignty, territorial integrity and international legality of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This Article III / 5 of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina was the legal basis for the adoption of the Law on Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which in its Article 84 prescribes an obligation on all state bodies to work on the future membership of BiH in the NATO Alliance.
WHAT IS MAP?
During its existence, NATO attempted to articulate its expansion through Article 10 of the North Atlantic Treaty, which set the criteria for admitting new states to NATO membership. Since the description was too ambiguous, leading to various initiatives and groups such as: Višegrad Group, the Vilnius Group, and the Adriatic Charter, NATO has designed and launched the MAP (Membership Action Plan) program, which has its own five criteria:
• Willingness to resolve international, ethnic or foreign territorial disputes peacefully, through commitment to the rule of law, human rights and democratic control of the armed forces;
• Ability to contribute to defence and missions of the organisation;
• Ensuring adequate financial resources for the armed forces in order to fulfil the membership obligations;
• Security of sensitive information and protective measures that will be provided in this regard;
• Compatibility of domestic legislation with NATO.
This is a brief overview of the significance of NATO's MAP program, with one note that this organisation sets specific criteria separately for each NATO candidate country, hence the separate criteria for Bosnia and Herzegovina, known as the Tallinn criteria.
WHERE IS BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA IN ALL THAT?
Bosnia and Herzegovina expressed its will and aspirations to join the NATO alliance in the Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina in 2005, when a decision was made to join the Membership Action Plan. Thereafter Bosnia and Herzegovina joined the 2006 Partnership for Peace program and signed an agreement on cooperation in the field of security in 2007. This led to NATO launching an Individual Partnership Program with BiH in 2008, which led to the launch of the "Intensive Dialogue Program" agreed at the 2008 Budapest Summit. After that, Bosnia and Herzegovina applied for the MAP in 2009, which NATO approved in 2010. The criteria added at the NATO Summit in Tallinn in 2011 included registration and entry of prospective military assets.
This is when the problems started because NATO has set individual conditions for BiH, which refer to the entry of 63 military locations as state property of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Those who may have dealt with this, who are lawyers, know that this is a more administrative-technical issue, where property is checked that has been transferred to the BiH Ministry of Defence through a decision of a relevant authority, which is, a rather technical process where no negotiation or political will is required. Unfortunately, this turned out to be a problem in our country which led to the Constitutional Court of BiH having had to make a decision which ultimately resolves this type of dispute and creates the necessary legal and formal conditions for the property to be registered.
In the meantime, the National Assembly of Republika Srpska entity adopts the so-called Resolution on the Protection of the Constitutional Order and the Proclamation of Military Neutrality of the Bosnian-Herzegovinian entity. Although the Resolution is a non-binding document, and it does not have the force of law, it creates political problems in the further NATO path of BiH. This resolution is used today to challenge the Tallinn Condition; it is used to draft an annual action plan that is technical rather than a political issue; which, ultimately, can be done by the executive authority such as a minister of defence alone. No new political decision by the Presidency of BiH is necessary, or by the Parliamentary Assembly of BiH; it is not even necessary for the Council of Ministers to react, i.e., let me be more specific, the body which is equivalent to a government of a state. It is possible to do this through a decision, that is, an action by the minister of defence of BiH who will shape all we talked about technically in a document and submit to NATO. Unfortunately, we have stopped here now. The will does not exist in one part of the political institutions, political forces in BiH to realise this; one part of those who were believed to be committed to NATO path of BiH is starting to calculate politically and move away from the whole technical part of the process, so that Bosnia and Herzegovina in this moment stands on one technical question, while all necessary decisions which included everyone, that is, all segments, all political institutions at the state level have been made.
WHAT IS THE EXIT STRATEGY?
The exit strategy is precisely in looking at the annual action plan as a technical issue, rather than a political one, and to submit the plan of action at the technical level to the structures to overview, approve and state whether it is good enough for this year.
Unfortunately, we have made a big political problem out of that. We have come to the stage where, because of the announced anti-constitutional and illegal activity in the area of NATO integration, I, as a member of the Presidency, cannot give mandate to the new Chairman of the BiH Council of ministers. His name is not controversial, his political background is not controversial; the fact is that he comes from a party that is one of the winners in past elections, but because of statements from his political party that he will not enforce decisions and laws on defence, we cannot assign him a mandate.
Unfortunately, any question, whether technical such as the annual action plan within the national NATO membership plan, can grow into a top political problem here. I think that there is a way out of this situation: the current minister of defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina submits the already prepared annual national MAP plan to NATO, they review and approve it, possibly add to it, and we continue our path towards integrations.
I have talked a while longer, but it is worth recalling some technical historical facts, put Bosnia and Herzegovina in certain contexts, and try to provide some answers to get us out of the current situation. I would like to thank the organisers once again for the invitation, and I would like to thank you for your attention. I stand at your disposal for all your questions or clarifications. Thank you.

title: Press statements of Šefik Džaferović, BiH Presidency member and Christian Dan Preda, Standing Rapporteur for Bosnia and Herzegovina in the European Parliament
content:
Friends of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the persons who have strongly supported BiH are paying a visit to Bosnia and Herzegovina today. Mr Dan Preda is one such person. I avail myself of this opportunity to thank him for everything he has done so far in order to ensure that Bosnia and Herzegovina becomes a member of the European Union as soon as possible.
Šefik Džaferović, BiH Presidency member
Dear ladies and gentlemen journalists, let me extend a warm welcome to you. I am grateful to you for responding to our call to be notified on what we discussed today at the meeting, which we find important, held at the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina with Christian Dan Preda and Mr Wigemark concerning the European path of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Friends of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the persons who have strongly supported BiH are paying a visit to Bosnia and Herzegovina today. Mr Dan Preda is one such person. I avail myself of this opportunity to thank him for everything he has done so far in order to ensure that Bosnia and Herzegovina becomes a member of the European Union as soon as possible. At the moment, it is up to us in Bosnia and Herzegovina to resolve the issue of answers to the additional questions most urgently. I expect that process to be completed in the following days. There are certain problems concerning education in Chapter 26, having in mind different competencies of the state, entity, and canton levels. I expect that the Council of Ministers will complete these answers in the following days, and submit them to the European Commission. This is the issue which is most urgent concerning Bosnia and Herzegovina and its European path.
The second issue we tackled today is the specific one concerning the functioning of the Parliamentary Committee on Stabilization and Accession. You are aware that this is an old issue, that the European Parliament's Parliamentary Committee on Stabilization and Accession is composed of and led by a group of the European Parliament members, and a specific group of members of the Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina, i.e. our Joint Commission for European Integration. You are aware that, for a relatively long period, there has been a discussion within that body on its rules of procedure, i.e. on its decision making procedures.
Namely, we have had a problem concerning the decision making procedures due to the position taken by the members of the state Parliament of Bosnia and Herzegovina, i.e. by those who come from the Bosnian and Herzegovinian Entity of Republika Srpska. The European Parliament has its own rules, and, in my opinion, Bosnia and Herzegovina should follow the rules and decision making procedures in the Committee in accordance with the recommendations of the European Commission. We also said that, after the state Parliament committees established, we from the Presidency would try to hold a meeting with the members of that specific Committee of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and, of course, with the members of the European Parliament's Committee in order to find a solution to the problem concerned. It is our goal that Bosnia and Herzegovina gets granted a candidate status as soon as possible in the course of the current year, and that it should be done before the elections for the European Parliament would be held. As we already discussed it together previously, and as we specifically emphasized at today's meeting, the period after the elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and before the elections for the European Parliament, should be used in a way ensuring that Bosnia and Herzegovina should not be idle or at loss concerning its progress along the European path. That was, in briefest terms, a summary of what we discussed at today's meeting. Mr Dan Preda will hold meetings with other officials in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Let me, once again, avail myself of the opportunity to extend my thanks to him.
Christian Dan Preda, Standing Rapporteur for BiH in the European Parliament
I would like to thank the media representatives for attending this event. First of all, I wish a happy New Year to you, with all of my best wishes to you and to the citizens of this country. I am here today in the capacity of the rapporteur on Bosnia and Herzegovina on behalf of the European Parliament. We adopted the report on BiH within our Foreign Affairs Committee. This is a report which was adopted in that form at the plenary session. However, as it was said already, no joint parliamentary committee has been established yet between the Parliament of the European Union and BiH. The committee would be composed of 50% members from BiH and 50% members from the Parliament of the European Union, and it should ensure a consolidated joint work on the European path of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Unfortunately, in the previous three years, we have not succeeded in persuading our friends from the Parliamentary Assembly of BiH to come to Brussels and Strasbourg in order to enable our joint work on these issues. Actually, what was attempted was to apply the rules used in accordance with the rules of procedure in BiH to the joint body of the two parliaments. In such way, actually, they tried to transform the European Union into a big BiH. The challenge is to do exactly the opposite, i.e. that BiH becomes a member of the European Union, and not that the European Union gets transformed into some big BiH. This would be my message. Namely, I am calling upon you as the media representatives to send an invitation, a letter to your Parliament members, and ask the citizens to do the same – ask the representatives in the Parliamentary Assembly to work together and cooperate with the colleagues in the European Parliament.
Please note that this mechanism of joint parliamentary committees is something that was already established by other countries in the Western Balkan. Further, it was mentioned that we waited for the replies to the additional questions of the European Commission. The candidate status of Bosnia and Herzegovina is something that depends on provision of replies to the additional questions because such replies will enable the Commission to prepare its opinion in a written form. So, in order to prepare such an opinion, it is necessary to have the replies submitted first. Let me just remind you that the Commission sent its additional questions in June 2018. We are now in January 2019. Therefore, I would say that it has taken a bit too long indeed. I hope that this issue will be resolved prior to any other issue.
Further, let me note that we discussed with two of the three BiH Presidency members the issue of importance of composing the authorities at all levels. After the elections anywhere in the world it is normal to compose both legislative and executive authorities accordingly. I hereby re-iterate that we are now in January 2019, so, could you please do this as well? Finally, I will add that we tackled the Dragičević case in the course of the discussion. No single political party has succeeded in mobilizing so many citizens around such issue as sensitive as this one. Therefore, I believe that the politicians should be most careful indeed. Something is going on, I would say, at the level of the society, people, i.e. the citizens are seeking justice and looking for solutions. This is not a problem of one individual, nor is it a problem of the prosecutors from Republika Srpska only. The citizens have insisted that justice should be done. I hereby invite the host authorities to solve this case as soon as possible.
Thank you very much.

title: Address by Šefik Džaferović, BiH Presidency member at the commemorative event dedicated to the memory of Lord Paddy Ashdown
content:
He was born in 1941, in the midst of the World War II, when the international order was fiercely disturbed by the aggression, and when the whole nations were under threat of extinction. Until the end of his life, Lord Ashdown was a great fighter for the values of the free world.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Bosnia and Herzegovina lost its great friend. His homeland the United Kingdom lost its great politician and diplomat, and the world lost a wise and a good man.
We have gathered today to pay respects to him. He deserved it by his deeds.
He was born in 1941, in the midst of the World War II, when the international order was fiercely disturbed by the aggression, and when the whole nations were under threat of extinction. Until the end of his life, Lord Ashdown was a great fighter for the values of the free world.
When the aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina started in 1992, he was at the zenith of his career as president of one of the leading parties in the British Parliament.
He recognized straight away the importance of resistance against the forces of tyranny, which conducted the aggression against our country and threatened our people with extinction.
He arrived to the besieged Sarajevo as early as in August 1992, met with the late President Alija Izetbegović, and offered his support to a struggle fought by a free and independent country, which symbolized defending the values of the free world.
Until the end of the war he was one of the most ardent advocates of the international community's intervention aimed at stopping the aggression and genocide.
It was by this undertaking during the 1990's that he won the right to repeat, years later, the truth that the genocide in BiH could have been stopped with more willingness and decisiveness of the international community. “We could have prevented this horror. We chose not to do so,“ he was saying and reminding the world.
Weighted down by quilt, such awareness became the foundation of a more decisive engagement of the international community in our country, particularly after the Dayton peace agreement was concluded.
Lord Ashdown was indeed a personification of such decisiveness.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina we will remember him as High Representative, who made the unfair Dayton peace a bit fairer through its correct interpretation and application alike, thus making Bosnia and Herzegovina more functional in the interest of all its citizens.
During his mandate in Bosnia and Herzegovina between 20002 and 2006 some significant reform-driven progress was made. Namely, the integration path of Bosnia and Herzegovina was laid out to its membership in the European Union and NATO Alliance.
Forming of many state institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina is an important heritage of OHR during the Ashdown's mandate.
During his mandate many democratic institutions of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina were either formed or strengthened, as the basis for sustainable peace and security, economic progress and the respect for human rights of all citizens and peoples in BiH.
A single Armed Forces, a single tax system, the state security agencies such as the Intelligence and Security Agency (OSA) and the State Investigation and Protection Agency (SIPA), as well as the state judicial institutions are just a part of the heritage for which the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina have good memories of a joint work of OHR, the Council of Ministers, and the Parliamentary Assembly of BiH from that period.
A decisive initiative of Lord Ashdown on the cooperation with the Hague Tribunal and on the persecution of war criminals and their collaborators was particularly important.
The truth is that for all his decisions he had a full political support of the overall international community through the Peace Implementation Council. However, Lord Ashdown provided a crucial contribution to the reforms by his energetic approach. These reforms enabled us to have a much stronger state.
Lord Ashdown was a man of action; a diplomat who gave priority to specific actions over being concerned and restrained.
He knew that the political forces which threatened the democratic values should be responded to decisively and prevented from their destructive intentions.
On the occasion of commemorating the 20th anniversary of the genocide, Lord Ashdown said that the western world had to remember Srebrenica not only as a witness to such horror, but also in order to understand what would happen when it turned its back.
This key lesson has resonated by the power of its essential meaning: the international community should not turn its back on Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Lord Ashdown did not turn his back. He fulfilled his political mission, and, above all, his mission as a human being.
He remained faithful and selflessly committed to Bosnia and Herzegovina to the end. “I really love the Bosnian people,“ he said in one of his last interviews.
Let us keep our memories of him by fighting for Bosnia and Herzegovina, for freedom, truth and justice.
May our friend Paddy rest in peace.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić on the occasion of the Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Dear soldiers, NCOs, officers, generals, Esteemed officials and guests! Bosnia and Herzegovina is one proud country, which has, through its thousands of years long tradition, also cherished the necessary aspect of defence of its territorial integrity to show and prove the existence of its sovereignty. The Armed Forces of BiH are yet another way of showing the sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the statehood anniversary of which we have marked recently.
Protection of sovereignty and territorial integrity is the task of all states, and each country organises their own system of defence in which the fundamental role is played by the armed forces. That certainly is not an aggressive role, but the role which by its definition is defensive and serves its fundamental task – defend in every moment territorial integrity of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In that regard, all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina rightfully count on the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which were formed with a task that is not at all simple, but with a very clear and decisive intention.
Besides this task, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina showed readiness to participate in activities during natural disasters in our country, where you had, almost every year, an opportunity to, through your engagement, save lives of our citizens as well as their property.
I wish to pay respect to members of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina for successful participation in international missions and exercises, especially for the participation in exercises in cooperation with the NATO forces, as well as congratulate the acceptance into the BiH Armed Forces six hundred new young soldiers. I hope we will create better conditions for their work in the next period.
One of the more important aspects of the BiH Armed Forces is also the part regarding NATO membership of Bosnia and Herzegovina, whereby we need to fulfil five conditions from the MAP program. We, as the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, are very close to the activation of MAP. Although we have done a lot of work on the fulfilment of conditions from MAP, we are still lacking the fulfilment of the final fifth condition or an added condition which regards the land registration of perspective military properties to the state institutions. That certainly does not depend on you, but on the current politics, but I firmly believe that we are bringing this difficult task to the end despite political obstructions directed towards weakening of the Armed Forces and the defence sector of BiH in general.
Therefore, it is necessary to, first and foremost, work strongly on modernization of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with a special focus on mobility and ability to fulfil basic tasks, but also in aid to the population in emergencies. Continuation of registering of military property and fulfilment of MAP conditions, as I have already said, must be our top priority. Furthermore, in the period ahead, it is necessary to strongly commit to increasing a degree of interoperability with the NATO Alliance member state armies, as well as the increase in the budget of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and further staff training within their structures. The Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina are not only the support to peace and stability of our state, but they are also the support to peace in the world, proven by our participation in peacekeeping missions. Therefore, it is necessary to continue giving support to our allies in the NATO peacekeeping missions and show that will continue to stand, shoulder to shoulder, alongside those with whom we wish to share our future.
Once again, to all members of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, wishing you all the best for this day and anniversary!
Thank you!

title: The address by the newly appointed member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Šefik Džaferović at the constitutive session of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, 20.11.2018
content:
For start, it is necessary for all to think about the words they articulate in public space. It all starts with a word. Heavy words, insults and untruths which are told, require an answer. Then that answer is followed by another. All this creates a spiral which produces bad atmosphere in which it is very difficult to work. That is how artificial crises arise. Investors start avoiding us. We lose time irrevocably, instead of solving real problems.
Excellences,
Eminencies,
Members of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Esteemed ladies and gentlemen,
Dear citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
I greet you with the feeling of great honour that I stand in this place today as a member of the Presidency – but more so with the feeling of greater responsibility towards the obligations that stand before us in leading our state in the next four-year mandate.
First of all, I wish to thank the citizens of our homeland for showing the democratic capacity in the recent General election.
It is down to us to establish the parliamentary majority speedily and efficiently, at all levels of government. In my opinion, these have to be program majorities comprised of, primarily, the winning political parties which have the capacity to rule at all levels.
We need a wide and stable parliamentary majority which would – bearing in mind the jagged responsibilities of different levels of government – cover the whole state. The election results show that such majority is possible to build. Everything else is a question of responsibility of political actors towards the assumed obligations. The government needs to be established as soon as possible, caring about the whole state, and without any conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Allow me to thank the members of the Presidency from the 2014-2018 mandate, who, despite numerous challenges, did a lot in the interest of Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens. Their contribution is particularly visible in the unblocking of the Euro-Atlantic path of our state.
The new Presidency members have the opportunity to enable the country to, based on the work done so far, move the country forward in the society of modern and prosperous European states from which the people would not be leaving, but would want to stay and build their and their children’s future here.
In order for that to happen, it is necessary to lead a few processes in parallel, and the key ones are reintegration of the country and its integration to the European Union and NATO. This to be followed by speedier implementation of economic and societal reforms.
People in this country are tired of useless and unnecessary quarrels. They wish to live in peace, to raise and educate their children, have security, social justice, hope and perspective. It is our duty and obligation to offer them that.
For start, it is necessary for all to think about the words they articulate in public space. It all starts with a word. Heavy words, insults and untruths which are told, require an answer. Then that answer is followed by another. All this creates a spiral which produces bad atmosphere in which it is very difficult to work. That is how artificial crises arise. Investors start avoiding us. We lose time irrevocably, instead of solving real problems.
If we approach each other with respect, even when we have different views, if we lead a civilized dialogue, if we aim to reach an agreement on key questions, and if we are committed to truth and justice, then we will be able to truly work on reintegration of the country.
That reintegration assumes the same rights for every citizen in every part of the state, regardless their ethnic and religious belonging, as well as a joint action in accomplishing the interests of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I am convinced that a huge majority of people wishes to live in such a state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I will advocate such Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Young people are leaving to organised and modern European countries, members of the European Union. That process can be halted only if we make Bosnia and Herzegovina the same as those countries.
Significant steps have already been made. Bosnia and Herzegovina is about to gain the candidate status for membership in the European Union.
It is necessary for all of us to further speed up the European path of our state. Fulfilment of conditions for membership in the European Union must be a top priority. Most of the program of the new governing coalition needs to include the European Commission recommendations which we are obliged to adopt in the accession process. I believe that there is a general consensus about this in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
If we do all this, then we can expect Brussels to offer us further impetus by responding fast with approving our candidate status.
Ladies and gentlemen,
In all these processes the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina plays a special role and responsibility.
I expect this Presidency to lead responsible politics which reflect in creation and preservation of political stability.
I believe that with such a stance, the Presidency will send a clear signal to all institutions at all levels of government that they also take a serious and responsible approach in executing of their obligations.
For it to be so – and for the Presidency to establish itself in the full capacity as chief of state – we have to consistently abide by the Constitution, law and democratic principles.
We must – without any doubt – respect and implement the General Framework Agreement for Peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina and its 11 annexes. We have just committed to that by giving a solemn oath. That includes the respect and implementation of the European Convention on Human Rights, and all decisions by the international and national courts, as well as all earlier laws and decisions,
All of that which is colloquially called “Dayton” in our public space. All of that is one whole and one package. There cannot be a partial approach. Everything must be respected and implemented equally and with the same intensity.
All of us –without holding back - must be committed to the rule of law and respect continuity of the previous decisions. That is the founding principle of a legal state. The adopted decisions by the institutions must be respected until new ones are brought, and they should not be contested or brought into question. The functioning of our system is not the thing of constant and repeated agreements, but of Constitution, law and adopted decisions. If we have adopted a law once, then that law must be implemented. Only questions which are not covered, or those that need changing can be a subject of an agreement. Until then, the current system must function and no one can condition or contend it as that would be an obstruction leading to anarchy.
Change of a political stance on some question is legitimate, but the adopted decisions and laws must be respected and they can be changed only in the same place as they were adopted in the first place.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Regarding the defence, we must commit to further reform of the defence system in accordance with the NATO standards and Defence Review which was adopted by the Presidency in the previous mandate.
