Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina must have the capacity to execute its tasks and missions from the Law on Defence, in every moment.
Our Armed forces largely apply the NATO standards already. They participate in international security and peacekeeping missions under the auspices of this organisation, as well as the Organisation of the United Nations. We expect that the Action Plan for the membership of Bosnia and Herzegovina in NATO will soon be activated, so that we could continue with the reforms of our defence system.
Beside the Euro-Atlantic path, as our key foreign policy goal, regional cooperation and relations with our neighbours are important to Bosnia and Herzegovina. We need a dialogue in the region. There are numerous open questions with our neighbours. They can only be solved by dialogue. The Presidency needs to insist on building cooperation with neighbours on the principles of full mutual respect and reciprocity as well as the respect of international law. It also must care for the interests and rights of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the rights of our legal entities and individuals. We ask of our neighbours only that which belongs to Bosnia and Herzegovina. We will never give up on that.
Alongside the cooperation in the region, Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to continue to build good relations with all our partners and friends in the world, and with all those who respect our country and are well-intentioned towards it.
There is a lot of work ahead of us, and many challenges. Let’s make this mandate be remembered as a mandate of cooperation, agreement, progress and prosperity of our state. I am convinced that we have enough maturity and wisdom to, with God’s help, make a step forward in that direction – to make sure that every person in this country feels comfortable, to live better, and to be proud of his or her homeland, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Thank you!

title: The address by the newly appointed member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina representing the Croat people, Željko Komšić at the constitutive session of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovi
content:
Ladies and gentlemen, our state is founded on the principles of anti-fascism. The time that lies ahead challenges us to show Europe and the world once again that we belong in the line of states which at their core cherish civilizational, European values, and anti-fascism is one of the greatest civilizational and European values. The idea of anti-fascism, in its essence, is interwoven with a vision and necessity for equality and unity. I deeply believe that only together we can take our country into a happier and better time and a better environment.
Respected gentlemen, members of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, esteemed officials, your excellences – members of the diplomatic corps, dear citizens and peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina, dear guests and friends, ladies and gentlemen,
I have been given a great honour and a large obligation once again to represent the interests of citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the people I come from. I have just sworn not to betray the trust I have been given, and I will put all my knowledge and effort in it. I will be the president of all citizens, affirm all values of a democratic society and civilizational heritage.
I would like to use this opportunity to thank our predecessors Mr Dragan Čović, Mr Mladen Ivanić and Mr Bakir Izetbegović for their work, in, what is now already a previous convocation of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The insistence and work on the rule of law, that is, affirmation of constitutionality, legality and justice as a general category, affirmation of democratic and civilizational heritage will be at the top of my priorities list.
Without the fight against every type of discrimination there is no freedom, and there cannot be freedom if there is if only one citizen of Bosnia and Herzegovina who has had his or her basic human and democratic right denied.
The citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina need to know that, as a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I will be an advocate to every kind of equality, national, religious, gender, social… simply, every equality.
Ladies and gentlemen, our state is founded on the principles of anti-fascism. The time that lies ahead challenges us to show Europe and the world once again that we belong in the line of states which at their core cherish civilizational, European values, and anti-fascism is one of the greatest civilizational and European values.
The idea of anti-fascism, in its essence, is interwoven with a vision and necessity for equality and unity. I deeply believe that only together we can take our country into a happier and better time and a better environment.
In order to succeed, we first must be responsible, accountable towards the state as a union and towards the people who live in it.
There is no responsibility towards the state if we tolerate crime, corruption, injustice, segregation and general insecurity of citizens, because we all know that these produce poverty, unemployment, discontent and at the end of the day despair of all kinds which drive our people from the homeland.
In its recent past, the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina has overpowered all the negative circumstances due to the strength of its citizens. Conscious of our historical responsibility, we today have to look into the future because, we cannot change the past, but the future should not be uncertain!
I am firm in my conviction that the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina lies in the membership in NATO Alliance and membership in the European Union. Those are also the guarantors of security and prosperity of our state and its citizens.
The NATO path of Bosnia and Herzegovina is in the same place it was when I was in the building of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the same position as today, just four years ago.
The time has come to change that, and I will not miss an opportunity to change this through activation of MAP for the membership in NATO Alliance. Nor will I miss the opportunity to actively promote those policies and processes which pull or push, whichever way we wish to look at it, Bosnia and Herzegovina only and exclusively forward. I will do this led by democratic and civilizational values and in cooperation with institutions of the European Union, United Nations and the states friends of our country.
In the next four years, Bosnia and Herzegovina should stop being an object but become a subject of international and regional relations. With that regard, I am ready to make an additional effort in accomplishing greater cooperation with the Republic of Croatia, the Republic of Serbia, with Montenegro, and, of course, with the Republic of Macedonia and the Republic of Slovenia.
Before me is also work on fulfilment of the planned activities and initiatives I presented in the “Presidential vision of progress”. This is the plan which has concrete ideas and goals. The priority is strengthening of our economic position, new approach to diplomacy and foreign policy of BiH, fight against foreign influences on the election process and prevention of the growth of violent groups in the country. I will actively promote the change of the coordination mechanism, and will also strongly advocate the implementation of the rulings by the European Court of Human Rights, and equal value of the voice of every citizen of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which has not been the case to date.
Ladies and gentlemen, lastly, a little reminder.
Today is the Universal Children’s Day.
On 20 November 1989 at the General Assembly of the United Nations the Convention of the rights of children was adopted. The Convention contains the universal standards the signatory states must guarantee to each child. Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of the countries that accepted this Convention.
Let the leading thought for us be about the kind of the country we are leaving to them, our children, our future.
Let’s make sure they are growing up in safe surroundings without violence, war, scarcity and illness. That is primarily what we owe to them, the children. But, we owe that to ourselves too.
Thank you.

title: Address by Milorad Dodik, the newly elected Serb member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the constitutive session of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, 20 November 2018
content:
Esteemed members of the Presidency, Esteemed members of the Presidency to date, Representatives of state institutions of government at the BiH level, Representatives of entities’ government President of the National Assembly, President of Republika Srpska, Members of the government, Your excellencies Your eminences It is a special honour for me to be here today to, together with my colleagues, take over the duty of a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
After the General election in which I received more than 370000 votes as a confirmation of my election, speaks about the way I will act, my basis, that is the home basis is Republika Srpska. I come to the Presidency as the representative of Republika Srpska and the Serb people, and I will fight to, together with other members of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and in accordance with the Constitution, return the position and dimension they have according to the Constitution. It is not my intention to do any harm to anyone or to do anything to prevent any Croat, Bosniak or any organizational unit, canton, municipality on the territory of Federation, or the Federation itself, in any development project.
I would like to make such cooperation which can prove to be effective. We have long moved from the causes of the war. This is a serious opportunity to take a step forward today and try to create a society which can exist led by democratically elected peoples’ representatives in democratic elections that repeat a few times in Bosnia and Herzegovina. My politics will be based exclusively on respecting the Constitution, that which is written in the Dayton Peace Accords, that which I accepted here to swear to, the Constitution and the Dayton General Framework for Peace Agreement. Naturally, many here know that I have many objections on the works of High Representative and the way the Constitution and the political system in BiH has been derogated. I think we will have to have discussions again about many questions and in that way show our ability to make new compromises.
The solutions reached 15 – 20 years ago may have suited that time, but the solutions which we have to adapt today must suit this time. I will advocate for the abolishment of the role of High Representative in BiH as soon as possible. I think the continuing role of High Representative has not been in the interest of the long term stability and development of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Many decisions which were brought, and these count to over 540, contained imposed laws, to which High Representative did not have the right to do, as well as the intervention in the Constitution of the entity which High Representative did not have right to do. The role of High Representative was introducted in BiH with Annex 10 of the Dayton Agreement, signed by Republika Srpska, FBiH, Serbia and Croatia. According to that annex, he can only implement civil parts of the Agreement, and we have seen that in the past, it was more than that.
I think we will have enough wish and will to make the best, and I know I will. I have said already that I do not wish to make any bad moves towards the Bosniaks or Federation or Croats and their cantons, but likewise, I ask for an adequate treatment of Republika Srpska which I represent here and the Serb people, wherever they may be.
Our politics, the politics of Republika Srpska, which is general knowledge, will be my politics. I am here as the representative of Republika Srpska and the Serb people, to implement policies in relation to military neutrality, and to reject any processes which lead towards directing Bosnia and Herzegovina towards something that is not in the interest of Republika Srpska and its people.
I think it will be necessary to work on that together, to have more understanding and mutual respect.
In any case, regarding the military neutrality, elements for it are part of the political consensus of all, the government and opposition in Republika Srpska, and I will very proudly implement politics which have a successful, comprehensive consensus with regards to this question. Naturally, I do not exclude a possibility and I have the need to say that the European Union needs to be the goal of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Therefore, together with my colleagues, I will ask at the next session that the EU and its structures, regardless that this may appear naïve, grants the candidate status to Bosnia and Herzegovina at soonest, so that we could create new dynamics.
And this will not be only to our detriment. We will express our commitment with statements, but we also want to see the commitment of Europe.
Europe, which has significantly modeled the political system here, the successes and failures of BiH, will now be in a position, this is not a condition, I know perfectly well that I can not make conditions, but in any case, I think it would be reasonable to get the candidate status as soon as possible and to develop our potential within this framework, and to get a new dynamic in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We will cooperate with all important factors. Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a member of multilateral and other organisations will continue to act in accordance with its own interests.
I will do my best for our relations with the European Union be good, and for our relations with the USA be good also. We support the politics of the American president who does not want to interfere into the affairs of other countries. I would like to see that in practice and I will advocate this since that is what I had heard.
Likewise, I do not need nor do I want to hide the fact that my cooperation with the Russian Federation has been very successful to date, and I will naturally not give up on this cooperation.
I consider it very important also that we have comprehensive cooperation with China, which will encourage investments and our development.
I wish to discuss and to be present, together with my colleagues, as the representative of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in other places, at bilateral and multilateral meetings and places where these questions are discussed.
I am not ready to leave the capacity gained at elections, that is 372000 votes, to anyone else and thus will not allow for anyone to impose decisions created in my cabinet. I will be very satisfied if we complete the mandate with the fact that we can say that we have done something good for all citizens and peoples in BiH, and that we did that with our own forces. As I have been doing to date, I will continue to actively and visibly advocate for foreign judges to leave the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We must return the judiciary to the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as has been prescribed by the Constitution. We must conclude that the judiciary reform implemented earlier by the OHR was completely unsuccessful, that is has produced a significant degree of corruption an that it has produced one lack of functioning and alienated centre of power in BiH beyond the will of the people who voted for political representatives, considering or putting us in a position to respect the independence of judiciary, which has been dependent on international institutions.
All this will naturally be difficult to achieve. I do not have an illusion about it now. Unlike my function to date, where I was the President of Republika Srpska, now I will have to and I will with my colleagues, jointly consider and reach certain decisions, and I believe we will be able to do that. I would not have accepted this duty if I did not believe that.
If Bosnia and Herzegovina does not start showing a new dimension and a new impetus, I do not see my place here. I have not come to take photos, receive salary, nor have I come here to travel the world; I have tried and seen all that. I want us to make an agreement here with full respect of, before all, two entities, three peoples, state institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all citizens in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Thank you.

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, Chairman of BiH Presidency at GIFA awards presentation ceremony
content:
Mr President Gueliehu, esteemed Reisu-l-ulema Dr Kavazović, esteemed Mr Azmi, Mrs President of the GIFA Award Board, dear organizers of the Sarajevo Halal fair, led by BBI Bank director Bukvić, ladies and gentlemen – Assalamu Alaikum!
I am sincerely honoured by the Global Islamic Finance Awards awarded in the categories of leadership and Islamic finance. Dr Azmi, let me avail myself of this opportunity to thank You and the Edbriz Corporation Board for the award, as well as for your decision to select Sarajevo as a host of this year’s ceremony.
This year’s GIFA is organized within the Sarajevo Halal Fair. I am glad that participants and exhibitors from 43 countries have come to Sarajevo, and that Sarajevo is hosting so many foreign guests.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has achieved a significant economic growth during the last four years. The Government of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina succeeded in stabilizing public finance and extrabudgetary funds, a strong GDP growth has been marked, the number of new jobs in manufacturing industry has increased significantly, a particular growth of the metal processing industry was achieved, as well as of tourism, textile and wood industry. The rise of exports last year was highest in the region, exceeding 17 percent. These facts and clearly positive economic trends in Bosnia and Herzegovina should lead to an increased share of the Islamic banking capital in the economy of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Islamic finance may play a significant role in the building of our infrastructure, firstly through the application of Public-Private Partnerships (PPP), which achieved excellent results in some countries like Malaysia, Turkey, Jordan, Djibouti. We are about to embark on a mass construction of roads, by which we will connect all parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Further, we will start building energy infrastructure, airports, roads, water supply systems, schools, hospitals. Given that such projects demand relatively large investments, there is an opportunity to mobilize more than one financial institution in order to ensure joint funding. I see an opportunity for funding through the Islamic finance there – in projects which would be built based on the Public Private-Partnership principle.
The potential and capability of Islamic banking in PPP have been recognized by the World Bank, too. Namely, in its analysis on fulfilment of the UN Global Agenda on sustainable development 2030, the World Bank has recommended Islamic banking as one of the most appropriate means of funding of the global sustainable development, including the infrastructure projects in particular.
Islamic finance is based on the philosophy of shared risk. In that context, infrastructure PPP projects are naturally conductive of Islamic finance. Funding of such projects requires a certain level of risk sharing with other project parties, whereas their purpose is both social and economic development.
A successful example of such business operations in Bosnia and Herzegovina and its region is the BBI bank, whose partnership-based projects have supported economy and industry. Very positive effects have been achieved indeed for the economy of Bosnia and Herzegovina through encouraging investment and presenting projects at the two flagship business events implemented by the BBI, i.e. the Sarajevo Business Forum, and the Sarajevo Halal Fair.
As far as I am concerned, I will continue to provide support to Islamic banking, which is a synonym for both ethical and humane banking, in which attitude towards man is equally important as earning profits. Led by such values, we have successfully implemented the Turkish credit line, through which the returnees were enabled to start their own businesses. It was by this credit line that over 7,000 jobs were created. This is a significant part of the economic growth of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in the segment which is very important to us, although it is sensitive and risky – supporting the poor people who start their own credit-supported business for the first time. This is a profile of people which the bankers have avoided.
In today’s word, which has comprehensively exhausted the resources selfishly and irresponsibly, the Islamic banking and halal production in general have offered hope and healthy alternatives because they have respected the God’s creations – nature, animals, and man.
Thank you!

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, Chairman of the Presidency of BiH at the 9th congress of the Global Alliance of Diaspora
content:
Dear congress Presidency, dear ministers, ambassadors, dear congress delegates, good morning and welcome to Sarajevo!
It is my pleasure to greet you at the start of the 9th congress of the Global Alliance of Diaspora and wish you a successful and fruitful work.
In particular, I hereby greet the leadership of the Global Alliance of Diaspora and all of you who came to your country from various parts of the world to pursue together with us solutions to the problems the diaspora has been facing, as well as the problems of our country. I hereby congratulate you for being persistent in holding the congress sessions, as well as for the serious topics you select and delegate.
Among you there is group of those who deserve to be noted in particular, i.e. those who have invested their money earned abroad in our homeland, thus enhancing the development and strengthening stability of our country. They have deserved a special gratitude.
Minister Borovac and Minister Osmanović ara also with us today. I congratulate them for their persistence in solving the issues their ministries have been facing, and particularly in view of progress achieved in cooperation with the diaspora and enhancement of its status.
This congress is an opportunity for me to present to you some processes which took part in our homeland recently. The previous several years will be remembered as the time in which a tough political struggle has been fought between those who strive to build peace, BiH, and a joint future in it, to start its progress along the EU and NATO path, and those who have strived to stop and dismantle the country, and achieve the war objectives by political means. I do refer here to the anti-constitutional referendums, verbal provocations and strikes against the territorial integrity, security and judicial systems, glorification and awarding of the war criminals and the war para-state projects. All this has taken place in our homeland. It was success to keep stability, make positive shifts forward in such circumstances and prevent blockades and deadlocks.
Under such unfavourable circumstances, we adopted the strategic documents which enabled BiH’s progress and a departure from the many years of deadlock on its EU and NATO integration path. After a 15-year delay, the Foreign Policy Strategy of BiH was adopted, too. After many years of trying to do so, we finally managed to adopt the Policies on cooperation with expatriates. By appeals submitted to the Constitutional Court we saved the citizenships of hundreds of thousands of Bosnians and Herzegovinians living abroad, their property was saved in the RS, the discriminating 9 January as the “RS Day” was disputed, and so on.
We completed and submitted the EC Questionnaire. These days we received the additional questions which would be completed shortly. We hope that by the end of the year we will be granted a membership status in the EU. The Survey of Defence, which is a precondition for our progress towards the NATO membership, was adopted, too.
Given the circumstances, the results achieved by the governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina in terms of stabilization of economic situation in our country have been solid. In this sense, we need to underline:
- A 3.0% GDP growth reaching a record 30.156 billion Bosnian Convertible Marks in 2017;
- Industry production average growth in 2016 and 2017 respectively was higher than 4.5%;
- continually increased Bosnian and Herzegovinian foreign trade, with an increased volume of trading, exports of goods, decrease of foreign trade deficit in goods and a better coverage of imports by exports. The exports have grown for almost17% in the previous year, and for the first time the coverage of exports by imports exceeded 66%.
- Concerning the public debt, Bosnia and Herzegovina is a moderately indebted country. Compared to other countries in the region, BiH is, in both absolute and relative sense, the least indebted country. The debt amounts to 6 billion Euro, which is less than 40% of GDP, whereas, for example, the public debt of Serbia exceeds 25 billion Euros (73% of GDP), and the debt of Croatia is higher than 40 billion Euros (over 85& of GDP),
- Bosnia and Herzegovina is in the list of the twenty countries in the world with highest number of tourist visits in the last three years. More than 2.6 million of overnight stays were recorded in 2017;
- My promise made in 2014 on 100,000 newly employed in the sector of production in the period of ten years will be fulfilled with a minimum 60% of that number achieved after four years already, which exceeds the plan.
Your activities, which we appreciate and for which we are grateful, have contributed to such results. The remittances which mainly represent financial assistance to families, and which exceeded three billion Bosnian Convertible Marks or 18% of GDP have helped the economic stability of our country significantly.
The state must do more for the diaspora. There are some who make obstacles to such processes as those who do not love BiH do not love its diaspora either. The resistance is strong.
The authorities of BiH, i.e. the responsible part of those authorities, have indicated a clear BiH’s commitment to be at its diaspora’s disposal, while providing a necessary support to ensure access to the diaspora’s rights in the homeland. First of all, we are dedicated to establishing and continually building a normative framework and institutional mechanisms for cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and its diaspora at all administrative levels, particularly at the local one. It is our objective that the cooperation with the diaspora becomes a part of the legal order of BiH.
It is our intention to enhance cooperation in ensuring that you have access to your rights in the countries in which you live now through bilateral cooperation with such countries, as well as through establishment and strengthening of your representative bodies. We need to pay a particular attention to supporting the preservation of the mother tongue, culture and identity of the peoples and minorities of BiH.
At the same time, we expect a proactive approach from you, as well as initiatives and suggestions in the form of specific projects and programmes. As you become increasingly important actors in the political economic, educational, sports, cultural life of the countries in which you live now, we expect from you to engage yourselves that in a similar way in the processes in your homeland Bosnia and Herzegovina,
You have possessed love for your homeland, but also the knowledge, skills, valuable information, financial and social capital, you have the experience gathered in the developed countries. We therefore invite you to build Bosnia and Herzegovina together with us and enhance it to the point when it will meet the standards of the countries you come from.
Let us be partners in building of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a modern, European state in which, at its every square foot, each citizen, regardless of a religious or national affiliation, will be equal and satisfied.
These are the processes which will last for years, and even for decades. These processes will demand patience and persistence.
There are also processes which last for one day only, i.e. sudden shifts which may compensate for the lost years. On the seventh of October this year the diaspora can show its strength and change the political balances in Bosnia and Herzegovina, particularly in RS, in which Bosniaks and Croats are still the third-class citizens.
The patriotic political forces in the country have become an important factor without which there are no calculations in BiH or in the Balkans. However, such political factor, in most cases, is capable of stopping the negative tendencies and attempts only.
We do not have enough strength for starting the country in the right direction. The instances of resistance to such endeavour are too strong. Additional strength can be given to us only by you, the diaspora. A mass registration and voting in the elections, voting for the patriotic, peace-making political forces may change the situation in the country which you love in one day only.
Do organize yourselves and make such effort!
Do make the 7th of October a day which all of us will remember.
Thank you, I wish you all best!

title: Press statements by Bakir Izetbegović, Chairman of BiH Presidency and Recep Tayyip Erdoǧan, President of the Republic of Turkey on 20 May 2018 in Sarajevo
content:
Turkey and Bosnia and Herzegovina have excellent relations. Turkey has supported us in the Peace Implementation Council (PIC), in our aspirations concerning the European Union, our membership in the European Union and NATO, as well as in the economic development of Bosnia and Herzegovina, whereas Bosnia and Herzegovina has supported Turkey in regards to the stability of that part of the region. We extend our congratulations to you for your strength demonstrated there in order to stabilize the situation not only in Turkey but for the entire Europe by doing that job. You have succeeded in taking care in a very humane way of three million refugees, in mitigating that pressure advanced towards Europe. You have been fighting with the terrorists from DAESH, FETO, PKK, your military actions conducted at the borders of Turkey did not result in large numbers of victims. Moreover, such actions were very successful in a military sense. Address delivered by Bakir Izetbegović, Chairman of BiH Presidency:
Esteemed President Erdoǧan, let me, once again, welcome you to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
This is our second meeting this year as we met already in Ankara. You are here with us today. In the meantime, Prime Minister Yildirim visited Bosnia and Herzegovina. We have maintained a good dynamics of mutual visits.
Turkey and Bosnia and Herzegovina have excellent relations. Turkey has supported us in the Peace Implementation Council (PIC), in our aspirations concerning the European Union, our membership in the European Union and NATO, as well as in the economic development of Bosnia and Herzegovina, whereas Bosnia and Herzegovina has supported Turkey in regards to the stability of that part of the region. We extend our congratulations to you for your strength demonstrated there in order to stabilize the situation not only in Turkey but for the entire Europe by doing that job. You have succeeded in taking care in a very humane way of three million refugees, in mitigating that pressure advanced towards Europe. You have been fighting with the terrorists from DAESH, FETO, and PKK. Your military actions conducted at the borders of Turkey did not result in large numbers of victims. Moreover, such actions were very successful in a military sense.
Turkey and Bosnia and Herzegovina have the highest number of signed agreements. Therefore, the economic cooperation has grown significantly and its current trend is to grow further. In the previous year the trading between our two countries rose to almost 800,000,000 American Dollars, which was doubled compared to the situation four years ago. I hope that many free trade agreements which we should sign shortly will additionally strengthen this cooperation, so that we will exceed the trading worth 1 billion Euros shortly. In particular, those parts of the agreement are important which refer to the meat quotas, which will be defined and fixed at eight thousand tons a year of exports to Turkey by preferential prices, which are somewhat higher than the current market prices, and we will be safe for five years in this way. So far this was done each year anew to ensure that sufficient time and incentives for the people to develop that business. Concerning the wheat flour, sugar and oil quotas, which will be exported from Bosnia and Herzegovina, we are talking about tens of thousands of tons in the forthcoming period. The most important project we discussed today with the Turkish side was, of course, the construction of the motorway ring leading to Belgrade via Tuzla and Bijeljina, and returning through Požega and Višegrad to Bosnia and Herzegovina. The feasibility study, completed by the Turkish side, is not too optimistic regarding the south branch of this road, i.e. there is no sufficient frequency over Goražde, so that, probably, we will have to decide to go for a slightly cheaper version of a fast road. After the meeting between the delegations, we continued the meeting with the prime ministers and ministers of traffic of both countries only, and it was agreed that in the summer we would launch a public call, a procurement notice which will define potential investors and builders of this road. A letter of intentions was signed today in this sense – the two ministers signed the letter of intentions containing the main elements. We support continuation of the bilateral cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Turkey and Serbia, and we hope that during the summer we will have a meeting in this sense. Further, the present meeting, which was supposed to be an official one, was turned into a working one. We were supposed to hold one in late June. There is still time enough to organize an official visit, too in the course of July or August, particularly if by we get to have new elements concerning the construction of the motorway.
The Turkish credit line has had excellent effects. It employed thousands of returnees to RS, and some in the FBiH as well, and ensured a normal living standard to dozens of thousands of families. I believe that we will soon have a response from the Turkish side, i.e. that the credit line concerned will be extended, and that it will be available for ten more years again, while we still have four years remaining to implement the current one. This cooperation should be mutual, so that today we noted with care the remark made by the Turkish side which re-iterated a lack of raw material for the two large Turkish investments in Bosnia and Herzegovina, i.e. for the Sisecam in Lukavac, and for the Natron Hayat. Bosnia and Herzegovina promised to provide a stable supply with the raw materials, and it does not meet that condition. Thus, we will have to invest an additional effort in order to keep these investors in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and in order to get, eventually, new hundreds of jobs which they are offering if we succeed in guaranteeing the raw materials.
I informed Mr Recep Tayyip Erdoǧan about the current situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina. I think that the image projected by the media is somewhat worse than the actual situation. Namely, Bosnia and Herzegovina, with a very active attitude of the Council of Ministers, the present ministers and the Council of Ministers’ Chairman, has actually arrived to the front door of the European Union, and the front door of the NATO Alliance membership. We have followed the region on economic issues, so that we are not lagging behind at all. In increased exports, which reached almost 17% last year, we are the leader in the region. We are the leader in the region in terms of reduction of the number of unemployed persons. Bosnia and Herzegovina is the least indebted country in Europe. Thank you.
Address by Recep Tayyip Erdoǧan, President of the Republic of Turkey:
Esteemed Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, esteemed ministers, and esteemed media representatives!
I hereby extend my most cordial and respectful greetings to all of you. It is my great pleasure and honour, after three years, to be in Bosnia and Herzegovina again.
Let me, once again, extend my thanks to Bakir Izetbegović, Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina for his hospitality to me and my delegation.
We held very constructive bilateral and inter-delegation discussions. We discussed in detail a number of issues focused on politics, culture, tourism, transport and agriculture, i.e. on what we could do and on which steps we would make.
We discussed the bilateral relations and many issues, including economics, trade, infrastructure, transport, energy and tourism. Moreover, we discussed specific applied industry sectors. We would like to advance our cooperation in all these areas in the forthcoming period, too.
Turkey will continue to provide all kinds of assistance for preservation of stability, peace and prosperity of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Let me, once again, confirm hereafter the importance we attach to the preservation of territorial integrity of the united and sovereign state which consists of the two entities and one district. I wish that the forthcoming elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina contribute to enhancement of peace, stability and prosperity.
We will hold our elections on the 24th of June. There will be the elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina in October. I hope that these elections will be opportunities for enhancement of our relations. I hope that the elections will be held in accordance with the democratic rules, in peace, and in a transparent and fair way. We believe that the issue of changes of the Election Law, which is an important issue on the agenda in this election period, is an internal issue of this country, and we believe that the parties will resolve this issue in accordance with the reason, dialogue and mutual understanding.
Esteemed media representatives, we have advanced our trading, and, in a short period, we would like to increase its worth to one billion dollars. We already have sufficient willingness and readiness to achieve this. Therefore, it is of huge importance to sign a new Free trade agreement promptly in order to continue to work on the basis of it. Likewise, it is our shared wish to ensure that all agreements needed for continuation of the negotiations enter into force as soon as possible. An intense cooperation between our officials will be continued in the areas of transport, logistics, energy, tourism, agriculture and livestock sectors. We have encouraged the Turkish companies to implement large investments in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and in the whole of Balkans alike.
Our country has provided a strong support to infrastructure and transportation projects in this region. The Turkish companies are always ready to participate in these projects. I believe that the Turkish companies will work more on the infrastructural projects in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and I believe that the project on Belgrade-Sarajevo motorway will be the best example of such infrastructure building projects.
Likewise, we attach a huge importance to establishment of regional relations, which will be based on trust. These relations will be led by the relations of Bosnia and Herzegovina with Croatia and Serbia.
We will continue to implement the triple mechanisms with significant contributions provided by all sides, between Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croatia, and Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia.
Dear friends, we will continue to work actively in order to activate the NATO Membership Action Plan as soon as possible, and we will never leave Bosnia alone on this path. It is our great pleasure that Bosnia and Herzegovina fulfilled its obligation within the European integration process. It is very important that Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted its replies to the European Union questionnaire on 28 February. We hope that such acceleration achieved within the European integration process will be continued without delays.
Following the attempt of a military coup on 15 July, let me, on my own and on behalf of my people, re-iterate my gratitude to Bosnia and Herzegovina for its solidarity demonstrated in relation to Turkey. As also underlined by Mr Izetbegović, FETO has continued to exist as an octopus grabbing all levels of the society. Therefore, we have to conduct a huge fight against this issue. We also expect that the efforts and measures against all structures of the terrorist FETO organization in Bosnia and Herzegovina will get completed as soon as possible. We are ready for all kinds of cooperation on this issue, and we will continue to cooperate with the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina in order to implement the specific steps. Turkey will continue to provide support to Bosnia and Herzegovina in all areas. Our country has not had and will not have any hidden intention or agenda other than establishing prosperity, unity and economic development of Bosnia and Herzegovina, particularly in the area of economic development and the issue of sending 8,000 tons of meat. I believe that this is insufficient. As we said today, we can increase this figure to 15,000 tons, and this will contribute significantly to new employments in Bosnia and Herzegovina. I used to work a bit in this sector in the past, and I am very well familiar with it. I know what livestock means, and I know what sliced meat means, too. Therefore, we can contribute, through our joint work, to Bosnia’s huge progress on this issue.
Finally, let me reiterate my thanks for your hospitality and close friendship, and extend my most sincere selams and greetings to all of you.

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, BiH Presidency member at the opening of the Muslim
content:
Salam, Shalom, and good afternoon.
I am deeply honoured to speak at the opening of the eighth Muslim-Jewish conference, which is held in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina this year, in a city in which Muslims and Jews alike have lived in unity for almost half a millennium, and in which the monotheistic houses of prayer have literally leant on one another.
Universal values are made of several milestones of human activities accumulated slowly in many layers over time, which, then, through culture and tradition, imbue each other over epochs and lead to one conclusion: it is futile and wrong to look for the meaning of existence in differences and divisions. Instead, it should be pursued in sparkling moments of understanding and unity which have almost always led to spiritual and material wellbeing and creation of great and powerful cultures and civilizations. It is this attitude indeed towards the use and misuse of an increasing power which will define most of the future Muslim-Jewish relations, as well as of the entirety of relations in the world.
Power without true belief, morality and responsibility loses its basic function and turns into violence. All divine revelations, including the Qur'an, the Old and the New Testament, have emphasized the value of a righteous leader. The Almighty God bestowed a unique power upon Sulaiman or Solomon, but warned him that power without responsibility and righteousness is nothing but a worthless violence. The Almighty God bestowed upon Davud or David a victory against a stronger and more powerful opponent in order to convince him that injustice and violence, regardless of their impact, cannot lead to a durable victory. The remains, ruins of once mighty civilizations and cultures are nothing but an advice to contemporary man that any instance of misuse of power leads to an inevitable disaster.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Islam and Judaism testify a belief in one and the only God who does not have a companion. The essence of belief is the same for Muslims and Jews alike.
The most important Jewish festivity Passover celebrates their departure from Egypt, i.e. the salvation from the unjust and Godless ruler. The Muslims count time from the Hijra, i.e. from the day when they departed from the blasphemous and violent community. Therefore, those who seek true friendship between the Jews and Muslims, rightly, ask themselves how comes that the peoples whose core belief is the same, and who have been exposed to so much injustice and violence, cannot find a shared word based on the Word of God, and establish a lasting peace? Fortunately, links between the Muslims and Jews have been more encompassing and stronger than the differences and disputes between them. Such differences and disputes started in the first half of the 20th century, and have reached their climax nowadays. Radicalization of events and resorting to violence as an ultimate solution will not bring about enhancement of the Muslim-Jewish relations worldwide. “All people are equal, as equal as the teeth of a comb”. This Hadith Mohammad Alaihissalam, Messenger of God, points to man’s undeniable responsibility for efforts not made towards achieving equality amongst people, and thus for a lasting peace everywhere and at all times. Peace that we constantly refer to and advocate by greeting each other with Salam and Shalom is a universal value and a shared responsibility of all people.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Bosnia and Herzegovina is, in the European and global terms alike, an example of how Muslims and Jews can live together in unity, while respecting and accepting their mutual differences and using mutual similarities. In the times of increasingly aggressive forms of antisemitism, Islamophobia and other forms of religious and cultural intolerance, the Muslims and Jews in Bosnia and Herzegovina have continued to nurture mutual respect and tolerance. That was how it was in the past, too.
In the course of the appalling persecution the Jews were exposed to in the Second World War, the Muslims saved their Jewish neighbours selflessly. All of us are proud of a considerable number of the Bosnian Muslims honoured as the Righteous among the Nations in the Yad Vashem Museum.
However, it was not only the human lives that were saved then. It was also the culture and heritage of the indigenous Bosnian and Herzegovinian people. On the two occasions, in 1942, and then in 1993, the Bosnian-Muslim intellectuals, both at positions of curators of the National Museum in Sarajevo, i.e. Dr Derviš Korkut and Dr Enver Imamović, preserved the Sarajevan Hagaddah, a valuable cultural evidence brought to Bosnia and Herzegovina by the Jews who had been expelled from Spain. Therefore, it is only natural that during the most recent aggression against our country the Jews, to whom Bosnia and Herzegovina has been the only homeland, were among the resistance leaders. Finally, I can bear witness myself on a deep connection between the Muslim and Jewish communities in Sarajevo, where I have been raised. The man I was named after was killed in the concentration camp together with his Jewish neighbours. Therefore, I have done all I could to support a sparse Jewish community. Certainly, without our Jewish community, Sarajevo and the rest of Bosnia and Herzegovina would lose a part of their identity that others recognize and respect us for.
Esteemed ladies and gentlemen,
I am glad to see that most of one hundred and thirty participants of the Eighth Muslim-Jewish conference are young people. That is why I will end my today's address by delivering a message to them, who are the only true future of our mutual relations.
Talk to each other and look for paths to reach others. Do not abandon dialogue as long as there is a single person willing to listen to you.
Finally, all that is reflected by this world of ours and life in it, including thoughts, efforts, achievements, have strived to reach out to the opposite shore, to the other side to which it aims and where it gains its true meaning.
Remember the words of God set out in the Torah, and repeated in the Qur'an, that “the one who kills one innocent man acted as if he killed all of humanity, and the one who saves one innocent man acted as if he saved all of humanity“. Do defend innocent people and you will save humanity.
I extend my heartfelt welcome to you to Sarajevo and the rest of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I wish you to have a successful conference, whose message is in encouraging mutual dialogue and understanding because that is the true nature of man. With these thoughts in mind, I declare this conference open.

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, BiH Presidency member at the commemoration in Potočari
content:
Dear mothers of Srebrenica, dear people from the Podrinje area, esteemed guests,
Nothing but silence and prayer are appropriate on this very day at this very site.
However, the time we have lived in demands that we speak out – raise our voice and respond to those who have not understood yet, or do not want to understand, a scary message of the genocide committed here.
It is well known what happened here in summer of 1995.
Pursuant to many years when they were conducting the siege, the death squads of the malefactors Radovan Karadžić and Ratko Mladić crashed resistance of the exhausted defenders and executed thousands of previously detained Bosniak men and boys in order to exterminate entirely the existence of one people in this area.
What was it and against whom that those boys and elderly men, who were executed mercilessly, of whom each and single one had defended their families and bare lives, did wrong? The answers to these questions will remain secrets hidden forever in the dark abyss of the malefactors' souls who executed them.
The entire guilt of the 15 year old Damir Suljić and the 72 two year old Alija Salihović was that they were Muslims, Bosniaks, and that both of them were born in Srebrenica. Džemila Mahmutović, in addition to the same guilt as Damir and Alija, was also guilty of being loyal to her brothers and male relatives, with whom she stayed, and refused to leave them behind even when she was faced with death approaching all of them.
We do know that the United Nations remained mute and passive. For days they used to receive precise data on massacres which were in progress, they had satellite images of the mass graves which were constantly growing. However, cowardly, they surrendered the “UN safe area“ to the total slaughter, which would be remembered as the United Nation's unfinest hour and one of the darkest moments in human civilization.
The conscience of the malefactors has never been awakened. They have continued, even now, as well as in the course of the previous 22 years, hiding and negating the crime they committed here.
However, the conscience of the civilized world, after the initial shock it suffered, was activated after all.
Both international and domestic courts have faced the horrors of brutal executions, mass graves, but also the perversion of the ideology which had ordered such crimes to be committed. They called it and judged on it by assigning it the only name possible – genocide.
The gruesome experience of Srebrenica has posed serious challenges and difficult questions before all of us who witnessed it. It sometimes seems to us as if there are no answers to those questions and challenges.
However, there must be answers!
The answers lie in the future filled with life and peace. The path to such future leads through reconciliation.
Reconciliation is needed by all – both ourselves and the future generations.
It is needed in order to ensure that never again any single mother in Bosnia and Herzegovina will have to look for the bones of her children throughout any mass graves.
However, one issue needs to be clear to all – there can be no reconciliation and better future in Bosnia and Herzegovina without justice and truth.
For, truth is the only supporter when one is faced with difficult challenges. We keep facing such challenges each time when the word Srebrenica is uttered. It will not be before we get strengthened by the truth that we will be able to resist such challenges.
The foundations of reconciliation must be built upon justice and truth. No reconciliation is possible if based on lies, denial of the genocide, relativization, provocations such as those we once again, witnessed prior to this anniversary. The reconciliation and better future will not take place until the ideology which created the genocide in Srebrenica is defeated entirely.
Therefore, it is today that from this sacred site we, once again, invite the Serb people and its political, religious and intellectual elites to accept the truth and cease to deny the genocide which was committed here – to, finally, make that step forward to a true reconciliation and a better future for all of us.
The truth requests from the Serb people not to invest their trust into those who offer them any artificial myths, those who lead them into conflicts, those who need that people only as accomplices or silent supporters in crime.
Such people, unfortunately, are still present. They continue to deny the genocide, decorate war criminals, adding salt to the survivors' wounds by doing so. Furthermore, they continue to threaten daily by secession of a part of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is our message to them that they will not succeed in such endeavour. We will never allow that Srebrenica, Tomašica, Brčko, Zvornik and all other sites of horrific crimes against the innocent Bosnian people be anything but Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is requested from the international community to ensure that the horrible lesson of summer 1995 should be learned in order to prevent any future Srebrenicas. While contemplating with anxiety on everything happening in today's world, I fear that such lesson, unfortunately, has not been learned fully.
Srebrenica is the deepest wound for the Bosniaks and they will never forget it. The violence they were exposed to demands that they detest the idea of any violent revenge, and they have detested it indeed. It is difficult to find any peoples in the world against whom such horrific crimes, including genocide, were committed, and who, nevertheless, succeeded in overcoming a drive for revenge thanks to their internal being and their spiritual strength. It is good that our position on revenge has been like that because any revenge would lead us into a vicious circle, from which there would be no way out. Justice and truth must be, and have been indeed, our only revenge.
Therefore, we will never quit our struggle for truth and justice.
Srebrenica was the scene of a horrific tragedy first. Then, it was a stage of speechless grief. It should become a reconciliation site in the future. It depends exclusively from readiness to accept the truth and discard lies whether the citizens of the entire Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Srebrenica, will start living in the prosperous future focused on life and peace, or whether such future will remain our unreachable dream.

title: Speech delivered by Bakir Izetbegović, BiH Presidency member at the opening of the First posthumous retrospective exhibition of Mersad Berber’s paintings, Vijećnica, 6 July 2017
content:
At the start of all our roads there is a clearly marked path at which a man stood up for the first time and started walking. At one such path, and there is an indefinite number of them in Bosnia, each one of us based his vision on wealth, beauty, and on the meaning of the world and life. On all paths one travels later in life, in all remote places scattered all over the world, most of our people draw their inspiration from that very first image conceived on some Bosnian path while they learned their first steps.
Dear members of the Berber family, your excellences, eminences, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen,
At the start of all our roads there is a clearly marked path at which a man stood up for the first time and started walking. At one such path, and there is an indefinite number of them in Bosnia, each one of us based his vision on wealth, beauty, and on the meaning of the world and life. On all paths one travels later in life, in all remote places scattered all over the world, most of our people draw their inspiration from that very first image conceived on some Bosnian path while they learned their first steps.
Ladies and gentlemen,
One of the most important painting exhibitions in the last half a century is now before you. It is an example of a magnificent artistic perception of condensed history and cultural heritage of the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as a testimony on a long and complex path travelled by the renowned artist Mersad Berber.
Only he and his family know how difficult and demanding that path he travelled was. However, one is certain, as it was said nicely by one of the leading thinkers of our times Peter Sloterdijk: “A man becomes man by choosing a more difficult path”.
And how many such paths are scattered throughout Bosnia which Meša Selimović, Mak Dizdar, Ivo Andrić, Aleksa Šantić, Nedžad Ibrišimović, Roman Petrović, Ibrahim Ljubović, Gabrijel Jurkić passed through? How many paths are there which, like the Zmijanje embroidery, wind through Bosnia, lending themselves to our sons and grandsons to learn to walk and stand up?
Dear friends, ladies and gentlemen,
The position of my country has led to permeation of different cultures and civilizations, leading to an unquestionable ethno-cultural intertwining and interdependence of the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
If there is anything certain in Bosnia, if history has taught us anything, then it is that our best people have remained loyal to their country at all times: ”Loyal to God, loyal to Bosnia”, as late noble Friar Petar Anđelović said.
“At moments, when in a foreign country, in which I lived due to bad circumstances and kept myself alive by miracle”, says Bosnian and Herzegovinian Nobel Prize winner Ivo Andrić in his memories, “piously, as a believer spreads his prayer carpet, I spread before me a hard and lofty Višegrad’s path along which I walked out into the world. That very path was the only one which cured all pain and eased all suffering.”
The work of Mersad Berber, like a windy, hard path conceived seventy years ago in Bosanski Petrovac, testifies on exactly that wealth and diversity of our culture, as well as on the climate we live in all its hardship and beauty alike.
Thus, for every person from Bosnia and Herzegovina, from birth to death, there is an obliging rule and motto – that all of us are indebted to our homeland as long as we live. Mersad Berber bestowed a lot to his Bosnia and Herzegovina. He repaid his debt. Actually, by repaying his debt to his homeland Bosnia and Herzegovina, he has never left it.
For, a human life is indeed nothing but a persistent returning to that path a man learned to walk on, and from which, really, that man never steps down.
Your excellences, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends,
It is with great honour that I am the patron of this unique cultural event – the First posthumous retrospective exhibition of Mersad Berber’s paintings – Allegory of Bosnia, which we present, with our hearts full of joy, to all citizens of Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina tonight at this hall of the Bosnian culture and tradition, which we restored and raised from the ashes.
Thank you.

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, BiH Presidency member on the occasion of marking the 25th jubilee of the Special Police Unit “Lasta“
content:
Dear member of the Special Police Unit “Lasta“, dear friends, as-salāmu ʿalaykum, and good afternoon,
It has been twenty five years since the Sarajevan “Laste“ (Swallows) started their warpath. That path was motivated by defending the right to life, to freedom, to equality of all citizens of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
While preparing this address, I remembered an event which I attended and memorized clearly at the time.
In 1994, two years after the Unit “Laste“ was founded, the Armed Forces of RBiH commander-in-chief late Alija Izetbegović handed over the war flag to the unit commander Mr Rusmir Mrković. Even now I hear the sound of Alija's words echoing as if uttered this morning. There was some fatherly care in these words, as well as the warrior's pride, given that there were best sons of our homeland affected by the aggression who were standing before him then.
“Do not forget“, said Alija Izetbegović then, “you can say with pride that at these both difficult and glorious times you were with your people. The people trust you. Do everything in your power to preserve that trust earned in the most difficult of circumstances. Such trust is the highest recognition one can receive indeed. “
Our president, our commander-in-chief Alija Izetbegović was referred to by these famous words of Richard Holbrooke: “If it were not for Alija Izetbegović, Bosnia would not exist today! “. Let me be more precise today and amend this Holbrooke's statement in the following way: “Were it not for the courageous guys like you and the units like “Laste”, who followed the political wisdom and estimates of Alija Izetbegović, were it not for such amalgam of the young and the old age, of wisdom and courageousness, there would not have been Bosnia and Herzegovina! “.
Twenty years later, we live in the times of difficult political and economic reforms which we must implement on our path to the European Union.
It sometimes seems that in such arduous daily political life, in the course of the political efforts which we have invested, the images of the war-related past have faded away, including the great and moving moments like the said meeting of the commander-in-chief and his elite unit. It seems that under the burden of daily responsibilities and pressures we tend to forget how expensive each piece of Bosnia defended by you actually is.
However, let me assure you that we will not get tired, we will not accept to forget. The reason why we cannot do that is each one out of the fifty six members of the “Laste” unit who did not return to their nests, to their families. The opponents of Bosnia and Herzegovina will get tired. We will not do so. That is my message to you today. We do not have the right to get tired, to forget, to become complaisant as being complaisant may lead to relativization of truth on our struggle.
Dear friends,
The “Laste” unit is an image of Bosnia and Herzegovina and of the overall BiH Army, composed of all patriots of this country, regardless of their religious or national affiliation. The names of Saša Petrović, Toni Badrov, Slavko Andžić, Darko Polunić have testified, and will continue to testify, how sincere and spontaneous that gathering was. In the name of those golden guys who, in the decisive moments - when faced with a dividing line between survival and disappearance, laid down their lives for their homeland, we cannot and will not allow the memory of their sacrifice and courageousness to fade away, and that the generations who now grow up think that the benefits of peace and freedom, which they possess and enjoy today, have been achieved or inherited in an easy way.
Therefore, in all our future efforts, we will drive our strength from that memory of the heroes of Bosnia and Herzegovina. They must be woven into each detail, into each step forward which we make. While moving ahead, we must be aware that change and prevalence in historic events are always brought about by small groups of courageous people.
Finally, let me share with you a short definition in order to remind ourselves of the essence of the war path of your unit: this was a unit without any stain on its path, without any doubt cast on it, without any crime committed or non-military behaviour exercised. It is there that the main difference between you and your enemies lie. They wanted one nation and one-mindedness, whereas you opted for democracy and multiethnicity. You opted for a possibility that peoples of different faiths and nations continue to live together. You defended the idea and the very being of Bosnia and Herzegovina. That is your identification card, the identification card of each and every one of you. You can and should be proud of it.
Dear friends, dear stouthearted good guys, I hereby extend my congratulations to you for this valuable jubilee, with my best wishes that in the near future we will make Bosnia and Herzegovina such state and society that you were fighting for!
May you live long and prosper.

title: Address of Bakir Izetbegović, BiH Presidency member delivered at the International Symposium “Middle way in religion, culture and politics – a thought on balance and moderation in the works of Alija I
content:
Esteemed Reisu-l-ulema of the Islamic Community in Bosnia and Herzegovina, esteemed President of the Community of Protestant Churches in Europe Mr Locker, esteemed Working Presidency of this scientific event, esteemed participants, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen!
It is my great honour to be with you at the opening of the International scientific symposium “The middle way in religion, culture and politics - a thought on balance and moderation in the works of Alija Izetbegović“. I hereby express my gratitude to those who initiated and organized the symposium for their noble idea and efforts invested in it. Furthermore, I hereby extend my thanks to all participants who, through their presentations, will contribute to a further scientific research of the works of a thinker and a statesman Alija Izetbegović.
One of the key thoughts in the context of confirmation of both balance and moderation in the works of Alija Izetbegović can be found in his book “Islam between the East and the West“. It refers to face off and reconciliation between the religious and the materialistic concepts, which have been the cornerstones in the ideological perception of the world. “It has always seemed to me“, said Alija Izetbegović, “sometimes more and sometimes less clearly, that the main message of religion is responsibility which cannot be avoided“. The skill to find a middle way in reconciling these two concepts was to become the main feature of Alija Izetbegović as a thinker and a statesman alike. His acknowledgement that doubts of the young age, triggered by the communist teachings on religion as “the opiate of the masses“ actually contributed to the firmness of his personal conviction that “the Universe without God is both impossible and meaningless“ lent itself as an evidence that Alija Izetbegović never distorted such balance of facing off. Re-recognition of faith, questioning, and raising the level of responsibility as the main feature of religion, would not be possible without the omnipresent materialistic counterthesis.
Moreover, in the “Islamic Declaration“, the work which has been attacked and defended with equally passionately by its respective attackers and defenders, the idea which dominates the text refers to the responsibility of Muslims to do something for their own history. However, on the other hand, as confirmed by the contemporary interpretations of this work, the responsibility as the main message of religion has been consistently incorporated in the core of the materialistic and social justice - by means of demanding more rights for Muslim women, protection of the weak, enhancement of the rights of minorities, etc. It is today that we can understand that, regardless of how much this book annoyed the Yugoslav ideological and political elites, it was, to the same extent, not in accordance with the Islamic conservative circles at the time because, through the model of Islamic understanding of responsibility, it opened numerous social justice-focused issues. Peacemaking is not an excuse for cowardness, dedication of the Muslim women to their homes and families does not lead to their passivity or the lack of access to their rights, rejection of one's own culture and tradition in exchange for faddism of the Western civilization does not mean progress by default. It is exactly the contrary indeed. In this regard the examples of Japan and Turkey have remained classic ones in the modern history. Namely, both these countries used to be empires respectively, each with its glorious past, and they used to be at approximately the same level of development and equal opportunities for the future. The reforms took place in both countries respectively then. In order to continue to live its own, and not someone else's life, Japan reconciled its tradition with progress. The Turkish “modernistst“ chose an opposite direction for Turkey. At the time of writing the “Islamic Declaration“ in the seventies of the previous century, Alija Izetbegović noticed that Turkey at the time was a “third-rate country“, whereas Japan grew into one of the world's leading nations.
“Can a country which does not know who it is and where its roots lie have a clear idea on where it is going and on what it should try to achieve“, wondered Alija Izetbegović in his “Islamic Declaration“. He provided an answer, which the comprehensive interpretations of his work, with a good reason, portray as a pattern for understanding of “the other and the different“, and of the way in which such relation need to be managed and should be managed indeed. In the “Islamic Declaration“ there is almost nothing of corresponding to the reason for which Alija Izetbegović was sentenced and imprisoned. However, there are a few definitions defining, almost exactly, a clear curve of development of the modern Turkish state as we know it today. Cultural heritage is a manner in which a nation remembers and lasts throughout history. By rejecting its rich tradition, the Kemalist Turkey rejected its memory of the past.
Spiritual poverty was promptly transferred to the sphere of public works and to lives of most of the people. It looks as if the new generation of Turkish politicians, led by Tayyip Erdoğan, studied closely the pieces of advice provided by Alija Izetbegović. They reconciled the tradition and progress and brought Turkey into the circle of fastest growing world’s economies.
Pursuant to this example, we can plastically point to the essence of both philosophical and political discourse of Alija Izetbegović, which can be discerned more clearly and easily from the following examples: “The core of all human civilization and progress lies in continuation, and not in destruction or negation“. It is there that we can find the answer to all confusion of numerous international and regional officials who expected that the Serb barbarism and destruction of religious, cultural and scientific institutions and edifices in the period of the aggression against BiH would be responded to by the same measure. They were not surprised less by the commitment to multiculturalism demonstrated by Alija Izetbegović, or, more precisely, to his commitment to preserving Bosnianhood as a multicultural concept of life in Bosnia. The Western civilization, as well as domestic radical and conservative circles, listened in disbelief to the Bosnian Muslims' leader focusing his attention, in the midst of the war, to preservation of the Orthodox churches, as well as the Jewish prayer books, while he was claiming that the spirit of Bosnia was preserved most authentically in the language of her Franciscans.
Ladies and gentlemen,
We can flick through hundreds and hundreds of pages of the works of Alija Izetbegović, and yet the lessons which will be found by any objective and well-intended readers will be: responsibility, consistency, unity, gathering, compromise, always at a clear distance from extremism and radicalism. It is as if, while writing his books and managing often difficult, fateful processes, Alija Izetbegović always had on his mind the ayahs from the Qur'an in which the Creator bequeathed moderation as the final stage of human wisdom and achievement. That is the very “middle way in religion, culture and politics, a thought of balance and moderation in the works of Alija Izetbegović“ as defined by the organizers of this scientific event; that is the very “thought-focused key“ of Alija Izetbegović, which has unmistakingly opened doors to all his books, as well as to his achievements.
One cannot demonstrate Islamic belief while carrying out non-Islamic acts, one cannot prepare anything, govern in a non-Islamic way, said Alija Izetbegović in the final part of his “Islamic Declaration“, while pointing his finger to such disharmony, a disbalance between words and deeds in which the whole reality of today's world may sink. Thus, such “middle way“ and “moderation“ exist only in harmony between the two mentioned demands – responsibility and consistency.
While he was imprisoned in Foča and Zenica, Alija Izetbegović was most horrified at the merciless communist censorship, which annulled even most fundamental human rights, including, first of all, the right to truth. Years later, in the besieged Sarajevo during the war, Alija Izetbegović responded to numerous remarks made by his interlocutors that “journalists write whatever they want in the war situation, and this sort of writing should be limited“ by stating that it was in the silence of the Foča prison that he took an oath to himself that he would never be in favour of bans of such kind.
“Even when I was faced with a possibility to spend the rest of my life in prison and die there among the convicts“, said Alija Izetbegović in his book “Memories“, “I reminded myself of the fundamental oath: consistency“. These two demands support and hold in balance, in harmony, what Alija Izetbegović was thinking and doing.
The meaning of the word Islam is translated from the Arabic to our language as: “commitment, peace, reconciliation“ - reconciliation with God, with fate, with people, as well as with everything that surrounds and reaches us. Alija Izetbegović, as a man, as a father, as a thinker, as a statesman, as well as a prisoner, both testified and confirmed such reconciliation wholeheartedly and truly.

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, BiH Presidency member at the International Scientific Symposium “The Bosnian language over time“ in Zagreb
content:
Dear Mayor of Zagreb, esteemed organizers of the International Symposium on the Bosnian language, esteemed participants, guests, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen, Let me extend my sincere greetings to all of you on the occasion of the opening of the Symposium on the Bosnian language, which has gathered a significant number of participants from the whole region.
The issue of language is one of the most important features of each people's identity. Language has always been a symbol and always a re-confirmation of both one people's spiritual being and their ethnic belonging. Language, as a poet put it, is “a real homeland of the specific people“. This definition is very simple and it represents a national model which has been functioning in Europe, with certain variations, since the mid-19th century. Struggling to preserve one's own language has often meant struggling to preserve the whole of a specific culture or, in the opposite, its inevitable assimilation and melting into other national groups. The Hungarians stand for a particular example of such model of preserving one's own identity through radical preservation of purity of their language. They preserved their language to such extent that nowadays there are almost no words of foreign origin in it.
The Bosniaks have remained committed to their language. Namely, from the late 15th century to the early 20th century they created literary works in the Oriental languages, too. Such languages, except at the level of usage of specific words and names, have never reached wide public and have not affected the purity of the mother Bosnian tongue.
Close to three hundred authors from that period left behind their works of various genres, in which, without exception, the language of the residents of Bosnia was called the Bosnian language.
Furthermore, many hundreds of authors from that time added to their name the reference Bosnavi/Bosnali/Bosniak/Bosnian, which underlined their powerful and durable connectedness with the motherland - Bosnia.
In the course of the four centuries of the Ottoman rule, our people never forgot or abandoned their language, and never forgot their homeland.
However, the Bosnian language has never been the language of Bosniaks, Bosnian Muslims only. There have been numerous examples in literary and historical sources of the presence of the Bosnian language in use by other Bosnians.
The key Croat writers in BiH- Matija Divković, Ivan Franjo Jukić, Anto Knežević, and others also called it the Bosnian language respectively.
Friar Pavle Dragičević, the Bishop of Duvno wrote in 1735 that there were nine priests in Bosnia who used “the Bosnian language“ to assist them in performing the religious ceremonies because they did not understand the Church Slavonic language well enough.
The Herzegovinian Orthodox leaders, including Prokopije Čokorilo, asked Ali-Pasha Rizvanbegović to appoint such Bishop who should be a man “adept in the Bosnian language“ It was back in 1881 that the Bosnian Bishop Vujičić called this language Bosnian.
In 1894 the Franciscans sent official letters replying to their opponents that they did not speak Serbian language, and that they spoke Bosnian instead.
It was not sooner than in 1907 that the Bosnian language was withdrawn temporarily from the official use in Bosnia and Herzegovina. This was done by the Austro-Hungarian Government for BiH in 1907. However, the Bosnian language has not been withdrawn for a single moment from the life of the people in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Why was the Bosnian language so widespread and accepted among the people? This was because it was based on the old heritage language, i.e. on the language we found as the primary source on the mediaeval Bosnian tombstones (stećak).
Dear ladies and gentlemen,
Language, as defined by the European national movements in the mid-19th century, defines national borders. Therefore, accepting the existence of the Bosnian language is the ultimate obstacle to some greater states-focused ambitions at the expense of BiH, of her cultural and territorial integrity. This is a stigma which has followed the Bosniaks throughout the 20th century, in the period of compromiseless and destructive unitarism carried out by the Karađorđević' dynasty, as well as in the period of the Yugoslav communist utopia, whose pattern of equality and equal access to rights, in its essence, maintained the Euro-centric national distinctiveness model. Initially, in the course of the Anti Fascist Council of the People's Liberation of Yugoslavia (AVNOJ) session in Jajce, the Bosniaks had been recognized as the distinctive people, as the sixth flame in the coat of arms symbolizing the respective peoples within the new state community of South Slavs. However, it was then by the Constitution of 1945 that they first lost their constitutiveness again, and then they lost the right to their language
The so-called 1954 “Novi Sad“ agreement on a shared language only reaffirmed the imposed constitutional changes.
The working group, in which three BiH representatives participated, including the Nobel Prize winner Ivo Andrić, concluded that the Serbs, Croats and Montenegrins were using the Serbo-Croatian language.
The Bosniaks, given that they lost their constitutiveness by the Constitution of 1945, were not even registered within the new Yugoslav language reality.
