Fortunately, the Bosniak intellectuals, including Alija Isaković with his demonstrated uniqueness and persistence for example, have never accepted such imposed reality.
By the 1990 democratic changes, followed by the 1992-1995 defence and liberation war, in which independence of the state of BiH was renewed, the Bosniaks restored both their constitutiveness and the right to their Bosnian language, as one of the three languages in the official use now. The fact that almost 53% of the overall population in BiH speaks Bosnian today is encouraging indeed.
Dear ladies and gentlemen,
The international symposium on the Bosnian language in Zagreb is one in a series of attempts undertaken over many decades by the Bosniak associations and institutions, aimed at finally affirming the Bosnian language officially, too, or, to put it more precisely, to ensure its systemic and organized teaching and learning in the Republic of Croatia.
Therefore, this symposium should contribute to a faster implementation of the Bosnian language in the curricula in the Republic of Croatia.
It is unacceptable that the Bosniaks, who are the second largest national minority in Croatia, do not have their mother tongue available in primary and secondary schools by any model, with the exception of the Islamic Secondary School “Dr Ahmed Smajlović“. It is obvious that assistance from the competent institutions has been insufficient to a necessary extent which would ensure the implementation of such objective. A lack of bilateral agreement between the two countries on the protection of rights of the Bosniak minority has certainly contributed to such situation. Such bilateral agreements have been signed with the neighbouring countries for their minorities in the Republic of Croatia. These issues can be resolved in a relatively short period. In my own capacity, I will aim to address these issues in my further discussions with the Croatian colleagues. What has been encouraging to a certain extent is that Zagreb and the Republic of Croatia are open for a discussion on the Bosnian language, as demonstrated by this symposium under the auspices of the Mayor of the City of Zagreb, and with the participation of the important persons from the Croatian academic community.
Finally, it is also a moral responsibility of the Republic of Croatia to make necessary steps to ensure that the Bosnian language becomes adequately represented in the official curricula. Let us not forget that the Bosniaks contributed to the defence and creation of the modern Croatian state with over 25,000 Bosniak defenders; 1,187 Bosniaks who got killed, as well as several thousands Bosniaks who got severely wounded in the process. All this constitutes our shared commitment and connectedness.
Dear ladies and gentlemen,
Let me extend my congratulations to the organizers of the International symposium on the Bosnian language for their courageousness, and for their persistence to address this difficult issue in the struggle for a full affirmation of the Bosnian language in the Republic of Croatia. To the participants and patrons of this event I owe my sincere gratitude for recognizing and supporting such idea.
It is my sincere wish that this symposium
I wish this symposium to meet the expectations concerned, as well as its set objectives. Let me extend my sincere greetings to all of you, and wish you all best.
Thank you.

title: Media statements by Dr Mladen Ivanić, Chairman of BiH Presidency and Filip Vujanović, President of Montenegro
content:
Generally speaking, a message for the region and the international community is that there are two states in this area – i.e. Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which have affirmed good neighbourly relations and regional cooperation as an example, and we invite all those who see this example as a good one to follow it fully, while we will continue, in the spirit of good neighbourly relations and regional cooperation, to maintain a full closeness and effectiveness of such cooperation.
Dr Mladen Ivanić, Chairman of BiH Presidency:
It is my pleasure to extend our welcome to Filip Vujanović, President of Montenegro. Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro have had best relations possible. I believe that ours are best bilateral relations within the region as, practically, we do not have a single open issue between us. We were the first ones who signed the Border Agreement without any particular problems, thus putting an end to the issue which has always been sensitive in this area. We have shared views on many issues both within and beyond the region. Discussions on the issue of the agreement on social insurance have been close to their final phase. Most of benefits covered by this agreement should be enjoyed by the citizens of both countries concerned. I hope that we will finalize it relatively shortly. There is a very high level indeed of mutual understanding and mutual support. We are very glad that Montenegro has made some significant steps forward, that it has started a serious economic development, and that it has been getting closer to the European Union. I believe that, in a way, it is one of the serious motors in the region, which drives it in the EU direction. We have discussed today a need to engage ourselves a bit more in some infrastructure projects, which are not only our shared topic, but the topic of other countries in the region, too. Such discussion includes the Adriatic-Ionian Motorway. Furthermore, there is a discussion on the pipeline which should start from Azerbaijan, and one of its branches would be installed through these areas. Better connectedness of the countries in terms of infrastructure is another shared topic we discussed. In particular, following a suggestion of Mr Vujanović, we will think very seriously on an option to have the border crossings between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro with practically one border control point per crossing only, i.e. to have one joint instead of two border control points per crossing, thus demonstrating to people who travel how good our relations are. I have to underline that this is the idea of President Vujanović, but I believe that we will do something on that issue, too. Therefore, this is a very pleasant visit. It is our pleasure to host President Vujanović in Sarajevo. We had a very pleasant discussion and a high level of shared views on practically all issues discussed.
Filip Vujanović, President of Montenegro:
Esteemed Chairman Ivanić, dear Mladen, let me extend my thanks once again for the invitation, a cordial welcome and, as always, an open, constructive, and very friendly discussion. Namely, we have indeed, as you said, affirmed the position of Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina as a good example in the region, i.e. as a good example in terms of both our good neighbourly relations and good regional cooperation. We have succeeded in resolving all issues. There is no single open issue between us, whereas there is a wide room still open for our further cooperation. It is our shared responsibility from the presidential level to encourage it – to make it comprehensive at the level of the two governments concerned, and, at the level of entrepreneurs, to make it economically effective. We concluded the State Border Agreement, which is the first agreement of this kind between any two countries of former Yugoslavia, thus showing that a sensitive issue could be resolved by an agreement between the two countries, without any external agency. Furthermore, we concluded a series of necessary agreements on cooperation in all fields, together with the latest agreement on cooperation in the field of European integration, in which we agreed that we would do everything together in order to enhance the progress along the path towards the European integration of both our countries respectively. We have made progress on this issue. However, we are ready to do everything we can to enhance further the progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We extend our congratulations to the Presidency and the Government for truly impressive progress achieved on the European integration process. We also express our expectations to you because we have communicated a message to the European Union to grant Bosnia and Herzegovina a candidate status by the end of this year or the beginning of the next year. We have achieved success through the implementation of the specific shared cooperation. However, there is a lot of room for our extended cooperation. At the bilateral level and in the spirit of good neighbourly relations alike, we must do everything we can to ensure that such cooperation is of highest possible quality. Within the regional organization of initiatives, we have really had a full and excellent cooperation. For example, within the Presidential initiative Brdo Brioni, which in many aspects initiated a renewed attitude of the European Union towards the Western Balkans region, such excellent cooperation was obvious. Furthermore, within the Belgium process, in which governments have exercised a high quality cooperation, but also within CEFTA, we have worked together to enhance mobility of goods and people and improve economic environment to enable further cooperation. Chairman Ivanić mentioned the specific projects we discussed. I believe that we must make use of that activity within the Belgium process, which provides an opportunity to implement regional projects in a high quality way, with the participation of the European Union member states, in the fields of road infrastructure and energy infrastructure. We have also discussed possibilities to enhance and encourage together the Adriatic-Ionian pipeline because that project does not have any problem of funding. In that sense, we have discussed a need for the two governments to cooperate more frequently and closely in order to achieve an even better quality of cooperation. We recently hosted a visit paid by Mr Denis Zvizdić, Chairman of the Council of Ministers, and had very concrete discussions. I will have a meeting with him later today. I am grateful to the Chairman for making this initiative public – our interest in border crossings with one border control post per crossing only. This model is very efficient. We have one such border crossing post with Albania. The effect of control of illegal trade is best there, whereas the satisfaction of those crossing the border is full because they face smallest of obstacles. Therefore, generally speaking, a message for the region and for the international community is that there are two countries in this area – i.e. Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which have affirmed their good neighbourly relations and the regional cooperation as an example. We invite all those who see this example as a good one to follow it closely. We will continue, in the spirit of good neighbourly relations and regional cooperation, to nurture full closeness and efficiency of such cooperation.

title: Speech delivered by Dr Dragan Čović, the Croat member of BiH Presidency to mark the occasion of the 1st of March, the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Your Excellences, Eminences, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen! It is my pleasure to address you today on this day which invites all of us to renew an intra-societal dialogue and commit more strongly to the idea of our homeland as a community of its constitutive peoples and all others who do not declare themselves like that, the community of equals who have the same rights.
All those fears that we experienced 25 years ago on the eve of the referendum itself, all the doubts and discussions on the wording of the referendum question, even back then exposed all the weaknesses of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which, as we witness, are still following us today: political immaturity, mutual distrust, rejection of constructive dialogue as the only path to achieving inclusive vision of Bosnia and Herzegovina, suited for all of us who perceive it as their homeland.
We all have to find the strength to look at events from the past in a way that does not burden our relations today, in a way that does not undermine the ability of thinking about common future. We need to have a much more courage, self-criticism and the strength to admit our own mistakes. Bosnia and Herzegovina is not an abstract idea. It is made out of social fabric, the groups that are living here for centuries; three traditional communities - the three constituent peoples and all others who care to nurture their language, culture, identity and uniqueness.
To glorify and celebrate BiH means to glorify and celebrate its people, their communities, but also everything else that defines them. The interest of any nation in BiH is not above the interests of BiH, as the sum of the interests of all its peoples. Our country is hostage today to issues of whose BiH is it, which parts of it belong more to whom, who is more equal, more thorough, more qualified, more important, better. I am deeply convinced, and I can assure you that we all want it equally, but not in any state.
We would BiH that is just, in which each nation has secured an institutional position and subjectivity, to elect their political representatives, manages its identity and all that is important for its maintenance in the areas of culture, information, public, education, economy, entrepreneurship and standards.
Tonight, as we celebrate independence of our Bosnia and Herzegovina, I invite partners in government to make a step towards the amendments of the electoral law. Croatian political representatives, gathered by the Croatian National Congress, have offered acceptable solutions that address the merits of the decisions of national and international judicial institutions, in the spirit of everything that what we had in mind when we went out in the 1992 on the referendum polls, to support the vision of an independent and sovereign Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a state of equal peoples, established to suit us all.
On this occasion, I also invite all those who shape public opinion to responsibly understand their role in building a healthier social and political environment. We have to be even stronger in strengthening of everything that binds us, in settling our relationships, removing tensions. I responsibly claim, there is no need for anyone to feel uncertainty and redundancy in this beautiful country, to say its name with apprehension and anxiety, to express their religious or national affiliation.
If in these times, full of trials, we succeed to maintain a common dialogue in the wake of a general consensus on the European future of BiH and its pluralistic multi-national and multi-cultural character, we will come to the stage of viability, which will include the ability to run this country and decide on all issues without outside help or coercion. Let us not seek role models and protectors beyond the country, but let us turn to each other. Let us use our freedom in the interest of unity and equality. Let us be responsible and respect the institutions whose credibility we are painstakingly building for years.
Dear friends,
to all of you gathered here tonight, and to all the residents of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I congratulate you Independence Day of our homeland, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I wish you all the best and cheers.

title: Address by Dr Mladen Ivanić, Chairman of BiH Presidency on the occasion of the opening of “The BiH Economic Forum 2017“ organized by the Faculty of Economics in Sarajevo
content:
Esteemed participants, let me, first of all, extend my congratulations to you on the idea to organize this kind of forum. This is a great opportunity for the executive authorities, academic public, people from the economic field, who create business environment and work in it, to share views on an adequate business-friendly environment which should be established.
BiH needs to dedicate more time and attention to the field of economics, which is a precondition for development. If we continue to focus on politics only, without turning towards economics, we will continue to be confined to the current position. Instead, we need to make giant steps forward in order to create an environment worth investing in.
BiH must change her political and economic image. There are issues which are not bad, but there has not been much discussion on these.
Regardless of criticism, we have a stable currency. It is important that it remains stable, that no experiments are made with the Central Bank of BiH, with money printing or anything similar. If this would be done, the ultimate consequence would be both inflation growth and currency instability in BiH.
The essence of economic reforms should be to reduce importance of the public sector. The share of beaurocracy and administration in GDP is too high, while there is not enough investment, particularly from the real sector.
Creating a favourable environment should be a priority. Tax rates should be reduced, while the monetary system stability should be maintained, and such conditions created that would ensure repayment of investments in a faster and easier way.
I do not refer to foreign investment only, but to domestic one, too. There will be no foreign investment as long as domestic investment does not raise profit.
The environment should be improved because the unemployment rate is still high. In the course of the previous year, there was one embassy which issued more than 15,000 working visas alone. There was no job for these recipients of the working visas so that they were forced to look for it outside BiH.
If we do not change something, such situation will become our durable prospect. We have avoided the reform of both pension and health care systems, and it is these reforms that are essential for improvement of the situation.
We have turned towards the economic reforms thanks to the British-German initiative. However, but we have lacked our own initiatives. That is why this forum is good, where the speakers are local people, with no external intermediaries. I am looking forward to hearing optimistic messages.
I declare the Forum open.

title: 1995 Genocide against the Bosniaks“ Project launch, Sarajevo, 12 January 2017
content:
It was the idea of late Alija Izetbegović that a book which would contain a comprehensive registry of crimes committed against the Bosniaks in the previous war should be made. In the late 1996 he presented this idea to Amor Mašović, suggesting he led a team of the book co-authors. However, Amor Mašović judged that it was still too early, that an important part of evidence material and documentation were not available yet at the time. Twenty years later, in the autumn of 2016, I discussed this issue again with Amor Mašović, and with the representatives of the Institute for Research of Crimes against Humanity and International Law. This time the idea was accepted.
Esteemed defenders of Bosnia and Herzegovina, esteemed Grand Mufti Kavazović, esteemed representatives of the churches and religious communities in BiH, esteemed Parliament members, prime ministers, heads of municipalities, mayors, ladies and gentlemen,
Esselamu Aleykum and good evening to you.
Thank you for attending this event. It is not easy to face again the images of horror which devastated our people in the course of the latest aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina. I extend my particular gratitude to the heroes present here, as well as to the families of the heroes who are not with us tonight. They risked and lost their lives while defending their innocent and unarmed people's right to life and survival. Without them, evil would have won. Without them then, there would not have been us, and there would not have been any Bosnia and Herzegovina now. The genocide would have been completed. Our people would have been extinguished.
The idea on a book which would contain a comprehensive registry of crimes committed against the Bosniaks in the course of the most recent war originates from late Alija Izetbegović. In the late 1996 he presented this idea to Amor Mašović, suggesting to him to lead a team of co-authors who would make such book. However, Mašović judged that it was too early, that an important part of evidence material and documentation were not available yet. Twenty years later, in the autumn of 2016, I discussed this issue again with Amor Mašović, and with the representatives of the Institute for Research of Crimes against Humanity and International Law. The idea was accepted this time.
The aim of the project is to establish a database which, in one place, down to the last detail, in a comprehensive and professional way, will register each crime, each victim, each perpetrator, all judgements, all testimonies and memories. The outcomes of this project are to create a truth-driven dark and bloody mosaic of genocide committed in order to extinguish one indigenous people from the territory they inhabited since the beginning of time; to preserve it from oblivion, manipulation and forgeries; to keep memory of victims alive, their faces, their life stories; to create a multimedia audio and visual presentation which will be easily accessible and available to all, and which will serve as remembrance and warning to both present and future generations.
Numbers are important indeed. They speak volumes. However, numbers alone are insufficient because people are not numbers. Each man is a specific world for himself, and it is with death of each man that the entire human species die anew.
The number of Srebrenica's 8,372 persons who were shot dead, would obtain its actual dimension and meaning after we see again the scenes of execution of the boys from Srebrenica committed by the “Scorpions“ unit, and when we try to imagine that all 8372 men and boys, each single one of them indeed, who used to be detained prior to being executed, had the same destiny and lived through the same suffering.
I was forced to listen and think about war crimes since my early childhood. Both my uncles - my mother's brothers - were killed at the Jasenovac Concentration Camp. My mother never stopped remembering them. As a middle-aged man, I was faced again with the horror of crimes committed against civilians, with the instances of ethnic cleansing and the genocide. I had to keep following a series of appalling news containing horrific details. I have tried to figure out what were the reasons behind these crimes. I have never succeeded in finding an answer to the question how is it possible for people to engage themselves en masse in torturing and killing innocent civilians, women and children.
A part of that reply was contained in the closing arguments made by prosecutor Alan Tieger in the trial against Ratko Mladić. The second part of the reply has been contained in the dark abyss of the perpetrators' souls. Prosecutor Tieger set out unemotional yet rational reasons for the genocide committed against the Bosniaks of Prijedor. He said that “... the genocide was a part of the wider objective, an organized effort aimed at reshaping the demographic structure of Bosnia... while it was clear that an ethnic division of ethnically mixed Bosnian population was not going to happen miraculously, but that severe crimes would need to be committed in order to achieve it... the genocide became the means aimed at achieving a permanent removal of non-Serbs from the targeted territories... this aim demanded from the military forces to create a new situation on the ground, which both the Muslims and the international community would be forced to accept... for, when in a place like Prijedor, in a short period, 1,500 people gets killed, thousands get starved, humiliated, tortured in appalling detention facilities, where they either died slowly or were brutally executed, when their homes were destroyed, mosques devastated, and when they got scattered penniless in the misery of exile... The real word describing these crimes, committed with such intention, is the word genocide...“.
Tieger emphasized in particular the murdering of reputable individuals, leaders in their communities, and the crime of mass rape as a method of shattering self-confidence of the attacked people, aimed at provoking a wave of ethnic cleansing. I quote: “... A group is not only a physical or a biological entity; its existence is based on the links established between its members, as well as on the factors of harmony which enable it to exist as a group... sexual violence has a destructive impact not only on direct victims, but also on their families, communities, and the groups as a whole... Such wider destructive impact is not the issue of physical destruction of some members of the group only, the aim is achieving destruction and dysfunctionality of family and social ties by means of sexual violence...“.
It is difficult to nurture painstakingly a collective memory of horrifying evil which devastated the Bosniaks in the recent past. However, we will have to remember it because those who forget risk that evil will be inflicted upon them again. We can forgive. However, we will never forget. Furthermore, we will never again be weak because it is weakness that invites those who are ruthless.
We need to and we will commit ourselves to working patiently on reconciliation. We will never by any means strive for revenge. Only the perpetrators need to be held to account, and they are the ones who must be punished.
Bosniaks and Serbs, in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as those in Serbia, have lived together for centuries, and will continue to live together in the forthcoming centuries. Such shared living must not be poisoned by hatred and retaliation. However, it must be based on truth, on accepting the truth – no matter how bitter and hard the truth may be. Such shared living and peace will be stable and durable only if it gets built upon the solid foundations of truth and justice.
That was my recent answer to a diplomat of one friendly country, who expressed his concern that the event taking place this evening could be perceived as a provocation against the Serb side. I told him that the truth can never be a provocation against anyone.
Therefore, I will finish this address by quoting the words of God's Last Messenger, which talk about the Truth – “Truth brings about salvation, even when it seems that there is disaster in it; while lie brings about disaster, even when it seems that there is salvation in it“.
Thank you!

title: Address by Dr Mladen Ivanić, Chairman of BiH Presidency at the Third Convention of the Coalition of the Marginalized Groups in Bosnia and Herzegovina - “KOMA“
content:
Good afternoon to all and thanks to the organizers for inviting me. I believe that it is a giant step that you have made by establishing this coalition of the marginalized groups because there is not much which can be achieved by disunity. When united, you can and will achieve much more. I think that your presence will certainly make an impact not only on politics, but on media, too, and, let me add, on the society as a whole, too. You will affect us to pay more attention to this segment of our society, which we have not dealt with often enough.
As a politician, I have tried to find a way to communicate with you. Many of you I have seen here whom I used to meet with at the time when I was still the President of the Government, as well as subsequently. Once when one feels the problems these persons are facing, when one really feels it, then, no matter how thick-skinned that one is, he will not be able to forget such problems. It is sufficient to have one conversation conducted by a serious politician with these persons to ensure that the gravity of the problem gets understood by that politician.
The name marginalized groups is not a good one. That very name proves that it was not created in accordance with the will of the persons who belong to these groups. It was, instead, created in accordance with the will of the majority in the society. It was the majority, and not the group members themselves, who marginalized these groups. Such marginalization was partly based on taboos, partly on prejudices, and partly on many other reasons. Within each such group there are individuals, persons, their lives, happiness, suffering, sorrow, pain, problems and struggles they struggle with. Attention must be paid and importance attached to these persons continuously.
I sincerely believe that this is not a problem that politics can solve on its own. It is a problem of the society as a whole. The society does not pay enough attention to these persons. Here follow two examples illustrating this. First, last year, I presented some small technical device to the Association of the Blind in Banja Luka. No media representatives attended the event. Second, as the Chairperson in the new mandate, I received the representatives of the World Congress of the Persons with Deafness and Hearing Impairments. No one attended the event either, although all were invited. I used to try in the past to attach more importance to these issues. However, I have had an impression that the society is not ready yet to do this in a way which is sufficiently good, and sufficiently comprehensive, that we need much education indeed, as well as basic human culture to approach these issues. We need to ensure that we do not run away from these persons, hide, or ignore that the specific problem exists.
It is not important to ensure funding only, although funding is important indeed to improve the position of these persons. However, I believe that it is much more important to treat the persons who belong to the marginalized groups as normal members of the society, as individuals who have their respective roles in the society, as opposed to perceiving them as a burden.
When we know that the general framework is as I described it, and I believe that, objectively speaking, it is like that indeed, then your organization, approach, accompanied by the media and public civil pressure exercised against the dominant majority in the society may make necessary impact in order to bring about change of approach.
I hereby fully support you to undertake such endeavour. At any time when you believe that it is appropriate and adequate, I will really do as much as I can in order to contribute to achieving the necessary change.
It is most important to demonstrate willingness. It is necessary to make pressure because, without it, many will not make any change upon their own initiative. I really encourage you hereby to exercise such pressure because it is your right to do so. It is the only possible way in which you can draw attention to yourselves, to your existence. That is how you will affect these persons, who spend their days, hours, weeks, months discussing the issues that ultimately remain unresolved, spend not even one tenth, but at least one thirtieth part of their time to try to understand and start solving problems of the persons who fall into the category of marginalized groups in BiH.
There is no one else to do this but you. Of course, we can and must help. That is our responsibility. But, creating a general environment, exercising some public pressure, opening issues, breaking taboos, removing prejudices - that must, dominantly, come from your own surroundings.
Therefore, once again, I extend my thanks to the organizers and to all of you for making this happen. I am certain that the Coalition, will keep gaining more and more significance over time, that, if it will prevail by remaining persistent, and accumulate a serious power necessary to change things in the right way - both in politics, but also in creating an adequate general social environment. Politics cannot do this on its own. The society can do it, the media can do it, too, and the intellectual circles can do it indeed. All these together can create such surroundings which will enable an individual, who belongs to the group, to be as happy as possible, live as normally as possible, and not to be treated as a problem but as an integral part of the society.
Thank you for your attention!

title: Address by the Croat Member of BiH Presidency on the occasion of 2016 Christmas reception
content:
My joy tonight would be complete if we could know that all of our countrymen, and all the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, can celebrate the upcoming holidays in the warmth of their homes, relieved of temptations and uncertainties of life.
Distinguished ladies and gentlemen,
Your Excellences,
Your Eminence,
Dear friends,
please allow me to welcome you this evening, as the host, on behalf of the great family of the representatives of the executive, legislative and political authorities of the Croat people of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I want to share with you a sense of joy, happiness and togetherness, as we have traditionally gathered during this time leading to Christmas.
Christmas enriches us, gives us strength, brings joy to our lives and restores faith in a better and brighter tomorrow.
Christmas fills our hearts with the blessings of love and peace, and inexhaustible desire to build a society of prosperity and love among people.
My joy tonight would be complete if we could know that all of our countrymen, and all the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, can celebrate the upcoming holidays in the warmth of their homes, relieved of temptations and uncertainties of life.
Let us, please, send our thoughts from the comfort of this Christmas gathering of ours, for at least a moment, to those exposed to the horrors of war throughout the world.
Let us also hope that the good Lord will send through our positive thoughts encouragement to all those who make decisions and can stop conflicts, to stop the suffering of innocent people, especially children.
Perhaps none of us gathered here can make global decisions or significantly influence those, but each of us can give at least a small contribution towards the prosperity of our homeland, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Dear God gave us this beautiful country to nurture as our inheritance, and it is up to us to run it in a way that will make it a pride of all three of its constituent peoples and each of its inhabitants.
During the last year’s Christmas celebration we clearly indicated the need to accelerate the Euro-Atlantic processes.
Despite the multitude of disbeliefs, today we can proudly say that we are successfully implementing these processes. That has not been an easy job. But it is possible.
I would like to thank all of you who believed in us, who helped us submit, despite the doubts of many, a credible application for the EU membership. That was recognized ten days ago when Commissioner Hahn handed us the Questionnaire for Bosnia and Herzegovina, marking yet another significant step forward made by this country. We certainly will not stop there.
In the year ahead, and on this path, we can not be stopped by any doubts about the functioning of the EU and the issues recognized regarding the concept of its expansion.
We all have a lot of work to do. We have to agree on the legislative infrastructure, to implement the decision of the Strasbourg Court and the ruling of the Constitutional Court.
Ultimately, at the beginning of next year, all that should be built into the electoral law regarding the election of the members of the Presidency, selection and the manner of decision-making at the House of Peoples, as well as the functioning of the City of Mostar.
The sense of constitutional and institutional equality must be complete and it should be the foundation of the modern and European Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Following the submission of the answers to the already received questionnaire, I am sure that by the end of 2017 we will get the status of an EU candidate country and activate the NATO membership action plan.
I believe that we have the political wisdom to recognize the need to seek strategic partnerships with our neighbors to the east and west.
In the New Year, at the internal level, our primary task should be the strengthening of the economic stability of the whole country and each of its parts, as well as the need for increased social sensitivity in all structures of society.
In order to succeed in all of this, dear friends, we should strongly focus on our collectiveness.
Let us be inspired by this festive time, let us find the strength and motivation to look forward together, while building peace and love among all people.
Be illuminated by the light of the birth of Jesus Christ and let it enlighten you with the truth and warmth to share with your loved ones.

title: Address by Dr Dragan Čović, the Croat member of BiH Presidency at the reception marking the occasion of the Statehood Day of BiH, Sarajevo, 24 November 2016
content:
Dear ladies and gentlemen, dear guests, dear friends! With cordial, friendly greetings, let me extend my welcome to you to the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We gathered today in order to show our adherence to our homeland Bosnia and Herzegovina, and remember the values woven into the foundations of her statehood – a historic commitment and decision made by all peoples of BiH that their country should be a state union of equal peoples and citizens. Such commitment was shown in a special way 73 years ago, when it was firmly built into our constitutional tradition. Then, in an identical way, it was transfused into the referendum question of March 1992, and included into the Dayton Constitution of BiH subsequently.
The statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina has been inseparably connected to her multinational character and plurality of her society. That is the true spirit of our country, the spirit which has permeated her throughout history and entrusted her, in entirely equal way, to all her peoples - the Serbs, the Croats and the Bosniaks respectively. Diverging from that vision, misunderstanding it and dreaming on establishment of a monolith society either in the whole territory of BiH or in just one of her parts, has been the greatest threat to her statehood, the statehood which we are solemnly marking today in a special way.
Despite of such tendencies, one should not have a slightest doubt that the constitutiveness and equality of peoples and equality of all citizens will remain the main determinant and direction after all future changes of the Constitution of BiH are completed. Such changes will have to harmonize, continue to affirm and implement the equality and equal rights for all. Sooner or later, the constitutiveness has to reach each citizen of ours because to be constitutive means to be satisfied, have equal rights, be equal and feel this country truly as one's own. This is a precondition of dignity for each person in BiH, both as an individual and as a member of any of her peoples. Finally, this is our constitutional and patriotic obligation, too. Due to all this, any hesitation in view of our fundamental constitutional values is, at the same time, the hesitation in view of Bah.
Those values which connect us, expressed nowadays in the form of principles of constitutiveness and equality, oblige us to keep contemplating on a far better and fairer Bosnia and Herzegovina than she is today, on a country in which all her peoples will have equal rights in institutional and political, social, religious, language, media, economic and any other sense. Therefore it is of extreme importance in these challenging times of ours to rely on the fundamental principles that are the foundation of statehood, as well as a kind of signpost marking a democratic construction of BiH. I am deeply convinced that it is within such frameworks that we have to look for inspiration for a vision of our homeland organized to suit all three peoples, as well as all those who are outside that identification framework.
Do all of us firmly believe in it at the moment? Honestly, I am not sure. It is certain that BiH is at a junction. It is no secret that today there are many who have doubted the European project. Such doubts and scepticism can only be conquered by a belief in the European future and a dedicated work aimed at achieving it. The reason for a true concern is that there are political calculations and insufficient honesty of many who are called to declare themselves on this destiny-shaping project. I fear and feel that not all of us are fully committed in our minds and hearts to fighting for and winning the European future of BiH. A doze of internal resistance is palpable, and that is a particular challenge facing all of us. Indeed, the only way to fight against it is through togetherness, which can only be achieved by building mutual trust, based on credible political actions. Due to all this, we have to find a way to unite ourselves around the shared constitutional values and organizational principles, and carry out a dedicated work in order to affirm them at all levels and within all structures.
It is entirely clear that many issues have not been resolved fully and consistently in our homeland, certainly not in a way that would ensure that all can feel equally good here. I believe that it should not be too demanding to regulate by law marking of the state and religious holidays. I believe that it is not a problem to regulate the election law to suit the needs of all peoples of BiH in order to introduce more symmetry, and more equal rights for all through that symmetry.
The EU accession process, which we have initiated, is an opportunity we have to make use of in order to achieve internal harmonization and meet our objectives. It is by regulating constitutional and legal frameworks that we eliminate disputed issues and enhance a democratic environment. At the same time, we have to fully commit ourselves to building a society of economic, social, political stability and comfortable standard of living. Attitudes to all these issues, derived from the imperative of constitutiveness, will show very shortly where each of us stands individually in relation to the values which have gathered us today, and to which extent we really are honest in everything we pledge for.
I extend my invitation to you hereafter that we build together, through a different, more responsible approach to mutual dialogue and understanding, a more positive environment in our Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I wish you all best. Cheers!

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, Chairman of BiH Presidency to the European Parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs
content:
This morning I would like to talk about these three issues: 1) the vision of Bosnia and Herzegovina's future within the European Union; 2) the steps we have made in order to turn this vision into reality, and, when I say “we“, I refer to the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina together; 3) the threats and challenges we have been faced with, and how we can oppose them together.
Esteemed members of the European Parliament,
Mr Brok,
It is always my pleasure to be in Brussels – particularly in the European Parliament, where there are so many friends of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I extend my thanks to all of you for this opportunity to share views with you.
This morning I would like to talk about the following three issues:
1) The vision of Bosnia and Herzegovina's future within the European Union;
2) The steps we have made in order to turn this vision into reality, and, when I say “we“, I refer to the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina together;
3) The threats and challenges we have been faced with, and how we can oppose them together.
For a moment, let me bring you back to 6 February 2014, when the European Parliament in Strasbourg adopted its annual Resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina. You set out in that Resolution your deep concern due to „a lack of shared vision on the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina expressed by the political leaders“.
A day later, on 7 February 2014, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina gathered in the streets to protest against the hardship social and economic situation and request from us, their elected leaders, to offer a vision of the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as to make concrete steps needed to turn that vision into reality.
Ten days later, Mr Štefan Füle, EU Enlargement Commissioner at the time, arrived to Sarajevo with a conclusion that there would be no agreement achieved by the political leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina on the implementation of the European Court for Human Rights' judgement concerning the case of Sejdić and Finci versus BiH. This did not happen because we had not been trying sufficiently. Namely, in the course of almost thirty months, we held more than 150 meetings, at which we discussed over 50 various suggestions. We did not manage to reach an agreement because some of the participants of these negotiations were expressing a mix of populism and alienation from the actual needs of our citizens. Therefore, it came as no surprise that Mr Füle stated, pursuant to our last meeting, that the political leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina “had to act more responsibly to address the citizens' needs“ – ensure more new jobs, more justice and better life standard.
In the weeks and months that followed the protests held in February, we held numerous meetings with various representatives of the academic community, civil society and businesspersons throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina. When friends from the EU capitals or Brussels visited us in Sarajevo and asked how they could help and what kind of assistance they could provide us with in order to ensure that we start moving forward, we told them what we understood through those meetings and encounters – that it was in the interest of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all her citizens that we should focus on the two issues: social and economic reforms and convergence in the European Union.
The idea was simple: that we dedicate ourselves to the actual needs of our citizens through the implementation of difficult social and economic reforms, while hoping that, pursuant to progress that we would achieve due to such reforms, it would also be easier to achieve agreements on the issues such as the implementation of the Sejdić – Finci judgement. Our friends from Croatia, Slovenia and other EU countries helped us present this argument throughout the EU. In November 2014 Germany and Great Britain officially proposed to other EU members the so-called “renewed EU approach“. In December 2014 their proposal was supported by all 28 member states, and it became the official EU policy then.
And, what has happened since then?
In short, Bosnia and Herzegovina returned to the EU accession path, and achieved more progress on that path in the previous 18 months than in the entire previous decade. The renewed EU approach enabled us to achieve such progress. We did the job ourselves in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the EU provided us with its invaluable support.
Mr Ivanić and Mr Čović, my colleagues in the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Id I initiated progress along that path by preparing the “Declaration on commitment to reforms within the EU accession framework“. It was not an easy task to gather the leaders of all 14 parliamentary political parties in order to ensure their agreement on the content of the declaration concerned. Our good friend Federica Mogherini, EU High Representative, who was with us in Sarajevo on the day when this declaration was adopted by the Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina, referred to that adoption as “a historic step in the right direction“.
The three of us in the Presidency agreed that it was our task to ensure that Bosnia and Herzegovina would keep moving forward in the set direction. The Chairperson of the Council of Ministers and the two entity prime ministers conducted very intense negotiations for months on the content of the social and economic reform agenda for the period from 2015 to 2018. Taking into consideration the lessons learnt from the previous experience, particularly concerning the need to enhance functioning of the labour market and the structure of the budget expenditures, we agreed on a comprehensive Reform Agenda, which promised most significant redirection of our economics since the time of the Dayton Peace Accords – from enhancement of the business climate to the reform of labour legislation, from the health care system reform to the implementation of a comprehensive pension system reform and more efficient collection of taxes. The content of the Reform Agenda was drafted in close cooperation with the IMF, the World Bank, and the EBRD. These institutions have provided their financial support to the implementation of the Reform Agenda. The European Commission has established that significant results have been achieved already due to the implementation of the Reform Agenda.
One such result was a significant increase of economic activity. Bosnia and Herzegovina is the most rapidly growing economy in our region at the moment. The GDP increase of in 2015 was 3.14%, which was twice as much in relation to 2014. We expect the GDP growth rate to remain at 3% this year, with a possible rise to 4% in the mid-term period. The revenue from indirect taxes has grown by 3%. The industrial production has increased by 2.2%. The unemployment rate has fallen by 4.4% in relation to the previous year.
We have also made significant steps towards convergence in the EU. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement came into effect in summer 2015. In February 2016 Mr Dragan Čović, my colleague filed our application for membership in the EU. In September 2016 the EU member countries accepted our membership application as a credible one. We are delighted that we will host Commissioner Hahn in Sarajevo on 9 December, when he will hand over the European Commission's questionnaire, which will assess our readiness for obtaining the candidate status. Let me assure you that completing the questionnaire will be the priority for all administrative levels in BiH because we want to receive an opinion from the European Commission as soon as possible on our readiness for the candidate status. That opinion will help us realize to which extent our institutions, legislation and practice deviate from the EU standards. Businesspersons and civil society representatives keep telling us that they see achieving the EU standards as a priority. Our citizens want to buy quality goods and services in accordance with the EU quality standards. Business companies and investors want to see legal security and the EU standards applied in BiH because that will enable them to do business with the EU in an easier and more simple way.
Dear friends,
I am not here to show you a pink image of today's Bosnia and Herzegovina, or to assert that a bright future is granted. We have been faced with many challenges and we have had many open issues. The political relations are still very fragile. The level of trust is not satisfactory yet. Instances of turbulence occur almost daily. To achieve the current progress has not been easy at all, and the path ahead will bring about even more challenges. Therefore, I believe that we should proceed along this path cautiously, while making sure that we do not jeopardize what has been achieved so far.
I believe that most of you will agree that mobilizing such political forces which will resist the growing populism, as well as winning our citizens' sympathy and support for such resistance, have never been more difficult than now. Support provided by some third countries to populists throughout the EU countries, as well as throughout the countries striving to join the EU, has been much stronger nowadays than it used to be a few years ago. They are not interested in any facts or in the long-term impact their actions will have to our societies.
In the EU member states these forces have been directed against the EU and our shared values. In Bosnia and Herzegovina they have been directed against the constitutional order, sovereignty and territorial integrity, as well as against our goal to reach the destination preferred by 80% of our citizens – i.e. the family of Euro-Atlantic states. In the RS entity such actors conducted a referendum by which the Decision of the Constitutional Court was flagrantly breached, the constitutional order was challenged, the Dayton Peace Accords was breached, and a serious threat to security and stability of BiH was posed. We have been faced with the populist forces which have obstructed adoption of the social and economic reforms. While playing the card of ethnic differences, some of these populists have also raised inter-ethnic tensions by making unfounded statements on their endangered vital national interests. They want to return us to the counter-productive and polarizing debates on constitutional reforms. We should not let them prevail!
The struggle against these growing forces can only be won if we oppose them together. Therefore, I firmly support the decision of the EU member states to accept our application for membership. We also appreciate all the assistance which we have received from the EU institutions and individual EU member states in order to enable us to meet the conditions we were given. Such support is very important because it sends a strong message to those political actors who have received support from the third countries to work against our shared future in the EU and NATO.
Dear members of the European Parliament,
In view of Bosnia and Herzegovina's accession to the EU, I want to share with you what I believe is realistic for us to achieve in the next 12 to 18 months.
First, we will complete the European Commission's questionnaire.
Second, we will intensify the implementation of the Reform Agenda.
Third, through the Coordination Mechanism adopted this summer, all administrative levels in our state will agree and adopt the state-level strategies in the fields of transport, energy and agriculture – in order to enable us to, finally, start using the pre-accession EU funds.
Fourth, as soon as the European Commission prepares its opinion on our readiness, we will work in accordance with that opinion towards achieving the candidate status. Our goal is to achieve the candidate status by the end of 2017.
And fifth, there is a possibility that we will reach an agreement on the implementation of the Sejdić-Finci case. That agreement could also take into account some legitimate remarks made by the Bosnian and Herzegovinian Croats. However, let me be honest with you. I fear that, despite urgency, it will be very difficult to agree on these issues because it is necessary to win a two-third majority in both houses of the State Parliament, gathering the representatives of 14 different political parties.
It would be of huge assistance to us if the implementation of the judgment on Sejdić-Finci case is not posed as a firm condition to our accession to the EU. I invite all in the EU to cautiously proceed, while thinking strategically which particular approach would bring about best results for all of us. It is my suggestion that all constitutional issues should be considered within the framework of opening chapters on negotiations for our EU membership. Wider constitutional reforms, which fall out of the framework of the Sejdić-Finci judgement implementation, are neither desirable nor doable at this moment because the key political actors in BiH would simply not be able to reach an agreement on their scope and content. In the next two years we will have to focus on the social and economic reforms, building of transport infrastructure, public administration reform and strengthening of the rule of law. These are the issues that the citizens need addressed, and that is what they expect from us.
Dear friends,
I would now like to talk about the contribution of Bosnia and Herzegovina to promoting our shared values, vision and objectives in the domain of foreign and security policy. This morning you shared views with High Representative Mogherini on the implementation of the Global EU Strategy. Bosnia and Herzegovina is fully committed to the principles and priorities set out in the Strategy, and will contribute to its implementation to the extent in which she can do so as a potential candidate state. We will accept our part of responsibility for facing security threats and challenges that Europe is facing nowadays.
We have been committed to the fight against terrorism in all its forms. As a member of the Global Coalition to Counter ISIL, we will continue to contribute, within our capabilities, to the international efforts invested in degrading and defeating this terrorist organization. We are the first country in the region which adopted the amendments to our Criminal Code in order to establish legal sanctions against fighters who fight wars abroad. Our legislation has been additionally strengthened in its segments concerning the prohibition against the financing of terrorist activities.
Terrorism is a threat which has affected all of us. No single country or society has been immune to that threat, and no single country can oppose it on its own. Terrorism has become a growing challenge which requires a comprehensive reply based on cooperation of all states not only through security measures, but through preventive measures, too.
Those who conduct, organize or encourage terrorist attacks, while claiming that they do it in the name of Islam, act absolutely contrary to the values of Islam and its universal principles of tolerance and coexistence. Violent extremism and terrorism are entirely unacceptable from the point of view of Islam. Terrorism in the name of Islam is terrorism against Islam.
Stability and security of the Western Balkans, and its ultimate consolidation within the EU framework are of Bosnia and Herzegovina's top strategic importance. We will continue to cooperate closely with the EU and the countries in the region in view of achieving these shared objectives. To that end, we very much appreciate and commit ourselves to regional dialogue and cooperation. We will continue to participate actively in all frameworks and mechanisms of regional cooperation with the EU, particularly through the Berlin Process. The instance of regional cooperation on projects of infrastructural connectedness builds trust, improves relations, and offers palpable economic benefit to our citizens.
However, political leaders in the region, from time to time, continue to use such rhetoric or activities which raise tensions and cause regional instability – very often due to mutual misunderstanding and a lack of trust. We witnessed it during the migration crisis, and during the elections held in the region recently.
I am convinced that what is needed, and still missing for the time being, is a high-level political dialogue between the EU and the Western Balkans, which would enhance stability and security in the region, and ensure its ultimate consolidation within the EU frameworks. Certainly, the political leaders in the region bear primary responsibility for building stable and safe environment which is conductive for general progress. However, the EU itself has a role to play in this process. Carefully defined and well structured political dialogue at a high level between the EU and the Western Balkans countries would create a much needed platform and mechanism through which the EU could provide its assistance and support to our region in achieving the following two shared objectives:
- Stabilize the political environment by mitigating crises and lowering tensions at their initial stages, and resolving disputes and remaining open issues in accordance with the international and EU standards;
- Develop both comprehensive and coordinated approaches through which the EU and the Western Balkans would react to security threats affecting the region and the EU, such as the migration crisis, organized crime, terrorism and radicalisation, with an ultimate goal of developing security networks and interoperability within the region, as well as building such networks between the region and the EU.
To conclude, let me assure you that we in Bosnia and Herzegovina remain fully committed to supporting a positive momentum and continuing implementation of the reform agenda within our EU accession process. The future of BiH lies firmly in the EU. We are convinced that a full integration into the EU is best course, leading to achieving stability, security and progress in our country. The accession process itself is most efficient mechanism for transformation of our country, aimed at achieving the contemporary democratic standards and enhancing our economic growth. No matter how many challenges there will be on that path, and no matter how many obstacles we will encounter, we will keep moving forward. For us, there is no alternative to that.
Thank you for your attention, and I remain available for your questions.

title: Statement by H.E. Mr. Bakir Izetbegović,Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the General Debate of the 71St Session of the United Nations General Assembly
content:
We are facing the worst forced-displacement crisis since the Second World War. Sixty million people have been forced to flee their homes because of wars, persecution, and human rights violations. They are scattered around the world, their livelihoods and communities shattered into pieces, their nations and cultures torn apart. Robbed of their dignity, living in despair in refugee camps, they are compelled to seek a better future on the borders of other countries. They are not faceless statistics, but human beings with every right to a future free of violence, a future of hope and opportunity. Their tragedy is our tragedy. Their future is our future.
Mr. President, Mr. Secretary General, Excellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen,
Peace and security, human rights and development are the pillars of the United Nations -- a founding promise to the world this Organization was created to safeguard. Yet, our world today is anything but peaceful and secure. It is marred with injustice, inequality and intolerance that erode the foundations of our humanity. We are witnessing human suffering of an unprecedented scale, reaching far beyond national boundaries or capacities. Poverty, hunger, disease, natural disasters and climate change afflict millions of our fellow human beings. Many states and societies are trapped in protracted conflicts, with cycles of violence claiming countless victims.
We are facing the worst forced-displacement crisis since the Second World War. Sixty million people have been forced to flee their homes because of wars, persecution, and human rights violations. They are scattered around the world, their livelihoods and communities shattered into pieces, their nations and cultures torn apart. Robbed of their dignity, living in despair in refugee camps, they are compelled to seek a better future on the borders of other countries. They are not faceless statistics, but human beings with every right to a future free of violence, a future of hope and opportunity. Their tragedy is our tragedy. Their future is our future.
This crisis requires not only a humanitarian response, but a sustainable political solution. It requires stronger political leadership and resolve, as well as rethinking of policy, operational and financing strategies at national, regional and international levels. But all too often nanow national interests impede the formulation of such joint responses. When crises transcend borders, like the current refugee and migrant crisis in the Middle East and in Europe, we must look broadly, not merely from the standpoint of national interests, because the consequences of our actions and omissions resonate beyond our borders.
As a country whose hundreds of thousands of citizens experienced the plight of being forced out of their homes, Bosnia and Herzegovina attaches a great significance to addressing this challenge. We recognize the importance and timely organization of the High-level meeting on large movement on refugees and migrants, and we welcome the adoption of the Outcome document that is clearly linked to the Agenda 2030. We hope the commitments Member States made in this meeting will have meaningful impact on the ground. In the Agenda 2030 we pledged that "no one will be left behind", and committed to empower the most vulnerable. For the millions of refugees and internally displaced persons that means the ability to return to their homes, to be better integrated into their host societies, or to be settled elsewhere if needed. It means the difference between a life of aid dependency and the opportunity for a life of dignity and self-reliance.
Mr. President,
Bosnia and Herzegovina fully supports the Agenda 2030. As a newly elected member of the Economic and Social Council, we will play an active role in the implementation of this transformative blueprint for change. Our achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals will depend on the availability of support for national implementation -- primarily from the revised and improved Global partnership for sustainable development, which must be a true global platform for exchange of best practices in the field of finance, trade, technology and capacity building between Member States. We support the Global mechanism and the monitoring of the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals, which will outline critical milestones towards a coherent and inclusive follow up and review of the Agenda at the global level.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Terrorism is a global threat that affects us all. No state or society is imrnune from it, and no state alone can counter it. With violent extremism on the rise, and a growing number of foreign terrorist fighters, terrorism is becoming an increasingly difficult challenge that requires a comprehensive response involving the collaboration of all States, employing not only security, but preventive measures as well. We face a problem that has deep and complex roots, that transcends national boundaries, and that cannot, and should not, be associated with any one religion, nationality or ethnic group.
Those who perpetrate, organize, and inspire terrorist attacks -- claiming to do so in the name of Islam -- want to turn Islam into an ideology of global fear. Violent extremism and terrorism are unacceptable from the viewpoint of any religion, including Islam. They undermine its system of values and its universal teachings of tolerance and coexistence.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is strongly committed to combating terrorism in all its forms. We are deeply concerned with the rise of violent extremism, and attach a great importance to countering it. We welcome the Secretary General' s initiative and Plan of Action to Prevent Violent Extremism, as another useful tool in a comprehensive, whole-of-UN approach to preventing violent extremism.
Prevention of extremism and promotion of human rights cannot be separated. Inclusive governance and respect for the rule of law are of paramount importance. Political, economic and social injustices around the world contribute to the rise of despair and hopelessness, creating a fertile ground for the emergence of radicalism and violent extremism. There is ever more injustice in the imperfect world we live in, but actions causing even greater injustice are not the right response. Our governments must and will respond to violence with force and repressive measures. However, if that part of our response is not can-ied out precisely and selectively, with respect for human rights and the rule of law, it will only cause a new wave of radicalization. The real fight and ultimate victory must and can only be on the ideological level.
Our approach and strategy must be holistic. We must apply a wide range of policies and measures that address the economic and social conditions conducive to the spread of violent extremism, which terrorist organizations exploit to drive recruitment and radicalization. In particular, we must work harder to eliminate discrimination, prejudice and xenophobia in our societies, reduce poverty and inequality, improve education and expand opportunities, especially for our young generations.
Mr. President,
Engagement of the United Nations has never been more critical, as we face unprecedented challenges in confronting the surge in violence of various forms around the world. Global action, guided by the principles of international law, is required to put an end to the violence and instability in UM-aine, Syria, haq, Libya and other crisis areas. Ensuring protection of civilians and compliance with international humanitarian and human rights law is imperative. Neutrality and indifference lead to resentment and frustration, further emboldening those who leave devastation and sorrow in their wake.
Humanitarian aid can never serve as a substitute for solutions that address the root causes of conflict. Nor can it create the necessary conditions for lasting peace and stability. The main causes of modern conflicts are discrimination and exclusion, failures of governance, impunity, deep-rooted poverty and lack of opportunities, aggravated by the growing effects of climate change. In our increasingly interconnected world, we can no longer keep the impact of far-away conflicts outside our borders, nor can we ignore their global consequences.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Over the past year we saw a renewed sense of unity and unprecedented levels of commitments. We agreed to the Sendai Framework, the Addis Ababa Action Plan, the Agenda 2030, the Agenda for Humanity and the historic Paris Agreement on Climate Change. We collectively committed to humanity, with renewed focus on conflict prevention and resolution, strengthened efforts towards sustainable development, equal opportunities for all, promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls.
Peace and security cannot be detached from either development or environmental agendas. Peace is not merely absence of violence. It is a freedom from fear and insecurity. There is no lasting peace and security when injustice and inequality are an everyday experience for millions of people, when basic rights and freedoms are denied to so many human beings. The resulting grievances make our states unstable and our societies vulnerable, and readily fuel extremism, radicalization and violence. Injustice and inequality diminish the human potential of our communities, leaving development and prosperity beyond their reach.
The road of progress goes from ending poverty to reducing inequality and building just, equitable, tolerant, open and inclusive societies, with respect for human rights and promotion of the rule of law at the core of our every action. History will judge us by the difference we make in the lives of millions of people who are suffering from marginalization, discrimination, poverty, malnutrition, disease, natural disasters and climate change. We must listen to their voices and respond to their needs, hopes and aspirations. We must find the will and courage to take urgent action to turn the agendas we agreed upon into instruments of true global change, honoring our pledge to humanity and leaving a legacy true to our values.
Thank you!

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, Chairman of the Presidency of BiH on the occasion of construction works at Hydroelectric Power Plant (HE) Vranduk launch
content:
We live in the times of great challenges. However, much has been accomplished in the course of the last several years. Out of issues that should be pointed out, I would mention hereafter the start of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s progress on the European path and a continued economic growth, as well as the launch of significant projects in the areas of infrastructure and energy industry.
Dear Chairman of the Council of Ministers, Prime Minister of the Federation of BiH, dear ministers, heads of canton and municipal authorities, esteemed investors, creditors, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen!
It was on the pages of the reputable British journal ”The Economist” that I recently read that actual improvement of issues was a result of a vision-driven acting. It seems to me that all of us here, who are dedicated to Bosnia and Herzegovina, should contribute to turning vision into action. Bosnia and Herzegovina does have its vision: membership in the European Union, and reliance on a new model of economic growth through exports, increased productivity, job generation, labour market-driven enhancement skills, energy efficiency, social inclusion and poverty alleviation.
We live in the times of great challenges. However, much has been accomplished in the course of the last several years. Out of issues that should be pointed out, I would mention hereafter the start of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s progress on the European path, and a continued economic growth, as well as the launch of significant projects in the areas of infrastructure and energy industry. Within the Reform Agenda we launched efficient projects on protection of the poorest and on mitigating erosion of human capital.
Furthermore, it cannot go unnoticed that Bosnia and Herzegovina has played a responsible, constructive and active role in the international community, as well as in the region.
In short, in the last several years, we have moved Bosnia and Herzegovina in the right direction.
The launch of the construction works at Hydroelectric Power Plant Vranduk is yet another indicator of stability and a strong economic momentum in our country.
This project is an impressive one. Its investor – the Public Enterprise “Elektroprivreda BiH”, the creditors – the European Investment Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, but all of us as well, can be proud of it.
This is one in a series of megaprojects, whose implementation will start in the course of the current and next year, when Bosnia and Herzegovina will become a huge construction site.
Ladies and gentlemen,
If we know that the hydro energetic potential of Bosnia and Herzegovina is four times larger than the one we have used so far, if utilization of the hydro potential in our country is lowest in Europe, than the conclusion is obvious indeed. The fast rivers of Bosnia and Herzegovina are our huge, but still untapped, strategic development opportunity.
Of course, in development strategies and plans, no one will take such risk as to jeopardize the environment and residents in the valleys of our rivers. Environmental standards must be our top priorities.
Finally, it is my wish that we send a clear message from here on the positive environment and potential of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as a message to investors that our country is ready for enhanced development, and that it is a safe place for placement of investment and money.
I hereby extend my congratulations to both the investor and implementers for the launch of construction works at the Hydroelectric Power Plant Vranduk, with wishes for prompt and safe implementation, and for a successful exploitation of the future plant.
Thank you!

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, Chairperson of BiH Presidency at the commemoration on the occasion of marking the 21st anniversary of the genocide committed against the “Safe UN Srebrenica Area“ Bosniak
content:
Dear Srebrenica mothers, family members of innocent people from Srebrenica who were killed, esteemed mayor Duraković, dear members of the Organising Board, dear guests, your excellences, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen!
I hereby express my gratitude to the Organising Board, which ensured today's commemoration to take place. I commend their commitment in pursuing truth and preserving the fundamental values of humanity, often under circumstances of open intolerance shown in view of their work. I extend my deepest gratitude to those who were stricken most by the genocide committed in Srebrenica. Nothing would have been achieved without their courage.
It is difficult at this place of such tremendous pain and suffering to find proper words to express what I have felt since the time when I first walked among these white gravestones in Srebrenica. What can be said to mothers, wives and children of those who, by their own lives, bailed out both this place and the state we have today? Pain, sorrow, and suffering of those who outlived their dearest ones, who are buried at this place, are of such nature that it would be best just to remain silent. The only voice worthy of their peace is a voice of prayer, of a sincere dua placed before their souls.
Let us also pray today for the boy called Avdija, who was fourteen, and for the old man called Mustafa, who was seventy seven. They were killed because of their names, their religion and their people to whom they were born into. Thousands of those like them lie here side by side. We are still trying to find at least one more thousand of them.
Namely, the remains of those killed were hidden in ditches, dug into the ground by excavators, scattered across the hills and forests with the intention of completing the crime and leaving no trace of the victims.
Twenty one years after the appalling aggression against BiH, validated by the genocide committed in Srebrenica, I am determined, more than ever before, to seek justice and truth for each killed person from Srebrenica.
Are we on a path towards achieving such justice? Are we on a path towards achieving justice for both the victims and their families in Bosnia and Herzegovina? We must achieve justice because, unless we do so, there will neither be reconciliation nor necessary prerequisites for forgiveness and rebuilding of trust. The souls will find rest, and the victims' eye lids will only close together when justice is achieved, or they will not close ever.
It will be only then when we, without any hesitation, put things in their right places, when we remove a slightest doubt on who stood on the right and who stood on the wrong side of history, that we will free ourselves from divisions and burden of the past. This is our debt to all to whom we are paying respects today, to each killed person, but also to the overall community struggling against fascism anywhere in the world. Finally, it is our debt to next generations. Both the past and the present need truth. However, it is the future that needs truth most.
In order to remain in the past forever, a crime must be matched with its punishment, whereas victims must be granted justice and satisfaction. It is justified to ask ourselves whether we in this region are bliss for the future or a curse from the past to one another.
The answer to this question lays in our readiness to draw lessons from history and turn them into a vision of peace-making, understanding and tolerance.
We have learnt a painful lesson, and it is our duty to share a warning driven from it – that a dream focused on destroying others always ends in self-destruction and defeat of its dreamer.
The policies which in the late 20th century saw a solution in divisions and separatism, force and violence, exclusion of others, in spreading fear and injustice, the policies which, ultimately, led to Vukovar and Srebrenica, must, once and for all, be abandoned.
Dear friends, brothers and sisters!
Today we remember the horrors of the past, but we take an oath that the past will not paralyse us. Today's commemoration at which we gathered is about the future – the future of our children and of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. All of us lived through some tragedies. However, despite of devastating pain, it is our obligation to those who survived, to continue to make this country a better place.
No one is born hating another person because of the colour of his skin, or his background, or his religion. People, unfortunately, learn to hate.
