Therefore, may those who negate the genocide in Srebrenica or remain silent think deep about it and reconcile themselves with darkest stain in their history. They must know one thing – accepting and recognizing truth is a first step to true reconciliation.
That is where any thought on coexistence lays and starts. Regardless of how unpleasant it may be, ultimately, the only thing which will be remembered the truth. It is indeed nothing but the truth, when uttered and accepted, which can liberate the future from horrible mortgage carried over from the genocidal past.
Dear friends, ladies and gentlemen!
What happened in the past cannot be changed. It can only be remembered, and it will be remembered indeed. However, we can change the future – the future of this country and the next generations to whom all of us owe accountability, peace, as well as a vision of prosperity.
Evil cannot be deleted, but we can defeat it by goodness. We owe such victory to those who lie here. It is our obligation to preserve memories, defend the truth, strengthen and build a community from which they were streamed away because it is only by doing so that we will preserve their lives and sacrifice from oblivion. This Potočari field full of gravestones, and the new rows of tabuts in it, remind us of sorrow and pain. However, they are also a plight for the ones who are alive, a testimony of the struggle which we ought to continue and complete.
Therefore, we will not become exhausted, and we will not allow lies, injustice and evil to prevail. The ways in which we will oppose lies, injustice and evil are by building unity instead of divisions, spreading love instead of hatred, and choosing life instead of death. We will guard truth and seek justice in the name of the past which we cannot change and the future which we must build.

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, Chairperson of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the NATO Summit (the meeting on Afghanistan) on 9 July 2016 in Warsaw
content:
Bosnia and Herzegovina is fully aware of complexity of the strategic context of Afghanistan, which is characterized by prompt changes, uncertainty and surprise, and strong impact they have on internal processes and their respective dynamism in Afghanistan.
While recognizing the characteristics of this context, Bosnia and Herzegovina has fully supported the instruments NATO has used throughout its ongoing mission aimed at achieving stability and prosperity in Afghanistan. We are ready to provide a military contribution to NATO efforts in order to train, advice and support development of the state security forces of Afghanistan by the time they will take over a full responsibility for the security of Afghanistan. We are ready to offer such support as long as there is a need for military resources and competencies which Bosnia and Herzegovina can place under the Alliance's disposal.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has supported the concept of the “Decisive Support“ Mission for Afghanistan. We understand that the moment of transition from the first to the second mission phase will be determined based on the status of the security situation on the ground and the level of readiness of the Afghan security forces to take over a full responsibility for their country's security. Bosnia and Herzegovina is determined, should there be a need for it, to offer NATO the same military contribution in the second phase, too, regardless of the envisaged structural reduction of the mission.
In addition to our contribution in terms of military resources, Bosnia and Herzegovina is willing to support the mission in Afghanistan by a symbolic participation proportionate to her capacity in numerous aspects of an ongoing comprehensive restoration of Afghanistan. In cooperation with allies and partners, we will also support financially the process of enhancing sustainability of the Afghan state security forces. We are determined to ensure a new donation of military equipment and ammunition for the Afghan state security service, in accordance with the Decision adopted by the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as offer cooperation on issues of special interest for Afghanistan.
Bosnia and Herzegovina reaffirms her interest to participate in planning and establishing a new, civilian mission in Afghanistan, after the “Decisive Support“ mission is completed.
On the basis of the information collected on the content and features of a long term partnership with Afghanistan, the needs of the future mission and economic potentials of our country, the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina will adopt necessary decisions in view of using resources of Bosnia and Herzegovina in development of a stable and prosperous Afghanistan.
Ladies and gentlemen!
This is also an opportunity for me to share with you a survey on preconditions which Bosnia and Herzegovina has to meet for MAP to be activated.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is decisive in her intention to continue the process of registering perspective military locations into land books. The Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina obliges itself to complete, pursuant to the activation of MAP for BiH, the registration of all remaining perspective military locations within ANP.
We have achieved a considerable progress in view of “Defence Review“. Based on the major work carried out by the Ministry of Defence of BiH and the Armed Forces of BiH, the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina recently resolved all doubts and open issues within the documents concerned, and we now expect it to be completed successfully by end-November this year. The HQ of NATO in Sarajevo had an active role in creating this document.
Moreover, Bosnia and Herzegovina has had an active role in fighting all forms of radical extremism, whereas, within its capacities, BiH has supported the global coalition opposing the so-called ISIS. Last year we donated 600 tons of ammunition to the Government of Iraq. Last month, the Presidency of BiH approved of another donation amounting to the same quantity of ammunition for the Iraq Army.
We are grateful to the U.S. Government for the assistance in preparation of these donations.
From the moment of transformation from a beneficiary to provider of security, we have decided to make further steps towards enhancing regional and global security, as well as steps directed at enhancing our partnership with NATO, which, ultimately, leads to our full membership in the Alliance.
Bosnia and Herzegovina extends congratulations to Montenegro for joining NATO. We see the membership of Montenegro as an additional factor of stability and cooperation in the region.

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Bakir Izetbegović at the Summit of the Heads of State and Government of the SEECP in Sofia
content:
Honorable Mr. Chairman, Excellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen, It is my pleasure to address you today. As you are well aware, Balkans is the region where history often creates burden too heavy to bear. But what we can and want to do, is to develop close relations with our neighboring countries and beyond, based on mutual respect and mutual interests
Bosnia and Herzegovina is positioned within the region as one of its core countries, and we develop close partnerships with all the countries in the region. The future of this region is integration, in the best interest of all the countries involved.
Bosnia and Herzegovina truly appreciates the importance of the South-East European Cooperation Process (SEECP) in bringing together the countries from the Adriatic and Black Sea to the Ionian and the Mediterranean Sea, and resolving important issues for two decades. This process has proven its lasting value, from its origins in Sofia 1996. up to the recent activities led by Bulgarian Chairmanship-in-Office.
All this time we have joined our forces to create a better atmosphere, to coordinate important matters in mutual cooperation, to reach our common goals – stability and progress for our countries.
Bosnia and Herzegovina remains strongly determined to continue strengthening regional cooperation in all areas. Successful regional cooperation is essential for creating a stable and secure environment, which the key the condition for economic development. I can say with firm conviction that we have the capacity and will to join forces allowing the South East Europe to become the exemplary case of successful regional cooperation, infrastructural connectivity, and friendly relations.
Two days ago the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina hosted the Brdo-Brijuni Process Leaders’ Meeting in Sarajevo, with the participation of the President of Italy as a special guest. The Summit was an opportunity to use the dialogue at the highest level in order to give an additional impetus for strengthening the regional cooperation and the processes of EU integration.
We also see the regional cooperation as a solid preparation for our future activities within the EU. I wish to remind you that the "Sarajevo Declaration" adopted on 21 April 2004 emphasizes regional cooperation as a basis of the European Union policy in the region of the Southeast Europe.
The EU itself has been built on foundations of regional cooperation in strategic areas. We see the EU membership as a chance for lasting peace, stability, security and prosperity, for all of our citizens.
Europe as a continent, including our region as well, faces a number of challenges; violent extremism, radicalism, and terrorism, human rights violations – those are matters of concern for all of us. European security and stability is an issue we take seriously. The crisis and conflicts in some parts of Europe concern us all, and it is our sincere hope that these conflicts will be resolved timely and peacefully.
However, we also need to be aware that some of these challenges, such as the vast migration of refugees heading north and west through our countries is a challenge that puts to the test not only our political resolve to cooperate, but also our very humanity. Bosnia and Herzegovina has not been on the path of this human wave. But we have been close enough to perceive and understand the magnitude of these events.
Many people in our countries have had the experience of seeking refuge from violence away from home in the past. We should draw a lesson of humility from that fact. And we should do our best to coordinate our efforts in handling this crisis.
Ladies and gentlemen,
In the framework of South-East European Cooperation Process (SEECP), our countries took political initiative to assume regional ownership in fostering peace, security, good neighborly cooperation and economic development. Our efforts have a core purpose to leave behind the past instability, conflicts and collective apathy, in order to become a partner to EU on equal footing.
The path to developing relations and fostering cooperation in the region is building trust, favoring economic ties, resolving conflicts by compromise, and developing joint projects in the strategic areas of development.
The region and its people need more trust, and it has to grow organically, at the grassroots level, in order to have a full and meaningful impact.
I firmly believe this process is irreversibly under way, but it takes time, and time waits for no man. Neither would it wait for our peninsula, rich and varied in culture, history, natural resources and human talent, but still prone to falling into stereotype of „Balkanization“.
Trust is the only lasting cure for „de-balkanizing“ the Balkans.
To build it, it is instrumental to communicate, as often and as sincerely as possible, both in bilateral and multilateral settings. SEECP is a major regional forum for political dialogue and we should live up to its purpose of ensuring the voice of the region is heard on all the matters of importance.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has a clear and strong interest of joining a stable and prosperous European Union. Bosnia and Herzegovina has cultivated many forms of coexistence in diversity, such as multi-ethnic solidarity and understanding, for centuries of our turbulent history. The core values of European Union correspond to the rich heritage we draw from the positive aspects and periods of our past. In many ways, the model of living together that developed in Bosnia and Herzegovina is a precursor of modern EU.
Hence, the EU membership is a top priority in foreign policy, and a strategic goal of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We submitted the application for EU membership on 15th of February, in Brussels. Our objective is to become an EU candidate country by the end of 2017. We will work to fulfill the remaining conditions, in order for the EU Council to consider positively our application as soon as possible, and forward it to the European Commission. We are already making institutional preparations to provide the Commission with required answers, once we receive European Commission questionnaire. We are aiming at and looking forward to a positive Avis.
Finally, I wish to congratulate Bulgaria, as the chairing country of SEECP, for the one year term of chairmanship-in-office, and to express my wish for the future chairmanship of Croatia to be successful.
Thank you!

title: Address by the Chairperson of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Bakir Izetbegović on the occasion of the opening ceremony of the restored Ferhadija mosque in Banja Luka
content:
Messages which we have sent today from the courtyard of the restored Ferhadija mosque have historical importance and strength that especially the future generations will bear witness to. In particular, those messages are powerful because we have sent them together with the representatives of the Serb people in Bosnia and Herzegovina who have strongly supported the restoration of Ferhadija by all means.
Dear Grand Mufti of the Islamic Community in Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Dear colleague Ivanić,
Dear Prime Minister of the Republic of Turkey,
Dear Chairperson of the Council of Ministers of BiH,
Dear presidents of the entities in Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Dear high officials of other religious communities,
Your excellences,
Ladies and gentlemen,
I am particularly glad that I can extend the salaam and greetings to all of you on this truly great day.
In histories of states and peoples rare are the events like today's one.
In the dark times when Ferhadija was demolished there were very few who believed that a day such as today would ever arrive.
However, those who had believed it would be possible, and made it possible by their good deeds, have achieved victory today.
Let us avail ourselves of this opportunity to remember all of them today, let us pay respect and extend our gratitude to them.
It is with particular piety that we remember Murat Badić from Cazin, who testified and confirmed his faith and commitment to this mosque with his own life.
Let this day be a permanent warning to those who demolished Ferhadija.
It was their goal to demolish and deny a multi-century context of co-existence and tolerance in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
They have not, and, with God's help, they never will achieve such goal.
The messages which we have sent today from the courtyard of the restored Ferhadija have historical importance and strength that future generations in particular will bear witness to.
Notably, those messages are powerful because we have sent them together with the representatives of the Serb people in Bosnia and Herzegovina, who have strongly supported the restoration of Ferhadija with various means.
By her monumentality and beauty Ferhadija bears witness to values which overarch time and space, while linking people of different cultures and beliefs in the same way in which good people of different religions and nations have been connected in the course of its restoration.
Let me extend my gratitude to all those who invested their material goods into this splendid building.
In particular, let me extend my gratitude to both the people and the Government of the Republic of Turkey, who have contributed over 4 million Convertible Marks to the restoration of Ferhadija.
Among hundreds of monuments of material culture, which have been restored by our friends from Turkey in the last decade throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina, many are of extraordinary beauty and importance, and some are part of the UNESCO-protected world cultural heritage.
However, you will agree that Ferhadija is the most beautiful of them all!
In its full symbolism, the restoration of Ferhadija is a confirmation of the victory of life and hope, a confirmation of a strong conviction that we will continue to live together in these areas.
The restoration of Ferhadija is a symbol of durable return of Bosniaks to these areas.
Namely, God's houses are not only the places where people pray. They represent a confirmation of survival of people who pray within them, too.
We, as responsible persons, have an obligation to build such future which will be based on mutual respect and appreciation.
Let us do everything we possibly can in order to understand each other better. Let us not jeopardize each other in any way. Let us learn about each other with lots of good will, appreciation and sincerity instead.
Dear friends,
Our numerous our cultural and historic monuments were wiped off the face of the earth in the course of the last war.
What was demolished most often were the waqfs - endowments, an important part of the cultural treasure owned by all our citizens and a confirmation of the identity of Bosniaks, as nation-building people. Unfortunately, among such demolished monuments were all mosques of Banja Luka, too.
Instances of such demolition also occurred prior to the last war, but never before did it happen to such large extent, with such intent, and with such persistence.
While not losing sight of the truth about the past, let us be decisive in our intent to go forward, and to look towards the future.
Harmonious relations between the peoples of different religions and nations in Bosnia and Herzegovina have their roots in the distant past and represent the value the generations of our ancestors have been proud of. The sounds of church bells and ezzans have never disrupted one another in this country. Indeed, they have complemented one another instead.
Therefore, I hope that our neighbours Serbs will experience the restored Ferhadija as a reunion of people, dedicated to their religious and cultural tradition, who respect the identity of others and of those who are different.
I believe that, by accepting the restored Ferhadija, the citizens of Banja Luka, while being determined to build a prosperous future in this beautiful town on the Vrbas river, have sent a message that they welcome and accept the return of their expelled Bosniak neighbours, with whom they wish to build such future together.
May the opening of the restored Ferhadija serve as an incentive for us to restore and strengthen these values to the benefit of all citizens of our homeland Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I am certain that we are starting fresh now. After Ferhadija opens its doors to worshippers, let us continue to open doors to each other, assured that our differences do not jeopardize anyone nor do they limit anyone.

title: Address by the Chairperson of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Bakir Izetbegović on the occasion of marking Europe Day on 9 May 2016 in Sarajevo
content:
Openness, unity in diversity, mutual respect and tolerance are such values which Bosnia and Herzegovina, its peoples and citizens have shared with Europe. I am certain that it is neither exaggerated nor pretentious to say that Bosnia and Herzegovina and this city in which different houses of worship almost lean on one another is a precursor of the spirit of a united Europe.
Dear excellences, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, today we are marking Europe Day and Victory in Europe Day.
We are marking and celebrating decades of peace, decades of development, cooperation and freedom.
The Old continent resisted the evil of Nazi totalitarianism and Fascist monism – of the darkness which had engulfed the whole continent.
Without the 9th May 1945 there would not have been the May of 1950.
Therefore, first of all, let me express my warmest congratulations to you on the occasion of Victory in Europe Day.
Europe Day marks a seemingly modest beginning of a glorious vision.
The Declaration of the French Minister Robert Schumann was initiated as an appeal to France and Western Germany to prevent next wars in Europe by uniting and coordinating their management over strategically important resources – coal and steel.
However, the principle initiated by this Resolution, on whose foundations today's European Union rests, has had far-reaching positive effects.
It is the principle of shared interest-focused cooperation, as an alternative to conflicts, which has made Europe more successful and advanced than ever.
The idea of cooperation aimed at strengthening of peace and progress has grown and broadened, branching out across the whole continent.
Obstacles to spreading to the East ceased to exist due to the fall of the Iron Curtain.
In the new century numerous new members have enriched the European family, shared new experiences and provided their contributions to further deepening of cooperation within the framework of the European Union, with a shared objective of preserving and developing democracy.
Such Europe that we have strived to reach is the Europe of open borders and open spirit.
That is not a Europe which is fenced-off and partitioned by barbed wire.
Openness, unity in diversity, mutual respect and tolerance are such values which Bosnia and Herzegovina, her peoples and citizens have shared with Europe.
I am certain that it is neither exaggerated nor pretentious to say that Bosnia and Herzegovina and this city in which different houses of worship almost lean on one another is a precursor of the spirit of a united Europe.
Ladies and gentlemen!
There is a heavy burden of history in our country.
The 9th of May is the Day of Golden Lilies for us, too, when we celebrate resistance, and the Day of Camp Detainees, when we remember the victims.
However, we are determined to learn a lesson from the conflicts we lived through, and to offer to the next generations the future of peace and progress - the European future.
Earlier this year we submitted our application for membership in the European Union. We will work diligently to meet all necessary requirements in order to be granted the candidate status by the end of 2017.
We are aware that our European course brings about an abundance of challenges as, in addition to the integration into the European Union, we must work even more diligently on the internal integration of the state, on reforms, on strengthening of the rule of law.
This process of positive reforms is equally important as the act of integration itself.
We can solve all problems, no matter how difficult or complex they may be, by joint forces – by dialogue and compromise, while being decisive to achieve the final goal.
That goal is clear – we want to be a part of an ordered, developed and united Europe.

title: Address by the Chairperson of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Bakir Izetbegović at the 7th Sarajevo Business Forum
content:
It is particularly important this year that Sarajevo Business Forum takes a step forward: it has exceeded its regional importance by hosting the Forum 16+1 for cooperation between the People's Republic of China and sixteen countries of Central and Eastern Europe. China is an economic generator of global importance. Its strategy of cooperation with economies of Central and Eastern Europe, whose economic impetuous has been powerful, is a huge opportunity for cooperation that will be useful for all who take part in it.
Esteemed excellences, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends!
It is my pleasure to welcome you to the seventh Sarajevo Business Forum. I am very glad that there are so many of you in Sarajevo today. We are grateful to you for your support to this forum, whose importance has grown each year and confirmed that Sarajevo is a relevant starting point for such big business visions that we, by joint forces, have turn into reality, into development and progress.
It is also thanks to the organizers from the BBI Bank that Sarajevo Business Forum has achieved such results. The engagement of this diligent team, led by Mr Amer Bukvić has been decisive in creating and constant advancing of this event, which keeps attracting investors from the whole world to Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as to the region.
Since it was established, Sarajevo Business Forum has had an ambition to gather and connect business persons and investors from all over the world with business persons, entrepreneurs and politicians from the region, using our specific position in the heart of Eastern Europe – at the crossroad linking the East and the West in both geographical and civilizational sense.
It is particularly important this year that Sarajevo Business Forum takes a step forward: it has exceeded its regional importance by hosting the Forum 16+1 for cooperation between the People's Republic of China and sixteen countries of Central and Eastern Europe. China is an economic generator of global importance. Its strategy of cooperation with economies of Central and Eastern Europe, whose economic impetuous has been powerful, is a huge opportunity for cooperation that will be useful for all who take part in it.
The Chinese vision of mass investment into infrastructure and energy projects along branches of the former Silk Road was initiated in 2011. It advocates linking Asia and Europe with high quality traffic corridors, along with development of business and trade links through joint investment. Such vision of huge potential is founded in history. However, it is entirely directed at the future.
We can be proud that Bosnia and Herzegovina is recognized as a possible focal point of that vision. By virtue of her position at the crossroad between the East and the West, Bosnia and Herzegovina can play an important and active role in creating economic potential and dynamism along the new Silk Road, as a link between the Chinese economy and the European one through Central Asia, Turkey, and the Gulf states.
Esteemed friends, dear guests!
This is the year when we wish to invest all our strengths in order to turn it into a year of success. Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted an application for membership in the European Union in February. A full integration into the European Union and NATO is best way to preserve stability, security and progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina. These integration processes are most effective tools for transformation of our country, for achievement of democratic standards, strengthening of the rule of law, strengthening of our institutions, building of competitive market economy, creating a powerful impetuous of economic development, and for enhancing such environment which will be entrepreneurship-friendly and investment-friendly.
It is clear that capital seeks prosperous countries and regions. The prospects of our country and region are prompt integration into the European Union, followed by strengthening of economic development and growth. That is the vision which we have implemented step by step, year after year.
We have witnessed that coordinated approach have ensured significant foreign investment inflow into the whole region – particularly in the areas of energy, infrastructure, agriculture and tourism – in which the scope of projects dictates the scope of cooperation. I hope that there will be more such projects in the near future.
Bosnia and Herzegovina shares three thirds of its borders with the European Union, and implements strongly the necessary reforms at all levels in order to join the EU as soon as possible.
Investors who recognize timely the potential that we have will stay a step ahead of those who hesitate, who stay trapped in the stereotypes of Balkans turbulent history. The times of conflict are over. The times of cooperation lie ahead.
What BiH can offer to investors in various fields right now is a dynamic development of traffic infrastructure, in which a lot has been done, but there is still a lot of work to be done.
There are also investment possibilities in the energy sector, which is a backbone of our economy. In the domain of energy our potentials are among most significant in the region. Our hydro-energetic potential is ranked as the eighth in size in Europe, while we have been using only 36% of it. We are a member country of the Energy Community. We also have coal reserves amounting to 6 billion tons.
With two and a half million hectares of arable land in the zones of continental, but also of the Mediterranean belt, our agriculture is capable of producing various fruits and vegetables, including the ones of highest quality – i.e. organic, for which there is a competitive demand from the developed markets.
The sector of tourism in our country has been constantly growing, and its full expansion is still ahead. We are ranked as the sixth destination per growth in tourist arrivals. It is estimated that by 2020 this market segment will have an annual growth of 10%.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a signatory of the Central European Free Trade Agreement, which enables access to the market of almost 27 million consumers in Serbia, Kosovo, Montenegro, Macedonia, Albania and Moldova for the products from our country. We have the Free Trade Agreement with Turkey, and preferential import regimes with the European Union, Canada, Japan, Russia, and the United States of America. Our currency is stable because it is pegged to the euro, which is why we do not have currency fluctuations. Our inflation rate is extremely low.
Our workers are skilled, knowledgeable, educated and they work at competitive prices. Our administrative structures have worked diligently on creating investment-friendly conditions by implementing accelerated reforms. Today foreign investors in Bosnia and Herzegovina have the same rights as the domestic ones. The tax rate for corporations is fixed at 10% and there is no capital gains tax, whereas imports of equipment needed for investment are exempt from customs duty.
We are determined to create a space for enhancement of domestic investment in the real sector of the economy and for strengthening of the private sector. The focus of our development is strategically focused on small and medium enterprises, which have been proven as best generators of economic growth. We have worked on reforms which will ultimately improve the business environment, remove administrative obstacles, and put public administration at service of investors and entrepreneurs.
Dear friends!
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country of cordial and welcoming people, a country of rich history. Sarajevo is an open and cosmopolitan centre, in which friends from all parts of the world have been hosted with warm and cordial welcome.
I wish you to feel comfortable as our guests, while exchanging experiences and ideas, creating new partnerships and building new visions.
I wish you successful and fruitful work during the seventh Sarajevo Business Forum.

title: Address at the Croatian National Theatre by the Chairperson of the Presidency of BiH Bakir Izetbegović on the occasion of the solemn academy marking the 100th anniversary of the legal and institutiona
content:
Dear Madam President of the Republic of Croatia, dear President of the Republic of Turkey, esteemed representatives of the Government and the Parliament of the Republic of Croatia, esteemed Grand Mufti of the Islamic Community in Bosnia and Herzegovina, esteemed president of the Mesihat of the Islamic Community in the Republic of Croatia, esteemed officials of other religious communities, your excellences, ladies and gentlemen,
It is a true honour and a great pleasure to be with you today.
I extend my congratulations the authorities and the citizens of the Republic of Croatia on the occasion of this valuable jubilee.
Historical zeal, which has borne fruit, has brought Croatia into the new century.
It is not by coincidence that, after all grave challenges it lived through, Croatia has progressed parallel to the growth and affirmation of the Islamic Community in this country.
Nowadays, Croatia is a bright example that, in a contemporary European society, it is possible indeed to arrange the relationship between a state and an Islamic community on the basis of true integration-focused principles.
While Muslims in some European states have been struggling spasmodically to preserve their identity and protect their religious and civil rights, they have had full access to such rights in Croatia.
Such Muslims are reputable Croatian citizens who have contributed in all areas to the state and the society.
The way in which Croatia solved the status and position of Muslims should direct and inspire others in Europe.
Ladies and gentlemen!
The presence and activity of Muslim intellectuals from Bosnia and Herzegovina in the late 19th and early 20th century in Zagreb, in both cultural and political sense, is closely related to the chronology of the official recognition of Islam in Croatia.
The Bosniaks laid foundations of the Islamic Community in Croatia as we know it today.
They brought from Bosnia and Herzegovina to Croatia their experience of co-existence and tolerance, accumulated over centuries. Numerous historic examples have borne witness to such experience, including the presence of the Bosnian Franciscans, which has lasted for almost eight hundred years, the arrival of the Spanish Jews, who found refuge in Bosnia and Herzegovina after the exodus - when no one else in Europe wanted to shelter them.
Moreover, in the course of the most recent aggression against the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, not a single church, monastery or synagogue got devastated in towns with Muslim majority population.
The Bosniaks have reciprocated Croatia in many ways.
They have demonstrated their belonging to this country, without hesitation or calculation.
Reputable artists and sportsmen, over 25,000 participants in the defence of the Republic of Croatia, as well as numerous silent and diligent neighbours have woven their lives into the progress of this state. The latter have done so outside the public arena.
Driven by the experience from their homeland, the Muslim Bosniaks have integrated effortlessly into the Croatian and other European host towns – while contributing with what was most valuable to these social environments, and accepting from them their positive experience and values in return.
Diversity should be our shared treasure today, too. Diversity should not be treated as a subject of controversy, divergence or conflict.
Muslim Bosniaks are a proof that the Islamic values have enhanced Europe to the same extent to which the European values have enhanced the overall Muslim community.
We have witnessed that Muslims in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croatia have served more and more often as a good example applicable to the integration of a hundred thousand Muslims who have sought refuge in Europe from the horrors of war and violence.
Islam is not alien to Europe, nor is it alien to her spirit.
To the contrary, what we now know as the spirit of Europe would probably not have existed without the participation and contribution of Islam in, literally, all areas of social live: from religion and philosophy, through arts, politics, economics, and state administration, to natural sciences, crafts, and even culinary art.
If Europe would try to eliminate systematically all Islamic elements and influences from her heritage, her own foundations would have collapsed.
The present Europe is home to over 20 million Muslims, who have become her increasingly important social segment.
They have been an integral part of the European culture and the best bridge for dialogue, understanding and cooperation between Europe and the Muslim world.
Dear ladies and gentlemen,
There are plenty of reasons for us to be proud tonight.
However, all of us will be filled with even more pride if we use our knowledge and wisdom to enhance the position of minorities throughout Europe in our respective contexts.
It is thanks to all religions and cultures in Croatia that we are marking this jubilee tonight.
Each one of them should consider their own internal relations as an example of a commitment to the fundamental values important for all man – such as the value of life and respect for its integrity, the value of faith and respect for its diverse expressions.
The protection of human dignity and respect for each and every one's specialness are such values that should be carefully nurtured and maintained by a modern society.
Therefore, let us keep opening doors towards other religions and different cultures, assured that cultural and religious diversity do not restrain or restrict anyone.
This has to be a vision of our shared future!
Thank you!

title: The speech given by BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović at the official opening of the annual meeting of the European Federation of Journalists (EFJ)
content:
Ladies and Gentlemen, Esteemed Excellences, Dear guests! It is my honour and pleasure to address you at such a great and important gathering of professionals from all parts of Europe and the world, dedicated to the topic which I consider extremely important – the freedom of expression and journalists’ rights.
First, I would like to express my sincere regret that the member of the delegation of the Palestinian Journalists’ Syndicate, Mr Omar Nazzal is not with us today. I most strongly condemn the action of the Occupation Forces which arrested him at the border passing of al-Karameh. I hope that your colleague will be freed as soon as possible.
The new century changes the rules of journalism brining increasingly greater challenges. Development and progress in the field of technology is speedier than ever before – journalists, in their everyday work, have to follow these trends, and governments need to create legislative frameworks speedier and with more flexibility than was the case in the past, so that both would keep the pace up with the times. The public, the space in which media and politics intertwine, often has no understanding nor patience for it. Traditional media relent under the market pressures, and new media set new rules of the game. What is good in all that is the widening of space for interaction of citizens, media and governments.
Technology brings about new dynamics, but the essence of democrating forming of public opinion and relations within it remain the same: politicians, those in power or in opposition crave influence, and control over media. Media, on the other hand, crave more freedom, as well as more influence. Many politicians control journalists, and some journalists would like to control politicians.
I believe the freedom of expression is of crucial importance for development of a democratic society, and a guarantee of development and preservation of democratic conscience in general public. However, what is often forgotten is that freedom also means responsibility. I am not talking here about the responsibility towards the government, opposition, politicians – but about the responsibility for every publicly spoken word and responsibility towards citizens.
Trust is hard to gain, easy to lose, and for a success of a society trust is essential. This means that in the work of the media, and in relations between media and government, it is of crucial significance to establish quality standards at the highest level. This ranges from the legislative framework, which will protect journalists from prosecution, public personalities from slander, and citizens from manipulations – from professional and ethical norms and codices, as well as regulatory and self-regulatory mechanisms which will enable public to trust media because it is from them that the citizens seek and expect timely, truthful and complete information.
In the fourth decade of democratic transition, at the door step of the third decade of peace, Bosnia and Herzegovina has made progress in the field of establishment of democratic institutions and forming of a democratic public. We are aware that there is a lot more effort ahead of us, but the goal is clear and achievable: a democratic political framework worthy of the state which aspires to become an EU member state at soonest, free and various media, and an informed citizenry.

title: Address by the Chairperson of the Presidency of BiH Bakir Izetbegović at the central solemn event marking the 11th anniversary of the Armed Forces of BiH 2nd Infantry (Ranger) Unit and the 24th annive
content:
Dear Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina members and generals,
Esteemed representatives of the families of shaheeds and fallen soldiers, and all combatants’ associations,
Esteemed representatives of all levels of legislative and executive authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Representatives of military and diplomatic missions, media, and all guests participating in this event dedicated to marking the 24th anniversary of the Army of the Republic of BiH and the 11th anniversary of the Armed Forces of BiH 2nd Infantry (Ranger) Unit,
Ladies and gentlemen,
Today, when we renew our commitment to remembering the historical role of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is worth recalling some most important features which determined indelibly the historical dimension of establishment, performance and durability of the Bosnian and Herzegovinian armed force, which represents the essence of the enigma known as “The miracle of the Bosnian resistance“.
The Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina resembled its people. From its foundation and earliest activities, in addition to its military professionalism, it has also nurtured some distinctive values of the Bosnian and Herzegovinian spirituality, as well as of the characteristics of the peoples who live in Bosnia and Herzegovina. As in earlier decisive moments in history, when viability and subjectivity of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina were defended, the Bosniaks constituted majority within the Army structure. However, it is equally important to underline that all BiH peoples took part in defence of freedom and independence of their homeland.
The Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina differed from its opponents. Although it was faced with brutal attacks, mass crimes, destruction of religious and cultural treasures, and violence from a much better armed and equipped aggressor, it strived to conduct its defensive struggle parallel to respecting the high moral and military norms. Such respect had ensured its first and decisive victory – the Republic of BiH Army had first achieved supremacy and victory in terms of morality, and then it started winning its battles at the battlefield, too.
The Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was fighting for the universal values of civilisation and humanity. In its defensive and freedom-loving expedition, the Republic of BiH Army was recognizable for respecting the universal values of civilisation and morality – it fought against killing of the weak and the unprotected, against devastation of religious and cultural monuments of any affiliation, and for protection of many other universal principles and norms, which ensured affection and support it received from a number of justice-loving and freedom-loving countries from all over the world. Such support is present nowadays, too, and it is very important for the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina and its integration into the family of most democratic and most advanced countries of the world.
The Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina stands for one of the most obvious examples of invincibility of the people. It emerged from the people, resembled its people, and was close to its people. Thus, the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina represents a bright illustration of invincible power of the people, of their indestructible and invincible energy and ability to cope with temptations and challenges of any intensity or duration.
The Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina is yet another philosophical and practical illustration of the belief that smaller and weaker armies, when fighting for just causes, can defeat larger and stronger opponents. Justifiability of causes the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was fighting for, despite all deficiencies and limitations it was faced with, particularly in the early phase of the war, stands for one of the most distinctive reasons and explanations why the strength of the members of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as of the Army in its entirety, were growing over time, why the Army of the Republic of BiH thrived and created the final preconditions for the defence of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Committed to the future of a democratic and multi-ethnic Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Army of the Republic of BiH has never exhibited triumphalism, including at times when others expected it to do so. It has demonstrated piety to its shaheeds and fallen combatants, respect to all categories of disabled war veterans, and gratitude to all its members who contributed to the defence and liberation of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Convinced that in times that lie ahead Bosnia and Herzegovina will have an increasingly recognizable face showing unity of its diversity, we are grateful to all members of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and we extend our deepest respect to all those who built their lives, parts of their bodies and health into the possibilities of a continued existence and development of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We hope that any new anniversary of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina will be marked in such Bosnia and Herzegovina which will grow more and more free, democratic and prosperous.

title: Address by the Chairperson of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Bakir Izetbegović at the Organisation of Islamic Conference (OIC) Heads of States Summit in Istanbul
content:
President Erdoğan, Secretary General Madani, Your Excellences, Your Highnesses, Excellences, as-salāmu ʿalaykum (peace be upon you)!
I am honoured to address the thirteenth Summit of the Organisation of Islamic Conference. I would like to extend the expression of my gratitude to my dear brother – President Erdoğan, and to the Government of the Republic of Turkey for their hospitality. I congratulate them for taking over the chairmanship, and for hosting this summit. Let me extend my most sincere congratulations to the Secretary General – His Excellence Iyad Madani for his skilful leadership over the Organisation, and let me thank him for promoting the participation of my country at this summit. We appreciate very much indeed the support provided by this organisation and its members to development of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a democratic, multiethnic and multicultural state. On behalf of the Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina and of her people, let me thank you for your efforts invested in improving the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We believe that a full integration into the European Union and NATO is the best way to achieve stability, security and prosperity in Bosnia. The process of European and Euro-Atlantic integration is the most efficient tool of transforming our country and society, aimed at attaining modern democratic standards, building a competitive market economy and enhancing our economic development. I am certain that, throughout this process of maturing, we will achieve an internal consensus to file an application for membership in this organisation in the near future. In the meantime, we will do our best in order to strengthen and improve our relations and cooperation with this organisation and its member countries respectively.
The Muslim world has been faced with serious challenges, including terrorism, sectarian violence and armed conflicts – to name a few most dangerous ones. Unity, solidarity and reconciliation among the Muslim countries are necessary for addressing these challenges. We have to join forces in order to find new approaches and right solutions to the problems that we have been faced with. Negative trends can only be stopped by a coordinated action of the united Islamic ummah (community).
We shared your concern about a continued implosion of peace and stability in the world, particularly in the Near East. The Israeli-Palestinian conflict, which has lasted for over 60 years, has been the main and constant source of instability in the Near East. The standstill in finding a solution to this conflict is worrying. A New incentive for negotiations is urgently needed there. We have strongly supported the current Quartet initiative on holding a peace conference, which will bring about a durable and just solution to the Palestinian issue, based on the principles of the international law, as well as on a consensus about peaceful coexistence of the two independent and sovereign states. This is the only realistic way in which the conflict can be solved. Peace in the world has also been jeopardized by violence and crimes committed against the Syrian people. The images from Syria have reminded us of the tragedy of Bosnia – we in Bosnia have also felt the pain of the Syrian people as our own pain. It is deeply concerning that the most powerful countries in the world, including the most powerful Muslim countries, have failed so far to find a peaceful solution to the crisis in Syria.
Bosnia fully supports the Geneva peace talks. The Syrian people have to decide on the future of Syria. A peaceful future of Syria is based on respecting the political will of the Syrian people, who must be allowed to demonstrate such will at a free and democratic election. If the will of the Syrian people were respected from the start, this war would not have taken place at all. I hope that this summit will contribute to peace and democracy to be established in brotherly Syria.
The plague of terrorism has affected all of us. It is unbearably sad for the whole of Islamic ummah that some of our mentally disturbed sons have spread death and destruction throughout the world. Bosnia condemns in strongest terms the recent terrorist attacks in Ankara, Brussels, Istanbul and Lahore. We would like to extend our deepest condolences and our express our most sincere solidarity with the families of the victims, as well as with the governments and peoples of Belgium, Turkey and Pakistan.
Bosnia, too, has been affected by the phenomenon of a radical interpretation of Islam, which has resulted in violent extremism and terrorist acts in the previous few years. Deviant ideology of tafsir has found a fertile soil in the post-war Bosnian society. We were late in recognizing the dangers represented by such ideology because it is in contradiction with our own inner beings, and with our understanding of Islam. For half of the millennium, the Bosnian Muslims have practiced an inclusive Islam, protecting and supporting diversity and cultural pluralism in our society. Exclusiveness, radicalism, violent extremism and terrorism are absolutely unacceptable from the position of Islam. Such features undermine the Islamic value system and are in contradiction with the universal values of tolerance and coexistence – which have been nurtured in Bosnia for centuries, and which we have been proud of indeed.
Islam stands for light, peace, goodness, forgiveness and reconciliation. It is our duty to defend Islam from darkness, evil, violence and hatred. We have to defend a bright and beautiful face of Islam. However, we also have to oppose anything that is contributing to the growth of radicalism or extremism in our societies. We have to eliminate injustice, inequalities, reduce poverty and unemployment, particularly among the young, while offering them hopes and new opportunities.
Political, economic and social injustice against Muslims throughout the world have contributed to the growth of desperation and desolation, and created fertile soil for the phenomena of radicalism and extremism. We are now faced with the problem whose roots are deep and complex. Our governments ought to and will use force and repressive measures to respond to violence. However, such components of our response must be both surgically precise and selective because, should they not be so, they will trigger a new wave of radicalisation. The real struggle and the final victory must and can be won at an ideological level only.
The key to a solution lies in the authentic interpretation of our Islamic tradition and in development of such contemporary social and political practices which are consistent with the authentic principles and teachings of Islam. United in our solidarity, we must seek global solutions in order to root out the causes of radicalism and violent extremism. Bosnia is committed to strengthening and deepening our mutual cooperation, as well as to preventing and fighting against terrorism.
The Organisation of Islamic Cooperation has gathered the Muslim world and represented its collective voice. However, the Muslim communities of Europe – which are important parts of the Islamic ummah – have not been adequately represented in the Organisation. Europe is home to over 20 million Muslims. Some of them, like Bosniaks, are autochthonous European peoples, who have inhabited the European continent for centuries. In addition to them, millions of Muslims have arrived to Europe either within global migration processes in the second half of the previous century, or within the current dramatic migration wave. Their integration into the European societies has remained a challenge, to which this organisation should pay a particular attention.
Islam is neither a foreigner in Europe, nor alien to the European spirit. To the contrary, without the contribution of Islam to establishment of the European identity and culture, the European spirit, as we know it now, would not have existed. Muslims have sought to preserve their identity and protect their rights, while constantly trying to find a formula for integration and inclusion, for a functional combination of Islamic and European values. The European Muslims represent an invaluable social, cultural, political and economic resource for the whole of Islamic ummah. They are the best bridge for dialogue, understanding and cooperation between the Muslim world and Europe, particularly at the times of crisis and evident growth of intolerance and prejudices against Islam.
Therefore, I believe that it is of utmost importance and urgency to find a mechanism which would enable the European Muslims to receive more attention and have more significant representation in this organisation. I hereby invite the esteemed Summit to consider most seriously a possibility to establish a European group within this organisation, modelled after African, Asian and Arab group examples respectively. I hope that you will support this proposal because the European Muslims need and deserve the attention and assistance of this organisation and of its member states in addressing the challenges, which keep multiplying.
Thank you.
As-salāmu ʿalaykum!

title: Address by the Chairperson of the Presidency of BiH Bakir Izetbegović at the opening ceremony of the “19th International Economic Fair Mostar“
content:
Dear organizers, esteemed businessmen, dear president Vujanović, president Grabar-Kitarović, prime minister Vučić, deputy prime minister Kurtulmuş, ladies and gentlemen! It is my utmost pleasure to be with you again at the opening of the “International Economic Fair Mostar“, a manifestation which has grown into one of most important fairs in the country, as well as in the whole region.
Since it was founded, Mostar has been a city which has connected people, a city of businesspersons, a city of tradesmen, a junction point, and a meeting place. I am glad that this tradition is continuing, that Mostar keeps gathering businesspersons, including those who run large and small business, domestic and foreign investors. Mostar is an active and efficient centre, whose importance keeps growing from year to year slowly but surely. This kind of manifestation is precious because it sends to the world a positive message on both Mostar and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Fifty thousand visitors are expected to attend this year's Fair. I am certain that their number will continue to increase in the years to follow.
I am particularly glad that the Republic of Turkey is this year's partner country of the Fair. The cooperation in all areas between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Turkey has been enhanced in the previous years. Between 2013 and 2015, BiH exports to Turkey doubled, amounting to over three hundred and fifty million Bosnian Convertible Marks, whereas the export - import coverage ratio has risen by around 20 percent. And this is, I am convinced, only the beginning, given that there is a lot of room for cooperation, and there is mutual willingness and eagerness to deepen this cooperation. I believe that the growth of the Turkish economy will continue in the future, and that the interest for investment to BiH will increase.
There are many areas in which such cooperation can be enhanced in the future right here, in Herzegovina. First of all, I would like to underline the areas of tourism and agriculture, which have been the axes of such cooperation. Therefore, it is very good that there are a number of additional events within the present event, including the Tourism Fair. With a bit of effort invested, Herzegovina can lead in this economic field, not only within the framework of BiH, but regionally, too. The tourism offer in Mostar will be enriched early next year with an opening of the restored Hotel “Ruža“ (Rose). The restoration was funded by the Turkish Ziraat Bank. This hotel will be available to host the guests who will attend the next fair.
Before almost two months, BiH filed her application for membership in the EU. Despite all our differences, disagreements, and conflicts from the past, we have had the strength to recognize the path which leads to the future. That path is the one of progress and integration, and it will enable our citizens to use all their advantages fully. Let me remind you that our currency is stable, regulations are investment-friendly and ensure safe foreign investment inflow, our energy sources are significant, we have remarkable natural beauty and cultural heritage, and, above all, we have a sufficient number of skilled and educated people who are ready to work hard.
When I delivered my speech at the opening of the 17th Mostar Fair in 2014, the environment in the country was different. At that time, we had seen mass riots and buildings set on fire. Catastrophic floods of the unimaginable scope were about to strike at that time, too. However, we have overcome all the difficulties, preserved the stability, and now we have the reason for being optimistic again. We have based such optimism on our aspiring to achieve a common goal, i.e. the progress for Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the progress for all who live in it.
We wish betterment and progress to our neighbours, too. Bosnia and Herzegovina has been committed to ensuring closest economic cooperation with her neighbouring countries – Montenegro, Croatia and Serbia. It is good that in the current period we have shared the same determination to achieve what Croatia achieved already – a membership in the EU. Furthermore, it is good that we have been ready to help each other progress in that direction.
Bosnia and Herzegovina can do better, as indicated by the changes we initiated in the previous year, the changes within which we committed ourselves to dialogue, compromise and reforms aimed at achieving progress. Events such as this Fair are concrete steps taken in that direction.
I extend my congratulations to the organizer for the effort invested, and I wish to all a successful and fruitful work at the Fair.
Thank you.

title: Speech delivered by the Chairperson of the Presidency of BiH Bakir Izetbegović on the occasion of marking the 70th anniversary jubilee of the Faculty of Law in Sarajevo
content:
Dear Chancellor of the University of Sarajevo, dear Dean of the Faculty of Law, esteemed professors and students, dear guests, your excellences, ladies and gentlemen! Law has been studied in Sarajevo and in BiH since the 19th century. Over a century ago, the College for Sharia Judges was established, which taught courses in law and legal science, and was one of the foundations of the current Faculty of Law of the University of Sarajevo, established in 1946.
In the course of its fruitful history, this Faculty has contributed significantly to further dissemination of knowledge on law and to the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina based on the rule of law, while capacitating generations of judges, attorneys and other specialists in various legal fields.
Throughout various historical circumstances, this reputable institution has nurtured high standards of legal profession, regardless of a side its cadre has occupied as judges, prosecutors or attorneys. Such contribution of the Faculty has been most significant and durable to development of the profession and enhancement of knowledge and necessary educational standards in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is worth pointing out that the Faculty of Law of the University of Sarajevo has operated well beyond its sole service provider role in education. It has also, to a considerable extent, educated young people in the spirit of our tradition, which requires that we respect our history, origin and diversity of our cultural and religious space.
It is of particularly important for future generations to continue to develop themselves in the same spirit, as well as in the spirit of those statesmen and scientists who marked this institution, including Aleksandar Solovjev, Hamdija Čemerlić, Alija Izetbegović, Sulejman Tihić, Kasim Begić, Vlado Jokanović, Samuel Kamhi, and others.
Such process is a continuous and demanding one indeed, and it includes re-defining of objectives, needs and agency for our whole community.
Dear ladies and gentlemen,
After renewal of the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Faculty of Law of the University of Sarajevo has continued delivering its rich scientific and educational agency. Such agency is particularly important nowadays, given the primary task of Bosnia and Herzegovina and her active inclusion in Euro-Atlantic integration processes.
All important processes and relations in a modern state are regulated by laws. Well educated professionals from the field of law are the only ones who can create good and high quality laws. Only high quality and good laws can build a stable and prosperous state.
Political and social reforms are neither an easy nor a simple process.
Such reforms demand that we harmonize legislation, state administration and judiciary with the European norms and criteria. It is precisely within these processes that we expect the Faculty of Law in Sarajevo to be an active actor in harmonizing the rule of law in BiH with the EU legal framework, regulating market and modern competitive economy, in developing of a democratic state committed to respecting the human rights, rule of law and values of the international order, particularly at this time of Bosnia and Herzegovina's submission of her credible application for membership in the EU.
We have not implemented reforms due to our European path only.
This obligation is, at the same time, a basic interest of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina because a developed, democratic and prosperous state is an ultimate objective for all.
Dear ladies and gentlemen!
Let us do everything we can in order to convey to our young people an idea and a drive on advancing and preserving the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
If we work like that, I am convinced that our prospects will be good, and our future among other European states will be bright and certain.
With such wishes, I extend my congratulations to the management, professors, and, in particular, the students of the Faculty of Law of the University of Sarajevo on the occasion of marking this valuable 70th anniversary jubilee of its work and existence.

title: Address delivered by the Chairperson of the Presidency of BiH Bakir Izetbegović at the solemn academy marking the 24th anniversary of the Ministry of Interior of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Esteemed “Bosna“ Special Unit members, dear friends! I extend my congratulations to you on the occasion of marking the 24th anniversary of the first war action and beginning of the war path of the RBiH Ministry of Interior Special Unit – the Police Squad “Bosna“.
While preparing this speech, I was thinking if there was anything more that one could say about the people who were at the first lines acting as organizers and most powerful link in a chain of resistance in most critical times of defending the city of Sarajevo and the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in times when there was a thin line dividing our survival and destruction, when it was questionable, under a strike of the brutal aggression, whether we would succeed in preserving sobriety and gathering people...
Is there anything more one can say about the people who could already see everything clearly at that time, and who were ready to give up everything for the freedom of this country?
It seems that, in the course of the last two decades, we have used all expressions of gratitude in order to show them our understanding of how sincere their struggle was, how great their courage was, and how deserved our ultimate victory was.
However, we should not get tired of expressing our gratitude because those who do not learn from their past, and who do not recall it, live through the same or similar adversities again. Therefore, we will re-iterate and remember, and seek anew such words which will be our reminder that those best among us were members of the Special Squad “Bosna“.
A multiethnic composition of this Squad is a synonym of the whole Army of BiH, consisting of all patriots of this country, regardless of their religious or national affiliation. The very fact that a significant number of the Serbs and Croats wished to join this unit on voluntary basis speaks about the character of its establishment, which was both sincere a spontaneous.
The first Bosnian special force member who got killed was Ozrenko Mandić-Buco, who defended his and our homeland from Karadžić' army.
Vinko Šamarlić, a pre-war special force member and a top athlete, got killed during the attempt of the special force members to unblock Sarajevo, just a day before he was supposed to depart from Sarajevo in order to participate in the Olympic Games in Barcelona.
On behalf of these people, who chose struggle and freedom in the decisive times when one was choosing between disappearance and survival, we cannot allow that remembrance of their sacrifice and their courage fades away, that the generations who are maturing and gradually taking over this country think that our current peace and freedom have been achieved and inherited easily.
There is no other way but to re-iterate and recall. All peoples who turned their struggle into healthy and functional states built such states on inherited values carved out by the people such as Dragan Vikić and Vinko Šamarlić, Kemal Ademović and Ozrenko Mandić.
I am encouraged by the fact that I can now see ex-members of the Special Squad “Bosna“in our highest legislative and executive bodies. They are a guarantee that we will, sooner or later, in these peace-time struggles which may not be as hard as the war-caused challenges, defend our values for which we have remained loyal to this country at all times through generations.
Loyal to God, and loyal to Bosnia - as it was nicely said by the late friar Petar Anđelović.
Challenges are still ahead of us, including arduous political and economic reforms, as well as changes that we have to make on our path to the European Union. It sometimes seems that, in such political spinning wheel, the pictures from the past are fading away, that we forget, under the weight of responsibilities and pressures, how expensive each piece of this country, which we defended, was.
But, there is no oblivion! In each next temptation we will keep deriving our strength from that remembrance, from memories about the heroes of Bosnia, about the sons who cancelled the Olympic Games, weddings and careers because Bosnia and Herzegovina was more important. That is why they need to be woven into each detail, each step forward which we will make.
God bestowed physical strength and courage on many people. However, rare are the ones who will use such gift in most selfless way – who will enhance their skills through laborious training sessions and abstinence, and then expose themselves to wounds and death, while protecting the weaker ones from strong and dangerous violators and attackers. Only the ones who are chosen and best dare to and can protect citizens, peoples, and the state from any sort of criminals, attackers or aggressors. I am honoured to have met most of you personally in most difficult days this city of ours and this country lived through.
Special forces members, courageous and good people, sincere Bosnians and Herzegovinians, I extend my congratulations of this anniversary to you from the very bottom of my heart.

title: Speech delivered by Chairperson of the Presidency of BiH Dr. Dragan Čović at the reception to mark Independence Day of BiH
content:
Dear ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, Your Eminence, Your excellences! It is my special privilege to be able to welcome you tonight, on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and, of course, on my own behalf, on the occasion of marking Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina. As you can see, I will avoid any stereotypical reading of a speech, but you will allow me to feel free to bring a bit more of emotion into it on this day because I believe that the current day and the current time in Bosnia and Herzegovina deserve it.
Therefore, dear friends, at the time when we are marking Independence Day, we are still very exposed on all sides, we are very vulnerable both as an organization and as a social community, and, as you can notice, I have greeted you on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, although not all three Presidency members are together.
However, this does not diminish neither the importance of this day nor the importance of history and times that all of us have lived through together. But, there is a particular commitment, which all three Presidency members made some one year and three or four months ago, that they would not make a single decision which would question the institution they represent, that, each time when they would go anywhere either individually or together, they would represent their homeland Bosnia and Herzegovina wholeheartedly.
And that is what, exactly, will be our attitude to the current day this evening. Therefore, I extend my thanks from the bottom of my heart to all of you who are here, thank you for being here, and to all those who are listening to this speech I extend, from the bottom of my heart, my congratulations on the occasion of Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I am certain that the current time deserves a few words to be said on the past, but only a few words on the past, given that I am sure that we, from our present perspectives, have at least three different views on that past. And, I am not sure that we can change that easily.
I am certain, though, that there is something else that we can do together. We can think together in a harmonized way about the shared future of Bosnia and Herzegovina. That makes me happy, and that is what we will do together on behalf of the Presidency and all institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina, on behalf of the executive, legislative and political authorities. You can also understand my tonight’s greeting to you, as well as our gathering tonight, as an incentive to do much more for Bosnia and Herzegovina than what we have done so far.
Let us not focus all the time on our differences, on what is separating us in a certain way, but let us look upon, in a particular way, the ways of creating such an environment in Bosnia and Herzegovina which will ensure that this is a country to which people will return, in which they will stay, and in which they will want to live. As I re-iterated a number of times, there is no country in the world that is more beautiful, and it depends entirely on ourselves how well we are going to live here.
To you, dear friends, your excellences who represent international institutions in Bosnia and Herzegovina, I extend my deepest gratitude for the attention you have given us in the last 20 and more years. I am sure that we can expect you to continue paying your attention to us in the following period, too. Bosnia and Herzegovina does have its future indeed. I am sure that it is, above all, a Euro-Atlantic future.
Therefore, I am proud that, as the Chairperson of the Presidency of BiH, I can now, a little while after the submission of our application for EU membership, assert that we have made a giant step forward, regardless of how we perceive it within Bosnia and Herzegovina, and regardless of how we perceive Bosnia and Herzegovina itself, how anyone contemplates, doubts if we have deserved it, if we are credible, and if we are trustworthy. I am convinced that the time has never been better for submission of such application, and that it is up to us, together with our friends from the European Union and beyond, and with friends from the international institutions in Bosnia and Herzegovina which have commitments towards Bosnia and Herzegovina, to continue to work faster, and that we will receive a positive opinion in the course of the current year, and that we will also become a candidate for the European Union membership in the course of the next year.
There is not a single reason for us not to make another giant step forward in May and June this year, also, and not to activate our action plan regarding our membership in the NATO Alliance.
Also, I believe that you can help us a lot in this endeavour of ours, but we have to be trustworthy ourselves, and show readiness to make key, bold decisions. I think that the previous period was not characterized by such attitude.
I am convinced that we have made a key step forward, despite all the challenges that we have been faced with. The remaining tasks are now those that we have to carry out at the domestic plan.
I cannot see a single reason why anyone would consider it a division of the country if we have to ensure information sharing in a language of constitutive peoples. I cannot see why it would be a problem and division if anyone requests to select representatives on behalf of their own people. That is why I am convinced that we will have the wisdom, courage, decisiveness, patriotism and love of this homeland of ours Bosnia and Herzegovina to pass our election law shortly, in order to resolve the issue of the judgement made by the court in Strasbourg, the issue of our Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina regarding the City of Mostar, and many other issues which would include us in the group of more orderly and more organized countries in our surroundings.
Of course, the key issue is the one of living conditions of those, primarily the unemployed, who depend on politics. These are pensioners; these are many groups of people who have struggled daily to provide for their basic living needs. I am convinced that this is, perhaps, one of the key issues that we have to resolve at the domestic front, and, I will underline it again – we have to do it ourselves.
We will not succeed without new jobs, without investments. Yet, I am sure that we have so many interested friends from abroad. It is for that fact only that, for me, the submission of the application for membership is a great act. It has to motivate us, encourage us strongly to pass laws promptly at both state and entity levels, as well as at all other administrative levels, i.e. such laws which will promote the values of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and enhance investment inflow to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I think that the time has come for us to close down on admission to the state institutions and public companies. We have spent huge amounts of money on exactly those areas in which we should not be spending. If we succeed in celebrating one of the following anniversaries – i.e. 1 March 2017 or 1 March 2018 - in the way that we do not re-open such issues in this way, then we will have succeeded for sure, and then we will have a full membership in the European Union and NATO Alliance.
Regardless of when will we become full members of these institutions, I am convinced that there is sufficient decisiveness today for such membership, even among those who negate the current day. We should not confront our ideas and discussions about the current day. It is a historic date for Bosnia and Herzegovina. Unfortunately, we do not have the power to pass strong decisions concerning, for example, the law on religious holidays. It is in that realm that everything is given to us by God, and yet, we still do not have sufficient wisdom to pass a decision ourselves. How can one expect, then, that we make a decision on public holidays at the state level? Let these, simply, remain the issues that we will harmonize smoothly along our way. In the meantime, let us build such an environment in Bosnia and Herzegovina in which it is worth living, in which it is worth investing efforts dedicated to Bosnia and Herzegovina, and, therefore, I kindly ask all of you, from the bottom of my heart, all of us from Bosnia and Herzegovina, to do a bit more than we have done so far for our motherland. It is when we do it that things will be better for all. You, our friends who come from abroad, do continue to follow and criticize. You do not have to do it in public, but do provide us with your criticism when you see that we do something in a slow or bad way, and do encourage us to keep moving forward. Bosnia and Herzegovina is a guarantor of stability in the whole of eastern and western areas around us, and I hope that I do not have to convince anyone of that.
Finally, thank you, once again, for responding to this invitation. I would like to inspire you to keep providing us with strength, encouragement to work on the Euro-Atlantic project of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to work on internal stability of Bosnia and Herzegovina together, in which we will enhance economy and ensure social stability because we are not sufficiently socially sensitive now. There are too many of those who are in need.
Finally, to all of you who have Bosnia and Herzegovina in your hearts, I extend my greetings on the occasion of Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I wish you all the best, and cheers!

title: Press statement by the Chairperson of BiH Presidency Dr. Dragan Čović and the President of the Republic of Albania Bujar Nishani
content:
Dr. Dragan Čović, the Chairperson of BiH Presidency: Dear Mr President, esteemed guests, dear friends, welcome to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
