I am glad that we have hosted a truly friendly visit today for the president of the country with which Bosnia and Herzegovina does not have any unresolved issues, the president of the country with which Bosnia and Herzegovina wishes to build excellent relations at cultural, economic and any other plan in general.
Through our previous discussions, we informed the esteemed guest delegation on the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, on the role of the three-member Presidency in accelerating our journey on the Euro-Atlantic path, and on Bosnia and Herzegovina's taking the role of such actor who should bring about stabilization of the situation through all the surrounding area.
For Bosnia and Herzegovina, there is simply no alternative to the Euro-Atlantic course. As I reported, 10 days ago we had submitted our application for membership in the European Union. Also, we expect from our friends in Albania to provide their support in Warsaw for activating the Membership Action Plan (MAP).
Concerning the foreign policy, we wish to create more than good relations with our neighbours, we wish to try to do it ourselves, and, in cases in which we cannot solve unresolved issues ourselves, and I refer here primarily to the issues concerned with Serbia and Croatia, we will aim to do it in the spirit of friendly and good neighbourly relations, and with the assistance of our friends from the European Union.
It is our key, and I would call it historic, task in Bosnia and Herzegovina today to resist entropy which may stop us in these plans of ours, but also to provide our full contribution in order to avoid, for a longer period, thinking about destabilization of political or any other circumstances in our region.
I am sure that we will enhance our bilateral relations and, in some way, compensate for those past periods of isolation and simply, through our corridors, including traffic, energetic and any other, bring our peoples closer to each other.
As we have had an excellent mutual understanding of each other, as we have wished to build a friendly environment through our relations, I am sure that there are many possibilities for enhancement of our economic cooperation, and, in addition to that, I believe that our cultural connections, our tradition and heritage have actually had common sources throughout history.
Therefore, I believe that it is through various forms of cooperation that we should enable a more significant cooperation in the area of tourism.
What we would like is to provide our full contribution to all regional projects in which we have participated together, to connect not only Albania and Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also all those who share the same destiny in this area.
Thus, Mr. President, we hereby invite You, Your representatives of executive and legislative authorities, to participate in such initiatives, and that we simply make our bilateral relations more dynamic.
I think that we should make a number of agreements between our countries in order to carry out smoothly all the projects that we have in mind. In any case, I, once again, extend my gratitude for Your visit, I wish You to feel here as a friend among friends, and that our cooperation becomes much more successful in the future. You are most welcome to be our guest!
The President of the Republic of Albania Bujar Nishani:
I hereby extend my gratitude to You, the Chairperson of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, to media representatives, and to all others who are present here. I extend my gratitude for hospitality which you have demonstrated to me and my delegation.
I would like to extend my gratitude for today's meeting of our two delegations. I would like to extend my gratitude for the topics we have initiated, which concern not only our countries, but the whole region.
Namely, we are the representatives of two countries which belong to the same region, we have a lot in common, and one of these issues we have in common is, indeed, our pursuit of the Euro-Atlantic integration.
Our relations are very good, we have no unresolved issues, our relations are also friendly, and I have availed myself of this opportunity to re-iterate an open support to sovereignty and integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We have succeeded in establishing contacts and communication at a higher level and I am assured, by my very visit and the way in which I was hosted, that Bosnia and Herzegovina has a sincere and friendly attitude towards Albania.
There is a series of agreements and contracts between our countries, which illustrate indeed such relations we have had.
Lately, a rise in exchange of goods between our two countries has been registered, and there is, certainly, a possibility that such exchange is enhanced to an even higher level.
There are sixteen companies from Bosnia and Herzegovina in Albania now. These companies have been included in various ways in industrial and economic development of Albania.
We have indeed worked towards strengthening of the economic cooperation and economic development of the two countries, which has not been reduced to our two countries only. Namely, we have also focused on the economic development at the level which is surely regional, and even wider.
One of the significant projects, which will certainly be of our mutual benefit, is the corridor of the Adriatic-Ionian Motorway.
I also mentioned today a possibility of creating a better environment for free movement of goods and persons between the two countries, and expressed my wish and hope that one day we would be able to visit these countries without passports, i.e. that we would be able to visit each other with identity cards only.
It is our shared goal to ensure free movement of goods and persons, particularly in the economic sense, because this is important. It is in this way that we can also achieve improved economic exchange.
In this sense, also, it is the Euro-Atlantic integration which is extremely important.
I am glad that recently, a few days ago, Bosnia and Herzegovina made another step towards the European Union and submitted her application for membership in the European Union.
Our country Albania already made such step. We have expected the next one in that direction.
I now avail myself of the opportunity to extend my congratulations to the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to Bosnia and Herzegovina as a whole, for all steps they have made, including numerous reforms, in order to get closer to the European Union.
I have also expressed my firm support to Bosnia and Herzegovina for her integration into NATO, in the same way in which we expressed such support for any other country in the region with such aspirations.
In this sense, Albania fully supports all steps, including those which refer to MAP Action Plan for joining, i.e. for membership of Bosnia and Herzegovina in NATO.
I have also expressed my wish that Bosnia and Herzegovina, among others, provides her support for membership of Kosovo in the Adriatic Charter. I believe that such step will only provide an additional contribution to stabilization of our region.
In the past, this region passed indeed through difficult times and burden which made relations more difficult. However, nowadays we have had new circumstances under which our relations have been relaxed.
In this sense, my position has been expressed that the present time should be used for as better cooperation as possible.
In this sense, I have also expressed the official position of the Government of Albania that Albania is oriented to good neighbourly relations and stabilization in the region of South Eastern Europe.
I have expressed my position that, in order to have good relations within the region, inclusion of all countries in the region is necessary.
Our cooperation in the region, as well as our accession to the Euro-Atlantic integration, demands specific steps to be made.
I have also expressed a firm support to Bosnia and Herzegovina and her current role in the Brdo-Brioni initiative, within which a series of meetings will be held in May in Sarajevo. We openly support this initiative and we are glad it is happening.
In this sense, I have initiated the issue of revision or re-consideration of a possibility of recognition of Kosovo by Bosnia and Herzegovina, and of recognition of documents of Kosovo by Bosnia and Herzegovina, because I believe that such step would be good, not only for improved relations between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo, but also for the whole region.
We have also discussed another shared interest, i.e. the coordination and cooperation in the area of security issues. We know that security has been threatened greatly by terrorism, as well as by the recent events in Syria, Iraq, and Afghanistan, where our joint action would be needed in order to address these issues.
Finally, let me re-iterate my gratitude to the hosts for their hospitality. I believe that this visit will initiate our enhanced relations.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member from Republika Srpska Dr Mladen Ivanić at the Christmas reception
content:
Christmas – the birth of Christ – is a holiday of love, peace and family, universal values for all people and for all times. This day brings us immaterial, but life's important values which cherish the history of men and lead to salvation.
In today's troubled times, we all deep down ask ourselves – what is the key message of Christmas? How do we greet with “God's Peace“ today – because on the dawn of Christmas Orthodox Christians have for centuries been sending the message, that is, the greeting – God's Peace.
The modern man has brought the planet and nature to the brink of destruction, people are waging wars in the name of God, although they should be spreading peace and love in His name. Through the modern migration of people we are watching the pictures of the Old Testament and migrations in the Middle Ages, we are keeping ourselves from others by building wired fences. We are opposing cultures, nations, religions. We live in the world in which the values system is pretty distorted.
We measure people against our needs, not against of what they really are. Strength and will is needed to resist this illness of selfishness which has made many people unhappy throughout history.
Patriarch Pavle said – “It is difficult to be a man amongst men”. These words carry their weight, especially today when many, and not only in politics, adapt the apocalyptic recipe of evilness which states – I “alone” am the measure for everything and if there isn’t me, there won’t be you! A selfish man is not a man of community, because a community assumes love towards another, care for another.
Because of that we need to find a measure in Bosnia and Herzegovina between a totally legitimate need to preserve identity of each of our peoples, on the one hand, and the necessity of a life together, on the other. I am convinced that it is possible to achieve this measure through greater mutual trust and through willingness to compromise. It is most important that we fight for better well-being of all, that we do not steal from one another nor from the community in which we live, that we are not isolated but that we are part of a larger and let’s hope happier family of European peoples.
I wish all Serbs in Republika Srpska, but also Serbs in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, our brothers in Serbia, Croatia, Montenegro and Diaspora, as well as other Orthodox Christians in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the world, to spend the forthcoming Christmas holidays with their closest ones in good spirit and to, at least then, forget all problems which burden our everyday living.
What is, therefore, the message of Christmas today?
The same one it was 2016 years ago and which states – love, peace, family. And this message has no alternative.
However strange these immaterial messages may sound to us in this material world – we are invited to renew them in ourselves and to live them, because out of love for a man and his salvation, God steps into this world. Out of love of God, the world and a man we celebrate Christmas and should not forget the magnificent, early Christian, ancient, but also the all-times message:
“Glory to God in the highest heaven, and on earth peace, good will toward men” (Luke, 2 14).
To all of you who came tonight I am sincerely grateful to, and I merrily greet you and your families with our traditional greeting:
God's Peace – Christ is born!

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of BiH Dr Dragan Čović at the reception marking Christmas
content:
Esteemed ladies and gentlemen, Your Eminences, Your Excellences, dear friends,
As in each previous year, which has become a tradition, what has gathered us here is a pre-celebration joy, which we wish to share with you. Therefore, do allow me, dear friends, to extend, as your host, as well as on behalf of the Croat people in Bosnia and Herzegovina executive, legislative and political positions holders, greetings to you from the bottom of my heart. I am glad that tonight, more than ever before, our commitment to be happy together because of this great Catholic celebration has gathered us, and for that I extend my deepest gratitude to you.
My joy would be much greater if one of the greatest Christian celebrations could be marked in the same way throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina, and everywhere in the world. Unfortunately, we know it is not like that, there are more and more people in need, those who expect a next day, full of incertitude, with grave worries.
There are more and more children in the world whose parents cannot see their future. The war areas have been widened continuously, security threats have deleted borders, and we have witnessed daily most horrific crimes committed in the name of religion, nation, skin colour, and a wide variety of other diversities.
Well, let our tonight's shared wish and belief prompt minds and hearts of all those who can change the world, so that these Christmas celebrations can become celebrations of love, joy and family warmth. Let us be open to another man – our brother, let us nurture and protect diversity.
Dear friends, esteemed guests, it is possible that, tonight, in this solemn ambience, we ourselves do not have the courage to change the world. However, it is most likely that we can and must change our society, our homeland Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I would like to hear a sound argument why would we not organize our country by her men's needs, ensuring human dignity, and full constitutional equal rights for all three constituent peoples. Why would we not build a full political stability, which would ensure a sway of investment inflow, economic growth and social stability.
Our foreign policy, which has achieved results, is based on a subtle friendly good neighbourly relation, for which there is no alternative, in the same way in which there is no alternative to our Euro-Atlantic course.
We have been building a modern society in a direct way. This society is now at its turning point. Such turning point, first of all, is reflected in our clear commitment on achieving internal stability through making compromises ourselves in order to solve problems.
That same turning point must present us as credible in the Euro-Atlantic project. This means clear acceptance of the standards of the organizations we are announcing to join, so that in January we can file an application for membership in the European Union, and in June open the NATO Membership Action Plan.
There is a lot yet we have to get done together in order to, through changes of election legislation and ensuring a rational organization of Bosnia and Herzegovina, eliminate an urge for dissatisfaction to be felt by any constituent people or citizen of this beautiful country.
Finally, let the celebration of Christmas, the birth of little Jesus, provide us with both motivation and strength to express our happiness together, while building peace, prosperity, joy and love between all peoples. As Jesus Christ means stands for love itself, let faith in Him make us better people.
To all Christians I wish a merry Christmas, and to all of us I wish a happy and successful New 2016.
Dear friends, enjoy yourselves in the warmth of tonight's collectiveness. Once again, thank you for being here and may dear God guard and follow you and your dear ones.

title: Speech delivered by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at the reception on the occasion of marking the Statehood Day of BiH
content:
Your excellences, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends! I hereby extend my greetings to you both on my own behalf and on behalf of the Chairman of the Presidency of BiH Dragan Čović. I thank you for participating, with a wish that, after this evening's celebration, at which we traditionally mark the Statehood Day of BiH, we get to embrace, even more decisively, the possibilities lying ahead of us.
We are remembering tonight a very important date from the history of our country, the date on which the statehood of our country was renewed, and her historical and legal continuity, based on the principles of full equality of all her peoples and citizens, was confirmed. By extending my gratitude to the generation that built the foundations of the sovereignty of BiH, let me dedicate my present address to our young compatriots - those who will inherit this country soon. That is why I will talk more about the future, about a need to open up venues to hope, to open up venues towards better life and changes, and narrow down the space for anxiety, uncertainty and apathy that have troubled our youth.
I invite all of us to encourage each other on that path, assured that better days will come, and that they must come.
Dear ladies and gentlemen!
Let us not turn to the past too much, while repeating that the situation used to be better then, and that it would be hard to achieve such prosperity ever again. The living standards in this country were, actually, more modest a few decades ago. There used to be more people who were poor, illiterate, unemployed, there used to be more places without roads, water or power supplies. There used to be villages without schools and teachers. The dissolution of the state union, which BiH used to belong to, was preceded by dissolution of the economic system, marked with a tri-digit inflation rate.
That is why we should not close venues to optimism. All indicators show that this country is moving forward, despite the large scale, almost inestimable, devastation caused by the war.
We have made visible progress within less than a year:
We responded to the British-German initiative by signing BiH Presidency Statement on our commitment to Europe and on necessary reforms on the path to the EU. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement was activated.
The Reform Agenda was adopted at both the level of entities and the Council of Ministers of BiH. This happened despite the artificially generated crisis in the first half of 2015, the crisis which was aimed at paralyzing the Government of FBiH; the unfortunate event in Zvornik; and another unfortunate event which followed in Srebrenica. Even under such circumstances, we managed to stay on the course of reforms and pass a new labour law. A general political consensus was reached on the reform course of BiH. We established, for the first time in the last 10 years, a strong “reform coalition” at both Federal and state level. This coalition has implemented the ongoing reforms decisively.
Gross domestic product rate has kept growing. We have a visible industrial growth, particularly the growth rate in exports. Tourism recorded a 28% growth this year. We had 10.000 newly employed persons until 1 November, which is supporting evidence to my promise on 100.000 new jobs to be generated in the following decade. Such employment growth rate has been unprecedented in the last decade.
Dear ladies and gentlemen!
We will not allow it that the future generations make reference to our indecisiveness. Our leaders were determined 23 years ago to keep this country in her internationally recognized borders, determined to return lost freedom and peace to our peoples. The fact that we are celebrating the Statehood Day today in a free, peaceful country is enough for us to remember them with the sense of pride and gratitude.
Their courage and determination has obliged us to stop conducting our discussions, TV daily news, conferences, lectures and receptions doubting in this country and her future.
Let us start encouraging each other on the path of economic growth, employment generation, and investment growth. Let us stop counting bad news, which will always be around, let us count investments, new tourists, and new employment posts instead.
It seems that there is no better opportunity than the present one for me to invite you to join a new wave of energy, and new optimism.
Dear ladies and gentlemen!
This is our country. We have no other motherland. She is more than beautiful, a rich country, which belongs equally to all our citizens at every inch of her territory.
Let us stop making new divisions. Let us gather, invite, forgive each other, even when it seems that all bridges are destroyed and that another river shore is distant.
Let us build bridges between us. No political option carrying this country in its heart is excluded from the process of reforms, whose implementation has started. All are welcome to join and support this process.
There will be no justification for missing the current historic opportunity we have. There is no justification for weakness, indecisiveness or faintheartedness. It is the future of this country that is at stake, and we are at a historical crossroads. Let us all be aware of that shared responsibility.
It will not be enough to say that we had wishes and readiness only. What will remain, what next generations will find themselves in, in what direction we will lead this country ultimately, that is indeed what will be remembered and what will count.
Dear ladies and gentlemen, dear friends!
Let us have faith in what we do for the benefit of this country and her citizens. Day by day, we will reassure all the fainthearted ones by showing that this country can, and that she does indeed move in the right direction.
Unlike now, we did not have such positive momentum a year ago. The current momentum is a benefit achieved by working, commitment, as well as belief.
In the course of the last year, we directed all our strengths to raising standards of the citizens and to the implementation of reforms. Do support us in this. Each voice of encouragement is important. Each word of support is welcome.
Seventy two years passed since the statehood of BiH had been restored, and two decades since it was confirmed in Dayton. There were deadlocks and crises in the post-Dayton period. However, I am convinced that we have finally started moving forward towards the goal which gathers all of us. It puts together me in Sarajevo, and Dragan in Mostar, and Mladen in Banja Luka, it gathers all of us in BiH. We are building a safe and prosperous future for our children and grandchildren.
In the name of this, I congratulate the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina to you. Thank you.

title: Press statements delivered by the Chairman of the Presidency of BiH Dr Dragan Čović and President of the European Council Donald Tusk
content:
The Chairperson of the Presidency of BiH Dr Dragan Čović: Good afternoon. I am glad that we have hosted our dear friend Donald Tusk today. We discussed the current problems in the whole of Europe, while focusing on BiH in particular.
My colleague Izetbegović and I informed our dear friends and guests on what we were doing in BiH, as an example of behaviour which could be adopted in our wider area, shared details on our foreign policy, our European, i.e. Euro-Atlantic path, on what we accomplished internally regarding economic and social stability in BiH, reorganization within the institutions in charge of security, intelligence agency, our judiciary, in order to ensure that we could act as partners in the difficult ongoing moments at the global scene.
Security problems that surround us should by no means be used as a reason to stop us on this Euro-Atlantic path. Moreover, we believe that this is, actually, a good opportunity for BiH to strengthen everything that she failed to strengthen in the previous 10-year period, in order to ensure that we submit our application for membership and continue with commitments we have made and defined in our agenda. We also discussed the latter issue with Ms Mogherini yesterday.
In the course of the last six months, we have really worked at all administrative levels in BiH in order to change the way of thinking of all our friends from the European Union on our European course because we are aware that, due to these problems, there are not many of those in the European Union who have been thinking about enlargement. However, the current phase of our application and path towards a candidate status will also stabilize all of us in BiH; such decisions will provide additional encouragement for us to continue, with more intense dynamics, to stabilize not only BiH, but also the environment both to the east and to the west of BiH.
We are aware that our commitments to the Euro-Atlantic path, for which there is no alternative, are not made because of our friends from the European Union, but because of ourselves, because of our country, because of our citizens and, simply, as I already stated, on that path, for which there is no alternative, we must demonstrate today in practical terms that we strongly want it in each segment of our lives, at both domestic and foreign policy fronts.
We know that there are issues in BiH which we must resolve decisively. One of these issues, which keep causing certain doubts, includes the issue of the referendum in the RS. Such issues must get resolved among us within BiH by reaching our internal agreement. Of course, I, once again, extend my gratitude to Mr Tusk for his visit, his encouragement, and I am convinced that each new report prepared by the European Union will be more and more positive for us, who have been working on the front of our speedy integration into the European family.
President of the European Council Donald Tusk:
Thank you, President Čović, for finding time to meet me today. Firstly, I would like to pay my respects to the victims of the terrorist attack, which took place recently in BiH. Terrorism affects all of us, terrorism knows no borders and, as we could see from the recent terrorist attacks here in Sarajevo, but also in Paris, Ankara, Beirut, Bamako, and Sinai, the danger of terrorism has not ceased to exist. We must work together to ensure that hope and future prevail over fear and terror. This is our shared responsibility. I appreciate your commitment to solving this problem, and your efforts invested in addressing the challenge, particularly here in Sarajevo. This also implies working towards prevention of radicalization and fighting against extremism. Another challenge, the current challenge that we have been faced with now, is migration, i.e. the refugee crisis. The number of refugees moving along the migration routes, including those located across Europe, is unprecedented, and the situation has additionally worsened by the fact that the groups of refugees have been additionally, jeopardized, so to say, by those who have been trying to smuggle certain elements in these groups. In order to stay in control, it is necessary to have a comprehensive plan and a coordinated operation in the whole region. I recently visited Belgrade, and I also visited Tirana and Skopje. The European Union will organize a special summit with Turkey next week. Two weeks ago we had a special summit organized with African countries. In fact, all this is a part of a joint plan, the plan with one goal, and that goal is to stop the influx of refugees and immigrants to Europe.
All states, including the European Union members, have responsibility and obligation to secure our external borders and to respond in an adequate way to the situation that has been changing quickly. Coordination is a key word here. I came to BiH with that same message. The European Union is at your disposal to provide assistance in stabilizing the situation, including security and humanitarian aspects, which are equally important.
I would like to say a few more words on the second important issue that I want to mention. This month we are marking the 20th anniversary of the Dayton Peace Agreement. BiH has lived for too long in the Dayton's shadow. I would like to support the efforts invested by BiH in the sense of progressing along the European path and achieving the European future for all your citizens. It is of key importance that we continue to invest great efforts aimed at these positive changes. Indeed, there are a certain number of challenges ahead of us, and these challenges should be addressed. However, the current momentum must be maintained, it must be used for the benefit of this country in order to ensure that BiH can achieve progress and, finally, leave that past behind.
Mr Chairman, the European Union will continue to support BiH in her efforts. Also, I will personally continue to support BiH. I strongly believe that there is no other alternative for BiH, and that the European future is the only alternative for this country.

title: Speech delivered by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at the Srebrenica 2015 Investment and Development Conference - Development Possibilities and Perspectives for the Municipality of Srebrenica
content:
My esteemed colleague Ivanić, your excellences, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends! It is my pleasure to greet you at the beginning of this very important “Srebrenica 2015“ Investment and Development Conference.
In particular, I would like to greet the Prime Minister of the Republic of Serbia Aleksandar Vučić. It is with great pleasure that I also greet Rafet Husović, Deputy Prime Minister of Montenegro, Dr. Denis Zvizdić, Chairperson of the Council of Ministers of BiH, officials from the Republika Srpska entity, President Milorad Dodik and Prime Minister Željka Cvijanović, as well as the entity ministers and other officials who are present here.
I would like to express my sincere respect and appreciation to the ambassadors of our friendly countries and international organizations for everything they have done for our country, who are also with us today, as well as numerous investors and businessmen. Your presence, as well as the support you have provided to Srebrenica, mean a lot to us.
I am grateful to a diligent team of organizers of this investment and development conference, led by Mayor Ćamil Duraković. It is thanks to their proactive engagement that investors, businessmen and politicians have met today in Srebrenica, with the intention to turn this environment into an investment-friendly destination, and a place for a better life.
Srebrenica and the Central Podrinje Region were an arena of fierce conflicts a few decades ago, resulting in a high number of crimes committed, and, ultimately, with a genocide committed against the Bosniaks, in which over eight thousand men were killed.
First connotations to Srebrenica include the war, funerals, commemorative events, the graves. That is why the interest of investors in Srebrenica has been insufficient, and the lives of its citizens has been hard.
It is our obligation to keep changing that image, and that is why we have gathered here today. The times we live in are turbulent, burdened by crises and challenges. However, the composition of today's event bears witness to our readiness to, through shared working and good neighbourly relations, in good faith, solve all difficulties and develop investment-friendly prerequisites in this town.
It is by this conference that we should open a new chapter in the life of Srebrenica and its people, as well as ensure satisfaction and benefit for all by enhancing positive trends in our relations with Serbia and other countries in the region to overall satisfaction and benefit of all.
We wish life to return to Srebrenica, we wish to meet young married couples with children here, who, like generations before them used to, walk smiling through the town; we wish to see satisfied people who will realize their dreams in this town and have successful business and family lives.
I am sure that we can achieve this if we use advantages we have, as well as opportunities ahead. Most important, albeit insufficiently used advantage, includes natural resources this municipality has on its disposal. In particular, mineral resources (copper, zinc, silver, bauxite, gold, decorative stone), forest resources, mineral and therapeutic waters (i.e. veliki guber, sinusna voda, očna voda, ljepotica, kožna voda, mali guber – kinds of therapeutic water available which heal various diseases), natural resources favourable for development of agriculture, and the very important cultural and historical heritage.
Srebrenica and the Central Podrinje Region have got all necessary prerequisites to become economically attractive to serious business and to serious investors.
Some investors have recognised the potential of this area, and have already invested in it. Today and tomorrow we will hear about their positive experiences. I extend gratitude to them, and invite them to continue strengthening the capacities.
I hope that their experience will help businessmen, domestic and foreign alike, to recognize opportunities to increase their capital by investing to Srebrenica, while generating jobs, encouraging the economic development of Srebrenica and the region, and ensuring that the citizens of these areas have access to dignified life.
We, politicians, will be their true supporters in such effort.
I wish you to spend pleasant days in Srebrenica, to reaffirm old and make new friendships during this conference, and to create as many successful business stories as possible. It is my wish that you return to Srebrenica as often as possible, and to always be satisfied on departure.
Do invest in Srebrenica, the now is the right time to do so!

title: Speech by BiH Presidency Chairperson Dragan Čović at the opening of the 11th World Islamic Economic Forum (WIEF) in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia
content:
Excellences, ladies and gentlemen! Sustainable development meets the needs of the present, while not jeopardizing needs of the next generations. Sustainable development achieves balance between calls for an enhanced quality of life, provision of social benefit and peace for all, and calls for protection of environmental components of natural wealth that both current and future generations depend on.
Respecting the principles of democracy, gender equality, social justice and solidarity, legality, the rights of man, protection of natural wealth, cultural heritage and environment contribute to protecting the Earth in order to sustain life in all its diversity. In this way sustainable development has been achieved by dynamic economy with full employment, economic, social and territorial connectedness, high educational level of citizens, as well as by protection of health and environment.
Sustainable development presupposes achievement of three general goals: stable economic development, fair distribution of social capabilities, and environmental protection. It also brings about changing the whole concept within which we operate, and, moreover, changing ourselves, too. Institutional framework and public services must ensure preconditions for this and plan for such strategy and development that are based on principles of sustainability, i.e. less focus on maximum profit, and more on community and environmental benefit. There will be no change without efforts invested by each individual. Furthermore, what is essential is mutual cooperation.
We have witnessed massive inequality in the world. The 2% of the rich use 85% of resources, while they produce 90% of waste. That is why it is always important to discuss sustainable development. Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development UN General Assembly Resolution, adopted on 25 September this year, as an action plan for people, planet and prosperity, was made in the spirit of continued importance of discussing sustainable development. The 2030 Agenda also aims to strengthen global peace and eliminate poverty in all its forms and dimensions, including extreme poverty, as most serious global challenge and irreplacable precondition for sustainable development.
17 sustainable development goals and their 169 associated targets indicate the scope and ambition of this new universal agenda. They constitute integreated and indivisible balance of the three dimensions of sustainable development: economic, social and ecological, while, at the same time, they take into account different national realities, capacities and levels of development, and respect national policies and prioities of each country concerned. In addition to the environmental balance, this presupposes both economic stability and social justice.
Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot, by any means, be viewed outside the global trends. It has often been the experience of this country that global trends have followed her, and drasticaly impacted all her internal and external spheres of life and work, even when she has not followed such trends herself.
Sustainable development, as one of the objectives of the strategic development of Bosnia and Herzegovina, refers to development of environment and of the environmental infrastructure, of energy and renewable energy resources, transport infrastructure and telecommunications, and development of agriculture and rural areas aimed at diversification of economic activities.
Key challenges to enhancement of sustainable deveopment, which need to be addressed, are:
· globalization and global financial and economic crisis
· climate changes – vulnerability of Bosnia and Herzegovina to floods, droughts, and other extreme events
· rapid decrease of non-renewable energy resources and increase of energy costs
· position of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the region (i.e. in the regions it belongs to) and cooperation with her neighbours
One of the consequences of the 1992-1995 war in Bosnia and Herzegovina is emigration of highly skilled labour force, which has strongly affected the country's developement. The World Bank estimates that the percentage of highly educated emigrants from BiH amounts to 28.6%. There is not precise data on “brain drain“ from the county, but, as an illustration of its scope, it can be mentioned that 79% of engineers and researchers in the area of technical sciences – 81% of MA degree holders and 75% of PhD degree holders, left Bosnia and Herzegovina. Nowadays, professors, researchers and experts of BiH origin, ready to help BiH through some form of temporary arrangement, work at European and American universities and at leading global companies.
Moreover, around 260,000 children of primary and secondary school age also left the country during the war. Many of them, in addition to the new generations, obtained tertiary education in the meantime.
Therefore, all of us together must work more and better in order to create new forces capable of implementing necessary and agreed changes in the country because progressing towards sustainable development is a social choice made by individuals and families, communities, civil society associations and organizations, as well as by executive and legislative authorities. For the very reason that it includes a possibility of choice making, change is possible only if based on wide inclusion of both the wider public and decision makers as the process concerned is a two-direction road.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, pursuant to her firm commitments, wishes to join the European Union and, therefore, has attempted, by her development policy, to enhance as much as possible the competitiveness of her economy. By doing so, she has aimed to fulfill the economic condition for becoming a member of the EU society.
Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are set as the main pillar of the European Union's economic system. SMEs constitute 60% of employment in the private sector, while, in some economic areas (e.g. metal processing sector, civil construction, furniture production), SMEs employ as many as over 80% of labour force.
Comparison between the current policies of enterpreneurship development in BiH and the five strategic areas the European Commission operates within, implies the following key challenges in the next mid-term period:
· enhancing entepreneurship-focused thinking;
· encouraging people to become enterpreneurs;
· supporting enterpreneurs to become more competitive;
· improving financial flows directed to enterprises in order to enable them to maintain their solvency;
· creating a better regulatory and administrative environment for small and medium enterprises.
Enhancing shared economic space and inclusiveness into regional markets and in the European Union market opens up possibilities, previously unthought of, for economic and social development in Bosnia and Herzegovina and for overcoming problems of apsorption capacity of a very small domestic market with inferior solvency margins.
At the same time, the term “shared economic space“ should not be exclusively linked to the arrangement of the interior space in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Exactly to the contrary, accepting the EU rules and standards, and including Bosnia and Herzegovina in the wider regional and EU market, will mean that the problem of creating a shared economic space is definitely solved, regardless if the internal space of Bosnia and Herzegovina is viewed on its own, or if her position is viewed in the wider regional integrations, and in the European Union itself.
Key political, social, technological and environmental factors that affect international competitiveness of Bosnia and Herzegovina, her macrostability, EU path, and, thus, her capability for sustainable development and employment generation are:
· changing demographic picture of both Europe and Bosnia and Herzegovina: ageing of the population, increased life expectancy, lower birth rates with strong impacts on pension and health systems, circulation of educated people to countries which are economically more powerful
· climate changes and constantly increasing imporance of renewable energy resources
· enhanced international competitiveness in the long-term, as a result of the increased economic globalization, and the “middle-income trap“ as a threat to Bosnia and Herzegovina and countries at the same level of development as BiH
· enhancing the role of innovation and research activities, which have become the central element of economic development
· global financial and economic recession with its consequences to economic partners of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to Bosnia and Herzegovina herself
· unstable prices of energy sources and food at the global market.
Experience of the European countries has indicated that employment generation is an irreplacable path leading to a modern society. The features of employment generation are:
· enterpreneurship reflected in creating as many small and medium enterprises as possible, and restructuring of the current enterprises, aimed at including as many people as possible who will be enabled to actively affect their destiny, and
· new approach to regional and local development, which is primarily relying on one's own strengths.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, despite relatively big problems she has had in the previous years, has preserved, to a high extent, her geo and bio diversity, which can be used as solid foundation for her sustainalble development. Adoption of the EU acquis communautaire in the near future should be done in the function of sustainable development, and it should not represent a burden to the economy, i.e. her competitiveness should be strengthened and not weakened. The area which can contribute most to sustainable development is an increased efficiency of energy usage.
Furthermore, Bosnia and Herzegovina has significant land area, almost an ideal climate, and processing industry developed to a significant extent, so that agriculture can strongly service her own food market, while she can export her food.
However, there is a number of challenges at that path. Economic globalization has made state borders more and more relative and given opportunities to capable enterpreneurs, while the role of state public administrations is to contribute, through their activities, to increased competitiveness and capabilities of enterpreneurs in the territory which is as large as possible.
Sustainability has become an art of making a right choice within the existing frameworks, which are not ideal. Sustainability is not a “fixed condition of harmony“. This is the leading idea for the 21st century. Namely, in the centre of its concensus, this idea accepts the following three dimensions: environmental, economic and social, which must be viewed with the same level of respect within local, regional and national strategies of sustainable development, as well as within international agreements achieved in the framework of global governance, aimed at ensuring sustainable development.
It is obvious that Bosnia and Herzegovina has been faced with a challenging path leading to her achievement of sustainable development goals, which are necessary for future generations, and a path leading to creating her legal and economic system in accordance with the EU standards and regulations. However, this is the only possible approach on the path of becoming a full member of the Union, and of becoming competitive to other countries in the region in terms of enterpreneurship and development. In order to overcome obstacles on her path and advance through the process of accession, Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to accept all her differencies and specific features, as well as her own constitutional structure, and use to a maximum extent the capable and healthy human potential in the society, such potential that is willing to move the country forward, in order to ensure joy and satisfaction for the next generations, who will follow after us.
Thank you.

title: Adress by dr. Mladen Ivanić, Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina June Session of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe Strasbourg, June 24, 2015
content:
Dear Madame President of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe; First of all, please allow me to express my gratitude for the opportunity to address you today. I am actually accustomed to call you my colleagues, since less than a year ago, I was one of the parliamentarians myself. I had the privilege to meet and befriend many of you, exchange opinions, discuss current events, and even share common fears. These friendships I will keep for the rest of my life.
I had an honour to serve as one of the acting vice presidents of this Assembly. Today, I address you as the Chairman of the Presidency of the Country chairing the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe for the first time in its history.
You are directly elected representatives of 800 million citizens across the lands stretching from the Atlantic to the Pacific, from the Northern Sea to the Mediterranean. It’s a position of prestige, but of immense responsibility as well.
We started our Chairmanship a little over month ago determined to perform our duties with the utmost responsibility and dedication. We cannot promise to be the best Chairmanship ever, but we can promise to do the best we can.
Please allow me to tell you a few words about the current situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Naturally, it is not ideal and there is still a lot to be done.
The Chairmanship of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe is also an opportunity to underline the great progress the Region of South East Europe has achieved over the past two decades, most notably, the establishment of the friendly and well-coordinated cooperation between our countries, accession of Slovenia and Croatia to the EU, and the dedication of the rest of the region to follow in their footsteps.
Twenty years ago one could hardly have imagined that Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia would simultaneously chair the two most important European organizations in the field of Security, Human Rights, and the Rule of Law, the Council of Europe and the OSCE. However, that is the reality of today. Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia not only chair Council of Europe and OSCE, but have a close and straightforward coordination of their activities, all in order to have the best possible response to the emerging crisis our continent is faced with today.
Mrs. President, ladies and gentlemen members of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe,
Sixty years ago founders of the Council of Europe found the courage and wisdom to build, here in Strasbourg on the ruins of the old Europe, the foundation of this organization, built to ensure the peace, stability, human rights, democracy, and the rule of law for all.
Unfortunately, the latest dramatic events, namely the terrorist attacks in the heart of Europe, humanitarian disaster in the Mediterranean, fragile truce in Ukraine remind us all that security, democracy, human rights, and the rule of law can never be, nor should be taken for granted.
The principles Council of Europe is built upon are confronted today with one of the most serious crisis, threatening to shatter the peace and stability on our Continent.
The question is what to do and how to overcome this crisis?
I am of the opinion that the last Secretary General's Report on State of Democratic Security in Europe can give us a part of an answer:
· Full commitment of the member states to fully respect the conventions and values of this organization;
· The use of exceptional know-how and so called soft power of the Council of Europe in order to intensify the struggle against hatred, intolerance, and radicalism;
· The full commitment by the member states to ensure that democracy, human rights, and the rule of law becomes the integral part of the European security system.
With that in mind I wish to express my support for the recently adopted Action Plan to fight the radicalism and terrorism by the Committee of Ministers, as well as the adoption of Additional Protocol to the Council of Europe Convention on prevention of terrorism relating to the issue of foreign fighters.
We are all concerned about the fact that many young Europeans, both men and women are joining terrorist organizations, most notably in Syria and Iraq. These people are numbered in thousands, which is a disturbing thought.
Therefore, I wish to use this opportunity to invite all member states to sign this additional protocol as soon as possible. It is my strong belief that this protocol should be open for signatures in the following months.
Problems we face today transgress the international borders, meaning they cannot be solved by countries individually. Only by working together, the member states of the Council of Europe in close cooperation with the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, the Committee of Ministers and the Congress can successfully tackle these challenges.
The Assembly, as the direct representative of 800 million of our citizens has a very important role to make.
Your activity in the establishment of the Alliance of Parliamentarians against the hate speech, as well as your recent debates on the problem of discrimination in Europe, on radicalism and terrorism, cybercrime, refugee crisis in the Mediterranean, and the decision to establish the status of the partner for democracy for the parliamentary delegations from the neighbouring region confirm your political wisdom and sense of momentum to react timely.
Since its foundation, the Council of Europe has amassed its magnificent system of conventions, covering practically all walks of life. With the European Court of Human Rights and the unique system of monitoring the implementation of its judgements, our organization has positioned itself as a global reference in the domain of human rights. At this point; please let me express our desire to see European Union soon resolve its procedural difficulties in order to become a contracting party to the European Convention on Human Rights.
Our commission for democracy through law, THE VENICE COMMISSION is renowned international authority in a domain of constitutional law, and its recommendations are sought after and applied even outside of the Council of Europe.
Over the past two decades, Europe has experienced huge political and institutional shifts. Despite of these changes, the Council of Europe with its three main pillars of activities- Human rights, democracy, and the rule of law- continue to have an important impact on the institutional architecture of our continent. Of course, it needs regularly to adopt itself to the circumstances of the given era and events, and remain open for new ideas and cooperation with other European and International organizations.
Today, seventy six years after the inception of the Council of Europe, the threats to peace and stability may have taken a different form, but the answer remains the same: democracy, human rights, the rule of law, respect for others, and those who are different.
Let us use wisely the capital our predecessors have built over the last seven decades in our best interests and the interests of the future generations.
Thank you very much.

title: Speech delivered by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at Central British manifestation for marking the 20th anniversary of genocide in Srebrenica at Westminister Abbey in London
content:
I have joined you today at Westminster Abbey at this solemn marking of the Memorial Day on the occassion of the 20th anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide.
Excellences,
Ladies and gentlemen,
Dear friends!
I have joined you today at Westminster Abbey at this solemn marking of the Memorial Day on the occassion of the 20th anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide.
We have gathered here in order to remember the 8,372 Bosniak men and boys of Islamic faith, who were killed in Srebrenica twenty years ago, and to pay our respects to thousands of genocide survivors, who have had to continue their lives with a lasting heritage of tragedy.
We have gathered here in order to try to understand and look back at what happened in Srebrenica, to learn the lesson about the genocide, and understand its consequences.
Global public condemnation of genocide will help in ensuring that such evil acts never occur again.
Being the first one in Europe and in the world to do so, Great Britain has organised a commemoration on the Srebrenica genocide, and promoted the truth on what happened there. Also, she has been the first one to have initiated education on genocide in order to ensure that the whole world gets familiar with this tragic event.
The United Kingdom is the only country in the word which proclaimed Srebrenica Remembrance Day.
On the occassion of the Srebrenica genocide anniversary, around 200 events will take place this year in various towns throughout Great Britain.
I am very pleased that “Remembering Srebrenica“ Foundation, funded by the Government of the United Kingdom, has planned to establish the first permanent global Memorial Centre “Srebrenica“, which will provide educational support to struggle against hatred and intolerance by means of leadership and commemoration networks, learning and educational activities.
We deeply appreciate the people and the Government of the United Kingdom for their support to genocide survivors – through funding provided for the Memorial Centre building in Srebrenica and the International Commission on Missing Persons, as well as for their support programmes for returnees to Srebrenica.
The British Government and the Prime Minister Cameroon personally took an unequivocal stance that the genocide in Srebrenica must not be forgotten, and that lessons, which must also be applied by the international community, must be learned from that tragic event.
I hereby extend my welcome to the efforts invested by Great Britain in launching and drafting the UN Security Council resolution in order to mark the 20th anniversary of the genocide in Srebrenica.
I strongly support this resolution because it marks the anniversary with due respect and pays tribute to the victims in a discrete way, while demonstrating solidarity with the survivors, and reminding the world of the appaling consequences based on the lack of reaction in the eve of the genocide.
This resolution should reaffirm and strengthen determination of the United Nations to prevent repetition of such atrocities in the light of the lesson learned on the Srebrenica genocide.
Pursuant to the Security Council Resolution 819, adopted on 16 April 1993, Srebrenica was declared a UN “safe haven“ and it was established that it should be defended by all United Nations Member States “by all necessary means, including the use of force“.
None the less, between 11 and 16 July 1995, the death squads led by Radovan Karadžić and Ratko Mladić executed 8,372 Bosniak men and boys in Srebrenica.
Tens of thousands of women and children were forcibly deported.
Families and communities got devastated.
Despite of their obligation to protect the civilian population of srebrenica, the United Nations failed to prevent the genocide.
Srebrenica - the UN “safe haven“ thus turned into the United Nations' darkest hour.
In his report on the fall of Srebrenica, submitted in 2000, Kofi Annan, Secretary General of the United Nations states that “through error, misjudgement and an inability to recognize the scope of the evil confronting us, the United Nations failed to do our part to help save the people of Srebrenica“.
This was the worst crime committed on the European soil after the Second World War.
Therefore, it is most appropriate and historically relevant that the United Nations Security Council holds a commemoration on the Srebrenica genocide, and pays tribute to the victims and survivors by adopting the resolution submitted by Great Britain, so that I am hereby inviting all Security Council members to vote in favour of this resolution tomorrow.
The best way for us to pay tribute to the Srebrenica genocide victims would be to learn lessons on the UN failure, and ensure that the same mistakes are made never again.
Unfortunately, it seems to me that this has not been done.
Contrary to frequent promises that lessons were learned from the tragedy in Srebrenica, so many times in the last twenty years we have witnessed unreadiness of the international community to act decisively in order to stop massacre of civilians elsewhere in the world, particularly when such action implied any risk, burden or price.
The international community opted a number of times for such policy which had failed in Bosnia.
Why do we have to keep learning the same lessons over and over again?
The UN General Assembly and Security Council determined in 2005 that they would accept responsibility to protect civilian population from genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity.
However, the responsibility to protect civilian population turned out to be more of a declaratory principle than an obligatory rule for any international action.
We must be more cautious in detecting and responding to early warning indicators on potential genocide, particularly to ethnic and racial intolerance, hatred, discrimination and marginalization.
Dear friends, diversity is a distinctive feature of human beings.
Our human race is a mosaic composed of rich amalgam of peoples, cultures and religions that blend into a dynamic and diverse bond.
It is our responsibility to preserve and protect that mosaic.
Historical experience in Bosnia has offered valuable lessons in that regard.
The unique multiethnic culture of Bosnia and Herzegovina has been woven for one thousand years of tolerance and respect among her citizens, regardless of their ethnic or religious affiliation.
The intention of those who committed the genocide was to destroy the multiethnic tissue of our society by means of mass slaughter, torture, rape, expulsion and looting.
Such intention culminated in Srebrenica in July 1995.
There is an ongoing struggle in Bosnia today between those who have striven to revive the pluralist character and tolerant spirit of our society, and those who have worked on strengthening and deepening ethnic divisions caused by force and crimes.
To fail to abolish the consequences of indescribable crimes which ripped up our society would certainly be a reward for those who committed them, whereas, at the same time, such failure would send a dangerous message to all those who would be willing to commit genocide, crimes against humanity or war crimes in the future – that such crimes would, ultimately, be profitable or worth committing.
Regardless of this, we in Bosnia, who firmly believe that cultural pluralism is most valuable treasure of humanity, will continue to invest efforts aimed at restoring our pluralist society and laying down the such foundations that will enable the future generations to overcome divisions.
Reconciliation and restoration of our society are crucial, albeit most difficult tasks we have been facing because remains of our recent past, particularly of the genocide-ideology, have not ceased to impede our progress.
Both physical and emotional wounds of our population, caused by the crimes committed during the war, have made our progress to true reconciliation a difficult and painful process.
Both ideological and political followers of those who were the main organisers of the genocide have obstructed our progress to achiving full stability, prosperity and membership in the European Union and NATO.
They publicly denied the Srebrenica genocide, despite the judgement passed by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, which confirmed that what was committed in Srebrenica was an act of genocide, and the judgement passed by the International Court of Justice, which concluded that the acts committed in Srebrenica contained all distinctive features of genocide.
They still keep dreaming about finalizing the political project of Slobodan Milošević, Radovan Karadžić and Ratko Mladić, which turned out to be catastrophic for Bosnia and Herzegovina and the whole region.
Almost daily, they have threatened to tear off the part of Bosnia and Herzegovina from which hundreds of thousands of non-Serb civilians were either expelled or killed.
Of course, they will not succeed because we will never allow that Srebrenica, Prijedor, Zvornik and many other arenas where horrific crimes were committed get separated from Bosnia.
We must confront this dangerous and irresponsible adventurism by means of strangthening our collective decisiveness to prevent inflicting new wounds in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Those who wish to have better relations with BiH, and with Bosnia, will have to accept the past, face the truth, stop questioning souvereignity and territorial integrity of our country, stop insulting the victims and genocide survivors, and stop denying historical facts confirmed by the courts.
These issues are not debatable. We can try to reach mutually beneficial agreements through dialogue and compromise on any other issues.
The truth on the Srebrenica genocide cannot be the subject of political negotiations, compromise, or of some arbitrary solution that is acceptable for all sides.
We strongly reject the stance that remembering and commemorating the genocide would deepen divisions in our society and have negative impact on stability in Bosnia. Indispensable prerequsitites for stability are the truth on each crime, regardless of who perpetrators and victims were respectively, and accepting such truth by all sides.
The only way in which reconciliation can be achieved is that it is based on truth and justice. The process of reconciliation cannot advance unless there is a shared recognition that the crime was committed.
Regardless of everything, the progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot be stopped.
The vast majority of our citizens wish peace, stability and prosperity, wish to build shared and safe future for themselves and their children.
Time works to the advantage of those who love our country, who have contributed to her progress, and who wish to see her as a safe and prosperous one - as a member of the European Union and NATO.
Gradually, Bosnia will return to her usual self – the place where people of different religions, cultures and identities live together in harmony, safety and progress,
Today, at Westminster Abbey, we can see these 20 candles lit on the occassion of marking the 20th anniversary of the genocide – each marking a year of pain and denial since the genocide took place.
We cannot bring back the dead, nor extinguish pain from the hearts of their loved ones.
What we can do is ensure dignity and justice to the survivors of the Srebrenica genocide, to those who lived through terrible pain and suffering.
We owe this not only to the dead and to the survivors, but also to ourselves, to humanity that each one of us holds within, and to the future generations, who do not deserve to bear the burden of their fathers' sin.

title: Media statements by BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Mladen Ivanić and President of the Republic of Turkey Recep Tayyip Erdoğan
content:
On behalf of the Presidency and in my own name I wish to express a true pleasure that we have an opportunity today to welcome President of the Republic of Turkey Mr Erdoğan here in Sarajevo, a man who knows Bosnia and Herzegovina well, a man who has been present for a long time, and as a man who is the leader of the country which has invested much in Bosnia and Herzegovina and which has been truly assisting the country.
BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Mladen Ivanić
Good afternoon all!
On behalf of the Presidency and in my own name I wish to express true pleasure that we have an opportunity today to welcome President of the Republic of Turkey Mr Erdoğan here in Sarajevo, a man who knows Bosnia and Herzegovina well, a man who has been present for a long time, and as a man who is the leader of the country which has invested much in Bosnia and Herzegovina and which has been truly assisting the country.
Relations between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Turkey are very good and friendly. We are grateful for the projects (over 700 projects, nearly 300 million Convertible Marks worth of reconstruction projects) which their agency TIKA has conducted, the agency which has really done much here in Bosnia and Herzegovina. An already high level of economic cooperation has been increasing, where Bosnia and Herzegovina has increased its exports significantly, especially last year. Those were the topics we devoted most of our attention to today; the economy: investments, increase of mutual exchange and creation of conditions for people, especially in Bosnia and Herzegovina, to have a better standard of living.
We are very grateful to Turkey for opening the import quota for meat from Bosnia and Herzegovina and we hope that the long term agreement will lead to increased production in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and that we will reach the capacity of 10,000 tons per annum, which would represent an extremely significant progress for our agriculture.
Today we also, naturally, discussed the export of milk, taking into account that milk producers in BiH have been facing great difficulties lately, especially after Croatia joined the EU.
We discussed many other aspects of mutual cooperation and I can freely say that there is no disagreement between us. We also share a joint stance on international affairs, and share a joint interest in fight against terrorism, and let me go back on the previous topic again, we are particularly grateful to President Erdoğan for including in his delegation today a large number of ministers, as well as a great number of renown business persons – people who are ready to invest in Bosnia and Herzegovina, people who wish to invest in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and we shall touch upon these topics in meetings later today.
It is a true pleasure to discuss and exchange information regarding the question of terrorism in the presence of such a high delegation. It is our mutual wish to jointly contribute to fight against terrorism, noting that Turkey perhaps at this moment is more exposed to it than we are.
I hope that today's visit will be very successful, and that the greatest effects of the visit today will be felt by the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, that there will be opening of new work places after this visit, as well as the increase of mutual exchange and even better understanding between our peoples.
Once again, on behalf of the Presidency, I wish to express a warm welcome to Mr Erdoğan and his whole team here in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Welcome!
President of the Republic of Turkey Recep Tayyip Erdoğan
Respected President!
Members of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
Dear guests!
Primarily the visit which we have realised in Bosnia and Herzegovina is of great importance to us, and I wish to say thank you in my own name, and on behalf of my delegation, to all those who have welcomed us here.
This visit is of great significance and it will contribute to a rapid development of relations between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Turkey. This will be a process which will develop our cooperation. The scope of trade between Turkey and BiH is around 500 million, but we believe that this level is not sufficient and we wish to increase mutual investments in import export. Our delegations discussed this topic. My ministers and I have made the necessary notes and after detailed talks which we will hold today accompanied by the businessmen who are part of our delegation, we will make concrete steps in all fields, particularly in the field of military, culture, politics and tourism. We wish to achieve concrete agreements and cooperation in the field of military industry between Turkey and BiH.
The support of Turkey to Bosnia and Herzegovina for membership to NATO Alliance continues. We shall not make any concessions. Besides, our support in the political field of EU integrations continues, and it will continue to show through numerous investments. Likewise, as you already know, in the period when I worked as the Prime Minister, I promised that we will grant a 100 million EUR credit. Most of this has already been used, and now we have ensured another 50 million EUR credit to small and medium sized enterprises. Naturally, the most important step in this respect will be made by the Turkish Ziraat Bank and these investments by the Turkish Ziraat Bank are an example of why Turkey is today a country which is on the list of top countries investing most in BiH. Likewise, we are currently importing large quantities of meat from BiH. Currently that import is at the maximum level. This is of great importance for me, because the import which amounted to 3 million dollars in 2012 has been increased to 80 million dollars. This best shows how important we consider this topic to be, and how determined we are regarding this question. This has contributed to a decrease in the deficit in the scope of trade relations between the two countries. We also wish to decrease the existing deficit in import export. Turkish agency TIKA has realised over 700 projects and continues with its work. The president of TIKA is present here today. We will continue with these investments in the next period, wishing to contribute to cultural heritage in Bosnia and Herzegovina, believing that Bosnia and Herzegovina can become a large, attractive destination in the field of tourism.
The same goes for the field of military industry. Bosnia and Herzegovina has great experience in this industry. We can accomplish great cooperation here. Similarly, we can have cooperation in the field of reserve automobile parts. We shall discuss this in more detail.
Bosnia and Herzegovina possesses a great wealth of forests. The sector of furniture and other products can be of great importance. We have some existing investments in this sector by Turkish investors, and we wish to strengthen this cooperation in the period ahead.
Furthermore, Turkish companies can make a greater contribution to the building of infrastructure and infrastructural projects, for example, we can work on the enlargement of the Sarajevo Airport, which would present a great advantage to BiH. It is for all these reasons that this visit has been very constructive in the field of cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Turkey. This solidarity and cooperation we have will continue in the future. I absolutely believe in that, because all these representatives who have been chosen to be part of my delegation, who are here today, they will investigate in detail and with determination what can be done in which field. I thank you for the hospitality you have shown.
Thank you.

title: Addresses by BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Mladen Ivanić and the President of the Republic of Croatia Kolinda Grabar Kitarović
content:
BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Mladen Ivanić:
It is my true pleasure today to, on behalf of BiH Presidency, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and in my own name, I can welcome, together with other members of the Presidency of BiH, President of the Republic of Croatia Mrs Grabar Kitarović here in Sarajevo.
The Republic of Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina are two truly friendly states which share a long border, and Bosnia and Herzegovina has had a true friend in Croatia which has always been of assistance.
I believe we had very honest and open meetings today, and I am pleased that the President of the Republic of Croatia chose Bosnia and Herzegovina for her first official visit. This shows the significance Bosnia and Herzegovina has for the Republic of Croatia, but also the significance the Republic of Croatia has for Bosnia and Herzegovina. We are very grateful for a strong support which we have from Croatia on our path towards the European Union and Brussels, as well as a very strong personal support from Mrs Grabar Kitarović which we had also had during her term as a foreign minister, and now when she is the President of Croatia. We are more than grateful for that. We are also grateful for the fact that this last, new European initiative has practically in a way had its roots in the initiatives coming from the Republic of Croatia.
I think we can be optimistic about the period ahead and our successful cooperation in the years to come.
It is my true pleasure to be her host today in Sarajevo.
Thank you.
President of the Republic of Croatia Kolinda Grabar Kitarović:
Good afternoon all.
It is really lovely and very pleasant to be in Sarajevo today.
I thank, before all, BiH Presidency Chairman Mr Ivanić and dear friend Mladen, as well as other Presidency members Mr Izetbegović and Mr Čović for their hospitality today.
As you know, we arrived to Sarajevo today by car, because I wanted to show how close Zagreb and Sarajevo are. The goal of my visit today is to send a message of friendship, good-neighbourly relations, and cooperation between the Republic of Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The basis of my relationship towards Bosnia and Herzegovina is the absolute respect of its sovereignty, territorial integrity and independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Equally, the respect of a total constituent and equal status of all three peoples – Serbs, Bosniaks and Croats in Bosnia and Herzegovina, bearing in mind and respecting the rights of citizens who do not belong to none of those three peoples.
I have personally always advocated and will continue to advocate for the European and Euro-Atlantic path of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and will do all in my power to further, on behalf of the Republic of Croatia as well as personally, continue keep the attention of the international community and the European Union, the USA and NATO to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Naturally, I welcome the British-German initiative which has grown into the European initiative, and which has its roots in the Croatian initiative. I also welcome all activities of High Representative Mogherini and all she does on implementation of that initiative and I can, without hesitation, say that the Republic of Croatia will be at BiH disposal, with its political support on the path towards European and Euro-Atlantic integrations, but likewise, with concrete assistance in regards to institution building reforms and everything else which awaits Bosnia and Herzegovina on that rather long and complicated path.
Therefore, Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina are and will remain friendly states. We shall continue to talk about all issues, including open questions which were not high on the agenda today, because I wish for this first visit to be the message of friendship and openness to every conversation and every discussion.
I am delighted with the atmosphere I see here, the atmosphere of cooperation between the members of the Presidency, and I really wish for the government to be formed at all levels at soonest, so that the reform path of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which I particularly encourage, can be continued. And I repeat one more time; Croatia is available for any kind of assistance.
Croatia is especially interested in economic cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina. Furthermore, we plan to discuss the cross-border initiatives which are of equal benefit to both states and all peoples, within the European Union.

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović at the Crans Montana Forum award ceremony
content:
Since I was elected a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina in 2010, I have done my best to promote reconciliation, reintegration, and rebuilding of trust in my country. I have worked hard to advance the European integration of my country and to foster dialogue, cooperation and mutual understanding in the Western Balkans as a whole.
Ambassador Carteron,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I am deeply grateful to the Crans Montana Forum for awarding me the PRIX DE LA FONDATION 2014.
It is a rare and special honor.
And I accept it with profound gratitude.
Since I was elected a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina in 2010, I have done my best to promote reconciliation, reintegration, and rebuilding of trust in my country.
I have worked hard to advance the European integration of my country and to foster dialogue, cooperation and mutual understanding in the Western Balkans as a whole.
I regard this award as an important recognition of my efforts, but also as an obligation to continue the work I have been doing over the past four years.
It is a remarkable privilege to be chosen for this award, especially taking into account the impressive list of the past winners.
This award also has a profound personal meaning to me.
The President of Switzerland personally presented this very award to my late father Alija Izetbegović.
So being here today brings back memories.
My father led our nation during the most difficult time in our history.
We have gone a long way since.
In fact, I believe we have traveled the longer and the more difficult half of the journey.
Ahead of us now is the task of completing the democratic development of our country.
And ensuring that future generations live in a secure and prosperous Bosnia and Herzegovina.
