Over the past two decades, we have made a tremendous investment in building peace and stability in Bosnia, and in the Western Balkans as a whole.
We must preserve and consolidate this achievement, so that our region can continue to stride towards prosperity.
But we also must remain keenly aware of the underlying tensions and dangerous undercurrents that have existed throughout our history.
Such as extremism, domination, exclusion, mistrust, fear of the other.
When allowed to surface and gain in strength, these undercurrents can give rise to new divisions, fragmentation, disintegration, and cause instability.
We thus constantly have to seek to discourage them and keep them in check.
Any disintegration trends must be stopped before they can threaten the progress we have achieved.
I am an optimist.
I strongly believe the currents of integration will overpower the relics of the past, freeing the way to a brighter future.
But, we must be willing to constantly learn from our past mistakes.
Too often we have been prisoners of our own mentality.
Some perceive willingness to compromise as a weakness.
But just the opposite is true – compromise requires courage.
We must break out of the worn patterns of the past.
We must correctly interpret and advance the interests of those we represent.
Some politicians too often look for easy, populist solutions, placing personal or political gain above the interests of their people.
We must listen, understand and respect each other more.
Our most important mission in the time to come will be to build bridges of trust, understanding, respect and cooperation.
That is hard work that requires daring leadership.
Those are the values to which I have been and will remain deeply committed in my work.
Those are the pillars of my political vision.
That political vision received a significant support among the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the parliamentary and presidential elections that were held in my country last Sunday.
This is a clear indication that our citizens want Bosnia and Herzegovina integrated into the positive global trends and achievements of the free world.
Dear friends,
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a small European country.
But Bosnia’s symbolic significance by far exceeds its geographical and geopolitical dimensions.
Bosnia’s historical experience offers valuable lessons.
Going forward, we can benefit from the lessons that my country has learned from constantly seeking to improve its understanding and management of diversity.
Bosnia is a meeting point of civilizations, a bridge between the East and the West.
Bosnia is a focal point around which events and developments in the Western Balkans revolve.
Its unique multiethnic culture has been woven through one thousand years of tolerance and respect among its citizens, regardless of their ethnic and religious affiliation.
That is why its preservation and success, as a specific microcosm, is crucial.
Bosnia needs Europe, the united Europe of stability, prosperity and cooperation.
And Europe needs Bosnia.
Because Europe’s future firmly lies with the very idea that Bosnian citizens have treasured and defended throughout our history – the unity of diversity.
Bosnia has always been a part of Europe.
Yet, Bosnia still remains outside Europe’s common house.
No less than its neighbors, Bosnia has a right to take a seat in that house – beside its fellow Europeans, in the family of European nations, family of freedom and democracy.
Thank you.

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović
content:
Our gathering today in Mostar with an aim of signing the “Declaration on the Role of the State in Addressing the Issue of Persons Missing as a Consequence of Armed Conflict and Human Rights Abuses” on the occasion of August 30th, International Day of the Disappeared, is highly important.
Ceremony of signing a “Declaration on the Role of the State in Addressing the Issue of Persons Missing as a Consequence of Armed Conflict and Human Rights Abuses”
Mostar, August 29th, 2014
Dear families of missing persons,
Esteemed presidents Josipović, Nikolić and Vujanović,
Dear ambassador Miller,
Ladies and gentlemen,
Dear friends!
Our gathering today in Mostar with an aim of signing the “Declaration on the Role of the State in Addressing the Issue of Persons Missing as a Consequence of Armed Conflict and Human Rights Abuses” on the occasion of August 30th, International Day of the Disappeared, is highly important.
I would especially like to emphasize the role and engagement of the International Commission on Missing Persons, whose representatives made a great effort and managed to gather heads of state of our region, in order for us to jointly assume obligations arising from this strategic document.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Achievements that Bosnia and Herzegovina made in the process of finding and identification of missing persons can serve as an example for the rest of the region, even in global framework.
People in my country suffered hardships and atrocities during the war, the consequences of which we still face.
Out of 40.000 missing persons in the region, the greatest number refers to citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
So far, out of 30.000 missing persons that are still searched for, more than 24.000 remains have been found and more than 22.000 persons have been identified, including 6.476 Srebrenica genocide victims.
Unfortunately, more than 8.000 persons are still being declared as missing.
Bosnia and Herzegovina adopted the Law on missing persons in 2004.
Its adoption stipulates forming the Missing Persons Institute with headquarters in Sarajevo, as the state institution responsible for searching for missing persons.
With the necessary support from the international community, Bosnia and Herzegovina decided to do everything in its power in order to be completely at disposal of families who are searching for their dearest.
It is a heinous crime to hide the remains of the victims.
The crime is also not allowing them to be buried with dignity, to mark their resting place in proper manner.
Many victims were found through work of entity commissions for missing persons, and later, Missing Persons Institute of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We are aware of the threat that a number of missing persons will never be found.
However, we will not give up for as long as there is hope for finding and identification of the last victim.
Hence, from this place, I call on all those who have information on missing persons, mass and individual graves, to cooperate with international and domestic institutions.
It is an act of humanity and debt to victims and their families who have searched for their dearest for decades.
It is not easy to talk about thousands of people with their tragic destinies.
All of those who were killed had their lives, their dreams, their joys and sorrows.
They had a name and a surname, people who loved them, families and friends.
I have visited many mass graves and attended numerous funerals of identified victims.
We are consternated, over and over again, by the proportion of committed crimes.
Although their pain is permanent, those who bury their murdered relatives following decades of searching are seeking justice rather than revenge.
It is the satisfaction they must get before the courts of our country or International Tribunal for Former Yugoslavia in The Hague.
For these crimes do not have statute of limitation.
The whole world was appalled by tragic examples of inexplicable evil, such as Tomašica mass grave in the area of Prijedor.
It took almost twenty years for this mass grave to be discovered, as well as the proportions of multiple systematic brutal attacks on remains of the victims that were dislocated to various sites, in order to conceal the crime.
Unfortunately, not all the mass graves from previous war in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region of Balkans have been discovered and exhumed.
Hence it is an imperative civic duty and responsibility to stop the horrible silence that conceals the truth about places like Tomašica for two decades.
We must not let families of missing person be alone until we have found the last victim.
It is only in this ways that we can settle the debt to them and their dearest.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the whole region as well, families of missing persons set example for their devotion and commitment in their humane mission.
More than 90.000 relatives voluntarily gave DNA Reference Samples to the International Commission on Missing Persons, which enabled DNA testing for identification purposes.
We must honour all these family members for persistence they demonstrate.
Along with excruciating pain they suffer, they also often face existential problems, as well as lack of understanding of their surrounding that sometimes wants to avoid painful topics that bring us back into the past.
Owing to engagement of the International Commission on Missing Persons in Bosnia and Herzegovina there has been a great scientific progress in applying forensic genetics in order to identify missing persons, which is an important achievement in global scientific framework.
It is the first organization that utilized the previously mentioned achievement and applied it to solving the cases of missing persons.
Now those achievements are applied worldwide where needed.
Our experts are very successful and esteemed in this field.
Dear friends!
I have mentioned only a few aspects in a difficult, and most of all, delicate process of finding missing persons that are characteristic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I believe that these examples, as well as Declaration that we are signing today, encourage all the other countries in the world to use our experience and pay special attention to this highly important social and humanitarian issue.
Unfortunately, other countries in the modern world, as well as our region, are facing the same or similar problem following the period of conflict.
Hoping for a better and more peaceful world, we have responsibility to draw important lessons for the future from recent tragic events.
All with a clear aim for the future generations to live without painful temptations and traumas that our countries and peoples suffered at the end of the twentieth century.
Thank you!

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović at International Donors’ Conference for BiH and Serbia in Brussels, July 16, 2014
content:
On behalf of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I wish to express our deepest appreciation to France, Slovenia and the European Commission for taking the initiative to convene this conference. We wish to express our most sincere gratitude to your countries, international organizations and financial institutions for the pledges you are going to make today to help us recover and rebuild.
President Nikolić,
Prime Minister Bratušek,
Minister Fabius, Commissioner Fule,
Ministers, Excellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen,
On behalf of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I wish to express our deepest appreciation to France, Slovenia and the European Commission for taking the initiative to convene this conference. We wish to express our most sincere gratitude to your countries, international organizations and financial institutions for the pledges you are going to make today to help us recover and rebuild.
We are deeply touched by the acts of solidarity your peoples and governments have extended to us over the past two months. I especially thank you for the immediate assistance – including rescue teams, equipment and humanitarian aid – that saved the lives of so many of our citizens.
The natural disaster that struck us did not respect borders. And neither did the response by peoples and governments of the world. In the most difficult hours and days of the disaster, we witnessed moving demonstrations of solidarity and cooperation that crossed all divides inside and outside of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
These acts of solidarity continued well after the water receded. Dealing with the grim aftermath, and the enormous implications of this disaster, requires the same level of cooperation and solidarity that was displayed during the disaster. We are convinced that a rapid recovery will be possible if we rebuild together – as is the motto of this conference, for which we are grateful and hopeful.
I am pleased President Nikolić and I are here together – making a joint appeal for your assistance in rebuilding our countries. Over the past years, we have invested great efforts to achieve better relations and improve our cooperation. As confirmed by the Summit held yesterday in Dubrovnik, cooperation in the Western Balkans has reached a level not seen before.
Today’s conference is a compelling display of our cooperation. This joint appeal to rebuild together makes us ever more determined to continue working hand in hand. We were struck by a natural disaster of catastrophic proportions.We suffered the largest rainfall and the worst flooding in the last 120 years.
The whole of the watershed leading to the river Sava was overwhelmed – generating flash floods that created a path of destruction and desolation. The accumulated downstream flow of water, mud and debris caused widespread floods in the plain.
As the river Sava peaked, drainage from the plain was made impossible – resulting in the retention of water in lowlands for an extended period of time. Water retention by soil and slopes was surpassed – causing several thousand landslides.
More than 80 municipalities in Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered enormous damages, losses, and environmental and social impacts. Almost 100 thousand of our citizens were temporarily displaced from their homes.More than 40 thousand took extended refuge in public or private shelters, or moved in temporarily with relatives or friends.
A large number of them are still without roofs. They will remain displaced until their houses and livelihoods are restored. An urgent response is needed to ensure that they do not face a cold winter without roof or income.
The human dimensions of the disaster are immense. The human stories of loss and desolation are devastating. No quantification can do justice to telling those losses. Everything that so many of our citizens had built their entire lives was destroyed or severely damaged in a matter of hours. Their homes washed away, their agricultural fields and farms destroyed, their livelihoods and future prospects erased.
Within the affected populations, vulnerable groups are affected even harder. Among them are tens of thousands of children, senior citizens, persons with disabilities, single parents and Roma. Many of them were already living below the poverty line.Many of the displaced are the same ones who had to leave their homes during the war. Having settled not so long ago, they now find themselves displaced once again.
These vulnerable groups cannot be expected to self-recover. We must give them special attention and priority support to secure their housing, livelihoods, and access to health and education.The total economic impact of the disaster is estimated to have reached 2.1 billion Euros – of which 1.3 billion Euros are damages and 763 million Euros are losses.
This is equivalent to nearly 15 percent of our GDP. Most impacted was the private sector. The hardest hit economic sectors were agriculture, transport and productive activities. The largest physical destruction was in housing and transport infrastructure. The largest cumulative impact with the highest social implications is on livelihoods, employment and productive capacity.
Damages and losses in the agriculture sector alone are over 180 million Euros. There is a risk of a large number of agriculture dependent households to go under the poverty line. In the most severe scenario, around 30 percent of households linked to the agriculture sector could go under the poverty line. The effect that diminished economic activities will have on the youth population – which already has the highest unemployment rate of over 50 percent – will be significant.
Public service facilities and services were severely affected, generating a reduced capacity to provide them to a population that now has increasing needs.
All this creates an amount of need that is financially unmanageable with our current resources and budgets. Our total short-, medium- and long- term recovery and reconstruction needs are estimated at 1.7 billion Euros.
Given the pressure to rapidly resume economic activities and restore homes and livelihoods before the winter, the short-term needs for the next 6 to 12 months amount to 652 million Euros.
The most important resource mobilization in the short term is for housing – repairs and reconstruction to ensure a roof before the winter to those displaced as well as compensation for destroyed or damaged household items. These immediate short-term housing needs are 181 million Euros.
Also very important are immediate repairs in the flood protection infrastructure, pending a major investment to be done in the medium and long term. Going forward, we must ensure an integrated river basin management and climate-resilient flood prevention.This requires an environmentally sound, regional perspective. The coordination and cooperation of the countries in our region that share the river basins is strategically indispensable.
I hope this conference will contribute to increasing operational cooperation on flood protection in the region, as well as, more generally, on natural disaster risk management.Having in mind our existing capacities and available resources, the early recovery period will be essential. Our recovery priorities in the next 6 to 12 months are rebuilding homes, sustaining livelihoods, restoring private sector productive activity and critical public services and facilities, such as schools and hospitals.
The situation in the affected areas is difficult. The challenges we face are complex. The needs are urgent, pressing and multidimensional.Tremendous efforts will be required from our population and government institutions to overcome the disaster’s extensive consequences.
Our government at all levels has already responded to the immediate needs. Many of those needs will remain for the upcoming months, requiring sustained support. We are employing all available domestic financial and material resources to respond to the needs. We are putting in place innovative mechanisms to provide rapid and transparent access to resources for recovery.
We are advancing legislation to compensate the immediate needs, including through solidarity funds. We will provide a base of resources to those funds through our internal efforts – budgetary reallocations and contributions from our citizens. But, that will not be enough. We need international donor support to provide liquidity to those funds.
Our combined recovery and reconstruction needs by far exceed our financial and material resources. Thus we are making this appeal for your assistance and cooperation. We intend to ensure a responsive, reliable, monitored and well-informed recovery process at all levels of our government. Our goal is to meet the post disaster needs of our population in a timely and targeted manner.
We will make all efforts to assure that the financial assistance we receive from donors is used efficiently, transparently and swiftly. Disaster recovery opens the possibility for change of past practices and the opportunity to move forward.
We see the recovery process as an opportunity to advance and accelerate the necessary transformative changes that are needed to achieve prosperity and generate opportunities for our population. We were encouraged by the demonstration of solidarity and cooperation during the emergency response that crossed ethnic and social divides.
This could be a step to the opening of a new social dynamic in our country. The people of Bosnia and Herzegovina are vital and resilient. We have overcome many disasters in our history. I am sure we will overcome this one as well. We will rebuild together everything this disaster destroyed.
I hope we can count on your assistance to rebuild better together. Our perspective is forward looking. We want to move with a positive outlook to the future.
Our future firmly lies with Europe. We are unanimous in wanting our country to become a European Union member. Timely integration is of critical importance to achieving our desired future. While the primary responsibility for securing that future lies with us in Bosnia, Europe’s active support is essential.
Bosnia has always been a part of Europe. Its citizens have treasured and defended European values throughout its history. Yet, Bosnia remains outside Europe’s common house.
No less than its neighbors, Bosnia has a right to take a seat in that house – beside its fellow Europeans. The situation we find ourselves in requires change of approach – of us in Bosnia and of our friends in Europe. Europe’s decisive engagement at the highest political level through an approach that takes into account Bosnia's specifics is necessary to accelerate our accession to the European Union.
The best approach would be to grant Bosnia and Herzegovina candidate country status and start accession negotiations immediately. All necessary reforms – including the implementation of the judgment of European Court of Human Rights in the case of Sejdić and Finci – should become subject of our accession negotiations under the relevant chapters of the acquis communitaire.
We are fully aware that we must fulfill our obligations. And I assure you that we will! But, let us begin with those obligations that we can fulfill right now, those about which we can achieve internal agreement.
This is flexibility Europe can and should show us. That would be a grand act of Europe’s true solidarity with Bosnia and Herzegovina.We thank you from the bottom of our hearts for helping us repair the terrible damage that nature inflicted on our country.
Just as nature can be repaired, so can history.
Bosnia and Herzegovina deserves it.
Thank you.

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović on the occasion of marking Srebrenica Memorial Day in Lancaster House in London on July 8, 2014
content:
. We highly appreciate the help of British people and Government for surviving victims of Srebrenica genocide. This is noticeable in great contribution to building of Memorial Centre in Potočari, as well as work of International Commission on Missing Persons and also active participation in programs of help for Srebrenica returners.
Esteemed Mr. Azmi,
Dear friends from organization Remembering Srebrenica education initiative,
Thank you for devotedly keeping the memory of genocide victims in Srebrenica with numerous activities.
Your voice is important. It is heard loud and clear across Great Britain and the whole Europe.
We have gathered here to remember with sadness those who were murdered, but also to appreciate those who survived and who are facing the darkness of permanent heritage of committed genocide. We highly appreciate the help of British people and Government for surviving victims of Srebrenica genocide. This is noticeable in great contribution to building of Memorial Centre in Potočari, as well as work of International Commission on Missing Persons and also active participation in programs of help for Srebrenica returners.
I would like to thank British Government and Prime Minister Cameron for their uncompromising attitude that genocide in Srebrenica must not be forgotten. The United Kingdom is the only state in the world that has proclaimed “Srebrenica Memorial Day”. Hopefully we can convince other countries to do the same. We are working together to ensure that next year, on the twentieth anniversary, genocide in Srebrenica is marked in capital cities throughout Europe. Support us in the United Nations, which we expect to proclaim July 11 as “Srebrenica Memorial Day.”
I would especially like to greet four courageous mothers of Srebrenica who are here with us today. Their confessions described us horrors of survived genocide and its consequences they are facing on a daily basis even after 20 years. Srebrenica survivors suffered a lot in many ways. Apart from the fact that they lost their loved ones in a terrible way, many of them experienced physical violence, assaults, offences, struggle for economic survival and psychological traumas that last.
Even after they survived horrors of genocide, after they lost their dearest, after years of pain and sorrow, they still have the strength to send out messages of hope in better world, with more justice. They ask for what belongs to them by laws of God and people- punishment for perpetrators and justice for victims. We are humbled by their courage. Their struggle for justice inspires us. Their determination testifies about unfaltering human spirit.
Mothers of Srebrenica had meetings with their friends in the Government of this country. They asked for Great Britain to work in the UN Security Council so as to proclaim July 11 as Srebrenica Memorial Day in the whole world, they asked for children in schools in Great Britain to learn about genocide committed in the heart of Europe in the 20th century and to prevent something like from ever happening again. Mothers invited the Prime Minister and other friends to visit Srebrenica before the twentieth anniversary of the genocide.
I will work with the Prime Minister and the Government of Great Britain to fulfil their requirements.
Europe must always remember what happened in my country at the end of the twentieth century. However, reminiscence is not enough. World must learn lessons from Srebrenica. It must do everything to make sure that genocide never happens again. Justice will not be done unless the ideology that led to genocide in Srebrenica is defeated. Justice will not be satisfied unless the policy of genocide is eradicated.
Unfortunately, in part of my country called RS genocide is still denied. They are not facing the truth. There is no catharsis necessary to complete the process of reconciliation and building of society where all benevolent people will see better future for themselves and their children. A few days ago, president of RS said in public that Radovan Karadžić and Ratko Mladić are heroes. He said that he respects them and that he will respect them even if they are convicted in the International Criminal Court in The Hague. While we were sending out messages of peace with the sound of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra on the occasion of the 100th anniversary of the start of the Great War, iconography of certain nationalist gathering in the entity of RS reminded of 1992.
Europe does not care again. It closes its eyes and ears; it remains deaf to horrible statements of leaders from the entity of Republika Srpska. Europe does not react to daily threats of secession uttered by leaders from the entity of Republika Srpska, the same way it failed to react in July 1995 when it allowed massacre and genocide in Srebrenica to happen. Europe tolerates dangerous propaganda about Bosnia and Herzegovina as an “impossible state” which is repeated by those who celebrate Mladić and Karadžić and who obstruct its each step toward a functional state, future member of the European Union. It is because of such policy of president of RS and his followers that Bosnia and Herzegovina, unlike the whole civilized world, is the country whose parliament has not adopted the resolution of Srebrenica. Even Serbia has done it, acknowledging, though euphemistically, genocide in Srebrenica. For the same reasons, Bosnia and Herzegovina still has no law which would sanction negation of genocide in Srebrenica. Political project of Karadžić and Mladić is still alive in heads of certain leaders of Bosnian Serbs. Their criminal spirit still hovers threateningly over Bosnia and Herzegovina and its future.
I do not want to scare anyone. It is not my aim to disturb conformist atmosphere of European capital cities. However, I do not have the right to close my eyes before everyday open threats and racist offences we are exposed to. I do not have that right because of 8.372 Bosniak men who were shot by Mladić’s criminal death squads from July 11 to July 16 of 1995. I cannot be silent because of boys from Srebrenica who were shot in the back of their heads by Milošević’s killers from notorious squad called “Scorpios”, although they were supposed to be protected by Blue Helmets of Dutch battalion. My message to those who are rhetorically shooting into Bosnia and Herzegovina again is that Srebrenica will never be and cannot be anywhere else except in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Both Srebrenica, and Tomašica cave where almost thousand innocent civilians were thrown and hundreds of other mass graves scattered throughout the territory of Republika Srpska will never be anywhere else except in Bosnia and Herzegovina. No secession or referendum can change that. We will never accept crossing the border in order to recite the Fatiha to our murdered brothers and sisters.
Dear friends,
I am convinced that you understand our sensitiveness when someone touches our wounds that are still open, and Srebrenica is our deepest wound. Hopefully a critical mass will finally be created among leaders of Bosnian Serbs, predominance of those who have the strength to face the truth about the past. We must finally master lessons from the past and turn towards the future. We believe in reconciliation and reintegration. We are committed to building joint future in Bosnia and Herzegovina integrated into the European Union.
We believe that strength of the integration process will overwhelm relics from the past and free the way towards brighter future.
It is with this hope that we will say goodbye to 175 shehids of Srebrenica genocide on July 11 and bury them in Memorial centre in Potočari.
Let eternal rahmat be bestowed upon them.
Thank you!

title: Address by the BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović at „Forum for Prosperity and Jobs in Bosnia and Herzegovina“, May 26, 2014
content:
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, we want sustainable, efficient and socially equitable development in the interest of present and future generations. We want to build a dynamic economy based on knowledge and innovations-economy with greater number of better jobs and social equality. I have recently stated that Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to create 100,000 new jobs in the next eight years. This vision is achievable if we utilize advantages we have and opportunities that arise.
Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen,
It is a great pleasure to take part in this Forum.
I would like to thank the Delegation of the European Union for organizing this gathering.
I am very pleased to be joined today by Mr. Ali Babacan, Deputy Prime Minister of the Republic of Turkey and Mr. Frank Walter Steinmeier, Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Federal Republic of Germany. Your presence and support are very important to us. Bosnia and Herzegovina can certainly apply many lessons and experience of highly successful development models of Germany and Turkey.
This is an excellent opportunity for representatives of authority, economic, political, civil, academic, business and media community that have gathered here to define together perspectives and strategy of socio-economic development of our country.
The focus of development of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the following period certainly must include following goals:
1. strengthening macroeconomic stability, by reducing public expenditure, upgrading public finance and better approach to sources of financing, especially for small and medium enterprises.
2. enhancing competitiveness of economy, by improving competencies of human resources, development of scientific, technological and business infrastructure, and establishment of single market and economic space.
3. employment, especially by accelerating job creation through development of small
and medium enterprise, efficient functioning of job market and adjusting education
system to market needs
4. attraction of foreign direct investments, especially through quality presentation of our comparative advantages and potential, and improvement of regulatory framework and investment climate.
5.rural development and faster development of agriculture,
6.development of energy potential, especially renewable energy sources
7.development of transport infrastructure and communication
8.development of environment management and protection
9.strengthening social protection and greater social inclusion
10.acceleration of the European Union integration process
What we need right now is a package of concrete, realistic and feasible policies and measures to accomplish these goals in the following eight years.
In order to ensure its realization and sources of financing, there must be full, sustainable and long-term consensus of domestic political, social and economic partners on this package, but it also has to be supported by the European Union, International Monetary Fund, World Bank, European Bank for Development and Reconstruction and other international partners.
That would be the real Agreement for development and prosperity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, we want sustainable, efficient and socially equitable development in the interest of present and future generations. We want to build a dynamic economy based on knowledge and innovations-economy with greater number of better jobs and social equality.
I have recently stated that Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to create 100,000 new jobs in the next eight years. This vision is achievable if we utilize advantages we have and opportunities that arise.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has an excellent geographical position, distinguished by proximity of the European Union and Mediterranean markets.
We have various and rich natural resources, including unpolluted soil and favourable climate.
We have a great opportunity to develop energy sector, eco-tourism, organic agriculture, wood processing and biomass.
We have possibility to satisfy our needs for food, but also to export food-especially organic products that are highly demanded on European market.
We have quality work force, research and management staff in our country and abroad, renowned domestic companies which have experience in doing business around the world.
I am sure that with quality appearance, we can attract foreign investments and open up new markets for our companies abroad.
We must conduct economic policy that is accountable; build a rational and functional administrative apparatus which will serve the needs of citizens and economy, rather than its own needs.
This implies reducing costs and size of public administration at all levels, rationalization, removing overlaps, revising economic validity, expediency and performance of certain agencies and institutions, stopping over-expenditure and establishing criteria to gauge responsibility and performance of managerial staff in public institutions and companies.
Budget savings and accumulated assets of public companies and income should be directed in development and employment funds, especially grants and favourable loans for development of small and medium companies in the sectors where we have competitive advantages and potential.
We must decidedly fight against corruption and economic crime, make a revision of privatisation and compliance with privatisation contracts, investigate the origin of property, and ensure that Prosecutor's offices and courts accelerate criminal prosecution of the cases of corruption, economic crime, tax evasion and malversations in the privatization process. We also must be more efficient in tax and income collection.
It is also necessary to accelerate and simplify launch of business activities and investments. For instance, the procedure to register new business takes 11 steps and lasts around 37 days, which ranks our country as 174th in the world by the World Bank. This procedure must be reduced to last one day, and this can be achieved by establishing institution which would provide all services in one place.
A range of measures must be taken to improve business climate and environment, remove different administrative barriers and simplify regulatory framework for business, especially regarding payment of tax and contributions, gaining constructors licences and property recording, reduce pseudo-fiscal and tax burdens, especially regarding contributions, and introduce easements and incentives for small and medium enterprises.
Our judicial system must be more efficient and faster in persecuting economic disputes and forced execution of contractual obligations, in order to ensure a greater level of investment protection. Thus investors would be more certain in their decision to invest in our country.
Primary responsibility to conduct necessary reforms rests, of course, with domestic political actors.
However, Europe also must have a more decisive approach.
The situation we face takes a change of relation and approach- this includes us, in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and our friends in Europe.
We do not ask for bar to be lowered, or conditions and obligations to be changed. It is clear to us that we must accept all the rules of Acquis Communautaire.
However, the question of when and how we will meet those requirements can be topic of more flexible approach of the European Union.
The greatest help that the European Union could provide us at this point would be to approve of candidate status of Bosnia and Herzegovina, so that we can start negotiations on certain chapters as soon as possible.
All the current preconditions for our candidacy should be transferred to negotiations on chapters in candidate status.
Thus, the current deadlock would be removed, and all the necessary reforms, including Constitution reforms, would become topic of negotiations within certain chapters that relate to them.
Let us start with obligations we can fulfil right now and that we can agree upon internally, and leave difficult ones for later.
That is flexibility that Europe can demonstrate in order to enable us to accelerate the accession process.
Bosnia and Herzegovina deserves it.
Dear friends,
Today's Forum is taking place in a very difficult moment for Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Our country was afflicted by natural disaster of catastrophic proportions in the past days.
It is only in the following weeks that we will have precise assessments and analyses of total private and public material damage and economic losses caused by this disaster.
However, we can say right now that damages and losses are enormous, and they can be measured in millions of BAM.
According to initial reports, 44 municipalities in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Brčko District, with near 1,7 million people, were afflicted by floods and landslides.
Dozens of thousands of our citizens lost their homes and existence, hundreds of firms and agricultural parcels are flooded, roads, bridges, railway network, schools and many other private and public facilities are destroyed.
Situation in afflicted areas is extremely difficult and complex, and requires all the government institutions to engage in damage repair and removing the consequences of this affliction.
We must build a national recovery plan of afflicted areas. This plan needs to contain short-term, medium- and long term measures to be taken at all levels of authority.
Every discussion about the future development of Bosnia and Herzegovina must begin with recovery and reconstruction of afflicted areas.
The Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina and governments of the two entities and Brčko District, together with municipalities and cantons should jointly make an assessment of damages, as well as analysis of needs and priorities in recovery process, and based on those parameters prepare a comprehensive national recovery plan. The plan will be a product of internal agreement of institutions at all levels and will be supported by the European Union and other relevant international institutions.
We will employ all the disposable and available financial resources we possess, as well as material resources to implement the plan of recovery and reconstruction.
Nevertheless, we are aware that our needs will surpass our capacities. Hence we have decided to organize, as soon as necessary preconditions are created, an international donor conference in order to collect devices that are not available in our country.
We will require help form the European Union funds, as well as from friendly countries. Regardless of the fact that Bosnia and Herzegovina does not have candidate status and it is not in the process of pre-accession negotiations, we expect European Union members to demonstrate humanity, solidarity and will, by making it possible for our country to access, among others, assets from European Union Solidarity Fund, especially bearing in mind wider regional implications of this natural disaster.
I avail myself of this opportunity to thank European Union member countries, as well as other neighbouring and friendly countries for their help in past days.
In these very difficult moments, our country, all their citizens and institutions, need unity. This natural disaster has united us and woken again the centuries-old spirit of Bosnia and Herzegovina- the spirit of solidarity and cooperation. The nation of Bosnia and Herzegovina is vital and resistant. In its history, it overcame more difficult atrocities. I am sure it will rise again- and we will reconstruct together everything that this natural disaster destroyed.
Thank you for your attention!

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović at the Conference “Social Media: Impact for Partners” organized by NATO headquarters in Brussels and BiH Ministry of Foreign Affairs
content:
Esteemed Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen,
Welcome to Bosnia and Herzegovina and the city of Sarajevo.
It is a true pleasure to attend this important gathering.
More than 150 members from 20 member states and NATO partners is a sure sign that this topic is very significant nowadays.
I would like to thank NATO Public Diplomacy Division for its decision to organize this conference in our country.
In this way, Bosnia and Herzegovina is trusted as a reliable and important partner, and future NATO member.
Esteemed friends,
I am convinced that topic of the conference is timely and highly useful.
We must not ignore the fact to which point social networks and media participated in changing social reality in various countries of the world. The reality that appeared unchangeable just a few years ago.
When it comes to my country, I would like to point out the fact that institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina set great store by regular and transparent informing the public about integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina in NATO.
We would especially like to explain to the public the nature of this association, participation of BiH in developing NATO partner policies, as well as contribution of Bosnia and Herzegovina to peacekeeping operations.
We do not want to be satisfied merely by afore mentioned, we would like to convince all our citizens about the benefit of integration that represents an exclusive club of the most developed and progressive countries- countries which demonstrate on daily basis, by means of their functioning, criteria and most important of all, common values, why this goal is desirable, but also doubtlessly attainable for Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In 2003, the BiH Presidency defined approach to the European Union and NATO as strategic goals of Bosnia and Herzegovina through document entitled “General Directions and Priorities for Implementation of Foreign Policy of Bosnia and Herzegovina”
In 2006, Bosnia and Herzegovina formally joined NATO “Partnership for Peace” program.
The BiH Presidency applied for NATO Membership Action Plan as the final phase towards full membership in 2009.
Unfortunately, a part of political establishment in Bosnia and Herzegovina ignores decisions of the BiH Presidency and deliberately slows down our steps to this important military-political alliance.
That is why for years we have not been able to implement a technical-legal norm such as registration of 63 perspective locations at Ministry of Defence of BiH, which is a precondition for MAP.
I would like to send out message from here that major part of Bosnia and Herzegovina wants to be part of NATO alliance and it will persevere in achieving that goal regardless of obstacles.
Finally, I would like to point out that in spite of challenges we face on the path to NATO integration, we are very proud of our contribution through participation in NATO-led peace- support operations.
The fact that our country went from being beneficiary to becoming a factor of security is a great achievement.
Dear friends,
Natural users and creators of website content are young people who formulate, articulate and represent their attitudes by means of relatively new spectrum of social networks.
Hence it is important to present end explain in true and transparent manner policies of very NATO members and partner countries such as Bosnia and Herzegovina through these communication channels, whose number of users grows exponentially year by year.
Informed and self-confident public, which does not refrain from asking right questions, is one of preconditions for all those values to take deep root in our ground.
It is the best shield against attempts of misuse and wrong topics that are often imposed upon us.
I am convinced that in the next two days you will elaborate adeptly all aspects of this topic and find best ways to send out your messages to the public through social networks and modern web technologies.
Nowadays it is highly important.
I wish you success in your work.
Cheers!

title: Address by the BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović at the Conference „ European Values and Identity: Compass for Political Cooperation in Bosnia and Herzegovina“organized by Konrad Adenauer Foun
content:
Bosnia and Herzegovina is essentially a true European country. Its unique diversity has been woven through centuries of shared life with incredible mixture of peoples, religions and cultures. You will perceive that as you stay in this city, whose residents have lived in harmony for centuries, helping each other build sacral objects which almost physically lean and rely on each other.
Esteemed president of the European People's Party, presidents of Serbian Democratic Party, Party of Democratic Progress, Croatian Democratic Union and Croatian Democratic Union 1990!
Ladies and gentlemen, dear friends!
It is a pleasure to be here with you.
This gathering could be remembered as a milestone in the political scene of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Today we will send from here messages of mutual understanding, respect and joint action in accordance with European values we share.
I would like to thank European People's Party and Konrad Adenauer Foundation for organizing this gathering.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is essentially a true European country. Its unique diversity has been woven through centuries of shared life with incredible mixture of peoples, religions and cultures. You will perceive that as you stay in this city, whose residents have lived in harmony for centuries, helping each other build sacral objects which almost physically lean and rely on each other.
Bosnia is one of those places on earth where many geopolitical, cultural and religious relations and interests tangle and untangle. That is why it carries a heavy burden of history, and the last hundred years can be rightfully called a century of warfare and violent transitions.
People’s political parties, whose members have gathered here, have been established in one of the most difficult periods of our recent history. During that period, they protected and articulated interest of their own people the best way they could. History will judge if they could have done it better.
We have different opinions about that time. We will not be able to agree about those visions of the past. However, it is more important to agree about the future. I am convinced that we can do that!
Building European future is a clearly expressed wish and vital interest of all the people in this country. Integration into the European Union is the only realistic platform on which we can ensure long-term stability and prosperity. Our absolute interest is to be part of community of organized countries where peace, understanding and a culture of negotiation prevail. The process of adjusting to European standards is the best tool for reforms through which we can achieve an organized society and country.
However, in spite of wish we expressed and interest that is recognized, there has been a stalemate in integration process and our country is lagging more and more behind in comparison with other countries in the region.
The question ahead which needs answer is: how to overcome this stalemate and move forward on the European path?
First of all, I think that we must truly turn to and devote to the future. Our country has realistic possibilities to make a great progress in a short span of time. It takes political will and trust to make the progress. Trust is built only by mutual respect, joint action, true and intensive communication and cooperation. We must stop succumbing to cheap populism, overcome narrow interests and used up political stereotypes. We must interpret more correctly interests of those we represent, be wiser, more responsible and ready to learn from previous mistakes. In order to build the future, we must make compromise. In the Balkans, many people consider compromise as weakness, but contrary is the truth. It takes courage to compromise.
Common future in this country can only be built by agreements which take into account interests and rights of the country, the three constituent peoples and each citizen.
History teaches us that Bosnia and Herzegovina moves forward only when everyone in it feels comfortable. Hence, future reforms in this country should not follow the direction of centralization or decentralization; they should rather take the direction of harmonization and coordination.
Political processes must be led in a way to benefit all the peoples of this country, because each step forward is possible only if it is in common interest.
Joint statement to be signed by our parties today is exactly one of those steps. It contains all the principles that I am talking about. This statement opens a new chapter in cooperation of our parties when it comes to building common future.
Our citizens want a functional state where law and common sense prevail. They want social justice and economic prosperity. They are also right to be dissatisfied with the current state of affairs.
Although a lot has been done in the past 18 years, more could and must have been done. There were mistakes and missed opportunities. Dissatisfaction that citizens demonstrated is a warning that things must change rapidly. We must stop wasting our time arguing about unrealistic scenarios and requests that will not be accepted by the other two sides. There is only one realistic road to the future, and that is not the path of splits, dissolutions and disintegration, it is the path of connection, cooperation and integration.
Hence I invite you to commit to task which will bring prosperity to everyone, which will bring tangible economic and social benefit to all citizens. Let us turn to serious debate about economic development, foreign investment attraction, job creation, and improvement of standard of living of our citizens, especially the most endangered social categories. Let us also devote to leading accountable economic policy, building rational administrative apparatus which serves citizens' needs.
We must start a decisive battle against crime and corruption, perform revision of privatization, be more efficient regarding collection of tax and contributions, save by reducing costs and size of public administration, release unused funds from public companies, and then channel those funds-in the form of direct grants and favourable loans-in development projects in areas where we have potential and comparative advantages. It is particularly important to focus on development of entrepreneurship and launching small and medium enterprises, because they are best generators of economic development and job creation.
As far as European integrations are concerned, the main task is to adequately and permanently empower institutions to lead the process of European Union accession. The Dayton Constitution did not do it, because it was not its goal. Although we hoped, experiences so far show that the flaw cannot be rectified by the very process of accession.
During implementation of almost every European condition or obligation there were arguments between different levels of government regarding responsibilities and actions. Europe expects us to communicate unanimously. Precondition for that is previous harmonization of communication within domestic institutions.
Complex organization of our country proved to be a serious challenge in the process of internal harmonization. Hence it is essential to establish an effective mechanism for permanent solution of conflicts and coordination of European matters within existing institutions. That mechanism must accept Dayton Constitutional order and serve as its addition, rather than dissolution.
Primary responsibility rests with domestic political actors. However, more resolute political approach on the part of Europe which accepts specificities of Bosnia and Herzegovina is needed. We do not ask for lowering the bar. We ask for stronger support to overcome that bar. We do not ask for favours or shortcuts, changing conditions and obligations. It is clear that we must accept all the rules of Acquis Communautaire.
However, the question of when and how we will meet these requirements might be a subject of a more flexible approach. We should start with responsibilities we can fulfil at this moment, those that we can agree about. Responsibilities which are more difficult to meet, the complex ones, should be postponed.
The European Union can demonstrate flexibility and create dynamics which will enable us to overcome existing deadlock and accelerate accession process.
Bosnia and Herzegovina deserves it.
Esteemed friends from Europe and Bosnia and Herzegovina!
The most difficult section of the road to recovery of this country is behind us. In order to move forward on that road, a change of the relation and approach is needed, both on our side, in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as our friends around Europe.
We who are gathered here share the similar vision of the future-it is a stable, prosperous, democratic Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is a member of the European Union. I am convinced that we possess enough wisdom and European mind-set to overcome challenges ahead.
Goals of this generation of political leaders are preservation of peace, internal and external integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I truly believe that we are all aware of that and capable of fulfilling that mission.
Thank you.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić at the Bosnia and Herzegovina Independence Day reception, Sarajevo, 28.2.2014
content:
Ladies and gentlemen,
I would like to use this opportunity to, before all, congratulate the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina March 1st – Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a glorious day in the history of this country, significant for many things. It is one of the dates which can surely be considered a milestone in a thousand-year-old history of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It should be observed, it should be celebrated regardless it is not being done on the territory of the whole of BiH, in hope that one day it will be, that one day, all of us who live in this country will accept it as an important moment, 1 March 1992, an important moment in history of the country of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all its peoples and citizens.
In view that there will be twenty years since the end of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina next year, I wish to express hope that Bosnia and Herzegovina, after all the events which it has lived through in its turbulent history as an independent state, will enter a phase of a normal and stable democratic state. The fact is that Bosnia and Herzegovina is after such a long time since the referendum on independence, and particularly after the war, fighting with its internal controversies which we can observe also as ethnic controversies, as controversies that concern general human rights of us as individuals, as citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with controversies of transition, the escalation of which we had a chance to see twenty days ago.
The year of 2014 is the election year. I hope that, regardless of what happens in elections this year, Bosnia and Herzegovina will obtain a government which will realise the importance of this moment, the importance of, ultimately, sacrificing for this country, for all people of this country. It certainly looks from this place that we are entering a new phase, a new time for Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is up to all of us, and primarily up to those who were elected by the people to lead this country, to what extent it will be good and to what extend it will be bad.
I wish you all the best! Thanks to all of you who are attending this reception, with a wish for Bosnia and Herzegovina to celebrate many more Independence Days. We have reasons to be proud of this day and we have reasons to mark and celebrate it.
Once again, happy Independence Day, I wish you much happiness and success.
Thank you for coming.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at the marking of the remembrance to the holocaust victims organized by the Jewish community in BiH
content:
On today’s day, 69 years ago, the notorious concentration camp Auschwitz was liberated. Auschwitz, as well as other Nazi concentration camps throughout Europe, was the largest “death factory”, evil which would leave indelible scars on the face of humanity.
Members of the Jewish community,
Excellencies and eminencies,
Dear friends,
Ladies and gentlemen!
We are here today to pay respect to the victims of the holocaust, in human history, the most horrid systematic, authorised and organised persecution and murder of millions of Jews, by the state, that is, the Nazi regime.
On today’s day, 69 years ago, the notorious concentration camp Auschwitz was liberated. Auschwitz, as well as other Nazi concentration camps throughout Europe, was the largest “death factory”, evil which would leave indelible scars on the face of humanity.
All that the Jews, but also other members of persecuted minorities went through during the Second World War unfortunately bear witness to the fact that evil in people can be infinite and inconceivably brutal.
The closest members of my family died in a Nazi camp – I grew up trying to grasp the reasons which make people into nonhumans. I have never managed to comprehend these reasons even as an adult in the time when the evil was repeated during the aggression on Bosnia and Herzegovina. I am sure in one thing, and that is, when evil and violence are of question, we must always and repeatedly oppose it.
Much is known today about the holocaust victims and the ways in which crimes were committed against those people. However, despite this fact, the whole world is obliged to continue to research and reveal every detail.
We must never give up from speaking the truth and warning the current and future generations about the importance of opposing to evil people and their sick ideologies.
By marking of the International Holocaust Remembrance Day we are cherishing the memory of the past and a pay duly respect to the victims, but we also trying to ensure a safer future.
Nothing similar, never and nowhere, must happen again.
Surely, such sentences can sound frustrating because genocides continued to happen after the holocaust. One of them also happened in Bosnia and Herzegovina in the last war, and all that in front of the cameras and the eyes of the whole world. It also happened in Rwanda, as well some other countries.
One of the God’s books says – “Fight on the side of the good, even if you are stunned by the amount of evil.”
We must continue to warn and do our best to reduce and prevent evil and violence.
People must be equal and respected. They must be safe wherever they life, minorities in particular.
God’s peace be upon the holocaust victims, as well as the victims of other genocides and crimes committed wherever and whenever in the world.
Thank you.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at the opening ceremony of the restored amphitheatre and auditorium at the Faculty of Political Sciences in Sarajevo
content:
Esteemed excellencies,
Respected professors and assistants,
Dear students!
It is my pleasure to participate in such a delightful event – official opening of a restored amphitheatre and auditorium at the Faculty of Political Sciences of the University in Sarajevo.
I thank all those who contributed to the restoring of this space, firstly the Government of the Republic of Turkey and the Turkish Coordination and Cooperation Agency TIKA, as well as the Turkish people as a whole.
There is a long list of projects which the Turkish Government realized in Bosnia and Herzegovina through its TIKA agency.
I will specify just a few of those (out of the total of 130 in the last three years), such as the restoration of the bridge in Konjic, the renovation of the building of the Civil Engineering Faculty in Mostar, the construction of a Memorial Gallery “Srebrenica”, modernization of a 100 maktabs in Sarajevo, the re-construction of a mosque in Fazlagića Kula, the renovation and equipment of schools in Travnik and Novi Travnik, renovation of Merhamet public kitchen in Zenica, renovation of the General Hospital in Doboj, the project of carpet production in Bosanski Petrovac, and there are also numerous projects in agriculture and livestock breeding in the whole of Bosnia and Herzegovina…
Just recently, TIKA has also finished the renovation of Karađoz-bey’s madrassa in Mostar which will also be opened today, and tomorrow there will be two opening ceremonies – the “Memorial House of Alija Izetbegović” in Bosanski Šamac, as well as a new Health Clinic in Visoko.
Historical and friendly relationships between the Turkish and Bosnian-Herzegovinian people and our states are profound and constructive.
Much is known about them, and thank God, they will remain as such.
We in Bosnia and Herzegovina are pleased about a remarkable progress has been making in the past ten years, as well as its ever greater capability to support Bosnia and Herzegovina in its development and Euro-Atlantic integrations.
Investment in education is one of the best ways for cooperation between two countries, and the Government of the Republic of Turkey has been helping us enormously in that segment.
Along the International University which has given the Sarajevo suburb of Ilidža a whole new energy, of a de facto contemporary student city, there is the support in the development of our state universities.
The Faculty of Political Sciences of the University in Sarajevo, where we are today, has in the past half a century grown into a respectable scientific institution.
A great human potential which it possesses in its faculty and students has deserved better working conditions.
I am pleased with the fact that TIKA as precisely in this place recognized space for engagement and support.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a peripheral area between the East and the West, has traditionally and in modern times been shaped in the summation of the scientific and civilizational achievements of the East and the West.
Modern Bosnia and Herzegovina firmly stands on a position that knowledge is the productive force and civilizational worth, and that scientific research and academic education of its citizens is one of the most important conditions for its success.
Development of education is the interest and the goal for Bosnia and Herzegovina and all its levels of government.
Only educated and mindful people can be a development factor of every society, and so the Bosnian-Herzegovinian one.
In post-war period, Bosnia and Herzegovina has made significant steps towards development of a network of high education, by joining the Bologna system of education which has for a while been an established educational system in the European countries.
The strongest lever for modernisation of our society is in the young people who are educated according to the most modern European standards.
Regardless of all apparent and political difficulties in our society, Bosnia and Herzegovina is successfully confronting the challenges and obligations which the inevitable educational progress imposes.
Respected friends!
I wish for the knowledge and critical mind of our young people be developed and spread in this reconstructed amphitheatre of the Faculty of Political Sciences.
I remind that generations of former students of this faculty have significantly impacted the dynamic of relations in the country and I am sure it will remain to be so in the future.
Without a strong, autonomous and free academic community, there is no strong democratic society. And such a society, all together, we wish to build in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Thank you! Cheers and all the best!

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at a Conference over the marking of the 20th anniversary of the International Criminal Court for the former Yugoslavia (The Hague Tribunal)
content:
Your Excellencies,
Estemeed organisers, participants and guests of the Conference,
Dear ladies and gentlemen!
I wish you welcome to Bosnia and Herzegovina and I thank you for the invitation to hold the opening speech.
This conference is organized over the 20th anniversary of the establishment of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, with an aim to open discussion on the role, significance and results of the Tribunal since its beginning to date.
While assessing the effects of the Hague Tribunal, its contribution, heritage and a message it leaves for the victims and perpetrators, states and peoples, international politics, law and justice, contemporaries and our children, the present and the future, I have to say that my opinion is divided.
But before I elaborate such a stance, I wish to highlight certain important facts. Bosnia and Herzegovina is the state which has, without any doubt, suffered most during the dissolution of the former Yugoslavia.
A brutal aggression was committed against the country, and genocide over the Bosniaks was committed. That is the truth.
I recently visited Tomašica near Prijedor, the largest mass grave after the Second World War in Europe, in which over 400 bodies of killed men, women and children have been found to date.
It is estimated that around 1000 bodies will be discovered.
I invite all those with conscience to visit the horrid places like Tomašica, which this country is full of, to see the picture of crime close up, out of sterile interiors of courtrooms, salons and cabinets.
Mister Meron has done that and with his human gesture paid respect to the innocent victims.
Ladies and gentlemen!
I cannot help feeling that there are two Hague Tribunals.
The first, established by the Resolution 827 of the United Nations in 1993, which was affirmed by persecutors and judges who shared enthusiasm and full awareness that they are doing something special, historically valuable.
That is the Tribunal which sent encouraging messages around the world that crime must be punished – that this is the civilizational achievement and a moral debt to the victims.
This first Tribunal, I hold in high esteem.
The hopes and convictions of my people were interwoven in its work – particularly those of the victims’ families – those hopes and convictions that there is justice in this world.
It is precisely that Hague Tribunal which passed some historically important judgments for Bosnia and Herzegovina, primarily, putting its stamp on the truth on the siege of Sarajevo and genocide in Srebrenica.
Along with that, the Tribunal gave enormous contribution to the development of international criminal law, and through its work, it promoted the principles of human rights protection on the international scene.
In particular, it should be noted that the act of rape, that is, sexual violence in an armed conflict, were for the first time adjudicated as a crime against humanity by the ICTY verdicts.
Unfortunately, in time which followed the Tribunal slowly moved away from its initial ideals and hopes. Behind the curtains and in silence a new, different Tribunal was being born, a court which, as contemporary analysts and numerous intellectuals claim, grew tired under the pressure of great and powerful interests and set itself a goal just to finish the job.
That new court started looking at committed crimes and victims with different eyes.
Because, how else can one understand the acquittals on Appeal of the heads of military, police and intelligence structures for command responsibility?
From a moral and legal point of view they are, to put it mildly, a matter of concern.
It is impossible, even for lawyers, let alone the victims, to explain how the defenders who were convicted in the first instance verdicts to 20 and more years of imprisonment for the gravest crimes, acquitted from responsibility in the Appeal.
It cannot be a valid argument, nor is it pertinent to talk about the knowledge or the lack of knowledge of judges of the one and the same court – where ones pass verdicts of 20 or more years imprisonment, and others completely acquit defenders.
Those responsible for the crimes from the top of the pyramid – planners, commanders and organisers – are evading justice.
The command responsibility has become almost impossible to prove.
Planners and commanders of crimes have become untouchable, practically protected from criminal prosecution.
The victims are asking what the world in which they live is like.
Is justice reachable to ordinary people, or is that just a privilege of those who are powerful?
How much is a life of a little man in the Balkans worth? Masterminds, planners of the crimes and genocide who took lives of tens of thousands of people, and aggrieved millions, will all together spend a few decades in comfortable prisons around Europe.
What message does this send to the victims, and what to the planners and lords of future wars?
Ladies and gentlemen!
The Hague Tribunal has not yet finished its job. A few important, capital processes remain. As the first president of Bosnia and Herzegovina once said – even war criminals have their rights.
Their right is a just punishment. A mental relief.
And he said another thing, which I repeat here: “We believe in justice even though it is sometimes slow!”
Therefore, despite all, citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina believe that the Hague tribunal will finish it job returning to its initial idea, the idea of universal justice, fairness and humanity.
We believe the justice is reachable and that the Hague tribunal has its historical role in its achievement.
The interest of the victims must return to focus, and their interest is justice! And that is not only the interest of the victims, but also the interest of everyone who wishes to live in a better and safer world.
Thank you!

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at the reception on the occasion of the Sovereignty Day, Sarajevo, 25 November 2013
content:
Esteemed excellencies, respected guests, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends!
Thank you for attending tonight the ceremony of the marking of 25 November, the Sovereignty Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Full 70 years have passed since the Founding Assembly of the State Antifascist Council of the National Liberation of Bosnia and Herzegovina in Mrkonjić Grad, one of the key events in the building of the modern statehood of our country.
At this assembly, centuries-old statehood continuity of Bosnia and Herzegovina was confirmed, which preceded its entry into the then Federative Yugoslavia, a few days later at the Second Assembly of AVNOJ in Jajce.
The historical facts are clear: Bosnia and Herzegovina was not created with the establishment of Yugoslavia, but just as is the case with other republics; it became its part with its defined sovereignty and territory.
The core ZAVNOBiH resolution permanently confirmed Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state of its citizens and equal peoples Muslims, that is Bosniaks, Serbs and Croats as well as members of other peoples and ethnic groups.
That historical agreement was based on, before all, antifascism as a core value and it should presently serve as an inspiration to new generations of leaders in confronting evil and xenophobia, as well as searching for dynamic formulae of full mutual respect and life together.
Bearing in mind the time and historical context, in which they were passed, the key messages of ZAVNOBiH, have not lost its universal value even seven decades later.
Therefore, those who negate ZAVNOBiH and this holiday of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and who cynically call it partial or non-existent, are disqualified themselves and are distancing themselves from the honoured marking of something which should a be a joint positive heritage and civilizational achievement of the first order and importance.
Someone who does not respect own history, own ancestors, can surely hardly expect to ever be a factor of stabilization, cooperation and progress.
The ZAVNOBiH negators and their antifascist platforms are those who do not have the strength nor wish to dissociate themselves from fascism and the darkest barbarism which reaped havoc in this country and left behind itself Srebrenicas, Tomašicas, Kozarac, Zvornik, the live pyres of Višegrad…
They have own choice, and we have ours.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, in all of its three national corpses and among all of its citizens, there are enough of those good, honourable and well-intentioned people who love their country, who wish it well and whose history they view in its fullness and unbroken continuity without forgeries, ideological prejudice and any other exclusivity.
Ladies and gentlemen, dear friends!
Bosnia and Herzegovina, with all of its burdens and problems, perplexities and dilemmas, is going in the right direction.
Perhaps we are going slowly, at times with longer halts, but our goals are clear and they will be achieved.
Our country will become a full and equal member of the European Union and the NATO Alliance, a prosperous and stable European state.
When will these goals be achieved?
When there is more political will, readiness for compromise and national consensus on the most important questions for a joint future.
It should also be said that, at least in the foreseeable future, Bosnia and Herzegovina will not be a comprehensive and stratified society it once was.
The aggression and violent segregation have done their part.
However, the results of the recently held census will show that the basic substance of a multinational community, the soul of this country has been preserved.
Although atrocious crimes have been committed throughout its territory, the entity of RS has not been completely ethnically cleansed.
Almost the fifth of the population which lives in that half of Bosnia and Herzegovina are Bosniaks and Croats.
And people will, for I am convinced, continue to return to their land, to restore their houses and properties in the time ahead.
They will live in the same country, together, villages and towns will rely on the same state structure, on the same institutions.
There are numerous examples which witness that people in the whole country are already cooperating and they will increasingly cooperate for mutual benefit.
The recovery trend in the multinational relations, along with occasional crises and halts, is clear. Things are looking up.
Gradually, a society will be built in which all of us will feel safe and pleasant.
Differences attract each other, they are our wealth and in time, do not doubt this, there will be more communication and communion.
There will be more and more of Bosnia and Herzegovina which we remember and which we wish to restore.
To all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I congratulate 25 November, the Statehood Day.
Thank you and cheers!

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić IBAC 2013, Sarajevo 10 October 2013
content:
The European bureaucracy created a geopolitical, marketing phrase “Western Balkans” for our region. Every man who learnt geography in these regions can ask a question: Isn’t therefore Greece Southern Balkans, and Rumania and Bulgaria Eastern Balkans? The Balkan is synonymous to conflicts, ethnic intolerances, backwardness and lack of perspective – an eternal powder keg. And that image is the result of our common history and different notion of multiculturalism, as co-habitation of ones with the others, or
Excellencies,
Esteemed members of the academic community,
Ladies and gentlemen!
I am honoured with your invitation to address this respected gathering in Sarajevo, which hosts the 3rd anniversary of the International Balkan Annual Conference. On this occasion I would like to thank the organisers, Istanbul University, University of Sarajevo and the International University of Sarajevo for making such a thematic conference in Sarajevo possible.
Furthermore, I wish to praise the organisers for entitling this year’s conference “Bosnia and Herzegovina: in Common History and Multicultural Atmosphere of the Balkans” since this is a needy topic for Bosnia and Herzegovina in the current period.
Allow me to present some of my observations and link them to the current processes as I am neither a historian nor a philosopher, but someone who, led by the past experiences, analysis of today and forecast of the future, tries to create his political engagement believing in our “shared society.”
Our society is faced with the subject, rather than saying a problem, of a three-levelled common history and multiculturalism. The first level is the one within Bosnia and Herzegovina, the second is the perception of the “Balkan” region and the third level is actually the idea of Europe.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, we are boasting with our multiculturalism, multi-ethnicity, openness for diversities which is the result of precisely that common history and co-habitation experience. However, very often we can show the worst in us by shattering all those proclaimed values during war conflicts.
Moreover, our present shows that we are ready to create and maintain institutionalised discrimination over those we consider “unconstituent”.
In doing so, the inexorability of historical processes is forgotten, whereby more than half a century of peace and socialistic structure created a new collective identity which is characterised by an unsightly collective name of “others”.
Moreover, from a legal perspective, a question is posed how one nominally civic and secular state can have citizens who are constituent and those who are not constituent, although all of them have lived there for generations. Our political reality identifies “others” as otherness. As something which is not ours.
