I am deeply honoured to be out in a position to deliver an introductory speech at this observation by which, in addition to other accompanying manifestations, we mark the 60th anniversary of organized archival activity in the Republika Srpska.
Let me, on behalf of the Organizational Board in charge of marking of this anniversary, extend my warmest greetings to you, and thank you for responding to our invitation, and for attending this observation, which presents only one in a series of manifestations dedicated to marking this great jubilee for archivistics and for the Archive of the Republika Srpska.
At the beginning, I would like to congratulate hereafter all archive workers of the Republika Srpska, as well as the management and employees of the Archive of the Republika Srpska for this great jubilee, and to wish them a lot of success in the future work. One of the proofs of their dedicated work includes yesterday's award they received from the President of the Republika Srpska, i.e. they were awarded the Medal of Njegoš of the First Order for special achievement in the area of public activities.
Sixty years of work and existence represents a respectable anniversary for any cultural establishment and institution even in such environments that are larger than Banja Luka and the Republika Srpska.
As the Chairperson of the Presidency of BiH, I accepted to provide my patronage for this important jubilee and anniversary, not only due to my personal commitment to the Archive of Republika Srpska and to arshivistics as an important social activity but, first of all, due to the fact that I am aware of the importance that the Archive of the Republika Srpska has had and should have in the future in the area of preservation of identity and self-awareness of the Serb people and of the Republika Srpska as a social and political community.
While chairing the Organizational Board for marking of the 60th anniversary of organized archival activities in the Republika Srpska, we aimed, by means of a number of symbolic manifestations, including the today's one, to present the previous work of the Archive of the Republika Srpska, new projects and plans, as well as to provide adequate social and political treatment of this important activity in preservation of a collective memory, as well as of identity of the people and of the state.
Let me avail myself of this opportunity to extend my gratitude to all those who helped us organize marking of this important anniversary, and thus familiarize ourselves better with the sixty-year old organized archival activity in the area of the Republika Srpska.
My promise necessarily contains a subjective note, given that I spent a large part of my working career in the Archive of the Republika Srpska. Such important anniversary cannot be marked without us reminding ourselves of some significant people, dates, events and decisions.
Prior to establishment of public archival institutions and archival services, written data and service books were kept by public institutions and societies, awhile organized storage was provided by museums and libraries.
Organization of storage, gathering, processing and protecting of archival records started 60 years ago, by the Decision on Establishment of the Archive of the City of Banja Luka, passed by the People's Board of the City of Banja Luka on 20 April 1953. Three years later, the Archive of the City of Banja Luka, pursuant to the Approval issued on 30 May 1956 by the Executive Council of the People's Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, grew into the County Archive of Banja Luka. Pursuant to the decisions passed by the county assemblies of Banja Luka and Bihać, the Archive of Bosanska Krajina was established in Banja Luka in mid-1963. This archive, in terms of its territorial mandate, was covering 23 municipalites of the Bosanska Krajina region. It was the largest regional archive in the socialist Yugoslavia.
Due to the outbreak of the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina in spring 1992, the Government of the Serb Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina passed its decision on establishment of the Archive of the Serb Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state-owned public institution based in Sarajevo.
Pursuant to the Law on Ministries of 1993, the Archive of the Republika Srpska was defined as a Republic administrative organization conducting administrative and expert tasks in the area of archival activities.
Today's Archive, with its status of the Republic Administrative Organization within the Ministry of Education and Culture in the Government of the Republika Srpska, is a central institution for protection of cultural assets.
On the occasion of marking of this jubilee, we should not forget to mention some important people who left an indelible trace in archival activities of the City of Banja Luka and of the Republika Srpska. We owe our deep gratitude for the status of the Archive and of archivistics in the Republika Srpska to Milan Vukmanović, Dušan Vržina, Verica Stošić, Dušan Popović, and other employees in this area of work.
Ladies and gentlemen,
We have just remindered ourselves of most important activities, difficulties and successes we have had in the last sixty years.
We live in the time in which our historical and archival heritage is subject to various interpretations and misuse that fall beyond the scope of archival and historiographic professional skills and profession. It is the task of archive workers and of archives as public institutions of special importance to, through their work, promote truth and scientific approach in treatment and presentation of archival records and documents on events from our past. There are many remaining subjects from the past of the Republika Srpska and BiH that have not been researched yet, and it is on these subjects that our archives should provide access and research. It is very important that all administrative levels in the Republika Srpska, in accordance with their possibilities, provide support and invest into this form of public presentation of our archival treasure, by which they also contribute to international promotion of archival institutions from the Republika Srpska, as well as to the international promotion of the Republika Srpska herself.
In a few moments we are about to open the exhibition of archival documents entitled “The Archival Treasure of the Republika Srpska“. The exhibition of archival documents “Jovan Dučić in Diplomacy“ was opened yesterday. These exhibitions resulted from shared efforts and cooperation of archival workers and all archives in the Republika Srpska and in Serbia. The aim of these exhibitions is to present to both professional and wider public the richness of our archives, but also to promote our work and archival profession. I am glad that those who love our cultural and historical heritage and archival assets, experts and our citizens alike, will be able to see these two exhibitions in the next few days and thus familiarize themselves with our archival treasure. That is why I believe that there will be more similar exhibitions in the future in other cities and places in the Republika Srpska.
Finally, with my congratulations for good and committed work, as well as for a socially justified and important role and function in preservation and protection of our collective cultural, national and identity-related goods and values, let me, once again, wish you a lot of success in the future work, and let me wish you to keep achieving good results in what you do and know best.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Nebojša Radmanović at the Business Forum of the BiH and Austrian business community, Vienna, 18 April 2013
content:
Bosnia and Herzegovina is traditionally linked with the Austrian market, particularly bearing in mind the fact that a large number of BiH citizens live and work in Austria. In addition, Austria represents one of the most significant investors in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is evident that there is a great interest for economic cooperation between BiH and Austria. In that sense, it is necessary to further strengthen direct contacts between BiH companies and interested Austrian companies.
THE PERSPECTIVES OF ECONOMIC COOPERATION BETWEEN BiH AND AUSSTRIA
Mister Chairman,
Dear businesspeople,
Ladies and gentlemen!
It is a great pleasure that I am able to see and greet the businesspeople of BiH and Austria in one place. These two countries have good, friendly and stable political relations, which I will confirm today in the meeting with President Fischer. That is an excellent basis for furthering of economic, trade, cultural and other relations and connections between our countries, businesspeople and citizens. That is why I am pleased to see today in Vienna the businesspeople from BiH, that is, from both of its entities – the Republika Srpska and the Federation BiH, and Austria, who can review and develop new opportunities for cooperation.
Why a Business Forum of businesspeople of the two countries, here and now?
Bosnia and Herzegovina is traditionally linked with the Austrian market, particularly bearing in mind the fact that a large number of BiH citizens live and work in Austria. In addition, Austria represents one of the most significant investors in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is evident that there is a great interest for economic cooperation between BiH and Austria. In that sense, it is necessary to further strengthen direct contacts between BiH companies and interested Austrian companies.
Austria is one of the most significant foreign trade partners of BiH; it is among top ten partner countries. Austria, with the total of 1,2 billion Euros, is the largest investor in BiH, ahead of Serbia, Croatia and Slovenia. There are around 400 Austrian companies and 200 branches of Austrian companies which operate within the BiH marketplace. Austria is an important trading partner to BiH, and it is one of the rare countries with which we are achieving a trade surplus, or at least, we have a balanced trade exchange. For BiH, Austria is on the fifth place as an export trade partner and on the eighth place as an import trade partner.
At this moment, many European countries are preoccupied with the economic crisis which is a threat to stability of our economies and societies. According to the general information available, Austria is being more successful than some other countries, in coping with the consequences of this crisis. That is one more reason why Austrian experiences and economic solutions should serve as a successful model.
I will briefly describe the economic trends in BiH in the last few years:
In the year of 2012 a fall of 0.5% GDP was noted, so that 2012 can be marked as the year of economic stagnation of BiH. That is a direct consequence of additional deepening of the crisis in the Euro zone and other countries, the main foreign trading partners of our county, as well as the insufficient economic activity in the country. It is encouraging that, in 2012, direct foreign investments continued to grow and they surpassed significantly the previous years. The overall value of the foreign investment inflow in 2012 in BiH amounted to 508 million Euros, which is a lot closer to the amounts which had been marked prior to the start of the crisis. Unfortunately, high and constant unemployment, transitional poverty, large and non-effective public sector and a small scale of real economy, are the greatest weaknesses of the BiH economy.
According to the Austrian indicators, BiH is an attractive destination for investments by Austrian companies, which is shown by the constant widening and growth of investment in the recent years. Austria has invested 22.2% of all investments to BiH from 1995 to 2011.
The major investment of Austria in BiH is within the banking sector. There are currently four Austrian banks operating in BiH. By its significant presence in the BiH banking sector, Austria shows interest in participation in the process of economic transition in BiH. Austrian investors are interested in investments in the construction, building of transport infrastructure and energy sectors.
It is assessed that opportunities for joint investments in the production sector have not been sufficiently used, together with the development of spa, sport and leisure and all other kinds of tourism, as well as exploration and the use of natural resources. Due to similarity in configuration of the terrain of the two countries, it would be good to exchange experience in the field of planning, development and joint investments of road, as well as rail transport. Only on the basis of joint investments, in the field of wood, chemical, textile and plastics processing, is it possible to make a more significant step forward in the maintenance of the foreign trade balance.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Allow me to give a few recommendations which can assist in better economic cooperation of our countries.
The investment climate in BiH, due to the global economic crisis and complicated rules and procedures is still unfavourable for many parties, therefore, for the Austrian investors also. This is why the local authorities have undertaken activities to simplify the existing administrative procedures for issuing of necessary permits for the work of companies, with an aim of easier and speedier investments.
Furthermore, electronic signature documents are still not recognised in BiH, which leads to many difficulties in doing business and goods exchange between the two countries, but, we are aware of this need, and we are working on its legislative regulation.
As far as the trade and goods exchange is concerned, it is necessary to increase the diversification of goods exchange.
I believe that the greater participation of Austrian companies in the process of privatisation of our local companies could be one of the fields of concrete cooperation to mutual interest. BiH has a need for new foreign investments in various fields of economic activity. BiH offers great opportunities for foreign investments in the fields of energy, agriculture, metallurgy, processing industry, tourism, local infrastructure, traffic and communications and many others. I am of the opinion that the structure of Austrian investments in BiH should include more investments in production sectors, and not only the service, financial and similar branches as has been the case to date.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has a signed Agreement on Avoidance of Double Taxation, Agreement on Promotion and Mutual Protection of Investments, as well as an Agreement on Social Insurance with the Republic of Austria. In the following period it is necessary to review what other agreements are necessary between the two countries, so that the economic cooperation is improved, then prepare those and suggest those to the Government of Austria and the Government of the Council of Ministers of BiH.
Finally, I once more praise the holding of this Business Forum today, and expect to make another similar meeting in BiH too, and above all, I express hope that this kind of cooperation of the business people of the two countries will continue in the future, to overall benefit of our economies, your employees and all citizens.
I wish you successful meetings during this Business Forum, and many new ideas and projects of mutual cooperation.
Thank you.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović in Ahmići, over the marking of the 20th anniversary of the slaughter of ethnic Bosniak civilians
content:
Today we have gathered to once again mark a sorrowful anniversary, to remember 116 residents of Ahmići, murdered 20 years ago, and to, in front of their graves and this shaheed monument, repeat that their sacrifice will never be forgotten.
Respected families of shaheeds,
Dear residents of Ahmići,
Esteemed Mufti Abdibegović,
Respected guests!
Es-selamu aleikum!
Today we have gathered to once again mark a sorrowful anniversary, to remember 116 residents of Ahmići, murdered 20 years ago, and to, in front of their graves and this shaheed monument, repeat that their sacrifice will never be forgotten.
Our murdered sisters, mothers, daughters, grandfathers, brothers and fathers, the innocent boys murdered, and the youngest victim, a three month old child in a cradle, are today in our thoughts and prayers, and our deepest sympathy is with their closest ones, their families, neighbours and friends.
Our truth is imprinted with the blood of the innocent, and it is permanent and indestructible, as is our centuries-long Bosnia and Herzegovina.
No matter how much effort its enemies make to destroy it.
Perhaps some of those who do not love this country wish for us to tire, to start leaving all to oblivion, to fall into their trap and say: fine, those are general knowledge things, in the name of the future and reconciliation among peoples we will not remember again.
But here also, in Ahmići, and all other places of our suffering, we repeat: we will never allow that.
We will gracefully and forever keep remembering, and carry the memory onto our children and grandchildren, keep from oblivion our own painful and hard, but honourable history.
Because, those who say that people who forget are condemned for the painful and tragic experience to repeat, are right.
But, we must also say the following: we do not remember so that we could take revenge.
We do not call for revenge or new bloodshed.
Absolutely not.
Our messages are clear, our intentions also.
We wish that Ahmići, Srebrenica, Kozarac, Foča, Višegrad, Zvornik, Bratunac, Vlasenica, Stolac, Brčko and all other toponyms of evil and crime, genocide and extradition in which innocent Bosniak people suffered during the aggression on our state from 1992 to 1995, never happen to anyone again.
My dear people of Ahmići!
I know you wish for the perpetrators and their chiefs responsible for the slaughter in your village be deservedly punished.
I also know that you have not received good news of this happening to an extent in which the justice is served and your pain at least somewhat subdued.
But, we will not give up.
War crimes do not become obsolete and we will not allow the perpetrators to rest.
We will continue to pursue them.
We should, all together, believe that the justice is reachable, have faith in our courts, as by believing that, we believe in our state which we are building through a lot of hardship and painful compromise.
And believe that the God’s judgment is final. Nobody can run away from that!
And in the end, I wish to tell you only a few more sentences.
I was in Živinice yesterday. We solemnly marked the Day of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, 15 April, our glorious and honourable Army!
I will repeat here what I had said to our soldiers.
The organization of our people into the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was the greatest achievement which shall be remembered by all future generations of patriots of this country.
This was always pointed out by our first President and Supreme Commander Alija Izetbegović.
The history teaches us that peoples and states lose battles and wars – even when they have the best of weapons – if they do not have a justified cause, the power of conviction and internal unity.
This message we must always bear in mind.
We must be united, strong and organized.
Discourage tyrants with own strength.
Only then, we can defend from assaults our beautiful country and ensure prosperous future for the generations ahead.
Thank you!

title: Speech by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina From the Republic of Srpska H.E. Mr. Nebojsa Radmanovic 67th Session of the United Nations General Assembly Thematic Debate ‘Role of
content:
Bosnia and Herzegovina /hereinafter BiH/ has welcomed the establishment of the ad hoc International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, as a legal framework for ending the tragic period for all the peoples of BiH. After the war, the BiH authorities have consistently and constructively cooperated with the Hague prosecution and the Tribunal, which was positively assessed in the relevant periodic reports and the documents of the United Nations.
Mr. Chairman,
Mr. Secretary-General,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
At the beginning I would like to express my gratitude to the President of the United Nations General Assembly for initiating the idea to convene the General Assembly thematic debate on the role of the International Criminal Justice in reconciliation that is getting more importance in the years after its establishment and instigate different views particularly in the countries and the regions for which the special international tribunals have been established.
I am honored to thank the UN Secretary-General, Mr. Ban Ki-moon, for his last visit to Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region and especially for the support expressed on that occasion.
Three years ago the 65th anniversary of the famous Nuremberg process was marked, where the perpetrators of the most serious war crimes from the Second World War were prosecuted, which have established several legal precedents still being the integral parts of the international law by having become an inspiration for all the subsequent trials at the international level.
Twenty years have passed after the establishment of the first ad hoc Tribunal in the international relations and the tenth anniversary of entering into force of the Rome Statute by which the first permanent International Criminal Tribunal in Hague was established. The fact that the United Nations decided to create several ad hoc, hybrid and special tribunals, confirmed the determination of this world organization to ensure peace, security and respect for human rights in the world, by criminal prosecution of all the perpetrators of war crimes and crimes against humanity. It is not easy to answer whether the twenty years is enough time to review its real effects especially on the reconciliation of the people, which are difficult to determine. Transitional ad hoc international criminal tribunals are relatively new legal mechanism in the international relations to enable rendering a final and decisive evaluation of their work and effects.
Bosnia and Herzegovina /hereinafter BiH/ has welcomed the establishment of the ad hoc International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, as a legal framework for ending the tragic period for all the peoples of BiH. After the war, the BiH authorities have consistently and constructively cooperated with the Hague prosecution and the Tribunal, which was positively assessed in the relevant periodic reports and the documents of the United Nations.
BiH is strongly committed to process all the crimes committed in Bosnia and Herzegovina and to have the perpetrators punished accordingly by the courts.
Trials for the war crimes committed in BiH, are being carried out at several levels: international, before the special international criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, at the courts of the third countries in accordance with the universal jurisdiction principle, at the state and local level before the local courts. The Hague Tribunal has undertaken to process the most sensitive and complex war crimes cases and some less complex and sensitive were assigned to the different levels of the domestic judiciary for further processing.
With the goal of strengthening the processing of war crimes committed during the war in BiH, in 2003 and 2004, special departments for war crimes of the BiH Court and the Prosecutor's Office were formed. National Strategy for War Crimes was developed and adopted by BiH. So far, the country has made significant progress in processing war crimes. According to the national and the international organizations statistics, there still is large number of war crimes that should be processed before the domestic courts.
Before we start the discussion about this complex and delicate issue we must ask ourselves: Why was the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia established? The International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia in Hague was established with the principal intention to prosecute the perpetrators of the worst war crimes in the former Yugoslavia thus preventing any future occurrence of such events, with clear and resolute message that such actions will be punished consistently and without exception. The ICTY was established to determine the individual guilt of all the perpetrators of the most serous war crimes on the territory of the former Yugoslavia and prevent the collectivization of the guilt to the whole population, ethnic and national communities. There is no collective guilt, but only the individual one. Whole nation cannot be blamed for the crimes committed by some individuals on the territory of the former Yugoslavia.
The priority task of the international criminal court should be simultaneous exercise of justice by punishing the war criminals and satisfaction of the victims’ rights, which should contribute to reconciliation among the peoples.
Establishing the truth in the events in BiH and providing justice for the victims of the war should prevent any kind of historical vengeance and retaliation which may come from any group or ethnic community in the country.
Did the court fulfill its duty from the Security Council Resolution? Did some Tribunal’s rulings further traumatize the victims thus having us departed from the ultimate goal: reconciliation through justice for all? Does ICTY with its verdicts return in the past or lead to the future and reconciliation of the people? These are all difficult and complex issues to which we today, I am afraid, cannot give complete and clear answer.
The evaluations of thus far ICTY work and its effects to the process of reconciliation in BiH, are still being done burdened by the increasing political tension within the country and current interethnic mistrust, therefore it is still difficult to bring an objective assessment of its work. The dissatisfaction with some of the ICTY verdicts is present among all three constituent peoples in BiH, as well as the victims of the war. This dissatisfaction is particularly intensified after the latest three acquittals by the ICTY in cases against the Croatian generals, one member of the Albanian paramilitary units from Kosovo and the Chief of Staff of the FR Yugoslavia Army Headquarters.
In my capacity as the Chairman of the tripartite Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina representing the Serbs but also, by the nature of my duty, all three constituent peoples and all the BiH citizens, I must say before this eminent world organization event, that we in BiH, the political representatives of the various peoples, the public and the citizens respectively, have different opinions of the ICTY work. The opinions and views are directly related to the perception the individuals and entire ethnic communities have towards certain verdicts of the Court and its overall activity. Generally speaking, many people in BiH are dissatisfied with the Tribunal’s work and consider their victims are not treated fairly, and that only the perpetrators from their own people are punished. However, there is something we all have in common: the perseverance for all the crimes committed during the war to be prosecuted, the perpetrators punished, and the community satisfied with a sense of justice and the victims’ rights.
There is the widespread perception among the public and the most Republic of Srpska officials that the ICTY is selective and discriminatory against the Serbs convicted before this Court. Among the Serbs people in BiH, some ICTY verdicts have created the sense that they were victims of the Hague Tribunal, apart from having been the victims of the war, as well as the members of other peoples in Bosnia.
The largest paradox of the Hague verdicts is that majority of the Serbs believe that the ICTY has tried only the Serbs people, while, on the Bosniak side, there is a growing dissatisfaction with the high sentences rendered in the cases of the war crimes tried.
Several acquittals having contained a long term sentence in the first instance proceedings were completely overruled after the revision. This has opened the question of how it is possible to completely overrule such judgment and how such judgments contribute to the objectivity and impartial credibility of the court and to what extent they challenge its expertise, objectivity and fair intentions. These acquittals reduce confidence into the overall international criminal justice and judicial system.
The most common complaints and comments from the public on the work of the ICTY are: disproportional sentences, double criteria in the procedure for the same offenses, the selectivity towards the indicted, negative attitude towards the plea agreement on the admission of guilt, overruling of complete sentences to the individuals having been sentenced long-term in the first instance proceedings, without clear indication of who would be responsible for the documented and proven crimes in these and many other cases. ‘The proportionality strategy’ being likely to impose by the Hague Tribunal is unacceptable for all in BiH, but for different reasons, which indicates that we are still far from a unified opinion and view of what happened in our recent past.
In the BiH public there are different interpretations of the events from the war in BiH. There are also manipulations regarding the number of victims and obstructions from the different levels of government and the political elite related to obtaining the facts and documentation of the committed war crimes circumstances. All this is burdening the completion of the extensive and complex engagement of transitional justice as the legal framework for recovery of the war-split society.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
How can the so-far work of the Hague Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia contribute to prevention and deterrence of the future conflicts and crimes, ensure the rights of victims and help the process of reconciliation in the countries that were involved in the local conflicts?
One of the ways to achieve that is to provide researchers and experts the access and insight into the existing archives of the Hague Tribunal, so that everyone has complete written sources from all sides related to the war events in order to get an overall impression of what happened, rather than having just one-sided view of the events. Long lasting peace and reconciliation among the BiH peoples cannot be obtained only by rulings of any court. Reconciliation of the peoples, after such violent conflict, is a process requiring a broad and comprehensive effort of all social and political factors in a society to create the preconditions for true reconciliation. To do so, it is necessary to have an open and honest dialogue of the different actors, government structures, civil society, organizations and associations of the victims and veterans, at all levels, in order to overcome the difficult legacy from the past. One of the ways to overcome this is the inter-ethnic dialogue, particularly between young generations through educational projects on human rights and peace activism. We are encouraged by the more noticeable trend of constructive dialogue and cooperation between the representatives of the associations of victims from different peoples in BiH.
We have set the high and honorable goals - punish all the perpetrators of the worst crimes and violations of international law and the legal system in the territory of the former Yugoslavia. Whether we succeed in that, depends not only on the international community and individual countries, but also on every human being and individual thus the civil society in general.
Thank you.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at the ceremony of marking the Day of the Armed Forces of BiH
content:
We will build the Armed Forces which are capable and ready to efficiently answer to all security and defence challenges, risks and threats – a modern, mobile and well-equipped, educated and motivated army, which fulfils all NATO standards. In order to achieve this final goal, we must continue with the reform activities and with the realization of obligations within the framework on the NATO integration process.
Dear Commander Milojčić, dear soldiers, generals, officers, NCOs, dear guests!
It is my great pleasure and honour to congratulate all members of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all the citizens of our country, 1 December – the Day of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Today we are marking the 7th anniversary of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina and we can proudly say that the defence reform is exactly our greatest success in the last 17 years. And the key achievement of this reform is the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Your commitment and efforts which you put in into this process were of critical significance. Our competent foreign friends marked the progress Bosnia and Herzegovina made in the defence reform as the greatest achievement which a candidate country for NATO accession made in such a relatively short time period. Especially taking into account the initial circumstances in which it was when it started the process of integration to NATO.
However, we have recently been witnesses of more open attacks on the sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina, bringing into question its sustainability, undermining its central institutions, attempts to reverse the reached degree of progress, to nullify the results of painstaking reforms. One of such attempts relates also to the defence reform through publicly expressed request for repeal of the Armed Forces of BiH and demilitarization. We who are building the future of this country and care about peace and security of its citizens will never agree to this. We will make even greater efforts to finish the job we started.
We will build the Armed Forces which are capable and ready to efficiently answer to all security and defence challenges, risks and threats – a modern, mobile and well-equipped, educated and motivated army, which fulfils all NATO standards. In order to achieve this final goal, we must continue with the reform activities and with the realization of obligations within the framework on the NATO integration process.
We are aware that the progress of this process now crucially depends on the fulfillment of the Talin condition for the Membership Action Plan. We are committed to enter the military property on the basis of agreement. We recently had a very significant Decision of the Constitutional Court, in which it was clearly stated that the state is the exclusive owner of state property, thus, and those 63 locations which the Presidency defined as prospective for the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina. That Decision removed all legal doubts relating to this issue, and I believe that it will significantly ease and speed up the fulfillment of the Tallinn condition, and that we will enter the military property very soon, and as a result get a green light to start our Membership Action Plan.
However, regardless of that dynamic, we surely have to continue with the reform processes and further the organizational structure, work and functionality of the Armed Forces and the Ministry of Defence, as that is in our interest.
I wish to clearly send the following message: the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina do not exists only because we wish to become a NATO member state. They exist and will continue to exist because they are needed to Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens. They are an instrument of sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Armed Forces are a guarantee of security and defence of our country. Therefore they will exist and more all the more efficient, strong and more functional.
We have to pay attention and invest considerable funds, especially for the procurement of equipment and technical resources which are necessary for the Armed Forces to execute its duties and obligations. That particularly refers to offering assistance to citizens and civil authorities during natural disasters, as well as the building of secure environment, which we were a witness to this year. Despite limited resources and often inadequate technical resources, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina showed and proved this year, through its efforts, commitment and professionalism, that they are indispensable partner to citizens and civil authorities in reaction to natural and other disasters, execution of demining operations, search operations, savings and medical transport as well as engineering works.
Immense is your contribution to the affirmation of our country at the international scene. Thanks to you and your participation in international peace-building support missions, Bosnia and Herzegovina grew from the recipient of security assistance, to an actor which actively contributes to global security. Spanning from Democratic Republic Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia and Iraq, to Afghanistan, BiH Armed Forces gained trust and respect of allies and showed our country in a positive light.
And this is why we are obliged to, in every opportunity, reaffirm your role and significance, and to ensure that each day, the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina grow stronger and better. With strong Armed Forces, Bosnia and Herzegovina is also strong and safe.
Thank you!

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović over the Day of Sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
It is important to remind again that the founding Decision of ZAVNOBiH Bosnia and Herzegovina was defined as the state of all its citizens and equal peoples – Serbs, Croats and Bosniaks – then the Muslims – as well as the members of other peoples and ethnic groups.
Dear Excellencies, respected guests, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends!
Thank you for coming to, together with us, officially mark 25 November, the Sovereignty Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Today, as is the case with all previous years, we remember with pride and gratitude one generation which in the faithful times stood on the right side of history.
The generation which built its rock to BiH's unquestionable lasting and existence at its First Assembly of ZAVNOBiH in Mrkonjić Grad, on 25 November 1943.
It is important to remind again that the founding Decision of ZAVNOBiH Bosnia and Herzegovina was defined as the state of all its citizens and equal peoples – Serbs, Croats and Bosniaks – then the Muslims – as well as the members of other peoples and ethnic groups.
The sovereignty of BiH, and all important decisions of the First Assembly of ZAVNOBiH, are historically confirmed in the time that followed.
An extremely important document in defining the full sovereignty of BiH also represents the Declaration on the Rights of the Citizens in BiH, which was adopted at the Second Assembly of ZAVNOBiH, a year later, in Sanski Most.
Regulations of this Declaration are in full consent with the modern European standards of protection of freedom of a person and a citizen.
As a reminder, the Declaration on the Rights of a person in BiH guarantees: the freedom of religion, freedom of choice and agreement, associations and press, personal and property security of citizens, freedom of private initiative, as well as equality of women and men.
The confirmation of continuation of the country and the state, the confirmation of equality of people who live in it – those two are the spirit and the letter of ZAVNOBiH. And those are the basic ideas which should always gather again all those who wish well to the peoples and citizens of BiH.
Unfortunately, 17 years after the end of the conflict in our country, some of those who can significantly influence the situation in it, are not ready to come, and together with us confirm these founding values.
On the contrary, some of them more openly and impertinently bring into question the accomplished level of positive reforms, functioning of institutions, as well as the integrity and the future of BiH.
Politicians who will last around a decade think they can bring into question the state which lasts a thousand years. Their anxiety and impertinence are a clear sign of weakness and awareness of own transience. They know that there will be Bosnia – with or without them.
Peace, territorial integrity, survival of BiH, are guaranteed by the superpowers, signatories of the Dayton Peace Agreement; these are also guaranteed by the BiH state institutions, but, before all, they are guaranteed by increasing mass of ordinary people, benevolent citizens in every part of this country.
These are guaranteed by the people who are tired of those who shed evil, hate, fear, xenophobia, from those who call for further divisions, and with it, inevitably, new conflicts.
The time is not on the side of those who stall and destruct progress. They will grow tired. We who build and promote this country will not tire.
The future is on the side of peace and reintegration. It is on the side of all those who love their native soil, those who want for their children to be educated in a stable, prosperous and free state, an equal member of the EU.
We will devotedly continue to work for such future.
We will not agree to oblivion. We will be marking the Sovereignty Day. We will cherish the idea of anti-fascism, universal human rights and freedoms. We will keep the memory of brave and noble predecessors, of their acts which brought light to the darkest moments of history.
We shall fight for BiH to be the country of free and equal peoples. The country in which nobody will suffer or be endangered because of its faith, nation, political opinion or convictions.
On that note, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, I congratulate you 25 November, the Day of Sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: Address by Nebojša Radmanović, BiH Presidency Member from the Republika Srpska and the President of the Organization Committee for the marking of 50 years of existence and work of the Boxing Club “Sla
content:
The Boxing Club “Slavia” tonight with pride celebrates its 50 golden years, and the Boxing Federation of the Republika Srpska its two decades of existence and work, just like our Republika Srpska. Both jubilees are for the sporting pride and long memory. However, jubilees are not only there to remind of the years and decades, but to, before all, keep from oblivion the people who, with their selflessness and enthusiasm wrote the best sporting and boxing pages of Banja Luka, as well as this part of the Balk
Dear friends of boxing,
Ladies and Gentlemen!
The Boxing Club “Slavia” tonight with pride celebrates its 50 golden years, and the Boxing Federation of the Republika Srpska its two decades of existence and work, just like our Republika Srpska.
Both jubilees are for the sporting pride and long memory. However, jubilees are not only there to remind of the years and decades, but to, before all, keep from oblivion the people who, with their selflessness and enthusiasm wrote the best sporting and boxing pages of Banja Luka, as well as this part of the Balkans and Europe.
All that together gives a new dimension to the boxing mission as a noble skill in this region, and it gives “Slavia” a note of recognition of Banja Luka, Republika Srpska and the whole region.
Thank you to Slavia and all those who proudly and boldly wore its kit in the past decades.
The Boxing Club “Slavia” enters the sporting arena of Banja Luka at the end of the 1950s. In November 1959, under this name, in the Factory “Rudi Čajavec” as part of the sporting society “Slavia”, a boxing section was formed. It was the time when the sport of Banja Luka becomes recognisable in the Yugoslav frameworks, thanks to excellent handball players who were led by: Jerolim Karadža, Petar Pero Popović, Vladimir Jović, brothers Stanivuković, who soon also became Yugoslav representatives.
The Football Club “Borac” sought its place in the Yugoslav premium football, and in the year 1960, as the representatives of Yugoslavia, Banja Luka men, Tomo Knez and Velimir Veljo Sombolac became the Olympic winners.
“Slavia” found its place in such society. The real place. The founders of the boxing sport in Banja Luka were, before others, Gojko Krstanović, as well as Muhamed Šehić, Momo Novaković, Duško Smiljanić, Zdravko Torbica and others. The first competitors were the boxing novices: Ćutković, Milanović, Terzić, Mustedanagić, Batar, Latkovac, as well as the ten competitors of the Military Club “Petar Drapšin“ Babić, Veljić, Harbaš, Butić and others.
The trainings used to be held in the basement of the hotel “Rudi Čajavec“ on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, and lasted for an hour. Friendly matches were held. At the beginning of June 1961 it was agreed to form the Boxing Club “Slavia”, and on 25 June 1961, a founding session of the Club was held. Žiža Ostojić, a director of “Rudi Čajavec”, was chosen to be the first president, and members of the committee were: Gojko Krstanović, Jovica Cvijetić, Mišo Bogdanović, Duško Josipović, Muhamed Kapetanović, Mile Babić, Milomir Gligorić, Boro Tadić, Muhamed Šehić and Duško Smiljanić, and on behalf of the competitors, Dragan Batar.
The matches were held at the stadium of sporting games, and when the weather conditions did not permit that, boxers also moved to the movie theatre “Rudi Čajavec”. Very soon “Slavia” became the sporting pet of the city, and the friendly matches used to be attended by more than a thousand fans.
As soon as the competition in the Republican League of Bosnia and Herzegovina was formed, “Slavia” became a member of that league, and its best boxers attended tournaments in Belgrade and Sarajevo. The members of the best team of “Slavia” in that period were: Ćutković, Milanović, Terzić, Andrić, Harbaš, Lajić, Avdić, Vulin, Latkovac, Veljić and Batar.
From year to year, “Slavia” grew stronger and more organised, and the basement rooms of the hotel became too small to accommodate young men who came to train.
The greatest champion of the club was Dragan Batar, who in the year of 1962 was on the list of the best sports persons of Bosanska Krajina came fifth, and five years later the same was accomplished by Satko Glamoč.
During the seventies, under the leadership of Sredoje Zekanović, “Slavia” grows into an excellent team and in 1972 it becomes the Yugoslav first league club. The core of the team comprises Tešić, Pejić, Glamoč, Batar, and Marijan Beneš from match to match grows into a boxing ace. Radovan Bisić comes to the club and Petar Krstić becomes a coach. The champion team is formed: Zdravko and Zvonko Pala, Zembo, Homa, Šindolić, Beneš, Dervoz, Košpić, Jokić, Bisić, Bašić, Ožegović and Ninković.
In the year of “Slavia“ becomes the champion of Yugoslavia. Its first team mark great results in the next almost twenty years. Marijan Beneš becomes the amateur and professional champion of Europe and vice champion of the world, Radovan Bisić wins the European bronze, Dragomir Vujković wins the world's silver, and the great competing period of “Slavia” is rounded by Anton Josipović, who grew in the Club, with the gold medal at the Olympics in 1984, when he was announced as the best boxer in the world by The New York Times. Until the nineties, “Slavia” dominated the Yugoslav boxing scene.
In the hard times of war, the Club existed, worked and was the bearer of activities over the establishment of the Boxing Federation of the Republika Srpska, formed on 25 September 1992, just after the Football Federation.
“Slavia” is the multi champion of today’s Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Today “Slavia” is on the road of big return to the Balkan and European boxing scene. It has proved this with a number of activities marking its 50 golden years. And it has the right to be proud: Anton Josipović is this year's winner of the “April Award” of the City of Banja Luka, the President of the Republika Srpska Milorad Dodik awarded Dragan Batar with the Njegoš medal. Slavia showed its size with the election of Marijan Beneš for the boxer of the century, and he was elected by the greatest aces of the Club, lead by the Olympic winner Anton Josipović.
“Slavia” is one of the rare clubs in the world which found itself on a postal stamp, a Memorial “Radovan Bisić”, held on the Krajina Square was selected, by the official marks of AIBA and EABA, among the best organised manifestations in Europe and the world in the Olympic boxing.
With this short recap, before all of “Slavia’s” very beginning, followed by that came next, I did not mention many little-great competitors, because that would lead us to infinity. I did not speak about the whole army of sporting enthusiasts and fans. To all of them, “Slavia” will soon gift a representation monograph with the best Banja Luka sporting and boxing stories, which will keep the memory of “Slavia’s” competitors, committee members, and Club secretaries, simply – all “Slavia’s” men in the past five decades will be in one place.
By opening of the exhibition of the past years, and this official Academy, “Slavia” is proving its greatness and opening doors for the great future.
Thank you.

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, at the General Debate of the 67 th Session of the United Nations General Assembly
content:
I also want to commend the Secretary General for his tireless efforts to advance dialogue and cooperation, and his firm commitment to the core values and principles of the United Nations. We in Bosnia and Herzegovina recognize the importance of, and we fully support his action agenda that identified five generational imperatives: prevention, a more secure world, helping countries in transition, empowering women and youth, and sustainable development.
Mr. President, Mr. Secretary-General, Distinguished Delegates, Ladies and Gentlemen, good morning!
I would like to congratulate you, Mr. President, on your election and thank Mr. Nassir Abdulaziz Al-Nasser for successfully presiding over the previous session of the General Assembly.
I also wish to express my deepest gratitude to Secretary General Ban Ki-moon for visiting my country this July. As we are marking the twentieth anniversary of our admission to the United Nations, his visit came as recognition that Bosnia and Herzegovina has travelled a long way since joining this Organization, having transformed itself from a recipient of security assistance into a contributor to global peace and security.
I also want to commend the Secretary General for his tireless efforts to advance dialogue and cooperation, and his firm commitment to the core values and principles of the United Nations. We in Bosnia and Herzegovina recognize the importance of, and we fully support his action agenda that identified five generational imperatives: prevention, a more secure world, helping countries in transition, empowering women and youth, and sustainable development.
Mr. President,
Today’s world is a scene of unfolding crises and mounting global challenges. The first and foremost of these is the disaster in Syria.
As we stand here, our fellow Syrians are fighting against a brutal regime. They are fighting to take their destiny into their own hands. The regime of Bashar al-Assad is answering their yearning for freedom and democracy with guns and bombs, just like his father's regime did thirty years ago. This is revolting and morally reprehensible. But so is our collective failure to stop it.
Once again, we are idly standing by while a human tragedy of dramatic proportions is unfolding before our eyes. We should do our part to help the Syrian people's historic stand for freedom. We should do our part to save the people of Syria from tyranny. We should. But we are not.
The images coming from Syria remind us of the tragedy of Bosnia. We in Bosnia and Herzegovina feel the pain of the Syrian people as our own because we went through the same horrors not that long ago.
When the Secretary General Ban Ki-moon visited Srebrenica with me this July to pay respects to the genocide victims, he said:
“The international community must be united not to see any further bloodshed in Syria because I do not want to see any of my successors, after 20 years, visiting Syria, apologizing for what we could have done to protect the civilians in Syria – which we are not doing now”.
His predecessor, Kofi Annan, stated in the report on the fall of Srebrenica:
“Through error, misjudgment and an inability to recognize the scope of the evil confronting us, we failed to do our part to help save the people of Srebrenica….The tragedy of Srebrenica will haunt our history forever….”
Today, these words ring true about this Organization’s failure to respond to the tragedy in Syria.
The best way to honor the victims of the Srebrenica genocide would have been to learn the lessons of that failure and not to commit the same errors ever again. Sadly, the United Nations, especially its Security Council, have failed to do so.
The international community has chosen, yet again, to repeat the trial-and-error pattern of policies that failed in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The resolutions, statements of concern, ineffective sanctions, observers, and no mandate to protect civilians are actions that have deadly consequences demonstrated in my country.
Make no mistake. Unless we act now and act decisively to help the people of Syria and put an end to their bloodshed, this tragedy will haunt our history forever, just like Srebrenica.
Mr. President,
The developments at the beginning of the twenty-first century defy rational prediction.
Indeed, who could have predicted such an explosion of freedom in the Middle East?
In the last few years, we have been witnessing a historic awakening in the Arab world. Underway now are profound social and political changes, aimed at creating democratic societies.
These changes have been fermenting for decades. They are the best confirmation that Muslims strongly strive for freedom, dignity, and human rights.
A well-educated, free-thinking generation of young Arabs has finally broken the chains of dictatorship. No force can prevent this new generation from taking charge of their destiny.
As a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, Bosnia and Herzegovina strongly supported the Arab peoples’ aspirations for greater freedom and democracy. We acted to ensure that the international community supported those who wanted free societies instead of closed ones, rule of law instead of rule of one person, democracy instead of dictatorship, justice and fairness instead of oppression and corruption.
Mr. President,
The stalemate in resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is deeply troubling. The peace process is not moving forward. The chain of violence has not broken.
A new impetus to negotiations is urgently needed because there is no alternative to a negotiated solution.
The Palestinians have every right – historic, moral, and legal – to a state of their own. Israel has every right to its security. The occupation must end. But so must the terror and violence.
All attempts to create new realities on the ground in the hope those will become accepted as a starting point of future negotiations must be rejected. The continuation of settlement activities on occupied Palestinian territories continues to pose the most serious obstacle to peace. Israel should immediately end all settlement activities in occupied Palestinian territories because these activities are illegal under international law. Doing so is in Israel’s own best interest if it truly desires peace with the Palestinians.
The state of affairs of sixty or six thousand years ago is not the right point of reference. The right reference point for a solution is the principle of peaceful coexistence of two sovereign states – an independent Palestine and a secure Israel. That is the only realistic way to bring about a just resolution to the conflict and ensure stability and progress in the Middle East.
To achieve such a solution, a more sincere attempt at good-faith negotiations is needed, especially by Israel. The road to peace does not go by way of ignoring the United Nations resolutions, by squeezing the Palestinians to the leftovers of the land that once belonged to their fathers, and by building settlements on those leftovers.
This Organization must send a strong message that its resolutions have to be respected – that there are no double standards or chosen peoples when it comes to the application of the international legal norms and human rights principles.
Mr. President,
In the past weeks we have witnessed disturbing violence linked to intolerance. The video that sparked these developments is deeply insulting. It deserves the strongest condemnation, and we absolutely reject its content and message.
There is, however, no justification for responding to this movie with violence. Violence in response to speech is unacceptable. There can be no debate about that. Violence is no way to honor religion. Responding to bigotry with violance only fans the flames of intolerance further.
We must draw the line at violence. But we also must find a way to prevent hate speech and bigotry. Yes, there is the right to free speech. But there is also the right to dignity.
We cannot impose our ideology or our religion on anyone else. We must promote tolerance. But we must also promote mutual respect. That is why, as responsible leaders, we should have a frank debate about the outer limits of free expression when that freedom is abused to incite hate and deliberately slander the dignity of others.
Mr. President,
There is no inherent contradiction between Islamic and Western values. To the contrary, these values are compatible. After all, they derive from the same sources. Throughout history, interactions between these values have led to tremendous achievements.
There is no clash. There are only those who need to create a false perception of clash in order to come to power or maintain their hold on power.
So many societies in today’s world are in transition, yearning to find a balance between traditional and modern values. The relation between the West and the Islamic world and between their respective value systems is going to be one of the most critical issues of our time. That relation will pass through crises and periods of misunderstanding and intolerance. In this modern age, we have to keep searching for a formula, a model for how to reconcile the relations between Islamic and Western values, between the East and West. No matter how hard it may be, finding that formula is going to be essential in the time ahead of us.
The human condition is one of diversity. Our human race is a mosaic composed of a rich variety of peoples, cultures and religions that shine together in a dynamic, sparkling pattern. Our responsibility is to nurture and protect that mosaic.
I come from a country whose historical experience can offer valuable lessons in finding a model for peaceful co-existence of such diversity. The whole world can benefit from the lessons my country has learned from constantly seeking to improve its understanding and management of diversity.
For hundreds of years, its citizens lived in harmony, helping each other to build houses of worship that almost physically lean on one another. The westernmost range of Orthodox Christianity and Islam, the easternmost range of Catholicism, Bosnia is a meeting point of civilizations, a bridge between the East and the West. Its unique multiethnic culture has been woven through one thousand years of tolerance and respect among its citizens, regardless of their ethnic and religious affiliation. That is why its preservation and success, as a specific microcosm, is crucial for the whole world.
But due to our recent past, a great struggle is now underway in my country between the idea of co-existence and the idea of division. I believe the outcome of this struggle will have a significant bearing on resolving one of the greatest challenges of our time -- that of conflict versus cooperation. If the idea of co-existence and cooperation does not prevail in Bosnia, it can hardly prevail anywhere else in this world of ours. If the unique social fabric of my country, that was torn by crimes and force, is not renewed, that will be a defeat for the very idea of co-existance. It will be a defeat that will produce a widening gap at one of the most delicate fault lines of our world.
Mr. President,
The growing power of humankind brings progress and prosperity. Yet, the selfish side of that power cuts into the very substance on which our future depends - our physical habitat and our spiritual essence.
The world we live in is changing at a speed and in a direction that is rightfully worrysome. Inequality, injustice, and intolerance are rising. There is more conflict and less cooperation. There is ever more violence and ever less compassion, solidarity, mutual care, healthy interpersonal relations and family life. People around the world take to the streets in a dramatic warning that there is ever less fairness in the societies in which they live. These unsetlling trends can be reversed only by a decisive and coordinated global action. The future we desire will not be a utopia if we join our forces in finding the right solutions. Cooperative approaches are difficult to accomplish but are needed more than ever.
We are not perfect, but we can be better. We can be wiser, more responsible, more willing to learn from our past mistakes. Too often we have been prisoner of our own mentality. We perceive willingness to compromise as a weakness. But just the opposite is true – compromise requires courage.
To build a future, we must make compromises. To succeed, we must stop indulging in manipulative kinds of populism. We must break out of the worn and frayed patterns of the past. We must turn to the future. Instead of having endless debates about what has been, we must devote ourselves to reaching agreements about what can be.
We must correctly interpret the interests of those we represent. We must listen to the views of others, no matter how different those views may be. We must understand each other better and respect each other more.
Mr. President,
Our most important mission in the time to come will be to build bridges between cultures, religions, and civilizations; bridges of trust, understanding, and respect; bridges to reach problems the true nature of which we have only begun to understand. That is hard work that requires daring leadership.
This Organization has gone through difficult trials. But it has always been the best framework for building those bridges. Let us keep it that way going forward.
Thank you very much.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović at the International Conference “Security of the Balkans, technology and education – challenges in the world of cyber infrastructure”, Sarajevo 13
content:
I see today’s conference as another confirmation of the firm commitment of all states in our region to the strengthening of mutual cooperation. I hope that at this conference, you will offer answers to numerous questions which the time of powerful, fast technological progress sets before us, but also to the challenges and security risks brought by this progress.
Minister of Security Ahmetović,
Prime Minister of the Republic of Serbia Dačić,
Distinguished ministers, ambassadors, representatives, professors,
Dear guests!
Welcome to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is my enormous pleasure to, as a sponsor of this conference, greet you and wish you successful work.
I wish to thank the Ministry of Security of Bosnia and Herzegovina, headed by the Minister Ahmetović, and the American University, headed by Mr. Prcić, for the organization of this conference.
I see today’s conference as another confirmation of the firm commitment of all states in our region to the strengthening of mutual cooperation.
I hope that at this conference, you will offer answers to numerous questions which the time of powerful, fast technological progress sets before us, but also to the challenges and security risks brought by this progress.
Security is the basis of stability and prosperity of every state.
In that context, the fight against organized crime is of the utmost priority.
Although it can sometimes sound as a known phrase, I will repeat it here: the fact is that organized crime acts jointly, in coordination, not recognizing the state borders, or national divisions.
The regional cooperation in the field of security has no alternative. In order for it to be a successful story, we need a clear regional security strategy, operational communication, coordination and cooperation.
But before all it is needed for us to have mutual trust. It is best built precisely through the dialogue of security leaders such as this gathering of today is.
None of our states can successfully confront nor protect from complex and mutually linked security challenges which threaten us in the modern global surroundings we live in.
Surely, none of the states of our region individually, or the wider area of the Balkans, can act alone without strong international institutions and systems, and in that context every single cooperation is necessary and welcome.
The specific thematic framework planned for this meeting is an excellent opportunity to approach the problem of cyber security, that is, the fight against the modern plaque of highly technological, computer crime, in a thorough, serious and scientifically relevant way.
It is my particular pleasure that the organizers of today’s gathering are the Ministry of Security of BiH and the American University.
A close cooperation among the government institutions and scientific-academic institutions is necessary and will be of key importance for us to dedicate a systematic and organized attention and successfully confront the threats and challenges in the field of cyber security.
The institutions which fight and which in future will face even more threats of cyber crime, are, along with the political support and financial resources, require necessary expert, educated staff with the necessary knowledge and skills to answer to the technically extremely complex types of cyber crime.
A tight link between the government institutions, education and economy is the key to every positive story.
That is why I do not doubt that today’s gathering will be the beginning of an all-encompassing and orchestrated process of cooperation in the field of fight against cyber crime.
Once again, I wish you a successful conference and pleasant stay in Sarajevo.
Cheers!

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović at the Opening of the International Conference for Peace
content:
Five months ago we marked the 20th Anniversary of the beginning of the siege of Sarajevo. We remembered our citizens who were killed - with dignity, in silence, with 11.541 empty, red chairs lined up along the main city street. The entire world of progress was with us on that day – as they were with us during more than forty months of siege; between 1992 and 1995.
Your Eminencies,
Distinguished Excellencies,
Dear Organizers,
Dear Guests!
Five months ago we marked the 20th Anniversary of the beginning of the siege of Sarajevo. We remembered our citizens who were killed - with dignity, in silence, with 11.541 empty, red chairs lined up along the main city street. The entire world of progress was with us on that day – as they were with us during more than forty months of siege; between 1992 and 1995.
Therefore, it is my great pleasure that in the days before us we are going to send powerful messages about the possibility of life together of the people of different religions and cultures – from the city which experienced the faith of the biggest Concentration Camp in the 20th Century Europe, the Symbol City, the city which in its hardest moments did not give up on the fight for the universal principles of humanism. .
For hundreds of years the citizens of this City have lived in harmony, helping each other in building oratories which physically almost touch and lean on each other. It is only in Sarajevo that within a kilometre square there are a Cathedral, an Old Orthodox Church, Mosques, a Synagogue, and a Protestant Church.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a special meeting point of the worlds – the most western reach of Orthodox Christianity and Islam, and the most Eastern reach of the Catholicism. The most unique culture of this country has been woven through the thousand years of tolerance, respect and trust amongst its citizens, regardless their nation or religion.
Through its thousand year history, this country has been a sanctuary and homeland to an incredible mixture of peoples, religions and cultures. It is one of the places on the planet Earth in which relations and emotions of the entire World entangle and unravel. Bosnia and Herzegovina is the junction of civilizations. That is why it does not belong to its citizens only. Preservation and success of Bosnia and Herzegovina, being a specific microcosm, is of crucial importance to the entire World. .
Fra Petar Anđelović, a great man, a great Bosnian, an associate and friend of my father Alija Izetbegović, while receiving the Human Rights Prize in Germany fifteen years ago, said the following:
“The very name of Bosnia, or the Bosnian, is not a term of national or territorial order. It is, before all, or more than anything else, a mark for a civilization process which through the historic changes and political events has been going on for a Millennium. Bosnia has been a place of clashes for only several years, and those projected from the outside. Bosnia has always been melting point of peoples, religions and customs. And for this reason it has always been great and unusual; and being such it cannot die, for if it dies, so will the example of how people can live together and live through the threats of the forthcoming times”
There is a historic battle led in Bosnia and Herzegovina result of which will answer one of the greatest dilemmas of our times: Will the idea of life together or the one of division win?
If the idea of life together does not win in Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is hard for that idea to win anywhere in this complicated World of ours. If for the thousand years woven weft torn by crimes and force is not renewed, the entire World will be defeated. It will be the defeat which will produce a widening gap in one of the most delicate binding of humanity.
The gatherings as this one is can be of crucial aid to the affirmation of a positive future scenario, for they bring together people of thought and spirit who create public opinion, and who recognize the importance of the process which is taking place here in Bosnia and Herzegovina to the whole World. The World can learn important lessons in Bosnia and Herzegovina: the lessons about good and evil, about open mindedness and narrow mindedness, about wisdom and stupidity.
The growing power of a man brings progress and wellbeing. Yet the selfish side of that power awakes the very substance on which the future of the planet Earth and human kind depend - tangible and spiritual essence. The World we live in changes before our very eyes and grows in speed and direction which is worrying. There are more and more wars, violence, pollutions and less of good, compassion, mutual care and healthy interpersonal relations and family life. It is only by decisive, global and coordinated action that this negative trend can be stopped.
We owe it to our home, the Blue Planet which is entirely unique in the whole Universe. There is nothing similar as far as the most powerful telescope can reach. Everything on it testifies about the Almighty Creator. About the One Who Creates and overcomes the nothingness with existence, the deadness with life, determination with freedom. It is us - who are imperfect - that have been entrusted with the perfect harmony. We are not, but we can be better. We can be wiser, more aware of the responsibility, more ready to learn from our earlier mistakes and not repeat them.
Dear Friends!
I wish you a pleasant stay in Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina. I wish for us to send important and clear messages from this city to the World – the messages of tolerance, mutual pervading life, respect for others and different, and respect of human rights.
In two years, in 2014, Europe and the World will mark the 100th Anniversary of the Sarajevo Assassination, the event which was the reason for the beginning of the WWI and an introduction into the century of wars and suffering of tens of millions of peoples. It will be an opportunity for all of us to jointly say that the humanity has overcome those horrible and important lessons. It will be an opportunity for us to, from this Martyr City, and the Hero City, we announce the century of peace and prosperity of the human kind.
Thank you!

title: BiH Presidency Member from the Republika Srpska Nebojša Radmanović received today Hideo Yamazaki, the Ambassador of Japan to BiH
content:
BiH Presidency Member from the RS Radmanović and Ambassador Yamazaki talked about the current political situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the current political problems faced by Bosnia and Herzegovina on its European path.
BiH Presidency Member from the RS Radmanović and Ambassador Yamazaki talked about the current political situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the current political problems faced by Bosnia and Herzegovina on its European path.
BiH Presidency Member from the RS Radmanović informed the Ambassador about the current political happenings and problems in fulfilling the commitments of the national leaders, as agreed with the representatives of the European Union in Brussels. He pointed out to a clear fact that Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot fulfill the commitments in the planned deadline, which is further negatively affected by the political confusion in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in relation to the composition of the ruling coalition, and the election campaign for the forthcoming local elections in BiH.
The two interlocutors expressed hope that, despite the evident political differences and the rivalry of the parties, the local elections in BiH will pass in a democratic atmosphere. BiH Presidency Member from the RS Radmanović thanked the Ambassador for his understanding of the political situation within Bosnia and Herzegovina and a great support which Japan continuously offers to BiH.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović in Brussels
content:
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a complex country with a difficult burden of the newer history. Our constitutional and political system is based on a peace agreement. That peace agreement is as it is and could not have been different because its goal was to satisfy the needs of the conflicting parties so that they have the mechanisms of protection against dominance. And such mechanisms are, in their nature, the mechanisms of stopping, and not the mechanisms of initiating.
Dear Commissioner Füle,
Commissioner Potočnik,
Chairman Bevanda,
Party presidents,
Ladies and gentlemen!
I wish to thank Commissioner Füle for the organization of this gathering today, which is the first of its kind.
These meetings should become a regular practice, because we need a more intensive political dialogue with the highest officials of the European Union.
I see today’s meeting as one more confirmation that the doors of the European Union are open for us. However, it is our responsibility to use this opportunity betters, so that we speed up the process of the accession of our country to the European Union.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a complex country with a difficult burden of the newer history. Our constitutional and political system is based on a peace agreement. That peace agreement is as it is and could not have been different because its goal was to satisfy the needs of the conflicting parties so that they have the mechanisms of protection against dominance. And such mechanisms are, in their nature, the mechanisms of stopping, and not the mechanisms of initiating.
Bosna i Hercegovina je kompleksna država sa teškim bremenom novije historije. Naš ustavni i politički sistem je baziran na mirovnom sporazumu. Taj sporazum je takav kakav jeste i nije mogao biti drugačiji zato jer mu je cilj bio da zadovolji potrebe suprotstavljenih strana da imaju mehanizme zaštite od dominacije. A takvi mehanizmi su, po svojoj prirodi, mehanizmi zaustavljanja, a ne mehanizmi pokretanja.
There are opposing emotions and differing views on the past and the future in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Because of that, it is hard to reach compromises, and particularly via consensus on important questions.
Still, building of European future and integration into the EU is a clearly expressed wish, intention and interest of all in Bosnia and Herzegovina. And there are several reasons for this.
Firstly, the European path is the only realistic platform on which a long term stability and prosperity of our country can be assured.
Secondly, we are aware of the advantages which the EU accession brings. It is in our absolute interest to be a part of the association of organized states among and within which there is peace, understanding, the rule of Law, equal standards, high level of human rights protection and culture of dialogue.
And thirdly, the process of association itself, that is, the adjustment to the legal heritage of the EU and the standards which are there in the various fields of social activities is important to us. That process represents a tool for reforms which we will utilise to create an organised society and functional state which guarantees prosperity.
Despite the awareness and readiness, expressed wish and recognised interest, Bosnia and Herzegovina seriously and every day increasingly lags behind the rest of the states of the region in the process of European integrations.
Therefore, the question we need to answer is: How do we make and maintain long term progress on that European path?
Before all, we have to look towards and dedicate ourselves to the future. We must stop with wrangling on what happened before and finally devote ourselves to reaching agreement on what can and needs to be achieved.
The European future of Bosnia and Herzegovina can only be built on the basis of compromise which recognise interests and rights of all: the state, both entities, all three of the constitutive peoples and all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
That is why the future reforms should not be directed towards the centralisation, nor should they be directed towards decentralisation, but towards integration, coordination and synchronisation.
We need to avoid situations in which any part of our country should feel jeopardised or neglected. The state, entities and cantons, as well as the Brčko District must have their property over the process of BiH integrations to the EU, for in any different way we would be facing blockades and procrastinations.
European Officials expect Bosnia and Herzegovina to communicate with the EU with one voice, the precondition for which is that all communication from our side be agreed in advance and within the framework of the existing institutions, at all levels of government.
A complex structure of our state has been a serious challenge in the process of agreement reaching and negotiations with the EU representatives.
The main problem is the absence of possibility of solving political disputes within the institutions, as well as the absence of obligation for the tasks taken to be executed.
