Therefore, it is of the greatest importance for us today to recognise the need and to reach fundamental consensus in establishing a single functioning and efficient mechanism of coordination of the European actions in BiH.
This mechanism of coordination must not be cumbersome. It must be “institutionally and politically correct”, that is, it must respect the Dayton Constitution organisation and the existing organisation of the state apparatus and in that way to represent an efficient upgrade of that apparatus.
It is necessary for this mechanism to formalise political coordination, which will have an obligation to solve open questions and disputes, and to give compulsory directives to experts and persons in charge at all levels of government. Besides that, we must strengthen the capacity of the state services in order for them to be able to carry out these tasks.
The today’s meeting is taking place at the time of another political crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina, especially in the Federation. It is due to that fact, of which we all here are very aware, I am inviting you to make sure that this gathering of ours passes in the atmosphere of tolerant talks focused on what we are all here for and on which we all agree. And that is the acceleration of the process of the EU accession. At this moment, all our mutual misunderstandings should be put aside for the sake of the higher cause.
I expect us all to clearly express readiness to, in the spirit of compromise, take necessary steps in order to fulfill all the conditions for membership application submission which would be considered credible by the EU. The most important of those is the implementation of the Sejdić – Finci Ruling. It would be an extremely good message to send if at today’s meeting we agreed to fulfill these conditions within the precisely set deadlines.
I am certain that we will have enough wisdom and the European way of thinking in order to cope with the challenges before us. Bosnia and Herzegovina is a European state, the Europeans live in Bosnia and Herzegovina and it is time for that ship to be anchored in her home harbor.
That historical task is of this generation of politicians and I firmly believe that we all are aware of it.
Thank you!

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member from Republika Srpska Nebojša Radmanović at the Summit of Head of States of the South
content:
This SEECP Summit is being held at the time of the global financial and economic crisis which in particular has shaken the Euro-zone and the countries of our region. Bosnia and Herzegovina has been, from the beginning, consistently dedicated to the regional cooperation as a way and the path which substitutes the times of conflicts and tense relations between the countries of the South-East Europe, which we confirmed during our presiding of this initiative some years ago.
Distinguished Mister Chairman,
Distinguished Presidents,
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
At the beginning I wish before all to thank the organisers of this important gathering, primarily to our host, President of the Republic of Serbia Tomislav Nikolić for the excellent and successful organisation of the Summit of Head of States of the South-East Europe Cooperation Process. Also, Mister President, I once again wish to congratulate you on having been elected the President of the Republic of Serbia and I wish you plenty of success in performing this great duty entrusted to you by the Serb people and other citizens of Serbia.
This SEECP Summit is being held at the time of the global financial and economic crisis which in particular has shaken the Euro-zone and the countries of our region. Bosnia and Herzegovina has been, from the beginning, consistently dedicated to the regional cooperation as a way and the path which substitutes the times of conflicts and tense relations between the countries of the South-East Europe, which we confirmed during our presiding of this initiative some years ago. Bosnia and Herzegovina seeks to develop regional cooperation in accordance with the overall European determination and its own economic and political interests.
The SEECP is a forum for political dialogue on the questions of cooperation among the states of the region and as such it has potentials. The existence and such work of the states in the South-East Europe does not limit other forms, models and channels for regional cooperation to also exist in the region.
The concrete activities on creating bonds among our countries in the fields of economy, trade, transport and communication represent regional property within mutual relations. The Council Regional Cooperation is a framework wide enough within which the regional cooperation can be exercised respecting basic rules. We are against further institutionalisation of the SEECP and other regional initiatives for it only leads towards further unnecessary bureaucratisation of this process and covering of the concrete core of the relations among the states. All other open issues among the states we should solve through bilateral relations, dialogue or negotiations, using existing institutional mechanisms of the UN, EU and OSCE on the basis of the International Law.
This year, the Council of Ministers was formed in BiH, fifteen months after the elections, which was followed by the launch of the started reforms. As a result the Laws on State Aid and Census, which for long were in the Parliamentary procedures, were passed. The structural dialogue on the Judiciary with the EU assistance is continued. The final consultations among the parliamentary parties with regards to the final formulation for the implementation of the Decision of the European Court in Strasbourg are ongoing with an aim of adjusting BiH Constitution to the European Convention on Human Rights. We now only need to begin talks on building coordination mechanism needed for BiH accession to the EU. If this job is successfully done by the end of the year, BiH plans to submit the EU membership candidate application. With this aim, we expect that the high level dialogue to be held on the process of BiH accession to the EU, which is to take place by the end of this month in Brussels, to offer certain solutions and guidance in this process.
BiH is devoted to the EU integrations, regardless the occasional halts and slowness in solving certain conditions set on that path. The EU is our goal so that any calculations with regards to further enlargement, prior deadlines setting for certain countries or the group of countries, which we hear of from certain European circles, can be counterproductive and damaging to the entire region. We oppose the suspension of further enlargement of the EU after Croatia joins in 2013, which certain political powers in Europe speak for such political divides the region and the rest of the countries in Europe, in those which can and those which cannot be the EU members. That is a bad message to the entire region but the Europe too. It will increase the euro-scepticism and which I, due to the euro zone crisis, strongly present in the region. It will too encourage further divisions and fragmentations in the region. The sooner we get the candidate status, the more motivated we will be to join the EU and work on the realisation of pre-accession obligations and vice versa.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
In BiH, we appreciate the understanding shown for our internal situation, the complicated constitutional-legal organisation and political specificity. We thank all of you who good willingly wish to help us, but here I have to say that, for further development and progress no outer mediators are needed. We can and must solve our internal problems alone, because it is in our best interest. We need support in what we agree in order to implement it. We need the input of positive experiences of other countries in similar situations, and not the recipes from the past, ultimatums and pressures. Bosnia and Herzegovina, based on the Dayton Agreement, and with the assistance of the EU Special Representative in BiH, has all realistic and needed conditions for fulfilling necessary reform obligations and changes towards the EU membership.
When BiH stance towards regional questions is of the matter I will repeat our well known and unchangeable position. Bosnia and Herzegovina stands for the question of Kosovo and Metohia to be solved through negotiations on the basis of a dialogue between Belgrade and Pristina, within the frame of the UN Resolution 1244 and negotiating arrangements with the EU.
Finally, I wish to once again thank the host for the well-organized gathering, constructive approach of the participants and wish plenty of success to all in future work of the regional initiative. I wish plenty of success to the host of our next SEECP in organising and preparing it.
Thank you

title: Address of BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović at the Ceremony of unveiling of the monument to the men from Bosnia and Herzegovina who fought and died on the Isonzo Front in the First World War
content:
These beautiful landscapes, miraculous beauty and well preserved natural harmony in no way today reveal that only a century ago here the history of Europe and the mankind was being written in blood. In these inhospitable mountain cliffs and canyons, most often in capricious storms, icy rains, snows and blizzards, thousands of soldiers were dying on the Isonzo Front, in the one of the strategically most important areas in the Great War, as WWI was called then.
Dear President Türk,
Distinguished hosts, dear friends!
These beautiful landscapes, miraculous beauty and well preserved natural harmony in no way today reveal that only a century ago here the history of Europe and the mankind was being written in blood.
In these inhospitable mountain cliffs and canyons, most often in capricious storms, icy rains, snows and blizzards, thousands of soldiers were dying on the Isonzo Front, in the one of the strategically most important areas in the Great War, as WWI was called then.
A significant number of Bosniaks fought within the Austro-Hungarian Army on the Isonzo Front. It is important to remind that all of the members of the Tzar’s Regiments from Bosnia and Herzegovina were called Bosniaks regardless they religion.
Bosnia and Herzegovina largely affected the destiny of Austria. The 40 year long Epoch, 1878 to 1918, characterised by the intensive historical events, marked a significant rise and the later disappearance of the Empire as the European and World power.
In all those events, Bosnia and Herzegovina was an unavoidable factor on which the lasting historical marks were left.
Historical facts are those that the Bosniaks had given an unexpectedly powerful resistance to the Austro-Hungarian occupation. It is truth that the Austro-Hungarian Monarchy was the State of Law in which religious and national rights were protected, which was fair towards the Bosniaks, and to which the Bosniaks returned by being fair and devoted –they were loyal, brave, professional and devoted members of the Tzar’s Regiments.
World War I began after Gavrilo Princip unfortunately assassinated Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo, the war in which the Bosniaks devotedly fought within the Austro-Hungarian Empire. Austria used the military potentials of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the maximum. According to data from those times, in the period of WWI, the troops of Bosnia and Herzegovina, within the Austro-Hungarian Military counted over 250 000 men.
There are numerous testimonies of the courage and fighting skill of the Bosnian soldiers. Hundreds of Bosniaks were awarded highest Austro-Hungarian medals.
Yet the biggest hardships and sacrifices of the War were taken by the Bosniaks, to which the Isonzo Front testifies and this cemetery on which we remember them today with the greatest respect.
The Bosnian 4 Regiment (BH Regiment 4) was one of the assault divisions which by chest to chest fighting broke through the Italian lines during the last Isonzo Battle, and brought the turn and the final victory to the Austrian side. During WWI almost 5000 Bosniaks lost their lives in the area of Slovenia, out of which 859 found their eternal rest at this cemetery.
I particularly wish to thank our distinguished Mufti Nedžad Grabus today who, along with the indispensible and important support of Slovenia, did everything for the cemetery in Log under the Mangart to be the place which will continue to preserve the memory of men to whom the history determined faith to leave their bones away from their homes and families, and away from their homeland. By placing the nišan tombstones the multi-decade long post-mortem injustice caused to Bosniak-Muslims on whose graves the religious symbols of others were placed during the SHS Kingdom era has ended.
This Ceremony too is an opportunity for us to testify that at places like this the history lessons are best learned and for us to send the messages of peace, to our region before all which still has not buried all of its dead from the wars of the 1990s, but to Europe too with the hope and belief that the 21st Century we shall spend without wars and bloodsheds.
Dear friends,
My country and my people have their own millennium and historical path. The Bosniaks fought for Sultans and Tzars, they loyally wore the Partisans’ five-point star, and with great passion tried to save Yugoslavia.
The wheel of history most of the times was against them, threatened to run them over and wipe them off the face of the Earth.
On such, most of the time tragic, experience the Bosnia and Herzegovina of today was made. In the last war Bosniaks fought for their country only. In future they are ready to be a part of state and military alliances which will guard and enhance global peace and prosperity.
The reformed Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina of today, made of three national components, take part in NATO missions contributing the construction of the architecture of world peace and stability.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, being yesterday’s receiver of aid, has become an active contributor in resolving the world crises. We shall continue walking that path.
The Euro-Atlantic integrations have no alternative for us, for it is only like that shall our future generations be in a position to live in peace and prosperity.
I hope that young Bosnians, yet all others too, will not leave their homes in future to fight wars, but to spend their energy on saving this planet of ours and making it a good place to live in mutual respect.
May the schools and universities be our most important frontlines.
In order to realize that we must never forget those to whom history determined a different faith, as it was with our ancestors, the brave and proud Bosnian warriors of the Isonzo and the Alps.
I pray to God to give their souls His compassion, forgiveness and eternal peace!
Thank you.
Slovenia, Log under the Mangart, 7 June 2012

title: ADDRESS BY THE CHAIRMAN OF THE PRESIDENCY OF BiH BAKIR IZETBEGOVIĆ AT THE 10th UNESCO SUMMIT OF HEADS OF STATES OF SOUTH EAST EUROPE, MOSTAR 02
content:
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a good meeting place, because each one of us can find a piece of his/her identity and tradition here. As you will see just a step away from this place, in Međugorje, Catholics from the whole of the world gather, and in its vicinity is the Blagaj Tekke (House) where Muslims, as if doing a pilgrimage, come, and the Žitomislići Orthodox temple is nearby.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a good meeting place, because each one of us can find a piece of his/her identity and tradition here. As you will see just a step away from this place, in Međugorje, Catholics from the whole of the world gather, and in its vicinity is the Blagaj Tekke (House) where Muslims, as if doing a pilgrimage, come, and the Žitomislići Orthodox temple is nearby.
Here live by origin and roots connected followers of Faith in One God, similar in all but the way they address Him.
The apparent Bosnian-Herzegovinian complexity was known to be the source of numerous prejudices and trivial simplifications, for which this country paid a high price. However, multi-religiousness, cultural and civilization complexity throughout her long history were more often the advantages and the wealth which she was recognised by, and much more rarely a handicap which brought her into question. Such Bosnia and Herzegovina, despite contrasts, or rather, thanks to them, has been carrying within herself a specific spirituality the significance of which transgresses her size, strength and wealth. The possibility of her existence witnesses the possibility of the survival of diversity, and with it, the world at large.
Parallel to Catholicism and Orthodoxy, surviving in the Middle Ages, with its peak in the 14th and 15th Centuries, was a strong heretical Bosnian Church, which we call Bogomil, so that trichotomy, lastly with Islam also, appears in her history as a kind of a dare. The worldly flair was given to this country by Judaism, which following the extradition from Spain, gained sanctuary in Bosnia, the then part of the Ottoman Empire.
One of the most distinctive characteristics of Herzegovina is the Old Bridge, the pearl of cultural heritage, where we have gathered today, next to its arch.
It is not coincidental that both Bosnian-Herzegovinian properties registered on the list of the world’s cultural heritage under UNESCO protection are precisely bridges: the Višegrad bridge, of Mehmed-pasha Sokolović, and this magnificent one, of Mostar. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, there is a special relation towards the bridges; constructors devote particular attention to their harmony because bridges connect river banks, people and nations.
And this country is a sort of a bridge, or at least, it wished to be so in her centuries-old existence; the bridge of understanding amongst the worlds, amongst various possibilities, the bridge between the East and the West.
On a tentative list for UNESCO patronage are our tombstones – stećak, unique medieval stone graves dedicated to death, but with its ornamentation glorify life.
A list of our candidates consists of, equally precious, Sarajevo as the unique symbol of universal multi-cultural society, natural and architectural ensemble of Jajce, historically-urban areas of Počitelj and Blagaj, natural and historical areas of Blidinje and Stolac, and the natural monument, the cave Vjetrenica with the architectural unity with the village of Zavala.
Let our joint candidacy for stećak as a cultural heritage be a good motive and example for better understanding and synergy of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Serbia and Montenegro, and a good spirit of those stones joins us in our endeavour to accomplish the goal and enlist into the world’s cultural heritage under the protection of UNESCO, 22 Bosnian-Herzegovinian necropolis, three from each Serbia and Montenegro, and two from Croatia. It will be an example of cooperation between neighbours linked more by their joint past than divided by it.
This is an opportunity to thank UNESCO on behalf of Bosnia and Herzegovina for numerous projects which it has supported in post war Bosnia and Herzegovina, in reconstruction of schools, religious and cultural buildings and giving expert assistance in various fields, but also in reconstruction of the Old Bridge here in Mostar.
Let us, whose destiny is to share this joint space of South East Europe, know very well that the good is not merely given, but that it needs to be fought for, make on this occasion also an honourable effort to be clearly heard and be better understood. With that wish and message, once more I greet you and wish you a warm welcome to Bosnia and Herzegovina, to this city of light, in the reconstructed building of the Town Hall, close to the reconstructed Old Bridge.
Let that spirit of optimism, tolerance and reconstruction be the silver lining of this and our every meeting ahead.
Thank you for your attention

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović addresses the NATO Summit in Chicago, 21 May 2012
content:
I would like to express our appreciation to the United States for hosting the Summit and warmly welcoming us to the beautiful city of Chicago. We have come here to reaffirm our commitment to NATO and further strengthen our valuable partnership with the Alliance.
Secretary General Rasmussen,
President Obama,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is a great honor and pleasure to take part in NATO’s 25th Summit.
I would like to express our appreciation to the United States for hosting the Summit and warmly welcoming us to the beautiful city of Chicago.
We have come here to reaffirm our commitment to NATO and further strengthen our valuable partnership with the Alliance.
As a country that has significantly benefited from international assistance, Bosnia and Herzegovina clearly understands the value of NATO’s efforts in Afghanistan.
For several years now, Bosnia and Herzegovina has been contributing to NATO’s activities in Afghanistan because we firmly believe we have a responsibility to play an active part in NATO’s missions.
The fourth rotation of our infantry company is currently deployed in ISAF under the Danish contingent.
Resulting from the progress made in our defense reform, we have decided to expand our participation in ISAF by deploying our military police officers with the United States National Guard of the State of Maryland.
As part of an Adriatic Charter regional initiative, we are also increasing the number of our military police instructors in the NATO Training Mission.
These military police officers and instructors will be providing niche capabilities that are currently in high demand in Afghanistan.
We are also contributing in other ways.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has donated significant quantities of weapons to the Afghan National Army, with the view that key to success of the transition are well-trained and well-equipped Afghan National Security Forces.
And we are considering contributing to the training of Afghan women-officers. We believe that by doing so – in the context of the United Nations Security Council Resolution 1325 – we would send a message to the people of Afghanistan about the values shared by the NATO Member States and the aspirants for NATO membership.
Having transformed from being a recipient of security assistance to being a contributor to global security, Bosnia and Herzegovina is aware that the sustained commitment of contributing nations is critical for securing a lasting stability in Afghanistan.
We are thus firmly committed to continue our engagement in Afghanistan until, and after, 2014 – to the extent allowed by our resources and capabilities.
Bosnia and Herzegovina support the transition in Afghanistan because this process will create preconditions for "local ownership", which is indispensable for securing sustainable peace in Afghanistan.
We welcome the recent signing of the U.S. – Afghanistan Strategic Partnership Agreement, as a critical step towards ensuring ownership by the Afghan authorities.
We also welcome the Danish 3C initiative as a good mechanism for long-term assistance to Afghanistan, and we are currently considering specific opportunities for our involvement.
We strongly support the process of reconciliation and reintegration in Afghanistan. Based on our own experience, we know this is a painstaking task that can be accomplished only by mutual respect and understanding.
We encourage all parties in Afghanistan to engage in this process and to make compromises to achieve what all citizens of Afghanistan desire – security, stability and prosperity for themselves and for their children.
Having understood the value of regional cooperation, we also urge Afghanistan’s neighbors to play a constructive role, and we welcome the results achieved in this respect through the Istanbul process.
In closing, I would like take this opportunity to thank you for the contributions that your governments and NATO have made to peace, security and stability in my country. We remain determined to protect that investment by ensuring that Bosnia and Herzegovina becomes a NATO member.
Thank you.
Chicago, 5/21/2012

title: Address of BiH Presidency Member from Republika Srpska Nebojša Radmanović at the UN General Assembly Thematic Debate: ‘Thematic Debate on World Economy and Finance in 2012', New York, 17 May 2012
content:
It is my pleasure to, on behalf of BiH Presidency, greet and address you at this distinguished meeting. In particular, I wish to greet Mister Ban Ki Moon, the UN Secretary General and thank him for the invitation to participate in today's Thematic Debate which surely deserves attendance and attention of leaders; before all, the leaders of states and the global business leaders.
Mister President,
Mister Secretary General,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my pleasure to, on behalf of BiH Presidency, greet and address you at this distinguished meeting. In particular, I wish to greet Mister Ban Ki Moon, the UN Secretary General and thank him for the invitation to participate in today's Thematic Debate which surely deserves attendance and attention of leaders; before all, the leaders of states and the global business leaders.
The world economy and its condition impose on us to, by the means of debates of this kind, deliver various views of the present state of economy and possible ways of overcoming and resolving the key economic problems.
Before all, I wish to say a few words on the state of the BiH economy, especially in the light of the political-economic relations in the region of the Balkans and the EU.
The economy of BiH is open and fully liberal, with foreign trade and economic links directed towards the states of the region and the EU. The geographic position, historical links, similarity of the market and the connections of the companies affect the dominant connections of BiH economy with the economies of the states of the region. The entire region of South-East Europe, regardless whether the states are the EU members or the ones waiting for the membership, is constituted of developing states. All of the countries of the region, thus BiH as one of them, had made the economic growth rate of 5% until 2008 and had made progress in the key economic indicators, such as the growth in industrial production, reduction in unemployment rate, the growth of GDP, and so on.
However, due to the world economic crisis, since 2008, the economy o BiH is in recession, regardless the last year's growth of 0.8%. The key problem is the growing unemployment, which exceeds 25%, a large foreign trade exchange deficit, the small amount of economic activity and successful companies, low level of direct foreign investment, and lastly the growth of the debt and deficits in the public sector. The weak competitiveness remains to be the Achilles heel of the BiH economy and the states of the region.
Unfortunately, BiH belongs to a group of the poorest countries of the region of the Western Balkans and Europe. That is a serious challenge to the efforts in overcoming the economic crisis. The long-lasting and huge unemployment and poverty are silent destroyers of our economies and social stability. In the region of the post-conflict transition, that is a constant threat to the political stability of the country and the entire region.
I feel free to say that the same or at least similar situation characterises the economies of the countries in the region. The only advantage, if I can say so, which BiH possesses at this moment, as well as the other countries of the region, is a very low level of the public and private sector debt compared to the participation of the debt in GDP.
BiH, like other countries of the region, has not been nor should it in future face the danger of living the scenario of indebtness or inability to pay off its debt, the situation which is present in some European countries which are members of the EU.
It is certain that in the projections of the leading world financial institutions, there are not any predictions foreseeing rapid fall or crash of the economies in the region of the SE Europe. Although the situation in the economies of these countries is rather difficult with a very weak real sector of economy, a possibility for economical stabilisation exists with a relatively small support.
Here, beforall, I refer to the support of the EU and its member states; both economical and political support in the same amount. From the economic side, we need a larger level of direct investments and larger availability of loan and grant assets through different funds in the area of the real sector in which BiH and the countries of the region possess comparative advantage. This refers to investing into energetic and hydro energetic potentials, as well as, investing into steel, wood and food industry.
Besides direct support to the sector of economy, it is necessary to equally enhance the political presence and engagement of the EU in BiH and the countries of the region in order to end the process of integration into the EU. The decreased level of the EU interest to expand to the countries in the region that together with BiH are not members of the EU, besides endangering the economic flows, can also have a great influence to the development of certain euro-skepticism which could in its later phase lead to political instability.
Considering the principle of economic solidarity on which the EU is based, I hope that the developed countries of the EU, and primarily the biggest and strongest ones, will find a model to help and invest in BiH and the states of the region, in order to secure economic and political stability of an important region in Europe, as is ours.
Apart from this, the multipolarity of the economic world represents additional advantage which we wish to use through the invitation for the economic presence of the BRIKS states and the USA.
A higher level of economic cooperation and connection, along with the investments in new modern technologies in the real sector of economy represent catalysts for economic recovery and stabilisation. We must reconstruct our economy in a way that we again build our own production capacities in the real economy, return to the production of goods and depend less on the financial sector. This is the only way through which we shall we be able to cope with the increasing demands of the social state.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I believe that the development of the Internet, the emergence of new forms of energy, linkage and widening of the market and changes in global management will bring a new, more just and balanced model of the world economy in relation to the one that preceded and greatly contributed to the global economic crisis. The highlighted global awareness of dissenters in all parts of the world speaks for itself: Nobody can save oneself alone. Either we all save ourselves, or nobody gets saved!
I hope that my participation in this debate succeeded in affecting the importance of the topic of the world economy, and thus enhance our interests in mutual co-operation, dialogue and agreement on the concrete strategic steps and activities in this field.
Thank you.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović to the participants of Sarajevo Business Forum
content:
Sarajevo Business Forum is here to offer a chance for all of us to profit in one way or another, meaning either by signing a good business deals, gaining brand recognition, creating jobs, or ensuring economic growth.
Excellencies,
Honorable Guests,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Es-sellam allejkum and good morning!
It is a distinct pleasure to welcome you to Bosnia and Herzegovina and to this year's Sarajevo Business Forum. The Third one!!
We are so happy to see you all, and proud to host such a unique event that connects investors, businesses, and governments from all over of the world.
Sarajevo Business Forum is here to offer a chance for all of us to profit in one way or another, meaning either by signing a good business deals, gaining brand recognition, creating jobs, or ensuring economic growth.
The Forum also aims to strengthen culture of the dialog among all stakeholders who benefit from organized and well functioning states, regional cooperation, and wider integration processes. All of us, at different posts, should work together in order to gain more for our citizens, internal and external customers or shareholders.
Bosna Bank International management and the employees again did a great job in organizing such a demanding event, and I thank them for that with all my heart. They are the ones without whom this gathering would be impossible to succeed.
Here with us is a man without whom Sarajevo Business Forum would never happen and become an annual event of the high regional importance. It is the Sarajevo Business Forum founder, my friend, and our former President, Dr. Haris Silajdžić.
Thank you President Silajdžić for honoring us again with your presence!
My dear friends and dear guests,
Bosnia and Herzegovina have great potentials to develop different industries very easily. It could serve as a perfect meeting point for the business people coming from the east and west. We understand them well since we share values and believes of both. Here, everybody is welcomed and appreciated.
Bosnia is also a center part of the wider Southeast European region, and friends from neighboring countries again came to this event to show how we can cooperate better.
Even though our recent past separated us, the business people and investors always perform as an engine of integrations! This region has many investment opportunities to offer. I firmly believe recognizing it will not pose a problem for you.
In any case, disintegration processes ended in the 1990s and now our region reconnects its ties and streams for new integrations. Bosnia, and I assume the same for the whole region, will further integrate into EU and NATO. Geographically, historically, politically, and culturally speaking - these Associations are the ones we should belong to. We will make it happen in the next few years.
That is why it is a right time for investors to come here. Efforts made now could pay off much more. It is better rewarding if you act as a groundbreakers and leaders, rather than as a followers and “safe players”.
We so far completed wide ranging political and socio-economic reforms. By doing that we improved business environment in our country in a great manner. Just since last year we succeed in passing the Laws which will enable us to better manage economic planning and come closer to filing credible Application for EU membership. These are Census and State Aid Laws.
We had some challenges in forming the Government in past year, but now we succeed it forming the ruling coalition. And, we did it on our own, without interference of international community. It is for the first time our complete “domestic product”, and I firmly believe it will prove to be the best one so far.
But even with last year difficulties our economy grew 1,6 percent. We expect our economy to grow at the same rate this year. These figures prove that Bosnia and Herzegovina economy is resilient and competitive.
This year, Turkish government provided us with the significant loan under specially good conditions. This loan is to help us increase agricultural production level in the regions where our returnees live.
I thank Turkish government, Turkish people and Ziraat Bank for this support very much. It is of the greatest importance for us since we do not use more than 50 percent of our agricultural land – high quality, unpolluted and fertile agricultural land.
I invite all potential investors from agriculture industry to take a deeper look into our unexplored potentials with this respect.
Let me also remind all of you that Bosnia is very rich with water, and that this huge potential is only modestly in use. This fact represents an opportunity to make investments related to bottled water or electric energy production.
Besides that Bosnia is very rich with coal, forests, strong winds, and numerous kinds of minerals. Also, and for sure, we here have oil! Shell Company representatives are exploring Bosnian oil fields as we speak. And soon we expect them to announce what our researches have already shown –Bosnia has significant quantities of oil!
We now need to focus on building infrastructure. In the last few years we made a breakthrough.
Insallah, by 2014 we will complete building of around 140 km of Corridor VC. That highway, when completed, will represent main physical and psychological reconnecting artifact of our country.
Bosnia also offers many other distinct benefits, such as: long industrial traditions, well educated and disciplined workforce, excellent geographic location, stabile currency pegged to the Euro, the rights of foreign investors equal to domestic ones, companies with long and rich tradition of engagement in international trade and business, etc.
We also signed the Central European Free Trade Agreement with the neighbouring countries, and have preferential export regimes with European Union, Canada, Japan, Russia, Turkey, and the United States.
So, if you really explore, and if you are courages and creative enough - our country is a land of many opportunities for you.
The City where this Forum takes places is a city of many opportunities for you as well. Sarajevo is one of the main historical, cultural, media, education, and industrial hubs of the region, and it welcomes you with open hands.
With that in mind, I wish you all success, and I invite you to enjoy your time here.
Thank you very much!

title: BiH Presidency Member from Republika Srpska Nebojša Radmanović's address at the central ceremony marking the Day of the Army of Republika Srpska and the Day of the 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srp
content:
We have reason today to feel proud, to feel solemn and triumphant. This year we are marking the Day of the Army of Republika Srpska and the Day of the 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srpska) in the year in which we are celebrating with pride the 20th Anniversary of Republika Srpska, as an important part of the political heritage of the combat of the Serb people in their long history for political and national identity.
Dear families of fallen and missing combatants of Republika Srpska,
Presidents,
Representatives,
Ministers,
Sir Generals, officers, NCOs, privates and civil persons serving in the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
We are here today to mark the Day of the Army of Republika Srpska and the Day of the 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srpska), whose heritage is the path of combat, the tradition of the Army of Republika Srpska and the liberation tradition of the Serb people.
We have reason today to feel proud, to feel solemn and triumphant. This year we are marking the Day of the Army of Republika Srpska and the Day of the 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srpska) in the year in which we are celebrating with pride the 20th Anniversary of Republika Srpska, as an important part of the political heritage of the combat of the Serb people in their long history for political and national identity.
This most important national date is accompanied by two other important anniversaries; the 20th Anniversary of the Army of Republika Srpska and the 7th Anniversary of the 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srpska).
Sir privates, NCOs, officers, Generals and civil persons of the 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srpska), I congratulate you on the Day of the Army of Republika Srpska and the Day of the 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srpska) with our traditional military salute: Pomoz’ Bog junaci! (God Bless Heroes. op.tr.)
The Army of Republika Srpska was formed on 12 May 1992, with the aim of defending and protecting the Serb people in this region where we have lived for centuries, under the circumstances of the open and organized political and armed destruction of Yugoslavia, as a united country in which the Serb people lived together with other peoples. We were the people’s Army and the organized military formation of the Serb people in the last war in BiH.
That is why today, here together with us, beside the members of the 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srpska), there are the ex combatants of the Army of Republika Srpska, war veterans, members of the families of fallen combatants, members of the associations and organizations cherishing the tradition of the liberating past of the Serb people and the Serb Army.
All our thoughts and memories today are with those who bravely and boldly gave their lives for the freedom and survival of the Serb people. We pay honour to all of them, and due piety and lasting remembrance. This generation of those living in peace owes much to the generation of those who gave their lives in war. It is our moral and national obligation to turn the ideals of the combatants of the Army of Republika Srpska into a lasting order of the democratic politics of the Serb people in Republika Srpska.
The 3rd Infantry Regiment Republika Srpska follows with pride the tradition of the glorious liberating battles of the Serb people overall in the past. Let us remember the last two centuries since the First and Second Rising, the Balkan Wars, WWI and WWII, to the last war in which the Army of Republika Srpska was formed. There is an unbreakable link between Republika Srpska and the Army of Republika Srpska in which the historical and national destiny of the Serb people is reflected. The centuries long exposure to foreign conquest, enslavement and suffering of many kinds, oppression and genocide, has developed into an instinctive feeling of danger and readiness to fight for the protection of our own national being in the face of threats to existence and survival. The Army of Republika Srpska, in the past war, defended the territory of Republika Srpska and saved the Serb people. The many lives of the fallen combatants and civilians, the heroic self-sacrifice and knightly struggles of individuals, the collective suffering of the entire Serb people were made in the defence of Republika Srpska during the past war. The high price paid for freedom and the defence of the national identity in war, is one of the reasons for the defence of Republika Srpska today in peacetime.
That is the reason why all the Serbs in Republika Srpska, and almost all outside it, stand in defence of Republika Srpska and are against political demands for its abolishment, regardless of the political party they belong to or where they live.
Along with our ceremony today, two days ago we marked the 9th May, the Day of the Victory over Fascism, which, due to its importance, also became the Day of Europe. That is the day on which the entire world of progress, democracy and anti-fascism, jointly marks the 67th Anniversary of the ending of WWII and the victory over Fascism and Nazism. The Serb people made an enormous contribution to the anti-fascist fight and the victory of the Allied Coalition in WWII, upon which the democratic united Europe has been built. That is why it is hard for us today when others, who then had taken the side which lost, are taking all the credit for the fight and participation in the People-Liberating Partisan Movement in the region of the ex-Yugoslavia, the Movement which consisted mainly of Serbs, together with other Yugoslav peoples. Many in BiH today, who wholeheartedly speak about anti-fascism, remain silent about the Serb contribution to the victory of Yugoslav peoples over Fascism and Nazism, and say nothing about the mass collaboration with the occupiers and their own national Corps. The historical facts are irrefutable, and everything else is an attempt at the revision of the events from this period of our past and falsification of truth for the purpose of short term politics. To those we are sending a message today from this very place that we shall not allow a monopolization and misuse of the anti-fascist fight from WWII for propaganda and political purposes in certain media and quasi academic organizations and associations. It is those political manipulators who attribute the anti-fascism to themselves and challenge it in regard to everybody else. It is those who do not let the families of the fallen Serbs lay wreaths and flowers in the Dobrovoljacka street and other places of Serb suffering in the Federation BiH, and use that right in Republika Srpska without any disturbance.
Ladies and gentlemen!
The 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srpska), as one of the three constituent parts of the joint Armed Forces of BiH, is the result of joint efforts in the reform of the defence system in Republika Srpska and BiH, with the aim of creating a modern armed forces, applicable to the peacetime needs of the country and potential threats in the future. The Republika Srpska and BiH in this process opted for the building of peace and stability as the most important factor of the wider security environment which brought Europe fifty years of development in peace and economic and social welfare. With that vision in mind, the 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srpska) has been contributing to our determination for the implementation of the necessary reforms and modernization of the defence and security sector, in the spirit of mitigating direct military threats to peace and security in the region and in this part of Europe. The institutions of Republika Srpska gave in the past a significant and constructive contribution to the necessary changes to the defence and security sector in BiH. Republika Srpska will, as it has done to date, request balanced access, equal treatment, gradualism in application of agreed arrangements, respect for the interests of all participants and strict respect for the Constitution of BiH.
The 3rd Infantry Regiment (Republika Srpska) has all the conditions to be a respectable defence component of the joint Armed Forces and a guarantee for the survival of the Serb and other peoples in BiH, but also of peace and stability in the region and in a united Europe.
If all of us in BiH in this process are most sincere and politically responsible, there is no reason why this should not remain so in future.
Thank you.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović at the opening of the 9th Meeting of the European Council of Religious Leaders in Sarajevo, 8 May 2012
content:
The representatives of historically founded religions on the European soil certainly can help much in overcoming the number of challenges that our continent is facing when the question is of the fight for the environment in which we all will feel well and safe. Every message that comes from such eminent people of faith is of great importance. The messages of peace and tolerance are, certainly, the most important ones.
Dear Eminencies and Excellencies,
Salaam, Shalom and God Bless!
It is my honour and pleasure to be here with you, to speak on the subject of the tremendous importance. A unique Blue planet, resembling nothing in the universe we can see, is an obvious sign of the Divine creation. Infinitely precise connection of everything on it and everything related to it, clearly speaks that the Earth is God’s gift, that is was created with an aim to be a pleasant home, a cradle for humanity. For us, and for those coming after us. We come out its essence, use it while we live and return to it.
It was created by the One who is perfect, and given to us, obviously the imperfect ones, to manage. The growing power of a man brings progress and well-being, yet the selfish side of that power can infringes the substance we depend on – the material and spiritual substance. The world is changing and it is growing at the speed and in direction which sometimes is of concern. There are more and more wars, violence, and theft. There is less and less good, compassion, mutual concern and healthy family life.
It is only with decisive, global, coordinated action of religious and political leaders that this negative trend can be stopped.
The representatives of historically founded religions on the European soil certainly can help much in overcoming the number of challenges that our continent is facing when the question is of the fight for the environment in which we all will feel well and safe. Every message that comes from such eminent people of faith is of great importance. The messages of peace and tolerance are, certainly, the most important ones.
The Europe of today is one of the most organised and stable parts of the world, the place where there is a high level of respect for human rights and citizens’ freedom. Yet, peace is a deceiving matter, and evil, disorder and violence are always there, in vicinity. They are waiting for a good moment to gain power and show face. Our continent has, throughout its history, older and the recent history, witnessed the most brutal violence and hatred. The dark ideologies of fascism and Stalinism were born on the European soil. The vortex of ideologically founded, technologically well organised evil have, in the name of accomplishment of some utopian heaven, created the hell on Earth, put in misery entire peoples and mocked the very core of the human dignity.
Millions of people were killed and tortured only because they belonged to some ethnic, religious or political group in the recent history. The genocide in Bosnia happened before the eyes of the world, only 16 years ago, while even today some criminals like Breivik are committing mass murders, killing innocent children in the name of their own “good” of some kind. The terrorists who falsely represent themselves as the “defenders of Islam” are killing citizens and children in Toulouse, and a few years ago in London and Madrid. The seed of evil is omnipresent.
We have to raise voice against every kind of violence, and especially that which has no end, and it has immersed in complete evil and nonsense. I speak here about that of the ethnic and religious basis. About evil which calls on good, which compromises it.
We Muslims believe that God, as He says in one of the verses of the Holy Qur’an: “has created various peoples on earth so that they would get to know each other”. That diversity is wealth. We know that we all will continue to live on this world together, next to each other or with one another, thus it is completely wrong to seek for supremacy of ones over others. Throughout the whole history, various civilisations were reaching their peaks and their downfalls, their golden and their dark days. This will be so in the future.
The European Council of Religious Leaders represents a very influential, eminent, ethically and intellectually superior community. The Council for this reason has an opportunity, but an obligation too, to do all so that we understand each other better in Europe, to learn about each other, to be of value to each other, and not to jeopardise each other. We will all, God willing, stay here and it is better that we cooperate. To get to know each other.
Dear friends and dear guests, allow me to, at the end of this address, wish you successful work and conference.
I wish you a pleasant stay in our beautiful country and our beautiful city of Sarajevo, which in full right is called the Jerusalem of Europe.
Wishing you all the best!

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Bakir Izetbegović attended the marking of the 20th anniversary of the creation of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the 7th anniversary of the creation of
content:
Twenty years ago, the Presidency of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina brought a Decree on integration of Territorial Defence, Patriotic League and other patriotic military units into the unified military formation which was soon to carry the honourable name – Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina
Respected fighters of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Respected members of the Armed Forces of BiH – soldiers, officers, generals,
Respected families of the shadeeds and killed soldiers,
Dear citizens!
Assalamu alaikum and good morning!
Twenty years ago, the Presidency of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina brought a Decree on integration of Territorial Defence, Patriotic League and other patriotic military units into the unified military formation which was soon to carry the honourable name – Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The Army was formed in the times of the hardest historical challenges which our homeland faced in its thousand-year-old existence. It was formed in the times when the aggressor forces from the East brutally attacked Bosnia and Herzegovina and then later also from the West, in order to achieve hegemonic, great-stately aims.
The creation, strengthening and defensive-resistant military path of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina is a story of the conjunction of vitality and wisdom. It is the story of the vitality of our people and the wisdom of the then state and military leadership. The Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina defended the country, defended the freedom and honour of the Bosnians and Herzegovinians. It defended what many call the “idea of Bosnia”; the belief that people of different religions, cultures and identities can live together. That very idea is in the foundations of the unification of Europe, the creation of the European Union.
Under unbelievably complex conditions, almost complete logistical blockade and halted economy, a respectable military force was created, the force which prevailed against superior aggressor armies, prevailed against international conspiracies and embargo, prevailed against those in its ranks who wanted revenge.
The first President of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the first Supreme Commander of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, late Alija Izetbegović, when he talked about the miraculous strengthening and resistance of our people and our Army, said “… once when analyses are made, when the miracle of the Bosnian resistance is deciphered from a historical distance, it will be discovered, for I am sure – that the secret laid somewhere within the souls or character of the people…”
Therefore, let us remember our heroes and that difficult, but glorious time. Let us not allow their role and significance in the history of our country and our people be forgotten! The results of their fight and their victim are the founding stone for the creation of a better future for the generations to come. We continue that fight today – the fight for the whole Bosnia and Herzegovina, the country of free and equal people regardless of their names and regardless of the way they worship God.
Resistances, conspiracies and disintegration attempts will continue to exist. But strong integration processes, the processes of reconciliation and normalisation will unquestionably continue to gain strength and they will prevail. A well set political aims are gaining constant and stronger support of the international community. Bosnia and Herzegovina has an excellent opportunity to speed its path towards the Euro-Atlantic integrations.
In the last weeks, I was twice in Brussels. In March, I conducted meetings with the leadership of the European Union, and a few days ago I had a meeting with the Secretary General and later with the overall Council of the NATO member states.
The readiness for assistance to Bosnia and Herzegovina on its accelerated path towards the European integrations was confirmed. Within a couple of months, we can create conditions for the submission of a credible application for membership to the European Union, as well as the taking over of the Annual Plan within the Action Plan for membership to NATO.
The doors of the European Union and NATO are wide open to us. The security of the NATO Alliance, the security for all in Bosnia and Herzegovina, political and economic stability which the EU membership offers – are the best possible inheritance we can leave to our children and descendants. This is the opportunity which this generation of Bosnian-Herzegovinian leaders does not have the right to miss.
Occasional crises that occur must not dishearten. It is imperative that we keep searching for solutions and come out of every crisis stronger and a step closer to the accomplishment of the set strategic goals.
A great majority of citizens in Bosnia and Herzegovina are tired of uncertainty and constant contentions, and want a better life and certain future for themselves and their descendants.
The politicians have to finally rightly interpret the interests of their electorate and direct the energy towards agreement which will enable the Bosnian-Herzegovinian society to strongly move on the path of stability, prosperity and security.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Today, while we stand in front of the Second Rangers Infantry Regiment of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the regiment which proudly nourishes the inheritance of the Army of Bosnia and Herzegovina, let us send a message to ourselves and others that the patriots of Bosnia and Herzegovina will never again will allow for weakness, that we will always be ready to defend our homeland.
But also, let us send a message that we are ready for agreement and cooperation. Most ready. We are ready to, while not forgetting the past, turn towards the future, towards what we can and should become, and that is the society in which every person in every part of Bosnia and Herzegovina, will peacefully live a life worthy of a man.
That is our debt to those who laid their lives in defence of one and only homeland of ours, Bosnia and Herzegovina!
To all the patriots of Bosnia and Herzegovina I congratulate this great day – the Day of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Thank you. Cheers!

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić's address on the occasion of Independence Day of BiH
content:
Exactly twenty years ago, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, more precisely its majority, answered affirmatively to the Referendum question which is always useful and worth of repeating: “Do you want Bosnia and Herzegovina to be an independent state of all its citizens and equal nations?”
Dear citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina!
Your Excellencies!
Ladies and Gentlemen!
Exactly twenty years ago, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, more precisely its majority, answered affirmatively to the Referendum question which is always useful and worth of repeating: “Do you want Bosnia and Herzegovina to be an independent state of all its citizens and equal nations?”
In the historical context of the day, it was a brave and fair question to ask. Brave because the question of independence of BiH inevitably meant facing and getting into a conflict with the brutal and bloody politics and force which had already been trampling upon and burning the regions of ex-Yugoslavia, and which had already made it clear to us that they had been against Bosnia and Herzegovina and against and any kind of equality of its peoples; and it was a fair question because, along the independence, the equality of all its peoples and citizens was implied.
If we take a closer look and think about it, we will easily notice that, in that at first sight a simple question, there were three co-related questions; three, I would say, basic concepts of Bosnia and Herzegovina of the day, Bosnia and Herzegovina of today and Bosnia and Herzegovina of the future: the question of independence, the question of equality of peoples and the question of equality of citizens. Those three questions were, and are, inextricably co-related. And it was clear then, as it is today, that if only one is missing then the whole of Bosnia and Herzegovina has a problem.
Unfortunately, in the time of today, honestly speaking, something is missing.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is an independent state today. Regardless whether some liked it or not, whether they were celebrating this day as a holiday today or not, Bosnia and Herzegovina as an independent state exists and remains. Even the greatest opponents of Bosnia and Herzegovina today must admit this fact as reality.
However, what is it today with, so to speak, the rest of the Referendum question?
Where do we stand today when the matter is of the equality of the peoples, and of the equality of citizens in the present Bosnia and Herzegovina? The answer is, I am afraid, defeating. Nor all the peoples, nor all the citizens as individuals are equal today in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Unfortunately, in the present Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is always that someone, somewhere on the territory of our country, is unequal. From that fact, the biggest political problems in Bosnia and Herzegovina derive.
A complete answer to the Referendum question of 1992 has not been given. The independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina has been reached, but it has not been followed with the equality of peoples and citizens. Although I do have my opinion and position on why it is like that and who is responsible or to be blamed for this being so, I do not wish to open that question now. I do not wish to open it because I find it more essential and vital to discuss how to overcome this situation, how to answer the other two remaining, questions of the 1992 Referendum – how to reach a true, not fake, farcical, equality of peoples and citizens in the entire Bosnia and Herzegovina. Do we have the strength for it?
Do we posses the will and the strength to, at least for our children if not for ourselves, ensure the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina in which equal people will live without fear of the unsecure future?
In today's political generation of people, to which people of Bosnia and Herzegovina have given honour and right to decide, lies a great responsibility, yet at the same time an opportunity to fully answer the 1992 Referendum question and thus fulfil the expectations of the March of 1992, and even the expectations of those who had not been born then and are our children today.
We will have the first test soon, during this year. Let us not allow the questions of Srebrenica and Mostar escalate in this year, since those two questions by far transcend the importance of the towns themselves and bear repercussions for the entire country.
It is perhaps the question of these two towns where we can show our readiness to build our country better, the country of us all Bosnians and Herzegovinians, the state of equal peoples and citizens.
Let us prove ourselves to be the people who go beyond their personal interests. Let us show that we are responsible people and politicians who will consider not only our own interests, but wishes and aspirations of those who belong to our political, ethnic, and religious or any other group. Let us think about the needs, wishes and fears of others, and not only those of “our own“alone! Let us think of our country and our future.
Twenty years, which passed very quickly, is a long time in a human life. In historical sense, it is almost unnoticeable moment.
Regardless the way you observed it, from a human or historical angle, in any way, in twenty years time, which, I repeat will pass very quickly, some other people, who will be standing here where we stand today, will appreciate us after what we have done for this country and whether we have fulfilled what the vast majority of Bosnians and Herzegovinians asked us in 1992, whether we have provided and secured independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, the state of equal peoples and citizens.
The answer and power to do so is today in our hands! Let us do everything for Bosnians and Herzegovinians to get what they asked for in the 1992 Referendum!
Dear Bosnians and Herzegovinians, I wish you happy 1 March, the Independence Day of our Homeland, our Bosnia and Herzegovina!
Thank you for your attention!

title: Address by Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Bakir Izetbegović on the occasion of the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Today's date has a special place in the history of our country. On this date, two decades ago, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina determined the fate of their homeland. Sixty-four percent of these citizens voted for a sovereign and independent Bosnia and Herzegovina; a state of equal citizens and peoples – Bosniaks, Serbs, and Croats, as well as members of other peoples who live in it.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Dear Friends,
Today's date has a special place in the history of our country.
On this date, two decades ago, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina determined the fate of their homeland. Sixty-four percent of these citizens voted for a sovereign and independent Bosnia and Herzegovina; a state of equal citizens and peoples – Bosniaks, Serbs, and Croats, as well as members of other peoples who live in it.
Despite that, there are still attempts to misinterpret the events of twenty years ago. But the truth is this:
Only when all attempts to reach a peaceful and democratic solution of the Yugoslav drama had been rejected – and I remind you that the most persistent and most consistent advocate of such an outcome was a late first president of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Alija Izetbegoviæ – did the Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina issue a decision to hold a referendum on independence.
That decision came at the request of the Badinter Arbitration Commission, and only after that Commission concluded that the Socialist Federative Republic of Yugoslavia was in the process of dissolution, and after the boundaries of SFRY's republics were recognized as future state boundaries.
The referendum was carried out throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina in a lawful, peaceful and transparent manner, and with full international monitoring. It was a democratic and lawful act by which Bosnia and Herzegovina restored its independence and sovereignty in a dignified manner, after the centuries of foreign rule.
These days I am asked by many: Are we living in the country for which its citizens cast their votes in the referendum twenty years ago? What is its future and prospects?
In a more idealistic projection, the response to this question might be negative. But we must be realistic. Bosnia and Herzegovina has already passed the more difficult – painful and threatening – chapter of its history.
Ahead of us is the task of completing the democratic reconstruction of our country, and ensuring that future generations live in a prosperous and stable Bosnia and Herzegovina. In Bosnia and Herzegovina in which all citizens are equal regardless of their religious, ethnic or political affiliation. In Bosnia and Herzegovina in which rights and reason rule.
The European path is the only realistic platform from which we can achieve the goals for which we have fought over the past twenty years.
But the question that has been posed for years and that we must finally answer is: How to faster move forward on the European path?
First and foremost, we must turn to the future, not forgetting the lessons learned from the past. Our country has a realistic prospect of making great progress in a short time. But we will seize those opportunities only when we stop wasting precious time on quarrels about what has been, and finally devote ourselves to reaching agreements about what can and should be.
Our most important mission should be to build trust. That is a painstaking process that can be accomplished only by mutual respect and understanding. To succeed, we must stop indulging in cheap populism. We must decisively break out of the worn and frayed political patterns of the past. We must correctly interpret the interests of those we represent, and listen the views of our interlocutors, no matter how different those views may be.
We must never lose sight of the big picture. We must not allow ourselves to risk defeat of the whole enterprise by getting carried away by the desire for personal victories in relatively insignificant political battles; a defeat that brings this country to a halt, causing loss to all and profit to none.
To build a future, we must make compromises.
If we have to choose between our country's prosperity and our own political ambitions, then the choice is clear: There is no political price that is too high to pay to enable our country's progress.
We must rapidly adopt the European Union acquis communautaire and implement modern European standards in all spheres of our society.
That includes building a rational and functional administrative system at all levels of government, a system that will serve the needs of this country's citizens, instead of serving itself. And for that we need, more than anything, political will. We must act more responsibly towards the duties we perform, and communicate and coordinate with each other, at all levels, better and more honestly.
In the future, before we start talking about creating a single new institution at any level of government, we must first ensure that every institution that has already been created serves its purpose and does its job. There is no point in creating new institutions if the existing ones do not work properly.
We must lead a responsible economic policy that is strategically focused on the realization of the enormous potentials and resources that our country undoubtedly has. To that aim, we must rapidly build infrastructure. Investing in infrastructure is the best way to employ our construction industry, increase trade, attract investments, and accelerate economic development.
We can build common future in this country only through agreements that respect the interests and rights of all: the state, both entities, all three constituent peoples, and all other citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
That is why future reforms in this country should go neither in the direction of centralization nor in the direction of decentralization, but in the direction of integration.
We must run reform processes so that they benefit all the peoples and citizens of our country. Every step forward is possible only if it is in the common interest of all in this country.
We face many dilemmas, but one thing is certain:
History has taught us that Bosnia and Herzegovina inexorably marches forward only when all its peoples and citizens feel at home here.
The only common future that is achievable is one that is acceptable to all wellintentioned people in this country.
And that is the future in which all of us in Bosnia and Herzegovina feel comfortable in one common state that gives us all security and prosperity.
To all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, my heartfelt congratulations for the Independence Day.
Thank you!

title: The Address by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at the closing ceremony of the Regional Office of the Saudi High Commission in Sarajevo and the change of the name of the Amphitheatre of the Cul
content:
Tonight’s closing ceremony of the Regional Office of the Saudi High Commission and acknowledging a genuine friend of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Bosniaks, Prince Selman bin Abdul-Aziz, after whom the Amphitheatre of the Cultural Centre “King Fahd” in Sarajevo will be called from tonight, is an opportunity for us to once more express our gratitude for all the help which Saudi Arabia gave to our country and people in the hardest moments of our defence against the aggression and the fight for survival.
Dear Mister Ambassador, dear hosts, dear friends, As-Salam-O-Alaikum and Good Evening!
Tonight’s closing ceremony of the Regional Office of the Saudi High Commission and acknowledging a genuine friend of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Bosniaks, Prince Selman bin Abdul-Aziz, after whom the Amphitheatre of the Cultural Centre “King Fahd” in Sarajevo will be called from tonight, is an opportunity for us to once more express our gratitude for all the help which Saudi Arabia gave to our country and people in the hardest moments of our defence against the aggression and the fight for survival.
My people are well aware of the exceptional role of the Saudi High Commission, which was led by esteemed Prince Selman, during its humanitarian actions in Bosnia and Herzegovina for almost twenty years.
How much importance was given to helping us is demonstrated by the fact that Saudi Arabia is the only country in the world which established a special commission to help the Bosniaks and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
There is a large number of orphans, shaheed families, expelled Bosniaks, who can never nor ever will forget the brotherly help which was coming from Saudi Arabia.
The figures that the Saudi High Commission cared for more than 12,000 orphans, established refugee camps and directly financed the return of around 13,000 refugees, and with various forms of assistance helped more than 250,000 Bosnian-Herzegovinian families – speak for themselves. During the aggression on Bosnia and Herzegovina, large quantities of necessary medical equipment were donated, wages for doctors and medical staff were being secured, and our wounded were transported and cared for in Saudi Arabia.
Furthermore, during and after the war, the aid was being directed towards infrastructure reconstruction, railway networks, water and electro-energy infrastructure, building and reconstruction of schools, numerous mosques and Islamic universities...
As a mark of respect and gratitude for such devotion of our Saudi brothers, President of Bosnia and Herzegovina, my father Alija Izetbegoviæ, awarded Prince Selman bin Abdul-Aziz with the Golden Medal of Bosnia in 1997.
Tonight at this ceremony we are before all speaking about the humanitarian mission of the Saudi High Commission, but the political support and help of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia in those fateful years to my country was immeasurably significant.
The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia was one of the first in the world to recognise the sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina and it strongly supported our right to defence of the sovereignty, territorial integrity and international subjectivity. I remind you that the late King Fahd bin Abdul-Aziz, together with the highest officials of Saudi Arabia, always put the question of Bosnia and Herzegovina in focus in international relations. There was no occasion where, in his contacts with the most influential world leaders, the Saudi leader did not significantly influence the forming of opinions towards Bosnia and Herzegovina. The activities of Saudi Arabia through the institutions of the United Nations, Organisation of the Islamic Conference and other most eminent international organisations contributed to the affirmation of Bosnia and Herzegovina on the international scene.
Such support was also continued after the signing of the Dayton Agreement which brought peace to Bosnia and Herzegovina at the end of the year 1995.
Dear friends,
Tonight’s ceremony in a way marks the end of an era in the friendly relations of Saudi Arabia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Our country survived, the enemies of our people did not succeed in their intentions to destroy neither the country nor the Bosniak people. Bosnia and Herzegovina, thanks to Allah, is no longer a humanitarian case. Bosnia and the Bosniaks are offering partnership for the future. With our own hands, our intellect, abilities which we possess, through cooperation with proved friends, we have to move forward. Friends from Saudi Arabia have their irreplaceable place and role in such our future. Now we need to cooperate on the economic basis and to mutual benefit. Some Saudi investors are already here, in our country. Sulaiman al-Shiddi is building the most modern centre in our country. He reconstructed Hotel “Bristol”, one of the symbols of Sarajevo, and is also planning other projects. This year’s Sarajevo Business Forum was also attended by His Excellency Saudi Minister of Finance Ibrahim el-Assaf. The Saudi businessmen and the representatives of the Saudi Fund for Development were also here. The economic relations need to be strengthened. There are projects, especially in agriculture, tourism, energy, and engineering, which can be attractive to Saudi businesspeople. Together we need to continue to work on this plan. There are of course bureaucratic obstacles, but we will be removing these in the period ahead.
Tonight’s ceremony is particularly emotional for me. It reminded me of the hard times of the war and the fight for Bosnia and Herzegovina, of the days when friendships were formed and strengthened, as is the friendship with the people of Saudi Arabia and our country. And the waqf in which building we are tonight, witness our brotherly relations, and it will be left for the generations to come who will nurture and cherish these relations.
Long live the brotherhood of the Saudi and Bosnian people!
Thank you!

title: The address of BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at the official Opening Ceremony of the First Congress of the Islamic Religion Teachers of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
The idea to organise a Congress of the Islamic Religion Teachers is to be praised. That is the best way to improve your work on preserving then values which you are passing down to the new generations through the exchange of the experiences. In the turbulent world which this generation will inherit, a renaissance of the faith will be needed more than ever before.
Dear Reisu-l-ulema,
Dear Chairman of the Islamic Community Parliament,
Dear Teachers, brothers and sisters, Ladies and Gentlemen,
Assalam -o-Alaikum and good morning!
The idea to organise a Congress of the Islamic Religion Teachers is to be praised. That is the best way to improve your work on preserving then values which you are passing down to the new generations through the exchange of the experiences. In the turbulent world which this generation will inherit, a renaissance of the faith will be needed more than ever before.
The development of the events at the beginning of the XXI Century is getting at the new dynamics and acceleration which are beyond any reasonable predictions. Indeed, who could have predicted such changes in the Islamic World and Europe at the beginning of this year? An explosion of freedom like this in the East and an implosion of the kind of the economic power and organisation in, at first sight, boringly sable Europe?
I went to Brussels a couple of days ago, and I had an opportunity to talk with important people from the European Institutions and gain the first hand information.
I do not wish to exaggerate, but I must warn you; the situation in the EU is not good, the crisis has entered into its dramatic phase.
If the solutions are not found in the week to follow, the Eurozone is threatened by a quake of uncertain consequences.
Greece has, as you probably know, experienced a full economic and social collapse; millions of people are there in the streets of Great Britain; unemployment rate in Spain is reaching unimaginable percentages; a financial break threatens Italy; France has been preparing itself for a similar scenario... In all this, as if German European leadership seems to be losing its strength.
We will wait, naturally, to see what the Governments of the key European states are going to do, yet we need to observe the things now with the greatest responsibility possible and seriously observe and analyse from an angle of their possible reflections and consequences on our region and our country.
Last night, German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated with regrets that Serbia has not fulfilled all the conditions to gain the EU candidate status. The reason is Kosovo and the local conflicts with the International forces.
That will for certain weaken the democratic government of Boris Tadić and will serve as a fuel to the extreme forces in Serbia. Such a scenario is not good for the region which may be stopped on the path of stabilisation, reintegration and reconciliation.
