It is in the past year, on this plan precisely, that we have vested in much effort and reached quite solid initial results. Only the brave leaders, those who do not indulge the masses, can change the state of spirit in the region. With the Presidents Tadić and Josipović I have had many meetings in the past thirteen months, we have established a good communication, and agreed on the most important strategic determinations on the path of our countries towards the EU and NATO.
A good basis has been created for us to continue solving open questions left from the times of the dissolution of Yugoslavia as the border question is, as well as the use of mutual resources, solving the property – legal disputes among the states.... The development of the situation threatens to halt the positive trends.
The question is how much the crisis in Europe is going to reflect on the processes started in the region. I wish to believe that we will have a chance to finalise the work we started to the benefit of all the states and peoples on this unstable Balkan of ours.
Yet, those wishing to move things towards the opposite direction are not without plans, neither public nor secret. In the region, there are political leaders with unhidden goals acting faced towards the past. They poison the public space, spread fear, manipulate with the stories on people being jeopardised, and on those bases they seek for new divisions and conflicts.
These disintegration forces are far weaker than the integration forces, but the crisis in the Euro zone, which I have already spoken about, the weakening of the cohesion forces in the European Union, could suit these destructive tendencies and their bearers.
In that sense, we must be ready for various challenges. The closest history and the experience, I hope, have taught us not to leave anything to chance.
Our state Bosnia and Herzegovina and our Bosniak people are exposed almost on daily basis to verbal denial, provocations, and even unhidden calls for the dissolution of the country through some alleged peaceful parting.
That is why we need to be united, politically responsible, and ready to answer to the challenges of that kind. Naturally, via democratic means, legal and institutional actions, we will not allow the constitutional order of the country to be brought into question, nor shall we allow physical existence of our people to be endangered.
As far as the development of the events is concerned, the revolution in the Islamic world, they had been predicted by someone. They were well described by Alija Izetbegoviæ in 1970, as if he had seen them from the close distance. And when dust started falling on his writings, when we had almost forgotten about them, the educated, libertarian generation of young Arabs started to break the chains of the dictatorship as they were threads. I quote: “The entire Islamic world is in the state of changes. No matter what this world will look like after these changes have passed through the opening upward round, one thing is certain: it shall no more be the world from the first half of this century. The epoch of passivity and stillness has passed forever.... Because one world with 700 million people (for, 40 years ago there were almost half less Muslims than today) and with huge natural resources and in a geographic position of the first order, which is a heir of the colossal cultural and political tradition, and a bearer of the living Islamic mission, that world cannot for long stay in the position of a hireling. There is no such a force which could prevent a new Muslim generation to bring such an abnormal condition to an end...”
We belong to the religion which will obviously mark the XXI Century. The religion which will have to stand against the greedy exhaustion of the substance of the human kind of the planet we live on. It will have to stand against the attacks on the system of values set by the Word of God and Order, to stop the collision of the moral system, destruction of family, disappearance of the humane inter-human relations. In the analyses of economic experts, the exclusive wish for the material goods is identified as a fundamental cause of the global crisis which is beginning to shake the whole world. Eminent sociologists call for forgotten mutual solidarity, and people from around go out to the streets, dramatically warning of the fact that there is less and less justice and perspective in societies they live in.
We belong to a small but proud Bosniak people. The people who are small in number, but great in courage and determinations and choices which we made on the recent historical crossroads. The people who chose freedom, and for unequal fight which that freedom required. And the people chose faith, an upward road, when it was easier to go downwards. The historical burden did not break the backbone of the Bosniak people, it made them stronger.
We belong to good people, and we have an obligation before it. All of us who which to strengthen and consolidate the Bosniaks, have an obligation to strengthen, before all, ourselves; to strengthen ourselves through mutual harmony, respect, cooperation, but also through constant education, perfecting and gaining new knowledge.
The spiritual, an by that physical existence and progress of Bosniaks in the times to come, is unreachable without a strong network of well educated religious teachers. It is therefore necessary for you to understand the job you do primarily as a mission, and then as a profession.
Dear religious teachers, I wish you success in the work of the Congress, God's help and success in the noble work and mission which you chose and dedicated yourselves to.
In the human and political capacity, I will always be there with you, opening doors for your actions protecting them from the pressures from those who do not, or do not wish to understand the irreplacable role of the faith and spirituality in the times to come.
Sallam and all the best!

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić’s Address at the Official Military Ceremony on the occasion of the Day of the Armed Forces of BiH
content:
It is my particular pleasure to, on behalf of BiH Presidency, the Supreme Command of the Armed Forces, and in my own name, address you today, on the 6th Anniversary of the Armed Forces of BiH. The December 1, the Day of the Armed Forces, is the day for us to be reminded of the contribution of many who vested their knowledge, hard work, efforts and expertise in the process of forming the Armed Forces of BiH.
Dear Excellencies, Generals,
Officers, NCOs,
Soldiers, dear guests!
It is my particular pleasure to, on behalf of BiH Presidency, the Supreme Command of the Armed Forces, and in my own name, address you today, on the 6th Anniversary of the Armed Forces of BiH.
The December 1, the Day of the Armed Forces, is the day for us to be reminded of the contribution of many who vested their knowledge, hard work, efforts and expertise in the process of forming the Armed Forces of BiH.
Today I will repeat what I have many times said, and that is that the Armed Forces of BiH are a better part of BiH society and that from day to day, they precisely show the way how successful reforms should be conducted in our country.
BiH Armed Forces are the best indicator of how BiH can and must function jointly and united, and in this respect you can serve as an example to other structures of our society and state.
Members of the Armed Forces of BiH, on a daily basis do all in their power to, as efficiently and professionally as possible conduct and execute the concrete tasks and the necessary reforms alike. It is for this reason that the state of BiH must be the one to provide and assure for them all assets necessary for the functioning and work, in accordance with NATO standards.
Every day, we witness how significant of a reform step was the forming of the united Armed Forces for a better future of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Being ahead in the reform of Defence, where we have gone the furthest, to the joy of us all, is a strong and positive message to all in Bosnia and Herzegovina. If that could happen in the field of Defence and Security, i.e. there where it was realistic to expect biggest issues after the war, then rightfully we may and must be optimists and hope for the improvement in other areas and fields of BiH society.
The process of forming and reforms in BiH Armed Forces is an example of a successful reform in our society, which gives the right to be sure that the reform will continue, yet we must not forget that it was a complicated process, which required much of the optimism, vision, decisiveness and patience.
It is familiar to all of us that, after a conditional NATO MAP was accepted, our obligation was determined to register the prospective military locations from the list of 69 facilities, which, unfortunately, has not been done to date. At this moment, there is a halt in this process due to the reasons of daily-political reasons, but I hope that there will be improvements in this area at soonest, since there is an extensive spectrum of reforms and obligations before us in reaching the Standards of NATO, which will lead us to NATO membership.
On this occasion I wish to again express hope that in the future, at one of the ceremonies of marking the Day of BiH Armed Forces to follow, I will address you as members of the Armed Forces member of NATO.
I also wish to point out that the Armed Forces of BiH, within their power and capabilities, give their contribution through the engagement in joint activities of Peace and Stability Operations in the areas of crisis around the World.
For everything we have done, today, on the Day of the Armed Forces, I give credit to all members of BiH Armed Forces who are active participants in the process of reforms. I am sure that BiH Ministry of Defence and BiH Armed Forces will in the future, on the principles of democratic openness and co-operation, give their contribution and do all necessary for BiH to become equal member of democratic family of European states.
Ladies and Gentlemen, once again, on behalf of BiH Presidency and in my own name, I wish luck and a lot of success to the Members of BiH Armed Forces and their families in the work and life ahead.
I thank you.

title: Bakir Izetbegović’s address at the opening of the 5th Congress of Nurses and Technicians in Bosnia and Herzegovina with International participation
content:
This Congress is an important event and it is truly an honour to me to be here with you tonight. The profession of nursing is more than a profession; it is one of the most humane occupations, which asks for dedication and devotion, courage and willingness to sacrifice.
Dear nurses, medical technicians, dear guests, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends!
This Congress is an important event and it is truly an honour to me to be here with you tonight.
The profession of nursing is more than a profession; it is one of the most humane occupations, which asks for dedication and devotion, courage and willingness to sacrifice.
It was said nicely here this evening – you are there with the people from their first moments after the birth to the days of sorrows and parting from this world.
You are there with the people in their hardest moments; when the help to them is of the most necessity, necessary to stand the pain and illness more easily.
Thus, it is precisely you who are like the closest members of the family to them; they turn to you with the greatest trust and closeness, expecting from you plenty of care, patience and strength.
Naturally, altruistic line is there at the heart of the profession of nursing, yet without good education there can be no good professionals.
Do we as a society dedicate enough attention to the field of education? To this question, you too will probably offer answers at this congress.
In any case, the health system in our country, compared to those in the neighbouring states and Europe, is one of the better segments of the society and the state.
Though they are sharing the majority of the problems we all are facing; though the economic crisis and recession has not avoided them – the personnel in the health care have been marking successes and have been keeping the pace with the developed countries. It has been proved that we have good physicians – both in war and peace. We do truly have good medical professionals.
At times, however, as if we are not aware of it, the people we educated leave, attracted by better incomes, offered in other countries.
Regardless the lowered capacities of the post-war society, we must not allow the stagnation in the health care. We must jointly keep trying to find ways for doctors, medical nurses and technicians to have the position in the society they evidently deserve.
The health system in our country, primarily in the Federation of BiH, has still been going through a dynamic period of all-encompassing reforms and we all together need to contribute to the quality of the changes which will make us part of the developed Europe in this field.
It is therefore that I believe that this Congress will also give a significant contribution to seeking for the answers and good solutions in the process of reforming of the health sector, in accordance with our strategic objectives and the highest standards of the developed world.
In the end, I wish to express my support to the plans for Bosnia and Herzegovina to soon get its own Chamber of Nurses which would become a full member for the European and World Association of Nurses and Nursing.
I bid you a successful Congress and a successful continuation of your noble mission.
Cheers!

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić on the occasion of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Every year Bosnia and Herzegovina, or to be honest and precise, a part of Bosnia and Herzegovina, marks the 25th November as the Day of Statehood of the Homeland. And that being one of the most important days, related to the antifascist fight which took place in our country but also over the entire ex-Yugoslavia.
Dear citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Your Excellencies, Eminencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Dear friends!
Every year Bosnia and Herzegovina, or to be honest and precise, a part of Bosnia and Herzegovina, marks the 25th November as the Day of Statehood of the Homeland. And that being one of the most important days, related to the antifascist fight which took place in our country but also over the entire ex-Yugoslavia.
That fight was bloody, sometimes desperate, ruthless...! All great battles led by the partisan units during the Second World War in the area of ex-Yugoslavia occurred on the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It can thus be freely said that the very core of the partisan resistance to the German Nazis and Italian Fascists, as well as other occupying forces, and also domestic Nazis and fascists during the Second World War, was in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Here, I am deliberately talking about the partisans and partisan units, and not about the communists and the Communist Party of then, because those two are not the same. Not all of the partisans and fighters against Nazis and fascists were communists, but the fact is that at the head of the organised fight against Nazism and fascism still were the Communist Party of Yugoslavia and Josip Broz Tito.
During those times, the times that can freely be called the times of struggle for bare life and survival, along with the armed fight, other key political things took place which directly or indirectly marked Bosnia and Herzegovina in the period after the Second World War, including the times of today.
The Session of ZAVNOBiH in the town of Mrkonjić-Grad in 1943 and the gathering of the antifascists in Bosnia and Herzegovina, who were not exclusively communists, returned, and I repeat, “returned“ and not gave historical and political right to Bosnia and Herzegovina to even today, after all, be called a state!
The State and Homeland of all of us together, and not more someone's than someone else's, and that each one of us has a right to the whole of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
For the sake of the truth, it should hereby be mentioned that then, as in the partisan movement, as also in the Communist Party of Yugoslavia, there were those who thought, wished and spoke for the idea that Bosnia and Herzegovina should disappear as a political, social and geographical fact. Furthermore, it should be sincerely said that, with his authority, the whole thing was overturned to BiH favour, by Josip Broz Tito.
What I have said is not a matter of my personal stance or opinion, but is about “bare“ facts and listing of those.
If anybody is not clear why the 25 November should be respected as an important date for BiH and ZAVNOBIH, let him just look back at the above mentioned facts which can simply be collected into four notions, or, illustratively said, four words only:
“Bosnia and Herzegovina, freedom, antifascism and equality!“
Order then in any way you wish, but to me, they carry the same weight and meaning, and it is absolutely of no importance to me in which order I state them.
Every attempt to jeopardise or give up on any of these notions, and thus to give up on everything that 25th November 1943 represents, causes great problems and troubles, including the war horrors in BiH at the end of the last Century, as in our homeland, as in the whole region.
Our generations have bitter, traumatic and tragic memory of the attempt to endanger or give up on the values of ZAVNOBiH and the 25th November.
In 1992, from the outside, outside of BiH, the values of ZAVNOBiH were endangered. Outside of Bosnia and Herzegovina, some attempted to simply erase the 25th November and ZAVNOBiH, and BiH, and our freedom, and antifascism and our equality, as if they had never existed. Naturally, we defended ourselves, just as anyone else sane would. We defended everything we believe in, we defended BiH, we defended freedom, we defended antifascism, and we defended the right to be equal.
Unfortunately, those from the outside had their allies in BiH, allies in those who gave up on the 25th November and on the ZAVNOBiH, and on BiH, and on freedom, and on antifascism, and on equality.
In those who gave up on all of this together or just some of the values of 25th November 19433 and ZAVNOBiH.
Those from the „outside“ are no longer there. They got what historically belongs to them, and what they deserved. If perhaps in the future time the similar ones emerge, I sincerely hope that they will not ever again, they will encounter the same fate as their predecessors and will end in similar way.
But those domestic ones are still there! Those who gave up or are ready to give up on Bosnia and Herzegovina, freedom, antifascism and equality, ultimately to give up on the 25th November and ZAVNOBiH. What I am going to say now, I will say because of our foreign friends, who are being called these days not to attend this reception nor the marking of 25th November, but also to make some things clearer, if they have not been already. Just observe the aim the relation to the 25th November and ZAVNOBiH in BiH carries. Observe the aim of relation towards BiH, towards freedom, towards antifascism, towards equality. Observe and much, if not all of it will become much clearer. It will be clear to you why Bosnia and Herzegovina does not have the Council of Ministers in accordance with the electoral results, and its Constitution; why Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot move forward towards NATO and the EU; why Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot implement the Decision regarding the fundamental human rights; why in Bosnia and Herzegovina there are still fascism and chauvinism; why are we still digging up the mass graves; why there is no bare, bitter truth on the war crimes committed; why are we bickering and arguing, etc..
Observe, in BiH, just the relation towards the 25th November, ZAVNOBiH and their values, and all will be crystal clear, if you wish it be so. And if you do not, no harm done! There are still those of us, and there will surely be more of us, who care about Bosnia and Herzegovina, freedom, antifascism, equality and the 25th November. And we will not lose hope in our wish and the attempt for this country, named Bosnia and Herzegovina to be and remain whole, free, antifascist, democratic state of equal peoples, equal on the whole of its territory. Think about what you believe in and what you think about all of this.
And then, only tell us how we are all the same!
Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Happy 25 November, the Statehood Day of our Homeland!
Thank you!

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at the reception on the occasion of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
First of all, I would like to thank you for your presence with which you express your respect and deference to one of the most important dates in the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina – 25th November which we are officially celebrating as Statehood Day. The essence of our country is the idea of antifascism, unity, equality, respect for others and those who are different during the centuries-long colourfulness of our differences.
Dear Excellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen, dear friends!
First of all, I would like to thank you for your presence with which you express your respect and deference to one of the most important dates in the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina – 25th November which we are officially celebrating as Statehood Day.
The essence of our country is the idea of antifascism, unity, equality, respect for others and those who are different during the centuries-long colourfulness of our differences.
It is precisely these noble general human visions that led the participants of the Session of ZAVNOBIH in Mrkonjić Grad, i.e. Varcar-Vakuf exactly 68 years ago.
In those difficult and fateful times of the Second World War, the fighters against the fascist evil strengthened the foundations of Bosnian statehood confirming the historical-legal continuity of our country with the proclamation of full equality of its constituent peoples.
Half a century later, Bosnia and Herzegovina would again be a target to fascists who wanted to divide it and erase it from the World map. Thank God, they did not succeed in their attempt. They committed tremendous evils, yet the people of this country, Bosnian-Herzegovinian anti-fascists, with the help from allies and friends, from the East and the West, succeeded in defending it.
The country is saved, preserved for the generations which, I am certain, will make it better and more prosperous.
Fifty-two years after the first Session of ZAVNOBIH (National Anti-Fascist Council of the People's Liberation of Bosnia and Herzegovina), in November of 1995, at the other end of the planet, in the American military base in Dayton, an agreement was reached to stop the war, and once again confirmed the international- legal subjectivity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In essence, along the confirmation of the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the seal was put in Dayton on all principles we have been cherishing since the times of ZAVNOBIH, with a strong affirmation of human rights and a resolute refusal of any kind of discrimination.
Unfortunately, the price of peace was the acceptance of imperfect internal organisation of the country and division into two entities. Still, with all its disadvantages, the Dayton Agreement created space for the reconstruction of the destroyed cities and villages, reintegration of the state, reconciliation of peoples and establishment of democratic system of the rule of Law within the Internationally recognised borders.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Almost seventeen years have passed since the renewal of the statehood of BiH. Next year we will mark two decades since the proclamation of independence.
Where is Bosnia and Herzegovina going; what are the perspectives of our country and society?
With certainty, we can say that the harder and more painful part of the road is behind us. There will be, of course, more crisis and halts on our path towards the community of free democratic states of the EU and NATO. Yet, this path is evident.
The process of normalization of the situation will be continued, trends leading to stability and full recovery of the society will prevail. Ordinary people will increasingly lead key processes, the integration trends will prevail. No further divisions are possible nor will they happen.
And at the end – the question when this date will be officially marked on the whole of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I do not have a sure answer. Yet, I am sure that love towards the homeland of Bosnia and Herzegovina will grow further on all its sides, in all its cities and villages…. We will have a national anthem which we will sing with joy, cheering our national sports teams. And we will have dates which we will celebrate together!
I am convinced that the Day of ZAVNOBIH will be one of these dates!
Once more, to the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I congratulate the Statehood Day!
I thank all of you who have honoured us with your presence at our gala reception.
Cheers!

title: Address by H E Željko Komšić, BiH Presidency Chairman at the 22nd Session of Igman Initiative, European Perspective, cooperation and stabilitz of the region, Belgrade, 14 October 2011
content:
It is my particular pleasure to speak here, today, at the 22nd Session of the Igman Initiative which is dedicated to the topic of the European Perspective, Cooperation and Stability of the region. It is important that the civil society follows the work of the institutions of our states in the process of stabilization and accession to the European Union. It is of particular importance to talk about all the challenges on this path at such a meeting of the people coming from different segments of the society a
Your Excellencies
President Tadić
President Josipović
President Vujanović
Dear Mr. Füle,
Dear representatives of the institutions and the civil society
Ladies and gentlemen,
It is my particular pleasure to speak here, today, at the 22nd Session of the Igman Initiative which is dedicated to the topic of the European Perspective, Cooperation and Stability of the region. It is important that the civil society follows the work of the institutions of our states in the process of stabilization and accession to the European Union. It is of particular importance to talk about all the challenges on this path at such a meeting of the people coming from different segments of the society and different states.
The states we come from are there at different stages of the process of association. The Republic of Croatia has successfully finalized association negotiations; Serbia is going to get a candidate status; Montenegro is getting a date for the beginning of the negotiations of accession to the EU, and I believe that Bosnia and Herzegovina will submit the EU candidate status application by the end of the year.
It is my opinion that there is no alternative to European integrations for Bosnia and Herzegovina, nor for the region. We cannot stay outside this process if we yearn for social and economic development and better standards for our citizens. However, the government structures of a state alone cannot be integrated into the EU but the society as a whole and due to this it is good that the non-governmental sector wishes to play an active and constructive role.
We must start investing into science, research and technology development. We must do more on a balanced economical development of the regions neglected. The sooner we start establishing the system in our society and adopting the standards of the EU, the sooner we will be closer to the EU membership. We must not understand the process of the EU integrations as something we are doing for the foreigners, but for ourselves and the future of our children.
Yet, there is a sequence of challenges ahead of us. For the region, as well as for BiH. Our mutual relations, at the level of the Heads of the States, are an example of how the regional co-operation should look like in every given field. It is so for we are sharing a common vision of the Western Balkans as a constituting part of the EU, since it is for our mutual co-operation on creating the stability in the region that opens the European perspective. Yet, it is in my opinion that the Governments of our states must intensify the activities on solving the issues, at both the bilateral and multilateral level. I wish to repeat here that I think that the principle of solidarity and mutual support is a fundamental principle on which the four countries should build common European future.
The challenges before BiH in the process of stabilization and association are at the level of political relations within BiH where there is no unified stance on the method, speed and the priorities in that process. It is about the question of jurisdiction in the reform implementation between the levels of authorities of the entities and BiH. Besides these, there is an issue of capacity of our administration and the constitutional framework which is of the extreme complicity. Finally, co-operation and implementation of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the process of establishing a functional state are of the extreme importance for all willing to become a part of the EU.
At the end I wish to thank the organizers of the Session who made it possible for us to talk about these, promote European values and openly talk about the problems we are having on that mutual path. I believe that this will bring to a better mutual understanding in the process of EU integrations.

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić held speech at the opening ceremony of the Third Forum of the Ministers of Health
content:
It is my particular pleasure to have the opportunity to address you at the Opening of the Third Forum of the Ministers of Health, which is held in BiH and for which I hope to bear certain results in the end. In the past ten years, the Network has contributed to the co-operation and mutual improvement through implementation of the regional projects in various fields, as for instance the field of Mental Health, Food Safety, neonatal Health and others.
Dear Ladies and Gentlemen, officials of the Governments of the network and Partners,
Dear Guests,
It is my particular pleasure to have the opportunity to address you at the Opening of the Third Forum of the Ministers of Health, which is held in BiH and for which I hope to bear certain results in the end. In the past ten years, the Network has contributed to the co-operation and mutual improvement through implementation of the regional projects in various fields, as for instance the field of Mental Health, Food Safety, neonatal Health and others.
I hope that this, Banja Luka Forum, will provide a chance for even better co-operation of the Health Network with other sectors and it will be pointed at the influence of the other sectors on the health, and vice versa. The joint actions are very important which will bring not only to the improvement of health of an individual, yet the society as a whole. It is a precondition for an economic and any other development of the society. The Health Network has proved the importance of the Health Sector in the process of trust regaining amongst the professionals and citizens, and pointed that there is a certain importance of the Health Sector in the process of reconciliation. It should be born in mind that this particular Network was one of the first which were created after the war in the region and the difficult social and economical situation in which the majority of population of the region was found. The foundation and the work of the Network alone have proved that there is no other way but the way of co-operation between states if willing to move forward. There is an example of Bulgaria and Romania, which today are the EU members, and which are also the Network members.
It is my pleasure that the Third Forum is held in Banja Luka, in Bosnia and Herzegovina, with a hope that this Forum will provide a clear guidance for the development of the Health Sector in co-operation with other Sectors, yet with other Networks and the Initiatives of the similar kind. When we look back at the first Forum, held in Dubrovnik in 2001, when the countries of the Region expressed their readiness to co-operate in the field of Health, and when it was decided to create the Network, over the Second Forum, held in Skopje, which brought to strengthening of the Network, now in Banja Luka we have an opportunity to see that the Network has justified its existence and that it, when the membering countries are concerned, came out the framework of the South East Europe. I hope that, along with Israel, who was accepted to be a member, other states will recognize the importance of such co-operation and approach to the Network.
Regarding the perspectives and goals of the states in the region states, the full membership is at the first place, and the Network is one of the tools that could accelerate this path. Due to all of these reasons, many countries have recognized the importance of this initiative and one of the positive aspects of the Network is its openness which makes the enlargement possible for all the states willing to exchange their experience and jointly work on the promotion of the importance of health.
There are many positive things in the countries of the region in the field of health, and they must be mentioned at this and similar sessions. We know that Croatia is the third country in Europe in the field of transplantations, right after Spain and Portugal. Our country of BiH has a developed system of rehabilitation in the Community for Physical and Mental Health – an example of the organisation of the services for mental health in a community is an example recognised by the WHO. We, as a state, offered assistance in this field to the new authorities in Libya, for we think that the Health Sector is one of the sectors which can help in a large capacity to all of us in the positive promotion of BiH and its experts.
Of course, there are certain parts where it is needed for additional efforts to be made in order to reach improvement. Here, before all, I think of insufficient legal adjustments, small scattered markets which are largely abused by the pharmaceutical industry and insufficient co-operation in building a system of fight against new challenges to the health, epidemics as the bird flu etc. I am certain that jointly you are going to find the solutions and answers for these disadvantages. In order not to take much more of your precious time, I once again whish you welcome and a pleasant stay in BiH and Banja Luka, as well as successful work. I thank you.

title: Address by BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović at the opening of 18th ZEPS Fair
content:
It is a great pleasure to be with you today. I always look forward to being in working Zenica, a town which is, thank God, speedily developing. I have many friends here, I know the way of life here but I also know how, under difficult conditions, new values are created and how it is fought for own prosperity and progress of the community.
Dear Hosts, Ladies and Gentlemen, dear Guests!
It is a great pleasure to be with you today. I always look forward to being in working Zenica, a town which is, thank God, speedily developing. I have many friends here, I know the way of life here but I also know how, under difficult conditions, new values are created and how it is fought for own prosperity and progress of the community.
Apart from the known internal problems, Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the majority of countries in the region are suffering from negative effects of global recessional trends, financial and economic crises which are affecting Europe.
But this gathering, 18th of its kind, ZEPS Fair, and the Eighth Specialised Fair of Metals ZEPS INTERMETAL, which gathered together an impressive number of national and international exhibitors are a proof that businesspeople are stronger than problems which they face.
This is why I believe that we, the politicians, whom you are rightly sometimes angry with, have an important obligation towards the business community to make way to courageous, decisive and creative managers, real leaders of progress. Only together, with a little will and a lot of cooperation, we can make Bosnia and Herzegovina a success story of 21st Century.
In my political vision, in my state contacts with presidents of friendly countries, economy is always one of the dominant topics. In that sense, regional cooperation is one of the priorities. We have to develop more intense economic relations with Slovenia, Croatia, Serbia and Montenegro.
The great and the strong have long ago joined up, why wouldn’t us, less developed ones, join forces and act together in global markets. Although we have inherited some political disagreements, we should be led by mutual interest in economy and we should be able to soon agree in this field.
When the future is concerned, the common European perspective is clear. When we will enter the European Union, is something we alone are deciding on. Some European funds are already made available to us and we have to use them in the reform processes.
We have to attract foreign investors, we have to help rather than hinder them with stringent bureaucracy. However, our diplomacy also must be more active and penetrating, particularly in the field of economy and opening of doors to our companies for businesses abroad.
Libya is one of the good examples which I wish to mention here. In the risky period of the local crisis, we managed to preserve the property of BiH firms and the contracted work of our companies. As soon as the conditions for it are reached, I intend to visit this friendly country with a large group of business people.
Dear friends,
Bosnia and Herzegovina has quality people and huge resources which will enable it to enter the company of the prosperous countries of the world. And, with your engagement, you are significantly contributing to the creation of conditions for this. Once more, I am honoured and I thank you for the invitation. I wish you success in your work and networking, as well as many new contracts.
I hereby promulgate the 18th ZEPS Fair and 8th INTERMETAL Fair open!
Zenica, 4 October 2011

title: Address by Željko Komšić, Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, at the General Debate of the 66th Session of the United Nations General Assembly
content:
Allow me to express my gratitude for all the cooperation and the support we received during Bosnia and Herzegovina’s membership in the UN Security Council, which will expire in few months. Speaking of our membership in the UN Security Council, let me once again reiterate the view that the presence and participation of "small states", such as Bosnia and Herzegovina, in the work and decisions of the United Nations Security Council is particularly important for maintaining balance within the Council.
Mr. President, Mr. Secretary General, Excellencies, Ladies and Gentleman,
It is a great honor to address the General Assembly today, in the capacity of the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Allow me, at the very outset, to congratulate you, Mr. President, as well as members of the Bureau of the 66th Session of the General Assembly on your election, and to express our full support to your future work. Furthermore, I would like to congratulate H.E. Joseph Deiss, on the results achieved during his presiding over the 65th Session of the UN General Assembly, in a period when this body, as well as the international community in general were facing an array of challenges related to current global issues.
I am especially honored to extend congratulations to the UN Secretary General, Mr. Ban Ki Moon, for his unanimous re-election as the UN Secretary General. Over the past five years, Mr. Moon has worked tirelessly to address the various issues facing the world organization. We wish the Secretary General to continue with these activities in his second term.
Mr. President,
Allow me to express my gratitude for all the cooperation and the support we received during Bosnia and Herzegovina’s membership in the UN Security Council, which will expire in few months. Speaking of our membership in the UN Security Council, let me once again reiterate the view that the presence and participation of "small states", such as Bosnia and Herzegovina, in the work and decisions of the United Nations Security Council is particularly important for maintaining balance within the Council. This way, along with the permanent members of the Security Council and the world powers, other countries also have a chance to express their views and participate in Security Council decisions making on important issues of international peace and security. It was our pleasure and honor to work together with all members of the UN Security Council, during our mandate for 2010 and 2011.
Bosnia and Herzegovina had the honor to chair the UN Security Council during the January 2011. Although chairing the Council is only one segment of the two-year experience in the UN Security Council, Bosnia and Herzegovina once again has proved that it can be an equal partner on the international diplomatic scene, and respond to variety of obligations arising from chairing the UN Security Council.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has played a constructive role in the work of the UN Security Council, through contributing to a better, more efficient and faster response of the Security Council to situations that could threaten international peace. Furthermore, Bosnia and Herzegovina has also aimed to share its own experiences in post-conflict peace-building, and actively contribute to a better and long-lasting understanding and reconciliation. Through its role in the Security Council Bosnia and Herzegovina showed that it can be an equal and competent partner in international relations.
The UN Security Council Thematic Debate on "Post-conflict peace-building: institution building", which initiated by Bosnia and Herzegovina, have reached a number of conclusions. I would like to some of those conclusions at this time:
-To enable the success of peace-building initiatives, a priority must be given to institution building; this will prevent a return to conflict and ensure the survival, renewed credibility and legitimacy of the states.
-However, the purpose of institution building is to progressively reduce dependence on the international community and promote sustainability. In any case, the ownership of the reform process is the main condition for the establishment of effective institutions and ensuring sustainable peace.
-Ultimately, success in post-conflict institution building depends primarily on establishing a partnership between the international community and post-conflict societies, a partnership that is based on a set of common goals.
Bearing in this mind we would like once again, to thank you all for the confidence you have shown us and the support you provided during the non-permanent membership of my country in the UN Security Council.
Bosnia and Herzegovina also continues to provide concrete contribution to the UN peace operations in Liberia, Sudan, Cyprus and DR Congo.
Mr. President,
In Bosnia and Herzegovina we are united in our determination to pursue the path of Bosnia and Herzegovina towards full membership in European Union, and this fact represents a solid basis for the achievement of this goal.
Bosnia and Herzegovina places special emphasis on regional and sub-regional cooperation and dialogue between the neighboring countries, which represent different cultures and traditions, present in the Balkans for centuries.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is committed to the future and cooperation with neighboring countries, based on the principles of mutual respect and respect for sovereignty and territorial integrity.
We are interested to share our experiences with others and to develop mutually beneficial relations in post-conflict peace building, based on mutual respect for differences which in our opinion, represent an advantage.
Mr. President,
I would like to take this opportunity to emphasize that the issues of neighborly and regional cooperation are closely related to the integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the EU and NATO, a strategic and high priority foreign policy objective for my country.
For us, this is the best and the only way to ensure stability, security, as well as the economic development and prosperity for all citizens of BiH.
The strategic goal of establishing formal relations and EU membership is based on the aspirations of Bosnia and Herzegovina to achieve the full functioning of our own institutions and further development of society, based on the principles of free market, rule of law and especially the protection of human rights.
Furthermore, my country wants to improve relations with the states of Asia, Africa, Latin America, Australia and Oceania, at the multilateral and bilateral level, in accordance with the common interests and real possibilities. Bosnia and Herzegovina was and still remains dedicated to principle of openness in cooperation with all the countries in the world.
Mr. President,
Many important world events occurred between the two General Assembly sessions.
Bosnia and Herzegovina follows the development of the situation in the friendly Arab countries that are affected by deep social and political changes with great attention, preoccupation and concern. Bosnia and Herzegovina supports democratic processes towards creation of free, democratic and prosperous societies.
However, such processes are often followed by tragic consequences. Therefore, we appeal once again to stop violence and create the peace in these societies.
We are deeply concerned by standstill in crisis resolution in the Middle East. Despite optimistic announcements and plans, expected peace process has not yet been revived.
The only way forward is the solution based on the principle of peaceful coexistence of two sovereign states: a viable and independent Palestine and a stable and secure Israel, with respect to the provisions of international law and instruments in the field of humanitarian law and human rights.
So far, the UN has supported and actively participated in creating a positive atmosphere in order to reach a just, comprehensive and lasting peace in the Middle East. Bosnia and Herzegovina believes that conditions for a lasting and just solution can be achieved with additional political will and responsibility of the negotiating parties.
We are witnesses that international community’s determination to deal with terrorism and at the same time to create conditions for peaceful development of Afghanistan offers some results. However, we must conclude that it will take much more effort to establish self sustainable peace and stability in Afghanistan. In April of 2010, as a sign of support to the international community activities, Bosnia and Herzegovina has issued a decision on sending an infantry unit to the ISAF mission in Afghanistan.
I would like to emphasize here that Bosnia and Herzegovina is still very concerned about terrorist attacks, which take innocent civilian victims in many countries around the world.
Bearing in mind that the modern world continues to face various forms of international terrorism, I express our support for full implementation of the UN Strategy for Combating Terrorism and the activities of the Committee in the Fight Against Terrorism. In this regard, let me repeat that Bosnia and Herzegovina is unconditionally dedicated to the fight against terrorism and particularly actively participates in cooperation with the countries of our region to raise the security level and preparedness for effective prevention of terrorist acts. Completing negotiations and adoption of the UN Comprehensive Terrorism Convention would be an important contribution in this field.
Mr. President,
In addition to the crisis of political issues, this year we are faced again with many other problems to which international community still lacks proper and effective responses.
Despite signs of recovery, unfortunately, I must say that the greatest economic and financial crisis in recent history has left visible consequences that are reflecting on global peace and security. It is more than obvious that countries individually cannot cope with this issue, no matter how efficient their governments may be. Global crisis seeks global solutions.
In the context of the United Nations activities, we must face the fact that the greatest economic crisis, since the foundation of the World Organization, has in some degree threatened and even has began to question the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals, one of the most comprehensive strategic tasks set by the World Organization since its establishment.
Therefore, individually and collectively it is necessary to do everything in order to prevent further erosion of this key strategic project.
We believe that it is necessary for international community to redouble its efforts, especially the UN, in order to assist primarily the least developed countries.
Mr. President,
The climate change problem caused by human activities leads to natural changes that can have catastrophic consequences for the entire mankind, if the agreement process on environmental protection is not intensified.
Bosnia and Herzegovina shares the concern of the most UN members that droughts, floods, sea level rise, lack of running water and food, deforestation and all other phenomena caused by global warming are a serious threat to the world security, which in the future could be a cause of conflict all over the world.
Therefore, extremely important climate change issue requires urgent action by the international community. Bosnia and Herzegovina has expressed interest to join the countries that support the Copenhagen Agreement, by which our country has joined a large number of UN member states which consider this agreement as a necessary step in relation to Kyoto, until the achievement of the final, legally binding agreement.
Bearing this in mind, it is my opinion that neither economic nor political interests should stand in the way of achieving a global consensus, as the beginning of the global/common struggle to preserve the natural balance of the planet. It is often forgotten that climate changes directly affect the development, poverty, hunger, and consequently the global peace and security. I am convinced that our common interest is to ensure that future generations inherit the best possible conditions on our common home, planet Earth.
Mr. President,
I hope that all of us who are here today agree that a comprehensive United Nations reform system is necessary, which must be carried out with extreme care and ensure the widest possible consensus of the member states.
Bosnia and Herzegovina sees the role of the United Nations and its agencies as a central for resolving key issues of international significance. Therefore, it supports the efforts and proposals for reforms that come from the UN Secretary General.
Through the United Nations reform, it is necessary to ensure efficient and coordinated functioning of all system agencies and bodies, bearing in mind to avoid duplication of activities in a more rational allocation of financial resources.
Regardless of the future configuration of the Security Council, we believe that the East European group of countries must have another non-permanent member, taking into account the fact that over the past two decades the number of countries in this group has more than doubled.
While presiding over the subsidiary body of the UN Security Council - an informal working group for the documentation and other procedural matters - Bosnia and Herzegovina has set the consideration of working methods and transparency of the Security Council, as one of the primary goals. BiH has also organized several informal meetings in cooperation with the partner countries and the UN General Assembly bodies, where the UN members expressed their opinions and visions and concrete proposals for improving the efficiency of the UN Security Council.
Mr. President,
I want particularly to emphasize that it is expected from the UN, particularly Security Council to be more active in preventive diplomacy. In order to make the work of this body much more efficient, we believe that the greater activity in this direction would provide a starting point to resolving many problems and crises in the world, before they flare up. Providing timely and effective action in conflict prevention, rather than reacting once the crisis has escalated, is certainly more efficient and less expensive instrument of action in preserving peace and security.
Mr. President,
During the six decades of its existence, the United Nations has passed through ordeals, but it always was and still is the best framework for seeking and giving adequate responses to a wide range of global issues we are facing.
Therefore, I urge you to work on the full implementation of all our agreements - in order to make the world a better place for our future generations.
Thank you.

title: BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović's address on the occasion of the Day of Shaheed
content:
Today, on the second day of Eid ul Fitr, we are marking the Day of Shaeeds. Entire Bosnia and Herzegovina is, as once our first President Alija Izetbegoviæ said, one huge cemetery of its best sons. They built their lives into the foundations of our freedom and democratic state in the times of glorious defence of our country from the aggression.
Dear Shaheed families’ members and members of the families of combatants
Dear friends and guests!
Today, on the second day of Eid ul Fitr, we are marking the Day of Shaeeds. Entire Bosnia and Herzegovina is, as once our first President Alija Izetbegoviæ said, one huge cemetery of its best sons.
They built their lives into the foundations of our freedom and democratic state in the times of glorious defence of our country from the aggression.
This is an opportunity to remember them, with sorrow, but with a particular pride and gratitude. With sorrow - because today they are not with their loved ones and those closest to them. With pride and gratitude - because had it not been for their sacrifice, new generations would not have been free and equal in their country of Bosnia, nor anywhere else in this world.
The ideals for which Bosnian sons fought and died have not been reached yet. But, our country has prevailed and is moving forward towards the community of free and democratic states.
Perhaps, we are not advancing at the pace which the most of us wish, yet we are advancing towards the goal. On that long path, the more difficult and the most painful part of the road is behind us. However, plenty of hard work is before us. That is why there is no room for despondency, passivity, indifference and selfishness.
There are still many of those who openly show their hostility towards Bosnia and Herzegovina, those who vainly dream of division of the country and threaten with secession.
It is not easy to listen and stand their insults and hate inciting. Yet, we will not be trapped to be side-guided by the offenders from the path of the truth, democracy, tolerance and civilisation values on which we are raising our country. For that is what they want – barren fuss, fights and new disputes in order for us to stay in one place instead of building our country and making it better and more prosperous.
Our future is, thanks God, clear and certain. And to the offenders and bad people we are sending the message from this place to think about the experience of their predecessors and let them draw clear conclusions for themselves from their destiny. It must be forever clear to all of them that - not a single inch of our in blood soaked country shall ever be anywhere else but within the boundaries of the State of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
These are the times of integrations, rebuilding of the bridges between the neighbours, the times of nearing the EU. But also, it is time for our integrations. I said this on 11 July 2011 in Srebrenica and I will repeat it here: we need a strong state, strong and united people. We must not divide; we must not be narrow-minded and short sighted. But, before all, we must never forget the best sons of this state, we must not betray the ideals and dreams of our Shaheeds.
In the times before us, we shall prove that their fight and sacrifice were not in vain. We shall build, with God’s help, free, peaceful and prosperous Bosnia and Herzegovina for all its peoples and citizens. For all the people of good intentions.
God bless all noble Bosnia-Herzegovinian Shaheeds.
May forever live the memory of the brave defenders of our Homeland.

title: Address by Bakir Izetbegović, BiH Presidency Member at the Potočari commemoration, 11 July 2011
content:
We are here to remember our people whom we wanted to but could not help 16 years ago. We are here to be with them at least today, to look for words of compassion and understanding.
Dear mothers, dear family members of Srebrenica’s, Bratunac’, Zvornik’s, Milići’s, Vlasenica’s, Han Pijesak’s, Rogatica’s shahids!
Dear friends from our and other countries who arrived here to share our sorrow and memory of the genocide victims!
Brothers and sisters!
We have gathered here to pay tribute to mortal remains of yet another 613 men, boys and elderly men, who looked at these hills and woods for the last time sixteen years ago, while faced with the horror that is inconceivable to a normal human mind; faced with the evil ready to go all the way; faced with their own death, with the deaths of their brothers, sons, neighbours, with the extinction of innocent people with no-one having been spared; faced with genocide.
We are here to remember our people whom we wanted to but could not help 16 years ago. We are here to be with them at least today, to look for words of compassion and understanding.
No words can describe the horrors of Srebrenica, no words can help us understand what happened here, and why it happened. No words can explain the inexplicable, irrational evil. A limitless and voracious hatred aimed at those people whose only guilt was that they were Muslims and that they defended their country, places, houses in which they were born. No words can explain readiness to burn villages down, expel their residents to this little town, then kill and starve them for years, and finally, in the end, to kill each one of them.
This genocide was not a consequence of an uncontrolled emotion that lasted for a mere few hours, nor did it happen due to the guilt of a few commanders. The entire military and police structure, led by Ratko Mladić, carried out detaining, executing, and covering up of horrific crimes.
They did this persistently, all the way through, to the very last detainee; to the end.
Nesib Muhić, whom we will bury here today, was 11 at the time when he was killed, and Redžo Pudarić was 82. Nezira Ibišević, a girl who refused to abandon her father and brothers, was just 20. Srebrenica is the deepest wound in the body of the tormented Bosniak people. Other wounds may heal with time. This one never will.
Srebrenica is a dark stain on the international community’s cheek. That stain will never fade away. Srebrenica is a dark hole on the consciousness of those who ordered and committed crimes. They will never get rid of it, it will drag them into its dark whirl as long as they exist. They will live with it to the end of time. They will be held responsible before a grain of their remaining consciousness, before their own face in the mirror, they will be held responsible before human courts and, finally – before the God’s court.
They will be held responsible for deliberate, persistent, cynical evil by which they humiliated and shamed dignity of human kind.
Radovan Karadžić is at Scheveningen, and so is Ratko Mladić. Justice is slow and, unfortunately, just partial. Hundreds of direct perpetrators still remain at large. A large part of Serbian people has avoided facing the truth. In parts of Serbia and in parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina Mladić has been celebrated as a hero. Some influential politicians state that credit is due to this criminal for creating some kind of Serbian state at this side of the Drina River. Those same politicians mention referendums that might question the sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina, separate Srebrenica from its territory. The international community yet again looks aside, demonstrates indecisiveness in condemning and sanctioning of a clearly anti-Dayton rhetoric and behaviour. There are still attempts to rewrite history, to relativise, to present all sides as equal. Attempts to find a grain in the eye of the defender, in order to equalize it with a beam in the eye of the aggressor. The returnees to Srebrenica and to other parts of RS still, with good reasons, feel like second rank citizens.
When we ask ourselves how we can proceed in this marathon race while dragging our legs cuffed with lead balls, how we can build our state and future with those who persist in salting our wounds by their words – we should bring to memory two messages.
The first one is the message from God and it says: “Give joy to the patient… there will be a relief after suffering”.
The second one are the words of late Alija Izetbegović, spoken on the occasion of the signing of the Dayton peace: “This is not a righteous peace, but it is more righteous than a continuation of the war. In the world as it is, in the situation as it is – no better peace could have been accomplished”.
The world of politics, unfortunately, has not changed significantly. It still finds it easier to follow the line of lesser resistance.
And therefore – in the world as it is today, in the situation as it is today, I hereby call on all Bosnian patriots to exercise additional patience. To share respect, unity and trust with one another. Let us not allow the feelings of powerlessness, hatred, or wish to revenge overwhelm us. The only revenge that is suitable for us, and to that I call on you to exercise, is to achieve victory against the war objectives of those who planned and committed the Srebrenica genocide.
That means to keep the sovereignty of our country, to ensure that forced migrants’ return, to locate and bury the victims. A dignified life of the living and a dignified peace of the dead. That means to insist on building a unified, well organized, prosperous state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Building of such country and society in which all fair and well-intended people see a clear future for them and for their children. In which only the wrong doers and bad people are worried about their future. No single criminal must live peacefully and remain unpunished. As long as they live, and as long as we live, we must continue to pursue them.
Let us continue to insist on strengthening our state and its institutions, improve living standards, and ensure sustainable return.
This is the time of integrations, of improvement of legal security of all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the time of accession to the European Union and NATO. It is also the time for our own integrations. We need a strong state and a strong, united people. We should not divide ourselves on the issues related to the interest of our state and people, we should not be narrow-minded and short-sighted. Each municipality in the Federation can assist return and everyday life of returnees in one of the RS municipalities. There is no excuse for passivity, indifference, selfishness.
There is a long way ahead. However, we already left the harder and most painful portion of it behind our backs. The ongoing processes have evolved slowly, but in the right direction. Each year we make several important steps to stability of our country, and each year several key criminals end up behind the bars.
Relations in our region have stabilised, too, and finally there are leaders ready to face the past and build a better future.
President Ivo Josipović is with us today. I greet him and thank him for his commitment and persistent action that opens up a new perspective of relationships with the region. In a few days we are planning to attend a regional meeting of regional leaders in Croatia, where we envisage to achieve another improvement in the reconciliation processes, share support to one another in the EU accession, and discuss a joint approach to building of infrastructure.
A year ago, on today’s date, Boris Tadić was with us in Potočari, too, and he promised he would do everything he could to arrest Ratko Mladić. He kept his word.
The Srebrenica genocide brought NATO about to intervene in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The slaughter committed in the UN Safe Haven, followed by the Sarajevan Markale market place massacre added two last drops to the glass that had been filled in for years. The death of these men and women stopped the war and saved lives of many others, including, probably, the lives of some of us who gathered here today.
Let rahmat (God’s mercy, grace, compassion) be bestowed upon all shahids of Srebrenica and Central Podrinje region!
Let rahmat be bestowed upon all noble Bosnia and Herzegovinian shahids!
Let there live forever a memory of courageous defenders of our homeland!
In the following years, with God’s help, we will prove that their fight and their sacrifice were not to no avail.
We will complete the fight for a peaceful and prosperous Bosnia and Herzegovina, a land of good and well-intended people!
Thank you!

title: Official speech of BiH Presidency Mr. Bakir Izetbegović on the occasion of the election of the Best Manager of the South East and Central Europe
content:
Dear friends, you are the most direct participants in the creation of success and positive stories in our countries and I congratulate you on this. Your co-operation opens space to every other form of co-operation and an accelerated linking of the threads and connections broken. For that I am glad to see so many faces from the entire region, known and respected in the world of business, and I hope that the events as this will encourage additional co-operation and friendship of yours.
Dear friends, Ladies and Gentlemen, Dear Guests!
It is a great pleasure of mine to address you here today on the occasion of election of the Best Manager of South East and Central Europe. I am truly happy to be here at the gathering dedicated to creative people who create additional values for all of us.
A high quality management of business organisations is extremely important for the community as a whole. In that way, among the rest, existence and affirmation for many people is secured, the society is enriched with better offer of products and services, and a constant transfer of knowledge and technology is ongoing. In the countries which are still in the transition process, as it is in our region, this is even more expressed since the system of a high quality business relations is yet to be established and which replaces the inherited way of thinking.
It is important to point out that efficient and effective business organisation represent one of the pillars of development of the concrete abilities of the entire nation and they must be supported. On the other hand, it matters that these organisations act as socially aware and to perform their role of corporative subject within the society in a dedicated and persistent manner. Everybody, in their own way, helps development of the community and I have no doubt that we are all aware of this.
Dear friends, you are the most direct participants in the creation of success and positive stories in our countries and I congratulate you on this. Your co-operation opens space to every other form of co-operation and an accelerated linking of the threads and connections broken. For that I am glad to see so many faces from the entire region, known and respected in the world of business, and I hope that the events as this will encourage additional co-operation and friendship of yours.
The capital, people and ideas must have space for circulation and may this gathering help the promotion of yours who are leaders in such understanding and representing of our overall relations.
I most sincerely congratulate you on your successes and I thank you for coming to our country and our city!
All the best and thank you!

title: Address of BiH Presidency Chairman Nebojša Radmanović at the Summit of the Heads of SEECP States
content:
At the beginning, I wish before all to thank the organisers and sponsors of this important Summit, primarily to our host, President Vujanović, for a good and successful organisation of the Summit of the South-East Europe Cooperation Process States.
Dear Mr. Chairman,
Dear Presidents,
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen
At the beginning, I wish before all to thank the organisers and sponsors of this important Summit, primarily to our host, President Vujanović, for a good and successful organisation of the Summit of the South-East Europe Cooperation Process States.
I am using this occasion to thank the representatives of Montenegro for a very successful one year presiding the SEECP during which several meetings and conferences were held at various levels and many of important results were made in the field of mutual cooperation of the states members. BiH expresses a particular gratitude to Montenegro for contributing the affirmation of the process during its mandate as “authentic voice of the region.”
This Summit of the SEECP is held in the midst of global economic and financial crisis which, for several years, has been influencing our countries as well as the countries of our surroundings and those of the European Union. The negative consequences of this crisis are heavily striking the economies of the states, due to which social and political stability of our societies is jeopardized.
For this reason, this is another opportunity to yet again send a message to all SEECP countries about the need for further strengthening of the regional cooperation, in the new forms of economic and trade links and relations in particular, as well as those in the field of security, communication, science and culture.
As it is known, BiH has from the very beginning been consistently committed to the regional cooperation as the only way to the solution of all questions among the countries of the South-East Europe, which it confirmed during its presiding over this initiative several years ago. BiH is endeavouring to adjust its actions in the field of the regional cooperation to the overall principles of BiH foreign policy within the international relations, before all the European commitments and widely accepted standards of the good-neighbourly relations.
All these years, we have been starting with the notion that the SEECP is the political strength of the region, capable of remaining open to cooperation and agreement of the countries in the situations when many of the global and regional circumstances are adverse. The South East Europe Cooperation Process has been and remains a political umbrella covering our mutual relations. The SEECP has confirmed to be a constructive forum for political dialogue about all open issues of the region. During the entire time of its existence and the work of the SEECP, solutions to many questions have been found to mutual cooperation of the member states, starting from the political dialogue at the highest level, parliamentary cooperation, to starting the solutions of the open questions that we do not agree on.
We do not hide that there still are many open questions among the countries, participants of this regional initiative, but also the readiness and will for these to be solved to mutual satisfaction and to the best interest of all involved. We have to be ready to use the capacity for dialogue of this forum, not just for good cooperation, but also the removal of the obstacles and the solution of all open questions in our joint work. It is the only way for us to answer to all the challenges that are there before our countries.
For the past years since it has existed, the Council for Regional Cooperation has constantly been workings on regional cooperation to which a particular contribution BiH has given, as a host country in which the headquarters of this Association is based.
Ladies and gentlemen,
BiH is firmly committed to the European integrations. It is an opportunity for us in BiH that we shall not miss, regardless of all the challenges, difficulties and disagreements which are following us on this path. This strategic commitment of ours is part of the overall progress of BiH, as well as our contribution to strengthening peace and sustainable development of this part of Europe.
At this place, I wish to convey the gratitude of the citizens and the authorities of BiH to the countries of the EU for the abolishment of the visa regime for all our citizens, which is a reward for successful reforms within the country, but also an encouragement for new progress. The visa-free regime has been functioning without any problems so that it has been bringing a multiple benefit to all its participants, our citizens, the country as a whole and the European Union.
Last year there were general elections in BiH. We have not succeeded in forming the government to this date, due to pronounced differences of the political actors on the models of national representation in legislative and executive government in BiH. The Dayton Constitution of BiH obliges for an equal participation of legitimate representatives of all constitutional peoples in BiH, which must mirror the calling of the executive government bodies at the state level. The Dayton Peace Accord remains to be the foundation of the existing and future relations of two entities and the three constitutive peoples in BiH
Regardless the deadlock in government forming at the state level, I must with pleasure say that with the participation of the EU, we have recently started the dialogue on the judiciary reform with an aim of implementing the European standards with regards to the rule of law, efficiency in reaching verdicts and the independence of the judiciary. The structural dialogue between the EU and Republika Srpska on the judiciary reforms, which had started as an internal political dispute, is a positive example of how a contentious internal question can be solved through the European political dialogue.
Compared to all the countries participants of the SEECP, BiH is still a limited democratic state, for having High Representative, without democratic electoral legitimacy and political responsibility. It is high time for BiH to be put on an equal par with the other states of the region and for it to take over the political responsibility for its future. We all talk about moving on to the phase of the European development of BiH, it is time to decisively move on to that phase, and on that path there is no room for High Representative.
Ladies and gentlemen,
At the end of this year we expect for all the countries of the Western Balkans to move on to the higher phase of the relations with the European Union. This is an opportunity to once again congratulate Croatia for finalising the negotiations and gaining the date of its accession to the EU. The Croatian accession to the EU brings the EU to the borders of BiH. It is a new challenge and an encouragement to all of us to triple the efforts on our European path.
Lastly, I wish to, once more, thank our hosts for a well organised Summit and wish more of the success to all in the future work of this important initiative. With a particular pleasure, I hail the decision of our hosts to open a special exhibition of the artists from the SEECP countries, as a contribution to the promotion of the dialogue among the cultures of the peoples of the South East Europe and the culture of peace in the region. This exhibition as well as the today's Summit of ours, shows that our artists, as well as our countries, have a lot to offer, not only to each other, but to the region and to entire Europe. It is for this reason that our joint voice should be louder. BiH is ready to give its contribution to it.
I thank you.
Sveti Stefan (Saint Stefan), 30 June 2011

title: Address of the Chairman of BiH Presidency Nebojša Radmanović at the closing of the Summer University for Democracy, Strasbourg, 27th and 28th June 2011
content:
It is my great pleasure to address you at the closing of the Summer University for Democracy of the Council of Europe. I am much obliged that I can share with you some thoughts on ethics and politics. Allow me, at the beginning, one slight remembrance. Next year will mark the tenth anniversary since BiH was accepted as a member of the Council of Europe. It was a large step for one small post-conflict country, which marked a new European beginning for our country.
Dear Secretary General,
Dear participants of the Summer University,
Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen!
It is my great pleasure to address you at the closing of the Summer University for Democracy of the Council of Europe. I am much obliged that I can share with you some thoughts on ethics and politics.
Allow me, at the beginning, one slight remembrance. Next year will mark the tenth anniversary since BiH was accepted as a member of the Council of Europe. It was a large step for one small post-conflict country, which marked a new European beginning for our country. It was a sure step that in this temple of human rights and democracy, there is space for new young democracies. BiH gives a small contribution to strengthening of the traditions of the European democracy and development of human rights. Unfortunately, BiH is still under the protectorate of the International Community in which many decisions are still made by the High Representative of the International Community, who has not been elected by the citizens and peoples of BiH, which is incompatible with democracy and human rights defended and represented by the oldest European organisation – The Council of Europe.
I have been thinking of what could be a suitable beginning for our discussion today on the topic of “Ethics and Politics“. This topic occupies the greatest minds of our time, scientists, politicians, journalists, and many citizens. This is an appreciative but a risky topic. Seemingly, it is easy to basically say that we imagine an ideal relationship between ethics and politics. But it is difficult to steer through the woods of various specific policies and the assessment of its ethical dimensions.
I do not know of a better example than the one I will tell you, and which originates from the region of former Yugoslavia, which BiH belongs to. When the Nazis at the beginning of the Second World War in 1941 occupied the then Kingdom of Yugoslavia and established the quisling authority, they asked, under the pressure of all notable Serb intellectuals, to support the occupational regime. Among the invited was a Serb classical philosopher, interpreter, Hellenist and professor of the University of Belgrade, Miloš Ðurić, who declined to sign this appeal, putting himself in grave danger. When a composer and professor of the Music Academy who had signed the above appeal, quietly suggested that it would be better for him to sign it too, professor Ðurić told him: “It is easy for you, you play an instrument, and I teach students the ethics“.
