It is important to emphasize that participation of BiH in the ISAF Mission is constantly growing, without causing any internal disputes. We will do everything to make Bosnia and Herzegovina a stable and reliable partner in the peacekeeping operation in Afghanistan.
Engagement of the AFBiH unit in ISAF Mission has so far been successful and this is supported by the assessments from the field. That speaks of good integration abilities of our officers and soldiers in new circumstances. ISAF military units also engage in significant civilian activities by providing assistance to the local population in their area of responsibility.
Providing training assistance to the Afghan Security Forces shall be the priority in the future.
Long term commitment of the international community in Afghanistan shall be directed towards the economic reconstruction and activation of natural and economic resources this country possesses in order for Afghanistan to take the path of peaceful transition and economic development.
Thank you.

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Nebojsa Radmanovic's addressing speech in the session of the UN Security Council in New York, 11 November 2010
content:
It is my pleasure to address the UN Security Council in the debate on BiH. Today's debate is a chance to familiarise better with the political situation in BiH and the progress that has been made in the past period. Since the last report, many new developments which changed the situation in BiH have taken place. There are many analyses and opinions among political subjects and citizens on the improvement made in BiH. BiH presidency has not had a united stance on this.
Mr President,
Mr Secretary General,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my pleasure to address the UN Security Council in the debate on BiH. Today's debate is a chance to familiarise better with the political situation in BiH and the progress that has been made in the past period. Since the last report, many new developments which changed the situation in BiH have taken place. There are many analyses and opinions among political subjects and citizens on the improvement made in BiH. BiH presidency has not had a united stance on this. Allow me to, as the Chairman of BiH presidency; deliver opinion agreed with the both of BiH Presidency Members, on the situation in BiH and possible directions of improvement in the future.
It has become popular today to speak about BiH using dark tones. It has been done so even from this platform. BiH is an ideal subject for different disaster seekers on which they wish to prove their theories. Unlike other similar regions in the world where the international community is engaged, BiH as a whole portrays a positive example of actions taken by the international community in the process of peace-building. It has been confirmed by numerous relevant reports from international organisations, independent institutions and nongovernmental organisations in the world. It is true that during the past six months BiH has had a slight deadlock on its path to reforms and transition. One of the reasons for this is the fact that this was the year of elections and political subjects were turned more towards electoral campaigns and winning votes, and not towards true issues of the country.
It is the fifteenth anniversary of Dayton Peace Agreement this year. Fifteen years ago BiH stepped out of a tragic conflict which destabilised the country and the whole region. Today, fifteen years later we ask ourselves: What have we done and how much from what we signed for and committed ourselves to, has been achieved?
Let me now say this: with the joint effort of the international community and local authorities, BiH has made significant progress in the post war period that represents a positive example in comparison to many other similar crises regions in the world. Name one peace agreement in the modern history of Europe and the world that was more successfully implemented? Some who are unhappy with the speed of progress in BiH are trying to find cure undermining the foundations of the existing peace agreement, which drags us into new conflicts and quarrels. Since the end of the war to date, Bosnia and Herzegovina has implemented all key elements of Dayton Peace Agreement: a stable peace has been established, the country functions on the constitutional basis of Dayton Peace Agreement, the largest number of refugees and internally displaced persons has returned its properties and many have returned to the places they had lived in earlier. For this reason, BiH represents a successful example unlike other areas in the region. Six general parliament elections have been held out of which several have been organised by domestic authorities, unique economic space has been created, macro-economic indicators of the economy are stable and show slow but positive upward trend, value added tax has been successfully implemented, defence reform and armed forces reform has been successfully completed, after initial arrests of those accused for war crimes by international military forces majority of the latter ones were made by domestic authorities, domestic courts are holding war crime trials, BiH has become a member of the European Council and other international organisations, the country has entered NATO Partnership for Peace programme, we have become members of free trade zone CEFTA, and as a result of all this, Stabilisation and Association Agreement was signed with the EU. The country has met 174 conditions for visa regime to be abolished on what EU has already brought decision. Public Administration reforms are in the progress as well as those of legislature, high education and public broadcasting system, and adjustment of the Constitution to agree with the European Convention on Human Rights and verdict of European Court for Human Rights in Strasbourg.
I am reminding you that, as a result of positive development of political and security circumstances in BiH, NATO has reduced its forces in BiH and their engagement was brought down to headquarters in Sarajevo only. Moreover, EURFOR, as a result of obvious progress on creation of safe and stable environment also reduced its forces in BiH.
There are different views on the position and status of the Office of High Representative in BiH. Political representatives from one people believe that the Office of High Representative should permanently remain in BiH. And representatives of others are of the opinion that it should be replaced by a Special Representative of the EU. Even if there were reasons after the war for the Office of High Representative to exist in BiH, fifteen years after that, they have been significantly reduced. In the last report on BiH by the European Commission it has been stated that BiH could not undertake further steps in the process of European integration until the transformation of the Office of High Representative is done to EU Special Representative Office.
All changes in BiH must be based on the rule of law. Therefore, full implementation of Dayton Peace Agreement is necessary. Dayton Agreement is firstly an agreement and not a framework from which one can take what one finds suitable and avoid accomplishment of other obligations. As far as the decision of the Office of High Representative according to which Annex 4 of Dayton Peace Agreement is changed, it is clear that legal acts can be changed only in the same way they were enacted unless those acts do not state differently. Therefore, discussions on these questions will continue.
An issue of building a functional state cannot be exclusively resolved with the changes in the constitutional and legal procedures for bringing decisions in BiH, through which higher unitarisation and decentralisation would be introduced. It is simplified and dangerous solution of complex and sensitive political issue. Such approach would question legitimacy of authority in a complex and multinational state such as BiH is, and ruffle the region which itself is not fully stable.
Basic pre-condition for building a functional state is reconciliation among the nations and mutual trust. Without punishing all executors of war crimes, from all peoples, there cannot be reconciliation and functional state cannot be built. The Hague Tribunal has estimated that BiH co-operates well so that all other estimates on this question are superfluous.
As far as the return of the refugees is concerned, there is a lack of understanding of these issues amongst domestic politicians and partly international community. In reality, there is no such case in the world where more has been done on the return of refugees and their property as it is the case in BiH. What is left is for sustainable return to be supported for which Bosnia and Herzegovina needs assistance from the international community. Double legal standards applied within a region 500 km wide in the Western Balkans, when return of refugees is concerned, is another issue that the international community should face, causing further injustice to refugees.
Today, all countries of the Western Balkans are at the certain level of progress towards accession to the EU. BiH is slightly behind its neighbours yet not as much as some with to portray.
These are all reasons to encourage BiH on its way to the EU where it belongs, for sooner transformation of the Office of High Representative, call for BiH political leaders to agree and organise the country based on their agreement without pressures from the outside. The essence of all reforms in BiH is an agreement, understanding, equality, tolerance and that should be encouraged and praised.
Thank you.

title: Chairman of BiH Presidency Nebojša Radmanović addressing speech at the constitutive session of BiH Presidency, 10 November 2010
content:
Elections are an important event in every country. They are chance and hope, an opportunity for a change, yet democratic consolidation of what has been achieved. Now that the elections are behind us we must turn to business in the future ahead. We must take political responsibility and fulfil promises given; it is so everywhere in the democratic world, so it should be in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Mr Presidents,
Your Excellencies,
Eminencies,
Ladies and gentleman
Elections are an important event in every country. They are chance and hope, an opportunity for a change, yet democratic consolidation of what has been achieved. Now that the elections are behind us we must turn to business in the future ahead. We must take political responsibility and fulfil promises given; it is so everywhere in the democratic world, so it should be in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Last elections in BiH confirmed political maturity of our citizens and their readiness to actively participate in the processes ahead of us. It is our task to make it possible for them. In this way, we shall strengthen our democratic capacity for the decisions that we should make. According to BiH Constitution, BiH Presidency is the highest authority in the country. BiH Presidency Members' conduct and understanding of this authority are based on this fact. This requires every Member to be responsible, visionary, principled but also ready for cooperation, compromise and agreement.
For the past four years, I have advocated dialog, cooperation, agreement and equality of entities and peoples as well as tolerant approach to solving of all open questions under the authority of BiH Presidency. It is the only politics that can be practised in every, but especially in a complex, multinational and conflict-ridden community such as BiH is.
BiH needs new landmarks and guideposts in the future.
Time which is before us will be decisive for the future of BiH and the region of the Western Balkans. As a member of BiH Presidency, I shall continue to contest for integration of BiH to the European Union and further development of good relations with the states of former Yugoslavia. I shall contest for the country to meet the necessary conditions for its candidate status on the path towards the European Union. Only with a candidate status, the accession process becomes irreversible for each country. This also means the closure of the Office of High Representative, and taking over the responsibility by domestic politicians for the future of the country.
I expect the European Union to be the guide and the landmark towards which we move but not to resolve our issues for us. Europe should have an advisory role and offer wider variety of solutions which meet the European standards, but not prescribe ready solutions to us and arbitrate our relations.
There have been errors made by a part of the international community in their dealing with BiH, which created a deeper mistrust between domestic political actors. The EU and the international community attitude on certain issues regarding recent reforms has been confusing. In several cases, bureaucratic parochialism and disorientation of certain individuals from the international community harmed democratic process of agreement within the country.
On political level, it is necessary to renew democratic dialogue and trust. For such to happen, the truth, punishment of all executors of war crimes, understanding and conciliation are necessary. It is very important to promote equality as a fundamental condition of life together. Moreover, we all should do all that is necessary to abolish a sense of individual and collective endangerment of any individual or a group of people in BiH. In BiH we all must show political patience. Nothing in BiH can be made ad hoc, by taking short-cuts or to a disadvantage of others. Even if this were possible, it would not be positive on a long term basis, because sooner or later it would emerge as a political mishit.
The new BiH Presidency Member mandate to me is an obligation, expression of trust, but also a serious challenge of responsibility. I do not underestimate issues that this country is facing and for this reason I approach to their solving with a full seriousness and responsibility. I have been doing so earlier; I shall continue to do the same in the new BiH Presidency.
Ladies and gentlemen,
At the end of our mandate it will be the year of 2014. It will also be a hundred year anniversary of the outbreak of the WWI, after which we have had different relations in the region of the Western Balkans. May this time the symbolism of round numbers be an encouragement to BiH Presidency and an invitation to the leaders of the Western Balkans to work together towards a long-lasting peace, turned towards the European Union and the future.
Thank you.

title: BiH Presidency Member Mr Željko Komšić’s addressing speech at the constitutive session on 10 November 2010
content:
I am addressing you with a deep sense of honour, pride and responsibility for the high duty of Croat Member of BiH Presidency, which I have just taken for the second term. The conditions now are even more complex than they were during the previous period. Thus the tasks are more difficult and challenging than they were in the past four years.
Respected citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Elected colleagues Members of Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Mr Radmanović, Mr Izetbegović,
Respected Mr Silajdžić,
Your Excellencies and Eminencies,
Ladies and gentlemen,
Dear friends!
I am addressing you with a deep sense of honour, pride and responsibility for the high duty of Croat Member of BiH Presidency, which I have just taken for the second term. The conditions now are even more complex than they were during the previous period. Thus the tasks are more difficult and challenging than they were in the past four years.
I am sure that we all share conviction that BiH must be a democratic, developed European state, a state of the rule of law and tolerance, a state in which nobody will be discriminated against for religious, national or any other beliefs, a state in which all citizens will be equal in every single part of BiH territory. It is for this reason that I am using this occasion to take an obligation to persevere in the same principles and take stance for the same aims in the period ahead.
We are not here to portray the past nor the present, but to contest for a better future of this country, still I have to, very briefly, recall the last four years during which I performed this duty.
On the international level, the state of BiH has made certain accomplishments. We must hereby remind ourselves of BiH membership to the UN Security Council, accession to NATO Action Plan, entering EU Stabilisation and Association Agreement, and finally, recent abolishment of Schengen countries’ visa regime for BiH citizens.
However, we must be honest and say that only a few in this country were satisfied with the past four years. Since I belong to a generation of devastated youth, it could be argued that I am subjective, but to me, each day, month let alone a year is not to be wasted. I feel the majority of our citizens feel the same.
Honestly speaking, economic and financial crisis as well as poverty is more obvious each day and the quality of life of every citizen of Bosnia and Herzegovina is being shattered.
Not a single citizen of BiH has deserved such hopelessness and lack of prosperity. It must not and it cannot be the future of our children!
It has to be changed, and that is what is expected by the citizens of this country. They expect this from us, those in whom they vested their trust and whom they voted for.
We are a very small country, there are not too many of us compared to European and especially global population.
This country does not deserve and cannot stand any further empty daily political phrases, false promises, i.e. immoral politics and lack of respect for fundamental ethical values as well as lack of care for an ordinary person and further divisions based on anything.
We surely possess knowledge and enthusiasm but we need a little bit more of goodwill, more mutual respect, more understanding, trust and appreciation for then our job will not be so difficult and our goal will be at an easy reach.
This goal is called Bosnia and Herzegovina in which it will be possible to live a life of a decent human being, Bosnia and Herzegovina that will be able to live off its own work and the results of its work, Bosnia and Herzegovina in which knowledge, expertise, qualifications will matter, rather than suitability, crime, corruption and ignorance.
Dear citizens!
I am addressing you and I am promising to persist in the same principles and take a stand for BiH to be a democratic state of all of its citizens, equal citizens and peoples. This has been and remains my highest objective.
I will continue fighting, guided by the same passion and responsibility for each and every one of you, whether it is about a Croat, or a Bosniak, Serb, Jew, Roma or any other citizen of BiH, because, to me, you are all mine, my Bosnian and Herzegovinians. I am not able to and do not wish to divide you.
Understandably, I will continue to stand for full equality of Croat people and their equal status under BiH Constitution.
I shall not spare effort in the next four years working for wellbeing and prosperity of our BiH, which we will make better and more successful, together. I would like to send a message to our neighbours that I will resiliently stand for normalisation of relations and co-operation, protecting the interests of BiH, its peoples and citizens, respecting the principles of equality, mutual appreciation, sovereignty, integrity and non-interference in the internal affairs of others.
I expect our neighbours to finally respect the same principles for BiH and to build different, better relations on these foundations.
Our past is dark, hard, bloody, but let us not allow such past to obstruct the way to the future. This of course does not mean we should forget it. It is such as it is, and we should not falsify or misuse it. We should draw true historical and life lessons from it and in this way create an honest basis for rebuilding the solid bridges that will not crash under the challenges of this Century.
I would like to thank our friends in Europe, America and other parts of the world for the help given to BiH. Our country has a need for their further support because we need to complete stabilisation, build more efficient institutions and accelarate the BiH accession to NATO and EU.
We are aware of the fact that the majority of work is on us, on the legitimately elected representatives of citizens and constitutive peoples, on determination and will to rapidly build BiH as a democratic European state, capable of caring and building better future for all who live here.
When it is about foreign politics of our country, I will stand for decisions to be made in unison, to modernise foundations for conducting foreign policy and better regulate foreign affairs through laws. I will expect our diplomacy and foreign service to stand for the state interests alone, and not just certain segments of BiH. It should affirm our country in the world, as it has already been achieved with non-permanent status at the UN Security Council, participation in the peace-keeping missions in areas of crisis and establishment of diplomatic relations with a vast majority of the UN member states.
Moreover, it is a matter of priority to build our institutions and their capacity for negotiation process of our accession into NATO and the EU.
Lastly, I promise that during my mandate of BiH Presidency Member, I will never be led by interests of daily politics nor party interests!
This duty obliges me to stand for and follow the only interest that there is, and that is the interest of our homeland and country Bosnia and Herzegovina, with all its citizens and peoples.
Thank you.

title: Inaugural speech of BiH Presidency Member Bakir Izetbegović, 10 November 2010
content:
At the very beginning, I would like to use this opportunity to thank all the voters whose will decided for me to be chosen for this honorable position of BiH Presidency Member. A special thanks goes to unreserved support of my wife and daughter, friends and associates. In the years that follow, I will endevour to justify their support, effort and trust.
Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen,
Respected colleagues, members of BiH Presidency!
At the very beginning, I would like to use this opportunity to thank all the voters whose will decided for me to be chosen for this honorable position of BiH Presidency Member. A special thanks goes to unreserved support of my wife and daughter, friends and associates. In the years that follow, I will endevour to justify their support, effort and trust.
The building that we are in today recalls special memories, reminiscences and emotions. I first entered the building of BiH Presidency through the formal entrance exactly twenty years ago, in November 1990. And then, for years, I closely witnessed rapid float of history that took place and was created within these walls. Those were the growing pains of the state in its creation. Long hallways, wide Austrian stairways, old paintings and furniture, were all engraved in my memory together with the news and events that were occurring one after another. Naturally, the strongest reminiscence and emotion are linked to the cabinet that I am to enter today, succeeding the man that I assisted and followed for a whole decade. Our relationship to homeland and political philosophy he expressed in a few simple sentences that say “…this that we call Bosnia is not a piece of land in the Balkans. To many of us Bosnia is not only a homeland. Bosnia is an idea. It is a belief that people of different religions, nations and cultural traditions can live together…”
Yes, the idea of Bosnia and Herzegovina obviously goes beyond its geographical size and its borders. The worlds meet here. This is the knot where they tie or untie, not only Bosnian and Herzegovinian but global relations too.
It is time for a positive turn of events.
If we are to judge by the political rethorics and atmosphere, we could conclude that our country is again at one of the crossroads. However, this is not a crossroad, because crossroads offer different paths, and we only have one. The rest are misleads and blind streets. The only true path is the path of integration, union, co-operation, dialogue, in one word – European path.
The path of swift implementation of European standards in the state organisation, legislative institutions, economy and before all, in a sphere of human rights and freedoms. The path of removal and relativisation of borders, visas, obstacles and divisions. Naturally, this implies urgent adaption of constitutional reforms that will adjust our Constitution to European convention on human rights. Reforms to implement European clauses into our Constitution, build the state apparatus which can solve internal obstacles, and function without constant arbitrage and protectorate from the international community.
BiH Presidency must give a special contribution to above mentioned reforms and positive changes in the country and the region. Presidency should initiate and take special care of the most important processes in society. We are obliged to answer to our constitutional role and expectations of our citizens, serve as an example to other state institutions.
I wish to point out that I personally will, in the mandate ahead, do my best for this institution to function on the basis of mutual understanding and on the basis of recognisable will for co-operation through clear working programs and agreed platforms for diplomatic conduct outside the country.
I will especially stand for Presidency to lead the process of true and long term co-operation with neighbouring countries. All of us in the region are interested in improvement towards the membership to the European Union, and there is no improvement without true regional co-operation in solving open questions among bordering states. I will pay special attention to accession of our countries to NATO and the EU, for the membership in these associations brings safety, stability and prosperity to Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens. It is only a safe and stable country that can create a suitable business environment, attract foreign investments and capital, employ the youth, and thus raise the living standards of every citizen.
In this sense, I will offer strong support to decisive fight against violence, crime and corruption in our country. To prevail in the fight against modern age plaque is a precondition to a healing of the entire society.
I will strife for continuation of the process of sustainable return, with an accent on sustainability. Some think it is too late, but it is not so, not too late, the land is waiting for people to farm it, and 150,000 are waiting to return. I will therefore give strong support to the projects which support agriculture, employ returnees, especially the young and educated ones. We can secure the means via credit loans which have already been approved by the Parliament of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
At the end of this speech, but not at the end of my priority list, is the interest for BiH diaspora. I feel to be a president and a representative of all the Bosniaks and Bosnians and Herzegovinians, as much as those in the country as those abroad. The diaspora has been on its own for too long, and one way co-operation through which diaspora supports the economy of our country sending billions of marks of direct financial infusion into our finances has also been lasting too long. It is time to systematically deal with diaspora, to organise it and help it. People who do not live in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but still love and help it, wish that, and they deserve it.
Thank you for your attention!

title: Statement by H.E. Dr. Haris Silajdzic at the General Debate of the 65th Session of the United Nations General Assembly, New York, 25 September 2010
content:
It is an honor to address the sixty-fifth session of the General Assembly of the United Nations. Allow me to express my gratitude to Dr. Ali Adussalam Treki for having ably presided over this body during the past year, and to congratulate Mr. Joseph Deiss on being elected the new President of the General Assembly. Fifteen years ago, the Dayton Peace Agreement ended the aggression and brought peace to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Mr. President,
Mr. Secretary-General,
Distinguished Delegates,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is an honor to address the sixty-fifth session of the General Assembly of the United Nations. Allow me to express my gratitude to Dr. Ali Adussalam Treki for having ably presided over this body during the past year, and to congratulate Mr. Joseph Deiss on being elected the new President of the General Assembly.
Fifteen years ago, the Dayton Peace Agreement ended the aggression and brought peace to Bosnia and Herzegovina. My country has gone a long way since, and I feel obliged to thank the governments, organizations, and individuals who assisted us in travelling this road.
When we asked you to support us to become a non-permanent member of the Security Council, you honored us with almost unanimous support. That demonstrated that you hold Bosnia and Herzegovina in esteem, and we are proud of that. As a member of the Security Council, we are doing our best to meet your expectations and honor the trust you gave us.
Thanks to the generous assistance of many of your governments, Bosnia and Herzegovina mainly completed the reconstruction process relatively quickly given the level of devastation. But the rebuilding of our devastated society proved to be much more difficult. From 1992 to 1995, an old, genuinely multicultural society of Bosnia and Herzegovina was brutally and intentionally torn apart by force. One-half of the population of Bosnia and Herzegovina had to leave their homes in order to save their lives. One million three hundred thousand of them still remain outside of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Systematic obstructions were the cause of failure of return programs, and they are still an obstacle to those who want to return. Those who made it back to their homes are often confronted with a wall of blockades or with outright violations of basic rights. That makes the restoration of our pluralist society the single most difficult task ahead of us. But hope remains that the upcoming constitutional changes will lay a foundation for the new generation to bridge the divides. No matter what, we will continue to revive the pluralist character and tolerant spirit of our society because we strongly believe that cultural pluralism is the mankind’s most precious treasure.
Good economy can be a powerful tool to achieve this goal. Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country rich in water and other energy-generating resources. We have made studies and have invited international investors to participate in developing these resources. Once completed, these projects will be the driving engine of our economy, enabling us to make progress in other areas, such as health care and social services. We continue to develop our infrastructure and agricultural resources, but not at a desirable pace. Although generally improved, our education system remains in some aspects hostage to divisive political influences.
On the other side, our rising trade activities have resulted in improving our relations with the countries in the region, and great opportunities can be unlocked through more intensive and more confident regional cooperation. Like in other societies, our greatest resource is our youth, educated in our country and abroad, ready to take over once our economy is able to absorb their skills and talents. I am confident that in the coming years a number of job opportunities will arise parallel with the development of the vast resources that lie still unused in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Defense reform is commonly seen as one of the greatest post-Dayton successes because it resulted in the unified, modern armed forces. Here again we have to express our appreciation to our friends and allies whose assistance made this possible. In short time our armed forces managed to earn the trust and respect of the United Nations through their participation in peacekeeping mission.
Like everywhere else, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina desire peace, stability and prosperity – a better future for themselves and their children. There is great potential for development, and opportunities are there to seize them. So, yes, there are reasons for optimism. But there are reasons for concern too.
Our progress is hindered by the remnants of those who still believe in the completion of the political project that proved catastrophic not only for Bosnia and Herzegovina, but for the whole region. In short, they think that the world has forgotten the atrocities committed against the civilian population, the concentration camps, the rape camps and the genocide. After hundreds of thousands of non-Serb civilians were killed and expelled from one part of Bosnia and Herzegovina, they are now publically calling for the secession of that part. They hope and “dream,” as they say, that the world would somehow recognize that entity as an independent state. Instead of feeling shame, these disciples of Milošević, Karadžić and Ratko Mladić are now ready to come and ask you to reward the genocide in Srebrenica, Prijedor, Zvornik, Sarajevo, Mostar and other sites of horrific crimes for which Karadžić is now being tried at the International Criminal Tribunal in the Hague. What a monument to inhumanity would that be!
Of course, they will not succeed. They can no longer count on the mighty armies of Slobodan Milošević because those armies were defeated through our heroic struggle. They do count on, as they say, favourable geopolitical circumstances. But they fail to take one thing into account, as did Milošević: Bosnia and Herzegovina will be defended!
They will, however, continue obstructing progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and they will continue destabilizing the region. They found inspiration in the inadequate response of the international community, whose patience they have been testing for the last fifteen years. So, our collective resolve to prevent the escalation and opening of fresh wounds in Bosnia and Herzegovina is being tested again. We must not fail this time!
This dangerous adventurism aside, I believe and I know that the train of progress cannot and will not be stopped. There is no doubt in my mind that Bosnia and Herzegovina and our entire region will maintain stability and achieve prosperity in the coming years, thus fulfilling the dreams and desires of every one of our citizens.

title: Statement by H.E. Dr. Haris Silajdžić at the High Level Meeting on Sudan New York 24 September 2010
content:
I would like to thank the United Nations Secretary-General, Mr. Ban Ki-moon, for convening this meeting and reflecting the high priority that the United Nations has given to Sudan. The Comprehensive Peace Agreement, which is fundamental and indispensable for peace and stability in Sudan, reaches a critical stage. In less than four months, the referenda that will determine the future shape of the Sudan will take place.
Distinguished Heads of State,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I would like to thank the United Nations Secretary-General, Mr. Ban Ki-moon, for convening this meeting and reflecting the high priority that the United Nations has given to Sudan.
The Comprehensive Peace Agreement, which is fundamental and indispensable for peace and stability in Sudan, reaches a critical stage. In less than four months, the referenda that will determine the future shape of the Sudan will take place.
Bosnia and Herzegovina supports full implementation of the CPA. The level of cooperation between the Government of Sudan and the Government of the South Sudan in the pre- and post-referendum period will determine the destiny not only of Sudan, but of the entire region. It is of critical importance that the CPA parties engage constructively in order to address outstanding issues with regard to implementation of the CPA. We hope that the CPA parties, for the benefit of their peoples, will resolve all issues in a friendly and peaceful manner. Bearing in mind that conducting of the referenda will pose risk to the security situation, it is important that the CPA parties timely undertake all appropriate measures in order to be able to provide security to the civilian population.
Mr. Secretary-General,
It has to be underlined that any option must not leave any side disadvantaged. If unity prevails, a just power-sharing system has to be established. Moreover, diversity and equality of all regions have to be respected. On the other hand, if independence takes place, both sides have to be unified around values and principles of friendly relations and good cooperation. Regardless of the referenda outcome, it is important to give priority to the capacity building of the authorities of the South Sudan to provide security and deliver services to their population, because only viable South Sudan with strong local structures will contribute to peace and stability in the region.
Sudan is a good example of close cooperation between the United Nations and the African Union. Symbiosis of a universal organization and a regional organization, and their collaboration in Darfur through their Hybrid Mission, UNAMID, have not only contributed to the improvement of situation on the ground, but gives hope and paves a way for peace as well. Experiences from this joint endeavor will help anticipate solutions for other conflicts and crises in Africa.
Mr. Secretary-General,
A just solution must be found for the people of Darfur. They have suffered for too long. The lasting solution for Darfur must include an equitable participation of the people of Darfur in the decision-making process and the creation of conditions to address their grievances.
Bosnia and Herzegovina fully supports political process and mediation efforts in Doha. It is essential that the Doha Peace Process goes within the timeline of the CPA. We call upon all parties to fully and unconditionally engage in this process. Allow me to express my gratitude to His Highness Sheikh Hamad Bin Khalifa Al-Thani, Emir of the State of Qatar, for initiating and facilitating the Doha Peace Process. I would also like to thank all the governments and organizations that have contributed to moving this peace process forward.
Bosnia and Herzegovina also welcomes the improvement in the relations between Chad and Sudan. We must always keep in mind that the situation in Sudan and the peace and stability of the region are closely interconnected. Conducive environment in the region will facilitate positive development and help the people of Sudan solve their problems.
Mr. Secretary-General,
In conclusion, at this critical time Sudan deserves and must have the full attention of the international community. We all have to assist the peoples of Sudan to find their way to a better future for their country. As a country that has traveled the difficult road from suffering the worst atrocities and civilian plight in Europe since the Second World War to being a member of the United Nations Security Council, Bosnia and Herzegovina is ready and willing to fully share its experiences to contribute to the international community’s efforts to bring lasting peace, stability and prosperity to Sudan.
Thank you, Mr. Secretary-General.

title: Statement by H.E. dr. Haris Silajdzic at the Summit of the UN Security Council, 23 September 2010
content:
I would like to thank you, President GÜL, and the delegation of the Republic of Turkey for convening this high level meeting in order to make a strategic review of the Security Council’s growing role in the maintenance of international peace and security. I would also like to thank the United Nations Secretary-General, Mr. Ban Ki-moon, for his excellent presentation.
I would like to thank you, President GÜL, and the delegation of the Republic of Turkey for convening this high level meeting in order to make a strategic review of the Security Council’s growing role in the maintenance of international peace and security.
I would also like to thank the United Nations Secretary-General, Mr. Ban Ki-moon, for his excellent presentation.
I sincerely hope that the outcome of our meeting today will serve as a useful tool for future Security Council deliberations.
The primary role of the Security Council under the United Nations Charter is to maintain international peace and security. We should live up to the expectations and send a unanimous message today that we commit ourselves to developing the means to fulfill this responsibility.
Mr. President,
Coming from the perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I cannot stress enough how crucial it is that the lessons learned in the past are applied accordingly. This Council has erred in the past, and Bosnia and Herzegovina is the most illustrative example of that in modern history.
By imposing and maintaining the arms embargo on Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Security Council added to the overwhelming military advantage of Milosevic’s regime that intended to aggrandize its own territories at the expense of the surrounding states through genocide and ethnic cleansing regardless of human cost. As a result, according to the ICRC data, 200,000 people were killed, 12,000 of them children, up to 50,000 women were raped, and 2.2 million were forced to flee their homes. May I also remind you that one million three hundred fifty thousand citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina still leave outside of the country as a consequence.
Some powerful members of this Council justified this course at the time by arguing that the lifting of the embargo would add oil to the fire. The result was that the fire was essentially quelled with the blood of the innocent.
And, then, the horrors culminated in the genocide that was committed in Srebrenica in July 1995.
In fact, the UN Secretary-General’s Report on Srebrenica from 2000 unequivocally admitted:
“Through error, misjudgment and an inability to recognize the scope of the evil confronting us, we failed to do our part to help save the people of Srebrenica from the Serb campaign of mass murder…..Srebrenica crystallized a truth understood only too late by the United Nations and the world at large: that Bosnia was as much a moral cause as a military conflict. The tragedy of Srebrenica will haunt our history forever.”
Mr. President,
We cannot bring back the dead, but we can give dignity and justice to the survivors. What we say today is not aimed at the past, but at the future. We owe it not only to the victims and survivors, but to our common humanity. The message that this Security Council sends to the would-be perpetrators of crimes in the name of a twisted ideology must be clear: your crimes will not pay off.
The errors that were made in Bosnia and Herzegovina have to this day not been corrected. To the contrary, the peace and security established by the Dayton Agreement and the progress made in many fields are now destabilized by open calls for secession of one part of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This destabilizing rhetoric was preceded by the testing of the international community’s patience for the last fifteen years.
Inadequate responses to the constant blocking of state institutions, return of refugees, and provocative rhetoric have been tolerated long enough for the perpetrators to believe that the time has come to turn the territories where atrocities, ethnic cleansing, and genocide were committed into their own fiefdom.
This is a threat not only to peace, security, and stability in which the international community invested so much, but also a test of the international community’s resolve to prevent the escalation and the opening of fresh wounds in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It would be a repetition of mistake to dismiss open calls for changing international borders as election campaign rhetoric. Our ability to prevent is tested once more.
President John F. Kennedy once rightly said that “an error does not become a mistake until you refuse to correct it.”
Mr. President,
I would also like to say a few sentences about the post-conflict peace-building operations.
Although all relevant national and international actors should be involved in the process, we consider the political will of the host country and the national ownership to be sine qua non conditions for the success of peace-building operations. The peace building process is primarily a national responsibility of post-conflict countries.
Promotion of dialogue between the parties to a conflict, particularly between decision-makers and civil society, is critical for national institutions’ capacity building and for confidence building and reconciliation process.
Holding accountable all those who committed crimes and bringing them to justice is of crucial importance to reconciliation process. Another unpleasant reminder is in order here: Ratko Mladiæ, the chief executioner of the genocide in Srebrenica, is still at large.
Peace building operations should be based on an integrated approach that includes establishment of good governance, rule of law, promotion of human rights, institution building, security sector reform, economic reconstruction and development, and full reintegration of refugees and internally displaced persons.
The role of women and their involvement in peace-building efforts should be strengthened in post-conflict societies as well.
Mr. President,
In our increasingly interconnected world, the issues of peace and security are inseparable. New threats and challenges emerge by day. No country can isolate itself from them or tackle them individually. The Security Council, therefore, must be prepared to deal with challenges in a coherent, comprehensive and just way. The Security Council must meet the expectations and fulfill the hopes of millions of those in need throughout the world. They expect nothing less from us. We must not fail them.
Thank you, Mr. President!

title: Statement by His Excellency Dr. Haris Silajdzic at High Level Summit on Millenium Development Goals New York 22 September 2010
content:
It is an honor to participate in this High Level Meeting on Millennium Development Goals. Allow me to express my gratitude to Dr. Ali Adussalam Treki for having ably presided over the General Assembly during the past year, and to congratulate Mr. Joseph Deiss on being elected the new President of the General Assembly.
Mister Chairmen,
Mister Secretary General,
Excellencies,
It is an honor to participate in this High Level Meeting on Millennium Development Goals.
Allow me to express my gratitude to Dr. Ali Adussalam Treki for having ably presided over the General Assembly during the past year, and to congratulate Mr. Joseph Deiss on being elected the new President of the General Assembly.
I would also like to thank the United Nations Secretary General Mr. Ban Ki-moon for calling on world leaders to attend this summit in order to give a new momentum to the pursuit of Millennium Development Goals.
Mr. Chairmen,
Ten years ago, world governments agreed to ensure a new vision in order to change reality, creating a crucial platform for global 21st century cooperation. At that historic moment, by the adoption of the Millennium Declaration, key challenges that humanity faced were set, and concrete measures to assess progress in attaining interrelated goals and tasks, associated with development, governance, peace, security and human rights, were defined.
Today, this assembly presents an opportunity to answer two important questions: What is the progress status of pursuing commitments we had assumed at the Millennium Summit? And can we be satisfied with what we have achieved?
The results achieved so far are surely not to be underestimated, but they are still far from satisfying. Moreover, the results achieved are compromised by new challenges and problems we are facing: economic crises, conflicts, climate change effects, and other global challenges.
Mr. Chairmen,
Bosnia and Herzegovina is fully committed to the attainment of Millennium Development Goals. As a country that recently suffered major war devastation, and thereafter received significant international support for reconstruction, Bosnia and Herzegovina now invests significant efforts in order to achieve sustainability and its own responsibility.
Working to overcome current problems and create conditions for improving social circumstances, various activities are being implemented and planned in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bosnia and Herzegovina has made its National Human Development Report on Millennium Development Goals, with the quantitative estimates of achieving Millennium Development Goals by 2015. We have also made the framework for defining the long-term strategic priorities, as well as the framework for harmonization of Millennium Development Goals with the social programs of the European Union. Our National Human Development Report focuses on Millennium Development Goals priorities of high importance for Bosnia and Herzegovina, especially poverty reduction, development humanization, and development support enhancement.
In 2003, Bosnia and Herzegovina incorporated MDG indicators into its first Medium-Term Development Strategy 2004-2007. The achievement of MDGs in Bosnia and Herzegovina thus became a vital part of the development strategy and its implementation. The final report on the implementation of the measures planned within the Action Plans indicates that the progress in the achievement of MDGs was made within that medium-term period.
In this regard, we have developed two strategic documents: the Bosnia and Herzegovina 2010-2013 Development Strategy and the Bosnia and Herzegovina Social Inclusion Strategy. These documents have now been finalized and are to be adopted. The purpose of these strategies is to provide for a more stable, efficient and competitive economy, to reduce poverty and to achieve social inclusion in Bosnia and Herzegovina as well as its integration into the European Union.
Both strategies have been drafted with a full participation of all levels of government and with participation of the civil society sector. Goals and priorities are corresponding to MDGs. The implementation of these strategies will be of great importance for our future progress towards achieving MDGs.
The Bosnia and Herzegovina 2010-2014 Employment Strategy is currently in the phase of public comments consideration. We have also adopted the 2008-2010 Decent Work Country Program document, which defines a set of policies targeted at mitigating problems in the field of employment.
With regard to solving social issues related to possible consequences of the energy sector reforms, Bosnia and Herzegovina adopted the Social Action Plan on the Memorandum of Understanding on Social Issues in the Context of the Energy Community[1]. The goal of this plan is to ensure the protection of the most vulnerable categories of our citizens in case of electric power price increase and to provide adequate measures for the protection and care of a possible surplus of employees in this sector.
In addition to the above, the document Disability Policy[2] created elementary conditions for creating solutions targeted at ensuring a higher level of social inclusion for this especially vulnerable group and enabling their access, among other things, to the labor market.
The Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina adopted the Decision on Ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities[3], while the state Ministry of Human Rights and Refugees is working on establishing a Council for Persons with Disabilities.
The project Strengthening the System of Children’s Social Protection and Social Inclusion is currently being implemented in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It aims to create a model of integrated child social protection through multi-sectoral cooperation. With the support of the Save Children UK, we are also currently implementing the project Standardization of Services in the Field of Children’s. These two projects will greatly contribute to harmonizing the regulations and improving the practice in the field of social and children protection.
Based on a series of international conventions and declarations as well as the Law on the Protection of the Rights of Persons Belonging to National Minority, adopted in 2003 at the state level and based on the document 2005-2015 Decade of Roma Inclusion, Bosnia and Herzegovina developed an Action Plan on Educational Needs of the Roma, who represent the biggest national minority in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Due to various reasons, the results are not satisfactory, and much still remains to be done, particularly in the areas of education and employment of Roma.
Mr. Chairmen,
Millennium Development Goals reflect the essence of all activities to which the United Nations are committed. It is, therefore, vital for Bosnia and Herzegovina to maintain the positive trend achieved in including these goals in our policies and strategies. We are fully determined to continue working with our partners in the international community in order to strengthen local self-responsibility and stimulate long-term development on the path to full membership in the European Union.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country rich in human and natural resources, especially in water, agricultural resources and renewable energy. We have not yet been able to fully realize our country’s potentials because our dysfunctional ethno-territorial arrangements hinder our efforts and prevent us from progressing at the desirable pace. In addition, we are witnessing an escalation of open calls for secession of one part of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which have a destabilizing effect on the entire region. for In order to be able to fully utilize our potential, Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to carry out constitutional reforms that will create a single economic space and make our government functional and rational, so that it can meet the needs of our citizens. The active support of the international community to Bosnia and Herzegovina in this reform process is of essence.
In conclusion, I would like to underline what we already know. In order to make real progress, it is necessary to improve the quality of support and coordination among donors, including financial and technical support, ensure full support by United Nations organisations as well as strengthen partnerships between the public and private sector and civil society. If this is done, I am hopeful that we can achieve the Millennium Development Goals by 2015.
Thank You!
Photo Gallery
[1] B&H Official Gazette no. 35/10
[2] B&H Official Gazette no. 76/08

title: Speech by BiH Presidency Member from the Republic of Srpska Nebojša Radmanović at the traditional folk assembly in Milića Gaj dedicated to the celebration of July 27, the Uprising Day of BiH Peoples
content:
It has been sixty-nine years since the historic decision to rebel against the Fascist and Nazi occupiers and domestic collaborators in then Yugoslavia, aligning the peoples of these territories, primarily the Serbian people, with the victorious antifascist coalition in the Second World War.
Dear Second World War soldiers,
Dear citizens of Knežpolje and Potkozarje,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my great pleasure to speak today, here in Milića Gaj, at the traditional folk assembly, dedicated to the celebration of July 27, the Uprising Day in 1941.
It has been sixty-nine years since the historic decision to rebel against the Fascist and Nazi occupiers and domestic collaborators in then Yugoslavia, aligning the peoples of these territories, primarily the Serbian people, with the victorious antifascist coalition in the Second World War.
This is an opportunity to remember the glorious battle of the Kozara, national heroes and others, known and unknown war heroes.
The Uprising decision was brave, visionary and deeply patriotic, one of the most important ones in the history of our peoples and nationalities. In then enslaved Europe, small nations raised arms against the occupier force, crime and terror. That is a great deed aligning us side by side with other freedom-loving peoples of Europe and the world.
The past of these areas has always been full of violent occupations by foreign troops conquering these territories, but also of freedom-loving and rebellious movements who would not put up with such a state. In general, the majority of cases involved a disproportional ratio of forces, even though small in number and military insufficiently prepared people in these areas were ready to sacrifice everything they had to defend thier land and freedom, sometimes paying a great price for their survival.
For that feat, in the Second World War, the merits go to the brave soldiers of the national liberation and antifascist movement, who had devotedly defended their country and the highest ideals of the humanity.
People in these areas have paid a great price for their freedom. Just remember the Calvary of the Serbian people in the Camp Jasenovac, their losses in the enemy offensive on the Kozara, as well as other trials and tribulations realistically described in Skender Kulenović’s poem «Stojanka majka Knežopoljka» and war songs and stories by Branko Čopić, from Grmeč to Kozara. Numbers tell us more than everything else does. Trough genocide against the Serbs and other war deaths during the Second World War, the municipality of Dubica had lost 54% of its pre-war population, which is a unique example of an ordeal in the world.
Therefore, we must never forget the contribution to the antifascist fight by the war partisan generation in the Second World War, thus joining the progressive forces of the entire humanity in the past century in the fight for every man’s freedom and freedom for all nations of the world.
I wish here today to pay respects and express my gratitude to all killed soldiers and innocent victims of Potkozarje and the entire Krajina from the Second World War and always to remember them proudly and with a necessary dignity. Additionally, I wish to express my deep gratitude to the fighters of the partisan movement for shown courage, patriotism, loyalty and devotion to permanent values that have kept us trough centuries, without which we could not last as people and as a society.
What that war partisan generation has achieved should be and must remain a permanent inspiration to the current and future generations of young people, as a testimonial of an adamant courage, self-sacrifice and patriotic loyalty to one’s country. I am convinced a lot can be changed in our lives, but the sense of indebtedness and appreciation to all those who sacrificed themselves for our freedom and humane ideals, will never fade away or disappear.
Although all this is known, today, in the public and political life of Bosnia and Herzegovina and other countries of former Yugoslavia, a «quiet revisionism» is slowly imposed, trying to equate the occupiers and the liberators, the criminals and the victims, the victors and the defeated.
So in BiH, books are written where facts are distorted about the partisan movement; monuments from those times are demolished; members of the infamous criminal formations who had committed mass crimes against the civilian population are openly glorified, some of them even have their streets, entire nations, Serbs among them, are denied participation and contribution to the national liberation fight and the real truth is left untold. All that is done by certain groups and individuals, for the daily political purposes in political fights against the political opponents.
Those who fought for a better and progressive world in the Second World War believed they were sacrificing themselves for a new world without wars and conflicts. Unfortunately, after forty years of peace, destiny played its part again in its tragic way and in early nineties, the peoples of former Yugoslavia became victims of statehood ambition of certain leaders and international imperial interests, when a strong and great state of Yugoslavia was broken, and its peoples were taken into quarrel and into a new war conflict. Between that war and the last patriotic war there is an unbreakable bond contained in the permanent resistance movement to defend what is ours and to be on our own.
Dear soldiers, dear friends,
Here, at this spot, we must say a few words about the current social and political moment in the Republic of Srpska and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Regardless of the current difficulties, we must say that the Republic of Srpska and Bosnia and Herzegovina, in the post-war period, achieved a high level of peace and progress, also confirmed by comparison with similar countries that went trough war and the post-war reconstruction.
We have a clear goal, no matter how far it may seem to us today - the European Union. We want to develop and look into the future, aware of all the difficulties and obstacles standing in our way. That is our voluntary choice and decision that in no way can be imposed on us. We want to live in peace with our neighbors and solve all open problems by agreement and in the general welfare of our citizens. All strategic issues of the Republic of Srpska’s future will be a result of the political will of the Republic of Srpska citizens and its legitimately elected representatives.
New elections are before us in the month of October. Once again, the citizens of the Republic of Srpska will be tested in political maturity and democratic election. It is up to them to decide who will represent them in the following election period. I believe that the citizens will elect those they believe would represent them best and best protect the interests of the Republic of Srpska within BiH.
In heavy circumstances of the world economic crisis and constant pressures on the Republic of Srpska, we must choose brave and decisive people who know how to strengthen the Republic of Srpska, who will be adamant in defending its Dayton position and competence, who will say NO to all pressures and all attempts to take away what is ours. For that, we need political unity and fraternal harmony.
In the end, I wish to send a message of peace from this spot to the current and future generations in BiH and all the neighbors. Let this war and suffering never happen again. Let all men and peoples live in peace, welfare and mutual tolerance, respecting each other, on their land.
Only that way, we will ensure the future for us and our children, together with other peoples of Europe, to enjoy the benefits of peace and development. Every other manner will destroy the future for all of us, and that is something we must not allow.
Thank you!
Milića Gaj, 27.07.2010

title: Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić’s address on occasion of the 15th anniversary of genocide against the Bosniaks of the „UN Protected Zone“ Srebrenica and the burial of ide
content:
I have talked with many family members of the Srebrenica genocide victims, wondering what their message to convey to you today would be. Everyone, without exception, emphasized truth and justice, and no one mentioned revenge. After terrible losses and suffering caused by their malefactors, such a position towards it astonishes us with its civility and human kindness.
Dear families of the Srebrenica genocide victims,
Excellencies Presidents, Prime Ministers, Ministers, Ambassadors,
Participants of the Peace March and everyone present,
Dear friends,
I have talked with many family members of the Srebrenica genocide victims, wondering what their message to convey to you today would be. Everyone, without exception, emphasized truth and justice, and no one mentioned revenge. After terrible losses and suffering caused by their malefactors, such a position towards it astonishes us with its civility and human kindness. I remind you about the fact that in Bosnia and Herzegovina, even besides and after everything that has happened, not a single act of revenge has been registered. However, it does not mean that these people will allow to have their human dignity waded.
Slobodan Milošević’s regime had made such a mistake, therefore it was beaten, morally, military and politically. These people did nothing to earn death and ethnic cleansing, just as they do not deserve today to see the genocide results used as a key weapon for blocking the construction of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a democratic country of equal peoples and nations and that is why the solutions leading towards ending this inhumane project will be discarded as so far.
We all know the truth. Slobodan Milošević’s regime planned in detail and executed all this evil, in aim of elimination or banishment of non-Serbs from the large part of the Bosnia and Herzegovina territory. The civilians were at the attack of an organized and powerful military force. The fact that the UN Security Council had kept the embargo on weapon import helped the aggressors, thus tying the hands and depriving those who had to fight of their right to fight. The question is how it is possible that international community has done such a thing.
The answer is simple: because the victims were Bosniaks, Muslims. „Embargo (on weapon import) was kept because it was to the detriment of Bosnia and Herzegovina, “says former US President Clinton in his book that was published after our last year’s gathering at this very spot. Explaining why his efforts to lift the embargo and allow the attacked people to defend their bare existence failed, President Clinton cites the arguments given to him by certain European leaders, making these horrible crimes acceptable. „That is a painful and realistic reconstruction of a Christian Europe“was one of the arguments privately offered to President Clinton.
It is clear that the Christianity, as a religion, has nothing to do with savagery against the inhabitants of Bosnia and Herzegovina. On the contrary. I remind you that today, we also send off our catholic fellow citizen with due piety, participating, as much as possible, in the pain of his closest ones. Therefore, one cannot be surprised that the US President Obama called the crimes in Bosnia and Herzegovina „stain on the humanity’s conscience“. Only truth and justice, arresting Mladiæ and others and not understating the genocide results could appease humanity’s conscience. Obstacles in that path can no longer be tolerated and considered relative. We have 775 reasons for it before us and for this year only. Thousands await a dignified send-off worthy of a man.
The international community admitted making a fatal mistake against the Srebrenica genocide victims trough recognition of the United Nations and trough declarations of certain democratic countries made individually: US Congress condemned the genocide, ethnic cleansing and aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina, the European Parliament declared July 11 the Day of remembering the Srebrenica genocide, and the Serbian Assembly condemned this crime and offered their apology to the victims’ families. So, nowhere in the world, except in Bosnia and Herzegovina, is this genocide denied.
Law proposal on Holocaust and genocide denial prohibition was blocked in the Bosnia and Herzegovina Parliamentary Assembly by those who deny genocide at the first place. It is clear that the current deniers of genocide will end as waste of the history of the world and of the Serbian people, just like Slobodan Milošević and Radovan Karadžić end up. However, it is tragic and confusing that some in the international community treat the deniers of horrible crimes in Bosnia and Herzegovina just as they had treated the perpetrators of those crimes. That must be changed, because, otherwise, all statements involving Srebrenica would seem empty. We expect the European Union to send a clear demand to the Bosnia and Herzegovina Parliamentary Assembly, i.e. adopting the proposed Law on Holocaust and genocide denial prohibition.
Proving genocide in the entire territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina is not a completed process. Radovan Karadžić’s trial is currently underway, who, according to his charges, had the genocidal intention to destroy BiH Muslims since October 1991. Srebrenica is a symbol of genocide against the Bosniaks in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but we do not forget the crimes committed by the Serbian forces wide across Bosnia and Herzegovina. A commemoration will be held in Omarska for the victims of the Serbian concentration camps from 1992. That event, like so many others, will not have such media coverage. That is why we, on the day of the Srebrenica genocide commemoration, also remember the victims from Prijedor, Ključ, Zvornik, Brčko, Sarajevo, Manjača, Foča, Bileća, Bijeljina and all those known and unknown who had fallen as victims of this fascistic project, regardless who they were.

title: Speech by H.E. Mr. Zeljko Komsic Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
It is an honor for me to greet you all here tonight. At the outset I would like to express our deep gratitude for your support for the candidacy of Bosnia and Herzegovina for non-permanent seat in UN Security Council 2010-2011 at the elections that will be held in two days in UN General Assembly. Allow me to underline the fact that my country gained support as the sole candidate from Eastern Europe, and I would like to use this opportunity to thank these countries for their trust. Your presence here tonight
Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen
It is an honor for me to greet you all here tonight. At the outset I would like to express our deep gratitude for your support for the candidacy of Bosnia and Herzegovina for non-permanent seat in UN Security Council 2010-2011 at the elections that will be held in two days in UN General Assembly. Allow me to underline the fact that my country gained support as the sole candidate from Eastern Europe, and I would like to use this opportunity to thank these countries for their trust. Your presence here tonight confirms that Bosnia and Herzegovina has numerous friends throughout the world. Today, these friends are helping us build a better and more equitable world.
Dear friends,
We are here in the United Nations, in the institution which represents the central point of the international cooperation. Bosnia and Herzegovina takes pride in the fact that, along with other former Yugoslavia successor countries, it can be considered as one of the founders of the United Nations.
My country shares concern about consequences caused by climate change, it being a global threat, and this surely demands active participation of all UN member states to the benefit of present and future generations. Planet Earth must remain a synonym for life.
We applaud disarmament programs, we actively support fight against terrorism, advocate strengthening of all mechanisms aimed at helping countries vigorously affected by the global economic crisis, and particularly support UN assistance missions in countries that are facing refugee and humanitarian crises.
It was in the United Nations that Bosnia and Herzegovina as a multinational, multicultural and multiconfessional country has affirmed its independence and found ways out from the worst historical situation and found solutions to its problems. Through active participation in UN peace - keeping missions we will use our experience in post-war recuperation, reconciliation and reconstruction of trust with the aim of preventing and solving conflicts. Above all it is our commitment but also a responsibility, as a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council.
Dear friends,
Thank you for your attention, support.
I wish you a pleasant evening.

title: Speech given by H.E. Mr. Željko Komšić, chairman of the BiH Presidency at the presentation of the First semi-annual report „Monitoring of the European Integration Process of Bosnia and Herzegovina” Bi
content:
It is a great honor to address you here today at the presentation of the First semi-annual report on Monitoring of the European integration process of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is highly commendable that the civil society is monitoring the work of BiH institutions throughout the stabilization and association process, especially if the findings are based on arguments and if they are possible to discuss during such event which gathered people from all walks of life.
Dear Excellencies,
Esteemed representatives
Representatives of institutions and civil society in BiH
Ladies and gentlemen,
It is a great honor to address you here today at the presentation of the First semi-annual report on Monitoring of the European integration process of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is highly commendable that the civil society is monitoring the work of BiH institutions throughout the stabilization and association process, especially if the findings are based on arguments and if they are possible to discuss during such event which gathered people from all walks of life.
It has been more than a year since the signing of Stabilization and Association Agreement and since the Interim Agreement entered into force. Following this major step forward Bosnia and Herzegovina confronted itself and its capacities in order to meet commitments it has assumed. However, not only the government of a country is integrated into the EU but rather the entire society. Therefore it is a positive fact that the non-governmental sector is ready to assume more active and constructive role.
I believe that there is no alternative to the European integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This country cannot remain outside this process if it wants to achieve social and economic development and better standard for its citizens. In order for Bosnia and Herzegovina to become a member of the European Union, it has to align its laws, regulations and its operational procedure with EU standards. The responsibility for alignment of regulations and standards lies not only with BiH institutions, but entities, cantons, Brčko District and municipal government as well. Therefore, it is highly important that competent institutions start doing their job in order to meet obligations from Stabilization and Association Agreement and create European atmosphere in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Unfortunately, there are many obstacles. They are evident in the sphere of political relations in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Namely, the leading political parties do not share a common view on methods, speed and priorities that in the future would make Bosnia and Herzegovina a candidate for membership and eventually member of the European Union. Mainly it is the issue of competence of entities and Bosnia and Herzegovina in matters relating to implementation of reform. Representatives from Republika Srpska believe that existing competence ought to remain at the entity level, even though many of those areas require a unique system of implementation that seeks for better communication and coordination of competent institutions. Furthermore, there is the issue of qualification of our administration as well as constitutional framework which is extremely complex and does not promote cooperation. And it is exactly cooperation and implementation of principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in process of arranging a functional system that are highly important for all those who wish to become a part of the European Union.
Thus this country needs young and educated people who will stay here and build it to be better than it is now, and those young people must be provided with proper work places. To this end we need both foreign investments and assets from the EU Funds. For this purpose Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to start to invest into science and development of new technologies. Bosnia and Herzegovina must engage itself in the area of balanced economic development of neglected regions. However, in a time of economic crisis we cannot achieve that on our own. The sooner we start arranging a system in our society and adopting EU standards, the closer we will be to the EU membership. We must not perceive the process of European integration as something we do for foreigners but rather as something we do for ourselves and the future of our children.
Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina must not suffer the consequences arising from the inactivity of administration and political disputes which result in delayed adoption of laws. Because of this I urged competent institutions to accelerate process of adoption of necessary laws and formation of institutions in order for Bosnia and Herzegovina to meet conditions for liberalization of the visa regime. In my opinion our citizens should be able to travel freely to EU countries and feel like free citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europe. Without free citizens there is no free or dynamic civil society which can be an influential partner to government institutions.
In the end I would like to thank the Foreign Policy Initiative and Sida who made it possible to discuss these issues, promote European values and openly talk about all problems we are facing on our common path. I believe that it will lead to better mutual understanding of all domestic and foreign actors involved in process of European integration.

title: The BiH Presidency Chairman Zeljko Komsic, who is leading the delegation of Bosnia and Herzegovina at XV Non-Aligned Movement Summit in Sharm-El-Sheikh in the Arab Republic of Egypt which gathers 116
content:
This is the first time that Bosnia and Herzegovina, as an independent state, attends this Summit at its highest level. As part of the non aligned Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, a country that was one of the co- founders of the Movement, we inherited the values of non-alignment, and we are proud of that. Although in recent history, Bosnia and Herzegovina was faced with the most daunting and fierce challenges, it has remained committed to the fundamental principles of the Non Aligned Movement, and
Mr. Chairman,
Your Majesties,
Excellencies,
Heads of State and Government,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
At the very outset, allow me to congratulate our host, the Arab Republic of Egypt, on its assumption of the Chairmanship of the Non Aligned Movement (NAM) as well as on the excellent organization of this important event and the great hospitality extended to all of us.
This is the first time that Bosnia and Herzegovina, as an independent state, attends this Summit at its highest level. As part of the non aligned Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, a country that was one of the co- founders of the Movement, we inherited the values of non-alignment, and we are proud of that. Although in recent history, Bosnia and Herzegovina was faced with the most daunting and fierce challenges, it has remained committed to the fundamental principles of the Non Aligned Movement, and has been actively implementing them in its political practices. My government decided to become a candidate for a non permanent member seat in the UN Security Council for the period 2010-2011 because we believe that Bosnia and Herzegovina as a symbol can significantly contribute to the efficient activities of the UN and reaffirmation of fundamental principles of the Non Aligned Movement. On behalf of my country I would like to take this opportunity to kindly ask for your support of our candidacy.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a small country, but it has a multiethnic, multicultural and multiconfessional character and a rich historic heritage.
