Therefore, it can understand various socio-political, cultural, and historical contexts and actively contribute and participate in resolving global problems. As part of the Non Aligned Movement, we consider that it is necessary now, more than ever, to include all capacities of our states in order to solve all issues, in the context of crisis areas and preservation of global and regional peace and stability. We ought to be united in fight against terrorism, in finding more efficient solutions for mounting global economic and financial crisis, relieving effects of climate change, preventing arms races, preventing brutal violation of human rights, bridging the gap between the rich and the poor and other challenges of the XXI century.
My country supports efforts by the Non Aligned Movement and the international community to ensure prerequisites and fulfillment of sustainable and Millennium development goals. It contributes to the reform of UN Organization, advocating the compromise acceptable to most member countries, emphasizing that strengthening of relations between the Security Council and the UN General Assembly will make the United Nations work more efficiently A special emphasis is put on better representation, efficiency and greater transparency at the Security Council.
Mr. Chairman,
Today, more than ever, it is important to conserve the nucleus of the modern world: endless wealth of multiculturalism and understanding between civilizations. In my country it is believed that the Non Aligned Movement has a special place in the preservation of this world. Bosnia and Herzegovina has always been a country of such habitus and that is the reason why we have always belonged to this family of nations. At the same time, we are following the path towards Euro Atlantic integration as a part of the globalization process of the modern world, but also in order to realize the values we share with the members of the Non Aligned Movement.
I would like to express my strong belief that friendly Egypt, one of the founders of the Non Aligned Movement, a country that enjoys great credibility on the international scene and that has been safely and wisely leading the Non Aligned Movement, will, in close cooperation with all of us, strongly reaffirm and modernize policies of the Movement for which safety, peace, human rights and economic development have no alternative. It is those values that Bosnia and Herzegovina will fight for in its capacity as a future non permanent member of the UN Security Council.
Thank you Mr. President
CABINET OF THE BIH PRESIDENCY CHAIRMAN ZELJKO KOMSIC

title: Address by the BiH Presidency member Dr. Haris Silajdzic on July 11, 2009 in Memorial Center Potocari, on the occasion of marking 14th anniversary of genocide against Bosniaks in ' UN- Safe Area' of S
content:
To our neighbours, notably Serbia, we send out the following message: we do want good neighbourly relations, but it will not be achieved fully until Serbia admits responsibility for the crimes committed by former Belgrade regime while Ratko Mladic is still at large and Serbia prosecutes our defenders.
Families of the genocide victims,
Citizens of Srebrenica,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Today we are burying 534 genocide victims, 44 of whom are underage children. Fourteen years on, some of those children would have been underage today.
We can never feel the depth of the pain that their families feel, but it is ours to share. Today’s gathering proves that Srebrenica will never be forgotten.
The International Criminal Tribunal brought an unprecedented verdict, but it was not given the attention it deserved. Those who discussed the verdict were criticized for ’dwelling in the past’. Unfortunately, this is our present. Trial of Radovan Karadzic is yet to come. Karadzic was indicted for genocide in 10 other BiH municipalities besides Srebrenica. Unfortunately, this constitutes part of our future as well.
The United Nations admitted the grave injustice they committed in case of Srebrenica. The Report adopted by the UN General Assembly reads as follows:
'Through error, misjudgment, and an inability to recognize the scope of the evil confronting us, we failed to do our part to save the people of Srebrenica from the Serb campaign of mass murder… Srebrenica crystallized a truth understood only too late by the United Nations and the world at large: that Bosnia was as much a moral cause as a military conflict. The tragedy of Srebrenica will haunt our history forever.”
Errors can be committed, but they must not be repeated. The injustice of such proportions can not be rectified by either neglecting the verdict by the International Court of Justice or by insisting on solutions which constantly accommodate the policy of maintaining the results of the genocide and ethnic cleansing. Such solutions will never be accepted.
U.S. President Obama also referred to the crimes in Bosnia and Herzegovina as ‘a stain on conscience of mankind’. The stain will remain unless we all engage in concrete, vital measures and solutions leading in the direction opposite from ideas of masterminds of those crimes. Their idea was to create ethnically clean territories and they mostly succeeded in their intentions because the return guaranteed by Dayton has never actually been achieved.
We cannot rectify injustice by measures and solutions which do not guarantee the minimum of human rights agreed in Dayton. Failure to implement the key Dayton elements is confirmed by hundreds of thousands of our citizens scattered around the world by force.
We are all obliged to make effort in order for our citizens to enjoy peace, stability and prosperity equally, and that is impossible without the minimum of justice.
To our neighbours, notably Serbia, we send out the following message: we do want good neighbourly relations, but it will not be achieved fully until Serbia admits responsibility for the crimes committed by former Belgrade regime while Ratko Mladic is still at large and Serbia prosecutes our defenders.
Confession is not a sign of weakness; it is rather a sign of strength and maturity. Truth and justice are not enemies of peace; they are foundations of peace and stability.
In this respect, we are encouraged by the Resolution of the European Parliament declaring July 11 the Day of Remembrance of Srebrenica genocide. The Resolution represents the embodiment of true European values and therefore it is welcome.
Nonetheless, mere words are not enough. It is time we took concrete steps and started applying values and standards in order to put behind the outcomes of this and other crimes. I am convinced that true European values in this country will fall on fertile ground. A lot of good in Bosnia and Herzegovina was suppressed by the evil that we confronted.
The fact that Croatia and Montenegro adopted the same Resolution proves how positive such a decision by European Parliament actually is. It would be crucial if Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia also adopted it.
Such a gesture pays respect to the victims and also brings back the hope of the common European future.

title: Speech by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina H.E. Nebojsa Radmanovic, 16th Summit of the Heads of State of Central Europe "Working Together to Overcome the 3E Challenges - Econom
content:
Today's gathering is being held in the light of three great challenges standing before our countries: one of them being the global financial and economic crisis with serious consequences for our economic development, the second one being the global problem of safe supply in all kinds of energy, and the third one, the challenges of the new enlargement of the European Union to the South-East of Europe, along with all dilemmas accompanying the process.
Dear Mr. Chairman,
Distinguished Presidents,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
At the beginning I would like to express my gratitude to the organizers and auspices of this important event, primarily our host, President Tadic, for a well-organized summit of the heads of state of the Central and the South-East Europe.
Today's gathering is being held in the light of three great challenges standing before our countries: one of them being the global financial and economic crisis with serious consequences for our economic development, the second one being the global problem of safe supply in all kinds of energy, and the third one, the challenges of the new enlargement of the European Union to the South-East of Europe, along with all dilemmas accompanying the process.
In the last few years Bosnia and Herzegovina has had a strong economic growth. Real growth of gross domestic product average, in the period 2003-2008, was 6% per year. Real economic growth is the result of implemented reforms and favorable external environment. The implemented reforms contributed to improving the business climate which led to the significant foreign capital inflows, mainly in the form of direct foreign investment. Tax reform was carried out successfully with introduction of the VAT system, which helped the recovery and consolidation of the public finances.
The global economic crisis strongly affects the economy of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Consequences of this crisis will lead to slower economic growth, loss of jobs and increase in the poverty rate. Relatively good results of exports growth, amounted to an average of about 20% in the last three years, were stopped in the last quarter of the last year and this year. The lower exports were caused mainly by the fall of prices and demand for key export products, aluminum, steel, wood, chemical and textile industry products. Reduced credit activity of commercial banks and decrease in the foreign direct investment inflow reduce the prospects for achieving the economic growth.
Bosnia and Herzegovina largely depends on foreign remittances being a relatively reliable source of external financing. It could be expected that the recession in the European Union and the United States, which the largest part of remittances come from, will reduce the capacity of the diaspora to make the transfer of funds to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Being aware of the possible consequences of the crisis, the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the governments of the Entities the Republic of Srpska and the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Central Bank have taken a series of measures directed towards maintaining the continuity of macroeconomic stability and supporting sustainable development as our medium term target.
As a support for maintaining the macroeconomic stability the agreement was reached with the International Monetary Fund to support our economic program through the Stand-by arrangements in the amount of 1.2 billion Euros for a three-year period of 2009-2012. The program aims to maintain continuity of the Currency Board arrangement, ensure fiscal sustainability and maintain the stability of the financial sector. Fiscal policy measures will be targeted to reduce expenditure from the approved budgets for 2009.
Small open economies like Bosnia and Herzegovina’s require greater involvement into the world market and finding the areas of their competitive advantages. Such an area is the energy sector. Our estimates are that the existing installed power of 4052 MW of hydro and thermal power plants could increase by more than three times, with the construction of new hydroelectric power plants, modernization of the existing ones and building new power plants. This is our great development chance, the implementation of which can ensure a long-term sustainable high growth rate, as well as the exports growth. We are the only country in the region that exports electricity. Bosnia and Herzegovina welcomes realization of the project "South Stream" for natural gas supply and other energy resources from Russia to the area of the South East and Western Europe. Therein our countries see their chance to build the necessary gas infrastructure and ensuring a safe natural gas supply for their own development needs. This is an opportunity to once again thank our host, President Tadic, for the assistance the Republic of Serbia has provided for the gas supply to Bosnia and Herzegovina, during the last gas crisis in Europe.
As it is known Bosnia and Herzegovina has, since the very beginning, been consistently determined for the regional cooperation as the only way of resolving all issues between the neighboring and geographically adjacent countries, which was confirmed in its attitude during the previous period. Bosnia and Herzegovina strives for harmonizing its activities in the field of regional cooperation with the general international, and primarily European, commitments and widely accepted standards.
The proof for this is the fact that Sarajevo is the headquarters of the Regional Cooperation Council which work Bosnia and Herzegovina strongly supports. In the previous year the Council did a lot for the regional cooperation of the countries and the special contribution was provided by Bosnia and Herzegovina as the host country of this regional initiative.
In the past years the regions of Central and South East Europe launched and solved many issues of mutual cooperation between the countries, ranging from the parliamentarian cooperation, political dialogue at the highest level, to the commencement of resolution of those still outstanding, unresolved questions.
We do not hide that there are a lot of open issues between our countries as well as the readiness and willingness to resolve them to the general satisfaction in the interest of all participating countries. That is the only way we can answer the challenges that stand before our countries.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is clearly determined for the European and Euro-Atlantic integration. This is the opportunity that Bosnia and Herzegovina will not miss, regardless of all the challenges, difficulties and disagreements on this way.
Last year Bosnia and Herzegovina signed the Stabilization and Association Agreement with the EU. The procedure for the SAA ratification by the EU member states is in the procedure. We expect that this process will be completed during next year.
We are convinced that all the goals and conditions set before us by the Peace Implementation Council for Bosnia and Herzegovina, could be fulfilled this year, which would lead to transformation of the Office of the High Representative into the Special Representative of the European Union. Therefore, any skepticism regarding our eventual future, existing both in Bosnia and Herzegovina and with the representatives of the international community, would be removed. That would be a clear sign that Bosnia and Herzegovina as a sovereign democratic state, without the Office of the High Representative, would be an equal competitor with other countries from our region in the process of the Euro-Atlantic integration. In this way, Bosnia and Herzegovina would acquire the requirements for submitting an application for a candidate status and improve its chances towards the full-pledged membership in the EU.
Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina hope that, upon fulfillment of the conditions from the "Road Map", in the second half of this year, there is liberalization of visa regime early next year, at the same time as in the other countries in our region.
There is no alternative to the enlargement of the European Union to the Western Balkans countries. Therefore, together we must knock stronger on the European door if we want to get inside. This is the way it will open for us, countries of the last not-integrated region in Europe. Otherwise, we would miss the opportunity that carries a number of challenges, as well as opportunities, to finally leave the past behind and step into the new European future together.
Thank you.

title: Speech by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina H.E. Nebojsa Radmanovic, Seventh Regional Forum on Cultural Corridors of South East Europe "Management of Heritage Diversity and its
content:
At the beginning I would like to express my gratitude to the organizers and auspices of this important forum, primarily our host, President Vujanovic, for a well-organized event and the opportunity to exchange our views on such important topics and the issues concerning the countries of our region.
Dear Mr. Chairman,
Distinguished Presidents,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
At the beginning I would like to express my gratitude to the organizers and auspices of this important forum, primarily our host, President Vujanovic, for a well-organized event and the opportunity to exchange our views on such important topics and the issues concerning the countries of our region.
I would also like to thank Mr. Koďchiro Matsuura, the Director-General of the UNESCO, and Mr. Terry Davis, the Secretary General of the Council of Europe, for cordial assistance they have been providing all these years since the forums are held of the South East European countries devoted to establishing and building the cultural corridors between our states.
This gathering of the representatives from the countries of South East Europe is a continuation of our previous forums related to the topics of richness of the cultural heritage and possibilities of cooperation in this area, as well as of the initiated conversations in the course of the last year, which was declared the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
South East Europe is an area of different cultures, national traditions, but also the common values of civilization. In addition to geographic proximity, our peoples and states are linked by the interweaving of different national cultures and traditions that build a unique cultural mosaic of Europe. Over sixty cultural monuments and natural properties of South East Europe are inscribed in the UNESCO World Heritage List, with more than a hundred sites on the national lists that are being prepared for a nomination, which speaks enough about the cultural diversity and richness of this region. In the past, on the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, there were mixtures of various ancient civilizations and cultures, which are still recognizable in the archaeological sites, written cultural resources, religious cultural monuments and the urban and historic values.
Historical researches confirmed that in the past there existed strong cultural relations of the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina with the European peoples and their countries. Many European and the world travel writers that were traveling in the last century throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina directed the attention of the European and world public to its cultural and historical heritage and natural beauty. What we failed to do - attract the world to our cultural wealth - has been made by the passengers and passers-by through Bosnia and Herzegovina, among whom there were prominent figures, ranging from writers, archeologists, ethnologists to diplomats. On the other hand, many famous scientists, artists, writers and cultural creators from Bosnia and Herzegovina, have worked in other European countries. In the past, students from Bosnia and Herzegovina were educated on the prestigious European universities thus spreading knowledge about our cultural and historical values and natural attraction. Thus our cultural and historical monuments, religious buildings, bridges, fortresses, but also traditional folk customs passed from travel writings into the tourist maps of Europe.
Bosnia and Herzegovina with its unique and rare cultural and historical monuments, has given a significant contribution to the cultural civilization heritage of Europe. Today, Bosnia and Herzegovina has two properties on the UNESCO's World Heritage List, the Old Bridge Area of the Old City of Mostar and the Mehmed Pasa Sokolovic Bridge in Visegrad. Ongoing are the activities regarding the nomination of the old city core of Jajce, and in the future, it is planned to nominate a few more cultural and historical monuments of the unique value. As an example of regional cooperation between the countries in the field of cultural heritage during this year it is expected the joint nomination of the medieval tombstones, by Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, Croatia and Montenegro.
Cultural and historical heritage is not only an expression of our identity, but also a powerful stimulus of economic development and tourist offer of our countries. Today the culture, understood in its broadest sense, is an important content of the tourist offer of many developed countries. Experts believe that in the process of globalization the future of tourism will be in the cultural offer because the people like what is authentic, original and different. This is the reason why many countries today are investing significant resources in culture and cultural heritage thus strengthen their overall tourist capacity and competitiveness in the world market. South Eastern Europe with its rich cultural and historical heritage has been recognized as an important tourist destination, which is evident from the tourist visits to the countries of the region.
Cultural tourism as a specific form of tourism, which includes the visit motivated by the interest for cultural and historic heritage, still does not take place it deserves in the tourist offer of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The reasons for this situation are in the war devastations of many cultural and historic buildings and sites, weak investments in their reconstruction, negative image of the entire region, and insufficient promotion of the wider regional and global scale.
In the general post-war reconstruction in Bosnia and Herzegovina, there was the restoration of damaged or destroyed buildings and cultural monuments. I would especially point out the Old Bridge in Mostar, to the reconstruction of which the UNESCO has given a great contribution, Mehmed Pasa Sokolovic Bridge in Visegrad, the Old City Core of Jajce, the Ferhad Pasa Mosque and the Kastel Fortress in Banja Luka, the Orthodox Monastery Zitomislic, the City Hall in Sarajevo, cultural and historical objects in Kraljeva Sutjeska, Pocitelj, Blagaj and numerous churches, mosques, monasteries, cathedrals and other cultural monuments of national and world importance.
I would also like to point out the three important archaeological sites from prehistoric, ancient and the Roman period in the place Donja Dolina near the town Gradiska, natural reserve Hutovo blato and Skelani.
I have to also mention the outstanding natural sites in Bosnia and Herzegovina, unique in the world. These are the wildlife reserve of Bardaca near the town of Srbac, which is enlisted on the World List of protected swamp areas, Perucica Forest, one of remaining primeval forests in Europe within the National Park Sutjeska, Blidinje Cultural Landscape and Vjetrenica Cave, the second cave in the world in terms of biodiversity.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
In the era of globalization, cultural identity and cultural diversity have become the values of key importance for every individual, ethnic and cultural community. On this basis, there is an interest in introducing other unknown cultures and civilizations.
This year, Bosnia and Herzegovina was the host of the World Rafting Championship, which was held in Banja Luka and Foca, on the rivers Vrbas and Tara, the largest sports events since the Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo in 1984. On that occasion, apart from the athletes, thousands of tourists and other businessmen and journalists from around the world visited Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Next year, Bosnia and Herzegovina will be the host of the European Fly Fishing Championship, also a very important sport, cultural and tourist event.
Culture and tourism may be one of the ways for a common change of a negative image that the countries of the Western Balkans still have, because of the recent war history. It is easier to change this negative image through a joint promotion of our cultural and historical heritage and tourist offer, rather than separately and individually, as it has been the case so far.
World economic crisis will be reflected on tourism as well as on reduced possibilities of making investments in culture. In such a situation, a common cooperation of the countries may reduce the negative consequences of the world economic crisis on cultural tourist offer.
Bosnia and Herzegovina through regional cooperation with countries that have a stronger tradition in tourism and the economy, can significantly improve its tourist and development performances. Unfortunately, Bosnia and Herzegovina still does not entirely use its cultural diversity and richness for tourist purposes. In addition to the significant monuments of culture and natural beauty, for increased visits of international tourists, it is necessary to change the previous bad habits, accept the new European standards and train tourism managers and tourism workers. Tourist image of Bosnia and Herzegovina will be improved by the construction of the highway Corridor VC which connects the countries of our region.
Our goal in Bosnia and Herzegovina is to, preserving its cultural and historical identity and the richness of diversities, be a part of the wider European cultural and economic space. This can be achieved through tourism and opening of our cultural and historical sights to guests and tourists from both Europe and the world.
Welcome to Bosnia and Herzegovina!
Thank you.

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Nebojsa Radmanovic at the 6th Annual South
content:
Dear Mr. Chairman,
Distinguished Presidents,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
At the beginning I would like to express my gratitude to the organizers and auspices of this important event, primarily our host, the President of the National Assembly of the Republic of Srpska, Mr. Igor Radojicic, for realizing the idea of gathering of the leaders from the region and the world.
Territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the wider Balkans and the Mediterranean region have an extraordinary importance for the contemporary cultural Europe. That importance is not only geopolitical that we are mostly speaking about, but primarily cultural and spiritual.
Cultural influences of three great religions are interwoven on this territory, and within them, each of the peoples developed their specific national culture. The level of development of those cultures is related to the economic prosperity of each society, and vice versa. Economic development is caused by the high cultural achievements.
The peoples of the Mediterranean Basin and their highly developed cultures have largely contributed to the development of human civilization. Unfortunately, many wars in the Balkans destroyed a lot of cultural and economic wealth, which is the reason for its being economically underdeveloped. This was also the reason why many social and cultural processes launched in this part of the world have never been completed.
Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Balkans represent diverse cultural variety, a little mosaic of traditions and cultural experiences, unlike any other region in Europe.
Trust, peace and understanding amongst the peoples who live in this territory require respecting their cultural diversity but also restoration of the previous cultural importance that this region represents for the entire region and Europe in whole. It should be emphasized that where there are diversities there are also problems and opposite tendencies. Living in diversity understands everyone’s responsibility for everybody else.
In the past of this territory there were trends which, in the worst possible way, denied the richness of diversity: through the wars, undemocratic regimes, selectiveness and intolerance of all kinds, but, at the same time, there was always maintained and preserved a strong willingness to respect the differences and foster them within the regional and the European context.
Modern civilization context puts before us political and cultural claim to be both different and same at the same time.
In the past influences on this territory came from the developed countries towards the less developed ones. Today, thanks to globalization, the Western Balkans region has the opportunity to emit important cultural influences within a wider cultural space of Europe and the world. It is not only the sum of different national cultures but the quality of higher order and value. This stems from the fact that the contemporary cultural and political identities are not static and unchangeable categories, but open creations exposed to different influences due to intercultural cooperation and communication.
Together with this openness in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the wider region there are still a strong efforts to deny our diversity, which are reflected in the attempts to unify the language, nationalize history, invent the tradition, force cultural homogenization, etc. There are two extremes in those efforts: on one side, an uncritical highlighting, at any price, of the differences amongst similar peoples who live in a relatively small territory of the Western Balkans, and, on the other hand, the denial of any differences that do exist in the real life. Because of all this, our choice is between the two options: to be entrenched in our tradition and prejudice or to be open to new influences in the united Europe as a wider context of our future common home.
Regardless of the obvious differences which represent the wealth of the region, nations and countries in Europe, call upon the same values today. Someone once said, if we opened the people we would find landscapes within.
Europe is a continent of culture, national traditions, but also common values of civilization. Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country with the three peoples, different cultures and religions. Bosnia and Herzegovina and its overall national cultural landscape naturally correspond into what Europe wants to become in the future.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Right to diversity is the basic foundation of modern society democracy. This entitlement includes cultural pluralism as an authentic expression of existence of different cultures in equal, tolerant and open relationship.
In the area of South East Europe, and especially the Western Balkans, there are nations with very similar cultures. Try as they may to look different from each other, the peoples of South-Eastern Europe look similar to those who glimpse at them from outside. Free existence of different original cultures, having inherited many common values of civilization, is the imperative of our time. We should not either hide, or overemphasize our differences. Sometimes there are more similarities than differences. The image we show to the world depends on us. Whether we will build our relations on disagreements about the myths of the past or a dialogue about the future hopes, entirely depend on us.
In the end, survival of our difference is not in contradiction with the necessary unity on our European way into the united Europe, whose active participants we want to be.
Thank you.

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina H.E. Nebojsa Radmanovic, Energy Summit "Natural Gas for Europe: Security and Partnership", Sofia, 24
content:
It is my exceptional pleasure to greet all the participants of this Summit. Let me thank the President Parvanov for convening and organizing this Summit.
Dear Mr. Chairman,
Distinguished Presidents,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my exceptional pleasure to greet all the participants of this Summit. Let me thank the President Parvanov for convening and organizing this Summit.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Global political and economic changes at the end of the last and the beginning of this century encouraged the creation of a more interconnected energy market. These changes are caused by the need of ensuring competition, increasing efficiency and security in the energy supply, which represents a precondition for the economic growth and development. Our common need is to establish a stable regulatory and market framework capable of attracting investors in the energy sector, in order to ensure stability of energy supply, which is of crucial importance for our economic development and social stability. Bosnia and Herzegovina is fully committed to implement all the accepted obligations, because it sees the opportunity for a faster economic development and approaching towards the European Union.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has great development opportunities in the electrical energy sector. Estimates are that the existing installed power of 4052 MW of hydroelectric and thermo-electric power plants could be increased more than three times, with the construction of new hydroelectric power plants, by the modernization of the existing ones as well as in building new thermo-electric power plants. This development opportunity has been confirmed in the recent European Economic Community conference on investment in the production of renewable energy sources, held in Sarajevo. We are encouraged by the fact that the investors, such as the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, in this occasion, expressed their willingness to invest in power sector projects in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the South East Europe region. Current production of electricity, not only meets the domestic needs, but a part of electrical energy surplus is exported, which is not a common feature of this region.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Development trends of the energy sector are increasingly turning to the environment friendly sources, of which the natural gas has a significant role. Europe will, not only now, but also in the future, be more and more dependent on natural gas as an important energy source. Being a part of the European family, we will also have the need for increased consumption of natural gas, increased import, as well as the need for new projects that will provide new directions and sources in the natural gas supply. The recent gas crisis requires us to plan on a wider regional level to resolve the issue of a long-term stability and security in natural gas supply. To meet that goal the construction of the new gas routes and new facilities for the gas storages would be available to all interested countries, either directly or via neighboring countries on the basis of full openness, good-neighborly relations and solidarity. Therefore, we support initiatives for the implementation of all new gas corridors and projects, including Nabucco, Adriatic-Ionian and Southern Corridor and their interconnection, which will contribute to a more stable and secure natural gas supply to our countries. We express our willingness to participate in the realization of the common infrastructure gas projects.
There is no domestic production of natural gas in Bosnia and Herzegovina and it completely depends on import. Pipeline system of Bosnia and Herzegovina is linked with pipeline system of Serbia which is a transit supply route for the imported gas from Russia. The pipeline, in the total length of only 191 km, connects a small part of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, through the direction of Zvornik-Kladanj-Sarajevo-Zenica, and is used for heating needs of the households, as well as the fuel in the two larger industrial customers, Alumina Factory "Birac" from Zvornik and Steel Factory
"Mittal Steel" from Zenica.
In the regional and especially the European framework, Bosnia and Herzegovina is currently a small the natural gas consumer. In the total consumption of energy, natural gas participates with about 6%. The current gas infrastructure is developed only in one part of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, thus the access to this important fuel is only available to a limited number of users. Natural gas supply from one source and one direction does not provide security in the consumers’ supply.
Countries of South East Europe are situated on the directions of several planned large gas corridors for distributing gas to this region. It is often the case that the countries which use the gas are the very impediment to construction of the gas corridors due to their being divided and monopolized. Therefore, we must create a common approach to this issue which can result in a direct short-term and long-term economic and the development benefits for all of us.
In this way, the issue of secure natural gas supply of the regions of South East Europe would improve the overall regional cooperation of our countries, which, both individually and jointly, qualifies us as reliable and credible partners on our way of accession towards the European Union.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Increase of the natural gas participation in meeting the energy needs, represents our strategic goal and interest. To achieve this goal, it is necessary to build transport and distribution gas infrastructure throughout the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and ensure the supply from several directions, by connecting the gas system to the systems of neighboring countries, which would ensure security and stability in the natural gas supply. We believe that, in the future, natural gas will have an important role in energy supply, among others, due to the additional and more favorable environmental characteristics in comparison to other fossil fuels. Apart from that, we are aware that in the near future we will have to harmonize the current lower prices of electricity in the internal market with higher prices in the neighboring countries and the countries of the European Union. This way the natural gas, being a cheaper fuel, will become a necessary substitute for electricity in the heating system in the cities, as well as fuel in the industrial plants wherever justified and practically possible.
With ratification of the Energy Charter Treaty on establishing the Energy Community of the South East Europe, Bosnia and Herzegovina assumed the obligation to implement the directions of the European Union into domestic legislation which regulates the natural gas. Establishment of the regulatory framework, despite the occasional delays and disputes, means progressing in the right direction in order to create a transparent and competitive market, which will provide secure gas supply and favorable environment for new investments.
The need to strengthen mutual connections and solidarity in the regional and European gas network proved necessary during the last gas crisis caused by the inter-state disputes about the transport, payments and natural gas prices. Then it was expressed a better linking and solidarity between the European countries and countries of the region. I avail myself of this opportunity to thank the government and the state leadership of the Republic of Serbia and the Republic of Hungary, which have expressed their full solidarity with the citizens of Sarajevo, Zenica and Zvornik, with intervening deliveries of natural gas during this January. This was a significant moral and political gesture, welcomed by the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the international community. That confirmed our readiness for solidarity, joint resolution of problems and development of mutual cooperation, for the benefit of the citizens of our countries and the entire region.
Thank you.

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency member Zeljko Komsic on the occasion of opening ceremony of the manifestation ‘Mostar Spring 2009
content:
We have been celebrating this extraordinary, renowned and praiseworthy cultural manifestation, Days of Matrix Croatica- Mostar Spring, for eleven years now. In the time of economic and political crisis, this manifestation best conveys appreciation of diversity and preservation of identity of one of the constituent peoples in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Dear friends of Matrix Croatica,
Ladies and gentlemen,
Dear guests, president of the Republic of Montenegro Mr Filip Vujanovic, dear friends!
We have been celebrating this extraordinary, renowned and praiseworthy cultural manifestation, Days of Matrix Croatica- Mostar Spring, for eleven years now.
In the time of economic and political crisis, this manifestation best conveys appreciation of diversity and preservation of identity of one of the constituent peoples in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
International dimension of this year’s Mostar Spring encourages cooperation with our neighbours in the region, which is our obligation, as well as the necessity on the path to full membership in the European Union.
I am convinced that this manifestation will be a source of pride to citizens of Mostar and BiH citizens and return Mostar with good news to the center of cultural events in BiH, because the language of art and culture is the best means for building of trust and understanding in this society of ours, in spite of scars from the recent past.
This is an opportunity to show once again our unequivocal fondness for beauty and art, respect for our homeland, our peoples and customs, but also for all the other peoples and countries in the region.
Ladies and gentlemen, we must direct our attention and strivings towards the things we have in common, and those are richness of diversity of cultures and customs and our unique goal- full membership in the community of European peoples, where we have our place and role. Culture and art are part of obligations which we must bring along with pride and share with others in other to be better understood.
With the best wishes which I send to all those who contributed to organizing this manifestation, on my own behalf, as the sponsor of the manifestation, and on behalf of the BiH Presidency, I would like to pronounce Mostar Spring 2009 open.
Thank you!

title: Address by the chairman of the BiH Presidency Mr Nebojsa Radmanovic at the international conference “Where Peace Begins: Pivotal Role of Education for Lasting Peace”
content:
It is an honor that exactly Bosnia and Herzegovina is hosting the International Conference that deals with the important role of education for lasting peace, because we believe that with our experience we can also promote the process. What kind of education can promote peace and how do we make sure that children receive quality education that will help them build peace?
Dear Mr. Chairman,
Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen,
Allow me to extend a welcome to all participants and guests who are attending this international conference. I wish you a pleasant evening and a successful conference.
Especially I would like to thank the government of the Kingdom of Norway that provided support for this conference as well as international organization Save the Children. Without their help the results we achieved in promotion of education of young people would not be as great as they are today.
It is an honor that exactly Bosnia and Herzegovina is hosting the International Conference that deals with the important role of education for lasting peace, because we believe that with our experience we can also promote the process. What kind of education can promote peace and how do we make sure that children receive quality education that will help them build peace?
These were the questions asked by organization Save the Children in March 2008, when it launched a global debate in order to invite Nobel Peace Prize Laureates, educationalists and representatives of governments to contribute to a greater understanding of the links between education and peace.
In September 2008 Bosnia and Herzegovina was one of the six countries that requested the President of the United Nations General Assembly to launch a debate on an issue that was of a great importance for the prompt response to exceptional circumstances and reconstruction process: the issue of approach to education in exceptional circumstances, post-conflict and transition situations caused by human conflicts or natural disasters.
I have to remind you that the right to education is defined by the General Convention on Human Rights adopted in 1948. Convention on the Rights of the Children obliges all States Parties to ensure that all children have access to education free from discrimination on any grounds. This Convention defines the right to a free and compulsory primary education. States are encouraged to develop secondary education and other forms of education and make them accessible and available to all. States Parties shall promote international cooperation in the area of education.
However, the real situation in many parts of the world and especially in conflict or natural disaster affected areas indicates that we are falling behind in our determination to achieve the second millennium development goal calling upon the member states to establish a universal primary education by 2015.
Approximately 75 million children still do not go to school and more than a half of them live in conflict-affected areas. Girls comprise more than a half of these groups whereas many children live in areas affected by natural disasters.
In addition to implementing all internationally adopted regulations and standards it is necessary to work more on social cohesion of people living in conflict-affected areas. United Nations need to refocus and divert attention as well as implement and secure the fundamental right to education. Organizing a thematic debate at the session of the General Assembly on probably the biggest obstacle to exercising this right – the access to education in exceptional circumstances, post-conflict and transition situation resulting from human conflicts and natural disasters - would be a timely and necessary step. The debate would provide a better overview of future activities, better coordination between participants and a dialogue on numerous topics such as finding children who do not go to school due to abovementioned circumstances. By ensuring the right to education in exceptional circumstances the international community could send an important message about the future.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Education is a key factor in development of society. Two years ago the world marked hundredth anniversary of education sociology. It was hundred years ago that this scientific discipline was formally included in education as a special subject. The importance of education can be seen in the fact that it is one of the priorities of united Europe. Education strongly encourages people to become members of community as well as broader European culture. Being an essential part of culture and an existential need, education has become an important precondition for competitiveness of contemporary economy. For the last few years Bosnia and Herzegovina has put enormous effort into education reform based on the model The Europe of Knowledge. Only an educated citizen can actively participate in social life, exercise democracy and contribute to economic and cultural development and progress of the community. The statement by a well known statesman who said:
“Being a European is not a matter of birth, but education”
proves the point.
Our wish is that the UN and the countries in the world acknowledge the importance of education and make use of debates on education in such conferences for promotion of this area of social life. I hope that today’s conference will send out significant recommendations and expert advice which can serve all countries to promote peace through education.
It is only in this way that results of education become lasting heritage to be passed on the future generations.

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency Chairman Nebojsa Radmanovic at the regional conference’2009
content:
Today’s conference proves that there is a highly expressed awareness about importance and necessity of BiH accession to Euro Atlantic structures among all walks of life in BiH, from representatives of state and entity authorities and local communities, to entrepreneurs, NGO, civil society, media, religious communities and citizens.
Dear Chairman
Your Excellencies
Ladies and gentlemen
Allow me, at the beginning, to express my gratitude to organizers of this regional conference, first of all European Movement in BiH, and other organizers and participants of today’s meeting. I am grateful to have opportunity to express my view on the current and long-term possibilities of accession of BiH and the Western Balkans countries to Euro Atlantic integration.
Today’s conference proves that there is a highly expressed awareness about importance and necessity of BiH accession to Euro Atlantic structures among all walks of life in BiH, from representatives of state and entity authorities and local communities, to entrepreneurs, NGO, civil society, media, religious communities and citizens.
The fact that there is European Movement in BiH promoting the idea and values of united Europe contributes to raising awareness about EU integration. Other associations and citizen organizations are also important, because they work everyday in order to bring BiH closer to EU, putting the idea into practice. It was for that reason that I decided to sponsor such an important conference and other activities that European Movement in BiH is planning to undertake during the year 2009.
I am convinced that EU had justifiable reasons to announce 2009 as ‘the Year of the Balkans’. Apart from common symbolic, there is more to it than meets the eye: there is deliberate intention to steer the Western Balkans countries in the direction of EU during this and following years. This year is, to a certain extent, crucial for BiH and other Western Balkans countries to shed the heavy load of long-standing isolation from European processes and take decisive steps towards European integration path.
These circumstances call for a short review of the position of the Balkans as compared to Europe, in the past and now, which can be useful in understanding of our ambitions in the future.
The relation between Europe and the Balkans was defined in the past between the two extremes: systematic negligence and violent interventions in the internal relations in the Balkans. Both approaches proved to be wrong in the long term. In practice, as regards political life, such approach was more detrimental than useful to peoples and countries of the Balkans.
The history of the region of the Western Balkans is fraught with wrong and reckless interventions by great forces and lack of understanding of objective political processes in this part of the world, which entailed wrong solutions which failed to bring stability, democracy and economic progress. The Balkans, as geopolitical region, has been unfairly and wrongly perceived in a negative way, as a region prone to permanent and insoluble conflicts and crises. The stereotype lingered for quite some time, and it is still dominant in the mindset of an average European. It was the reason for systematic negligence and isolation of the region from the rest of the Europe, which brought about enormous damage to the process of prompt integration of the region in political, economic and cultural life of Europe. The complexity and importance of the Balkans as a strategic region connecting West and Central Europe with the Mediterranean and Near East was disregarded.
Viewed from today’s perspective, we can say that responsibility for such a state in the Balkans rests first of all with political elite of their countries, but also with great forces and international community. The current political situation in BiH and other Balkan countries is part of broader political context of outstanding issues which originate from the area of the so-called ‘East Issue’, annexing of BiH by Austria-Hungary, Balkan wars, World War I, creation of Yugoslavia and finally, its disintegration during the last decade of the twentieth century. In the last 150 years, the region of Balkans saw world war, Balkan wars and several local wars. The region of BiH and the Balkans was the scene of conflict and collapse of great empires, and all these conflicts affected the political situation in those countries.
Following majority of wars led from 1991 to 2001, the region of Western Balkans enjoys a peaceful period, which is obviously the most important thing. War conflicts resulted in a high death toll, a vast number of wounded and refugees, and almost complete destruction of economy. With intervention by international community, several peace agreements were made in the Western Balkans- which definitely brought an end to war, establishing peace and stability in the region.
I would like to highlight at this point the importance of peace agreements made after the ending of conflict in this region. Some of them, like Dayton/Paris peace agreement for BiH, not only ended hostilities, but they also defined political solution.
Dayton Peace Agreement from 1995 was a highlight of the political and diplomatic invention of peacemakers and home politicians, and it is one of the greatest success stories of peacemaking in the history.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Europe has confirmed clearly that its strategic interest was integration of the region of the Western Balkans in European political, economic and security structures. The Western Balkans countries, on their part, clearly voiced their firm commitment to Euro Atlantic structures.
There is a high percentage of citizens and political parties in BiH that opt for EU accession. Wide acknowledgement of BiH as a country which belongs to Europe in all terms: historical, geographic, political, and cultural- contributes to the high percentage, regardless of the fact that it is not formally an EU member. Last year, BiH signed SAA, which is the first contractual relation between BiH and EU in the process of EU integration.
It is an important and incentive step for the country on its path to full EU membership. Also, in the same year, the relation between BiH and NATO Alliance was raised to the level of intensive dialogue, which is a step forward towards full membership. In that respect, we cannot be dissatisfied with the results achieved at the level of Euro Atlantic integration of the country. However, in the last months the country faced a temporary standstill regarding this issue. Political differences between BiH parties contributed to the standstill.
Long-term strategic stabilization of the Western Balkans will start with final solutions to the outstanding issues which are stumbling block between certain countries in the region. These issues include: questionable independence of Kosovo and Metohija, adjudication of FYROM, dispute between Slovenia and Croatia over the mainland border, efforts to undermine Dayton Peace Accords, which is the cornerstone of stability of BiH as democratic, decentralized and complex state with two entities and three equal peoples.
In the last few years, the Western Balkans has experienced ‘the shock of Europesation’, the process which strikes one as a fever which spreads through society and changes our previous habits and relations completely. It is more than obvious today, and experience of other countries proves it, that EU integration process is an all-encompassing, comprehensive venture and effort of the whole society, not only an exclusive responsibility of state institutions. When a country becomes EU member, it is not its government, or part of society that becomes the member, it is the country as a whole, as a result of joint effort to achieve the set goal,. On that path, apart from state institutions, legislative and executive authorities, everyone is in invited and welcome, from companies that make effort to reach European standards and results, to civil society which strives to embed the spirit of European integration into its daily performance and communication with citizens.
There are shared responsibilities, on this path, including our society, and also between BiH and EU as institutional and political framework that the country is attempting to join. Our responsibility is to fulfill all the conditions and aims we obliged to do, and EU’s responsibility is to accept the results and provide necessary support for further progress in that process.
Today, the Western Balkans is between marginalization and integration. Promises made at numerous EU summits regarding European perspective of the region must not be failed, because it would push the Western Balkans in a bigger depression and isolation. Hesitation of Europe in that respect already breeds skepticism towards Europe in BiH and other Western Balkans countries. Quite contrary, integration processes of the Western Balkans in EU must be intensified and accompanied by concrete financial and political measures which would put in motion a fast economic development of the region.
Dispute between Slovenia and Croatia over the outstanding issues of sea border, which led to a standstill in accession negotiations of Croatia in EU integration process illustrate what these issues can bring about, when they are fuelled by important and long lasting differences. Such a situation results in ‘domino effect’ which can in the future spread on other Western Balkans countries, which could lead to new obstacles in the EU integration process.
The Western Balkans still has negative connotations to its name with the international public. Such a negative image can be successfully toned down, if every country worked separately. It is only done by joint effort and cooperation of all the countries of the region and by involving all the political, economic and human resources at hand. EU must fortify its engagement in intensifying regional cooperation between the Western Balkans countries in all walks of life, in order to resolve the outstanding issues that encumber their relations nowadays.
Economic and cultural cooperation between the states can be an important element of integration and stabilization of the Western Balkan countries within states and Europe as well. It is about existing bonds, but cultural, linguistic and other similarities between peoples can build a bridge of cooperation, which can enrich Europe considerably.
Which direction is it appropriate to take in order to explore possibilities for prompt accession of BiH and Western Balkans countries to Euro Atlantic integration?
When it comes to BiH, it is, first of all, closure and transformation of OHR as an institution inappropriate for the new phase of integration processes. Under current conditions, the Protectorate Country is attempting to access the association of its protector, which is unprecedented in international relations. It is high time that BiH and EU established a normal accession relation based on trust and fulfillment of obligations. Transformation of OHR into the Office of EU Special Representative would be a definitive step towards EU, which has no turning point. It would be a clear message to home authorities to take responsibility and offer and search for solutions to their own problems in the spirit of EU accession obligations.
BiH must have equal status with other countries of the Western Balkans region in terms of its opportunities to join EU integration processes. With OHR in BiH, it is impossible. At this point, it means two things: gaining EU membership candidacy for all Western Balkans countries simultaneously, and establishing visa- free regime of all countries with EU. All the region of the Western Balkans with other five (countries without visa-free regime) countries has less population than Romania. Many parameters of social, political and economic state in the Western Balkans countries are similar to those that have recently been accepted to EU. Hence, the process must not be stalled and brought into question by ambiguous rhetoric and inexplicit messages from Brussels. Recent statement by EU Enlargement Commissioner about abolition of visas for the Western Balkans countries by the end of the year is an encouraging act by Brussels administration.
Ladies and gentlemen,
The history of the Western Balkans was characterized by frequent changes of geopolitical structure. Common characteristic of regional security dynamics is temporary character of structures, which failed to consolidate as a stable, permanent state. For the first time, the Western Balkans has an opportunity to become a stable, safe connection between the center of Europe and its Southern periphery. For such a venture, we need the help of Europe. We must develop integral approach of EU accession, and focus strongly on the final aim of the integration, which is fulfillment of conditions for full EU membership. On that path, we must leave behind petty, partial and other issues which can present an obstacle to the main, final goal. Our long-standing internal disputes and common accession and other issues can be solved in integration process of united Europe which will make room for the Western Balkans countries.
I am aware that it is not popular to give unreal promises. I am also aware that by painting reality black, hard as it might be, is not fair to citizens. Elected politicians are there to give hope, retrieve optimism and show the way forward, and that is why we must work harder and believe that we will finally achieve what we are all committed to, democratically.
Maybe on this path we could use some advice:
'Will the Balkans open its sleepy eyes, see its enormous cultural capacity, if it swings as a whole?' , wrote a famous novelist more than 50 years ago.
We that live and work in the Western Balkans countries know that it is possible. It takes more work, committment and responsibility and final aim will not go amiss.
Thank you
Sarajevo, March 10, 2009

title: The speech by the BiH Presidency member, H.E. Zeljko Komsic, on the occasion of celebrating BiH Independence Day
content:
Let me express my gratitude that you joined our celebration of the landmark in the recent history of BiH, its Independence Day. It is a day marked with gold letters in the thousand-year-old history of BiH, because on March 1, 1992 we held a referendum on independence of BiH.
Your Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, dear guests and friends...
Let me express my gratitude that you joined our celebration of the landmark in the recent history of BiH, its Independence Day. It is a day marked with gold letters in the thousand-year-old history of BiH, because on March 1, 1992 we held a referendum on independence of BiH.
It was on that thay that a vast majority of BiH citizens started implementing their democratic decision. Also, on that very day, a historic path of hell began for BiH, as a sovereign independence state, accompanied by the most difficult war circumstances.
We only had our indomitable will and courage of those who loved their homeland as weapons against the enemies of BiH and the enemies of people of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We had nothing more, but it was quite enough! We had nothing on our side at that time! There were plenty of enemies. The true friends of our country were few. The truth is, we had too many false friends!
We, people of Bosnia and Herzegovina, believed in our country then, we believed we were doing something quie normal and expected. When they jeopardize and attack your family, friends, home, freedom, homeland, what else can one do but fight for it all.
That is why this might be an opportunity to send a message to all those who think BiH and its people are tired, exhausted, at odds, divided, and that it is the right time for political implementation of war goals.
This is opportunity to tell them, do not even think about it! Back in 1992 you also thought you could tear this country apart in few days.
There is no policy, circumstance or force that could allow you to do that. BiH can only dissapear if its people give it up! And it will never happen! Every inch of this land, every piece of this ground, belongs to Bosnia and Herzegovina, regardless of its name, and its every part has belonged, belongs and will belong to every person in Bosnia and Herzegovina, regardless, also, of their name!
Dear friends...
It is high time we understood reality and started building the future on that grounds. No one here has another homeland. All of us, either far away, or here, are foreigners to them. We are merely from Bosnia or Herzegovina to them. We remain a single state, we can not single out an inch of this blood drenched country, and we owe apsolutely nothing to anyone.
We are part of former Yugoslavia, part of the Balkans, but also part of Europe and we will act that way, but we will also harmonize our way of life, work and obeyance of European standards in all walks of life from the smallest, most common human ways to educational, cultural, religious scientific, technological, economic ways.
However, we, people of Bosnia and Herzegovina will also have to reconcile each other! Because, it is only natural in this country, it is the only way in this country! Respect each other, listen to each other, try to understand each other! Otherwise, pardon my French, it will all ‘ go to hell’!
Because in this country, no one owns either the country , or any part of it!
It is our common country, it belongs to all of us!
We have to apply self-criticism and realize that we have over 700 000 unemployed people, low birth rate, that 9 out of 10 young people want to leave our country. Disabled people are forced to pull down the doors of BiH Parliament in order to reason with authorities! Only someone naive, a liar or malicious person can think or say that everything is all right in our country. Of course it is not so, but we have to work hard to change that!
It will take a lot of hard, honest, thorough work! We must be ready for that! We are up for it, sooner or later. Certainly better now than later!
With more willingness, less fear, less vanity, more reconciliation with each other, which is our destiny, we are looking at unimaginable horizons of prosperity and progress of our country.
Dear people of Bosnia and Herzegovina, this is our homeland, our Bosnia and Herzegovina, and such as it is, it is only ours, we respect it and we are loyal to it!
May its seventh anniversary of independence, as well as all the forthcoming independence anniversaries be better and merrier.
Thank you!
Sarajevo, February 27, 2009

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency member H.E. Dr Haris Silajdzic on the occasion of celebrating BiH Independence Day
content:
Throughout our history, we had to defend our independence, and this generation also had to do it. Thus I feel it is the right time to say that we owe a debt of gratitude to all those who defended this country, and those who gave their lives during the last aggression on Bosnia and Herzegovina or fought for its freedom.
My colleague in BiH Presidency, Mr Zeljko Komsic has already said most of the things I wanted to say. Let me greet you, dear Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, and express my gratitude that you joined us in celebrating this important day for us, BiH Independence Day.
Throughout our history, we had to defend our independence, and this generation also had to do it. Thus I feel it is the right time to say that we owe a debt of gratitude to all those who defended this country, and those who gave their lives during the last aggression on Bosnia and Herzegovina or fought for its freedom.
We express our gratitude to those who made effort, and who will continue to do so, those in internatonal community helping us build a democratic, rather than ethnocratic country. A democratic country of equal citizens on every inch of this territory. In order to solve all the tasks, political and economic, which are difficult, this country must function properly, and it is not the case at the moment. I hope that we will all together fulfill that task, for people who brought us here, myself and my colleague Mr Komsic and Chairman Radmanovic, who is absent, those we are here for expect us to do it.
To conclude, I must say that today I had opportunity to spend some time with Association 'Children- pillars of the world'. They call themselves like that, and that is what they are. I would like to greet them, they are here with us now. Among the messages they conveyed, they singled out this one: 'We want to become a member of the European Union, we braced ourselves for that '. Let us all make their wish come true.
Thank you

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency member Zeljko Komsic on the occasion of return of members of VIII rotation of the Unit for destroying lethal unexploded weapons (NUS unit) of BiH Armed Forces and I rotati
content:
Let me greet you on behalf of the BiH Presidency and my own behalf, give you my heartfelt welcome and wish you a happy return to Bosnia and Herzegovina. I would like to express my gratitude and appreciation for successfuly completed tasks you were given within the peacekeeping mission in Iraq.
'Dear gentlemen soldiers, non-commissioned officers, officers and generals...
Dear ladies and gentlemen, members of the BiH Armed forces, dear guests...
Let me greet you on behalf of the BiH Presidency and my own behalf, give you my heartfelt welcome and wish you a happy return to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I would like to express my gratitude and appreciation for successfuly completed tasks you were given within the peacekeeping mission in Iraq.
We are here, today, all happy, proud, and satisfied with your engagement.
We are happy because all our members of the BiH Armed Forces returned safe and sound, from a dangerous mission in Iraq, to the loved ones, those who awaited their return with suspense and fear.
We are proud that you completed all your military tasks within your mission, your role resembling the one of BiH ambassadors, at the highest professional level, with highest grades. We are satisfied that your quality showed the world that we are a serious, responsible country, and that there is no task you are not capable of fulfilling, even in extreme conditions. Representing our country with dignity and fulfilling complex, risky tasks in peacekeeping missions around the world is something we all must take pride in, because quite often it is forgotten that your engagement contributes to the reputation of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Bosnia and Herzegovina will in the future participate in international peacekeeping missions in various regions of the world. It is a responsibility of the Ministry of Defense and BiH Armed Forces as a whole, especially its command department, to prepare for the participation in these missions with a quality training and continuing work with people at all levels.
Regardless of the current global economic crisis, representatives of authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina must understand that these Armed Forces deserve all the necessary support and improvement of the conditions of life and work in every respect.
I will personally see to it that all the budget allocations for BiH Armed Forces are raised to the necessary level, a level in accordance with NATO requirements, because Bosnia and Herzegovina’ s path to full membership in NATO Alliance must not be stalled in any way.
Finally, I would like to wish you all a lot of happiness and satisfaction in the days to come, congratulating you all forthcoming holidays.
Once again, welcome and thank you all.

title: Speech by BiH Presidency Chairman Nebojsa Radmanovic at the ceremony celebrating December 1, Day of BiH Armed Forces
content:
It is a special pleasure to address you on the third anniversary of establishment of Day of BiH Armed Forces in the name of BiH Presidency, as civil command of BiH Armed Forces. Marking December 1, Day of BiH Armed Forces is our joint recollection of contribution of many people, who put a lot of energy, effort, knowledge and expertise in the process of establishment of BiH Armed Forces.
Your Excellency,
Dear generals, officers, non-commissioned officers, soldiers,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is a special pleasure to address you on the third anniversary of establishment of Day of BiH Armed Forces in the name of BiH Presidency, as civil command of BiH Armed Forces.
Marking December 1, Day of BiH Armed Forces is our joint recollection of contribution of many people, who put a lot of energy, effort, knowledge and expertise in the process of establishment of BiH Armed Forces.
Today, when we celebrate for the third time Day of BiH Armed Forces, we should remember all the hardships and obstacles we had to overcome on our way, in order to arrive at joint organization of BiH Armed Forces, and pay respect to all those who take credit that we succeeded in that mission.
Three years might be too short a period to comprehend the significance and importance of this achievement. The time ahead will show how important reform step forming of Armed Forces was for BiH, its peace stability, trust and equality of the three constituent peoples.
Why did we succeed in achieving planned reforms in the area of defense and security sector and efficiently established BiH Armed Forces?
It is due to our patient, committed, step-by- step work that we achieved reforms. We built mutual trust, respecting equality of all three constituent peoples, as a guiding principle underlying our relations. We also succeeded owing to the fact that we consulted opinion and proposals based on expertize and science from this area and had advisory help from international community.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina we have a broad consensus for accession to EU and NATO, which is a respectable political attitude, bearing in mind that we have different opinion on many issues in the country. BiH has seen many reforms and changes in various areas of political, economic and social life in general. However, reform of Armed Forces is an example of a successful reform in a post-conflict society which gives us the right to believe that it will continue in the future, with the same or stronger dynamics. This reform is example for other areas as well, if we wish to succeed in conducting necessary reforms and changes on our path to EU integration. As we are talking about a very complex, gradual and balanced process of reforms, it takes vision, determination and patience of all the actors for the reforms to succeed.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Celebrating December 1, we must not forget that once independent components and now united BiH Armed Forces have given a great contribution to the implementation of Dayton Peace Agreement, development of trust and cooperation between conflicted parties and building of lasting and sustainable peace in the BiH region.
Within the framework of general activities of bringing BiH closer to EU and other Euro Atlantic integration, this year, an ‘Intensive dialogue’ with NATO alliance has been established, making another major step towards final membership in this organization.
After accession to NATO program ‘Partnership for Peace’, it is a new ladder of progress of our Armed Forces, which will entail new responsibilities in the future, and reaching other standards, as requested by NATO Alliance.
BiH Armed Forces, within its possibilities give necessary contribution to collective safety in the world through engagement in joint activities of securing peace in crisis-affected areas.
Several days ago, the BiH Presidency adopted ‘Defense policy’, a document which, together with Safety policy and General principles and priority for conduction of foreign policy of BiH represent a long-term, general strategic and conceptual framework of political activities of the country.
Also, the BiH Presidency, at its last session, named three liaison officers in the mission of BiH with NATO in Brussels, which will make our communication with Euro Atlantic safety structures more efficient and quality.
Finally, I would like to congratulate you on the Day of BiH Armed Forces, wishing you a lot of success in the future work.
Thanks

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency member Zeljko Komsic on the occasion of November 25, National Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Celebrating this national holiday, when 65 years ago in Mrkonjic Grad, in Europe besieged by fascism, in the middle of seized territory, a landmark occurred in the history of our country, let us recall this important historic date, as a foundation stone, upon which modern, democratic BiH rests.
Councilors of ZAVNOBIH, dear comrades, ladies and gentlemen, Your Excellencies, dear friends, respected officials…
On today’s day, exactly 65 yaers ago, at the first session of ZAVNOBIH held in Mrkonjic Grad, 173 councilors from Bosnia and Herzegovina took part in the session.
Out of 173 afore mentioned councilors, 8 are still alive. Unfortunately, for health reasons following councilors are not attending this ceremony: Boro Popovic, Ibro Sator, Rade Hamovic and Enver Redzic. However, we have the honour to host other councilors, including: Krstan Bijeljac, Oskar Danon, Ljubo Babic and Mile Perkovic. I would kindly ask you to greet them.
I extend my sincere greetings to you all and congratulate you the National Day.
Celebrating this national holiday, when 65 years ago in Mrkonjic Grad, in Europe besieged by fascism, in the middle of seized territory, a landmark occurred in the history of our country, let us recall this important historic date, as a foundation stone, upon which modern, democratic BiH rests.
I will not repeat this time the legendary ‘3 and’ or ‘nor 3’ from the ZAVNOBIH session, but I will remind you that it was the session of the Council of BiH antifascist from all the BiH peoples. It is true that antifascist movement was led by communists, but the fact is that most antifascist and patriots were not members of Communist party of Yugoslavia.
I would like to point out that we are talking about the event which not only confirms the continuity of the BiH statehood, in the only right way. And that is- every citizen of BiH is equal in his rights and way of life, regardless of the part of BiH he lives in, and regardless of the fact whether or not he belongs to ‘majority or minority’ in that part of our homeland. Or, to put it simplier-Bosnia and Herzegovina, every part of it, even the smallest one, belongs to every BiH citizen.
In its history which is thousands of years old, its peoples have demonstrated, although they suffered and lived through numerous blows dealt by various enemies and policies, that peace, tolerance, and co-existence become something of a genetic code, to put it that way.
I would like to send out the message to our friends from international community, to those, who, as opposed to us from Bosnia and Herzegovina, all this might not strike them as something close and familiar.
I am aware of the fact that, those who do not wish well to our country, tell stories to you who are not from here, trying to convince you of something, present you with the so-called historical facts, that almost ‘the natural condition’ of this country is conflict, lack of tolerance, and the only way to peace and stability is division, separation, ethnic disintegration, to the stories that BiH should be wiped off the face of political world map.
However, if that is the way things are, don’t you think that this country would have disintegrated before, and that history would have waited for its present enemies to complete the task?
Bosnia and Herzegovina has neither disintegrated nor separated before the forces of that time, including Ottoman Empire, Austro-Hungarian Empire, Hitler’s Germany, Mussolini’s Italy, Ustasas’ NDH, cetnik military movement, before neighbouring fascists at the end of the XX century. Those were forces too strong for such a small country, but small BiH still exists. I think that all things said lead to a irrefutable conclusion!
Conflicts and wars in BiH have always been bloody and fierce, but according to historical parameters, they lasted shortly, and most importantly, they were always imported, started beyond the boundaries of BiH.
