Dear friends…
There is no doubt that ZAVNOBIH is a foundation stone of modern BiH statehood, but also that it is a model which points to the way we cannot only live together, but equitably and happily, something that no country can live without.
If we live in the same country, if we are the citizens of the same country, than the minimum of civilized behaviour, historical recollection and civic culture implies to celebrate today’s date as the common national holiday of all its citizens and peoples.
As for the appropriate mode of celebrating the National Day, that is, the reason for not celebrating it in certain parts of BiH, I would like to repeat the following:
The date of signing the Dayton Peace Agreement I consider as an important date in the recent history of BiH, which should be celebrated in a dignified manner, but 25th November, the date of celebration of ZAVNOBIH, and reaching decisions, I personally find of utmost importance, as a crucial landmark, and the sole National Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is the task of this generation to path the way towards the common future, and that is free, democratic and prosperous Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Our only future is BiH as the unity of equal and egalitarian peoples, a society composed of equal and egalitarian citizens where there would not be those with fewer or no rights, and those with more rights.
Finally, what we must remember on today’s path to Europe is that we must learn from Europe, take advice, learn from its experience, of course, not haphazardly, and never fail to remember that we can and must do for ourselves mostly by our own forces.
With the wish to remain adamant in building and strengthening of our country, as a country of well-being, security, and common well-being, I would like once again to extend my sincere congratulations on the occasion of the National Day!
Thank you!

title: Speech by Dr Haris Silajdzic, BiH Presidency member on the occasion of the BiH National Day
content:
It is a great honor to bid you welcome to the reception on the occasion of the BiH National Day. Our country is celebrating today the 65th anniversary of the first session of ZAVNOBIH, held in Mrkonjic Grad, where the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina was confirmed.
Ladies and Gentlemen, respected Excellencies, dear friends,
It is a great honor to bid you welcome to the reception on the occasion of the BiH National Day. Our country is celebrating today the 65th anniversary of the first session of ZAVNOBIH, held in Mrkonjic Grad, where the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina was confirmed.
During the first 65 years, Bosnia and Herzegovina has come a long way of defense and affirmation of its statehood. Those who made a stand against fascism remained loyal to Bosnia and Herzegovina, confirming its viability as a state. The next generation continued this struggle, especially during the aggression (1992-1995)
First of all, I would like to express my appreciation and gratitude to those who contributed to this struggle, especially those who sacrificed their lives. Today we remember them with great admiration. It is thanks to them, now we have a privilege to live in our own country, whose sovereignty, independence, and territorial integrity are beyond doubt. Thanks to them Bosnia and Herzegovina is a full member of the international community of states. Thanks to them we are here today. It is them that we owe the obligation to continue building a sense of statehood, especially through affirmation of rights and interests of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
We must always bear in mind that state exists to ensure its citizens economic security and economic development, and create conditions for a better standard of living. One of the challenges ahead is to adequately and timely respond to negative effects of global economic crisis, which is already being felt by BiH citizens.
At the session of BiH Presidency tomorrow, we will consider possible measures that BiH institutions should take in order to protect the citizens from the effects of that crisis. I would like to call all the political actors in the country to leave disputes aside and focus on preparation and realization of those measures, with joint forces, without any delay.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Some people might be afraid for the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Nowadays, some people doubt that this country is capable of responding to challenges ahead. Due to these doubts and fears, some think that survival of this state might be ensured by weakening rather than affirmation of its statehood attributes. There have been many attempts in the history of BiH to bring its survival in question, even by means of arms. However, one thing is certain. All those attempts were futile, but only because defenders of BiH remained committed to their principles they affirmed in Mrkonjic Grad. Not only do those principles represent the brightest point in our history, they are also the key link of the future. Not a single inch of this country has ever been Serbian, Croat or Bosniak, it belonged to all the BiH peoples. So it used to be. It will be so in the future, because what brings us together is much stronger than what tears us apart.

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency Chairman H.E. Nebojša Radmanović at the Regional Economic Forum South
content:
It is my pleasure to greet you and to thank the organizer for inviting me to participate in this Forum. It is of a crucial importance for our European future and regional cooperation to exchange our views and experiences and encourage cooperation in all areas of importance to our peoples as well as mutually good relations trough these or similar gatherings.
Esteemed Presiding,
Distinguished Presidents,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my pleasure to greet you and to thank the organizer for inviting me to participate in this Forum. It is of a crucial importance for our European future and regional cooperation to exchange our views and experiences and encourage cooperation in all areas of importance to our peoples as well as mutually good relations trough these or similar gatherings.
Bosnia and Herzegovina achieved considerable recovery and economic prosperity in the past 13 years. Strong investment activity, financed by donations of the international community, has contributed to the high post-war GDP real growth rate. What encourages us is the fact that economic growth was also continued after the foreign help was reduced. In the period 2002 – 2007, the average economic growth was 5.2 % annually, which puts Bosnia and Herzegovina at the equal status with other states of the former Yugoslavia. In spite of this, Bosnia and Herzegovina is lagging behind its neighbors, concerning GDP per capita. The reasons for that greatly lie in the past war events, which left marks on its economy and population.
Bosnia and Herzegovina was successful in achieving macroeconomic stability. Domestic currency – Convertible Mark is stable, with the constant growth of foreign exchange reserves. The fiscal budget balance has been established, thanks to the successful tax reforms, and especially the introduction of value added tax. Fiscal discipline has been intensified due to establishment of the treasury business transactions and the public sector audit office. Bosnia and Herzegovina managed to establish a competitive banking sector with strong supervisory bodies.
Long lasting unemployment rate and high foreign trade deficit represent the main hindrance to the economic growth and development of Bosnia and Herzegovina. That is due to the low rankings in competitiveness of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s economy. We are aware that the competitive economy cannot be accomplished only by creating the stable macroeconomic environment. It is necessary to build the efficient institutions, mastering the contemporary technologies, developing corporative management, investing into research and development, together with the appropriate level of economic freedom and entrepreneur capacities. Building competitive economy represents a difficult, lasting and complex process that requires constant and persistent work, which is confirmed by experiences of developed countries. We must use all our creative energy in fostering competitive economy for our better future and the well-being for the generations to come.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is significantly lagging behind in building necessary infrastructure for joining the European integration and global market. Therefore, we are not surprised by the huge efforts put in by the European Union in investing infrastructure in order to ensure relatively equal conditions for development of all regions. The road infrastructure of Bosnia and Herzegovina has become an impediment for a greater scope of foreign trade cooperation with the neighborhood and the world. That is why our Entities’ governments put in efforts to fix the situation in that field using concessions and our own resources. I would like to use this opportunity to express our readiness to build major regional road routes, trough joint ventures that would contribute to the faster development of the entire region.
Looking towards the future, the key challenge for Bosnia and Herzegovina and its economic development is in utilization of the electric power potentials through building new power generating plants, in order to resolve the growing needs in power supply in the country, and increase the export scope within the regional market. Entities’ governments have been undertaking the numerous initiatives and steps on attracting and engaging foreign capital for modernization the existing ones, as well as in building new capacities. The encouraging fact is that there is a great interest of foreign investors for investing in the power sector. That also represents a challenge for the countries of our region to start building electric power capacities, through joint ventures. Bosnia and Herzegovina is open for that way of cooperation.
Ladies and gentlemen,
We are about to face the years of high uncertainty, caused by the world financial crisis. It is sure that the economic crisis will not avoid this region. There is no doubt that the international financial crisis will indirectly influence the countries of the whole region and reduce the prospects for continuation of high economic growth rates from the previous years. In regard with Bosnia and Herzegovina, it could be expected that the economic crisis will reflect to several key segments. First, banking credits will be more expensive which will reduce the scope of investments and liquidity in the economy, the scope of total demand for goods and services, and slow down the economic growth. Second, there is a justified fear of lowering direct foreign investments flow. Third, recession, which will probably take Europe and the Region, being our most important foreign trade partners, will have a detrimental effect on export, which is our crucial need. Fourth, it could be expected that the value of our diaspora remittances lowers, particularly due to the recession which may cause loosing the jobs for part of this population. Fifth, further privatization of the state capital in the companies will be slowed down, since this is not a very favorable time for their sale.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has the advantage of having the foreign debt, both public and private, relatively small, compared to the countries in the broader Region. Level of the bank credits is also moderate, and the credits are quite well secured. These are significant advantages for mitigation of the economic crisis consequences.
Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Entities’ respective governments and the Central bank have undertaken necessary measures for preservation of financial stability. However, the future time will certainly require undertaking numerous new measures. Before all, more attention and efforts should be put in the issues which contribute to improvement of competitive abilities of the economy, in order to increase export. It is necessary, as much as possible, to direct a part of public expenditures into production purposes, in order to mitigate negative effects of investment reduction. Economic crisis imposes the need for protection of socially vulnerable categories of the population which are the most sensitive to its consequences. In simple terms, it is necessary to realize a more productive production, lower spending, higher saving, and export more while importing less.
Global crisis should be resolved jointly with other players, to the extent possible, at the same time not neglecting our own interests. In times like these, great economic powers primarily preserve their own interests. In our reality, we must not allow ourselves to be a collateral damage of the world financial crisis.
Global financial crisis requires global responses. The time has shown that it is impossible to manage the 21st century economics with the 20th century instruments. Many rules of playing in the world financial market must be changed, in order to have the global financial system preserved from any imprudent moves.
Thank you!

title: Address of BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić on the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe
content:
It is an honor to address the autumn session of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. Allow me to express my sadness at the passing of Lord Russell Johnston, who was your peer for twenty-three years and who ably presided over this Assembly between 1999 and 2002. Lord Russell Johnston worked tirelessly on human rights issues until the very end, and our thanks and sympathies go to his loved ones.
Mr. President,
Mr. Secretary-General,
Distinguished Delegates,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is an honor to address the autumn session of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. Allow me to express my sadness at the passing of Lord Russell Johnston, who was your peer for twenty-three years and who ably presided over this Assembly between 1999 and 2002. Lord Russell Johnston worked tirelessly on human rights issues until the very end, and our thanks and sympathies go to his loved ones.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Bosnia and Herzegovina highly values the work of the Council of Europe and its bodies and institutions. We have often been direct beneficiaries of this work, and have as a result of it made improvements with respect to the rule of law, human rights, and democracy. For this, I convey to you the gratitude of the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We are mindful, however, that we continue to face a number of obstacles We have a long way to go before Bosnia and Herzegovina is able to live up to the principles that constitute the very foundation of this body.
Even the progress that Bosnia and Herzegovina has made often falls prey to the discriminatory arrangements that are built into our system of governance. While Bosnia and Herzegovina was among the first five countries to ratify Protocol 12 to the European Convention, it is the only country in Europe, and the world, whose Constitution, bars some of its citizens from seeking office solely on the basis of their ethnicity.
To be sure, the Dayton Peace Agreement ended the war, aggression and genocide. Its value in such a context cannot be denied. But Dayton was also intended to reduce discrimination and reverse the effects of genocide and ethnic cleansing. On paper, it had all the necessary elements to do so.
Indeed, Annex 7 of Dayton guarantees that all refugees and displaced persons shall have a right to “return in safety, without risk of harassment, intimidation, persecution, or discrimination, particularly on account of their ethnic origin…” In practice, and in the words of the Bosnia and Herzegovina Constitutional Court, we have been witnessing:
“a systemic, continuing and deliberate practice of the public authorities of Republika Srpska with the goal of preventing the so-called ‘minority’ returns, either through direct participation in violent incidents or through the abdication of responsibility to protect the people from…violent attacks due solely to their ethnic background.”
Ladies and Gentlemen,
This matter, clearly, is not solely our concern. On the contrary, we are hearing statements this week, in these halls, that the right to return in another European context is not an important right, as demonstrated by the fact that it was never implemented in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Do these statements suggest that Republika Srpska has succeeded in creating an international precedent? Does one get to keep the ethnically clean slate created by butchering and expelling those who are different?
If that is allowed in Bosnia and Herzegovina, it will serve as a dangerous precedent and will seriously undermine this institution’s other objectives in my country. Dayton was clearly not designed with a la carte implementation in mind, as one of its components cannot function without the full functioning of the others. Obstruction of some of Dayton’s elements was born precisely out of a desire to stifle democracy and preserve ethnocracy.
One effect of this obstruction is that entity voting has morphed into an ethno-territorial mechanism, whereby only 22 percent of deputies in the State Parliament, all of them Serbs, and all of them from Republika Srpska, can block any decision they desire. Indeed, precisely because 1.2 million have not returned, there are only two non-Serb deputies from the RS, far from enough to unblock obstruction. Conversely, since a vote from RS is worth double a Federation vote under entity voting, this is a one sided mechanism.
And what has this entity voting been used for? Just in the last two years, it was employed five times to block changes to the Citizenship Law that would permit dual citizenship. Unless these changes, modeled on the European practice, are passed, over half-a-million Bosnian refugees, who fled the country not of their own volition but under the threat of death, stand to lose their native, Bosnia and Herzegovina citizenship.
This, Ladies and Gentlemen, is genocide and ethnic cleansing by other means. The plan calls for eliminating on paper those who could not be eliminated in person. The weapon of choice is entity voting. And this weapon is still there despite the clear language in this Assembly’s resolution 1513 that mandates that entity voting itself be “eliminate[d].”
It is not the implementation of Dayton, but the violation of its core principles, that led to the ethnic apartheid we see today in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
We are about to start work on a new Constitution, and allowing this practice to continue will not make that process a successful one. Instead, we will see secretive and pressurized negotiations, resulting in a flawed document. I know because I was there two years ago when the April package of amendments, that the Venice Commission heavily criticized, was offered instead of a meaningful constitutional reform. You know as well, because you were here at that time, adopting a Report that unequivocally stated that it was the “this [entity] voting system, the insistence on it and its political implications, which is to blame for the failure of the constitutional initiative, not a handful of individual representatives who voted against the [April package].”
It is for these reasons that I ask you to clearly identify the culprits and hold them accountable. Indeed, if Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot end school segregation because Dayton gives it no competencies to do so, where should the finger be pointed? Likewise, if only 22 percent entity-voting deputies block the law on the census, refusing the EUROSTAT-recommended disaggregated data, should the 78 percent majority who voted for the census be equally blamed? Finally, if we do not create a Supreme Court, as you and the Venice Commission tell us we should, is the blocked majority to blame?
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Please clearly tell us what the European standards are, and I, for my part, pledge that I will entirely accept those standards. I am certain that I speak for a clear majority of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina here. There are those who say that they would choose an ethnocracy and its institutions over Europe, but should such views be relevant in today’s Europe?
In fact, is today’s Europe substantively different from Europe 60 years ago? Are we now only declaratively in favor of the rule of law, human rights, and democracy, but secretly still harbor respect for brute force? Do we condemn genocide through a verdict of the International Court of Justice but do nothing to eliminate its results? I hope that we are not such a Europe. I hope that we are a Europe in which ICJ judgments are implemented and not left in the archives of that Court. I hope that we are a Europe that realizes that, in the long run, values will always win against short-sighted pragmatic interests.
I could quote the ICJ Judgment to remind you what values are at stake, but, instead, I will quote my good friend Lord Russell-Johnston, whose account of the Srebrenica genocide is almost identical to that of the Court seven years later: “almost ten thousand…husbands, fathers, and sons, some only ten or eleven years old, even babies,… were killed in a five-day-long spree of homicidal madness, committed by the Bosnian Serb troops under the command of Ratko Mladic, an indicted war criminal, who is still at large.”
While we applaud the recent arrest of Radovan Karadzic, the fact remains that some of the institutions that the ICJ Judgment explicitly identified as perpetrators of genocide are still in existence. We also applaud the revision of the indictment against Karadzic, which now includes two counts of genocide, across Bosnia and Herzegovina, and against both Bosniaks and Croats. Finally, considering that the ICJ Judgment is the first and only judgment under the Genocide Convention in history, I hope that this Assembly will consider its implications.
Dear Friends,
We have not forgotten the help we received from many of you, and for that we thank you once again. However, without a comprehensive reform of the Dayton Constitution, little progress will be made, threatening peace and stability in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region. I hope that the monitoring process will continue, and that we can also count on the continued help of the Venice Commission in this regard. Rule of law is important as it regulates an otherwise chaotic world, and we need such regulation more than ever. There must be a notion that justice exists, and people must be able to believe in it.
Finally, I hope that we can count on you to identify those who are committed to Europe of the twenty-first century versus those whose thinking is still dominated by the sixteenth-century ideas of ethnic fiefdoms. Ironically, Bosnia and Herzegovina was for centuries a genuine multi-ethnic society whose unique fiber was almost destroyed through mass slaughter, rapes, torture, abuse, expulsion and plunder at the end of the last century. Helping us reverse the effects of those crimes and to build a modern constitutional state that is true to its multiethnic character will make both Bosnia and Europe a better place.

title: Speech by Chair person of Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina dr Haris Silajdžić on 63th General Assembly of the United Nations
content:
It is an honor to address the sixty-third session of the General Assembly of the United Nations. Allow me to express my gratitude to Mr. Srgjan Kerim who ably presided over this body during the preceding year, and to congratulate Father Miguel d’Escoto Brockman, the new President of the General Assembly.
Mr. President,
Mr. Secretary-General,
Distinguished Delegates,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is an honor to address the sixty-third session of the General Assembly of the United Nations. Allow me to express my gratitude to Mr. Srgjan Kerim who ably presided over this body during the preceding year, and to congratulate Father Miguel d’Escoto Brockman, the new President of the General Assembly.
The first time I stood at this podium was in May 1992, as the Foreign Minister of a newly-independent Bosnia and Herzegovina. At that time, I recounted the unspeakable atrocities that were unfolding in my country. I also warned that, if not stopped, such atrocities would only get worse. In fact, I merely asked that Bosnia and Herzegovina be afforded the right to defend itself, the right guaranteed by the UN Charter.
We know what has happened since. Some in the international community insisted on maintaining the arms embargo imposed by the UN Security Council in 1991, thus adding to the obviously overwhelming military advantage of Milosevic’s regime that was bent on destroying Bosnia and its people. They justified this course by claiming that the lifting of the embargo would add oil to the fire. The result, inevitably, was quelling that fire with the blood of the innocent.
According to the ICRC data, 200,000 people were killed, 12,000 of them children, up to 50,000 women were raped, and 2.2 million were forced to flee their homes. This was a veritable genocide and sociocide. The intent of the perpetrators of this genocide was to forever destroy the unique multi-ethnic fabric of Bosnia and Herzegovina through mass slaughter, rapes, torture, abuse, expulsion and plunder. Despite of this, defenders of our country conducted themselves honorably, as demonstrated by the ICTY acquittals of most of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s military leadership.
All this culminated in Srebrenica in July, 1995. The International Court of Justice, in its Judgment of February 26, 2007, ruled that
“[T]he Bosnian Serbs devised and implemented a plan to execute as many as possible of the military aged Bosnian Muslim men present in the enclave…, that the acts committed at Srebrenica…were committed with the specific intent to destroy in part the group of the Muslims of Bosnia and Herzegovina as such; and accordingly that these were acts of genocide, committed by members of the [Army of Republika Srpska] in and around Srebrenica from about 13 July 1995.”
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Through its acts and omissions, the United Nations, by its own admission, bears a part of responsibility for the crimes committed at Srebrenica. In fact, the UN Secretary-General’s Report on Srebrenica from 2000 unequivocally states:
“Through error, misjudgment and an inability to recognize the scope of the evil confronting us, we failed to do our part to help save the people of Srebrenica from the Serb campaign of mass murder…Srebrenica crystallized a truth understood only too late by the United Nations and the world at large: that Bosnia was as much a moral cause as a military conflict. The tragedy of Srebrenica will haunt our history forever.”
We do not want the United Nations to be haunted. This organization’s credibility is too important to the world to carry the burden of this failure. Errors can be committed, but errors must not be repeated. We want the UN to right the wrongs. In fact, international law mandates that this must be done. Namely, the International Law Commission’s Articles on State Responsibility, adopted in this Assembly’s Resolution 56/83 of 12 December 2001, mandate that: “no State shall recognize as lawful a situation created by a serious breach of a [peremptory norm of general international law],” which clearly includes the crime of genocide and the crimes against humanity, “nor render aid or assistance in maintaining that situation.”
If these principles had been applied, would the institutions identified by the ICJ as perpetrators of genocide still exist? Would vast portions of a country remain ethnically clean? Would over 1 million of refugees and displaced persons remain outside their homes? In short, do these principles allow for the arrest of Karadzic and the simultaneous preservation of the results of his project?
We cannot bring back the dead, but we can give dignity and justice to the survivors. What we say today is not aimed at the past, but at the future, and not only for Bosnia and Herzegovina. We owe it not only to the victims and survivors, but to the humanity as a whole. The message to the would-be perpetrators of crimes in the name of a twisted ideology should be crystal clear: do not even think about it, your terror will not pay off.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, we had the opportunity to make that true by a consistent implementation of the 1995 Dayton Peace Agreement, which ended the aggression, stopped the genocide, and brought peace. These were its major accomplishments, and their value cannot be overemphasized.
Dayton, however, was also intended to reverse the effects of genocide and ethnic cleansing. It had all the necessary elements to do so. Instead, in the words of the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina, its main provisions have been a victim of: “a systemic, continuing and deliberate practice of the public authorities of Republika Srpska with the goal of preventing the so-called ‘minority’ returns, either through direct participation in violent incidents or through the abdication of responsibility to protect the people from…violent attacks due solely to their ethnic background.”
Dayton never intended such ethnic apartheid to take root in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is not the implementation of Dayton, but the violation of its core principles, that led to this result. It would be a grave mistake to recognize this result as lawful and legitimate.
It is the responsibility of this organization to make it right. Just as we should not have been forced to smuggle arms to defend ourselves, we should not be forced to smuggle basic human rights, justice and democracy into Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Without righting this wrong can we genuinely celebrate the 60th anniversary of the adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights this December. Moreover, can we celebrate the 60th anniversary of the adoption of the Genocide Convention if the first and only judgment of the International Court of Justice on the crime of genocide remains in the archives of that Court?
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Now is the time to right these wrongs. We are about to start work on the new Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the outcome of that process will answer many of these questions.
To those who now seek to legitimize the systemic violations of the Dayton Agreement, we all must say: make no mistake, genocide will not be rewarded.
Rewarding genocide could send a dangerous message throughout the world, and would surely undermine the chances for permanent peace and stability in both Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region. Seekers of justice are not the enemies of peace. They are the guardians of peace.
Certainly, there are those in Bosnia and Herzegovina who would not agree with this, but they are surely not the victims of genocide.
Dear Friends,
We have not forgotten the help we received from many of the countries represented here today. A number of your soldiers, diplomats, aid workers and journalists died in Bosnia and Herzegovina while working to end the aggression, bring peace, ease the suffering, or to make sure the rest of the world knew about it. For that we thank them once again, and renew our sympathies to their families. An even greater number of countries have assisted us in rebuilding our society after the aggression, and we extend our heartfelt gratitude for that as well. Bosnia and Herzegovina still needs your help in this regard, and we hope that we can work together in order to ensure permanent peace and stability in my country.
Photo Gallery

title: Address of BiH Presidency Chairman dr Haris Silajdžić on occasion of the 13th anniversary of genocide in Srebrenica
content:
Today, Bosnia and Herzegovina and the entire world lag behind in paying respects to the genocide victims and to rise above the evil and the transgressions committed in these areas, while the rest of Europe was living in peace. Although this site and scene constantly disturb us, steps forward are encouraging enabling us to send off those who were killed not for what they had done, but only for what they were.
Families of the genocide victims,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Citizens of Srebrenica,
Today, Bosnia and Herzegovina and the entire world lag behind in paying respects to the genocide victims and to rise above the evil and the transgressions committed in these areas, while the rest of Europe was living in peace.
Although this site and scene constantly disturb us, steps forward are encouraging enabling us to send off those who were killed not for what they had done, but only for what they were.
Over the last year, this cemetery has been transformed from the Foundation into the Memorial Center under auspices and protection of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. OHR and particularly the Governments of USA and Great Britain, as well as the International Institute for Missing Persons have helped us in that largely.
I also want to thank the US Government for appointing the Special Representative for Srebrenica and initiating changes of the Election Law that ensured voting in Srebrenica for all living genocide victims regardless of where they might be. The good thing is that registration of voters is going on well and significant steps forward have been made in this field. I hope that all people from Srebrenica would use the opportunity to decide on their destiny at these elections, aiming to rebuild a progressive and multiethnic community in this field.
We also owe gratitude to the Governments of Pakistan, Turkey and the United Arab Emirates for achieving sustainable return and to all those who in any way contribute to recovery and life of people in these areas.
Bosnia and Herzegovina also owes gratitude to all nongovernmental organizations that unselfishly work on seeking justice for the families of the genocide victims. Many members of these organizations, from various parts of the world, are here today with us, including numerous members of the Peace March.
However, a special place is reserved for the Srebrenica Mothers, who have been fighting tirelessly for justice for thirteen years, and many of them are still searching for their dearest ones. Such associations represent a driving force and a moral compass for all the efforts and actions that I have mentioned.
What I want to underline is that all those who are here today and all those working on the issue of Srebrenica, contribute to the development of culture of remembrance, which is of extreme importance for the generations to come. Because, remembering and teaching prevents repetition.
Dear friends, many of us still find it inexplicable that the genocide in Srebrenica happened while Srebrenica was under protection of the United Nations. In his Report on Srebrenica, the United Nations recognized their fatal mistake, stating the following:
“Trough mistakes, bad decisions and an impossibility of comprehending the evil that stood against us, we failed to fulfill our duty and help to save the people of Srebrenica from the Serbian campaign of mass murder. No one regrets more the missed chances for peace and justice than we do. No one condemns more the failure of the international community to take decisive actions to stop the pain and the war that took so many victims than we do.”
However, if mistakes were made and chances for justice were missed during the summer 1995, the question remains why mistakes and oversights are still being made, especially in relation to the implementation of the Verdict of the International Court of Justice. The recent decision of UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon to refuse the request of two BiH Presidency Members for implementation of the Verdict is also in discord with this recognition, because the third BiH Presidency Member did not sign the request.
For long, we have witnessed the minimization of what had happened here. Somehow, many people simply could not or would not articulate the word genocide. Now, when we have the Verdict of the highest international judicial instance stating that genocide was committed here, the first and the only verdict of that kind in history, we are witnessing attempts to minimize or even ignore the Verdict.
At a forum of importance for Bosnia and Herzegovina that I had attended, a representative of a European country unpleasantly surprised me with his comment by saying that the Verdict existed, but should remain in the Court’s Archives. It might have been a hasty statement, but it reflects the tendency of some that the Verdict should be treated as stillborn. Such an approach encourages the destructive forces and its consequences are visible today in Bosnia and Herzegovina and in the attitude of others towards Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Everyone should read the Verdict before giving such statements because the Verdict, inter alia, stipulates:
“After occupying Srebrenica in July 1995, the Bosnian Serbs made and implemented a plan to kill as many adult Bosnian Muslim males who were present in the Enclave as possible. The Court decided that the actions were committed in Srebrenica with a specific intention to partly destroy a group of the Bosnian Muslims as such, and the genocide actions were committed by the Republic of Srpska Army. The function of the Republic of Sprska Army officers, including General Mladić, was to act on behalf of the Government of the Bosnian Serbs, especially of the Republic of Srpska; they performed elements of public authority of the Republic of Srpska.”
The experts studying the phenomenon of genocide agree that the possibility of genocide repetition is greater if the consequences of the committed genocide have not been adequately treated in the way defined by the international law regulations. Therefore, the Verdict must not remain in the Court’s Archives, but must be adequately implemented. The Verdict is not only of concern to Bosnia and Herzegovina, but to the entire world.
Finally, I remind you that the Verdict also instructs Serbia to arrest all the accuse of genocide in Bosnia and Herzegovina without delay. The attempts to attribute Serbia’s responsibility to the “reign of Slobodan Milošević” are simply impossible because the post-Milošević power in Serbia has been hiding the accused longer than Milošević himself. Therefore, we expect of Serbia, the first and the only country in history found guilty of violating the Convention on Genocide, to arrest and deliver all those who participated in the genocide project in Bosnia and Herzegovina as soon as possible.
In the end, allow me to close with words of US Congressman Chris Smith, a great fighter for human rights, at the speaker’s stand of the US Congress, while speaking about the genocide in Bosnia and Herzegovina:
“Justice is a necessary precondition for sustainable reconciliation. Regardless of how long it might take, we must never be tired or discouraged in our quest for justice. Reconciliation and further consolidation of democracy must be based on systematic reform. The perpetrators of genocide would best prefer it if we were to forget. However, that is certainly something we could never do. Ever!”
Without these basic postulates, it is hard to renew the truly multiethnic society, where people live with each other, not next to each other, and which is the only guarantor of peace and stability in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the entire region. The best example is that such a society is possible in Bosnia and Herzegovina, where people, after all they have been trough, are still ready for coexistence and construction of truly democratic Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Dear friends, today, the eyes of the world are pointed at Srebrenica and Bosnia and Herzegovina because the past and the future of the entire world are reflected in Srebrenica. Therefore, it is important to validate our determination, not only in words but in actions as well, that justice is still attainable, that policy of genocide cannot achieve political goals and that we can build a victory of peace and coexistence on the example of Srebrenica.
Thank you!

title: Speech by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, dr Haris Silajdžić, at the Southeastern Europe Heads of State in Athens, 13th July 2008.
content:
specific geographic position at the crossroads between the East and the West, the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, valleys of big rivers such as the Danube and Sava, as well as a very rich and tumultuous history of our region, have made the Southeastern Europe a mosaic of religions, cultures, traditions and languages. Being a historically multiethnic country, Bosnia and Herzegovina considers these diversities to be one of the greatest riches of our region. I fully share the opinion with UNESCO that it is
"Mr. President of the Hellenic Republic,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentleman,
It is my great honor to thank our host the President of the Hellenic Republic, Dr. Karlos Papoulias, for his warm hospitality and excellent organization of this gathering, and especially to greet the UNESCO Director General Koichiro Matcura and the Secretary General of the Council of Europe Terry Davis.
I would like to express my satisfaction over the organization of today's meeting which we see as a continuation of a dialogue process at the highest level of the countries of the Southeast European region in the domain of culture and cultural heritage, which was initiated under the patronage of UNESCO in Ohrid in 2003.
A specific geographic position at the crossroads between the East and the West, the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, valleys of big rivers such as the Danube and Sava, as well as a very rich and tumultuous history of our region, have made the Southeastern Europe a mosaic of religions, cultures, traditions and languages. Being a historically multiethnic country, Bosnia and Herzegovina considers these diversities to be one of the greatest riches of our region. I fully share the opinion with UNESCO that it is precisely the domain of culture that offers enormous opportunities for the establishment of close cooperation in the Southeast Europe region. In this context, I would like to welcome UNESCO's activities and those of its Director General.
I believe that the joint affirmation and joint promotion of our cultural heritage could be one of the best and most effective ways of creating a better portrait of our region.
In addition to its cultural and historic values, our cultural wealth could also be an important basis for economic and sustainable development.
I also wish to express my pleasure with the fact that a decision was made at the last session of the Committee for Cultural Heritage in Christ Church in New Zealand, on enlisting the Mehmed PaĹˇa SokoloviÄ‡ Bridge in ViĹˇegrad on the UNESCO World Heritage List. This act, combined with the addition of the Mostar Historic Town Centre along with the Old Bridge in 2005, represents a stimulus for our country to step up the restoration and protection of our cultural and natural wealth. Bosnia and Herzegovina has recently nominated another cultural and historic monument to be added to the World Heritage List â€“ namely the Old City of Jajce. We do hope that a positive decision will be made at the 33rd World Heritage Committee. In addition to this we are preparing the nominations of Vjetrenica Caves.
Once more I would like to point out that Bosnia and Herzegovina is interested in nomination for enlisting the National Park of Sutjeska in the World Heritage List, which is a joint project with the National Park Durmitor in the neighboring Montenegro. I believe that this is the best way to permanently preserve the natural wealth of our countries â€“ especially the canyons of rivers Drina and Tara. Allow me to use this opportunity to repeat that BiH is fully committed to respecting the 1972 Convention on World Cultural and Natural Heritage. Furthermore, I would like to point out that Bosnia and Herzegovina has recently ratified the 2005 UNESCO Convention on Protection and Promotion of the Cultural Expressions, and that we are in the process of ratifying the Convention on Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage.
Ladies and Gentleman,
Allow me to mention some other projects for promotion of the historic and cultural heritage, which are of a great importance for my country.
I would like to thank UNESCO and the General Director Matcura for the participation in the reconstruction of three symbolic religious objects in our country â€“ the Ferhadija Mosque in Banja Luka, the Orthodox Monastery in Mostar and the Catholic Monastery Plehan in Derventa. The reconstruction of these objects will further improve our efforts to rebuild a multiethnic and multicultural society in Bosnia and Hercegovina , where the cultural diversity is considered to be a part of our wealth and a comparative advantage.
The active participation of UNESCO in the realization of these projects additionally underlines the important role that UNESCO has in the protection of the treasures of our region and the promotion of multiethnic and multicultural society in the very geographic center of Europe.
I would like to thank UNESCO for the support in completing the project ARS AEVI, which is one of the most important European museums of modern art in Sarajevo. Due to this project, Sarajevo and our region have become one of the worldâ€™s leading destinations of modern art.
Ladies and Gentleman,
As you know, Bosnia and Herzegovina has undergone a period of post war recovery and reconstruction. It has been a tough period for our country and our citizens. The country was almost completely destroyed and not only did we have to rebuild the cultural and historic monuments and values but also the trust among people of our region. A special segment of our post war reconstruction was the reconstruction of cultural life, for which we had a strong support of UNESCO and its member states. The experience of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the view of establishing a cultural dialogue is of a great importance, because we can offer constructive models for culture in the globalized world.
Generally, we all found our societies and cultures near water. It is source of life and all big civilizations have been established on the banks of big rivers. Bosnia and Herzegovina contains in its name the name of one of our six big rivers and its natural borders are rivers Una, Sava and Drina and in the south the Adriatic Sea. Various cultures were founded on these water ways; cultures that have been developing since the neolith. Every great civilization and religion is somehow closely connected to the culture of water. Every cultural part in our region could signify the fact that there are no borders in the nature and that the water connects people by ensuring the existence of all people. Therefore, Bosnia and Herzegovina supports development and intensification of cultural corridors with the aim of establishing a closer connection and ensure the survival of the unity of diversities. Exactly this unity of diversities is the cultural wealth that we have to preserve in the Southeast Europe. I believe that the cultural corridors related to maritime and river routes could be a useful tool for the realization of the intercultural dialogue.
By establishing affirmation and joint promotion of our cultural heritage, we could turn the Southeast Europe region into a destination which, thanks to its cultural wealth and all its diversitiy, would once again attract visitors from the entire world, and in that way open new development perspectives for our countries.
Thus, we send a clear political message of our willingness to constructively include our countries in all international processes and our determination to make the Southeast Europe region an example which proves that good relations and cooperation can be established if they are based on a constant dialogue and plentitude of cultural diversities.
Thank you for your attention."

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić on the occasion of the BiH
content:
Invaluable contributions and assistance were provided by the tens of thousands of US Government representatives and members of the Armed Forces engaged as part of the international forces for establishing and maintaining peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina, humanitarian aid, renewal and reconstruction of this war-torn country.
Excellencies,
generals and officers,
representatives of legislative and executive government, dear guests,
It is an honour to welcome you to today’s event organised on the occasion of 5 June – the Cooperation Day between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the United States of America in the domain of international cooperation in defence and security.
I would like to use this opportunity to thank all of you for taking the time to honour this event by your presence, and we owe particular gratitude to the organisers and participants of the spectacular performances by members of the US Armed Forces and the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
This event today, just like the defence reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina whose results are evident, could not have been achieved without the help of friendly countries, and especially the United States of America.
Invaluable contributions and assistance were provided by the tens of thousands of US Government representatives and members of the Armed Forces engaged as part of the international forces for establishing and maintaining peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina, humanitarian aid, renewal and reconstruction of this war-torn country.
Later, this assistance continued through training, equipment and professional advice for the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
With the strong support of the United States of America, at the end of 2006, Bosnia and Herzegovina was invited to join the NATO Partnership for Peace Programme, and as of April this year, it was also invited to establish Intensive Dialogue with the NATO Alliance with the ultimate aim of full membership.
Due to limited resources, cooperation and assistance will continue to play a significant role in the professional development and modernisation of the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is committed to these goals and expects that through engagement within the NATO and other programmes and initiatives, the United States of America will remain its most significant strategic partner in the domain of defence.
Bosnia and Herzegovina will also continue to strengthen cooperation and friendly relations will all interested countries from its surroundings, members of NATO, the Partnership for Peace and other countries from the region.
Accession to the European Union and NATO remain the main priority in activities at all levels.
In view of its geo-strategic position and overall characteristics, Bosnia and Herzegovina is an important factor for the stability of the Southeast European region. It will, therefore, strive to provide its utmost contribution to improving the total relations and cooperation between countries in the region.
NATO’s engagement in Bosnia and Herzegovina is of crucial importance for establishing and maintaining peace in the post-Dayton period. That is why Bosnia and Herzegovina will participate in all the activities of the NATO Initiative for Southeast Europe aimed at harmonising and supporting regional cooperation in matters of defence, as well as in concrete projects.
Bosnia and Herzegovina will continue to develop the capabilities of its Armed Forces for participation in peace support operations.
As a member of the Partnership for Peace and an aspiring candidate for full NATO membership, Bosnia and Herzegovina requires NATO’s assistance in surveying its existing capacities, equipment and capabilities for participating in peace missions.
As proof of cooperation with the United States of America, through the Implementation Agreement that will be signed today, the United States of America will provide additional education and training for the Armed Forces of BiH within the IMET programme amounting to one million dollars. This is a continuation of the programme that trained over 150 members of the former entity armies in the past.
Dear guests, the reform of the defence system in Bosnia and Herzegovina was an important step towards full NATO membership, and it was all done with the support of friendly countries, and especially the United States of America. We expect to receive support up to the moment of full NATO membership when Bosnia and Herzegovina will become an active participant and give its contribution to regional and global security.
Finally, I would like to thank all of you once more for being here today, and I hope we will make this event a tradition.

title: BiH Presidency Member from the Republic of Srpska Nebojša Radmanović’s address on occasion the celebration of the Day of the 3rd Infantry Regiment “Republic of Srpska”
content:
We have traditionally gathered here today at this spot to celebrate the 16th anniversary of the Republic of Srpska Army’s establishment and the 3rd anniversary of the Third Infantry Regiment (Republic of Srpska) within the reformed BiH Armed Forces. On that occasion, I congratulate those who deserve these congratulations....
“Gentlemen presidents
Of the Republic of Srpska, the National Assembly and the Government of the Republic of Srpska,
Your excellencies,
Gentlemen generals, officers and soldiers,
Esteemed families of the killed and missing soldiers of the Republic of Srpska Army,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
We have traditionally gathered here today at this spot to celebrate the 16th anniversary of the Republic of Srpska Army’s establishment and the 3rd anniversary of the Third Infantry Regiment (Republic of Srpska) within the reformed BiH Armed Forces. On that occasion, I congratulate those who deserve these congratulations:
All the members of the 3rd Infantry Regiment “Republic of Srpska”;
All the members of the Republic of Srpska Army,
I would also like to express our gratitude and respect to the
Families of the killed, missing and wounded soldiers of the Republic of Srpska Army in the past war,
On the day of the Republic of Srpska Army, remembrance of the recent and distant past simply imposes on us.
During the nineties, the common state of the Yugoslavian peoples was destroyed and divided in one of the most brutal wars led in these areas. Just like some earlier times in the past, during those years, various dangers threatened the Serbian people and their survival, freedom and national identity. In such circumstances, in 1992, the Serbian people in BiH formed the Republic of Srpska Army as an armed force for defending the Serbian people and the territory they inhabited for centuries.
We owe it to the plebiscitary expressed democratic will of the Serbian people in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Army of the Republic of Srpska that defended the Serbian people and their historical, national, cultural and political values and heritage in an armed fight for the existence of the Republic of Srpska.
The previous war in BiH took many sacrifices on all sides, and in the Serbian people as one of them, and that is why we must not forget that the Republic of Srpska was created with huge efforts, sacrifices and aspirations of the entire Serbian people, especially the RS Army members. The war in BiH, just as any other war, left behind heavy trauma in the hearts of people that had lost their closest members, members of their immediate family or distant relatives. That obligates us to take a better care of the invalids and wounded soldiers, families of the killed and missing soldiers of the Republic of Srpska Army in the past war. The Republic of Srpska National Assembly would soon consider the reviews and amendments to the Law on rights of soldiers, disabled war veterans and families of killed soldiers of the defensive and patriotic war, which will ensure an increase in the monthly income of the disabled war veterans and families of the killed soldiers. For the first time, the rights of these categories have sound financial guarantee trough regular monthly payment.
In the post-war period, the Army and the Republic of Srpska institutions significantly contributed to implementation of the Dayton Peace Agreement, preservation of peace and building trust and cooperation between the sides in the conflict, as well as defense sector reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Within the general process of military and defense sector reform toward the Euro-Atlantic integration, since our last gathering at this very spot, just in a year, several important activities in this domain have been conducted.
At the last NATO Alliance Summit in Bucharest this year, relations between the BiH Armed Forces and the NATO Alliance have been elevated to the Intensified Dialogue level, which is recognition of the successfully completed reforms in the previous period.
The Agreement on the final ownership of the rights and obligations on movable property that would continue to be used for the BiH defense purposes has recently been signed, which is a significant progress in solving this complex and sensitive matter.
Activities on establishing the BiH military mission at the NATO Headquarters in Brussels are underway.
Additionally, preparations for sending military attachés to three BIH diplomatic and consular missions in Serbia, Croatia and Turkey are in the final phase.
The process of accepting first 300 soldiers for professional service in the BiH Armed Forces has commenced.
BiH Armed Forces units, soldiers and officers from the Republic of Srpska among them, are successfully participating in several peace missions in the world within the UN engagement in the collective security system in the world.
We celebrate the Republic of Srpska Army Day and the 3rd Infantry Regiment Republic of Srpska immediately after the great holidays, May 9, the Day of Victory over Fascism and the Day of Europe. Serbs and the members of other nations in BiH have given their enormous contribution to the Antifascist fight during the Second World War, for which they deserve an honorary place among other nations of Europe and the world. That is something that we must not forget, for the sake of the truth, as well as for future generations in the united Europe.
We build today’s BiH as a community of equal nations, toward the EU membership. Unfortunately, there are those at high places in BiH that contest the equality and still believe that they can decide on others’ rights and way of life. We say to them that it is not possible in a modern society, contesting one’s rights on equality mostly harms one’s own people and sets him farther from others, from the united Europe to which we aspire.
In the end, I wish the 3rd Infantry Regiment Republic of Srpska and the entire armed forces of BiH to serve for peace, security and stability of the region. That is the only way to ensure that the heavy war past never happens again.
Thank you.”

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić has addressed today the participants of the 15th Summit of the Heads of States in Ohrid
content:
“The solution for Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region called west Balkan is the European Union and there is no other alternative to it. We need security, therefore the biggest interest of Bosnia and Herzegovina is to be in good terms with its neighbors all heading toward the European Union” said BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić in his address.
“The solution for Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region called west Balkan is the European Union and there is no other alternative to it. We need security, therefore the biggest interest of Bosnia and Herzegovina is to be in good terms with its neighbors all heading toward the European Union” said BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić in his address. According to his words, Bosnia and Herzegovina is a part of the solution because it can contribute to constructive dialogue. Multi-culture and pluralism are the solution for the countries that have bitter experience like Bosnia and Herzegovina - said Chairman Silajdžić.
He emphasized that Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens want to be integrated in the European Union and NATO and there is no doubt about it. “BiH did not sign the Stabilization and Association Agreement event though we had met all requirements, believing that reform process is very important and that we were not racing with time. The crucial issue is not whether we would sign the Agreement this month or the next one, but that there is a sense of resentment and bitterness”, said Chairman Silajdžić. He stressed out that Serbia did sign the Agreement, even though the International Court of Justice confirmed with its verdict that the country was responsible for the genocide in BiH. According to his words, the Court’s decision was being ignored and he asked the Summit participants what they would have done if that were happening in their countries. He underlined that he was an optimist believing in Europe as a solution for BiH, offering BiH’s experience to Europe, success and failure altogether.
During his address, Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić said Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country that can produce energy and in that way make its contribution to the European Union.

title: BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić’s speech on occasion of celebrating the Battle at the Neretva river
content:
Fellow fighters, I know you have a hard time, you are in pain because of the negligence of the present authorities, and what is worse, certain people that are proud of their Chetnik or Ustashi descend and their ideology are holding, or used to hold, important positions in this state. However, you must know that there are also those that would never give up, those who consider Bosnia and Herzegovina their only homeland, we are determined to fight for it, because Bosnia and Herzegovina is ours, it belongs
“Dear comrades,
Ladies and Gentlemen, antifascists, partisans,
It is my honor to be standing here today, at this glorious part of the BiH land, to be able to invite the memory of the brave and honorable heroes who did their best to save their fellow soldiers, their comrades, from the claws of the Fascist criminals and their domestic collaborators, the Chetniks and the Ustashi.
There are many told stories, many memories, but unfortunately, there is more and more looking down on the significance of the War of National Liberation, the heroic and honorable battle fought by all people in our former common State.
We must not forget and we must not allow the heroic battles, such as this one, to be forgotten or even worse, we must not allow the distortion and the falsification of the character of the entire fight against the Fascists and local collaborators.
The fourth enemy offensive, or Vol Weis as the Fascists called it, was initiated for the purpose of destroying the headquarters of the War of National Liberation, the majority of the partisan forces and what is worst, the main partisan hospital. The offensive was supposed to strengthen the Fascist creation definitely, the Independent State of Croatia, the position of the criminal Chetnik “patriotic” soldiers and the Fascist German and Italian occupation troops.
The Fascists did not count on your faith in victory; therefore, none of the combat tasks represented any unsolvable problem for the partisan units.
They personally experienced it, especially the Chetnik formations, which seized to exist after this battle as a military factor and were only what they were actually from the beginning – criminals perpetrating crimes against the helpless and innocent civilian population.
Certain parallels could be drawn with the war conflict that unfortunately took place in our more recent history. That war again brought back the domestic Fascists who committed horrible transgressions, war crimes and genocide.
That shows that fight is not over yet and breaking their forces that happened here in 1943, was not final.
Therefore, we must never stop and become discouraged, for our future and for the future of our children and those that are yet to come.
Fellow fighters, I know you have a hard time, you are in pain because of the negligence of the present authorities, and what is worse, certain people that are proud of their Chetnik or Ustashi descend and their ideology are holding, or used to hold, important positions in this state.
However, you must know that there are also those that would never give up, those who consider Bosnia and Herzegovina their only homeland, we are determined to fight for it, because Bosnia and Herzegovina is ours, it belongs to all of us, the Bosniacs, the Serbs, the Croats, the Jews, the Roma, and the others, it belongs to all its citizens, it is our country, every part of its territory, regardless of the name we wear, the God we pray, no matter if we are the majority or the minority.
No one, not any people, not any politics, not any individual can or will be an owner of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and certainly not an owner of any of its parts, even the least one!
It belongs to the Bosnians and the Herzegovinians, the entire Bosnia and Herzegovina! Only that Bosnia and Herzegovina, and why not say Bosnia and Herzegovina defined at ZAVNOBIH, is a normal country, the country of future, a happy country!
May 9, the Day of Victory over the Fascism is in a few days! By paying respects to all Antifascists who gave their lives for freedom, I wish to emphasize again that Antifascism is our historic legacy, we will proudly take it to the European family that inherited the same values as the basis for the modern democratic world!
May all those who made sacrifices in the fight for freedom against the Fascism have the eternal glory.”
Jablanica, 26.04.2008
Željko Komšić
BiH Presidency Member

title: Speech by BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić on occasion of opening the 20th International Book Fair “ Sarajevo, a world book”
content:
It is my pleasure to be able to share the joy for holding a jubilee Sarajevo fair, here at the XX International Book Fair in Sarajevo that has brought us together under the symbolic title “Sarajevo, a world book”. Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country with every house filled with books testifying about the meetings of civilizations and their bonding trough culture and art.
“Ladies and Gentlemen, Your Excellencies,
Dear authors and book creators, publishers, printers and booksellers,
It is my pleasure to be able to share the joy for holding a jubilee Sarajevo fair, here at the XX International Book Fair in Sarajevo that has brought us together under the symbolic title “Sarajevo, a world book”. Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country with every house filled with books testifying about the meetings of civilizations and their bonding trough culture and art. The Bosnian house is not cramped for anyone, it has never taken anyone’s living space, it has always been open in the best tradition of our millennium life experience, and in it, we dedicate ourselves to the books in the year declared as the international year of books by the United Nations. We celebrated the Earth Day and we celebrate the World Book and Copyright Protection Day today, a day that UNESCO promotes reminding us about the importance of books and works of authors in our lives.
The capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina- Sarajevo is therefore a natural place for it, where authors, publishers, librarians, booksellers, scientific workers dedicated to the books meet and create. The history of Sarajevo and cultural, historical, artistic, spiritual and natural heritage and contemporary creativity confirm that this is a city that rightfully belongs to the most important regional and world centers of art and culture.
For the Book fair and many other events dedicated to books: “Sarajevo Poetry Days”. European literary meetings of the “Andre Malraux” Center, upon invitation of PEN Center, Writers’ Society, Publishers’ Association, many world authors come in Sarajevo proving the importance of the BiH cultural ambience, in which one could create freely and fully express oneself without any restriction. Bosnia and Herzegovina respects the principles of free expression and free publishing and information in accordance with the UNESCO basic principles, defined in Articles 19-27, the Universal Declaration on Human Rights and the Agreement on importance of education, science and culture (the Florence Agreement).
Sarajevo is a city where is the BiH Academy of Art and Science, the Town’s Archives and of BiH, and the Museum of Theatrical Art and Literature, with one of the most important collections of BiH contemporary worldwide recognized writers, such as Nobel Prize winner Ivo Andrić, Meša Selimović, Isak Samokovlija, Mak Dizdar, Tin Ujević and others.
This town contains one of the oldest Balkan libraries – Gazi Husrev-Beg Library, established in 1537, as well as the Zemaljski Museum, which in its rich treasury also holds Hagada, created in the period 1350 -1370, as well as many other extraordinary manuscripts. In Sarajevo, there is also the Oriental Institute and other scientific institutions, the Language Institute, Institute of Balkan Studies, the Academy of Arts and all other art academies (music, theatre, fine art)
It is particularly important that in Sarajevo, there are specialized libraries, such as the Library for the blind and those with poor vision.
I personally express my full support to your efforts to create better economic conditions for the development of publishing, bookselling and printing, better status for the authors and greater possibilities for the readers, a better accession to the books. There can be no scientific, research, artistic creation or education in life without books; therefore, on the 20th jubilee meeting in Sarajevo, I support your effort to abolish VAT on books, because that is a tax on mind, tradition, future. I support your efforts to restore the libraries, school and university, to open new public libraries and bookstores throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina, to renew the printing technology and bravely enter the Information Era and create better conditions for digitalization and connection with the entire world. We are obligated to support the completion of the Cultural Policy Strategy of Bosnia and Herzegovina, focusing on books and everything related to the books, art, culture, creativity and education. We are obligated to do it for ourselves, for the creators and extreme talents in all fields in our country, and for our commitments toward the Council of Europe, our role in UNESCO, which is not only referring to protection of cultural, historical and natural heritage, but to the entire creativity, our Euro-Atlantic integration and world standards, care for the book and responsibility of the countries for its role in the development of a society. I support your appearance at the impending International Book fair in Podgorica and your appearance at the 60th Frankfurt Book Fair and the initiative for the entire region’s appearance at this unique place in the book world. That way, this southeastern part of Europe would be shown in the best light with its literary and the entire cultural and historic heritage.
I support your efforts to make Sarajevo a world book city, as Amsterdam has been this year, I support Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina becoming the hosts of the World Publishers’ Congress, as Seoul has been this year. I support your initiative for Bosnia and Herzegovina to support the best of its creators by awarding state-level recognitions and awards, valorizing their work, education and affirmation in the country and the world, as well as with full social protection of creators, who have invaluably contributed to our country’s development. I recognize the BiH Association of Publisher and Booksellers for all these initiatives and efforts as a part of the world publishers’ association. I especially recognize the organizers of this XX International Sarajevo Book Fair, KSC Skenderija, co-organizers TKD Šahinpašić and the BiH Association of Publisher and Booksellers, I most cordially greet all participants of the Fair from the country and the world, because this is an event testifying about the value of joint work on book, culture and creativity promotion in connecting the modern world dedicated to development, democracy and new relations.
Thank you.”

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić’s address on occasion of the celebration of the 16th anniversary of “Pretis 92” action - remembering Safet Hadžić
content:
It is my pleasure to attend the celebration of the 16th anniversary of the “Pretis 92” action together with you, as well as this program dedicated to brigadier general Safet Hadžić, who died during that action as a regular soldier.
Sarajevo, April 18, 2008
“Dear Hadžić family,
Dear soldiers,
Dear guests,
It is my pleasure to attend the celebration of the 16th anniversary of the “Pretis 92” action together with you, as well as this program dedicated to brigadier general Safet Hadžić, who died during that action as a regular soldier.
Ordinary people, patriots, members of the Patriotic league, Green Berets, Territorial Defense and the RBIH Ministry of Interior, all quickly realized the danger that was threatening our sovereign, independent and an internationally recognized state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
They were aware of the plan that was devised to divide Bosnia and Herzegovina, and that mass murder, concentration camps, ethnic cleansing and sieges were about to ensue. They were aware that JNA was cleansed from any “unfit element” and a rough and an unequal fight for preservation of our state, its peoples and citizens was about to take place, those peoples and citizens that considered Bosnia and Herzegovina their homeland.
Precisely for those reasons, the “Pretis 92” action was planned and carried out, in the night between April 17 and 18, 1992, aiming to extract armament and military equipment necessary for Bosnia and Herzegovina’s defense.
The action was a success in relation to extracting the armament and the military equipment, however, it was also painful due to the death of the deceased Safet Hadžić, Sead Velić, Nermin Zeljković, Fahrudin Čavčić, Almir Islamović and Senad Čirić.
Safet Hadžić died as a regular soldier, but he was also the President of the Crisis Headquarters of the Sarajevo region at the time of his death. He realized on time the destiny of his country ad his people. Therefore, he was a member of the Patriotic League, he gathered officers that had left JNA and he included them in the Sarajevo region Crisis Headquarters. He had a large number of patriotic friends, his informal operative headquarters where they made plans for defending Sarajevo.
General Safet directly planned and participated in the “Pretis 92” action with his friends-fellow soldiers, when he died bravely and honorably on April 18, 1992 at the time of the “Pretis”.
Hero Safet, and all other patriots that gave their lives and health for the independent and sovereign Bosnia and Herzegovina, we owe it you to preserve stability, democracy, economically stabile state and the integrity of our Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We owe it to them, especially their families, their children, who must have their future safe and secured. We must all be proud of the fight that was led by our soldiers, their families can walk proudly, and their closest ones have deserved it with their honorable fight, because they did not answer to savagery with savagery, destruction and mass murder. They just defended their country and their people.
We must remember General Safet and all killed soldiers, patriots and their families every day, we must celebrate anniversaries, defend their deeds from oblivion, proudly mention their names and the important battles, because that is our duty and an our obligation.
In the end, I wish to mention the first President of the RBiH Presidency, the deceased Alija Izetbegović, who also always had special words of respect and love to say about the soldiers. He always emphasized that politics can achieve only as much as the soldiers have ensured it the field.

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić’s address on occasion of laying a cornerstone for the new US Embassy building in BiH
content:
It is my great pleasure and honor to welcome you on behalf of the Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency at this festivity, and to wish you a successful construction of the new United States of America Embassy building in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
“Dear Excellencies, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen,
It is my great pleasure and honor to welcome you on behalf of the Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency at this festivity, and to wish you a successful construction of the new United States of America Embassy building in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The United States, with its continuous presence in Bosnia and Herzegovina, since the hardest days in our history, showed significant support to our country, its progress and preservation of its sovereignty and territorial integrity. Its building symbolizes the continuation of the United States’ interest in development and strengthening of bilateral relations between our two countries.
The close relationship between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the United States of America has existed since the very independence of our country. The United States were among the first to recognize the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina, on April 7, 1992.
The diplomatic relations were established on August 6, 1992, and the United States Embassy began with work on November 10, 1993 within the US Embassy in Vienna. The first Embassy of the United States of America in Sarajevo was opened in July 4, 1994, on occasion of celebrating the 218th anniversary of USA independence, during the most difficult times.
Madeleine Albright, the US Ambassador to the United Nations at the time and a friend of Bosnia and Herzegovina attended the ceremony. Besides sending her support to the citizens of the surrounded Sarajevo during that visit to Sarajevo with words “Ja sam Sarajka”, Ambassador Albright envisaged the future relations between our two countries, by saying “Your future and the future of the United States of America are inseparable.”
14 years later, her words are even more significant, because the Unites States of America have been, continuously and with an equal intensity, supporting the development of democratic values, human rights and rule of law in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Our two countries’ experience is also tightly connected. Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as citizens of USA, are appreciating and believing in the advantages of the multiethnic society, and they are guided by an idea of coexistence, mutual respect and tolerance. Bosnia and Herzegovina has been based on these ideas and values for hundreds of years, and the recent past experience only emphasized the importance of supporting and defending these values. In that sense, the help from the United States that naturally understand the advantages of those values is of crucial importance for further development of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a functional, multiethnic democracy.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is trying to return the help the United States are extending to our country, and is becoming more and more important partner of USA in the series of fields.
