Our two country’s soldiers are helping to preserve peace in several missions worldwide, and Bosnia and Herzegovina’s progress toward the NATO Alliance membership represents a symbol of our country’s determination and its citizens to have as closer cooperation as possible with the United States in our joint efforts for peace, stability, democracy and prosperity in the Balkan and Europe in general.
The mutual relations between our two countries are better and better over the years. Political and strategic cooperation has always been present and at the very high level, and economic and cultural cooperation is getting more and more stronger, therefore I hope that business relations would be more intensified, especially by the American corporations’ investments in projects in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I use this opportunity to thank the United States on behalf of the Bosnia and Herzegovina citizens, and to thank for the determination to continue with an active engagement in our country. Besides thanking the current Ambassador, H.E. English, we also owe gratitude to previous six US Ambassadors who performed their duty in our country, and the first one among them has survived grenades and other dangers on a daily basis together with the citizens of Sarajevo. We owe a special gratitude to the United States for stopping further destruction and death in Bosnia and Herzegovina and that is something we will never forget.
Now, allow me to express a deep gratitude to Robert Frasure, Joseph Kruzel and Nelson Drew, who gave their lives to give peace to us. I wish to say to their families – we will always remember your loss and their sacrifice.
In the end, Your Excellency, allow me to express my gratitude by laying the cornerstone, and my hope that you will have a successful construction of the new United States of America Embassy building in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The today’s ceremony and the new building are the best ways to symbolize the friendship between our two countries and the continuation of good bilateral relations and strong cooperation in a series of fields.”

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Dr Haris Silajdžić’s address
content:
Reception on occasion of registration of Mehmed–Pasha Sokolović’s bridge in the UNESCO World Heritage List
“Dear Mister General Director Matsuura,
Excellencies, esteemed guests, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends,
It is my honor to greet you on behalf of the Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency and to welcome you. It is a pleasure to host the General Director of UNESCO, an organization that promotes and encourages education, science and art trough preservation of variety of the world’s cultural diversity.
Preserving unity in diversity, on which uniqueness and inimitability of the BiH culture are based on, we primarily consider it as our own responsibility. However, after the systematic destruction of the BiH unity in diversity at the end of the twentieth century, when UNESCO had stressed out the proclamation of that principle as a goal of the humankind’s desirable structure, we rightfully reiterate that we expect UNESCO’s multiple help for renovation, strengthening and preservation of that unity in its variety in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
For all previous cooperation and professional engagement of officials and employees of UNESCO, on behalf of the Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency, I pay respect to you and I thank you for supporting the projects we are trying to carry out in the field of heritage, science, culture and art.
We proudly present our country’s heritage as a bridge between the East and the West, between the North and the South. Mehmed-Pasha Sokolović’s bridge, a work of Mimar Sinan, a court architect and the head builder of the Great Turkish Empire in the 16th century, a monument to the historic ties in the Balkan between the Christian and the Islam cultural world, the economic ties between the West and the East. The bridge in Višegrad is an architectural achievement of the classic Turkish style, and its artistic values are an important phase in the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Europe and humankind. By preserving these values of the past, we are paying respects to our presence and we are building bridges of understanding and intercultural dialogue. Bosnia and Herzegovina is known for its bridges. Three years ago, the Old Bridge in Mostar was the first historic and cultural monument in our country registered in the World Heritage List.
Therefore, I stress out as a symbolic important fact – in the mosaic of universal and permanent values of the world heritage, Bosnia and Herzegovina is represented with the two rocks; architecturally brave, artistically and historically thrilling bridges –both from the 16th century. In the architecture and the history of the Old Bridge in Mostar, a structure of Bosnia and Herzegovina has been reflected – this is an amazing country; what was impossible to join in other parts of the world, has been joined in it for centuries. Like the MostarBridge, the structure of this country was destroyed in the late twentieth century. Just as the Old Bridge was heroically reconstructed as a symbol of victory of building over destruction, beauty over hatred, Bosnia and Herzegovina is going trough a complex process of reestablishing its structure. From the fragments that it had collapsed into, we are trying to rebuild it as a testimony of permanence of bridges between people.
Dear Mr. Matsuura, the Old Bridge in Mostar is not threatened and I ask of you to pass on that truth and by doing so, ensure additional help to our heritage. The Old Bridge, as well as the entire historic centre of Mostar, has recently been turned into the most shameful world ruins – impoverished and devastated. In a society that is still faced with the tackling of the consequences of physical and internal devastation, the Old Bridge reconstruction was only possible with a help of the world, especially the UNESCO, as a key organization for preservation of cultural diversity.
Our need for your assistance, dear Mr. Matsuura, is not slight, not even in the conditions when facing the task of harmonizing the need to reduce poverty with development in the part of Mostar that was terribly devastated and ensure the implementation of standards set in the Convention on World Heritage
Construction of the Ruža hotel in Mostar is a great investment, significant for the city’s development, which has been stopped in full for over two years, because, in compliance with the decision of the World Heritage Committee, we are trying to find a solution that will harmonize development and heritage. I reiterate – the construction of the Ruža hotel does not threaten the Old Bridge, because the construction has been stopped and will be continued only when the UNESCO experts confirm the hotel’s architecture compliance with the unique and universal value of the Mostar historic centre. On behalf of the Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency, I repeat our request for UNESCO’s assistance to Mostar until the solution is achieved. I repeat our request now for the UNESCO experts to give their view on the new solution, before the 32nd session of the Committee, so we could continue with our work.
A bridge, as a means to ensure a crossing from one side to another, is one of the most famous symbols. A bridge symbolizes a crossing from the world of human imperfection to the world of openness and merger. That, at the level of higher symbols, is a crossing from earth to heaven, from transience to immortality. Today, our attention is again turned to the Mehmed-Pasha Sokolović’s bridge in Višegrad, which was registered in the World Heritage List at the 31st session of the World Heritage Committee.
That eleven-arch construction ensured the world of remembrance for: its founder Bosnian - a grand vizier three emperors, Mehmed-Pasha Sokolović; its builder – a great name of the world architecture, Mimar Sinan; its chronicler, a writer of a novel on the bridge, who received a Nobel prize – Ivo Andrić, as well as numerous other known and unknown men who had build it, lived beside it for five centuries, walked over it or drew their inspiration from it.
I invite you also to register the names of 3000 people from Višegrad, with a special respect, in the world of universal recollection of humankind, among them 121 children, who were tortured or killed on that bridge or in its vicinity in 1992. The people from Višegrad who survived, witnessing that part of the history of Mehmed-Pasha Sokolović’s bridge, deserve our respect, and their pain – our compassion. More than that, when we celebrate the beauty and the glory of the bridge that is undoubtedly the world heritage, we are obligated to express our determination to recover the bodies of the dead, to punish the perpetrators of the crimes, and to ensure the memory of the victims dignifiedly. On that path, we need the United Nations’ support, so that a bridge could be on the World Heritage List connecting people, taking us to the future after facing the past.
Only that way, dear friends, full symbolism of the bridge and full symbolism of the world heritage syntagm could be fulfilled. The bridge in Mostar and the bridge in Višegrad, trough the catharsis of their today’s custodians, those in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the world, can be preserved forever as universal symbols of good and permanent ties between people and human communities.
This is an opportunity to congratulate on that possibility to all the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all citizens of the world, a possibility contained in the today’s formal act of confirmation presentation that The Bridge on the river Drina is a world heritage.
Dear Mr. Matsuura, thank you for the UNESCO’s support. In the end, allow me to wish you a nice stay in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić’s address on occasion of the BiH Independence Day celebration
content:
Allow me to thank you for joining us in this celebration of an extremely important day for us in the recent history of BiH, the BiH Independence day. For us, this day is inscribed in golden letters in a thousand-year long history of BiH, because on that day, 01.02.1992, we held a referendum on independence of the state of BiH. Based on those results, and bearing in mind the developments in the field, the European Union Council of Ministers, on 06.04.1992, in Brussels, reached the decision on the internation
"Your Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, dear guests and friends…
Allow me to thank you for joining us in this celebration of an extremely important day for us in the recent history of BiH, the BiH Independence day. For us, this day is inscribed in golden letters in a thousand-year long history of BiH, because on that day, 01.02.1992, we held a referendum on independence of the state of BiH. Based on those results, and bearing in mind the developments in the field, the European Union Council of Ministers, on 06.04.1992, in Brussels, reached the decision on the international recognition of the Republic of BiH.
That is how BiH’s historic walk on fire began as a sovereign and an independent country, founded in the most difficult war conditions and on an unbreakable and clearly expressed will of its citizens and peoples to live on their own, together with all those that consider BiH their homeland.
Dear guests, I unfortunately must state that regarding the perception of BiH as a shared state, a sense of respect for it has not changed significantly over the last 16 years.
It is clear that everybody draws partial conclusions and only what they need out of this history of ours, so we find ourselves again in the situation when we must vigorously fight to preserve BiH whole and independent and responsible in the future as well, and that no one is amnestied for all the bad things one is doing to its homeland.
We must finally comprehend the reality and build our future on it. We remain one country, not an inch of this country soaked in blood will be separated and there will be no more of settling accounts with anyone. We are part of Europe, so let us act like it and let us adjust our way of life, work and respect for European standards in all spheres, from the smallest and the commonest human, educational, cultural, religious, scientific and technological, economic and all others. When we realize it and accept it, there is a great possibility that we would not need any tutorship or this kind of actions by the European Union organs in our country. Then we will be able to talk about the true independence of BiH.
I believe in that and I want the current High Representative and other high officials and Excellencies to realize it and if they want, wish and can, to help us to reach that level of comprehension and action! However, if they do not want, wish or cannot do that, we must do it ourselves! I know it will be hard, but we will succeed!
There is room for all of us. This country is large enough for all and rich enough for all, and above all, it is our homeland, just the way it is and just the way we are and may it have a happy sixteenth anniversary of independence and may it have all following anniversaries even happier, particularly those that our future lies on – our children!
Thank you and cheers!"

title: Address by the Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Nebojša Radmanović
content:
Meeting of the Political Directors of the PIC Steering Board, Brussels, 26-27 February 2008
"Your Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Today’s meeting of the Peace Implementation Council Steering Board is an opportunity to exchange our views on political situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina and progress of the country in the Euro-Atlantic integration process. Since the last meeting of the Peace Implementation Council, many things have happened in Bosnia and Herzegovina that changed the earlier situation in the country. There are many analyses and various opinions about the achieved progress in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Today, I would like to express my attitude on the situation in BH and possible directions of the reform in the future.
Unlike many other regions in the world where the international community is present, BH represents a positive example of the engagement of the international community, seen as the entirety since the signing of the Dayton Peace Agreement till today. It is confirmed by many relevant reports of the international organizations, independent institutions and non-governmental associations in the world.
In the last year, BH had some minor deadlocks and political crises on its way to the Euro-Atlantic integration. One of them was caused by imposing the decisions of the High Representative on the way of decision making in the institutions of BH, which led to resignation by the Chairman of the BH Council of Ministers and slowed down the reform processes in the country. In spite of that, the leaders of the political parties reached an agreement and signed the Mostar Declaration on police reform. These days, the BH Parliament has been discussing the laws on police reform, which represents a step forward in fulfillment of the requirements for signing the Stabilization and Association Agreement. Also, the BH Parliament has confirmed the election of the Council of Ministers and adopted the Budget for the BH institutions for the year 2008.
At this moment, the international community should encourage and support all national political players in final fulfillment of the outstanding requirements for signing the Stabilization and Association Agreement. The still existing Euro-optimism should be employed.
We have heard several times from the diplomatic sources in BH, as well as from the EU, that the ambition of the international community for BH is to sign the Stabilization and Association Agreement as soon as possible. When we are in the position to practically do so, we hear from certain international representatives the reasons for stay and extension of the mandate of the OHR in BH. Last year, at the session of the Peace Implementation Council, in this very place, I presented the arguments for closing the OHR.
Here are some more arguments:
So far, there have been several decisions on transformation of the OHR in BH by the international community, and none of them has been fully implemented.
OHR decisions are often inconsistent with the Peace Agreement, or unnecessary, which causes political crises and represents a threat to stability.
OHR presence in BH does not contribute to democracy, but even impedes it. In order for BH to become a sovereign democratic country, it must be released from the influence of the instructions of any office. Management of this country should be in the hands of the democratically elected representatives of the people in BH.
BH would progress much faster without OHR presence and arbitration in the relations between the national political leaders and the parties can complain to. I believe that the politicians in BH would reach agreements more rapidly if they are enabled to do so.
BH is not a sovereign country as long as the OHR exists as such with issuing orders. All the issues of the further BH development may be resolved in partnership relations of the national authorities and the EU institutions in the process of progressing towards its full membership.
On the basis of that, I do believe that the international community should, as soon as possible, reduce its civil engagement in terms of issuing orders in BH and put the responsibility for the future of the country into the hands of the legally elected representatives.
I would like to remind you that, as the result of positive development of the political and security situation in BH, the NATO reduced its forces in BH and diminished its engagement to the Headquarters in Sarajevo. EUFOR has also reduced its forces in BH as the result of the improvement of the situation in the field of security and stabilization.
I have already been told that the OHR would not be closed in June this year, but I do believe that the transformation process of the OHR into the Office of the EU Special Representative should be accelerated with determining the exact deadline for transformation within the year 2008.
Thank you!"

title: BiH Presidency Member Dr Haris Silajdžić’s address at the meeting of the Peace Implementation Council in Brussels
content:
At the today’s session of the Peace Implementation Council, BiH Presidency Member Dr Haris Silajdžić expressed the determination of the majority of citizens in Bosnia and Herzegovina to sign the Stabilization and Association Agreement with European Union as soon as possible.
At the today’s session of the Peace Implementation Council, BiH Presidency Member Dr Haris Silajdžić expressed the determination of the majority of citizens in Bosnia and Herzegovina to sign the Stabilization and Association Agreement with European Union as soon as possible.
Dr Silajdžić stressed out that there are numerous challenges ahead of BiH that require the continuation of the High Representative’s mandate with full Bonn powers. That will be necessary as long as Bosnia and Herzegovina functions under the Dayton Constitution that allows a series of blockades. “What we need now is a new constitution that would ensure a more efficient functioning of the state, quicker reform processes and a full implementation of the European plan”. Designating any dates for closing OHR is unnecessary. Instead, we need a clear strategy that would involve issues necessary for a full functioning of the state with “path with no return” criterion in the European Union integration process.
Dr Silajdžić also expressed his concern regarding the attempt to connect certain regional issues, like Kosovo, with Bosnia and Herzegovina. No parallel can be drawn between the change of Kosovo’s status and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The independence, the sovereignty and the territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina are guaranteed with the United Nations Charter and any attempt to violate them, whether they are coming from outside or within Bosnia and Herzegovina, would not be tolerated.
Dr Silajdžić confirmed that BiH is determined to fulfill its international commitments, including the cooperation with the Hague Tribunal. However, in accordance with the verdict of the International Court of Justice, which celebrated its anniversary yesterday, that confirmed that genocide was committed in BiH, we will insist on the fulfillment of commitments that stem from it. In accordance with the UN General Assembly Resolution 56/83 on commitments of countries to end the situation created by violating the international law peremptory norms, as well as not to recognize the situation or aid the preservation of the situation, Bosnia and Herzegovina will continue to implement the mentioned verdict.
Bosnia and Herzegovina must go forward, but on that way, it will need help of the international community. BiH must be a democratic country, where individual, not collective representation will have priority. Respect for human rights must be ensured for all citizens regardless of their ethnic or religious affiliation. Only the multiethnic Bosnia and Herzegovina in all its territory can bring success for domestic and international factors.
At the end of his speech, Dr Silajdžić invited the Peace Implementation Council representatives to support Bosnia and Herzegovina in joining the family of democratic countries and becoming a constructive and respected member of European Union.

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić’s address in Brussels, 27.02.2008
content:
“Your Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for the invitation and for the opportunity to address you! Contrary to the previous meeting of the Peace Implementation Council held in Sarajevo, those who organize these session decided that it might be good to hear an opinion of the BiH Presidency Members on some of the most important issues for the country with us at the head! I hope that what we think and say would be of use to you and to us!
Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić made a speech at the today’s meeting of the Peace Implementation Council in Brussels given here entirely:
“Your Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen,
I thank you for the invitation and for the opportunity to address you! Contrary to the previous meeting of the Peace Implementation Council held in Sarajevo, those who organize these session decided that it might be good to hear an opinion of the BiH Presidency Members on some of the most important issues for the country with us at the head! I hope that what we think and say would be of use to you and to us!
I will try to lay my views and opinion in short regarding some of the topics of this PIC session.
I believe that it is a well-know fact the almost all political factors in BiH do not question, in my opinion, one of the most important strategic goals of BiH – becoming an EU member country! Even more importantly, I am also certain that most of the Bosnians and the Herzegovinians, ordinary people, citizens, see Bosnia and Herzegovina in the future as a full-fledged member of EU! Conviction that BiH’s European path simply has no alternative is an important fact in the political life of BiH. That is a fact with an amazing level of consensus in BiH, in politics and among citizens! Therefore, when it comes to the determination level, we in BiH have no dilemmas, contrary to some regional countries, in relation to our country’ s determination toward the EU integration! Of course, the question arises why things go unbearably slow when there is such a degree of agreement; so slow that we are wondering if we are heading toward EU at all! In my opinion, the reasons for such a state can be found in the composition of current authorities in BiH and the unresolved basic political issue in BiH – the issue of our country’s constitutional structure. Current authorities in BiH are made of six political parties, which essentially advocate three different concepts of BiH’s constitutional structure. Since the basic internal political issue - the issue of future constitutional structure - it is quite logical that all political factors in BiH use every political event, development, process, etc. as a possibility to assume and take the best possible position for themselves before the unquestionable issue for BiH – the issue of the country’s constitutional structure! In my opinion, therein lie the reasons for all political and economic problems of the country!
Changes for the better or popularly called – reform processes – are necessary for BiH to continue its European path; a path toward the better life is in a halt phase. The essential issue at this moment is whether these that you and we call reforms, are truly reforms, i.e. are we heading toward the better, toward EU. My opinion is that, except for the defense reform, these are not reforms and the reform process is not underway! I would call them “virtual reforms”, reforms without any content, pure satisfaction of form. I would be very pleased if someone would persuade me that what we call police reform in BiH is a reform, i.e. if someone could answer me a simple question: what is reformed there and what is essentially different and better from what we have now? Of course, the responsibility of domestic politicians and parties goes without saying, but there is also a responsibility of the High Representative who should be the one that supports the European values and standards at all times, in details and generally.
The future of the High Representative’s Office and his role in BiH, in my opinion, is not in question. BiH, unfortunately, still needs OHR with full powers and capacity. There are two kinds of reasons for this opinion of mine. I call them, ultimately conditionally, the internal and the external reasons. The internal reasons can be found in the insufficient state-level institutional power and capacity to assume most of the functions that any structured state possesses; the institutions that are unable to create and lead any reform without assistance or, let us be honest, a certain pressure of the international community. I think that I do not need to explain to you the external reasons, primarily regarding the security and political situation in the region. Attempts to connect other regional issues, in this concrete case – the issue of declaration of independence of Kosovo, with the situation in BiH are not ending. On the contrary, all things prove that they are gaining on intensity. The current High Representative’s passiveness in relation to this matter is inexplicable and impermissible, unless that is a lack of his political will as an individual to react or it is a received political instruction, a directive not to react?! Whatever may be the case, this is a very dangerous situation for BiH that will continue to deepen political and ethnic tension, divide BiH as a state and the BiH society! I belong among those who think it is necessary, even without any previously set time limit, to preserve the OHR institution with full powers and capacity. Without those powers, and more importantly, their utilization, the existence of that office would be pointless. Have not we been witnesses these days that OHR seemed tragicomically helpless expressing his concern and only concern, while the integrity of the country he is authorized and mandated for by the IC is being seriously threatened? To have Bonn powers and not to use them would be as if he did not have them at all! OHR is concerned and yet he has such powers that can, among else, eliminate that “terrible concern” ruling in OHR and return smiles on the worried faces of the High Representative and the employees in his Office, let alone to speak about us – the BiH citizens – and our wish to smile a bit?!
I know that what I have just said will not be crucial when you are making your decisions. I know that while you are making your decision you are guided by your own assessments and primarily, by the interests of the countries you come from, but please allow me to be guided by my own assessments and interests of my country as I see them in my address!
Thank you!”
Photo Gallery

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić’s address at the 24th International Festival “Sarajevo Winter”, 07.02.2008
content:
It is my great pleasure and honor to welcome you on behalf of the Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency, which is the traditional patron of this magnificent display of the most creative people and top art achievements.
Dear participants of the International Festival “Sarajevo Winter”, dear friends of culture and art,
It is my great pleasure and honor to welcome you on behalf of the Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency, which is the traditional patron of this magnificent display of the most creative people and top art achievements.
Bosnia and Herzegovina counts its existence from one altogether symbolic document – the Charter of Kulin Ban from 1189, a document, which is not only a state or a trade act, but a charter of freedom of speech, a sing of culture in dealings with others, of removing the barricades, obstacles and borders. Bosnia and Herzegovina has always been a part of Europe and the world and has accepted all positive and open-minded influences. You can see that on every corner of our beautiful country.
Many of us were young people during the student turmoil in 1968, but we also remember that the students and the pupils from Sarajevo, while following an example of their European counterparts, were” realistic and looking for impossible” under the police sticks. Even today, when we boast about our democratic accomplishments in our countries, we must be aware, especially us politicians, that there can never be enough of freedom, that the liberation has not been completed and that there are always barricades to be removed in order to be able to communicate freely.
Therefore, the “Sarajevo Winter” has been good news from Bosnia and Herzegovina for 24 years, and not even the snow or the ice that frequently covers the surrounding hills, could hinder the creative communication with the thousands of artists from worldwide, nor the fog that closes the airport, not even 1479 days of the longest military siege in history. The “Sarajevo Winter” has become a global cultural phenomenon, like no other festival in the world, because of the fact that it has endured all trials believing in art and artists, believing in good.
It is my honor to welcome you to the International Festival “Sarajevo Winter” in Bosnia and Herzegovina, during the European year of intercultural dialogue.

title: SPEECH BY BIH PRESIDENCY MEMBER DR HARIS SILAJDŽIĆ ON A RECEPTION AT THE PRESIDENCY IN HONOR OF THE UPCOMING HOLIDAYS
content:
Ladies and gentelmen, Excellencies,
Dear friends,
It is my pleasure to welcome you to the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina reception in honor of the upcoming religious holidays and the New Year.
These holidays present an opportunity to remember where we come from and what preceded the times in which we live. Bosnia and Herzegovina, a country of the „good Bosnians,“ as our neighbors would call us, was mostly a good example of coexistence for hundreds of years. Mutual respect, tolerance for another and for the differences, openness and good neighborly relations were the rule, not an exception. It was not easy to accomplish all that in this region. We were destined to live at a fault-line that more often than not was a meeting point of different peoples, ideologies, religions, interests and everything else that is common to all people, but slightly different between them.
This means that our predecessors invested in coexistence, that they not only tolerated each other, that, under trying times and different regimes, they found a way to provide to themselves and their ancestors a normal life to the extent that, as we sometimes say, the circumstances allowed it. They accomplished this without the aid of the communication mechanisms that we today have at our disposals, without the human rights conventions, without the United Nations and the civil society. They did not dispute the harmony that flows out of the multitudes, the unity of the differences, nor the quality that is produced by pluralism. They did not theorize about the enrichment of the different cultures that meet here in the upward spiral. They did not organize round tables about the expansion of horizons and the benefits of a pluralistic society. They simply lived together and mostly attempted to make their lives easier.
In our times which are the times of uniting, exchange, cooperation, communications, and meetings, this task appears far easier and simpler. Led by the example of those who came before us, we must find a way to turn some defeats into victories and to leave a society and a state that is comfortable to live in to the generations that will come after us.
The human and material resources allow us to do that. If we unite our strengths, our country can become prosperous for all its people in a relatively short time. This means that we can provide everyone with modern education, good health care, employment, and that we can generally have a good living standard.
We finally came to a time that we can be free in our country regardless of the difficulties that we face. But freedom, above all, means responsibility and duty to respect the freedom and the rights of another. That obliges us to continue to work on establishing the rule of law in the full sense.
The curing of the society as a whole, its security and stability, cannot be accomplished as long as those who are responsible for the crimes in our country are not brought to justice. Unfortunately, some of them today enjoy complete freedom, and even the privileges of working in the security structures, in local and other government bodies.
We owe this primarily to the victims of the crimes, to those who defended the freedom and independence of our country and to the generations that are still to come.
Ladies and gentlemen, Excellencies, dear friends,
It is a promising fact that we were able to meet the requirements for the initialing of the Stabilization and Association Agreement with the European Union despite our political differences. We will do everything in our power to continue the on the path of integration of our country into the European Union and the NATO alliance. I am certain that our partners in the international community will help us in those aspirations. Our success is their success as well.
Finally, I wish to all of you, as well as all of the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina, to spend the upcoming religious holidays and the New Year in peace and surrounded by your loved ones, neighbors and friends.
Thank you!

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić’s address at the Formal Academy on occasion of the 2nd anniversary of the BiH Armed Forces, Sarajevo, 30.11.2007
content:
Today is the second anniversary of the BiH Armed Forces – a common holiday of all of us that consider BiH our homeland, regardless of the Entity we live in, or to which people and religion we belong. I stress out that the BiH Armed Forces first, in this country, realized and practically carried out the unique and joint action, and that is a fact and the reason for pride of everyone who worked on that goal as well as of the entire BiH.
BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić’s address at the Formal Academy on occasion of the 2nd anniversary of the BiH Armed Forces, Sarajevo, 30.11.2007
“Dear excellencies,
Gentlemen generals, officers and noncommissioned officers,
Gentlemen soldiers,
Dear guests,
Allow me to congratulate you the BiH Armed Forces Day on behalf of the BiH Presidency as well as personally and to wish you all plenty of personal fortune and success in performing such an honorable and a responsible duty.
Today is the second anniversary of the BiH Armed Forces – a common holiday of all of us that consider BiH our homeland, regardless of the Entity we live in, or to which people and religion we belong.
I stress out that the BiH Armed Forces first, in this country, realized and practically carried out the unique and joint action, and that is a fact and the reason for pride of everyone who worked on that goal as well as of the entire BiH.
It in fact speaks about the character of the people who now comprise the BiH Armed Forces or are outside of it, who gave their contribution to their development.
Those people are professionals, in every sense of the word.
Just as many times before, I reiterate that the Armed Forces are the better part of the BiH society, and many of us should follow their example in work and behavior.
The BiH Armed Forces exerted a great effort and restructured their lines, which elevated the level of proficiency to a higher level. For many reasons, thanks to the BiH Armed Forces, our country has become a member of the Partnership for Peace and it is now getting closer to the required standards for the NATO membership.
Worthy representation of our country and fulfilling complex and risky tasks in the peace missions in various parts of the world is a reason for all of us to be proud.
It is commonly forgotten that the engagement and the professional behavior of its members in the peace mission greatly contributes to the reputation of BiH.
These Armed Forces deserve to have their life and work conditions improved in every way and to have the maximum of understanding and support.
In any case, I will stand for elevating the budgetary funds for the Armed Forces to the required level, which is in accordance with the NATO demands.
It is a matter of extreme importance for preservation and improvement of professionalism and human dignity, because the state institutions, with their attitude, even negligence, must not humiliate, in any way, the members of their armed forces and, by doing so, to hold down BiH’s path to a full-fledged NATO membership.
In that sense, I wish you all plenty of that success and I promise you a full support.
Once again, happy holiday and thank you!”

title: Address by BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić to the representatives of the French Enterprises’ Association
content:
I wish to express a great pleasure with the presentation of economic possibilities of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the MEDEF International and to emphasize our determination further to intensify economic relations with the Republic of France.
Pariz, 28.11.2007
Ladies and gentlemen,
Mr. General Director Montaigne,
I wish to express a great pleasure with the presentation of economic possibilities of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the MEDEF International and to emphasize our determination further to intensify economic relations with the Republic of France.
Our desire is to make this meeting a driving force of the economic cooperation between France and BiH.
The fact that BiH is a NATO Partnership for Peace program member and a potential candidate for entering the European Community, opens the possibilities for starting a new phase of cooperation in the economic filed.
Regardless of the circumstances and the subtlety of our political situation deriving from the complexity of the regional context, the BiH economy is in a constant rise: in 2005 GDP rose by 5.3%, in 2006 by 7.1%. The World Economic Outlook envisages the real GDP rise by 6.0% in next two years.
BiH manages to maintain its macroeconomic stability with economic growth, stable currency and low inflation.
When analyzing our trade exchange, many would be surprised that BiH exports in France more and isn’t that an opportunity for France to “come” in BiH. We are expecting you as businessmen and as tourists as well!
Improving the investment climate and the economic growth results in 4.4 billion EUR of direct foreign investments.
BiH is now offering a favorable legal and investment environment for foreign investments; numerous bilateral agreements is an advantage and human resources our greatest treasure.
We are certain there is plenty of space for intensifying the economic cooperation:
Possibilities for new investments of the French companies in BiH,
Already successful model of joint investments of BiH and French companies for appearance at the third markets,
Cooperation enhancement in the field of tourism.
Very successful ten-year long presence of the IntermarchéGroup in BiH, as well as the arrival of the Lafarge show that BiH can be an attractive destination for the French investments.
Isn’t the time right for a French bank to come in Bosnia and Herzegovina, where big Austrian banks have been working successfully for a longer period, as well as the investors from Germany, Italy, Turkey, countries of the Persian Gulf? In that sense, we welcome the interest of Société Générale in coming in our country.
The food industry is a very attractive sector for the French investment.
We are preparing great infrastructure projects, the BiH highway among them, within the Vc Corridor, which should in the shortest way link the Baltic and the Adriatic Sea.
There are possibilities for increasing the trade exchange volume in both directions. BiH companies’ interest in business with your country is great. Examples are the Aluminija Mostar, the ASA PREVENT Group and our wood industry.
There are also possibilities for cooperation in the field of energy, civil engineering, pharmaceutical and chemical industry and electric engineering.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Tourism is also an opportunity for intensifying our cooperation.
I avail myself of this opportunity to thank the French Government for the expertise help in the elaboration of our country’s tourist strategy. Besides the French Government experts, the consortium of French consultants from the renowned companies ORGALIS and BCEOM were engaged in two important projects.
Study on property relations and tourist sector in BiH
Drafting the Business Plan for the Bjelašnice and Igman tourist centre
Your great experience as a tourist superpower will be of great use to the country, which, considering its potentials, aspires to become a preferable destination for the French.
We wish the Accor, Pomagalski or Pierre et Vacance groups’ soon participation in the development of the BiH tourist offer, to which the presence of AIRFrance would significantly contribute.
Gentlemen, we are here for those reasons and we are at your service.
This is also an invitation to visit Bosnia and Herzegovina!

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić’s address at the Regional Economic Forum for the South East Europe
content:
It is my great pleasure to address the participants of this year’s Regional Economic Forum for the South East Europe, which is held for the fourth time, topic is “Competitors and partners on the path to Europe”.
Ladies and gentlemen!
It is my great pleasure to address the participants of this year’s Regional Economic Forum for the South East Europe, which is held for the fourth time, topic is “Competitors and partners on the path to Europe”.
The presence of such a large number of Heads of States clearly speaks about the importance of the Forum itself and the selected topic.
Professor Zlatko Lagumdžija’s address about the latest Report of the World Economic Forum and the analysis of parallel indicators of competitiveness of the regional countries and the countries in the immediate neighborhood speaks enough about the seriousness of the economic situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Unfortunately, I must assert that such economic state is a consequence of the political crisis, which has been, more or less, present since the Dayton Agreement. The crisis has escalated these days with the Bosnia and Herzegovina Council of Ministers Chairman’s resignation and the certain paralysis in both of the Parliament Houses at the state level.
Even though all politicians in our country agree that the road to the European integration is the only true solution, some of them persistently refuse reforms necessary for advancing in that road.
Unified political will, therefore, exists only declaratively, and in reality, it does not allow the implementation of reforms and decisions that are conditions for entering the European Union, with all negative political and economic consequences that are clear to us.
Cooperation with the countries of the South East Europe, for the mentioned reasons, is even more important for Bosnia and Herzegovina and we are very pleased it has been progressing with most of those countries in a satisfactory way, politically and economically.
The fact is that it ranks 104th in the list of 127 countries in the world, in relation to the global competition index, which is a lot worse then the previous two years and we must be seriously upset about it. I am still convinced that we have the potential for a relatively quick progress, economically speaking, if we can first solve the current political crisis.
I am not basing my optimism merely on a wish that Bosnia and Herzegovina would not be a country that the youth wants to leave and where a great part of the population lives in poverty, but also on the recent assessments and prognoses of the European Commission, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
I will cite a few economic indicators on which at least moderate optimism of these prominent international institutions is based.
When it comes to the macroeconomic stability, several indicators are showing progress. GDP in 2006 was 6.2%, and 4.3% the previous year, which was a consequence of the growing domestic demand and the significant export increase. A significant contribution to it was provided from the industrial production and civil engineering, which is encouraging. The total export increased by 29% in relation to the year before and reduced our trade balance.
Direct foreign investments, so needed in our country, have significantly increased, in that way increasing the foreign exchange reserves by 25%. The foreign debt of Bosnia and Herzegovina has been reduced from 26% of GDP in 2005 to 21% in 2006.
The improved total macroeconomic indicators in 2006 also resulted in improving all indicators that depend on macroeconomic stability. For example, savings of the population have significantly increased reaching the level of 4.8 billion KM.
The financial sector development, in banking and other financial services as well, was significant in 2006. This especially refers to the leasing and the insurance services, as well as the micro credit sector reaching 2.5% of GDP.
Optimism can also be noticed in the human resources development, so important for gaining competitive advantages in the foreign markets. The Framework Law on the state-level higher education has been made, and the implementation of reforms in accordance with the Bologna Declaration should bring about higher successfulness and faster graduation of students at universities.
The export and industrial production structure, which was unfavorable for a long time after the war due to the domination of the products of lower phases of processing, is now gradually improving toward the products of higher phases of processing.
We are encouraged that small and medium enterprises in the private sector increasingly show dynamic growth, in spite of the still unfavorable overall business environment in our country. The total support to this business sector, which generates most of new jobs, has been improved in both entities, i.e. the Republic of Srpska and the Federation, even though it still has not been coordinated at the state-level.
Positive characteristics of the Bosnia and Herzegovina’s economy should include the fact that we are a small open economy with the total trade exchange of 103% of our GDP. That is encouraging and increases the chances for economic cooperation with the countries of the South East European region, especially after our signing the CEFTA Agreement.
The European Union is still our most important trade partner participating with almost 70% in export from Bosnia and Herzegovina, and around 60% in import.
BDP per capita in our country, corrected for the purchasing power index, has reached around 30% of the European Union’s average.
Ladies and gentlemen, the mentioned positive facts about the economy of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which exist despite the political situation and the unfavorable business environment, are not intended, on my part, to hide an extremely bad place in the rank order of countries monitored by the World Economic Forum, or our other objective and subjective weaknesses.
On the contrary, this address of mine at the today’s Regional Economic Forum for the South East is intended to motivate you all for cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina as a partner and a competitor on the way to Europe.
Thank you.

title: BiH Presidency Member Dr. Haris Silajdžić’s speech on reception on the occasion of celebration of the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
It is my distinct pleasure to welcome you to the reception in honor of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Sixty-seven years ago, on November 25, 1943 in Mrkonjic Grad, the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina was confirmed at the First Assembly of the Anti-fascist Council of Bosnia and Herzegovina (ZAVNOBiH). Four days later, on November 29, in Jajce, at the Second Assembly of the Anti-fascist Council of Yugoslavia (AVNOJ), Bosnia and Herzegovina, through the will of its political representatives
Ladies and gentlemen, respected excellencies,
dear friends
It is my distinct pleasure to welcome you to the reception in honor of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Sixty-seven years ago, on November 25, 1943 in Mrkonjic Grad, the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina was confirmed at the First Assembly of the Anti-fascist Council of Bosnia and Herzegovina (ZAVNOBiH). Four days later, on November 29, in Jajce, at the Second Assembly of the Anti-fascist Council of Yugoslavia (AVNOJ), Bosnia and Herzegovina, through the will of its political representatives, entered the former Federative People’s Republic of Yugoslavia (FNRJ) as one of its six federal units.
The importance of this date was especially confirmed in the struggle against the aggression between 1992 and 1995. ZAVNOBIH confirmed the statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina in its medieval borders, which are among the oldest boundaries in Europe. As a result, today’s generation owes a great debt to our predecessors who, during World War II, preserved the integrity of the medieval Bosnian state in their heroic and just struggle against fascism. Through their resistance and bravery, the patriots of our country stayed on top of this honorable tradition, and were able to preserve the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
These historical facts are undisputable because ZAVNOBiH is the deed and legacy of all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which fully confirmed the historical and political individuality of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a multireligious, multiethnic, and multicultural state of the Bosniaks, Serbs, Croats and others.
I am sadened that with us tonight are not all of the represetantives of Bosnia and Herzegovina, that is those who do not recognize this holiday because they believe that the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state begins in Dayton. The Dayton Agreement ended the war and confirmed the already existing statehood and independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the first Article of that Agreement clearly states that Bosnia and Herzegovina shall continue its legal existence under international law as a state.“ Anex II of that Agreement emphasizes that „[a]ll laws…in effect within the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina when the Constitution enters into force shall remain in effect…until otherwise determined by a competent governmental body of Bosnia and Herzegovina.” As a result, Bosnia and Herzegovina does have the Law on state holidays back from its republic days, and November 25 is the BiH Statehood day under that Law.
I hope that over time all representatives of this country will recognize these undisputable historical facts, including this date as the Statehood day of our common country. The representatives of the Serbs, Bosniaks, Croats and other citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina behaved in such a manner, united in the anti-fascist movement, through their adoption of a political decision that paved the way to organize their country according to their will and interests based on the results of the armed struggle of the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
After forty-seven years of peace on the basis of that struggle, Bosnia and Herzegovina faced an attack by a new wave of facism and extreme nationalism, that had as its goal not only the destruction of the Bosnia and Herzegovina statehood, but of an entire people as well. Milosevic's Serbia, together with the political representatives and the military, paramilitary, and police forces of the then self-proclaimed Republika Srpska, attacked with all available might the Bosnian cities and tows, holding the capital Sarajevo under siege for 1,300 days, which is the longest siege of a city in modern military history. Forcible removal of population, killings of civilians and concentration camp were orchestrated. The entire organized campaign ended with the most gruesome crime of all – the crime of genocide.
Despite the overwhelming advantage of the aggressor, the patriots of this country of all nationalities rose to the defense of Bosnia and Herzegovina, unarmed, but ready to defend their homeland and its people. From the very start, this was an uneven struggle, because the aggressor had every weapon available, while the defenders were forced to smuggle even the basic military equipment due to the international arms embargo.
Under these circumstances, the best sons of this country died defending it. This is an oportunity to remember them with the feeling of indebtness and gratitude. We owe our thanks to them because facism did not prevail, because nationalism and one-mindedness do not prevail in Bosnia and Herzegovina of today, and because we can still argue for an exit out of the political crisis for the life of all our people in a stable, democratic, functional and economically developed coutry. To them we also owe the preservation of peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the peace that all of them fought for, so that the future of their loved ones will be brigter from the recent past.
We have much to do in all these fields. In the last twelve years, some strides were made in the fields of monetary and tax policy, as well as defense policy and some other fields, but all this is not sufficient to allow Bosnia and Herzegovina to be a functional state and to undertake all necessary reforms for the entry into the European Union. Today there is almost no relevant political option within Bosnia and Herzegovina, including the representatives of the international community, that does not believe that the Dayton Constitution must be changed. This period is ahead of us, but in the meantime we must do all in our power to ensure that the Dayton Constitution, as long as it is in force, is fully implemented. The Dayton Constitution, as any other constitutuion, is respected through its full implementation, and not through empty and politically motivated declarations.
On this road, Bosnia and Herzegovina direly needs the help of the international community. With this in mind, the continuation of the OHR mission and the foreign troop presence is necessary, and we especially welcome the today's decision on the extension of the mandate of the EU Police mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina. In addition to the active presence and participation of the international community in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the people of this country must receive motivation from Brussels. Instated of a strong support of the European Union at the time of a political crisis, Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered a disappointment due to the European Commission's decision to allow Serbia to initial the SAA, while postponing a similar move with respect to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
While Bosnia and Herzegovina completely respects the right of the European Commission to independently decide whether to continue the talks with another State, it is critical to note that Bosnia and Herzegovina has a legitimate stake and interest in this matter. On February 26 this year, in a dispute between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia, the International Court of Justice found Serbia responsible for violations of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide (the Genocide Convention) on three counts, holding that Serbia has violated the Convention by, inter alia, failing to prevent genocide in Bosnia and Herzegovina and for failing to arrest and transfer to the ICTY the persons accused of the crime of genocide. With respect to the ordered measures, the Court ruled that Serbia must immediately arrest and transfer to the ICTY the individuals in question. Needless to say, Serbia has ignored the Court’s order, thereby continuing to violate its international obligations towards Bosnia and Herzegovina under the Genocide Convention.
Considering these international obligations, and in light of the previous unequivocal European Commission’s pronouncements, we can only understand the Commission’s decision as having been influenced by the impending resolution of the Kosovo status. Such strategy, however, does not promise results, as history has demonstrated that an appeasement of the nationalist forces in Serbia in one field has never occasioned a positive resolution of another matter. More importantly, the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina are distressed over the fact that the Commission has effectively embraced a country that continues to violate the most important international obligations toward another prospective member State. Equaling of the blame for the failure of police reform could have been at one point understood as a temporary political need, but time has demonstrated that such strategy brings no results either. The time has come to finally call things by their true name.
The European Commission has refused to proceed with the initialing of the SAA with Bosnia and Herzegovina due to the fact that the police reform has not yet been carried out by Bosnia and Herzegovina. For years, we have witnessed the obstruction of all attempts to usher in police reform in Bosnia and Herzegovina, starting with the Martens plan, and continuing with the plan of the Police Reform Directorate. All of these plans were put forward by the European Union institutions and all of them have been rejected by the leadership of the Republika Srpska entity. While it was clear from the start that Serbia played an important role in encouraging such obstruction, the recent pronouncements by both the President and the Prime Minister of Serbia have offered solid proof of this fact.
I, hence, avail myself of this opportunity to clearly state that this is not 1992, that this time the radical forces in Belgrade are not able to transform their wishes into actual deeds, and that it is high time that Serbia turns to solving its own problems, but also to the fulfillment of a number of international obligations that it still has towards Bosnia and Herzegovina. Considering, however, that Belgrade has already managed to create a certain level of political crisis, there is a danger of individual excesses, which is proven by the recent armed attack near Banja Luka on Mr. Murat Tahirovic. The international community, hence, is aware that it needs to double its efforts in order to prevent the continued importation of this manufactured political crisis into Bosnia and Herzegovina in order to especially protect the returnee population in the RS entity. Such an engagement is the only way to ensure the full stability of Bosnia and Herzegovina and its progress toward Euro-Atlantic integrations.
There are indications that the international community is aware of this obligation and responsibility, and I therefore view the meeting of the presidents of political parties in two days in Sarajevo with optimism. I believe that the Mostar Declaration opens the possibilities for the return of the country onto the European path, and that we must continue to work on this. We need to continue the dialogue, with the goal of overcoming this manufactured political crises in Bosnia and Herzegovina, with the final goal of a democratic, functional and modern Bosnia and Herzegovina, a member of the EU and NATO, and based on the strong legacy of the anti-fascist struggle of all its peoples and citizens.
Once again, I wish you a sincere welcome, and I thank you for honoring the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina by your presence here.

title: A welcoming speech of BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić on occasion of celebrating 64 years of holding ZAVNOBiH, Sarajevo, 20.11.2007
content:
On November 25, 1943, in Mrkonjić Grad, right in the middle of the subjugated Europe, for the first time in the BiH history, representatives of all its peoples met and made a political decision that represented a turning point in the history of BiH, laying a foundation for a modern and democratic BiH.
ZAVNOBiH counselors,
Your excellencies,
Comrades,
ladies and gentlemen,
dear friends,
esteemed guests,
dear citizens,
On November 25, 1943, in Mrkonjić Grad, right in the middle of the subjugated Europe, for the first time in the BiH history, representatives of all its peoples met and made a political decision that represented a turning point in the history of BiH, laying a foundation for a modern and democratic BiH.
In Mrkonjić Grad, based on the principles of Antifascism, a historic turning point of bringing Bosnia and Herzegovina to all its peoples was made.
ZAVNOBiH was a session of the Bosnia and Herzegovina’s Antifascists comprising the members of all its peoples.
Dear friends,
At this moment, there are still those who favor the ideologies that did not recognize BiH, just as they do not recognize it now. Today, just like in the World War II, those that favor certain ideologies are claiming BiH exclusively for the Serbs, the Croats or the Bosniacs and see it only as they would like it to be, to their taste.
In BiH today, there are political forces that would prefer erasing Antifascism from the history of this country. There are also strong political forces that prefer, mildly put, forgetting the ZAVNOBiH principles. Negating ZAVNOBiH and its principles, as principles that ensure the equality of all BiH peoples and citizens, on the entire territory of BiH, is in fact a negation of the existence of BiH as a state. It is also a negation of the present universal democratic principles, the principles equalizing all people, regardless of their ethnic background, religious belief, political affiliation, etc.
Regarding the appropriate ways to celebrate the BiH Independence Day, i.e. not celebrating it in certain areas, I wish to emphasize the following:
The day of signing the Dayton Peace Agreement is an important day of the recent BiH history and no one should or can refute it, however, November 25 – the ZAVNOBIH Day – is sacred, untouchable and the only Independence Day of our homeland.
Those that negate it should be aware of the fact that by negating November 25 they are also negating the principle of constitutionality of all peoples in all parts of the BiH territory. In that way, and citing the national interests of their people, they are, most of all, harming their very own people denying them the same rights on the entire territory of BiH, especially in those parts of BiH where their people are not a majority.
The principle that certain parts of BiH are in fact a war trophy of peoples, parties, individuals and an exclusive life space for members of one ethnic, religious, political or any kind of group, is in fact Fascism. Need I remind you that the fascism has already been defeated once and historically speaking, does not stand a chance?
Dear friends,
It seems that the ZAVNOBiH principles have never been more necessary than today. The resistance to the equality of peoples and individuals on the entire territory of BiH is strong. It comes from the political and interest groups that, above all, protect their material and economic interest, often criminal, as well as their war trophies, by inspiring fear in ordinary people, citing the so-called national interests. As if the highest nationals interest is not living in security and peace, having equal rights as others, regardless of the ethnic, religious, political or any other affiliation, regardless of the quantity, regardless of the political conviction, regardless of the part of BiH in which we live, or similar. In long term, that policy of fear does not stand a chance, in BiH or in the Balkan, especially in the united Europe.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is our homeland, built on the several-century long way of life. The way of life, that of course means us living with each other, not beside each other.
Ladies and gentlemen, comrades, for some time now, simply put, our civilized way of life has been in danger. The way of life with room for all of us, different as we are, as God or the nature has made us!
Will we defend it?
I will!
Happy holiday and thank you!

title: Address of the Chairman of Bosnia and Herzegovina Presidency H.E. Mr. Željko Komšić on the occasion of The Srebrenica Investment Conference
content:
It is a great honor and pleasure to welcome you, and to wish you a pleasant stay and pleasant company at this reception organized on the occasion of The Srebrenica Investment Conference.
Sarajevo 05.11.2007, Konak residency
Ladies and gentlemen, distinguished guests, your Excellencies, distinguished media representatives.....
It is a great honor and pleasure to welcome you, and to wish you a pleasant stay and pleasant company at this reception organized on the occasion of The Srebrenica Investment Conference.
We all know that 12 years ago Srebrenica unfortunately became a planetary known town of Bosnia and Herzegovina, so on this occasion I will not remind you of the tragic event that forever placed Srebrenica in the history as a place where genocide occurred.
This is a time when we have to help Srebrenica to leave the dark tunnel of desolate streets; somber facades covered with grenade scars and ill feeling of death that can be felt by looking at each of the thousands of tomb stones in Srebrenica.
Time and life require of us to turn to future, and there is no future without work, but also without the aid required in that sense.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a small and developing country, but a country which wishes to join the circle of developed countries. Not as a pendant or an adolescent who always needs help, but as someone who will do Europe and ourselves proud.
I would like to emphasize that this is the moment to encourage Srebrenica to integrate itself in the wider economic development of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and also of the South Eastern Europe. Furthermore this is the moment to encourage not only foreign but domestic investment as well, investment that will help this area to stand on its own feet and to move forward to, I’m convinced, a brighter future.
Personally, I believe that regardless of the current political uncertainty our country is facing, it is time that we turn to economic development and prosperity, that will not only for us, but especially for the future generations open a road towards a better tomorrow and give them a reason to stay here and build Bosnia and Herzegovina as better, more beautiful and much more appealing to live in, instead of waiting in lines and doing everything in order to leave their homeland.
This Conference is an opportunity to concretely consider possibilities of what can be done for the area of Srebrenica, to make return sustainable, not only thru donations and aid, but mostly thru investing in development of infrastructure as well as economic potentials and capacities, because people in Srebrenica wish and want to work.
I believe that this is the only way to motivate young people to come, to return, to stay and to decide to build their better tomorrow there, because there is no future anywhere without educated and qualified youth.
My wishes and my work are focused in this direction. I wish for others to except it and I will be especially happy and proud if The Srebrenica Investment Conference leads this way.
As for mutual solidarity I will appeal and address only the mayors of the municipalities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, by function my former colleagues. I know that every municipality in Bosnia and Herzegovina has a great deal of its own problems but the situation in Srebrenica is now the hardest. However, with a little of heart and soul each of the municipalities can in its own way help Srebrenica and I am sure that Srebrenica will never forget this and will give them back much more.
In the end I would like to take the opportunity to welcome you and to thank you for showing your support to the conference and to the development of Srebrenica area.
I wish you a pleasant evening and thank you once again for your presence.

title: Speech of esteemed cardinal Tercisio Bertone, the Secretary of State
content:
Mr. President, the esteemed, the revered, ladies and gentlemen,
Today is a historic day in the relations between the Holy See and Bosnia and Herzegovina. It signifies the end of an era and the beginning of a new that one we want marked with a long and fruitful cooperation. The importance of the act is evident: regulations agreed with the Basic Agreement signed on April 19, 2006 went into effect due to it; the Agreement designated the paragraphs of mutual interest for the Catholic Church’s life and work in Bosnia and Herzegovina. They notably referred to the recognition of a legal personality of the Catholic Church and its institutions within the civil society, its independence in piety and apostolate, its specific contributions in cultural, educational, pastoral, military, philanthropic and charity area, as well as the medias.
Mr. President,
I thank you for your words, as well as for the atmosphere in which the path of negotiations was completed.
Not going into further details, I would only like to remind that the Agreement signified a positive process of strengthening the law and democratic principles on which Bosnia and Herzegovina wants to base its future. Practicing religious freedom by every individual citizen and religious community in a legal framework is actually an unavoidable foundation of the western culture and represents a necessary condition for respecting the human rights in all parts of the world. However, the principle of equality before the law requiring a different position toward the different realities is recognized in the same manner. Therefore, in this case, contrary to what may happen in case of other religious communities, we are faced with a legal instrument that has an international character, as a consequence of the fact that the Holy See, i.e. the central administration of the Catholic Church, consisted of the Roman Archpriest and institutions of the Roman Curia helping him in His service (usp. ZKP, kan. 361), is a subject of the international law, independent due to the fact that it enjoys the same sovereignty in the territory of Vatican as any other state. Particularity of the institutional organization of the Catholic Church therefore requires special position on the part of the States, so that its believers would be guaranteed the generally recognized rights in a special way.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
In a country, such as Bosnia and Herzegovina, which includes a multiethnic and multireligious society within its borders, this Agreement represents the best legal guarantee of ensuring a proper implementation of religious life, first of all in its public implications. Proper implementation of the agreed will favor the country, since it will present a positive image of itself in the international scene; it will contribute to surpassing difficult problems inherited from the past and building a better future; country’s aspirations can be achieved in the future, the country which historically and geographically represents a unique crossroads of different identities, but which rightfully belongs to Europe.
Its diversity, in a globalized world such as ours, should become everybody’s source of enrichment. The Holy See, on its part, will not stop paying a special attention to different issues that appear in that joint walk, and wished the Catholic believers’ community to continue to contribute to the enrichment of the entire Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The additional protocol, signed on September 29, 2006, which is an integral part of the agreement, envisages an appeal of the mixed commission that might support its interpretation and application. I am convinced that the commission will be useful for preserving the spirit of cooperation that marked the course of negotiations.
Mr. President, the esteemed, the revered, ladies and gentlemen,
I whole-heartedly wish that the implementation of the regulations of this international agreement would benefit the peaceful coexistence and the entire development of the country, as well as to support the local Catholic Church in performing the task that Christ entrusted it with, for the wellbeing of the entire population of this country.

title: Speech by BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić on occasion of signing the Basic Agreement with the Holy See
content:
Exchanging the ratification instruments of the Basic Agreement between the Holy See and Bosnia and Herzegovina - Vatican, 25.10.2007
BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić’s Speech
Your Eminence, Mr. State Secretary, esteemed Cardinal Bertone,
It is my pleasure to greet you on behalf of the State institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina, especially the BiH Presidency, as well as personally. I also greet the Holy See Delegation, particularly Cardinal Vinko Puljić, our fellow citizen and your colleague in the Cardinal Body, your associates and everyone present. I do it with a special pleasure, because the meeting organized on occasion of completing such an important and well-done job that everyone can be satisfied with, is actually a true and the deepest satisfaction.
The Basic Agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Holy See, and its formal exchange of the ratification instruments that gathered us, began as an idea with your esteemed predecessor in these very premises in early nineties, last century, when the war was still going on in our country as well as the ordeal of the innocent people throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina. Therefore, I avail myself of the opportunity warmly to thank you for full support in those difficult times to our independent, threatened from outside and from within, and wounded country, the support that came from Pope John Paul II – a great pope, a serene memory and the Holy See, that has kept on till today, which I have witnessed during the today’s very affectionate talk with Pope Benedict XVI. We in Bosnia and Herzegovina do not forget the strong appeals of Voytila from 1992 to the European and world men of power to stop the war in our country, and the citizens do not forget his Sunday homilies either when he refused to miss the opportunity to warn about their trials. We also remember his efforts to appoint our man a cardinal of his Church and his sincere wishes to visit Sarajevo in early war years, 1994, to warn the world that senseless sufferings must cease. His two later friendly visits to our country, Sarajevo and Banjaluka, are also remembered, the visits that were inspired by preaching peace, just solutions and concern for the exiled and the refugees. We impatiently await Pope Benedict XVI’s visit to Bosnia and Herzegovina, whom I had the opportunity to officially invite to visit us. Therefore, ratifying the Basic Agreement, whose serious preparations and adoption was accompanied by extremely good relations between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Holy See, ended a phase of our bilateral relations and has simultaneously opened a new page that I hope we would fill in, directly and trough our diplomatic representatives, to a mutual pleasure.
Your Eminence, Mr. Secretary of State,
Allow me to use this brief address to emphasize the significance of the Basic Agreement in view of formally re-recognizing the two international subjects, the State of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Holy See, with this document.
For our country, a community of equal peoples and citizens, multinational, multireligious, of multicultural efforts, civil in the sense that the religious communities have their guaranteed freedoms, that bears a special value not only at this moment.
By accepting the Agreement, we have accepted the international democratic principles of the modern world as our own; the atmosphere such as the one in the European Union countries, which membership Bosnia and Herzegovina desires.
It is worth emphasizing in the moment of completing the job that Bosnia and Herzegovina, based on this Agreement, has created a legal framework for the Catholic Church’s work in our country, which is a historic step forward. Of course, that is not favoring in regard to the other religious communities because Bosnia and Herzegovina is intensively working on contractual regulation of relations and all religious communities. This Basic Agreement was an inspiration to our work on similar agreements with other religious communities wherein his special value lies. I also believe that it can serve to the Holy See as a quality foundation for reaching bilateral agreements with those states that have conditioned demographic structure and are enriched with multicultural and multicivilization intricacies.
Your Eminence,
With all accompanying difficulties of the post-war and transitional society, Bosnia and Herzegovina sees itself as a member of the Euro-Atlantic integration. Formerly faster, nowadays slower than we would like, we are heading toward the European Union and NATO, as a safe environment in the great European family of peoples. Now, we are doing it in Bosnia and Herzegovina hoping to succeed and to offer the positive experience as our contribution to others within the mentioned integration and wider. Considering the positive historic secular experience and tradition, as well as the reality of the ever more restless and intolerant modern world, it seems that the choice has no alternative.
Your Eminence,
Wishing a fruitful continuation of a quality cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Holy See, esteemed Mr. Cardinal, I thank you for your friendly and cordial reception for our delegation, and I reiterate my great pleasure for the fact that His Holiness Pope Benedict XVI received us all. I avail myself of the occasion to show proper respect to all those who worked hard on this job and I hope that the enthusiasm would continue. I am convinced that Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Holy See are heading for the period of fruitful and mutually beneficial cooperation.

title: BiH Presidency Member Dr. Haris Silajdžić’s speech at the formal academy on occasion of honoring the fourth anniversary of death of Alija Izetbegović, the first president of the RBIH Presidency
content:
From the very beginning, he distinguished himself by calls for coexistence, affirmation of the values of togetherness, human rights and individual freedoms, tolerance and compromise, both in the inter-ethnic and inter-human relations.
