In the atmosphere that ruled that day, a man of such tolerance and such view of the world represented an enormous capital not only for Bosnia and Herzegovina, but for all others that sought a humanistic exit from a situation that was forced upon by the ideology of murder and
Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, honored friends,
venerable members of the Izetbegovic family,
Towards the end of the eighties and the beginning of the nineties of the past century, Bosnia and Herzegovina was entering one of the most difficult eras of its long history.
The former state neared its expiration date. A plan was hatched for the division of Bosnia and Herzegovina by all means, including mass killings, concentration camps, ethnic cleansing and siege of the cities. In order to serve the goals of the Belgrade regime, the former Yugoslav Peoples Army was purged of all undesirable elements, and a media campaign that was to justify all that was forthcoming was orchestrated. A broad hatred was spread with the goal of severing all social mechanisms of multinational ties between the people, and a struggle for the biological survival of the Bosnian people and the unity of Bosnia and Herzegovina was imminent. This was the time of ethnic mythology, heated passions, and utter confusion. Unveiled threats forecasted bloody years of a collapse of the state and the making of a new order. On the basis of the grand ambitions, especially by the then regime in Belgrade, it was clear from the very start that this would be a war against the civilians and that the struggles would be difficult and unequal.
Against such a backdrop, Alija Izetbegovic appeared on the Yugoslav scene. From the very beginning, he distinguished himself by calls for coexistence, affirmation of the values of togetherness, human rights and individual freedoms, tolerance and compromise, both in the inter-ethnic and inter-human relations. In the atmosphere that ruled that day, a man of such tolerance and such view of the world represented an enormous capital not only for Bosnia and Herzegovina, but for all others that sought a humanistic exit from a situation that was forced upon by the ideology of murder and brute force. Exclusiveness and force were completely alien to his world view and his composition. He was deeply aware of the difficult burden of the past, not only in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but in the entire region, but he remained dedicated in his search for the possibilities of a peaceful solution and compromise.
He remained steadfast in his humanism, even during the hardest of moments, and he was particularly sensitive about human suffering, doing everything in his power to ensure that the victims that were inevitable would be minimal. He did not follow the policy of revenge, and he paid attention about the sensibilities of all in Bosnia and Herzegovina, about tradition, religion, culture and all that is sacred to humanity.
Because of this, those who defended Bosnia and Herzegovina can stand tall because they were not led by the policy of force that responded to brutality with more brutality, destruction, mass killing, concentration camps and all that which branded the aggressors on Bosnia and Herzegovina and those in their service. All that can still be seen today, and it is something that is recognized by the entire world. That policy was pursued with a hope that the seed of coexistence, nurtured by us for hundreds of years, will remain in Bosnia and Herzegovina. As the war removes all masks, and the people show themselves for what they truly are, I can say with full certainty, as can all those who worked and shared difficult moments with him, that Alija was a brave man. He adopted difficult decisions when the choice was limited to bad and the worse. He entered the global stage with very little in favor of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but he persevered. The satisfaction is that he witnessed the defeat and the condemnation of the ideology that brought so much evil and misery to the people of this region. He ascribed the credit for this to our defenders above all others.
He always emphasized that the politics can accomplish only as much as the defenders on the ground allow it. And he always had special words of respect and love for the defenders.
During the long and difficult negotiations, he always sought out the possibility of compromise and peaceful solution, mindful above all of the people in our country who faced numerous tragedies. Srebrenica, and other grounds, are examples on which we should waste no words. He viewed the Dayton agreement as unjust, but he accepted it, as this was, after all, peace, which signified the end of killings, tragedies, and destruction in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Dayton agreement brought peace, but its very nature paved the road for disagreements and obstruction in the post-war period.
Alija Izetbegovic tried by all means to connect the broken mechanisms, he fostered the rebuilding of the inter-people and inter-ethnic relations in our country with his own example.
He was a man of a calm spirit, sedate, benevolent, and he knew how to respect an opinion that differed from his own. He was prone to philosophical reflection and a very amiable and valuable conversation partner.
On one occasion we flew over the Mediterranean coast. I remember that he then said “Look how pretty the earth is, but what good is that when us people are lousy.”
I remember our conversation in April 1992, on the occasion of the recognition of independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina. He said “See what can happen in one day,” and then he added, paraphrasing a thought from the Qur’an – “But after the hard part comes the easy part.”
With Alija Izetbegovic I shared the view on the reality of the former Yugoslavia and a similar understanding of the position of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Bosniak people in those difficult circumstances. We were connected by a shared vision of the future. It is with sadness that I have to say today that I myself, and I believe many others, missed the opportunity to more often examine our own beliefs with this wise man of great political prowess. However, I had the honor to closely work with him up until his death, a very premature death from the viewpoint of the need for his contribution. When the peace was established and when the amalgam of choice increased, President Izetbegovic and I had differences in interpreting the hierarchy of priorities, but we nonetheless remained equally committed in our determination for building a modern and democratic state.
Privately, with his passing I lost a friend and a strong footing.
Izetbegovic always steadfastedly asserted that the highway of Euro-Atlantic integration was the optimum direction of Bosnia and Herzegovina toward a stable and prosperous future. When pronouncing such a statesmanlike position, he always knew that he enjoyed the support of all those who love this country and who are ready to work on transforming that vision into reality.
In conclusion, I would like to emphasize the following:
President Izetbegovic left us all with a debt. The way we repay that debt we express our own commitment to a noble cause that he pursued: Bosnia and Herzegovina as a state and society of free people, such people who are more enriched by their differences than they are divided.
Let him rest in peace and thanks!

title: Farewell speech of the Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Nebojša Radmanović, at the funeral of Dr Milan Jelić, the President of the Republic of Srpska in Modriča
content:
We do not realize it at first, we cannot understand. We are looking for reasons. There are none. Why good men, true friends leave? Then we begin to realize. True parents, good friends, the creators, they complete their missions, because they think faster than we do, they work more than we do, but leave traces, visible road signs.
Dear Jelić family,
Dear friends,
It has been peaceful and silent in Modriča and the entire Republic of Srpska for three days now. Polemics have silenced, there are no divisions, no different opinions. There is a reason for it. Dr Milan Jelić is departing, a son, a husband, a father, a brother, my friend, your friend, the President of the Republic of Srpska.
We do not realize it at first, we cannot understand. We are looking for reasons. There are none. Why good men, true friends leave? Then we begin to realize. True parents, good friends, the creators, they complete their missions, because they think faster than we do, they work more than we do, but leave traces, visible road signs. They should be understood and followed, then our friends are constantly near, then we never forget them. Milan’s traces are clear. We can read clear messages in them. They stem from his life, which was all dedicated to others. His concern about his family, his mother, his wife, his son, his workers at the Refinery, for athletes, for Modriča, for the Republic of Srpska, it was visible.
He wanted things better, prettier, not for himself, but for everybody else, he knew it was possible and how to reach it. Many obstacles in that way, in economy, education, sports, politics, he bravely and decisively jumped over, and some he destroyed for a reason.
No one like him expressed the formula of political living and survival in these restless areas that clearly and precisely; the formula is dialogue and agreement, consensus and compromise.
He was an honorable and straight man. “Freedom is life” – he often sincerely said. He valued honesty, he was honest to others and he expected honesty in return. He truly believed that we should and could live peacefully in this beautiful, yet restless area.
He never reached for someone else’s, but he clearly warned that we should protect our country, our people, and our religion carefully and decisively. It was never pointed against others and he proved it in action. With a successful organization and management, he practically showed that it is possible to suppress exclusivity and achieve success by enforcing tolerance and nurturing equality. Many failed to follow that visionary idea, especially to put it into effect in their political and daily life. That remains a visible road sign for his friends, especially the younger generations that he loved and unselfishly gave his knowledge.
Lifetime is measured in years, but in acts as well. Calculating the years, Milan lived shortly and left too soon, but he belonged to those that know that a man lives as long as his acts to. Therefore, he continued to create and he achieved a lot. His work is a trace we follow that we shall never loose.
Dear friend, you knew what your mission was and why you came to this world. You completed many tasks, we heard your messages and we shall never forget them. A three-day silence and the people’s dignity in the Republic of Srpska show how much everybody loved you and understood you and that binds your friends and followers and warns all the others.
May you rest in peace good man!

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić’s speech on occasion of the 15th anniversary of the 1st BiH Army Corps
content:
Allow me to greet you most cordially and congratulate the 15th anniversary of the 1st BiH Army Corps to us all.
“Dear guests,
Allow me to greet you most cordially and congratulate the 15th anniversary of the 1st BiH Army Corps to us all.
I welcome every soldier, former members of the 1st BiH Army Corps, officers, generals, receivers of the highest war decorations as well as all the present guests.
I especially welcome the members of the shehits’ and killed soldiers’ families.
Not so long ago, this valley and this city echoed in fire bursts, grenades were falling, screaming and crying everywhere! However, there was also song; fists and bodies of this city’s soldiers were clenching with a clear message,”We must persevere, no matter how hard it may be, and we will not give his city to anyone – because it is ours and it must be free! Free for the people who love it to live in it; free for living for those who are yet to be born.” Free for everybody, regardless of his or her name, which God he or she is praying to and for all those who are proud of such a Sarajevo!
Over 10.000 people from Sarajevo gave their lives in that path. Civilians, soldiers, children! We knew how to defend Sarajevo, defend BiH, that is why we have endured; and you can remember knowing it had not been easy. We started in sneakers from Yugosport and jeans, and ended as a respectable military force!
We fought in the bloody battles for the streets and squares, but also for the unknown hills and valleys around Sarajevo that we had not heard of before the war.
We fought for the order and discipline in our units; we fought for an honorable image of a BiH Army member, an image that would clearly show to everyone a difference between us – the defenders of Sarajevo, the members of the 1st Corps and those whose names I do not want even to mention.
In most cases, we succeeded, and we are proud of that and that is why we were supported and helped worldwide. To all those who helped us in any way during those most difficult moments, I thank you on this occasion on behalf of all of us.
However, for the sake of our honor and reputation, for the sake of the truth that is the only sanctuary of honorable and decent men, we must be honest!
There were those among us who did not behave in the war as it was ordered, those who stepped over the line of honor, military and human! There were those who committed horrible acts and crimes, against innocent victims as well as against the powerless enemy; acts and crimes that cannot be forgiven or forgotten.
For the sake of our honor and integrity, we must continue our battles from 15 years ago even today, but this time, also against those who wanted or attempted to sully our honor and heroic deeds. They must be punished. I first, and I believe all honorable members of the 1st Corps, will never accept the slightest stain in our war path because of them.
Therefore, I avail myself of the opportunity, as a highest positioned former member of the 1st BiH Army Corps in Bosnia and Herzegovina and a receiver of the highest Army decoration, on behalf on all honorable and decent fighters of this Corps, to apologize to the families whose members were subjected to impermissible and never ordered crimes and acts committed by certain renegades of this famous Corps. I hope that this apology can alleviate their pain and grief at least a little bit!
Dear fellow soldiers and friends!
You are witnesses, even today, that some still want to divide our country, that certain parts of the country are seen as their war trophy, a war trophy of an individual, party or one people. That is not possible in BiH, nor will it ever be! That is not normal in BiH, that is not the way to live here, nor has it ever been!
We do not accept that a part of BiH is not ours, regardless of its name. When I say ‘ours’, I think of all of us, Bosnians and Herzegovinians, Bosniacs, Serbs, Croats, Jews, others. The entire Bosnia and Herzegovina, every inch of it belongs to all of us, Bosnians and Herzegovinians! No more no less each, equally to all!
Those people do not see that their selfish fight for their daily political and so-call national interests obstruct the interests and wished of the youth from their very own nation.
Some people do not want to have our children studying peacefully together, going to school together, playing together, in the world of knowledge to fight for their place, their city and the country, family, i.e. their people, culture, religion…!
But, I say to you all, them also, BiH will survive, all of us here today such as were are; this country will be happier and prettier, economically wealthier, because that is a BiH we have fought for and that is how one day it is going to be!
Therefore, my dear friends and fellow soldiers let us remain in the same formation of soldiers for BiH that we have solemnly sworn to uphold by joining the ranks of the 1st BiH Army Corps.
This is an invitation to all the citizens of our capital Sarajevo, and entire BiH as well, to support us and together with us build our joint homeland BiH.
Thank you all!
Sarajevo, 01.10.2007

title: BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić’s address at the 62nd session of the United Nations General Assembly
content:
It is my honor as a Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina to participate in this 62nd session of the United Nations General Assembly. I would also like, Mr. President, to congratulate you on your election and to use this opportunity to express my respect and gratitude to H.E. Mrs. Sheikha Haya Rashed Al Khalifa for her successful presentation during the 61st annual session.
Mister President,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my honor as a Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina to participate in this 62nd session of the United Nations General Assembly.
I would also like, Mr. President, to congratulate you on your election and to use this opportunity to express my respect and gratitude to H.E. Mrs. Sheikha Haya Rashed Al Khalifa for her successful presentation during the 61st annual session.
Mister President,
The United Nations, as well as other organizations, depends on the collective strength of its members. Strength must stem from the consensus of the member countries.
In that context, I wish to point out my regret that the Security Council reform has lost its momentum. Over the last years, our countries’ delegations met at a global level, ready to complete the Millennium Declaration Goals, and the role of an efficient UN system has an instrumental significance in its completion.
It is known that my country, in the recent past, has paid a high price due to the imperfect and inefficient UN system. The United Nations themselves have admitted their guilt and in their Report underlined for Srebrenica that “United Nations’ experience in BiH was one of the hardest and most painful in the history of this organization”, that “Srebrenica crystallized the truth that the United Nations and the world had realized far to late: BiH was equally a moral obligation as it was a military conflict” and “the tragedy of Srebrenica will haunt us forever”. The International Court of Justice, the court of the United Nations, on 26.02.2007, gave a verdict in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia and Montenegro concerning the application of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of Genocide Crimes. The Court decided that genocide had been committed against the Bosnian Muslims in and around Srebrenica in the East Bosnia and Herzegovina. Of course, you will agree that it was not an isolated case; all the more reason for BiH decisively to dedicate itself, with a majority of members, to the necessary reform of the world organization.
In the light of that, BiH believes that only strong UN could be an efficient instrument for collective regulation of international relations based on the UN Charter and the International Law. Besides the necessary reform of the Security Council, it is necessary further to work on revitalization: including the reform of the General Assembly and its committees, the Economic and Social Council, the Secretariat and other bodies.
This also includes defining a series of issues, such as: the number and the category of the Security Council members; ways to elect new members; the veto right and its use; regional representation; working methods; and other, all speaking in behalf of the complexity of that ongoing reform process. Productive way ahead certainly leads to opening key negotiations in this context, instead of the previous consultations. I wish to emphasize that the interest of Bosnia and Herzegovina – in case that the reform should result in an increase of non-permanent members of the Security Council- is that the eastern European group certainly deserves one more seat.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a multiethnic and multi-confessional country, with its historic heritage, experienced mistakes of the International Community; the United Nations above all, with severe repercussions to my country. However, a positive experience in the post-war peace construction and cooperation with the UN representatives, organs and agencies, could significantly contribute the United Nations to become an efficient instrument for collective regulation of international affairs. My country believes that peace and security cannot take place without economic and social development. It continues to support the Security Council as an unavoidable body of the international sphere of peace and progress in rights of all nations. Since BiH has outlasted the test of historic challenges and is now able to offer its experience to the turbulent world, it is determined to intensify its commenced activities regarding the candidacy of BiH for the non-permanent Security Council member in the period of 2010 – 2012, expecting an understanding and support of the United Nations member countries for our election in the Security Council.
Mister President,
I come from a country that made a shift from a post-conflict phase to building a modern democratic society and has embarked on the path of integration in the European and Trans-Atlantic structures. Therefore, my country is fully dedicated to strengthening international cooperation at the regional, European and global plan.
With a special satisfaction, I can now stress out that BiH is an active participant in all initiatives and process of regional cooperation of the South East Europe.
During 2007, BiH has received important recognitions for its proactive approach at a regional level. At the SEECP Summit in Zagreb, held on May 10, 2007, a decision was made to elect Sarajevo the Headquarters of the Regional Cooperation Council Secretariat (RCC). The establishment of RCC represents a final phase of South East Europe Stability Pact’s transformation, i.e. the process of taking regional responsibility by the Stability Pact member countries, that is, SEEC member countries. With this decision, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina becomes the center of the future regional cooperation.
BiH has also accepted Sarajevo to be the host of the Disaster Preparedness and Prevention Initiative Secretariat; by doing so, this initiative has been transformed from the framework of the Stability Pact for South Eastern Europe into a regional property. In October 2007, a BiH representative will assume the managerial position at the Regional Arms Control Verification and Implementation Assistance Center (RACVIAC), with the Headquarters in Zagreb.
BiH continues an active cooperation with the regional countries in fight against organized crime. We are actively participating in the SECI Centre for Cross-Border Crime Prevention’s work in Bucharest. By achieving an efficient cooperation with the neighboring countries, establishment of an electronic system for personal documents issuance, as well as an efficient management of border control, BiH has managed significantly to reduce the number of illegal migrants across its territory, as well as all forms of cross-border crime.
With the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) in Vienna, we are developing cooperation in detection and prevention of illegal transport, i.e. the proliferation of radioactive material across the BiH territory.
With the neighboring countries, BiH is building relations based on equality, full independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity. BiH and its neighbors are aware of the fact that development can be fully achieved only by joining the European Union. The goal will be accomplished by continuing the development of neighborly relations in all areas, the democratization of the regional countries and accepting general European standards.
The position of BiH is not interfering in internal issues of sovereign countries, and believes that the Kosovo issue solution should be sought within the dialogue of the concerned parties. BiH supports Belgrade-Priština dialogue, and within regional initiatives, it is prepared to help in finding the solution that would be acceptable for both sides. Bosnia and Herzegovina welcomes the engagement of the Contact Group mediating troika and hopes that they would find a modus for solving the Kosovo status issue. A longer delay in reaching the final Kosovo issue solution would in long-term surely bring negative consequences for the region of Balkan.
Concerning the wider international level, BiH has also achieved important breakthroughs.
In late 2006, Bosnia and Herzegovina was invited to join the NATO Partnership for Peace program as a full-fledged member.
The new recognition followed during the elections for the Human Rights Council (HRC), held in May 2007, when BiH became a member of this new, extremely important body within the system of UN.
On May 31, 2007, BiH assumed the chairmanship duty of the Hague Code of Conduct (HCOC) signed by 126 UN member countries. My country and the Code signatory countries, believing in a collective security, are ready to fight against proliferation of missile technology and are aware of a great threat that non-State factors possessing it pose, which could misuse it for destructive purposes in the world. Therefore, I would like to invite the countries that have not yet joined HCOC, especially those with ballistic capacity, to join the Code. Additionally, I would like to invite all UN members to vote for the Framework of the relevant resolution prepared by Bosnia and Herzegovina and Portugal.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, within its possibilities, has participated and will continue to participate in activities of the International Coalition in fight against terrorism, and has declaratively decided to join the activities of the European Union in view of stamping out terrorism.
In 2006, the BiH Council of Ministers adopted the BiH Strategy for fighting terrorism for the period 2006-2009. The Draft of Reviews and Amendments to the BiH Penal Code in its part concerning the fight against terrorism is in procedure, which will define measures more precisely, i.e. sanctions in fight against international terrorism, in accordance with the international conventions.
Bosnia and Herzegovina supports the intention of other UN members to continue with joint efforts in order to strengthen the UN system for human rights, aiming to ensure the conditions for all people to enjoy all human rights – civil, economic, culture, political, social, development and others.
BiH has accepted the Initiative of the Italian Government to co-sponsor the Resolution on Universal Moratorium on Execution and Abolishment of Death Penalty, which is scheduled for evaluation during the UNGA session.
BiH achieved a significant progress in meeting the requirements according to the instruments for protection of human rights, by filing relevant reports to the UN High Commissariat of Human Rights in Geneva.
I also want to avail myself of this opportunity to emphasize that Bosnia and Herzegovina in UN, during the last couple of years, in cooperation with Jordan, has promoted the work on the new humanitarian world order so that the world would become more efficient in his adequate response and reaction to humanitarian disasters.
Mister President,
The authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina remain permanently resolved to maintain full cooperation with ICTY. All persons suspected of war crimes in the territory of former Yugoslavia, must be brought to justice.
So far, positive steps in cooperation with the Hague Tribunal have been made, on the issue of processing the indictments and delivering the suspects, contacts among competent authorities, ensuring the access to the documentation, creating the working conditions for the court representatives and others in the territory of BiH.
In BiH, a legal framework was created and processing war crimes in the special division of the BiH Court for War Crimes has begun, which is one of the requirements for establishing mutual trust and reconciliation in the post-conflict BiH. Besides that, ICTY should not stop with work until the most wanted war crime suspects are brought to justice, especially the war leaders of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadžić and Ratko Mladić and others.
Mister President,
BiH supports all activities and peace initiatives are directed at conflict prevention. It carefully monitors and supports activities of the Roadmap for establishing a permanent peace in the Middle East. BiH has military observers in Congo and Ethiopia and civilian police in Sudan, Cyprus, Liberia and Haiti, within peace operations of UN. Additionally, BiH has sent a smaller mine action unit to Iraq, as our help to the Iraqi people in establishing a democratic self-sustainable country.
We are convinced that strengthening the UN multilateralism could bring efficient measures in prevention of armed conflicts. In that sense, it is necessary to respect the principles of political independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of all countries, guided by the Declaration on International Law Principles and in full respect of human rights. BiH supports the Quartet Initiative and the Roadmap that provides basis for opening a true dialogue between Israel and Palestine, with the US mediation, and in lines of EU views. BiH appeals for comprehensive, unconditional and reciprocal cessation of hostilities, release of all prisoners and reopening a dialogue on the final two-State solution to the Israeli-Palestinian issue.
BiH invites all ethnic and religious communities in Iraq to abandon sectarianism, actively join political processes, and with joint efforts of the International Community and the Iraqi Government, to encourage the comprehensive national political dialogue, placing an emphasis on full respect of the Geneva Convention set of rules from 1949.
Bearing in mind the possible catastrophic consequences of aggravating the crisis of the Iranian program of nuclear technology development, BiH welcomes Iranian readiness for full cooperation with the International Nuclear Energy Agency and political dialogue with the key actors.
The UN role in solving conflict situations in the world is essential. UN did not play an adequate role granted by the Charter during the world crises, especially in the former Yugoslavia. Iraqi crisis shows how many weaknesses UN is facing in tackling issue of conflict prevention in the world. Unless UN assumes responsibilities mandated by the Charter, a series of numerous unilateral interventions could occur, without the UN control, which could bring grave consequences to the international stability.
Foreign policy of BiH is directed at preservation and enhancement of permanent peace, security and stabile democratic and comprehensive state development and contribution to the international peace and security. In international relations, activities of Bosnia and Herzegovina are based on principles contained in the UN Charter, the Helsinki Final Act and other documents of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, as well as the generally accepted International Law principles.
Recognizing the threat that nuclear, chemical and biological/bacteriological weapon poses to peace and security in the world, especially if possessed by terrorists, BiH has undertaken significant steps toward the establishment of a complete control and prevention of mass destruction weapon dissemination.
BiH has ratified or successively taken the most important international documents from this field, and is ready, in view of an efficient fight against the dissemination of weapon for mass destruction and their means of delivery, for a full cooperation with other countries, as within the relevant multilateral organizations and initiatives, as in the bilateral level.
BiH has adopted the Law on Implementation of Chemical Weapon Prohibition Convention.
As one of the countries most severely affected by the consequences of distribution of explosive elements during the previous war, BiH pays a special attention to the implementation of responsibilities deriving from the Ottawa Convention.
BiH is actively involved in UN programs related to AIDS relief and prevention, an illness that is spreading over the world more and more. BiH’s fight against this vicious disease was defined in the Strategy for Prevention and Fight against AIDS for the period of 2004–2009.
BiH regularly pays its contributions to UN and all other international organizations whose member it is. BiH appeals to other countries as well, especially great contributors, to carry out their duties on time. Above all, this applies to ICTY funding and UN Budget for peace operations, for which member countries have not been regularly paying their contributions.
Mister President,
Two days ago, we had, above all useful and constructive exchange of opinions concerning one of the most serious and potentially dangerous phenomenons of our time – climate change.
I wish to use this opportunity to stress out the crucial importance of a timely and efficient treatment of this issue in the world organization. My country has ratified the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change back in 2000, which went into effect on July 15, 2007. I invite UN members that still have not done so, to do it immediately.
I thank you for your patience and attention.
New York, September 26, 2007

title: Speech by BiH Presidency Chairman Željko Komšić at the UN Special Session on Climate Change – New York (09
content:
It is my honor and pleasure, as a Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, to participate in the meeting that deals with one of the most challenging issues of our time – the climate change.
Dear Chairmen,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my honor and pleasure, as a Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, to participate in the meeting that deals with one of the most challenging issues of our time – the climate change.
Constructive approach to this global issue certainly surpasses the competencies of the respective countries and prompts us differently to view this planet, on which and of which we live. In any case, not from a perspective of our own selfish interest, but from a perspective of sustainable development, i.e. survival of future generations, bearing in mind the necessary basis for the survival of the entire life on earth. If we have been faced with globalization primarily in the economic field, now, we are facing, above all, a serious, planetary problem of global warming.
In spite of the truly impossible mission of predicting the climate development in full, as well as the consequences of its change, there are data that raise no doubt. According to the latest studies, these past 11 years have been the warmest over the last 150 years.
The warming trend is considerably affecting all continents and oceans, and has an extremely negative impact, particularly on the poorest and least developed countries.
There is no dilemma on the need to establish a continuous and productive dialogue, thus avoiding all forms of polarization in debates, especially for the sake of common good, and to do everything possible clearly to articulate the voice of the least developed, poor and vulnerable.
Dear Chairmen,
Allow me briefly to inform you about the activities undertaken in Bosnia and Herzegovina within our today’s debate on the subject of climate change.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has ratified the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change in 2000. The Kyoto Protocol accession instrument of Bosnia and Herzegovina has been deposited at the depository – United Nations Secretary-General on 16.04.2007, and went into force on 15.07, 2007.
Synchronizing the national legislation with the requirements of the European Commission is a priority of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and joining the Kyoto Protocol represented, for our country, one of the basic and key steps in the process of European integration. The next step is the establishment of the Clean Development Mechanisms, and preparations in my country are underway.
The level of greenhouse gasses effects in Bosnia and Herzegovina is currently lower than the level in the specified year of 1990. In spite of that, there is already a series of programs underway in Bosnia and Herzegovina, such as energy consummation rationalization, gasification, afforestation, healthy food production programs etc, which represents a significant basis for joining the protective international activities against global change.
That includes the improvement of meteorological and hydrological system and efficient execution of climate programs within the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), systematic observation and exploration of climate, as well as the maximum development of renewable energy sources (water, wind, sun etc.) and biomass.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has also recently signed the Agreement on Regional Energy Community based on the Athens Memorandum from 2002/3, which established an integrated market of natural gas and electric energy of the South East Europe, based on common interest and solidarity. The goal of the Agreement was to create a legal and economic framework for energy network establishment in the South East Europe and its connecting with the European network, and includes EU acquis implementation in the area of energy, environment, competition and renewable energy sources.
Dear Chairmen,
Today, more than yesterday, and tomorrow inexorably intensive, our countries are becoming complexly interconnected and dependent on each other, and, by the same definition, faced with global climate change, whose impacts must be efficiently tackled by our governments sooner or later, in cooperation with the rest of the world, all in view of sustainable development.
I thank you for attention.

title: BiH Presidency Chairman, Željko Komšić’s address on occasion of 13th Sarajevo Film Festival at Zemaljski muzej BiH in Sarajevo–(8
content:
Ladies and gentlemen,
Dear friends of art,
Dear guests,
I am very pleased to be able to share with you this moment of happiness and contentment when Bosnia and Herzegovina for the thirteenth time presents itself in the world of culture as a centre of film art through the Sarajevo Film Festival.
In addition to film and other cultural activities we had an opportunity, and I am sure that we have used it well, to prove ourselves as good hosts.
Every festival year is a new celebration, a new reason to be happy and to remember the very first beginnings of this festival which started in hard times when it meant something that gave us hope, desire and strength to live.
Throughout years, the Sarajevo Film Festival has grown, developed and matured, so what we have today, I dare to say, is the most prestigious and most influential film festival in the region which is at the same time well known, recognised and appreciated in the whole world.
That is the role assuming huge responsibility, but above all, the festival is primarily the image of heart and sole of our country and Sarajevo.
So let us be content and proud because we take part in something which throughout the years has raised the reputation of BiH to the highest cultural level.
I am happy to see a number of guests who will carry the most beautiful impressions and memories from Sarajevo and most probably will share them with others making it possible for them also to feel the warmth of this city and this country.
In the spirit of our hospitality and kindness I hope you will enjoy this evening.
Thank you...

title: BiH Presidency Chairman, Željko Komšić’s address on occasion of the joint exercise of the BiH Armed Forces and the US Army at the Mahovljani Airport - Banjaluka
content:
Today’s festivity shows that Bosnia and Herzegovina is on the best way to become a full-fledged member of NATO, which is one of our strategic state priorities. I must emphasize that this day also best depicts the friendship between BiH and USA and the unselfish support that USA has been showing to our country.
Dear Mr. Radmanović, Excellencies, generals, officers and noncommissioned officers, esteemed guests, dear friends!
It is my great honor to greet you most cordially, wishing that this meeting would take place in a festive and comfortable atmosphere, worthy of the importance of the BiH Armed Forces and the US Armed Forces to all of us.
Today’s festivity shows that Bosnia and Herzegovina is on the best way to become a full-fledged member of NATO, which is one of our strategic state priorities. I must emphasize that this day also best depicts the friendship between BiH and USA and the unselfish support that USA has been showing to our country.
The significance of the BiH Armed Forces is the most illustratively shown by the recent fires across BiH that would have been practically impossible to localize and extinguish without the outstanding contribution and engagement of the members and the technology of the BiH Armed Forces.
The BiH Armed Forces’ members are doing their utmost to perform and execute the concrete assignments and necessary reforms in the most efficient, professional and quality way. For that reason, the State of BiH must ensure and provide them all necessary for their work and functioning in accordance with the NATO standards.
BiH unstoppably continues its journey to the Euro-Atlantic integration and the EU membership. Our future faces peace and healthy relation development between neighbors. Our imperative is creating conditions for economic prosperity of a sound, stabile, healthy, strong and even prettier and happier BiH, whose component part – Armed Forces – are organized in accordance with the highest NATO standards.
Thank you!

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Nebojša Radmanović at the Energy Summit of the Heads of South
content:
Present production of electrical energy satisfies not only the current needs of the consumers in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but about 10% of the produced energy is exported which is not characteristic for the region.
Distinguished Chairman,
Distinguished Presidents,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my great pleasure to greet all the participants of the Summit. Allow me to express my sincere gratitude to our host the President Mesic, for initiating and organizing this event. It is of a crucial importance for our European future to exchange our experiences and views through the events like this one, as well as to foster more cooperation in all the fields of importance for our people and good mutual relations.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
General globalization of the world economy and modern trends of liberalization and privatization reached the energy sector which is going through the process of fundamental reforms. Energy sector, from the very beginning up to the last decade of the past century, conservative and strictly regulated one, has been opened to the market where the competition and a free choice were making the principles for its functioning. Liberalization of the energy market has given the strong impetus to the efficiency and investments growth, as the key development factors. European Energy Charter from 1991 and the Directions of the European Union on liberalization of the energy market of the member countries had the key role in starting the process of establishing of the global liberalized energy market in Europe. As the part of the European family, by the Athens Memorandum we have expressed our commitment for establishing the regional energy market in the South-East Europe and therefore opened the way for integration into the internal energy market of the European Union. Our commitment was recognized by the signing the Treaty on Establishing the Community of South-East Europe. With participation in this process, Bosnia and Herzegovina confirms its determination for energy sector reform, liberalization of the energy market and harmonization of policy with the EU standards. It represents a great challenge and hope for all of us. Our common need is to develop a stable regulatory and market framework which would attract the investors to the energy sector for ensuring the stable energy supply which is of key importance for our economic development and stability.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has large unused development potentials in the energy sector. The estimations were that the existing installed power of 4052 MW in hydro-electric and thermo-power stations could be more than three times increased by building new hydro-electric power stations and modernizing the existing ones, as well as building new thermo-electric power plants. In activating the energy potentials Bosnia and Herzegovina recognized a great development chance in order to ensure long term energy stability for the country and the region.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The energy sector suffered from the large war damage in this territory. Owing to the significant international community donation support and favorable loans of the World Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development the reconstruction of the electric power sector in Bosnia and Herzegovina was successfully done. Normal and consistent electric energy supply was established through increased coal production and reconstruction of production and transmission capacities. Electric energy production achieved the pre-war level. Electric power transmission network was interconnected with the neighboring countries, thus becoming the integral part of the European energy market. Present production of electrical energy satisfies not only the current needs of the consumers in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but about 10% of the produced energy is exported which is not characteristic for the region. The three vertically integrated electric power industries, two in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and one in the Republic of Srpska, are functioning successfully thus realizing satisfactory results.
In order to ensure faster economic progress towards safer and more stable long term energy supply, during the last and this year the numerous initiatives and steps have been taken by the Governments of the Entities to attract foreign investors for modernizing the existing and building new energy capacities.
Allow me to emphasize some of the above mentioned developing projects. The Republic of Srpska Government concluded the agreement with the electric power industry of the Czech Republic (CEZ) on construction of the new thermo-electric power station called Gacko 2, in the place of Gacko, with installed power of 660 MW, and modernization of the existing thermo-electric power station of 300 MW. In this project it will be invested around 1.4 billion euros thus representing one of the largest investments in the region. In the vicinity of the lignite mine called Stanari the EFT Group from London was planning to realize the project of building a modern thermo-electric power plant of installed power of 420 MW. The estimated investment is 650 million euros. State-owned capital sale of the oil refineries in Brod and Modrica to the Russian company Zarubezneft was successfully done, thus ensuring more stable and safer oil derivatives markets supply. Apart from that in the last and this year in Bosnia and Herzegovina was approved more that 120 concessions for building small hydroelectric power plants.
The encouraging fact is that there is a large interest from foreign and domestic investors in investing into the electro energy sector. It is also the challenge for the countries of our region to jointly invest into the construction of the new energy capacities. Bosnia and Herzegovina is open for such endeavors.
Institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Entities Governments put high priority to the energy sector reforms. Our key goal is to make the legislation related to the electric power compatible to the European Union practice and establish the regulatory framework to create the conditions for new investments and competition and opening energy and natural gas markets. We see the realization of this goal in further development of the integration in the region and, within it the important part is to establish regional electricity and natural gas market which will increase the degree of exchange within the region, greater competition and direct foreign investments inflow.
Acting as the signatory country of the Athens Memorandum and the Treaty of Energy Community of South Eastern Europe, I would like to renew our full support and willingness for fully implementation of the requirements from the document.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has already achieved significant results in restructuring the energy sector, establishing regulatory framework in legislative and institutional way, long-term review of development as well as separating production, transmission and distribution of the electricity, in order to avoid reciprocal subventions. The process of electricity market liberalization has started and, as of 1 January this year, the electricity market was liberalized for all the customers with annual consumption of over 10 GWH. In the next year it was planned to enable all the customers, apart from households, a free choice of the electricity supplier, and as of 1 January 2015, to all the customers including the households as well. There is lot to be done in this dynamic process such as to improve the legislation, increase the activities of the regulatory bodies, liberalize the market, and especially in the environment protection.
We are confident that this support and determination towards establishing the common energy market will open a great developing perspective to the entire region. I believe that we shall use that chance for the benefit of our people and the countries of the region.
Thank you!

title: Address by the BiH Presidency member Dr Haris Silajdžić at the meeting of Political Directors of Peace Implementation Council Steering Board
content:
Mr. Komsic and I today dispatched a letter to the UN Secretary General and to over a hundred governments and international organizations, asking for the same thing I ask of you tonight: assistance with transforming Bosnia and Herzegovina into a modern, functional, democratic, European states, with equality and justice for all its people in every portion of its territory.
Respected excellencies,
First of all, please allow me to welcome you to Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to express my deep appreciation for your continued engagement toward peace and stability in our country and the region as a whole. I am especially grateful for your assistance with our efforts to embark on the road towards Euro-Atlantic integrations, which will benefit the entire country and all its people.
The Peace Implementation Council has been engaged in Bosnia and Herzegovina for almost twelve years now. Without a doubt, progress has been made. Immediately following the war and genocide, Bosnia and Herzegovina was severely crippled, with some 200,000 people dead and countless wounded, with over a million refugees and displaced persons, and with its economy and infrastructure literally in ruins. We all, including all of you here, inherited that situation.
However, because of the hundreds of thousands of lives that were lost, because of another half a million that never returned to their homes, those who for a decade now have insisted on full implementation of the Dayton Agreement and on reforms, and those who have done everything to undermine Dayton and block reforms, cannot be equated, as some in the international community attempt to do. This strategy cannot bring Bosnia and Herzegovina closer to Europe and NATO and cannot guarantee long term peace and stability. In order to accomplish those goals, a serious and meaningful change in policy course is required.
Throughout the war, the international community did far too little to end the murderous campaign the like of which Europe had not seen since the dark days of the Holocaust. As the UN Report on Srebrenica said, the embargo: AND I QUOTE: “left the Serbs in a position of overwhelming military dominance and effectively deprived the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina of its right, under the Charter of the United Nations, to self-defense.” END QUOTE Only after the genocide at Srebrenica did the U.S.-led air strikes force Serbia and the Republika Srpska leadership to the negotiating table, resulting in the Dayton Agreement. Dayton stopped genocide, but left Bosnia and Herzegovina divided into two semi-autonomous entities, its multi-ethnic character all but obliterated and its central institutions virtually powerless.
Today, almost twelve years after the war, the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina remains hostage to ethno-territorial arrangements. Some of these arrangements are found directly in the Constitution, which constitutes Annex 4 of the Dayton Agreement, but most of them are the result of the fact that the Dayton Agreement was only partially implemented. In particular, Annex 7, which guarantees the right of all refugees and displaced persons to return to their homes failed to be implemented in any meaningful way, particularly with respect to the territory of the Republika Srpska entity.
And then, there is the judgment of the world’s highest judicial body – the International Court of Justice. As you are all aware, on February 26, the ICJ unequivocally ruled that – AND I QUOTE – “the acts committed at Srebrenica were committed with the specific intent to destroy in part the group of the Muslims of Bosnia and Herzegovina as such; and accordingly these were acts of genocide,” committed by the institutions of Republika Srpska, namely by the Army of Republika Srpska and the Police of Republika Srpska.
As the United Nations Report on Srebrenica states – AND I QUOTE AGAIN – “As part of the larger ambition for a ‘Greater Serbia,’ the Serbs set out to occupy the territory of the enclaves; they wanted the territory for themselves. The civilian inhabitants of the enclaves were not the incidental victims of the attackers; their death or removal was the very purpose of the attacks upon them. The Bosnian Muslim civilian population thus became the principal victim of brutally aggressive military and para-military Serb operations to depopulate coveted territories in order to allow them to be repopulated by Serbs.” END QUOTE
As is evident today, it was a job well-done. After all, the name “Republika Srpska” literally means “the Republic of the Serbs,” and from the pre-war population of over forty-five percent Bosniaks and Croats, only four percent of non-Serbs remain in that part of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Thus, the situation that has been created in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and that has been further solidified through the partial and selective implementation of the Dayton Agreement, is a direct result of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes. Don’t take my word for it, simply refer again the ICJ’s Judgment and the UN’s Srebrenica Report, or any of the dozens of ICTY’s judgments. Hence, Slobodan Milosevic’s project lives on.
However, the principles of customary international law, as codified in the International Law Commission’s Articles on State Responsibility, and as reproduced in a 2001 U.N. General Assembly resolution 56/83, mandate that – I QUOTE – “no State shall recognize as lawful a situation created by a serious breach of a peremptory norm of general international law,” which includes the crime of genocide and the crimes against humanity, “nor render aid or assistance in maintaining that situation.”
It is unfortunate that some in the international community ignore these legal obligations, choosing the path of least resistance by pursuing the option of not meddling with the “situation on the ground,” while fully aware of how such a situation was created in the first place. If you ask us to accept the results of Milosevic’s project, that is something that we cannot do. It is, indeed, impossible to do so while at the same time remaining steadfastly committed to reform.
With all due respect, I must ask you: what are the bases of the international community’s current policy toward Bosnia and Herzegovina? What are the bases of the proclaimed reform? The Dayton Agreement has not been fully implemented. International conventions and other international legal obligations have been severely violated. The ICJ’s judgment is being ignored. At the last elections the people clearly stated what they want and what they do not want. It is unclear, then, what remains. It is clear who wants status quo and who wants reform. The only thing that remains unclear is whether the international community will adopt the legal and moral highground, the sole guarantees of permanent peace and stability, or it will support the status quo.
We are accused of focusing on the past and not looking into the future, but let’s examine the facts for a moment. We have introduced changes to the Citizenship Law in order to ensure that over a half a million Bosnian refugees – scattered throughout the world for no other reason than as a result of genocide and ethnic cleansing – do not lose their Bosnian citizenship. Ten deputies from the Republika Srpska entity have repeatedly used entity veto to block this law with the sole – and proclaimed – goal of divesting those people of their citizenship.
We have introduced a law prohibiting denial of the Holocaust and genocide in order to criminalize behavior that we see daily on the streets and the stadiums of Republika Srpska and which greatly stifles the return. The same ten deputies blocked that law as well. You then told that it was our fault that the law was blocked because we “did not draft it properly.” For your information, the law was modeled almost entirely on a similar Belgian law, and does not appreciatively differ from similar laws in force in eleven EU countries.
We have accepted all attempts at Police reform, even when every subsequent attempt included serious erosions of the previously agreed-upon solutions. We balked at preserving Police of Republika Srpska, but we offered a compromise that would have created the Police of Bosnia and Herzegovina in Republika Srpska. This proposal fully follows the instructions of Mr. Vincenzo Coppola, the Chief of EU’s Police Mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina, who unequivocally stated last month that in order to satisfy the European standards, AND I QUOTE: “You may have the police in Republika Srpska, but not the police of Republika Srpska.”
You proclaim that you want us to follow the European standards of freedom, equality and democracy, but criticize us when we actually take you seriously and attempt to apply those standards in practice.
These are the facts and they cannot be disputed, not with a straight face anyway. It is, indeed, abundantly clear who in Bosnia and Herzegovina does not want reform and who does. The Council of Europe told us that reform must entail elimination of entity voting and we based our positions on that directive. The European Parliament then told us that entity voting may henceforth apply only to a limited set of competencies, and last month in Washington we agreed to a U.S. proposal along those lines.
Indeed, entity voting would not even be a contentious issue if the Dayton Agreement had been fully implemented. If refugees had returned to Republika Srpska – as mandated by Annex 7 – entity veto would not be an ethno-territorial mechanism that is used by the leadership of this entity to block any and all reform aimed at making Bosnia and Herzegovina a modern, democratic and functional member of the European family of nations. It is the leadership of that entity that focuses on the past, with the sole aim of preserving the situation created by, in the words of the United Nations, “the operations to depopulate coveted territories in order to allow them to be repopulated by Serbs.”
While I am convinced that you are all mindful of the fact that is the Republika Srpska leadership that is responsible for the political stalemate, you must find a political will to identify the culprit, however strategically or politically inconvenient that may be at the present time. Instead of justifying the current course by the alleged “fights” of the local politicians, it must be answered why Dayton has not been fully implemented. There are, indeed, no “fights.” There are only those who want to keep Milosevic’s project alive and those who want to end it. The international community must take the principled stance in this struggle, as any other solution threatens to further destabilize Bosnia and Herzegovina and to seriously reflect on the stability of the region in the long-run.
Mr. Komsic and I today dispatched a letter to the UN Secretary General and to over a hundred governments and international organizations, asking for the same thing I ask of you tonight: assistance with transforming Bosnia and Herzegovina into a modern, functional, democratic, European states, with equality and justice for all its people in every portion of its territory.
The UN Srebrenica Report said – AND I QUOTE – “The UN experience in Bosnia was one of the most difficult and painful in our history. Through error, misjudgment and an inability to recognize the scope of the evil confronting us, we failed to do our part to help save the people of Srebrenica from the Serb campaign of mass murder. No one regrets more than we the opportunities for achieving peace and justice that were missed. No one laments more than we the failure of the international community to take decisive action to halt the suffering and end a war that had produced so many victims. Srebrenica crystallized a truth understood only too late by the United Nations and the world at large: that Bosnia was as much a moral cause as a military conflict. The tragedy of Srebrenica will haunt our history forever. END QUOTE
I hope that you will recognize the value and importance of this input in order to avoid future reports, of which there are already way to many, that lament the failures of the international community in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I again wish to express my appreciation to the international community for bringing brutalities in Bosnia and Herzegovina to an end. But, while Dayton ended the military conflict, and genocide, Bosnia and Herzegovina today remains as much a moral cause as it was twelve years ago. While Srebrenica will indeed forever haunt our collective history, the magnitude of that experience will only increase if the results of genocide are allowed to stand, and peace and stability will always be threatened.

title: Speech by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Nebojša Radmanović in Bucharest and Sibiu, Romania 7-8 June 2007 at the Summit of the Heads of State and Other Leaders from the South
content:
It is a real pleasure to discuss with friends this important and actual topic like the bridges between our countries and nations, unlike the difficult and delicate political issues that represent a burden to the modern world today.
Speech by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Nebojša Radmanović in Bucharest and Sibiu, Romania 7-8 June 2007 at the Summit of the Heads of State and Other Leaders from the South-East Europe
“CULTURAL DIVERSITY – A BRIDGE BETWEEN CULTURAL HERITAGE AND THE CULTURE OF THE FUTURE”
Mr. Chairman,
Distinguished Presidents,
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
At the very beginning, I would like to express my sincere gratitude to the organizers and the auspices of this important summit, first and foremost to our host the President of Romania, Mr. Băsescu, the Director-General of UNESCO, Mr. Koïchiro Matsuura and Secretary-General of the Council of Europe, Mr. Terry Davis.
It is a real pleasure to discuss with friends this important and actual topic like the bridges between our countries and nations, unlike the difficult and delicate political issues that represent a burden to the modern world today.
As the introduction to the today s topic, let me recall the visionary words of Robert Schuman, one of the founder fathers of the European Union who said long ago, in the fifties:
“Before it becomes a military alliance or an economic entity, Europe needs to be a cultural community in the very sense of the word“.
Europe is a continuity of different cultures, national traditions, as well as the common civilization values. Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country of the three peoples, several various cultures and religions. Metaphorically speaking, Bosnia and Herzegovina, within itself and in the relations with others, signifies a cultural and civilization bridge. Integral part of our identity is to act like a bridge between the East and the West.
Since their settling on these territories, peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina have always belonged to Europe, as well as to its cultural heritage and historical ties and relationships with other peoples and countries. Geopolitically, spiritually and culturally, Bosnia and Herzegovina belongs to Europe. Historical research has shown that in the past there were close connections between the people in Bosnia and Herzegovina and other European nations and countries. Though being a small country, Bosnia and Herzegovina has been giving noticeably important contribution to the cultural-civilization heritage of Europe on the cultural, scientific, artistic, humanistic and spiritual aspect since the ancient times. That was affirmed by numerous examples. Many famous scientists, artists, writers and culture creators have worked in other European countries. Young artists, students, cultural authors from Bosnia and Herzegovina attended the leading European universities thus making the important ties of our country with the European tradition and cultural heritage.
Bosnia and Herzegovina highly appreciates the special cultural projects for the South-East European countries launched and organized in the past by the European Union, the Council of Europe and UNESCO.
Those projects have essentially contributed to the stabilization of the South-East European countries by promoting the cultural cooperation and exchange between the countries on their way to the European Union.
It was clearly shown from the past that the culture is very important for keeping the peace building a democratic society on the basis of connecting, exchanging ideas and dialogue between the cultural and creative industries, not only on the local and state but also the international level.
Thanks to the organizations of several great cultural events and happenings of the regional and European importance, culture became an important factor of economic and social development of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In general process of the post war reconstruction in Bosnia and Herzegovina there was rehabilitation of the destroyed and destructed cultural objects and means. I would especially emphasize the reconstruction of the Old Bridge in Mostar, owed to UNESCO s tremendous contribution. I would like to use the opportunity of the presence of the Director-General of UNESCO to once more express my gratitude on behalf of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Inscription of the ancient core of the city of Mostar on the UNESCO s World Heritage List, the very first of a kind in our country, has come as the result of an active policy in the field of preservation of the cultural heritage. There are current activities for nomination more tangible and intangible cultural heritage sites from Bosnia and Herzegovina to the worldwide cultural heritage list.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The right to the diversity represents the basic precondition for democracy of the modern societies.
Existing governments may not only declaratively recognize the existence of many cultures within the same society, but also really respect and support the demonstration and development of a different practical cultural activities and creativity.
This means a cultural pluralism as the authentic way of existence of the different cultures in an equal, tolerant and open relationship.
In the South-East European region and especially the West Balkans live culturally similar peoples. The more the people of the South-East Europe have tried to be different from each other in their linguistic, religious, cultural and historic way looking from aside they seem to be the same. Modern Europe is still looking to the West Balkans as a stereotype and in a negative way, as the place of the constant conflicts and crisis, forgetting the tremendous cultural and historical heritage and artistic production created and developed in this region, without which the European identity of diversity is not complete.
Therefore the culture could be one of the ways for a shared change of the bad image of the West Balkans countries.
South-East European countries and nations should develop and build interactive multiculturalism of the European type. This means free existence of the various autochthonous cultures with shared and common civilization values. This is also the relationship between the different nations and their cultures based on the equality, emphasizing the similarities existing between the close and similar cultures, rather than pointing to the differences.
In the globalization era the cultural identity and cultural autonomy become a validity of key importance for every individual, ethnic and cultural community. From that background there was the resistance of small cultures to the more expressed cultural unification of the world, which represents the direct threat to the opulence of the diverse cultures. In such circumstances the ideal of many minority cultures and groups is a new motto – „Work in global economy – live in local culture“.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Let me conclude with a symbolic comparison. Ivo Andric, a Croat born in Bosnia and Herzegovina, who lived and worked in Belgrade, novelist and the Nobel Prize laureate for literature, once said: “There is nothing more important the human being is making and building in the world, than bridges“.
Building the bridges of culture between our peoples and countries will be our most valuable contribution to the common European future.
Thank you!

title: BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić’s address during today’s visit to the Municipality of Višegrad
content:
Deeply believing that the Mehmed-pasha Sokolović’s bridge would soon become an official part of the entire humanity’s heritage, I am inviting you to contribute to such a decision by spreading the truth about its harmony and its documentary value.
BiH Presidency Member Željko Komšić, before numerous domestic and foreign guests, made an appropriate speech, given here entirely:
"Excellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen, Dear Friends,
Thank you for being my guests in Višegrad, a town known by its people and their deeds worldwide. Today, we want to direct your attention at the bridge, a valuable work, not a mere building. That bridge, which lies on eleven harmonic arches, is a witness of time and a crystal of Bosnia and Herzegovina cultural remembrance. Deeply believing that the Mehmed-pasha Sokolović’s bridge would soon become an official part of the entire humanity’s heritage, I am inviting you to contribute to such a decision by spreading the truth about its harmony and its documentary value.
Mehmed-pasha Sokolović’s bridge in Višegrad reflects, or finds its reflection in power, art or abilities of three important historic persons – its founder – a grand vizier Mehmed-pasha Sokolović, its builder – the greatest builder in the Great Turkish Empire, Koça mimarbaša Sinan and his “biographer” – a Nobel Prize winner, Ivo Andrić, a writer of a well-known novel “The Bridge on the Drina”. In this way, its construction, historic and symbolic values merge into an exceptionality of expression of one of several images that are emblems of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Due to its harmony, beauty and documentary essence, the Mehmed-pasha Sokolović’s bridge belongs to the most important works of humanity.
I believe that I must use this occasion to mention that the bridge had witnessed dark sides of a human mind, or to be more precise, of a human madness, so I avail myself of the opportunity to ask the families of the victims for understanding and support to including this bridge in the World Heritage List. That will be some kind of a monument and a reminder of their suffering, ordeal and pain, as well as of their closest ones.
Mehmed-pasha Sokolović’s bridge – The Bridge on the Drina – like no other similar place in the world, with its beauty, it bears witness to the ultimate human achievements and the deepest darkness of human falls. This bridge, its architecture, history and testimony of crimes and sufferings in the heart of Europe at the end of the twentieth century, meets all the requirements to become proclaimed a world heritage.
Whether the bridge in Višegrad would truly be proclaimed a world heritage during the June session of the World Heritage Committee – we do not know. We expect support to making such a decision from your country’s representatives, Ladies and Gentlemen, Excellencies, dear friends. In a country, such as Bosnia and Herzegovina, where we, its keepers, are facing with negation of its identity, the World Heritage Committee’s decision on placing the bridge in the World’s most precious assets, could significantly contribute to strengthening the public awareness of heritage importance and our responsibility to preserve it. This is an opportunity to express my warmest gratitude to the Government of the Republic of Turkey for its decision to ensure funds and, in cooperation with the Commission for National Monuments Preservation and the Municipality of Višegrad, to rebuild the foundations of the bridge and restore its original look. I also wish to send expressions of the utmost gratitude to many of you, dear Excellencies, who have ensured support to re-establishment of more than three thousands of objects of construction heritage in Bosnia and Herzegovina that was destroyed in the war. Our cultural memory testifies about the voluptuous tangle of our diversity and of our European descending. With your support, that wealth is a deposit to offer to the world."

title: Speech of the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Nebojsa Radmanovic at the Conference: “South
content:
I would use this opportunity to inform you about Bosnia and Herzegovina's admittance to the United Nations Human Rights Council one of the most important bodies of the world organizations.
Mr. Chairman,
Distinguished Presidents,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my great pleasure to be here taking part at this Conference. I would like to express my sincere gratitude to our host for cordial welcome and successful organization of this event.
Allow me at the very beginning to extend my congratulations to the President of Montenegro Mr. Vujanovic, on the recent admission of the Republic of Montenegro to the Council of Europe.
I would also like to thank all the countries of the Region on the support Bosnia and Herzegovina has received at the Summit of the South-East European Process of Cooperation recently held in Zagreb which resulted in designating Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina as the seat of the Regional Cooperation Council Secretariat until now known as the Stability Pact of the South-East Europe. Decisions from the mentioned event represented a step forward of the countries of the Region of taking their own responsibility for the future of this territory.
I would use this opportunity to inform you about Bosnia and Herzegovina's admittance to the United Nations Human Rights Council one of the most important bodies of the world organizations.
Membership to the Human Rights Council is of great importance for the implementation of the UN mission throughout the world therefore our country is ready to face numerous challenges. Bosnia and Herzegovina will demonstrate that it is worth the role it has been entrusted with. The membership is recognition for the progress realized in the recent years both in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the entire Region. This fact could contribute significantly in the restoration of the image of the country and the region of the Western Balkans.
Speaking of the relationship between the South-East Europe and European Union, we cannot avoid the challenges through which this Region has gone in the recent past, as well as all the difficulties and impediments that are still standing before our countries on their road towards the European Union.
Bosnia and Herzegovina welcomes the progress that all the counties of the region have achieved in the last few years, which brought stability and economic progress.
In all these processes it was shown that the prospective of European Union membership represented a strong impetus and motivation for all the countries in the region to undertake necessary reforms in order to achieve that goal.
I can state with great pleasure that our everyday experience confirms that the countries of the Region are fully dedicated to strengthening the good neighbor's relations, peace and cooperation. For fast and successful integration of our region into the EU, it is necessary to have a common attitude and cooperation, in order to strengthen the efforts which every country individually puts into. Continuous strengthening of bilateral relations between our countries should represent the foundations to all future activities.
Bosnia and Herzegovina follows with great attention the situation related to all the open issues in the region, puts efforts in the political dialogue in their resolving and supports all the solutions reached through negotiations on the basis of compromise and European principles and values. Currently the most sensitive issue is the solution of the status of Kosovo and Metochia. We do expect that it is going to be resolved by the agreement between Belgrade and Prishtina with the assistance of the international community so that in the future it would not represent the source of instability for the entire Region.
In the course of last and this year there have been certain stoppages in implementation of required reforms on the way to fulfillment of the requirements for signing the Stabilization and Association Agreement. It has been emphasized several times that police reform along with some others, is of key importance for progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina towards the Euro-Atlantic integration. I would like to express my confidence that the agreement on police reform will be reached soon, which would be a positive signal that Bosnia and Herzegovina has successfully passed this step towards the Euro-Atlantic integration.
We are fully aware that fulfillment of the requirements for joining the EU is primarily in the interest of our country and citizens, in order to ensure a prosperity for the generations to come. It is often forgotten that for the success of the integration, along with the consensus of all political factors in the country, it is also required the consensus between the state and the citizens. The integration of our countries to the European Union must be a collective effort of the whole society for it is dealing with the changes the social and economic relationships in their very essence.
South-East European countries need to try to realize their development prospects within the framework of the Central European Agreement on free trade which should intensify the economic cooperation and trade exchange between the member countries within a new trade space.
There is only one way for the South-East European countries to reach the long-standing peace and stability, and that is the economic development and greater level of mutual integration to the final membership to the European Union.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
