According to all relevant assessments, the latest EU enlargement had positive effects on the member countries. At the same time, skepticism has also grown amongst the citizens in some of the EU countries. In the South-East European countries there is a wide-spread feeling that EU, having been busy with the process and the outcome of the future EU Constitution, slowed down the integration of these countries into its structure. Bosnia and Herzegovina expects that EU will keep its door open for all the countries of the South-East Europe, since without them Europe is not complete in its historical, geographical, economic and cultural sense. Regardless of how the internal relations will be regulated within EU, it is very important for the countries of the South-East Europe that the prospective of their membership into the EU will never be uncertain or slowed down.
European integrations gradually and fully transform the destiny of the countries of the South-East Europe and their peoples. Final success on that way requires primarily changing ourselves in order to make the European values - peace, democracy, market economy and rule of law, to become our own values too.
Stable and developed Bosnia and Herzegovina, the country with the three equal peoples belonging to the three great global religions, situated in the very center of the Region can be a powerful bridge between the South-East Europe and the European Union as well as the integration factor in the Region on the basis of a dialogue, cooperation and understanding amongst the religions and the nations.
Joining of the South-East European countries to the EU is a mission which has no alternative, either for us, since we wish to be a part of a stable and prosperous community, or for EU, since the process of enlargement will not be finished until all the countries in the Region become its members.
Thank you!

title: Speech by Chair of Presidency of BiH Nebojša Radmanović in Brno,Czech Republic on Central
content:
CENTRAL EUROPE: CURRENT PROBLEMS AND CHALLENGES FOR THE FUTURE
CENTRAL EUROPE: CURRENT PROBLEMS AND CHALLENGES FOR THE FUTURE
Your Excellencies, the Presidents,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Allow me to greet you in the name of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina and at the beginning to express my sincere gratitude to the host of our today’s gathering - the President of the Czech Republic, Mr Vaclav Klaus, for his warm welcoming, as well as to congratulate on successful preparations and organization of this gathering.
Bosnia and Herzegovina gives its full support to the activities of such gatherings, because it recognizes multiple possibilities in them to connect countries, to make room for political dialogue, to enhance relations and diverse cooperation between the countries with different levels of social and democratic development.
In BiH, we believe that gathering the Central-European countries, regardless of all the heterogeneity of the countries’ composition and the diversity of their position is a strong instrument for prompting integration processes in Europe and strengthening democracy in these areas.
Central Europe, trough various forms of cooperation with the countries of Central Europe, has brought these countries closer to the countries of the West, simultaneously with the ideas and the spirit of the West that have entered the territory of the Southeastern Europe. On the other side, trough the countries of the Southeastern Europe, the countries of the Central Europe are achieving necessary connection with the Mediterranean countries, which makes the borders and the spirit of Europe expanding.
The cooperation of the countries of Central Europe and Southeastern Europe has significantly decreased the negative effect of a bipolar division in Europe that had dominated by the nineties of the last century, and after having new members from this part of the Central Europe and the Southeastern Europe in EU, the process of building Europe without frontiers has been improved.
Europe without the Western Balkan countries is not complete, so we rightfully expect that the process of admitting new countries to EU would not be stalled or stopped.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
After a decade of conflicts and crisis, the region of Western Balkan experiences stabilization. After several cycles of free and democratic elections in all the regional countries, the democratic authority has strengthened. The countries of the region are undergoing reconstruction toward economic recovery and sustainable development.
In the period after signing the Dayton Peace Accords, Bosnia and Herzegovina has been constantly going trough the process of positive changes that ensure the society’s democratic institutions strengthening.
Early this year, BiH has concluded the technical part of negotiations on the Stabilization and Association Agreement. Our expectations are that in spite of the temporary halts in our way to the European Union, we would sign the Stabilization and Association Agreement by the end of this year, fulfilling the key conditions of the mentioned package of reforms.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, we expect the European Union countries and others to invest in our country’s economy more than ever, not based on support and donations from the early periods, but following the market criteria.
Last year, Bosnia and Herzegovina was accepted to NATO’s program Partnership for Peace, which is recognition of an achieved progress in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as a stimulus for continuation of commenced reforms until the full-fledged membership in NATO Alliance.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has seen a constant progress in the field of security. Establishing an efficient system of border control and building an electronic system of issuing personal documents and having an efficient cooperation with the neighboring countries, we have multiply reduced the scope of illegal migrations from and trough our territory.
Fight against organized crime, human trafficking and corruption has given good results, but continues to be a permanent activity of institutions.
Negotiations on police forces reform are underway, which will establish rational and efficient police structure at the state level based on European standards.
The regional countries that aren’t in Europe are seeking their own forms of cooperation as supplements to the current interregnum until the full-fledged membership in the European Union. I use this opportunity to inform you that it has been decided these days that Sarajevo and Bosnia and Herzegovina are to be the headquarters of the Regional Cooperation Council of the transformed South East Europe Stability Pact. I invite all the present countries to give their contribution to the new forms of cooperation, especially in the economic field. Allow me to ask you for help in building the regional road corridor VC, which represents a strategic investment project for Bosnia and Herzegovina, an important section for the Central Europe countries and the shortest road to the Mediterranean.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The South East Europe countries are facing new challenges today.
One of the main challenges is to strengthen democracy in our countries, which should put an end to common historic conflicts, to ensure stability of democratic institutions and promote ethnic and religious tolerance. Stability and progress achieved in all of the West Balkan countries are still fragile. Exclusivity and unilateral solutions continue to be the main obstacle to reconciliation and integration of our countries, regardless of the side they are coming from.
A great challenge for the South East Europe countries, especially the West Balkan, is certainly the negotiations on the final status of Kosovo and Metohia. Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a neighboring country, is interested in democratic solutions for these open issues. Bosnia and Herzegovina advocates the solution achieved trough negotiations between Belgrade and Pristina representatives, with a support of the International Community.
The key challenge for all of us will be a reaction to the situation after reaching a solution for Kosovo and Metohia status. Although it is perceived as a final unresolved Balkan issue, Kosovo and Metohia, could be transformed into a longer problem than it appears now, unless a real, right measure of compromise in negotiations is found. Kosovo and Metohia could easily become a precedent that would instigate independence aspirations of other territories.
We rightfully fear that solving these open issues with unilateral decisions, contrary to the international law, based on the precedent principle could slow down the integration process of this region’s countries in the European Union, and create unforeseeable consequences for the entire Europe.
I dare to conclude with a symbolic portrayal. A well-known legend says that a Greek God Zeus stole the beautiful Europe. Today, we are well aware of that fact that Europe means more than a woman’s name – it is an idea that draws us with its strength and dares us to change ourselves for the better.
Thank you.

title: ADDRESS BY THE MEMBER OF PRESIDENCY OF BIH ŽELJKO KOMŠIĆ ON THE OCCASION OF THE 15TH ANNIVERSARY OF ADMISSION OF BIH TO THE UNITED NATIONS
content:
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Dear friends,
It is my pleasure to be in New York this evening, celebrating the 15th anniversary of Bosnia and Herzegovina's membership to the United Nations in the company of friends. On that day, following a democratic referendum, declaration of independence and international recognition by most other sovereign countries, my country established its international identity as an independent, sovereign and united country. This is why I consider the 22nd of May 1992 as one of the most important dates in the history of our peoples. I think that this date is also very special for our friends, the Republic of Croatia and the Republic of Slovenia, who were admitted into the United Nations that same day and with whom we are closely tied not only by our recent past, but also our present and our common European future.
On behalf of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and my own behalf; this is an opportunity to wholeheartedly thank the friendly nations and their governments, numerous non-governmental organisations, the media and most of all democratic public opinion and millions of anonymous friends who were supporting Bosnia and Herzegovina through one of the most difficult periods of our centuries-old history. I want to express special gratitude for everything the United Nations have done and are still doing for my country.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country where people who share the same roots, who in essence belong to the same civilisation and cultural circle and differ only in terms of ethnic and religious belonging, together form and have for centuries maintained a single multiethnic, multireligious and multicultural society. This society has stood the tests of historical challenges and can offer today's turbulent world its experience. Personally I and many citizens of my country reject the imposed theory of a "clash of civilisations". Even though, throughout our history we have faced numerous ordeals, our experience shows that coexistence, tolerance and peace are the basis without which there is no survival or progress of today's world.
This month we are also celebrating the Day of Victory over Fascism, victory over evil which in a changed form and with new protagonists still shows signs of life. I want to remind you that the UN was created to prevent re-emergence of this evil. With pride I would like to stress that my country was part of that assembly which founded this universal organisation and that antifascism is an integral element of our society. We continue to have strong solidarity with other antifascists in the world, despite the efforts by certain forces in our region and elsewhere for revision of the past. This is why I stress the importance of antifascism as an instrument of prevention against any form of dictatorship and totalitarian regime. Today, more and more countries are genuinely committed to peace, among them Bosnia and Herzegovina, which paid an enormous price in order to defend its independence.
Only 15 years ago, the World was sending their soldiers to our country to help us defend our sovereignty, establish peace and stability. Today, Bosnia and Herzegovina sends its soldiers on peace missions throughout the world, as from its own experience it feels obliged to give its contribution to peace and prosperity elsewhere.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is still facing serious transition challenges, difficult war legacy, incomplete state and social infrastructure, serious economic decline, poverty and heightened nationalism which do not contribute to accelerating reforms needed for Bosnia and Herzegovina to become a modern and democratic state. My country is committed to it, majority of the citizens want it and I am personally advocating Bosnia and Herzegovina becoming a member of Euro Atlantic structures as the best way forward to permanent peace and stability; not only for Bosnia and Herzegovina but also for the whole region of South East Europe. Political forces in power bear a huge responsibility for blockage of the reform process we need to implement in order to progress towards joining the Euro Atlantic family of peoples. I want to believe that those in power will have the power and knowledge to overcome this situation as quickly as possible; otherwise we will face serious consequences. This is why I am convinced that the work of the international community in Bosnia and Herzegovina is not yet complete and we still need friendly and other forms of support to help us on our way to the future.
Allow me to conclude this speech by again expressing my pleasure that we are amongst friends here in New York and in the host country of our Organisation which, together with other countries, unselfishly works on stabilisation of my country. The United Nations remain an irreplaceable framework and deserve full engagement by Bosnia and Herzegovina in implementation of the UN Charter.
Thank you for your attention and you will always be welcome in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
New York, 21 May 2007

title: SPEECH OF THE CHAIRMAN OF THE BIH PRESIDENCY NEBOJŠA RADMANOVIĆ ON THE OCCASION OF THE 15TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE ARMY OF THE REPUBLIC OF SRPSKA AND THE DAY OF THE 3RD INFANTRY REGIMENT ( REPUBLIC OF SRP
content:
This year we mark the 15th anniversary of the Army of the Republic of Srpska and the 2nd anniversary of the 3rd Infantry Regiment ( the Republic of Srpska ) which belongs to the reformed BiH Armed Forces.
Dear President of the Republic of Srpska,
Dear Presidents of the RS National Assembly and the Government of the Republic of Srpska,
Your Exellencies,
Generals, officers and members of of the BiH Armed Forces,
Esteemed families of perished and missing soldiers of the Republic of Srpska,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
This year we mark the 15th anniversary of the Army of the Republic of Srpska and the 2nd anniversary of the 3rd Infantry Regiment ( the Republic of Srpska ) which belongs to the reformed BiH Armed Forces.
In this jubilant mood, it truly is a great pleasure for me to attend this ceremony and address the guests.
First I would like to extend my congratulations.
I express my congratulations on the Day of the Regiment to all members of the 3rd Infantry Regiment, and to all members of the Army of the Republic of Srpska I would like to congratulate their 15th anniversary. This Regiment embodies and fosters tradition, identity and military legacy of the Army of the Republic of Srpska.
Each anniversary, including this one, brings us back to the past, recent or remote history, and gives us necessary reminders.
The Army of the Republic of Srpska was created because Serbian population across the territory of BiH was seriously jeopardized in terms of their survival and national subjectivity. Facing threats and danger, Serbian people created the Army of the Republic of Srpska in 1992, in order to protect themselves and the territory they had inhabited for centuries.
The tragic conflict in BiH claimed many victims among Serbian people, which compels us never to forget that the Republic of Srpska, as a permanent creation, was created with great effort, renunciation and striving of the whole Serbian population, especially members of the Army of the Republic of Srpska.
This obliges us to show constant concern for families of perished and missing soldiers, as well as those who are injured and disabled.
Following the signing of the Dayton Peace Agreement, the Army of the Republic of Srpska and other institutions in RS gave a considerable contribution to the implementation of this Agreement, building trust and cooperation between belligerent parties, as well as permanent, sustainable peace in the BiH territory.
As part of general activities aimed at bringing BiH closer to the European Union and Euroatlantic integration, many important and wide-ranging defence reforms were undertaken in the post-war period, and institutions in the Republic of Srpska framed the concept of these reform processes. The process of reforms was complex, gradual and balanced, and it took vision, commitment and patience of all the people involved in order for the process to be successfully completed.
Taking into account similar experiences of other post-conflict societies, and the progress that has been achieved so far, we can say that the reform processes have been conducted successfully.
The evidence of this progrees is the accolade that BiH received last year, when it was admitted to NATO PfP programme, which entails new obligations and requires reaching new standards that full membership in NATO implies.
Furthermore, at this moment, units of the BiH Armed Forces among whom are soldiers and officers from the Republic of Srpska, are deployed in joint peacekeeping units in several missions around the world, thus giving necessary contribution to communal safety in the world.
In the process of reform of the BiH Armed Forces we had to reduce military staff drastically, and many individuals lost their jobs and had to change their vocation. This process stil causes social problems, and we are trying to mitigate its consequences by wide-ranging measures of economic and social policies.
The BiH Presidency reached a decision last year declaring 2006 and 2007 the years of reduction of the BiH Armed Forces staff which is considered to be redundant.
As part of the ceremony marking the 15th anniversary of the Army of the Republic of Srpska, and the 2nd anniversary of the 3rd Infantry Regiment, delegations of civil institutions of the Republic of Srpska and BiH, as well as military and soldier organizations, will lay wreaths on monuments dedicated to victims of fascism of World War II, as well as perished soldiers and civilians of the last war in many towns and cities in the Republic of Srpska. Two days ago, on May 9, BiH joined other European countries in celebration of two grand events celebrated simultaneously, not by coincidence: Europe Day and Victory Day. This is a place and time to reiterate that peoples in BiH, especially Serbs, gave a considerable contribution to anti fascist battle during World War II, which built the modern Europe. This is something we must not forget, something that we must constantly repeat as a proof of our European political modernity.
In conclusion, we must not in this solemn moment fail to mention hard and unpleasant truth and facts from the last war that was fought in the BiH territory. The war claimed many victims among different peoples, wrecked the country's economy and impoverished many individuals and families. In this conflict many individuals from different belligerent parties committed war crimes for which they must be prosecuted before competent courts.
It is the only way to ensure sustained peace which will take root and prevent the history from repeating. In such peaceful and prosperous future professional soldiers will be loyal guardians of the country and deserving members of democratic society.
Thank you.

title: Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Nebojsa Radmanovic Summit ”Long Term Energy Stability - a Prerequisite for Economic Development” in Ohrid, 20 April 2007
content:
It is my great pleasure to greet you and to express my sincere gratitude to our host for the invitation to participate at the Summit. It is of a crucial importance for our European future to exchange our experiences and views through the events like this one, as well as to foster more cooperation in all the fields of importance for our people which would result in good mutual relations.
Address by the Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Nebojsa Radmanovic
Summit ­”Long Term Energy Stability – a Prerequisite for Economic Development” in Ohrid, 20 April 2007
Distinguished Presidents,
Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my great pleasure to greet you and to express my sincere gratitude to our host for the invitation to participate at the Summit. It is of a crucial importance for our European future to exchange our experiences and views through the events like this one, as well as to foster more cooperation in all the fields of importance for our people which would result in good mutual relations.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Global process of liberalization and deregulation of the world economy opened the process of introducing the market competition even in the traditionally monopolistic parts of energy sector. As the part of the European family, by the Athens Memorandum we have expressed our commitment for establishing the Regional market in the South-East Europe and therefore gradually ensure the way for integration into the internal energy market oriented towards the European Union, which resulted in signing the Treaty on Establishing the Energy Community of South-East Europe in July 2006. With participation in this process, Bosnia and Herzegovina confirms its determination for energy sector reform, liberalization of the energy market and harmonization of policy with the EU standards. It represents a great challenge and hope for all of us. Our common need is to develop a stable regulatory and market framework which would attract the investors to the energy sector for ensuring the stable energy supply which is of key importance for our economic development and stability.
The basis of the energy system of Bosnia and Herzegovina is made of the electric power sector which is the main development resource. The estimations were that the existing installed power of 4052 MW in hydro-electric and thermo-power stations for production of the electric energy could be more than three times increased by building new hydro-electric power stations and modernizing the existing ones, as well as building new thermo-electric power plants. Especially important is the share in the hydro-energy potentials, which increased the supply safety and environment protection. Given the importance for further development of Bosnia and Herzegovina I will put emphasis to the electric energy sector in the following presentation.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The reconstruction of the electric power sector in Bosnia and Herzegovina was successfully done owing to the significant donation support and favorable loans of the World Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Normal and consistent electric energy supply was established through increased coal production and reconstruction of production and transmission capacities. Electric energy production achieved the pre-war level. The whole territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina was re-harmonized with the Union for Coordination of Transmission of Electrical Energy in Europe (UCTE). Present production of electrical energy satisfies the needs of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and about 10% of the produced energy is exported. The three vertically integrated electric power industries, two in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and one in the Republic of Srpska, are functioning successfully thus realizing satisfactory results.
Reforms and development of the energy sector are the high priority for the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Governments of the Entities, the Republic of Srpska and BiH Federation respectfully. Our key goal is to make the legislation related to the electric power compatible to the European Union practice and establish the regulatory framework to create the preconditions for new investments and competition. We see the realization of this goal in further development of the integration in the region and, within it the important part is to establish regional electricity market which will increase the degree of exchange within the region, greater competition and direct foreign investments inflow.
Acting as the signatory country of the Athens Memorandum and the Treaty of Energy Community of South Eastern Europe, I would like to renew our full support and willingness for complete implementation of the requirements from the document.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has already achieved significant results in restructuring the energy sector, establishing regulatory framework in legislative and institutional way, long-term review of development as well as separating production, transmission and distribution of the electricity, in order to avoid reciprocal subventions. The process of electricity market liberalization has started and, as of 1 January this year, the electricity market was liberalized for all the customers with annual consumption of over 10 GWH. As of 1 January 2008, it was planned to enable all the customers, apart from households, a free choice of the electricity supplier, and as of 1 January 2015, to the households as well. There is lot to be done in this dynamic process such as to improve the legislation, increase the activities of the regulatory bodies, liberalize the market, and especially in the environment protection.
Looking into the future, the key challenge for Bosnia and Herzegovina and its economic growth was the expansion of the electricity production capacities in order to resolve a long-lasting problem of growing needs in electricity supply in the country and foster the export volume within the regional market. During the last and this year the numerous initiatives have been taken by the Governments of the Entities to attract foreign investors to modernizing and expanding the existing and building new capacities for electricity production. One of the initiatives is the agreement of the Government of the Republic of Srpska and CEZ group on construction of the new thermo-electric power station in the place of Gacko, with installed power of 700 MW, and modernization of the existing one of 300 MW, including the mine. Apart from that in the last and this year in Bosnia and Herzegovina was approved more that 120 concessions for building small hydroelectric power plants. The coal reserves were estimated to 4 billion tons.
The encouraging fact is that there is a large interest from foreign and domestic investors in investing into the electro energy sector including small projects such are small hydroelectric power plants. It is also the challenge for the countries of our region to jointly approach the construction energy capacities. Bosnia and Herzegovina is open for such way of cooperation.
We are sure that this support and determination towards establishing the common energy market will open a great developing perspective to the entire region. I believe that we shall use that chance for the benefit of our people and the countries of the region.
Thank you!

title: SPEECH BY THE BIH PRESIDENCY MEMBER NEBOJŠA RADMANOVIĆ AT THE CEREMONY ON THE OCCASION OF THE 50TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE SIGNINIG OF THE TREATIES OF ROME
content:
It was in Rome 50 years ago, on March 25, 1957, that by signing of the Treaties of Rome foundations were laid for the creation that we know today as the European Union
Your Exellencies,
Esteemed guests,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is a great honour to greet you on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It was in Rome 50 years ago, on March 25, 1957, that by signing of the Treaties of Rome foundations were laid for the creation that we know today as the European Union. In this way, the idea of the united Europe that was for a long time a mere dream of philosophers and visionaries came true. Each anniversary is an opportunity to reassess the key ideas of the founders of the European Union and evaluate the future perspectives. It is also an opportunity for the Europeans to consider what kind of Europe they want in the future. It is also an opportunity for the people in Bosnia and Herzegovina to assess their own position on the road to the European Union and give a new stimulus to that process.
The European Union is the unique political creation. It was designed to prevent possible conflicts in Europe, after the horrors of the two World Wars and with the aim of overcoming legacies of fascism in the 20th century. It opened up new horizons for the peoples and citizens of Europe. In today's perspective, we can say that the European Union is the greatest venture and project achieved through selfless effort of men and women who shared the same convictions, courage and determination. Liberty, peace and prosperity are the main achievements which were made possible through creation of the European Union. However, the fact that the European Union eliminated war and use of force as means of resolving conflict in Europe is its most important legacy.
Bosnia and Herzegovina belongs to Europe geographically, historically and culturally, but it has not yet become member of the greatest regional integration in the world. That is why we are going to re-double our efforts in order to meet the conditions for full membership in the European Union.
We do not have the right to miss the opportunities that are offered, just like the “ founding fathers” did not miss the opportunity to create the European Union when historical circumstances called for such an action. This resulted in a new optimism and trust in common European future and gave a new impetus to Europe's unification.
After all the atrocities that people suffered here, in Bosnia, and all these post-war years of transition and reconstruction, I strongly believe that membership in the European Union would be a well-deserved reward for efforts we made and difficulties we experienced.
What can Bosnia and Herzegovina learn from the process of European association and integration?
The European Union resolved conflict by implementing peace, it replaced desintegration by creating integrations on new foundations, encouraged new cooperation instead of old hostilities and advocated negotiation in lieu of force. Instead of forcible unification, existing cultural differences and national traditions were acknowledged, as well as common values. Equality for all nations was accented as opposed to domination of one nation.
Messages and lessons from the European integration can serve as a guide for Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bearing in mind that there is a basic consensus expressed in Bosnia and Herzegovina, starting from the majority of citizens to political representatives of different political parties, that we all want to gain membership in the European Union, we must build a two-way road: one that will lead Bosnia and Herzegovina to Europe, and another, which will bring Europe to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Let me make a comparison between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Union. The process of the European integration and unification was made possible in the favourable climate, when a common awareness developed of the need for democratic dialogue and mutual trust. There is also one more resemblance between the European Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is not by accident that the main visionaries behind Europe's unification lived in border areas and multinational countries which were destroyed by national and interstate conflicts. Only this kind of experience and common awareness could have produced the need for peaceful unification of people on the broader ground.
That is why solutions for Bosnia and Herzegovina must be sought within the framework of European tradition.
What we need in order to find sustainable solutions in Bosnia and Herzegovina are dialogue, consensus, patience, mutual respect and equality of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
We must remain committed to the set aims, including the constitutional reform, acceleration of economic development, refugee return. We must also take care of socially threatened people, bring war crimes suspects to justice and start the necessary procedures and build institutions in order to ensure equality for all the peoples and citizens, etc.
Ladies and Gentlemen, let me recall the words of one of the visionaries of the European Union, Robert Schuman:
“ Depending on the circumstances surrounding its creation, Europe will be more or less complete. Will it ever be complete? No-one can say. This is not a reason for delaying the effort to achieve unification. Action is better than resignation and the desire for perfection is a poor excuse for inaction."
There is a place for Bosnia and Herzegovina in this vison.
It depends on the efforts that we are making towards this goal.
Thank you

title: Address by the BiH Presidency member Dr. Haris Silajdžić at the Reception in Honour of the Fifteenth Anniversary of the Independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
It is an exceptional honor to welcome you to the reception in honor of the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina, specifically the fifteenth anniversary of that independence. At the referendum held on February 29 and March 1, 1992, over 66 percent Bosnia and Herzegovina’s citizens of all nationalities voted for a sovereign and independent Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Address at the Reception in Honor of the Fifteenth Anniversary
of the Independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina
Respected Excellencies, reputable guests, and dear friends,
It is an exceptional honor to welcome you to the reception in honor of the Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina, specifically the fifteenth anniversary of that independence. At the referendum held on February 29 and March 1, 1992, over 66 percent Bosnia and Herzegovina’s citizens of all nationalities voted for a sovereign and independent Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Bosnia and Herzegovina paid a bloody price for its independence, celebrating the first three anniversaries under siege and exposed to massive and gruesome war crimes, crimes against humanity, and the very crime of genocide, against the non-Serb population. Two days ago, the International Court of Justice confirmed that, as a matter of law, that the authorities of the then self-proclaimed “Republika Srpska” committed those crimes, including genocide against over 7,000 Bosniak boys and men in Srebrenica, a United Nations “safe area.” Serbia, for its part, was convicted for failing to prevent and to punish the crime of genocide.
It is disappointing that the Court did not accept the undeniable proof that Serbia at the very least was an active accomplice in this genocidal project. However, the Court unequivocally decided that Republika Srpska committed genocide due to the fact that its authorities “had the specific intent to destroy the Bosnian Muslims in Srebrenica.”
It is crucial to understand that the Bosniak people see the Court’s limited decision as a sign of prejudice toward Muslims. This feeling is not solitary, and it has to be taken into consideration. During the darkest days of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Richard Holbrooke, the author of the Dayton project, rhetorically asked: “What would the West be doing now if…a Muslim force was trying to destroy two million beleaguered Christians…?” In the struggle for democracy in the Islamic world, the international community must send a message that the determination for a fully democratic system, such as the unquestionable determination of the Bosnian Muslims for precisely such a system, shall be rewarded rather than punished.
It is also crucial to understand that the target were not just the Bosniaks as a people. The authors of the genocide project had the intent to destroy a unique, multi-ethnic culture, built through the millennium of history, dignified tolerance, respect, trust and coexistence among all of the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina regardless of their ethnic or religious background. The massive crimes, including genocide, also aimed to frustrate the will of the large majority of the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina who, exactly fifteen years ago, opted for a democratic and equal constitutional and territorial arrangements of our country.
The project of these crimes, however, left us a legacy of an ethnic apartheid in almost half of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, that is in the portion whose authorities, according to the ruling of the International Court of Justice, committed the most gruesome of all crimes, the crime of genocide.
Such a decision of the Court, then, clearly indicates that the constitutional arrangement that is based on ethno-territorial principles was directly caused by genocide, the massive war crimes and crimes against humanity. This ruling, hence, mandates that the results of genocide be nullified, and that is possible solely through the adoption of a completely new constitution which will create a democratic system of government in accordance with the multi-ethnic character of Bosnia and Herzegovina that existed prior to genocide.
Namely, international law places an obligation on all countries of the world:
1. Not to recognize as lawful the situation created by war crimes, crimes against humanity and the crime of genocide; and
2. To cooperate with other States in the application of measures designed to eliminate the consequences of such crimes.
It is, hence, our responsibility and an obligation of the international community to undertake specific measures aimed at nullifying the results of these crimes and to persevere in that struggle.
Primarily, those measures include:
1. Immediate establishment of a special status, outside of the competencies of any of the entities, for Srebrenica and the other Eastern Bosnia municipalities from which the victims of genocide hail;
2. Immediate effectuation of a full and self-sustaining return of all exiled victims of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and the crime of genocide;
3. Immediate adoption of the law prohibiting genocide denial and securing the most rigorous and the most comprehensive application of that law
4. Immediate change of the Citizenship Law whose discriminatory dual citizenship provisions represent a direct continuation of the project of genocide and ethnic cleansing;
5. Constant collection of new evidence which undeniably exist in Serbia’s secret archives and which prove the direct involvement of that country in the crime of genocide in Bosnia and Herzegovina, all with the goal of a reopening the case before the International Court of Justice within the allowed ten year period.
6. Adoption of a completely new constitution which will, in accordance with the Decision of the International Court of Justice and with the principles of international law, completely annul the results of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide on which the current ethno-territorial constitutional arrangement is based; and
7. Final return of a truly multi-ethnic character of Bosnia and Herzegovina in every corner of its territory.
The international community, including the United Nations under whose protection Srebrenica was during the genocide, are obligated under international law to assist Bosnia and Herzegovina with the implementation of these goals. Our duty, in the meantime, is to also work on the betterment of the economic and social situation in our country with the final goal to celebrate the twentieth anniversary of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s independence in a modern, prosperous, fully democratic, multi-ethnic society which will fully annul the results of genocide in every corner of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Address by the Chairman of the BiH Presidency Nebojša Radmanović at the session of the Political Directors of the PIC Steering Board, Brussels, 26
content:
The country that strives to become a member of the European Union may not have any administrative structure above the democratically elected representatives and legal constitutional-political institutions. The forthcoming reforms that Bosnia and Herzegovina is facing, should be a result of the agreement between the elected representatives of all constitutional peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina and should aim at the common progress of the country towards the European future.
Address by the Chairman of the BiH Presidency Nebojša Radmanović at the session of the Political Directors of the PIC Steering Board, Brussels, 26-27. 02. 2007
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Opinions on further role of the international community in Bosnia and Herzegovina are different, both between the political parties as well as among the citizens in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina also has no unique attitude regarding the matter.
Therefore, let me be allowed to express my standpoint as the member of the BH Presidency on this important issue for the future of our country.
At the very beginning let me begin: Owing to the great joint efforts of the international community, local authorities and civil society, Bosnia and Herzegovina has realized a great important progress in the post-war period, which reflects a positive example comparing with other similar crisis regions in the world.
The mandate of the international community that in the past eleven years resulted in numerous advantages, and has helped Bosnia and Herzegovina to stabilize, consolidate and start towards development, on the other hand it has created total dependence of Bosnia and Herzegovina from the international community in political, economic, military and administrative way, which resulted in negative consequences in neglecting domestic political potentials in overtaking their part of responsibility for the destiny of our country.
The current status of the Office of the High Representative does not open the space for credible and responsible political elites and civil society capable to leading Bosnia and Herzegovina towards the European Union.
Each prolongation of such a status of the OHR in Bosnia and Herzegovina with the Bonn powers, keeps the country under the supervision and dependence.
Bosnia and Herzegovina must pass from the status of the international politics object to the status of an authentic subject and creator of its own position in the world.
Bosnia and Herzegovina must be a partner to the international community rather than just a satellite, and it is able to achieve that, should it be given an adequate opportunity. One of the ways is to cease the present mandate of the OHR and its role.
The Office of the High Representative of the international community has exhausted its role in Bosnia and Herzegovina formulated within the Dayton Peace Agreement. The very example is the mandate of the present High Representative, which has provided the space for agreement of the domestic political powers’ representatives, which has proven to be very useful in practice.
Domestic politicians and citizens must be given the opportunity to build their country themselves with the help of the international community on the widely accepted principles of the European standards.
The international community should stay in Bosnia and Herzegovina in the role of an advisor which is most welcome and necessary.
Transformation of the Office of the High Representative into the Office of the Special Representative of the European Union would confirm that Bosnia and Herzegovina has made a significant progress in the reform processes and that the time has come for the domestic politicians to undertake the responsibility for further leading of the country.
All the results that the country has achieved so far, as well as the oncoming reforms, simply require the cessation of the OHR mandate and the abolishment of the High Representative’s the Bonn powers, if the progress of the country towards the European integrations is desired.
The country that strives to become a member of the European Union may not have any administrative structure above the democratically elected representatives and legal constitutional-political institutions.
The forthcoming reforms that Bosnia and Herzegovina is facing, should be a result of the agreement between the elected representatives of all constitutional peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina and should aim at the common progress of the country towards the European future.
Thus the greatest responsibility lies on us, politically elected representatives of the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Our visions, understandings, patience and courage to face the truths, personal and collective delusions, shall influence the speed and tempo of our progressing in the future.
Thank you!

title: Address by the BiH Presidency member Dr. Haris Silajdžić at the session of the Political Directors of the PIC Steering Board (Brussels, February 27, 2007)
content:
The role of the International Community is of prime importance in this respect, and hence it is necessary to prolong the mandate of the OHR with full Bonn powers until Bosnia and Herzegovina is on a safe path to EU and NATO membership. Timeline for prolongation must not be limited. Strategy of the departure of the International Community must be synchronized with the process of Bosnia's integration to Euro-Atlantic institutions.
In his address to the PIC in Brussels, Dr. Silajdžić emphasized that Bosnia and Herzegovina had no alternative to its Euro Atlantic integration path.
The role of the International Community is of prime importance in this respect, and hence it is necessary to prolong the mandate of the OHR with full Bonn powers until Bosnia and Herzegovina is on a safe path to EU and NATO membership. Timeline for prolongation must not be limited. Strategy of the departure of the International Community must be synchronized with the process of Bosnia's integration to Euro-Atlantic institutions.
First of all, Bosnia and Herzegovina needs a new Constitution. A Constitution which would restore its multiethnic character which took centuries to build.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has great potential which can provide better life for all its citizens. However, current constitution system in Bosnia and Herzegovina divides its economic space and prevents it from fulfilling its full potential. Therefore, it is necessary to remove all the obstacles in order to create a single economic space and provide prosperity for all the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
A unique education system is also essential for building a sound democratic society in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The dispersed system of education which we have now separates the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and we still need assistance from the International Community in this respect.

title: Address by the BiH Presidency member Željko Komšić at the session of the PIC Steering Board
content:
I feel that, due to the complicated executive, legal and administrative structure in BiH, the Peace Implementation Council should prolong the mandate of the Office of the High Representative in BiH, including reliance on the Bonn powers, until the BiH Parliament adopts Constitution changes and BiH signs the Stabilization and Association Agreement. In this way, the OHR would fulfill obligations stipulated by its mandate and defined by Dayton Peace Agreement.
Address by the BiH Presidency member H.E. Mr Željko Komšić at the session of the PIC Steering Board- Brussels, 26-27 February 2007
After twelve years of peace in BiH, taking into account our structural complexities, we can make a general conclusion that BiH has taken the right direction of progress and development.
Occasionaly we have certain problems and bouts of stagnation but this can not be considered as the main characteristic of the situation in BiH.
The current situation can be described as a dissacord between “process” and “result”.
Millions of BiH citizens are becoming more and more impatient listening about reform processes and progress, but as we are all aware, there are no final results and their lives remain unchaged.
Objectively speaking, a lot has been achieved, and I do not wish to repeat the well-known phrases which somehow became symbols of progress, like VAT, the reform of defense, OSA, SIPA, CIPS, SBS, etc.
Your Exellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen,
I do not wish to deliver a speech on reasons for this situation. It is obvious that the parties which have ruled in the past 12 years bear primary responsibility for this.
We are all aware that petty daily political and party interests are often more important than issues which can bring about improvement and results.
Even more important is the fact that, as a result of complicated government structure and the heritage of Dayton Agreement, even the slightest sign of lack of political will delays further reforms and blocks them altogether, which might lead to crisis as regards functioning of government institutions.
This “ lack of political will ”, which is necessary for implementation of key reforms which will benefit all citizens, results in unacceptable waste of precious time, which we can not afford.
We can note waste any more time on our path to EU and NATO membership which we are committed to securing. It is even more relevant to realize that we can not waste time wating for “ political will “ which will improve lives of the BiH citizens.
Your Exellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen,
I feel that, due to the complicated executive, legal and administrative structure in BiH, the Peace Implementation Council should prolong the mandate of the Office of the High Representative in BiH, including reliance on the Bonn powers, until the BiH Parliament adopts Constitution changes and BiH signs the Stabilization and Association Agreement. In this way, the OHR would fulfill obligations stipulated by its mandate and defined by Dayton Peace Agreement.
If Bosnia achieved progress beyond the Dayton constitution, the mandate of the OHR would be terminated.
As long as our structure remains unchanged and the support from Europe becomes more adequate and efficient, we need an institution which can remove the obstacles and obstructions in the reform processes.
Citizens in BiH are tired and they can no longer be hostages to endless “processes ” and “ tranzitions” that produce no specific results and improvements.
I am aware that during decision- making process in this case people in charge will consider external factors, like the situation in the region, the status of Kosovo and EU progress of neighbour countries. However, in Bosnia we have our own perspective. This means that we wish to be part of prosperous and thriving region, not hostages to possible instability which might arise in the region, or artificial internal crisis in politics created by local authorities.
We have a lot of tasks ahead, but it is only by sufficient political will in Bosnia and Herzegovina as well as adequate assistance from institutions of the International Community that we can overcome all the obstacles.
Thank you for your attention!

title: Address by the BiH Presidency Chairman Mr Nebojša Radmanović at the North Atlantic Council Meeting
content:
Eleven years ago my country came out of the war which took thousands of human lives, destroyed our economy, and almost took the future away from its peoples. Today, eleven years after, I stand before you ready to sign the NATO PfP Framework Document on behalf of Bosnia and Herzegovina
Dear Mr Chairman,
NATO Secretary General,
Your Exellencies, Ambassadors of the North Atlantic Council,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Eleven years ago my country came out of the war which took thousands of human lives, destroyed our economy, and almost took the future away from its peoples. Today, eleven years after, I stand before you ready to sign the NATO PfP Framework Document on behalf of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Is it too little, or too much, is it too fast or too slow for this time? I am not able to answer this question, and it is historians who should pass their judgement on that matter. I am aware of the fact that Bosnia and Herzegovina is changing each day, that the changes are positive, and that our country is not the same as it used to be several years ago. This is a big day for BiH, its peoples and citizens.
It has been long since our country indicated its readiness to assume the responsibilities and rights implied by the membership in Euro-Atlantic family of free, democratic countries, thus expressing its determination to join the NATO Partnership for Peace programme. This decision reached by the BiH Presidency was reflective of our willingness and hope for the European future, as well as determination to satisfy the criteria and meet all the requirements through necessary reforms. Internal difficulties that our country was facing, as well as obstacles it encountered in foreign policy were accepted as true challenges worthy of effort and renunciation in order to achieve the ultimate goal.
Government bodies in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as our society in general, began introducing fundamental, wide-ranging reforms in the following key fields: economy, defence, public administration, justice, security system, tax system, education, structure of police forces, and many other fields.
The reform in the defence field had a special place and role on the path to Euro-Atlantic integration structures, because of its real significance, complexity, and comprehension.
In short, complex reform processes are aimed at achieving two strategic goals: establishment of functional institutions which guarantee the citizens and peoples of BiH secure and stable surroundings as well as the integration of BiH into Euro-Atlantic structures, especially NATO and the European Union. The PfP membership is one of the first decisive steps on this path.
We owe a debt of gratitude for comprehensive progress and results we achieved to the NATO Alliance: the NATO Headquarters, NATO member countries, and the Headquarters in Sarajevo. NATO stood for Bosnia and Herzegovina with devotion and persistence, and its peacekeeping forces in BiH formed a protective “ shield”, thus creating an atmosphere where
the reforms were accepted as an opportunity and necessity. NATO also encouraged, directed and supported all our reform processes, accepting BiH as its partner.
There are many individuals who put their knowledge, willingnes, and energy in our joint success.We give them our sincere thanks, and they can be essentialy and symbolically represented by the institution of NATO Secretary General.
We will do everything in our power to make BiH a stable and reliable partner, and signing of the Framework Document means more than institutionalizing our relations with the NATO Alliance. Our ultimate goal, which is reflective of general support from political structures and wider public, is the full membership in the NATO Alliance and the European Union.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is at the same time determined to establish and promote bilateral and multilateral relations in the defence field with all the countries that are interested in such a form of cooperation, which would be based on the principles of mutual respect and cooperation. Active participance in attempts to find the solution, as well as to create the programme at the regional level, shows that Bosnia and Herzegovina is determined to enhance its role and importance in the regional cooperation.
As a NATO Alliance partner, we want to develop relations in all the fields that will render our security and defence system proportionate with today's threats and challenges to peace and stability, and at the same time be able to participate and contribute to the international peacekeeping efforts in the system of collective security.
I would like to express once again my thanks for your invitation. I assure you that we are fully aware that this act is merely a step on the long path and that we are ready for new responsibilities and challenges. We are determined to stay on this path, using all our knowledge, energy and efforts which will lead us to further progress.
In this respect, I would like to confirm our determination to cooperate fully with the ITCY and to take all the measures to bring war criminal suspects to justice. The PfP membership does not diminish or neglect our obligations to the Tribunal. Quite the contrary, it presents additional responsibility and opens up new possibilities and perspectives to strengthen the functional institutions which can sucessfully rise to all the challenges, including this one.

title: BiH Presidency Member Haris Silajdžić attended working lunch organized by US Chamber of Commerce (AmCham BiH)
content:
FOREIGN INVESTMENTS AND POLITICAL STABILITY IN BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
Address of BiH Presidency Member Dr Haris Silajdžić
FOREIGN INVESTMENTS AND POLITICAL STABILITY IN BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
“Ladies and Gentlemen
It is a pleasure to be with you here today. I thank you for inviting me here and for inviting me to share with you some of my ideas in an area in which you are yourselves very much involved in Bosnia as well.
INTRODUCTION
Investments for Bosnia and Herzegovina have always been my priority and, although the times have not always been so kind to Bosnia, I can see the new momentum on the horizon. I believe that Bosnia has a very good future and its economic boom is around the corner.
However, the road to success is not an easy one. The political stability is a key factor in that process and, therefore, we will need a fast-track adaptation to suit new trends which are fast becoming our most pressing challenges. The challenges to offer our economy a real chance of showing its full potential.
Bosnia’s progress is very much dependent on its future strategy on economic Euro-Atlantic integration. Political stability and foreign investments are two core issue which need to be addressed. They are also both inter-linked. Political stability is an essential requirement for attracting foreign investment, however, the investments are those that by default offer stability. Bosnia needs to get its priorities right so that we make sure one thing does not become a hostage of the other.
Political stability is a key driving force in establishing a unified economic space, however, it is the economic recovery and its progress that ensure a long-lasting political stability. Delivering an effective economic policy is important in order to unlock the true potential of Bosnia’s resources.
Bosnia’s at the crossroads between the true progress in the Euro-Atlantic integration and its negligence on the margins of the Western Balkans. It must not allow its backward political forces to stop its future generations in claiming true reward of their economic prosperity. That is why some key political issues must be resolved to ensure the next six months bring to Bosnia what all of its peoples deserve – a firm path towards EU and NATO membership.
The International Community must also play its part in that process. The upcoming meeting of the Peace Implementation Council in Brussels is another opportunity for the International Community to show that Bosnia is welcome in its selected membership. Therefore, we need to unblock the outstanding reform processes with the help of the International Community and move forward to signing the Stabilisation and Accession Agreement sooner than later. International Community owes this opportunity to Bosnia’s people. We are ready to accept the challenge as much as we are ready to face our responsibility in the Peace for Partnership program, recently agreed upon.
Bosnia has been showing strong commitment in its path towards democratisation and outward looking. The improved credit rating is one of the signs that the progress is underway.
DEVELOPMENT
Some Economic Indicators
According to the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Relations of Bosnia and Herzegovina direct foreign investments in our country from May 1994 to June 2006 amounted to just over €2 billion. Foreign direct investment to the Bosnian economy was on the highest level in 2004 with the amount of €618 million. In the first six months of 2006 different investors from abroad invested in our country totalling €107 million.
When foreign investments are divided by the sectors it is visible that €1.2 billion in the same period were invested in production sector, which is 57.2 % of total amount. In the second place we find the banking sector with €337 million, or 16.8 %, followed by trade sector with €144 million or 7.2 %. Tourism, service, transport and other industries cover the remainder of 18.8 % of foreign investments.
Foreign investments divided by investor countries in the same period, between 1994 until June 2006, are as follows:
Biggest foreign investor in our country is Croatia with €316 million, or 15.7 %, followed by Austria with €293 million, or 14.6 %. Slovenia is in third place with €257 million, or 12.8 %.
United States of America is in 15th place on investors list with €20.7 million, or just 1 %. Some indicators show that since 1995 to date, the US have spent more then $1 billion in support of peace process, economic transform, increase of transparency in political and public life, building infrastructure, NGO sector, media and many other useful projects, as well as it largely contributed to the humanitarian aid in addition.
On the other hand, despite the sharp increase in inflation rate following the introduction of Value Added Tax (VAT), the Economist Intelligence Unit expects that strong investments and exports will drive Bosnia’s annual average real GDP growth of 5.4% in 2007-08. Moreover, even though the foreign export deficit in Bosnia and Herzegovina is high, at €3.2 billion, the exports have risen by 25% as opposed to the 11% increase in imports. In terms of the trade the Bosnia is in the best position with the United States of America. The US appears to be the only country so far that Bosnia’s trade is not in deficit. Of course to this position big help comes in from the recent sharp increased in activity. In the last 10 months the level of trade with the US has increased by astonishing 90%, according to Bosnia and Herzegovina Chamber of Commerce. This is all a result of an increased activity by the US, not only in trade, but also in other areas, such as, helping young people find their first jobs by establishing a new web portal, as well as a transfer of $8 million to 4 micro-credit funds by USAID. More opportunities will come when the new initiative on CEFTA agreement materialises, which we hope will happen soon. Many opportunities lie with the Small and Medium Enterprises in Bosnia and Herzegovina. We hope that big international companies specialising in mediation will realise the potential in establishing contacts between Bosnia’s SMEs and those around the world. Our problem with the privatisation currently administered at the entity level is hampering the level of activity in Bosnia, which otherwise would have been much higher, however, this gives a lot of advantage to new SMEs. Of course, more effort will be needed to compose efficient and effective SME strategy proposal. The failure to adopt the workable SME strategy is one among other reasons for the decrease in the foreign direct investments (by 4% by mid-2006).
On the other hand the trade with the EU is far the greatest. 70% of all trade in Bosnia is carried out with 5 countries, three of which are from the EU. Again the list of goods exported fits a narrow list. They are mostly from minerals, metal and metal related goods, 40%, while chemicals and wood products account for further 20%.
To single out one sector that performs at an envious level it would have to be the banking sector. The operations continue to grow strongly and total assets have increased to 80% of GDP. There are only 6 banks in FBiH left to be privatised, while most of other banks are owned by foreign banks – current percentage of share of foreign capital stands at 73%.
Overall, the economic growth in the last year was recorded at 5.5%, even thought its mainly based on raw materials and related manufacturing. More diversification and increase in value and prices should help the figures grow even higher. Of course, the major contributing factor will be the straightening the countries institutions so that the legislation does not block the growth but rather serves to stimulate it.
State strategy for economic development
First and most important step for Bosnia and Herzegovina is to define State strategy for economic development.
- What is going to be the main focus of our economic development?
- How to be recognised in the world?
When we define our goals, all other steps will follow that decision. We have to apply strategic marketing management and try to manage our country as a corporation. There are lot of discussions in Bosnia about economy, our potential, chances, and resources which can bring a better life for all. We can often hear that Bosnia has good chances for economic growth if it develops and invests in energy sector, tourism, wood industry, healthy food production, and, of course, construction of corridor 5-c. In the last few years a development of computer industry has also showed very strong growth. In 2002 there were 200 companies in this sector. In 2005 that number jumped to 2,587 companies. A very interesting point here is that 70 % of these companies are partially or completely owned by Bosnians.
When we define strategic directions of our development we will present our projects and attract foreign investments. Based on our goals of strategic expansion we will need to build our infrastructure across the spectrum.
State marketing: Proactive managing of state image
Promote Bosnia and Herzegovina and its resources. Bosnia needs to be recognised as attractive tourist destination and good place to invest capital in.
How is Bosnia’s image supposed to be recognisable? What are the Bosnia’s recognisable features?
- Switzerland, fore example, is recognised by secured banks.
- Bosnia’s trademark is in tourism, healthy food, multi-cultural monuments, huge energy potential.
Recent CNN promotion of Bosnia and Herzegovina is good example of our changing marketing strategy in the series of short promotional clips - “Enjoy life in Bosnia”.
Targeted investment projects
Bosnia needs stable political system, good economy, modern infrastructure so that we build strong platform for progress. What are some of the forthcoming challenging and optimistic projects?
Corridor 5 – C
Every one is talking about construction of this very important European highway. This project has to be approached seriously and professionally. We must not make the same mistake twice. The initial project proposal by American Bechtel and Turkish company Enka was a missed opportunity. Had we taken it up, we would have been well into the building of one of the most important corridors which would link north border of Bosnia to the Adriatic Sea. Today we have to approach that project with more conviction and remove all administrative and political obstacles and start with the construction. Everyone is aware how this project can push economic growth forward in a number of sectors. This project should be our common goal and it should show our unity, and not just ours but also of our neighbours. All people in our country are expecting that. We are sure that we can bring the investors who will be able build this highway.
Energy sector
This sector holds a great opportunity for Bosnia and Herzegovina as well. There is huge competition in the region for it. We cannot be late in this competition. Europe needs additional energy production. Our country can offer that energy, because of our great resources. We have enough space and potential to built new hydro and thermo power plants. Our government has received some offers by a number of large foreign investors and we hope that some of them will materialise. It is important to ensure the environment is protected, the competition is transparent and the investment is in the best interest of Bosnia’s people. Also, a number of world banks have expressed interest in contributing to the financing of this project as well. The energy sector is believed to have the potential to attract few billion Euros of foreign investment and we will commit our best efforts to see this come through.
Tourism
Before the war of 1990s Bosnia was recognized throughout the World by hosting 14th Olympic Winter Games in 1984. It is time for another fresh positive image of Bosnia in the world. Bosnia still has beautiful Olympic mountains throughout its territory. Winter sport resorts at Jahorina, Igman, Bjelasnica, Vlasic, Kupres and Trebevic offer unique beauty and potential for winter tourism. Besides winter tourism, our country can offer heritage and religious tourism. Four main religions: Islam, Catholicism, Christian-Orthodox and Judaism meet each other in this country. Those attractions can be interesting for many regional and international tourists. Besides mentioned possibilities there are beautiful rivers and other untouchable areas of Bosnian nature which can be attractions for many visitors. This sector can develop and attract investors to build modern hotels and resorts, which can bring billions to the Bosnian economy. Tourism will be one of the priorities of our development in the future.
Incentives for Foreign Investments in BiH
Firstly, the main tax incentive is a 5-year tax deduction relief for foreign investors with 20% or more share of company assets, plus a 100% tax relief for the re-invested profit of the same business.
Secondly, for the politically averse investors who are concerned about transfer restrictions, expropriation, war and civil disturbances and denial of justice, the availability of the political risk insurance offers peace of mind. This type of insurance is available through the European Union Investment Guarantee Trus Fund for BiH, which is administered b the Mulitlateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), which is a member of the World Bank Group. In addition, the US Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) also provides political risk insurance for investors. However, the recently improved credit rating score given to BiH by Moody’s means less concern for the investors in respect of political risk.
Thirdly, many countries have signed agreements with Bosnia and Herzegovina on avoidance of double taxation, however, not the United States of America, unfortunately.
Fourthly, many foreign investors see a lot of advantage in establishing their businesses in one of several Bosnia’s duty free zones, which have many advantages in relation to taxation.
On the other hand, Bosnia has many riches and they are not just its natural resources (energy, mines, tourism). Bosnia also has young and well qualified workforce. This is one of its great assets, especially considering that shortage of skilled labour is a big problem with which many EU countries are facing themselves.
SUMMERY
Our economic strategy is full recovery of Bosnia’s potential. The path towards Euro-Atlantic integration requires strenuous work on the reform process. Partnership for Peace membership means much more responsibility for us, however, the investments are needed in Bosnia and we will work hard to make sure those responsibilities are taken seriously. The SAA agreement is also needed to help boost Bosnia’s hope for the better future and simultaneously help the democratic progress as well.
We need the International Community not just as the critic of our shortcomings but also as our partner – partner that will endure our political complexities and help us transform our politically fragmented mind-frame and steer it towards building more stable democracy.
Everyone understands that it is the economic stability through the participation of the foreign investments by which Bosnia sees its stability improve. The will of the political leadership across the international spectrum is needed to help Bosnia’s transformation.
Our economic priorities are building our infrastructure, such as highway – corridor 5c -, which will not only help Bosnia’s economy, but it will also open the door for more democratisation and building a stronger civil society.
Exploring our energy sector, such as construction of the electric power plants, will enhance Bosnia’s competitiveness on the open market and, thus, improve our export capabilities. This will in itself help increase the employment rate as it will open up other opportunities in the mining sector and others as well.
Eco-tourism is still awaiting its recovery and we hope to achieve significant developments there. More winter sports, mountaineering, sightseeing, thermal baths, beach snorkelling are just some of the attractions of Bosnia’s tourism potential.
In the end, we ask for the extended presence of the International Community in Bosnia and to help us establish Bosnia on the firm path towards Euro-Atlantic integration. We welcome its assistance in all sectors of our political reform. We urge the political leadership of the International Community to exert all the necessary political pressure here and abroad to secure Bosnia’s irrevocable process of EU integration. We still need some strong presence of the International Community through the Office of the High Representative until we are securely on this path.
Last but not least, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your time. Thank you for listening and I hope you will yourselves play a part in Bosnia’s new phase of economic recovery."

title: Speech by the BiH Presidency Chairman, Nebojša Radmanović at the ceremony of celebrating the first anniversary of the BiH Armed Forces
content:
Precisely due to all achieved and today, the Armed Forces Day, I pay my tribute to all the active participants in the reform processes. I am convinced that the Bosnia and Herzegovina Ministry of Defence and the Bosnia and Herzegovina Armed Forces, based on the democratic principles and cooperation, would do everything to grow Bosnia and Herzegovina into a country where everybody would feel equal and contented.
SPEECH
BY THE BIH PRESIDENCY CHAIRMAN
NEBOJŠA RADMANOVIĆ
AT THE CEREMONY OF CELEBRATING THE FIRST ANNIVERSARY
OF THE BIH ARMED FORCES
01.12.2006
“Your Excellencies,
Gentlemen generals, officers non-commissioned officers, soldiers
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my great pleasure to address you, in the name of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is the Chief Ccommander of the Armed Forces, on the first anniversary of the established Bosnia and Herzegovina Armed Forces Day.
Celebrating December 1st represents a lot more then simply an act of our joint memory of the process of establishing the armed forces. It is, we have to point it out today, a very painstaking, work and agreement-filled process and by itself, it represents an important step.
That successful job, both amply and with high quality, was filled with efforts and knowledge of a large number of people from Bosnia and Herzegovina, with a help and impetus of a part of the International community. At the same time, that act of BiH Armed Forces establishment sent out a message that if there were a readiness and concerted actions of all the subjects equally, there would be a success.
Excelling in reforms in the area of defence that has gone the farthest and that is something that should please us, is a strong and positive message from Bosnia and Herzegovina. If that could happen in the area of defence and security, i.e. exactly where it is reasonable to expect the biggest problems after the end of the war, then we can rightfully hope to see progress in other areas as well. The best confirmation of our joint efforts in this area is an invitation for Bosnia and Herzegovina to join the NATO program”Partnership for Peace”.
Naturally, something like that requires a great effort and will on the part of the debate participants as well, and the sincere wish to seek solutions that would be in the interest of all the subjects. I sincerely hope that trough these processes, we have learned something, which would allow us progress in other areas.
Precisely due to all achieved and today, the Armed Forces Day, I pay my tribute to all the active participants in the reform processes. I am convinced that the Bosnia and Herzegovina Ministry of Defence and the Bosnia and Herzegovina Armed Forces, based on the democratic principles and cooperation, would do everything to grow Bosnia and Herzegovina into a country where everybody would feel equal and contented.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
We will remain in the reform process continuum as long as the main goal is not fulfilled, which is dimensioning the armed forces in accordance with the country’s realistic opportunities, in the function of its foreign policy of developing friendly good-neighbourly relations. The neighbours of Bosnia and Herzegovina share that orientation, and the goal of every country in the region in which we are located, is the Euro-Atlantic, economic, political and military integrations.

title: The speech by Željko Komšić, the BiH Presidency Member on occasion of celebrating the National Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
The BiH Presidency Member, Željko Komšić, on occasion of the National Day of BiH, has laid flowers at the commemorative mausoleum Papirna in Zenica, where he addressed a great number of citizens with an appropriate speech.
The BiH Presidency Member, Željko Komšić, on occasion of the National Day of BiH, has laid flowers at the commemorative mausoleum Papirna in Zenica, where he addressed a great number of citizens with an appropriate speech.
“Comrades,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Dear friends,
Dear citizens,
In the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina, ZAVNOBIH is one of the most important events, whose decisions unrepeatably confirmed the historic and political individuality of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a State union of the Bosniacs, the Serbs, the Croats and all other peoples living in it.
In blizzard, great winter and storm, during the German occupation, on November 25 1943, 247 delegates, heroes, members of all peoples in BiH, hungry and frozen, broke trough to reach the first session of ZAVNOBIH in Mrkonjić Grad and there, they laid foundations of a new statehood of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
After 480 years of Bosnian country’s kismet, in 1463, on this day, 63 years ago, the foundations for statehood of BiH were laid again, guaranteeing the equality to all its peoples.
It is beyond dispute that the ZAVNOBIH is a cornerstone of a modern, up-to-date statehood of BiH, but at the same time, is it a model pointing at ways in which we could live happily, not just together.
I believe that ZAVNOBIH is one of the most important dates in the history of BiH. It has established one free, sovereign country, an equal community of all its peoples and citizens. Without those principles, of course, there can be no State in these areas.
BiH has undergone a lot since the ZAVNOBIH times ‘till today, something due to certain enemies, something due to certain politics.
