Therefore, I wish to thank the European Commission for ensuring funds for building eight border crossings, out of those three have already been built. I remind you that the European Commission funds were used to rebuild the bridge on river Sava as well. In addition, I thank ambassador Michael Humphreys.
Ladies and Gentlemen
This border crossing, as well as the others, will ensure a faster and a more efficient work of border guards and customs officials. That will ensure a shorter stopping and a quicker crossing, which is important as for the citizens, as for economy as well.
That is also important for Bosanska Posavina. Completing this project, as well as the others, primarily in the area of waterpower engineering and agriculture, will be development stimulus for the Posavina region. Construction of the Corridor 5c and railroad and harbour transport also fall into that category. Here we have an oil industry as well. In that way, Bosanska Posavina will take its rightful place in development of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
I expect to have support from the International Community in these projects, primarily the European Commission.
In the end, I wish a fast and successful work completion and I hope that we will soon have an opportunity to witness the ceremony of opening this crossing, and the successful completion of other projects in this region as well.
Thank you!”

title: H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech on occasion of opening the Visoko
content:
I congratulate and thank everybody who contributed to the construction of this highway section, notably the Government of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and B-H Telekom.
Opening the Visoko-Podlugovi section of the Sarajevo-Zenica Highway
July 10, 2006
“Dear Ladies and Gentlemen,
I wish to say salaam and greet you, as well as to express my pleasure for witnessing the ceremony of work completion and opening the Visoko-Podlugovi highway section.
I congratulate and thank everybody who contributed to the construction of this highway section, notably the Government of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and B-H Telekom.
The construction of this highway section, the quality work and meeting the highest standards confirm that Bosnia and Herzegovina has a construction practise and experts capable of building modern highways. Therefore, I congratulate them as well.
As every citizen, I expect that the work on the next section Kakanj-Visoko will continue as soon as possible. We have to go faster and build much more highway kilometres per year. That is why we need a better organization and the European legislation. We must adopt laws ensuring the just compensation and efficient procedure urgently, which will accelerate the construction work.
Of course, we also need large financial means. As a possible solution to ensuring the necessary means, I see using the profit made by selling the public companies, including the one made by privatising the BH Telekom.
It is not good to reach the standards of the 21st century in the sphere of telecommunication while still being in 19th or first half of 20th century in motorway and railroad communication. With the privatisation funds, we will ensure money not only for the Corridor 5c but also for fast motorways Sarajevo-Tuzla, Stolac-Neum, Sarajevo-Gorazde, Busovaca-Travnik etc. We must also modernize the railroad transportation.
I believe that for our country, still burdened with repairing the consequences of sufferings and destruction, this is the best way. The Budget cannot do it, and a major debt would endanger other development projects. We can hardly get concessionaires, and we do not have time to wait for them any longer.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The Corridor 5c is a project of uniting the country and its progress. Where the corridor passes, the lines of separation and division (entity, cantonal, municipal) disappear.
We must create foundations in order to build the Corridor 5c in several sections – north and south of the country. Toward that goal, I find important to start with the work in the north part – the entrance in Bosnia and Herzegovina. That means building a bridge on the river Sava near Svilaj, at the border with the Republic of Croatia, and a Highway section toward Doboj.
With better roads, we are ensuring linkage between our regions, a regional development, and an even demographic disposition. In addition, we are connecting Bosnia and Herzegovina with other countries; we are establishing better business cooperation and creating grounds for development and enhancement of tourism.
Therefore, I wish that opening this highway section would be a NEW BEGINNING, not just faster construction of the Corridor 5c, but also of the entire development and prosperity of our country.
Once again, I congratulate everyone who participated in this project, especially the contractors.
Thank you!”

title: H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech at the inaugural assembly of the Adriatic Euro
content:
The District of Istria, with its position, history, diversity, tolerance and openness is the best place for founding, i.e. holding the Inaugural Assembly of the Euro-Adriatic Region
Pula, June 30, 2006
“Dear President Mesic,
Head of District Jakovcic,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I thank you for inviting me to participate in the work of the Adriatic Euro-Region and an opportunity to address you.
The District of Istria, with its position, history, diversity, tolerance and openness is the best place for founding, i.e. holding the Inaugural Assembly of the Euro-Adriatic Region.
The Adriatic has always had an important role in our countries’ relations – mostly as a factor of connecting various peoples and cultures of its coasts. Unfortunately, sometimes it served as a pretext for conflicts. For a very long time, the Adriatic Sea also served as a major traffic route for trade between the rest of Europe and the world and our region, but also as a path, which was used by the foreign conquerors and their influence. We want it only as a connection and cooperation place and that is why we are here today.
Our countries connected by the Adriatic Sea have many things in common – history, similar traditions, cuisine, and the charming southern mentality we share. All that represents an additional reason for intensifying our cooperation.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a maritime country, not so much as the others, but is faced toward the Adriatic in many things. As a multiethnic country, where different peoples, members of the four great world monotheistic religions, have lived for centuries, Bosnia and Herzegovina is very interested in establishing a comprehensive cooperation with the other countries of the Adriatic region.
There is plenty of room for that kind of cooperation, at the local and regional level as well as at the State one, in tourism, environmental protection, culture, sports, economy, infrastructural projects, and cooperation in the International organizations.
The regional connection will certainly contribute to the protection of the Adriatic, strengthening the economic and cross-border cooperation, aiming at a quicker access to the European Union for the member countries. Apart from that, connecting the Adriatic to its inland is also important. Here I mean the economic and tourist connection. When we in Bosnia-Herzegovina talk about the Adriatic – Neum, we must also mention Medjugorje, Mostar and the Olympic mountains of Sarajevo and other attractive destinations. This is important as for tourism, as for the cultural cooperation. Here today, are also the representatives of a B-H region – the Herzegovina-Neretva Canton, but they also represent the entire Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Therefore, I once again congratulate you on this good initiative. In the name of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I give you my full support and send my best wishes for a successful work.

title: H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech at the session of the Peace Implementation Council’s Supervisory Board
content:
I thank for the possibility to address the Peace Implementation Council Supervisory Board today. The announcement of reaching a decision to close the Office of the High Representative and the transformation into the Special Representative of the European Union is certainly one of the most important decisions after the Dayton Agreement
Speech at the session of the Peace Implementation Council’s Supervisory Board
Sarajevo, June 22, 2006
“Dear members of the Peace Implementation Council’s Supervisory Board,
Mr. High Representative,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I greet you and welcome you to Bosnia-Herzegovina and Sarajevo. I thank PIC and the Supervisory Board for the support in the previous implementation of the Dayton Agreement.
I thank for the possibility to address the Peace Implementation Council Supervisory Board today. The announcement of reaching a decision to close the Office of the High Representative and the transformation into the Special Representative of the European Union is certainly one of the most important decisions after the Dayton Agreement.
First and foremost, I would again like to emphasize the firm determination for our country’s European way, as a perspective without any alternative. Bosnia-Herzegovina’s membership in the European Union and NATO is the best way to establish a permanent peace, stability and prosperity as in Bosnia-Herzegovina, as in the entire region of the Southeastern Europe.
A significant progress in all fields has been achieved in Bosnia-Herzegovina. After ten years, many would agree that it was a logical follow-up and that it is time for the B-H institutions to take over the full responsibility.
It is completely normal that it is also a wish of every citizen of Bosnia-Herzegovina, because it would be a confirmation of the previous progress and the achieved results, as well as the comprehensive stability in the country. It certainly means ending the OHR and Bonn powers. However, apart from the achieved progress, many in Bosnia-Herzegovina, including myself, are concerned about the announcement of an impending adoption of such a decision.
Why? Because the constitutional-legal and political requirements for the B-H institutions to take over the responsibility for the situation in the country have not been met yet.
Withdrawing the High Representative and ending the Bonn powers now could lead to work blockade of the institutions of Bosnia-Herzegovina, as well as a hold-up in conducting the reforms and meeting the European requirements. The Annex IV of the B-H Constitution cannot function without the Annex X – the Civilian Implementation, i.e. OHR, unless reviews and amendments to the Constitution were carried out prior to it.
Furthermore, almost all institutions at the level of Bosnia-Herzegovina are composed on the principle of parity and consensus decision-making. The institute of veto is widely represented and can be used, almost limitlessly, under the form of so-called protection of ethnic or entity interest. All of these are constitutional mechanisms of institutional work blockade, and without any de-blockade mechanisms (the example of work blockade of the Parliament, Council of Ministers, appointing the SIPA Director, DGS, revenue distribution, police reform, etc.)
If, without the previous Constitutional review, the Office of the High Representative is shut done and the Bonn powers are ended, there will be a possibility of endangering the previously achieved progress. Transferred powers of the formed institution of Bosnia-Herzegovina and their functioning could seriously become endangered. We are witnessing the common announcements of returning the transferred powers from State to Entity and the blockade of B-H institutions’ work.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Whatever the case may be, I believe that the time is not right for making such decisions. I am primarily referring to the failure in adopting the amendments to the B-H Constitution and the radicalisation of situation due to it. This is an election year when it is normally difficult to carry out the reforms. Closing the OHR and ending the Bonn powers will encourage the antireform forces in blocking or delaying the execution of reforms, waiting for the OHR mandate to expire.
The second reason is the situation in the region, affecting the situation in Bosnia-Herzegovina in one way or another. We are witnessing the appeals for referendum for the RS’s secession, after announcing the Montenegro’s independence. Before us is a decision on the final status of Kosovo. What also needs to be mentioned is that the most wanted war criminals are still at large.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Because of all previously mentioned, I believe that such decisions should not be reached today, not even in the form of an announcement. Prior to it, we should:
1. wait for the election results and form the government
2. adopt amendments to the Constitution of Bosnia-Herzegovina that will create legal grounds for the discontinuation of mandate and ending the Bonn powers of the High Representative
3. sign the Association and Stabilisation Agreement with EU
If the moderate forces win the elections, form the government, adopt the first phase of Constitutional reforms, and sign the Association and Stabilisation Agreement, it will be logical to reach such decisions. In the meantime, the Kosovo status will be solved, and most likely, the remaining war suspects will be arrested.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my duty and responsibility to point out to you the possible consequences of a premature adoption of such a decision. Do not allow the destabilisation of situation and repeating the situation from 1992 due to a bad judgement. You have a great responsibility.
Do not allow that a successful project of the International Community becomes endangered. We are close to success. We have a chance in Bosnia-Herzegovina, where the greatest monotheistic religions meet and most intensely intertwine, to confirm the thesis of possibility of coexistence of diversity, and in that way, to refute the theory of civilisation conflict in the best possible way.
Please, before making a decision, reconsider what I have just told you.”

title: H Presidency Member Ivo Miro Jovic’s speech at the Central Conference of the 14th festivity ‘Lipanjske zore Mostar 1992
content:
SPEECH BY B-H PRESIDENCY MEMBER FROM THE CROATIAN PEOPLE
Mr IVO MIRO JOVIC
ON OCCASION OF CELEBRATING THE 14TH ANNIVERSARY OF FESTIVITY
‘LIPANJSKE ZORE – MOSTAR’,
THE CROATIAN CENTRE ‘STJEPAN KOSACA’, JUNE 21, 2006
“Dear defenders of Mostar, members of HVO, ladies and gentlemen,
I greet you all at this central gathering, organized on occasion of the traditional 14th anniversary of festivity ‘Lipanjske zore-Mostar’ 1992-2006.
This is an opportunity when we can remind ourselves of the great and difficult moments for the defenders of the city of Mostar, the members of HVO and the entire valley of the river Neretva.
The importance of events in June 1992 bears a historic dimension for the Croatian people, HVO, the city of Mostar and the entire B-H.
We must always stress out these facts so that history could properly appreciate the given contribution of the Croats to the defence of Bosnia-Herzegovina and the Republic of Croatia. Therefore, we are glad to say thanks to Zvonimir Puljic the Mayor of Split, for being here with us today…
In these events, the Croats of the valley of Neretva, organized in HVO units, stopped the enemy in his strategic direction of attack, in that way defended their home, their city of Mostar, and gave an immeasurable contribution to the defence of the entire B-H.
Proud of those days, of all the participants of those events, I wish to thank them on this occasion as well.
Considering the magnitude and the significance of the defence of the Neretva valley, we cannot but to express our dissatisfaction with the fact that some of us, to this day, are not ready to accept those facts and say thanks to defenders of the city of Mostar, thanks to members of HVO.
Instead, today we face the strongly-expressed desire for criminalization of our Patriotic War, its most important participants, who are incarcerating, persecuting, abusing and arresting.
Such actions aim to belittle the truly given contribution of the Croats and HVO in defending B-H, but also to frighten us, and weaken us in our fight for the equality of peoples in B-H.
All this is part of political processes, trough which the Croatian people is being deprived of their rights and not brought in the same position as the other two peoples in B-H.
However, we cannot and will not be discouraged or despair because of those challenges and intentions. This is our country, this is where our home is and so it shall remain.
We proudly emphasize our given contribution in the Patriotic War; we condemn everything unacceptable that was done, because we cannot fall into a trap of a collective guilt of the entire people, and allow others to attribute our credits to themselves.
We cannot and will not allow it.
Dear defenders, members of HVO,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The current political moment in B-H demands patience, persistence and wisdom from all of us in order to have the peoples in B-H participating in political processes, which should result in a new just constitutional-legal organization of B-H as a home for all three constituent and sovereign people that will enjoy all the deserved collective and civil rights trough legislative, judicial and executive power.
It will not be easy to achieve that goal, especially bearing in mind the fact that points to the political disunity of the Croatian essence, manifested trough the establishment of a great number of political parties with the Croatian mark on them, which considering the Croatian demographic situation in B-H, could be dangerous during the impending general elections in B-H.
Everyone must be aware of these facts, i.e. must stop disbanding the political origin of the Croats in B-H, especially if the reason is within an individual personal interest.
Because of your sacrifice, defenders, no one has a right to these actions in this country.
Our better political future is directly conditioned with our real political unity without declarative, verbal, empty statements and calls for the need of political unity.
An example of this real unity was shown by you defenders, during the most difficult war times; that example must also be followed by the current political Heads.
Without such approach, we will not be a political factor as a people, and our representatives in the power bodies will be elected by others.
Today, when we are celebrating this important anniversary of the Patriotic War, we want to send a message to everyone in B-H – the Croats are for the political cooperation based on principles of equality, without domination of one over the other, including the respect for every European democratic standard ensuring the basic rights of preserving the identity of every people.
With such an idea, you defenders have stood up, made a sacrifice and defended your and our town Mostar.
Once again, I wish to say a sincere human thanks to all the members of HVO, victims’ families and wounded defenders of the Patriotic War, believing that the sacrifice you made will not be in vain. That is why we are here today to be proud of your deeds.
THANK YOU”

title: H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech at the press conference
content:
in the period of June 6-8, 2006, upon invitation of the Emir of the State of Qatar, His Majesty Hamad bin Al-Thani, I was in an official visit to Qatar
Speech by B-H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic
at the press conference
Sarajevo, June 8, 2006
“Ladies and Gentlemen,
in the period of June 6-8, 2006, upon invitation of the Emir of the State of Qatar, His Majesty Hamad bin Al-Thani, I was in an official visit to Qatar.
During the visit, I had following meetings with:
- Emir of Qatar Hamad bin Halifa Al-Thani
- Prime Minister of Qatar Sheikh Abdallah bin Khalifa Al-Thani
- Minister of Foreign Affairs of Qatar Ahmad Abdallah Al-Mahmud
- President of the Qatar Foundation for Education and Qatar Emir’s wife Sheikha Moza bint Nasser Al-Misned
I also had a meeting with President of the Qatar Economic Chamber Council Sheikh Halifa bin Jassim Bin Muhamad Al-Thani and 80 prominent Qatar’s businessmen, whom I had informed with the economic potentials of our country.
On that occasion, the Protocol on establishing the Business Council for Economic Cooperation between Bosnia-Herzegovina and Qatar was signed. Mr. Tomislav Grizelj, the President of Businessmen’ Association and the Vice-president of the B-H Foreign Trade Chamber’s Administrative Committee signed the Protocol on behalf of Bosnia-Herzegovina. Mrs. Jasna Krivosic-Prpic, the FIPA General Director’s deputy was also a member of the Delegation, and she had a distinguished speech and a presentation of possibilities for investing in our country.
I also visited the University of Qatar, as well as the Qatar’s City of Education, where I talked with the officials of those institutions.
During my stay in Doha, I also visited the head office of Al-Jazeera, where I gave a longer interview.
The main contents of the visit:
1. I have initiated Qatar’s participation in two great business projects in our country:
- Building the Corridor 5C
- Qatar’s entry in the oil and natural gas market in B-H, trough privatization, i.e. additional capitalisation of our companies/facilities in this domain.
The Emir of Qatar took these proposals with a great interest and he authorised the Government to examine them thoroughly.
2. The initiative for discussions about additional capitalisation of Air Bosna/BH Airlines was accepted, in the way that the Qatar national airline company, or a private sector, would enter their capital in Air Bosna, using the airport in Sarajevo as their port to Europe, and open the line Sarajevo – Doha – Malaysia – Australia.
3. Qatar has shown interest for the spring water import from our country. Emir Hamad bin Halifa Al-Thani agreed with me that during the next visit to his country, we should drink the water from Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Since we are talking about the great project, it is necessary to create a consortium of the largest B-H water producers, so that they would come out as a joint brand in not only the market of Qatar, but the entire region as well.
4. They confirmed their willingness to continue with the completion of projects of sustainable returns to our country. In that sense, an initiative to finance a concrete project in Srebrenica – building a Factory for fruit and vegetable canning, has been accepted.
5. Emir also accepted a request for Qatar’s financial support to the B-H Court and building the state penitentiary.
6. An initiative has been accepted for awarding permanent scholarships for educating a certain number of children without parents in our country, with the continuation of scholarships for B-H students in abroad.
7. Aiming to enhance the relations, opening the embassy of Qatar in Bosnia-Herzegovina has been agreed, because we are currently being covered from Rome – Italy.
8. Qatar Emir gladly accepted an invitation to visit Bosnia-Herzegovina soon.
Qatar has a very friendly attitude toward Bosnia-Herzegovina, which we experienced ourselves during this visit. Not only were we accepted with the highest State honours, but His Majesty Emir of Qatar has personally provided a special airplane for a trip to Doha.”

title: H Presidency Chairman, H.E. SULEJMAN TIHIC addressing the businessmen of Qatar
content:
It is our wish that Bosnia-Herzegovina, in the following period, becomes the most important destination for Qatar’s investment in the Southeastern Europe. Bosnia-Herzegovina can become a door to European Union for Qatar’s businessmen
The Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia-Herzegovina, H.E. SULEJMAN TIHIC
addressing the businessmen of Qatar
Doha, June 7, 2006
“Your Excellency Sheikh Halifa bin Jassim bin Muhammad Al-Thani, the President of the Qatar Economic Chamber,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Allow me to express my pleasure with having this opportunity to speak to you today, here in Doha, on occasion of my official visit to the friendly State of Qatar.
The State of Qatar and His Majesty Emir Sheikh Hamad bin Halifa Al-Thani have a special place in our hearts. We will never forget your support to our country in the most difficult moments of our past, nor the help to the post-war reconstruction of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
It is my great pleasure to witness today the signing of the Agreement on establishment of a Joint Business Council of Bosnia-Herzegovina and Qatar, which we see as an important step in intensification of economic cooperation between our two countries.
There is a lot of space for establishing the economic cooperation between our countries.
It is our wish that Bosnia-Herzegovina, in the following period, becomes the most important destination for Qatar’s investment in the Southeastern Europe. Bosnia-Herzegovina can become a door to European Union for Qatar’s businessmen.
And now, couple of information about my country:
Bosnia-Herzegovina is a multi-ethnic State where three largest world monotheistic religions – Islam, Catholicism and Orthodoxy – most intensively meet, intertwine and coexist. In Sarajevo, which is also called the European Jerusalem, and in other B-H cities as well, for hundreds of years, side by side, stand mosques, catholic and orthodox churches, somewhere even synagogues. After the war ended 10 years ago, an established peace has never been violated. We are restructuring the country and economy, but also the multiethnic structure of society.
A macroeconomic stability has been achieved with an inflation such as is in the European Union. We have the strongest currency in the region. Compared to the post-war period, GDP has been tripled. Foreign exchange reserves have been increased 15 times. We are regularly paying off our foreign debt. The industry production and foreign investment are in a constant growth. Banking system has been consolidated, and now is a complete private property. In Bosnia-Herzegovina, there is a large number of well-known banks and renowned world investors, such as Coca-Cola, Siemens, Volkswagen, Ispat Group, Kia, LNM, Daimler Chrysler, etc.
We have a very competent and educated human potential. B-H companies have a significant experience in working in the world markets and can be a good and useful business partner. Bosnia-Herzegovina has signed agreements on free trade with also every country in the region of the Southeastern Europe. Thus, when arriving to Bosnia-Herzegovina, you get the market of around 150 millions of consumers. We have a free, duty-free export to the countries of European Union. Apart from that, we have the most liberal law on investment that makes no difference between the domestic and foreign investors.
The possibilities for investment in our country are countless. I would like here to point to our comparative advantages in the sectors of industry, agriculture, energy, tourism (winter, summer, spa and religious), information technologies, oil industry and mining. As a good example of potential investment, I would like to cite a possibility of investing in the national airline company BH AIRLINES.
We are especially interested in investing in great infrastructural projects like Corridor 5c – building a freeway across Bosnia-Herzegovina in length of 320 km., this project is of extreme importance, not only as an infrastructural, but also as a development and integration project that reunites Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Due to all that, I invite you to come to Bosnia-Herzegovina and convince yourself of all the advantages our country can offer to you. Welcome to Bosnia-Herzegovina!

title: H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech on occasion of the visit of the Turkish war ship TURGUTREIS
content:
This visit represents a continuity of friendly relations between our two countries, but also a confirmation of a sovereignty of Bosnia-Herzegovina in its territorial waters
The visit of the war ship TURGUTREIS of the Republic of Turkey
to the territorial waters of Bosnia-Herzegovina
Neum, June 3, 2006
“Mr. Ambassador of the Republic of Turkey Bulent Tulum,
Mr. Commander of the war ship Omer Cetin
Gentlemen Ministers, Ambassadors,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I wish to say salaam to you all, to greet you and express my pleasure for gathering here at the Turkish war ship TURGUTREIS today.
I especially wish to greet the ship’s crew and express welcome to the territorial waters of B-H’s part of the Adriatic Sea.
This visit represents a continuity of friendly relations between our two countries, but also a confirmation of a sovereignty of Bosnia-Herzegovina in its territorial waters.
Today we have a visit of the Turkish war ship. A while ago, there were French, German and American war ships here. Due to those, and for other, primarily economic reasons, it is necessary that the authorities of Bosnia-Herzegovina examine the justification of building the harbour in Neum, where these and similar ships could dock.
Such visits are important, as for friendly relations of Bosnia-Herzegovina and Turkey, as well as for B-H’s cooperation with the NATO Alliance.
And in the current political moment, this visit is an important message.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The friendship between the Republic of Turkey and Bosnia-Herzegovina has a long-lasting value. Many things are in common to our countries, starting with the fact that we are part of the region of the Southeastern Europe, a joint history, culture and other contents, but also a joint future membership in EU and NATO.
The Republic of Turkey is an important member of NATO. Its support to Bosnia-Herzegovina on that way is very significant.
In the period of 1995-2005 in Turkey, 426 officers and soldiers from Bosnia-Herzegovina completed their military training. Besides that, 906 completed combat arm specialising courses, out of which 7 for airplane pilots and 10 for helicopter pilots. 1919 members of armed forces complete a collective training in Turkey. Currently, 7 members of B-H armed forces attends the Turkish military-medical academy, 5 members attend the lad forces school, etc.
It is important to emphasize that this training is being conducted according to the highest NATO standards.
A special gratitude we owe to Turkey for support and assistance to Bosnia-Herzegovina in the most difficult moments of our country. The Turkish units are constantly present in Bosnia-Herzegovina in a function of establishing and preserving the peace and stability as a part of UNPROFOR, SFOR, EUFOR forces.
Versatile relations between our countries are crowned with the recent visits at the highest level of Taip Erduan the Prime Minister of Turkey and President Ahmet Sezer. The today’s visit is also a confirmation of our friendly relations.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Bosnia-Herzegovina is determined to meet all requirements laid on front of here in order to become a member of the Partnership for Peace and the NATO Alliance as soon as possible.
We are conducting the defence system reform. That means having one army, depoliticised, multi-ethnic and professional. We are already capable of having our military forces in peace missions worldwide. We are no longer a receiver but also a provider of international military assistance.
Small countries can best ensure their security trough the NATO Alliance membership. Especially important is cooperation and support of NATO member countries, among which Turkey has an important place.
Therefore, I once again wish to welcome the crew of the war ship to the territorial waters of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Long live Bosnia-Herzegovina! Long live the republic of Turkey!
Long live the friendship of Bosnia-Herzegovina and Turkey!”

title: H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech at the Southeast Europe Heads of State Regional Summit under the aegis of UNESCO in Opatija
content:
I find that today’s meeting is a continuation of a dialogue process at the highest level of the countries of the Southeastern Europe in the domain of culture and cultural heritage, which initiated under the patronage of UNESCO in Ohrid in 2003
Communication of heritage – A new vision for South East Europe
Opatija, June 1-2, 2006
"Mr. President of the Republic of Croatia,
Gentlemen presidents,
Mr. General Secretary of UNESCO,
Mr. Secretary-General of the Council of Europe,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I share the congratulations and gratitude to our host and a friend, Stjepan MESIC the President of Croatia, for his warm hospitality and en excellent organization of this gathering.
I find that today’s meeting is a continuation of a dialogue process at the highest level of the countries of the Southeastern Europe in the domain of culture and cultural heritage, which initiated under the patronage of UNESCO in Ohrid in 2003.
A specific geographic position at the crossroads between the East and the West, the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, as well as a very rich and tumultuous history of our region, have made the Southeastern Europe a mosaic of religions, cultures, traditions and language.
The joint history and the ethnic structure of our countries refer to a comprehensive cooperation. In our region, peoples, religions and cultures meet, intertwine and more or less coexist in harmony. One people often live on the both or more sides of the border, on one side as a majority, and in other countries as a minority population. The same is with our monuments and symbols of culture, which are everywhere in the region. These relations, including the protection and reconstruction, must be built in accordance with the European standards. Representatives of a majority people, above all, are responsible for the protection and reconstruction of cultural-historic heritage of minorities. They have to preserve the cultural heritage of minority peoples. In that way, they are providing an example how other should treat their cultural heritage.
By rescuing the cultural heritage as a witness of our span, we are preserving self-awareness and investing in future. Everyone should be proud of the entire cultural heritage, regardless of the period, culture or people it derives from. That is our affluence and our advantage, by no means a drawback. On these foundations, we should build bridges of cooperation for a better joint future of the Southeastern Europe as a region of tolerance, reconciliation and an intercultural dialogue.
Bosnia-Herzegovina is a region in small, because there, different peoples, religions and cultures meet, intertwine and coexist for centuries, mostly in harmony. In Sarajevo, which is also called the European Jerusalem, Mostar, as well as the majority of other B-H towns, side by side, for centuries, stand mosques, catholic and orthodox churches, synagogues and other cultural-historic monuments and symbols.
In the wars that signified the 20th century in these areas, especially in the period of 1991-1995, there was a systematic destruction of cultural-historic monuments and other sites. Therefore, the protection and reconstruction of a cultural heritage is important for history as well as for future. It contributes to the preservation and strengthening the State identity and ensuring the fundamental human rights. Every protected and/or reconstructed object brings us a step closer to a return of trust and tolerance, which are parts of our several centuries’ long tradition.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I wish to express my pleasure with the fact that a decision was made at the last session of the Committee for Cultural Heritage in Durban in South Africa on enlisting the Old Bridge and the historic centre of Mostar in the UNESCO World Heritage List.
Its symbolic meaning is even more important because in the Declaration from our previous Summit held in Varna last year, the Old Bridge in Mostar was pronounced the symbol of coexistence and reconciliation in the region.
That was an important incentive to our country to intensify activities in restoration and protection of our cultural and natural wealth.
Bosnia-Herzegovina has recently been nominated for another cultural-historic monument to be enlisted in the World Heritage List – the Mehmed-Pasha Sokolovic Bridge in Visegrad. Besides that, we are also preparing the nominations for the complex of the Old City of Jajce and the Vjetrenica Caves.
We are also interested in nomination for enlisting the National Park of Sutjeska in the World Heritage List, as a joint cross-border project with the National Park of Durmitor in the neighbouring Montenegro. In that way, we will permanently preserve the natural wealth of our two countries – especially the canyons of rivers Drina and Tara in the best possible way.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I use this occasion to thank UNESCO and the General Director Matsuura personally for the shown concrete readiness to accept the initiative of the B-H Presidency that UNESCO should include three symbolic religious objects in our country – the Ferhadija Mosque in Banja Luka, the Serb Cathedral in Mostar and the Catholic Convent Plehan in Derventa in the reconstruction.
I would like to thank UNESCO for the previous support in completing the project ARS AEVI – the establishment of one of the most important European museums in Sarajevo. In that way, Sarajevo and Bosnia-Herzegovina, as well as the entire region, will become one of the leading destinations of modern art.
Ladies and Gentlement,
A month ago, intensive archaeological excavations started in the area of Visoko, 30 km from Sarajevo. According to the findings of the eminent group of archaeologists, there are remnants of several pyramids.
Previously performed testing, including the one performed by the Egyptian experts for pyramids, confirm the shown results.
If this thesis becomes definitely confirmed, that will be one of the biggest and most spectacular archaeological discoveries in the world that will significantly changed the history of Europe and turn our region into one of the most important destinations for scientific explorations and tourism.
Bosnia-Herzegovina will extremely appreciate if UNESCO decides to send several experts to Visoko. Additionally, I invite all the archaeologists of the countries in the region to take part in the excavations in the field.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
After the period of confinement caused by the division of our continent and the recent conflicts marked with wars, sufferings and destruction of cultural monuments, our region is entering a new period – a period of openness, good-neighbouring relations, cultural and all other forms of cooperation.
That new period should be marked with the reconstruction and affirmation of the rich cultural heritage of the Southeastern Europe.
Therefore, I strongly support the intensification of cultural cooperation between our countries and the establishment of network of cultural corridors and cultural pathways.
We support the initiative for intensification of activities in promoting the cultural-historic wealth of our region, and therefore, we believe that the new information technologies can be a very useful tool for that promotion.
By establishing the cultural corridors, the affirmation and the joint promotion of our cultural heritage, we can again make the Southeast European region a destination that will attract visitors from the entire world due its heritage and diversity, and in that way, we will open new development perspectives for our countries.
Thus, we will send a clear political message of willingness constructively to include our countries in all international processes and of determination to make the Southeast European region an example of establishing good relations and cooperation based on a constant dialogue and wealth of cultural diversity.
Thank you.”

title: H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech at the celebration of the liberation of the Suada Delibasic and Olga Sucic Bridge
content:
B-H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech
at the celebration of liberation of the Suada Dilberovic and Olga Sucic Bridge
Sarajevo, May 27, 2006
“Ladies and Gentlemen, Dear citizens of Sarajevo
Mr. Minister Mekachera, Admiral Lanxad, General Gobilliard,
Esteemed Ambassador of the Republic of France to B-H Mr. HENRY ZIPPER DE FABIANI,
Members of the Diplomatic Corps,
Exactly eleven years ago, May 27, 1995, two French soldiers AMARU and HUMBLOT, gave their lives right here, on the Suada and Olga Bridge in a mission of peace in then surrounded Sarajevo.
This is an opportunity to remind ourselves of that event:
Early in the morning, on May 27, the French lookout military positions, right beside the Vrbanja Bridge in Zagrebacka street, was suddenly occupied by the Serbian paramilitary formations dressed in the UN uniforms. The French Military Command considered this situation unacceptable and ordered a counterattack. That meant the liberation of the post, during which two French soldiers w ere killed and 17 were wounded.
Their action signalled the turning point in International Peace Forces’ approach to the war in Bosnai-Herzegovina. Until then, mostly the observers of the B-H citizens’ sufferings, they became active participants in preventing and stopping the war and establishing a permanent peace and stability in Bosnia-Herzgovina.
In this fashion, France ended an absurd logic of behaviour of the International Peace Forces that equalized the aggressor and the victim. Under its influence, disposing of the forces for quick intervention and lifting the siege over Sarajevo, the NATO engagement, the cessation of hostilities, and in the end, signing the peace agreement, all soon came about.
Therefore, in a certain way, this action has become a pioneer in new politics of the International Community in which France had had a significant role.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Bosnia-Herzegovina and its citizens cannot forget what France had done for our country.
Eighty-four French soldiers gave their lives for the establishment of peace in our country. They will forever remain in our memories.
Today, ten years after the establishment of peace, we can say that their sacrifice was not in vain.
The established peace has never been violated; Bosnia-Herzegovina is on a good way to join the Euro-Atlantic integration. We are conducting powerful reforms. We are integrating the society. We are reconstructing the multi-ethnic structure of our country. We are building a unity of diversity based on the multi-century long tradition of our peoples’ co-existence.
Only ten years ago, the world sent soldiers to peace-establishing missions in B-H. Today, our military and police forces are participating in the international peace missions worldwide. B-H is no longer just a receiver but also a provider of an international military assistance.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I want to express my extreme pleasure with the fact that the Ambassador of the French President, Mr. Hamlaoui Mekachera the Minister for Veterans’ and Admiral Jacques Lanxade the Commander of the French Army Headquarters during that action, as well as General Gobilliard the UNPROFOR Commander in the sector of Sarajevo of that time are here with us today. Their presence here is a proof of friendship between our countries.
Once again, I wish to emphasize the important role that French President Jacques Chirac had had in putting and end to the war and the establishment of peace.
The friendship between Bosnia-Herzegovina and France has a long, long tradition. Two hundred years ago, France appointed its first consul to our country.
France was also the first country to accredit an ambassador to an internationally recognised and independent Bosnia-Herzegovina - in June 1993. The citizens of Sarajevo will never forget the fact that the first French ambassador, Mr. Henry JACOLIN had shared with them their most difficult war days in our surrounded Capital.
Because of all that, we are convinced that France will continue strongly to support Bosnia-Herzegovina and now, when our country is in a decisive phase of a European path.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
This site has a special symbolic meaning for the City of Sarajevo. Here, in 1992, fell a first victim of war. On the same place, French soldiers AMARU and HUMBLOT were killed, which signified the beginning of war in our country.
This and other events remind us of our past, which we must accept, our present, which we have to use in the best possible way and to build a better future for all our peoples and citizens.
We want these and similar sufferings never to happen again in our country, as well as anywhere else in the world!
Long live Bosnia-Herzegovina! Long live the Republic of France!
Long live the friendship between Bosnia-Herzegovina and France!

title: H Presidency Chairman at the 13th Summit of Heads of Central European countries
content:
I would especially like to emphasize the significance of the further strengthening and enhancing the economic relations among our countries, and to welcome the initiative of our host to attach an economic dimension to this Summit, trough the participation of a number of eminent businessmen
Speech by Sulejman Tihic, the B-H Presidency Chairman
at the 13th Summit of Heads of Central European countries
Varna – Bulgaria, May 19, 2006
THE PRESENT AND THE FUTURE OF EUROPE
"Your Excellencies, Presidents and Prime Ministers,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I would also like to congratulate our host for the excellent organization of this Summit and the shown hospitality.
I would also like to express my pleasure with the cooperation intensification and the meetings at the highest level of representatives of the Central European countries.
I would especially like to emphasize the significance of the further strengthening and enhancing the economic relations among our countries, and to welcome the initiative of our host to attach an economic dimension to this Summit, trough the participation of a number of eminent businessmen.
Some of the countries will become members next year, some have started negotiating the full-fledged membership, some have gained or are awaiting the candidate status, and some have started negotiating to sign the EU Stabilisation and Association Agreement. We are all going in the same direction, faster or slower. We are becoming a part of the democratic community of equal peoples – European countries, united in the European Union and NATO.
In that sense, I would like to express my pleasure with the recently achieved agreement on enlargement of the Central European free trade zone with the countries of the Southeastern Europe, which is also an important step forward for the integration of the entire region in the European Union.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
This is also an opportunity to inform you about the achieved progress in Bosnia-Herzegovina:
Regardless of our difficult past, we are facing toward the future. The peace established ten years ago has never been violated. Around a million, i.e. 50% of the exiled and refugees have returned so far. In that way, we are restoring the multi-ethnic structure of our country and building the unity of diversity, such as was the one that had existed in Bosnia-Herzegovina for centuries. We are building a State where Bosniacs, Serbs, Croats and all other peoples and citizens will be equal. We are making compromises in that way, because Bosnia-Herzegovina can only survive if it is made to fit all our citizens and peoples. We are seeking to find what we have in common, what unites us and bonds us, not what separates us.
Claims that there was a religious war in Bosnia-Herzegovina, based on multi-century old intolerance and impossibility of co-existence of different religions and cultures are unfounded! We are talking about a conflict between the two ways of life and organizations of society. One, based on domination, totalitarianism, intolerance and negation of everything that is different, and the second, preaching equality of all people, tolerance, multi-ethnic and multi-confessional society, where differences mean wealth and advantage.
In that way, Bosnia-Herzegovina is a living proof of a complete senselessness of theories about the so-called unavoidability of conflict of civilisations.
We have started negotiations on signing the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the European Union. We are expecting to have this Agreement signed by the end of this year or the beginning of the next. We are conducting comprehensive reforms of defence system in order to be adjusted to the NATO standards. Instead of three multi-ethnic armies, we are establishing one professional, depoliticised and multi-ethnic army. Bosnia-Herzegovina is not only a receiver, but also a giver of military help. Our military and police units are participating in the International peace missions in Iraq, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Congo, Eritrea, etc. We are expecting B-H to be accepted in the Partnership for Peace, and by 2008, to be invited to join the NATO. Of course, this means an unconditional cooperation with the Hague Tribunal, including arresting the remaining six war criminals from the Hague list.
I hope that, together with others, we will soon fulfil this commitment. That is primarily in our interest, because only on foundations of truth and justice, we can build a better future.
We have started the process of constitutional reforms and achieved an agreement on modalities of the first phase of our Constitution’s changes. That will mean a more efficient and a more functional authority that would alleviate and accelerate not only the process of an internal integration, but also the membership in EU and NATO. The agreement received support from the largest number of citizens and a majority of Parliament members. Unfortunately, due to two votes, the amendments did not get the 2/3 majority and are not adopted yet. Regardless, I hope that in the following period these amendments will be adopted.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I would like to convey Bosnia-Herzegovina’s position on two issues our region is going to face with in the following period – the issue of referendum on independence of Montenegro and resolving the Kosovo status.
Bosnia-Herzegovina is satisfied with the fact that Serbia and Montenegro have found a compromise regarding the modalities of organizing the referendum in accordance with the EU demands, and we are convinced that the both sides would fully comply with the referendum results, regardless of what they might be.
The issue of Kosovo is much more delicate, so we believe that one should carefully approach to its solving. Bosnia-Herzegovina finds that the issue of Kosovo can only be reached trough negotiations, a compromise between Belgrade and Pristina, in accordance with the principles of the Contact Group.
We energetically reject making any kind of connection between Kosovo and the situation in Bosnia-Herzegovina, and we think that it would bring catastrophic consequences to peace and stability in the region.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The progress our regional countries have achieved in the previous period has largely been achieved thanks to the perspective of becoming a member of the European Union that has become even more concrete two years ago, when five more Central European countries became full-fledged members of EU.
I think that you will agree with me when I say that the concrete perspective of membership in the European Union was the main driving force of the entire series of very delicate reforms conducted in our countries in the previous period.
The Central European region is another confirmation that the European integrative processes are the best ways to establish a permanent peace, stability and prosperity in our countries and the continent.
We fully understand certain internal problems that some of the European Union countries are currently facing with, but we believe that stopping the process of EU enlargement would be a mistake, that might lead to a new division of our continent.
Therefore, we believe that it is extremely important that one of the main messages of the today’s 13th summit of the Central European countries would be stressing out the necessity of continuation of a historical process of EU enlargement. Such a message is even more significant because among the participants of the today’s Summit are the countries that full-fledged members and co-founders of EU, as well as the countries that are heading toward the European Union.
It would be highly significant if our Summit sends a message about the need to liberalize, i.e. put an end to the visa regime, which constitutes a natural step toward the European Union.
Such messages would also be the best answers to the topic of the today’s Summit– the present and the future of Europe.
I would also like to use this opportunity to thank our host – the Republic of Bulgaria and to congratulate its entry in the European Union.
Thank you!”

title: H Presidency on occasion of celebrating the 14th anniversary of RSA and the Day of the 3rd Infantry Regiment (of the Republic of Srpska)
content:
It is my great pleasure and honour to greet you all and to congratulate the Regiment’s Day to the members of the Infantry regiment of the Republic of Srpska, and the 14th anniversary of foundation to all the members of the Army of the Republic of Srpska
Speech by Borislav Paravac, the Member of the B-H Presidency
on occasion of celebrating the 14th anniversary of RSA and
Day of the 3rd Infantry Regiment (of the Republic of Srpska)
“Mr. President of the Republic of Srpska,
Gentlemen Presidents of the National Assembly an the RS Government
Your Excellencies,
Dear generals, officers and soldiers of the Armed Forces of B-H,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my great pleasure and honour to greet you all and to congratulate the Regiment’s Day to the members of the Infantry regiment of the Republic of Srpska, and the 14th anniversary of foundation to all the members of the Army of the Republic of Srpska.
The Day of the Infantry Regiment of the Republic of Srpska, fostering the identity and the military heritage of the RS Army, and at the same time the heritage of the Serbian people, and the 14th anniversary of founding the Army of the Republic of Srpska, is a chance to remind ourselves about the time when the Serbian people in these areas was faced with a danger of a complete lose of its national sovereignty and identity, but is also a chance to point out the place and the role of our army in the Dayton Bosnia-Herzegovina and the current reform processes.
As a respond to the threats and danger on May 12, 1992, the Assembly of the Serbian people in B-H, during its session in Banjaluka, brought a decision that the people are to create their army for the purpose of protecting and defending the territory where they lived for centuries.
The RS Army, born from the people, together with its institutions and elected representatives in the four-year long armed and political fight and great sacrifices has defended the Republic of Srpska as the most valuable heritage and a guarantee in protecting the national and all other democratic rights and interests of the Serbian people.
After signing the Dayton Peace Agreement, the RS Army gave its enormous contribution to the implementation of that Agreement, building trust and cooperation between parties, building a permanent and sustainable peace on the territory of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
In times of comprehensive reforms in Bosnia-Herzegovina, the RS Army, the RS Ministry of Defence and other institutions of the Republic of Srpska have actively participated in planning and conducting the reforms in the area of defence and the entire security sector, and all that for the purpose of bringing B-H closer to the European Union and other Euro-Atlantic integration.
The Army of the Republic of Srpska today has a completely different role and a position to be fully integrated into the Armed Forces of Bosnia-Herzegovina, to adopt and apply the highest democratic and military standards in executing the missions and tasks, which will enable B-H to join the program Partnership for Peace and the full-fledged NATO Alliance membership.
The RS Army and its members in the joint command and units at the level of Bosnia-Herzegovina, especially in units preparing for participating in the peace operations in the world, today, and in the future, will dignifiedly represent the Republic of Srpska and follow aims and goals of the foreign policy and defence of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
In all these reform processes and the defence system reorganization, the Republic of Srpska and the Serbian people have not diminished their political and military importance in the B-H Armed Forces, because trough legal solutions, trough the regimental organisation of Armed forces, we have secured the identity of the Serbian people and the military heritage of the Army of the Republic of Srpska.
The adopted strategic and normative-legal documents at the level of B-H are fully ensuring the foundations for B-H getting accepted in the Partnership for Peace program, and afterwards the NATO Alliance membership.
The defence institutions and commands at the level of B-H must primarily be enabled for the efficient command over the Armed Forces, which is a prerequisite for achieving the strategically set goals, and the B-H Presidency, as a civil command, will provide help and support in building a unique structure and organization of the B-H Armed Forces.
The set goals in building the completely professional armed forces bind the political leadership to ensure conditions for raising the entire standard and quality of life of soldiers and officers, their permanent training and qualification, and modernisation of military funds as a prerequisite for conducting the defined mission and tasks.
I am convinced that the achieved results in building the system of defence and armed forces, as well as our responsibilities in getting closer to an active participation in the Euro-Atlantic integration, are also our opportunity to become a part of the collective security system and an active participant in building peace in the world.
Thank you for your attention.”
Banja Luka, May 11, 2006

title: H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech at the University George Washington
content:
Allow me to express my pleasure with having this opportunity to address you today, at the prestigious University George Washington
Speech by Sulejman Tihic, the Chairman of the B-H Presidency
At the University George Washington
Washington, May 10, 2006
BOSNIA-HERZEGOVINA, TEN YEARS AFTER DAYTON – ON ITS WAY TO BRUSSELS
“Mr. Director, Ladies and Gentlemen,
Allow me to express my pleasure with having this opportunity to address you today, at the prestigious University George Washington.
Bearing in mind that the Day of Victory over Fascism was celebrated worldwide yesterday and the day before, I wish to congratulate you this great holiday. The United States of America had an enormous significance and a great role in the victory over fascism.
When we all believed that the fascism has been beaten forever, the evil happened again. Horrible crimes in their worst form were being repeated in Bosnia-Herzegovina in the period of 1992-1995, perhaps even worse then in the Second World War.
The Fascism was repeated! How do we call over 500 mass tombs and over 2500 joint tombs found so far other then fascism! If not fascism, then how to call hundreds of camps and over thousands of destructed religious objects? Wasn’t it fascism the ethnic territory cleansing and the persecution of over a million citizens from their homes and hundreds of thousands of demolished, burnt and ravaged houses?
This is a chance to thank USA once again, which had had a decisive role in putting an end to a war and sufferings in B-H.
I thank you for helping to restore and establish a democratic and civil society in my country. USA is the largest individual donor with over one billion USD.
Some of your best sons, Ambassador Robert FRASER, Colonel Joseph CRUESEL and Nielson DREW, gave their lives in the mission of establishing the peace in my country. We will remember them with gratitude.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It has been ten years since the end of the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina and signing the Dayton Agreement. Bosnia-Herzegovina has come a long way –from a completely destroyed and ravaged country by war, to a country that started the negotiations with the European Union for signing the Stabilisation and Association Agreement several months ago, i.e. a country that is certainly heading toward the EU and the NATO membership.
Bosnia-Herzegovina ten years ago, immediately after signing
the Dayton Agreement
Towns, settlements, economy, infrastructure, communication, all devastated, damaged or ruined. Bosnia-Herzegovina is split with war, entity or other lines of separation. On the field, three conflicted and well-armed armies, with around 500 thousand soldiers and 60 thousand members of the international military forces. Three large police forces, far from any professional and democratic standards.
State borders are porous. The freedom of movement limited. Crossing the entity lines considered as an act of bravery.
The legal system of Bosnia-Herzegovina is split and more connected with the neighbouring countries then internally. An intense presence and interference in the internal affairs from the neighbouring countries.
Over 2.2 million in exile and refugees (more then half of population). Their property destroyed, devastated or usurped. The return was inconceivable, and those who dared to return were putting their lives and health in danger. Some were even killed or wounded during such attempts.
The war criminals at large. The cooperation of a larger number of institutions (RS and the so-called Herceg-Bosna) with the Hague Tribunal almost inexistent. Over 27.000 missing persons.
The economic and social situation extremely difficult. Hundreds of thousands of pensioners, disabled veterans, families of shehits, killed and demobilised fighters without any kind of compensation. Those who were employed and receiving pay checks were rare, and the pension funds completely empty.
The State institutions virtually inexistent, and those that were established did not function. At the same time, entities and other para-institutions acting as a State in a State.
Bosnia-Herzegovina today, ten years after
Today, ten years after, Bosnia-Herzegovina is indisputable as a State and there are no any serious political forces anymore, in or outside of it that could bring its territorial integrity and sovereignty in question. Additional responsibilities and numerous institutions have been established at the State level.
A significant progress in the return of the exiled and refugees has been achieved. According to the UNHCR data, over a million (around 50%) of the exiled and refugees have returned so far. Taken property, although often destroyed and devastated, has almost fully been returned. Freedom of movement has been ensured, including safeguarding the returnees. The returnees are still facing many problems, starting at unemployment, the right to health care, education, pensions, etc.
The return re-establishes the multi-ethnic structure of the country, which also strengthens the State of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
The macroeconomic stability has been ensured, with inflation as in the European Union. We have the strongest currency in the region. Compared to the post-war period, GDP has been tripled. The foreign exchange reserves have been increased 15 times and they amounted to 2.2 billion EUR last year. We regularly pay off our foreign debt amounting to 2.1 billion EUR (around 20% of GDP). Our banking system has been consolidated. The industrial production and foreign investments are in a constant growth, and we have seen a constant growth in public revenues.
Bosnia-Herzegovina on its way to the Euro-Atlantic integration
The beginning of negotiations with the European Union in signing the Stabilisation and Association Agreement represents the most important political event in our country after signing the Dayton Agreement ten years ago and signifies a definite transition of Bosnia-Herzegovina from the Dayton phase to the Brussels phase.
That was preceded by a completion of a great number of extremely difficult and complex reforms. Here, I would like to mention some of those: the border and the fiscal system reform, the establishment and development of a State Border Service, the unified Intelligence-security agency, the introduction of VAT, the PBS reform, the judicial system reform, etc.
We are conducting the defence system reform. Instead of the three mono-ethnic conflicted armies, we now have one multi-ethnic army. The Entities no longer have any jurisdiction over that matter, and the State of Bosnia-Herzegovina has professional, unified and multi-ethnic armed forces, organized according to the NATO standards. The Armed Forces of Bosnia-Herzegovina today have 12 thousand soldiers.
Only ten years ago, the world sent soldiers to our country, to help us to build peace and stability. Today, Bosnia-Herzegovina, within its powers of course, is sending its own soldiers to international peace missions. Our soldiers and police officers are today in Iraq, Liberia, Sierra Leona and some other areas in crisis.
The reform and adjustment of our armed forces to the standards of the North-Atlantic Alliance is going very well. Bosnia-Herzegovina has a real chance to join the group of countries that will become the full-fledged members of NATO in 2008.
Joining the European Union and NATO is the main priority of our foreign policy. It is also, the best way to establish a permanent peace and stability not only in Bosnia-Herzegovina, but also in the entire region of the Southeastern Europe.
We hope that by the end of this year, we will have ended the negotiations and signed the Stabilisation and Association Agreement.
We are fully aware that meeting the requirements for entering the European Union is primarily in our country’s and our citizen’s interest, so that we could ensure a prosperous future for our children and the future generations.
Therefore, we support the EU’s insistence on meeting the set requirements strictly, as when it comes to Bosnia-Herzegovina, as well as to other candidate countries. This especially refers to a request for an unconditional cooperation with the Hague Tribunal, i.e. arresting the war criminals still at large.
Here, I primarily mean arresting Karadzic and Mladic who are, besides Slobodan Milosevic, the personification of crime and sufferings in these areas.
The extradition of Karadzic and MLadic to the Hague Tribunal would finally close a war chapter of our history. It would enable hundreds of thousands of their direct and indirect victims to finally find peace and commit themselves to a normal life. Their arrest would surely set loose a new bulk of positive energy, as in Bosnia-Herzegovina, as well as in the entire region.
How we treat the war crime and criminal is the most important issue not just in Bosnia-Herzegovina, but the entire region. It is not enough to arrest Karadzic, Mladic and other suspects indicted by the Hague Tribunal! It is necessary that the local administration of justices processes several hundreds (perhaps even thousands!) of other criminals. It is inadmissible that in today’s Europe, or anywhere else in the world, the war criminals are being considered national heroes, and the crime being justified with the so-called ethnic interest! There is no excuse for that!
Gradually though, the war crime awareness and the attitude toward criminals is changing. Besides the Hague Tribunal, the domestic courts are also processing the war crimes. The Court of Bosnia-Herzegovina has been established, whose task is to take over a certain number of cases from the Hague Tribunal and process the most responsible ones for war crimes.
Around 12.000 missing persons have been exhumed from over 400 mass tombs found so far.
The process of meeting the requirements on our way to the European Union could be going even faster. The problem lies also in the existing constitutional structure of the country. Bosnia-Herzegovina has a dysfunctional and expensive political system, a weak State and strong Entities.
We have started the process of constitutional reforms. We have achieved a political agreement of six largest political parties on modalities of the first phase of constitutional reforms. The Agreement was supported by the majority of citizens of Bosnia-Herzegovina and the convincing majority of our Parliament’s members. Unfortunately, we have not been able to achieve the two thirds of votes necessary for the change of the Constitution. Still, that has not disheartened us! The Constitutional reforms will be our obligation in the following period, because that is good for our country’s future.
The relations with neighbours and Bosnia-Herzegovina in the region
I would like to say something about the relations with our neighbours and the situation in the entire region of the Southeastern Europe.
Bosnia-Herzegovina has fully understood the message from Brussels saying that the regional cooperation is a key for institutionalisation of relations of our countries with the European Union. In that course, we are supporting the idea of establishing a free trade zone of the West Balkan countries.
Ten years after the end of the war, we have mostly normalised the relations with both of our neighbours – Croatia and Serbia and Montenegro. Unfortunately, all the necessary agreements (the borders, the property-legal affairs) have not been signed something.
We have full diplomatic relations with the both countries; we have signed a great number of bilateral agreements in various domains, including the agreements on free trade. Citizens of our three countries can travel to Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Serbia and Montenegro with nothing but an ID card.
As you can see, a lot has been done. Parallel with the further contractual regulation of relations, I believe that it is necessary to intensify efforts on improving the infrastructural connection between our three countries. This is particularly because during the last 80 years, a unified infrastructure was being built within one joint country.
On this occasion, I would also like mention two open issues in our region: the upcoming referendum in Montenegro and the issue of resolving the Kosovo status.
When it comes to the referendum in Montenegro, I am convinced that both parties will fully comply with the rules established by EU, and that there will not be any major problems, regardless of the result of the referendum.
The Kosovo issue is far more complex and that is why one should be more careful when it comes to solving it. Bosnia-Herzegovina finds that it should be solved through compromise and dialogue between Belgrade and Pristina.
However, we energetically reject any attempt of making any connection between the Kosovo status and Bosnia-Herzegovina. Any such attempt would directly jeopardize the peace and stability of the entire region and would impose the unforeseeable negative consequences.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Equality, tolerance and respect for differences are the foundations of the modern democratic world and values that European Union is based on, as well as the multi-century tradition of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Bosnia-Herzegovina is a place where four great monotheistic religions have met, bringing to our country and its citizens all the splendour of their cultures and traditions, as one of the rare autochthonous European multi-ethnic societies.
In virtually every B-H city, side by side, for hundreds of years, stand a Catholic and an Orthodox church, a mosque, somewhere even a synagogue. Our peoples have learned to live in peace and tolerance together, and wars in our country were consequences of the world and/or regional wars, larger or minor interventions from the neighbouring countries. Such was also the case in the period of 1992-1995.
This is why we are very proud of our differences and our multi-ethnicity, which we consider our greatest wealth and a comparative advantage. The uniqueness of differences, as a continuous process, is a part of living in Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Among else, and perhaps even because of it, Bosnia-Herzegovina is one of the rare countries, which has very good relations as with European Union and USA, as well as with China, the Russian Federation and the Islamic world.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Now, I would like to address you as a member of the B-H Presidency from the Bosniac people, i.e. as a Bosnian Muslim.
In today’s world, more and more often we could here those talking about the clash of civilisations and the impossibility of different religions’ co-existence. In that context, Muslims are the ones being mentioned most often, especially after the terrorist attacks on the United States of America of September 11, 2001, considering Islam to be a religion for terrorism.
Based on an example of Bosnia-Herzegovina and the Bosnian Muslims, such theories are being discarded because they are unfounded.
The Bosniacs, i.e. the Bosnian Muslims, are the autochthonous European people practising Islam at least for 600 years. After the withdrawal of the Great Turkish Empire from our territories 130 years ago, our people has several times been a victim of mass crimes, genocide and persecution, especially during the two world wars and the regional conflicts. The last one in a row of such demise of the Bosnian Muslims was in a period of 1992-1995, when over 10% of the Muslim population was murdered, i.e. around 70% of the killed in this war.
Even though we have suffered the most, we have never reached for retribution, especially not for terrorism as a method of fight. Terrorism is immoral and counterproductive. It is immoral because the innocent suffer, and it is counterproductive because it does not solve, but complicate the problems.
Like war criminals and criminals, terrorists do not have any religion or nation. They are always only terrorists and criminals.
We, thank God, have defended our country and people in the past war; we have preserved our religious and cultural tradition, and stayed an autochthonous Europeans.
Regardless of the sufferings, we have survived, also thanks to our neighbours the Serbs – Orthodox and the Croats – Catholics. We have adjusted our religion of Islam – and our culture, to the environment and conditions we are living in, and that is why we are recognized in the world as Bosnian or European Muslims. Together with other B-H peoples and citizens, we are building our joint homeland, where everyone will be equal and free, regardless of their religious, ethnic or any other membership.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Although we sometimes complained about the West not stopping the war and genocide in Bosnia-Herzegovina on time, still it was the West, lead by the United States of America that helped put an end and stopped further sufferings, especially of the Bosnian Muslims, which were in the most difficult position. If there had not been for your engagement, the military intervention in B-H, everything would have been worse.
The United States of America, together with others, have stopped the genocide from happening in other places in Bosnia-Herzegovina, such as was the one committed in Srebrenica.
I am not saying this only here, in the USA, but everywhere and on every occasion. That is the truth, we are appreciating it and we are grateful to you, and the world needs to know it! I have already repeated this statement two times at the Summits of the countries of the Islamic Conference Organization in Kuala Lumpur and Mecca, as well as during the official visits to Pakistan and Iran.
In Bosnia-Herzegovina, as in the United States, a vision of a modern, reintegrated, multi-ethnic State, based on equal opportunities and rights for all its citizens always wins. The citizens of Bosnia-Herzegovina are successfully taking the historical test of co-existence of various religions and cultures. We are on a good way to achieve it. Therefore, we still need your help and I hope you will provide it.
Thank you!”

title: H Presidency Member Ivo Miro Jovic’s speech at the International Conference “ESTABLISHING THE TRUTH IN THE POST
content:
For every citizen of this country, undoubtedly, the Dayton Peace Agreement has put an end to the war agony and opened real possibilities for restoring the life in this area.
“Dear Ladies and Gentlemen,
Dear friends,
For every citizen of this country, undoubtedly, the Dayton Peace Agreement has put an end to the war agony and opened real possibilities for restoring the life in this area. Two elements of this Agreement have had a special task: punishing everyone who committed a war crime and the refugees’ and displaced persons’ right to return.
The Dayton Peace Agreement blemishes became fully expressed due to the failure to implement its provisions. It happened within these two most important items. The problem of uncompleted return of refugees and displaced persons to their homes is dangerous to the establishment of a permanent peace and co-existence. For example, in Bosnia-Herzegovina today, there are over 45% of Croats missing – a modern history in the world does not recognize such a ratio of persecution or genocide! This problem deserves a proper attention, but we will talk about it at some other event. We are here today to talk about the problem of punishing, or unpunishing, the perpetrators of war crimes as a precondition of the normalization of situation in the West Balkan and its Europeanization. Identification, arresting and processing the war criminals is precisely the first precondition for the countries of this region on their way to Euro-Atlantic integration. However, it is the attitude toward the war criminals where we can notice a true attitude of some countries toward the European principles. The fact that two of the most wanted criminals, Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic are not in Den Haag yet– only confirms the insincerity of all the factors in this process. This attitude becomes even more evident when it comes to presenting the investigators with the relevant documents, which could be of a great importance to the Tribunal’s work.
In addition, while on one hand, we only have the ignorant attitude toward the Tribunal and the European Union existing without any significant sanctions, on the other hand, we have the cooperation and collaboration left without any appropriate results.
Regardless of the fact that since the establishment of the Tribunal there were certain signs that the Tribunal could primarily be a political court, I belong to those who believe that the Tribunal, trough its work, righteousness and adherence to principles, will give its best respond to its critics.
In spite of accepting all the difficulties that the Tribunal has stumbled upon, we are deeply disappointed with the unequal treatment in certain processes.
It is unacceptable that not even a single criminal has been charged at the Tribunal for the Croatian demise in the Central Bosnia. It is similar to other Croatian agonies such as in Grabovica, Uzdol, Bugojno, Kriazancevo selo etc.
It is incomprehensible that the authority of that time, as was Enver Hadzihasanovic, the Commander of the Third Corp, to this day has not been made responsible for the murder of a single civilian – Croat, even though there were four hundred and twelve (412) killed and over fifty (50) killed Serbs on the territory of the Third Corps’ military jurisdiction and he has been indicted for only one (1)? In addition, existence of 40 camps for Croats has been proven.
