I wonder if the numerous evidences, witnesses’ testimonies, as well as the FB-H Army documents are found irrelevant by the Hague Tribunal, when the numerous crimes have been left out of the verdict?! Considering that this Court has finished with investigations, and that the domestic administration of justice in the territory of the Central Bosnia has not convicted even a single member of the B-H Army for a crime over Croats, I am afraid that these crimes could easily remain unpunished! This is where the role of the institutions of authority is indispensable, but also the role of media who have to show a lot more investigative journalism sensitivity and the responsibility for the written, given to citizens with a hope for better future.
A frightening message has been sent to people expecting justice, because besides the question whether there is justice, there is also a question of is that an encouragement to the perpetrators saying that when a crime gets unpunished it can be repeated!? People are humiliated because their victims were taken too lightly. For killings, plunder, arson and home destruction, desecration of religious facilities and a great population persecution, NO ONE IS GUILTY and they are wondering, should not the Court exist for making a judgement honourably?
All this points to the fact that in the future, we must dedicate ourselves more to investigations and processing the perpetrators of war crimes, in order to meet the justice, to give the victims at least the moral satisfaction, and to create conditions for the establishment of trust between our peoples. That is our great responsibility, because war crime does not have a time limit, and because of the future generations that should live in a different milieu. In that regard, all of us, especially the investigators, have a great task of uncovering and affirming the truth. Only the truth, no matter how unreachable it might be for those seeking it, is the only firm foundation of our future co-existence.”

title: H Presidency Chairman’s speech at the Summit of Heads of State and Governments of the Southeast European countries
content:
“Presidents and Prime Ministers,
Ladies and Gentlemen!
I would also like to congratulate our host for an excellent organization of this Summit and for the given hospitality.
I would like to express my pleasure with intensification of cooperation in our region and the fact that all our countries are undoubtedly coming closer to the goal fulfilment – the EU and NATO membership.
Some countries are to become members next year, some have started negotiations on the full-fledged membership, some have gained or are awaiting the candidate status, and some have started negotiations on signing the EU Stabilisation and Association Agreement. We are all heading in the same direction, faster or slower.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
This is also an opportunity to inform you about the achieved progress in Bosnia-Herzegovina. We have started the negotiations with the European Union for signing the Stabilisation and Association Agreement. The negotiations are going well and we are expecting to sign this Agreement by the end of this year or the beginning of the next. We are conducting the comprehensive reform of the defence system for the reason of adjusting to the NATO standards. Instead of three mono-ethnic armies, we are establishing one professional, de-politicized and multi-ethnic army. Bosnia-Herzegovina is not only a receiver, but also a giver of military assistance. Our military and police units are participating in the international peace mission in Iraq, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Congo, Eritrea, etc. We are expecting that Bosnia-Herzegovina will be accepted in the Partnership for Peace by the end of the year, and will be invited to join the NATO in 2008.
Both these things mean reforming the police, public broadcasting system, certainly the unconditional cooperation with the Hague Tribunal, including arresting the most wanted war criminals. I hope that we, together with others, would soon fulfil this commitment. It is primarily in our interest, because only on the foundations of truth and justice, we can build a better future.
We started the process of constitutional reforms and achieved an agreement on modalities of the first phase of changing our Constitution. This will mean a more efficient and functional authority that would significantly alleviate and accelerate not only the internal integration process, but also the EU and NATO membership. The Agreement received support from the largest part of citizens and the most members of the Parliament. Unfortunately, due to two votes, the amendments have not received the 2/3 majority and have not been adopted yet. Regardless, I hope that in the following period, these changes will be adopted.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Our countries have separately, but also jointly, invested great efforts and achieved a significant progress in order to change the stereotype of our region as a backward, problematic and a conflicted European suburb.
Our geographic positions, joint history, ethnic structure of population, infrastructural and economic ties, all refer us to a comprehensive cooperation. Different peoples, religions and cultures meet, intertwine and co-exist here in our region. We need to do everything to make our mutual understanding and tolerance an example to others.
Our region has progressed in the further economic connecting. I would like to emphasize the significance of the Agreement on joining the EU energetic market, the Agreement on enlargement of the free trade zone of the Central Europe with countries of the Southeastern Europe, the establishment of a highly profiled railroad network, the cooperation in the domain of fight against the organized crime, human trafficking and illegal emigrations. Most of the countries in our region are on its way to bring the border control regime in accordance with the EU and Schengen systems. I believe that the time has come for European Union to consider the possibilities of liberalisation, i.e. putting an end to the visa regime with the countries of our region. This would represent a significant support to our countries in conducting reforms and a message to citizens to support it.
Seeking to have a better coordination of our joint activities, primarily towards EU and NATO, but also between our countries, i think that the time has come to institutionalize this cooperation in a form of a permanent Secretariat. This Secretariat could be having an important role in the upcoming reform of the Stability Pact for the Southeastern Europe.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Bosnia-Herzegovina expresses pleasure with the fact that Serbia and Montenegro have come to a compromise on modalities of holding a referendum in accordance with the EU demands. We are convinced that the both sides will fully acknowledge the referendum results, regardless of what they might be. The issue of Kosovo is much more delicate and we believe that one should carefully approach to its solving.
To Kosovo status needs to be resolved trough negotiations and compromises between Belgrade and Pristina, in accordance with the set principles of the Contact Group. We energetically reject any kind of association of the Kosovo status with the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Bosnia-Herzegovina!
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The EU membership perspective has been a driving force in conducting a series of highly delicate but crucial reforms in our countries. The region of the Southeastern Europe is a confirmation that the European integrative processes are the best way to establish a permanent peace and stability.
Therefore, I find that one of the main messages of today’s Summit should be underlining the need for continuation of a historical enlargement of EU with the West Balkan countries. That is primarily in the interest of the regional countries, but also in the interest of the European Union countries in the long-term. Furthermore, we should send a message about the need to liberalize or put an end to the visa regime as a natural follow-up on the region’s road to EU.
I use this opportunity to thank our host – the Republic of Greece on its successful chairmanship over EU, which has constantly supported the West Balkan countries in their coming closer to the European Union and NATO, and I wish the Republic of Croatia to have a successful chairmanship over the next period.
Thank you.”

title: H Presidency Member Borislav Paravac’s speech at the ceremony of opening the NATO headquarters in Sarajevo
content:
The basic goals and directions of the foreign policy of Bosnia-Herzegovina are represented by a full-fledged membership of the European Union, joining the NATO program Partnership for peace and a full-fledged membership of NATO alliance
"Excellencies,
Ministers,
Generals,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The basic goals and directions of the foreign policy of Bosnia-Herzegovina are represented by a full-fledged membership of the European Union, joining the NATO program Partnership for peace and a full-fledged membership of NATO alliance.
Previous experiences in joining the European Union show that joining the NATO program Partnership for Peace and the NATO membership is one of the pre-requisites for entering the European Union. We find that our road to NATO has no alternative and is our foreign policy’s priority at this moment, more so because such a decision is also shared by our neighbours Serbia and Montenegro and the Republic of Croatia, which increases the stability of the entire region of the West Balkan.
The defence reform and the reform of the entire security sector, which we have completed successfully and which were the conditions for entering the Euro-Atlantic integration, could not have been possible without the professional and material help from NATO at large, especially the NATO headquarters in Sarajevo.
It is my pleasure to state today that our efforts in the defence reform and the cooperation with NATO in that area have resulted in building a unique defence system and unified armed forces, and that we have basically fulfilled all the professional and technical conditions for joining the program Partnership for Peace.
I would also like to express my pleasure with the opportunity to place the NATO headquarters in Sarajevo in a quality premises and that defence structures at the state level, first of all the Ministry of Defence and the Armed Forces Joint Headquarters, are to continue their even more successful cooperation in implementing the reform solutions in the area of defence and fulfilling the requirements toward the full-fledged NATO alliance membership.
I use this opportunity to thank General Weber and all his predecessors who commanded the NATO headquarters in Sarajevo for their unselfish help, as well as to express hope that today we are opening a new page of cooperation with NATO on the foundations of a true friendship and partnership.
Thank you"
Sarajevo, May 3, 2006

title: H Presidency on occasion of signing the Basic Agreement between Bosnia
content:
Speech by Ivo Miro Jovic, the B-H Presidency Member
on occasion of signing the Basic Agreement
between Bosnia-Herzegovina and the Holy See
Sarajevo, April 19, 2006
“Eminent Cardinal,
Your Excellency, the Nuncio in Bosnia-Herzegovina,
Representatives of the religious communities,
Father bishops,
Father provincials,
Authority representatives,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my great pleasure to greet you today on occasion of signing the Basic Agreement between Bosnia-Herzegovina and the Holy See. This is a result of work and efforts of the representatives of the both signatory sides, with which they legally frame the relations between the State of Bosnia-Herzegovina and the Catholic Church. This confirms the future cooperation, which aims at the spiritual and material development of man, as well as promoting the common good.
This Agreement has a special importance to Bosnia-Herzegovina, because the right to religious freedom is being confirmed trough it, which is extremely important to this country that aspires to become recognisable by cherishing the religious tolerance, the respect for each other and respecting the differences. Bosnia-Herzegovina has undoubtedly chosen the European path, wishing to ensure its peoples and citizens to enjoy all the rights defined with the international democratic standards. By signing this Agreement, the State of Bosnia-Herzegovina acquires an additional international credibility in the international relations, as a European democratic community.
This way, the Holy See and Bosnia-Herzegovina will confirm, once again, the high degree of cooperation and a mutual friendship, and that is something we have Holy Father John Paul II to thank, who showed his deep affection to Bosnia-Herzegovina during the most difficult times of war.
I would like to emphasize the significance of this Agreement for the Catholic people in Bosnia-Herzegovina, who have lived for the Catholic religion for centuries, which was a part of their identity, and at the same time a part of the European civilisation, and this makes Bosnia-Herzegovina a part of Europe not only geographically.
I am convinced that such or similar agreements would soon be signed with other Churches and religious communities in Bosnia-Herzegovina as well, which will contribute to a better mutual understanding.
Your Excellency,
I especially send greetings to Holy Father Benedict XVI, with a sincere invitation to visit Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Finally, I would like to thank all those who gave their contribution to the creation of this document and preparations for signing it today

title: H Presidency, Sulejman Tihic’s speech in occasion of the celebration of the Day of Army of the Republic of Bosnia
content:
The Second infantry and ranger regiment has a task to cherish the highest values and goals, for which the RB-H Army has fought as a legal army of the Republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina. That is Bosnia-Herzegovina, a State of equal peoples and citizens – Croats, Serbs, Bosniacs and others
Speech of Sulejman Tihic, the Chairman of the B-H Presidency
in occasion of the celebration of the Day of Army
of the Republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina
Sarajevo, April 17, 2006
“Dear families of shehits and killed members of the RB-H Army,
Disabled veterans, demobilized fighters!
Gentlemen soldiers, non-commissioned officers and officers,
Gentlemen generals,
I congratulate you your 14th anniversary of forming the Army of the Republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina!
I congratulate you the Day of the 2nd Infantry-ranger regiment of the Armed forces of Bosnia-Herzegovina. With its forming and quality work, we will preserve the tradition of our Army, keep our honour and the multi-ethnicity and universality of goals it fought for.
The Second infantry and ranger regiment has a task to cherish the highest values and goals, for which the RB-H Army has fought as a legal army of the Republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina. That is Bosnia-Herzegovina, a State of equal peoples and citizens – Croats, Serbs, Bosniacs and others.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Thank you for answering our invitation and confirming, together with us, that the memories of the defenders of our homeland, Bosnia-Herzegovina, are still alive. This is an opportunity to promise, once again, to continue to defend the values for which our best sons gave their lives, and that we will provide care for the families of shehits, killed fighters and disabled veterans.
Today, 10 years after the Dayton Agreement, Bosnia-Herzegovina is undeniable as a State! No longer are any serious political forces inside or outside of Bosnia-Herzegovina that could endanger its territorial integrity and sovereignty. Your responsibility is to preserve it permanently.
We are conducting comprehensive reforms in all the important segments, starting with the fiscal, administrative, security and defence system.
We have reached an agreement on the first phase of the constitutional system reform. It means that we will have a stronger State, a more functional and efficient power. It is a result of agreement between the domestic political forces.
Bosnia-Herzegovina, the joint State of Bosniacs, Serbs, Croats and others, must be built by agreement. It can and should be organized in the way that representatives of all our peoples and citizens will agree on. There must not be any imposing or outvoting, but we must make compromise and built consensus in order to ensure a better future for our children.
The Armed forces of Bosnia-Herzegovina has been and will be a continuity of an idea of a free, independent and prosperous Bosnia-Herzegovina, which has enough room for all its peoples and citizens.
Even now, with its structure and training, and with its equipment tomorrow, the Armed Forces of Bosnia-Herzegovina represent a guarantor of peace and prosperity in our country and its quality membership in the security structure of Europe and the Euro-Atlantic space. The transitional process, in which the Armed Forces are today, is a process of its continued progress toward NATO and growth into the factor of stability and security of the region. Establishment of the efficient chain of command, a permanent acquiring of knowledge and skills, accepting the modern standards and operative procedures, will make our Armed Forces more mobile, efficient and economically affordable.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
This is also and opportunity to thank the NATO and the International Community for support and assistance in the establishment of the State defence institutions, as well as for willingness to help us in the process of implementation of reform laws and decisions. I also find the support trough the NATO Trust Fund in taking care of numerous members of the Armed Forces important, as well as educating the young officers and comprehensive strengthening of probably the youngest armed forces in Europe.
Thanks to the achieved progress, Bosnia-Herzegovina is no longer a receiver today, but is also capable to be a giver of international military assistance. The Armed Forces units are participating in the international missions worldwide.
Gentlemen soldiers, non-commissioned officers and officers,
Gentlemen generals,
You are expected to show maturity, seriousness, a military responsibility and loyalty to your homeland in execution of given tasks. Our goal is to be accepted in the Partnership for peace, i.e. the NATO and to attain the European Union membership. Only within the Euro-Atlantic democratic institutions, we can ensure the prosperity and security.
The State structures bear the responsibility to create conditions for the Armed forces’ functioning and the execution of the function that is defined by the Constitution and laws.
This way is the best way to show our gratitude and respect to all the fighters of our State of Bosnia-Herzegovina, especially to those who gave their lives and health in that name.

title: H Presidency Chairman, on occasion of the visit to the French Navy minesweeper “Verseau” in Neum
content:
A speech by Sulejman Tihic, the B-H Presidency Chairman, on occasion of the visit to the French Navy minesweeper “Verseau” in Neum
“Mr. Ambassador of the Republic of France to Bosnia-Herzegovina,
Mr. Commander of the battle ship “Verseau”
Ladies and Gentlemen,
First, I would like to welcome the crew of the French minesweeper “Verseau” to the B-H territorial waters.
I am glad that you have come to visit my country. That is a symbol of friendship between our countries and a confirmation of my country’s sovereignty, not only on land, but also in the territorial waters of the Adriatic Sea.
The visit of your battle ship and of US Navy and German ships has confirmed that Bosnia-Herzegovina is a part of the family of maritime countries. That certainly meant ensuring the free passage to our territorial waters.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The friendship between B-H and France has a permanent value. We cannot and must not forget what France has done for B-H.
Eighty-four French soldiers gave their lives for the establishment of peace in our country. They will remain in our memories forever.
If it is any consolation, today, ten years after the establishment of peace, we can say that their sacrifice had not been in vain.
The established peace has never been violated. B-H is on the right way to the Euro-Atlantic integration. We are conducting strong reforms. We are integrating the society. We are restoring the multi-ethnic structure of our country. We are building the unity of differences. B-H citizens are on the right way to pass an examination of a mutual life of different religions and cultures. That is a result of a joint life of our peoples, and it is several centuries long.
Today, our military and police forces are participating in the international peace missions all over the world. B-H is no longer a receiver, but also a giver of international military assistance.
We expect that by the end of the year the EU Stabilization and Association Agreement will be signed, as well as our country’s admission to the NATO program Partnership for peace.
We will all make additional efforts to meet the existing requirements, including arresting the war criminals at large, which the Hague Tribunal insists on. This will open a perspective of B-H becoming a full-fledged member of NATO in 2008.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Our satisfaction with your visit is even greater due to the fact that your visit has been realized in the scope of celebrating the 200 years of appointing the first French consul to B-H. 200 years ago, at the time of the Ottoman Empire, France appointed its consul, Mr. DAVID, with the headquarters in Travnik. That was also the first diplomatic mission in B-H.
Even then, France recognised the path our country has taken, which leads to the family of the European countries.
France was also the first country, which accredited an ambassador in the internationally recognised and independent B-H – in June of 1993. Citizens of Sarajevo, our Capital, will never forget that the first French ambassador, Mr. Henry Zakolen shared their hardest war days in the surrounded Sarajevo.
Finally, once again, welcome to B-H.
Long live the friendly Republic of France! Long live B-H!
Thank you!”

title: H Presidency Chairman, at the CLINGENDAEL Institute
content:
A speech at the CLINGENDAEL Institute
Den Haag, April 14, 2006
BOSNIA-HERZEGOVINA, TEN YEARS AFTER DAYTON-ON ITS WAY TO BRUSSELS
“Ladies and Gentlemen,
Please allow me to express my pleasure with having this opportunity to address you here at the prestigious CLINGENDAEL Institute in The Hague, which was attended by numerous diplomats, from Bosnia-Herzegovina as well.
For us in Bosnia-Herzegovina, The Hague has a special, symbolic meaning – as a headquarters of the International Criminal Tribunal for former Yugoslavia and the International Court of Justice.
The role of these two international judicial institutions is irreplaceable in establishing the truth and the character of the war in B-H, and persecution of citizens. Only on foundations of truth and justice, we can build trust between people, peoples and countries in the region, and a better future for new generations.
I would like to use this opportunity to thank the Government and the people of the Kingdom of Holland for their extremely significant help given to Bosnia-Herzegovina. With 324 million USD of bilateral aid and participation in European Union’s help to Bosnia-Herzegovina, Holland was certainly one of the most important donors during the reconstruction of our country.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It has been ten years since the war ended in Bosnia-Herzegovina and since the Dayton Agreement was signed. Bosnia-Herzegovina has gone a long way – from a completely destroyed and ravaged country, to a country that has started to negotiate with European Union on signing the Stabilization and Association Agreement several months ago, i.e. a country that confidently walks toward the EU and the NATO membership.
Bosnia-Herzegovina ten years ago, immediately after signing the Dayton Agreement
Towns, settlements, economy, infrastructure, communications were devastated, damaged or destroyed. Bosnia-Herzegovina was divided with war, entity or other lines of separation. On the field, there were three conflicted and well-armed armies, with around 500 thousand soldiers and 60 thousand members of the international military forces. There were three police forces, which were far from professional and democratic standards.
The State borders were porous. The freedom of movement limited. Crossing the entity lines was considered an act of bravery.
The legal system of Bosnia-Herzegovina was divided and more connected with neighbouring countries then internally. There was an intensive presence of neighbouring countries and their interference in the internal affairs.
War criminals at large. Cooperation of a number of institutions with the Hague Tribunal was almost inexistent and there were over 27.000 missing persons.
An economic and social situation was very difficult. Hundreds of thousands of pensioners, disabled veterans, soldiers’ families, killed or demobilised fighters without any indemnity. The employed people receiving salaries were rare, and pension funds were completely empty.
The State institutions were almost inexistent and those that were established did not function. At the same time, there were entities and other parainstitutions working as a country inside a country.
Bosnia-Herzegovina today, ten years after
Today, ten years after, Bosnia-Herzegovina is indisputable as a State and there are no serious political forces in it or outside that could endanger its territorial integrity and sovereignty. Additional authorities and numerous institutions at the State level have been established.
A significant progress in returns of refugees and displaced persons has been achieved. According to the UNHCR data, over a million (around 50%) refugees and displaced persons have returned so far. Property that was taken away, almost fully has been restored, though often destroyed and devastated. The freedom of movement is granted, including the security for returnees. The returnees still have many problems, starting with unemployment, rights to health care, education, pensions, etc.
Return means re-establishing the multi-ethnic structure of the country, which also strengthens the State of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
The macroeconomic stability has been ensured, with inflation as in the European Union. We have the strongest currency in the region. Compared to the post-war period, GDP has been tripled. Foreign exchange reserves have been increased 15 times and they amounted to 2.2 billion EUR last year. We pay off our foreign debt regularly which amounts to 2.1 billion EUR (around 20% of GDP). Our banking system has been consolidated. Industrial production and foreign investments are in a constant growth, and we have also seen a continuous growth in public revenues in percentages exceeding 10%.
Bosnia-Herzegovina in the European path
The beginning of negotiations with the European Union for signing the Stabilization and Association Agreement represents the most important political event in our country after signing the Dayton Agreement ten years ago and symbolises Bosnia-Herzegovina’s transition from the Dayton to the Brussels phase.
The realization of a number of extremely difficult and complex reforms preceded to it. I would like to mention some of them: customs and fiscal system reform, establishment and development of the State Border Service, the united Intelligence Agency, introduction of VAT, the PBS reform, judicial system reform, etc.
We are also conducting the defence system reform. Instead of three mono-ethnic confronted armies, we now have one multi-ethnic army. Entities no longer have any jurisdiction in that matter, and the State of Bosnia-Herzegovina has professional, united and multi-ethnic armed forces, organized according to the NATO standards. The Armed forces of Bosnia-Herzegovina have 12.000 soldiers today, and it had 500.000 soldiers in 1995.
Only ten years ago, the world sent soldiers to our country, to help us build peace and stability. Today, Bosnia-Herzegovina, within its possibilities of course, is sending its soldiers to international peace missions. Today, our soldiers and police officers are in Iraq, Liberia, Sierra Leone and a few more conflicted regions.
Reforming and adjusting our armed forces to the standards of the North-Atlantic Alliance is going very well. Bosnia-Herzegovina has a real chance to join the group of countries that will become full-fledged members of NATO in 2008.
Joining the European Union and NATO is our country’s main priority. This is, at the same time, the best way to establish a permanent peace and stability, not only in Bosnia-Herzegovina, but also in the entire region of Southeastern Europe.
We hope that by the end of this year we will have ended the negotiations and signed the Stabilization and Association Agreement.
We are fully aware that meeting the requirements for entering the European Union is primarily in the interest of our country and citizens, so that we could ensure a prosperous future for our children and future generations.
This is why we support EU’s insistence on a strict fulfilment of given requirements by Bosnia-Herzegovina and by other candidate countries as well. This especially refers to the request for an unconditional cooperation with the Hague Tribunal, i.e. arresting the war criminals.
I primarily mean arresting Karadzic and Mladic, who are, besides Slobodan Milosevic, the personification of crime and death in our region.
The extradition of Karadzic and Mladic to the Hague Tribunal would finally close the war chapter of our history. This would allow hundreds of thousands of their direct and indirect victims to finally find their peace and commit themselves to a normal life. Their arrest would certainly set loose a new quantity of a positive energy in Bosnia-Herzegovina, as well as in the entire region.
How we treat war crimes and criminals is the most important issue not just in Bosnia-Herzegovina, but also in the entire region. It is not enough to arrest Karadzic, Mladic and others accused by the Hague Tribunal! It is necessary that local administration of justice processes several hundreds (perhaps even thousands!) of other criminals. It is inadmissible in today’s Europe, or anywhere else in the world, to have war criminals considered to be national heroes and to justify the crime with the so-called ethnic interests!
The war crime awareness and position toward criminals, is being gradually changed though. Apart from the Hague Tribunal, domestic courts are also processing the war crimes. The Court of Bosnia-Herzegovina has been founded, whose task is to take over a certain quantity of cases from the Hague Tribunal and to process those who are the most responsible for war crimes.
Around 12.000 missing persons have been exhumed from over 400 mass tombs found so far.
The process of meeting the requirements in order to join European Union and NATO could be going even faster. The problem is also in the current constitutional structure of the country. Bosnia-Herzegovina has a non-functional and expensive political system, a weak State and strong Entities.
After a couple of month of intensive discussions, the most important political parties in our country have recently reached an agreement on modalities of the first phase of constitutional changes. Agreed changes mean a strong State and institutions that are more functional. This will allow Bosnia-Herzegovina to fulfil all commitments in its European path without being disturbed.
I expect that by the end of the month, the Parliament will adopt these amendments. The greatest value of this agreement is that it was a result of the domestic politicians’ agreement, without any pressure from the international community that we have got used to. We have agreed that this will be the first phase, and after the election, there will be a second phase of constitutional reforms.
Relations with neighbours and Bosnia-Herzegovina in the region
Bosnia-Herzegovina has fully understood the message from Brussels that the regional cooperation is a key for institutionalisation of relations of the countries in our region with the European Union. In that course, we support the idea of establishing the free trade zone of Western Balkan countries.
Ten years after the end of the war, we have mostly normalized the relations with both of our neighbours – Croatia and Serbia and Montenegro. Unfortunately, we still haven’t signed and verified all the necessary bilateral agreements.
We have full diplomatic relations with the both countries; we have signed a great number of bilateral agreements in various domains, including the agreements on free trade. The citizens of our three countries can travel to Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Serbia and Montenegro with nothing but an ID card.
As you can see, a lot has been done. Parallel with the further contractual regulation of relations, I believe that it is necessary to intensify the efforts on improving the infrastructural connection between our three countries. This is particularly because during the last 80 years, a unique infrastructure was being built within one joint country.
In regard to the referendum in Montenegro, I am convinced that both parties will fully comply with the rules established by EU, and that there will not be any major problems, regardless of the result of the referendum.
The Kosovo issue is far more complex and that is why one should be more careful when it comes to solving it. Bosnia-Herzegovina finds that it should be solved through compromise and dialogue between Belgrade and Pristina.
However, we energetically reject any attempt of making any connection between the Kosovo status and Bosnia-Herzegovina and its territorial integrity and sovereignty. Any such attempt would directly jeopardize the peace and stability of the whole region and would have unforeseeable negative consequences.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Equality, tolerance and respect for differences are the foundations of a modern democratic world and values that European Union is based on, but also the multi-century tradition of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Bosnia-Herzegovina is a place where four great monotheistic religions have met, bringing our country and its citizens all the splendour of their cultures and traditions, as one of the rare autochthonous European multi-ethnic societies.
In virtually every B-H city, side by side, for hundreds of years, stand a Catholic and an Orthodox church, a mosque, somewhere even a synagogue. Our peoples have learned to live in peace and tolerance together, and wars in our country were consequences of the world and/or regional wars, larger or minor interventions from the neighbouring countries. Such was also the case in the period of 1992-1995.
This is why we are very proud of our differences and our multi-ethnicity, which we consider our greatest wealth and a comparative advantage. The uniqueness of differences, as a continuous process, is a part of living in Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Among else, and because of it, Bosnia-Herzegovina is one of the rare countries, which has very good relations as with European Union and USA, as well as with China, the Russian Federation and the Islamic world.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
In Bosnia-Herzegovina, regardless of our difficulties, the vision of a modern, united Europe, based on equal possibilities and rights for all its citizens, always wins. This is the only future for B-H and for the entire our continent.
Only such Europe would definitely be an oasis of peace, stability and prosperity, where all its citizens, regardless of their ethnic, religious or cultural membership, would feel at home and be proud of the European unity of differences.
Positive processes in B-H and the region I have been telling you about are, among else, a result of Bosnia-Herzegovina’s and the regional countries’ choosing such an idea of Europe.
The European Union should not waste the given chance to realize such a vision of our continent. On account of that, regardless of the difficulties and the current complex internal situation in some of the member countries, a historic process of enlarging the European Union must be continued.
We must not forget that it was the establishment of a permanent peace and stability in at that time destroyed and divided Europe, that were the main guiding ideas of the founder of what European Union is today. The previous history of European integration showed that those visionaries were right.
Today, half a century later, EU and its members have the opportunity to ensure a permanent peace, stability and prosperity in the entire our continent by continuing to enlarge the Union.
I am convinced that the Kingdom of Holland, as one of the EU founder countries, will support this historic project, providing it with a significant contribution.
Thanks.”

title: H Presidency and Ahmet Necdet Sezer, the President of Turkey
content:
Toasts
made by Sulejman Tihic, the B-H Presidency Chairman
and Ahmet Necdet Sezer, the President of Turkey
on occasion of dinner, organized by
Chairman Tihic and Members of the Presidency Paravac and Jovic
in honour of the President of Turkey
“Mr. President and dear friends!
Allow me to greet you once again, in the name of the B-H Delegation, and to welcome you to our country.
Meetings between the Turkish and B-H businessmen were a very good introduction to this visit. I expect it to be a very significant stimulus to the entire economic cooperation, which doesn’t fail to keep up with the friendly relations of our countries.
Your visit, Mr. President, confirmed the continued cooperation and visit exchange at the highest level. I am convinced that this will lead to a further development and strengthening our friendly relations and establishment of concrete cooperation in all areas.
Bosnia-Herzegovina and our citizens appreciate and will always remember the unselfish help, which the Republic of Turkey and your people have given to us in the bygone times. Turkey also played a very important role in the process that ended the war in our country.
Your soldiers participated in peace missions, during the war and after. Turkey significantly helped the reconstruction of our country. Besides that, the friendly Turkey has been continuously providing the important diplomatic support to Bosnia-Herzegovina and our lobbying to be accepted at International organisations, primarily the NATO.
The Republic of Turkey is also a country with whom Bosnia-Herzegovina has signed the most of bilateral agreements. Our countries also have a very good cooperation in the area of defence.
Mr. President,
Bosnia-Herzegovina and Turkey bear many similarities and have a lot in common –history, cultural heritage, architecture, cuisine, even the significant percentage of words originating from the Turkish and other Oriental languages, which have grown together with our language and become a part of it.
I am convinced that Bosnia-Herzegovina and Turkey have a joint future within the European Union, NATO and other Euro-Atlantic structures.
It is certain that much needs to be done on the path of our two countries to Brussels. However, this journey will be easier if we establish an even stronger and complete cooperation.
Allow me to wish our countries and peoples a prosperous future and a permanent, unbreakable friendship, and you, Mr. President, I wish a good health and success in leading the Republic of Turkey.
Long live Bosnia-Herzegovina! Long live the Republic of Turkey!"
“Dear Chairman and Member of the Presidency,
Esteemed guests,
I am happy to be in Bosnia-Herzegovina. I thank you for the warm hospitality that has been given to us from the moment we have arrived in Sarajevo.
Bosnia-Herzegovina is a country with whom Turkey has strong historic, cultural and human connections and with whom it cherishes excellent relations in all areas. In the heart of the Turkish people, Bosnia-Herzegovina has always had a special place. A great number of our citizens originating from Bosnia-Herzegovina make our connections even stronger.
Turkey has always concretely supported sovereignty, territorial integrity and multi-ethnic structure of Bosnia-Herzegovina. With this kind of approach, Turkey has given its contribution to the process of security and stability that started after signing the Dayton Peace Agreement, as well as in comprehensive efforts to reconstruct the country. Our unit called “Altea”, stationed within EUFOR in Zenica, continues with its self-sacrificing work in order to establish a permanent peace in Bosnia-Herzegovina.
For a long period, Bosnia-Herzegovina was being remembered by war and terrible sufferings. I am happy that during this visit I was able to see that things have started to change, that Bosnia-Herzegovina has become a dynamic country, which can achieve the new and comprehensive changes, tries to achieve social prosperity, aiming at integration with the Euro-Atlantic institutions. We approvingly monitor and support these progresses.
The fact that Bosnia-Herzegovina left behind the “Dayton period”, which symbolised the efforts toward reconstruction and stability, and has entered the “Brussels period”, which symbolises the Euro-Atlantic orientation, connects our countries in common goal. I believe that the goal we share will stimulate us to develop relations with our neighbours, to build the future on the foundations of tolerance, agreement and mutual understanding.
Today, one of our fundamental values we pay so much attention to, is co-existence of different cultures, confessions and ethnicities. Strengthening the multi-ethnic and multi-cultural structure of Bosnia-Herzegovina, based on wishes of its constituent peoples to live in peace together, represents a significant contribution not only to stability of the country and the region, but to peace in Europe as well. Turkey will be the proudest of Bosnia-Herzegovina, a country developing in peace and stability, within the European family.
Dear Chairman and Presidency Members,
During today’s discussions, we have comprehensively examined our bilateral relations, which are at a very high level. We have evaluated steps to be taken in order to raise the level of our trade exchange, which amounted to two hundred million dollars last year, to reach a level that could reflect the real possibilities of our countries. In Turkey, day after day, grows businessmen’s interest to invest in Bosnia-Herzegovina. More and more often our businessmen meet, which confirms our wish to develop economic relations between Turkey and Bosnia-Herzegovina. We believe that our deep friendship will transform economic relations into a true partnership and will serve a joint interest.
Dear Chairman and Presidency Members,
During today’s discussions, we were convinced that mutual understanding and trust, which govern our relations, are enabling a sincere approach to all topics. The duty of us officials is to use this favourable environment in the best possible way and to develop our relations in all areas to the greatest possible extent.
With these kinds of thoughts, I raise this glass to your health and happiness, in honour of the mutual prosperity of peoples of Turkey and Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Serefe!

title: H Presidency Member at the 14th anniversary of founding the HVO
content:
Speech of Ivo Miro Jovic, the Croatian Member of the B-H Presidency,
at the 14th anniversary of founding the HVO,
in Mostar, April 7, 2006
“Mr. Commander,
The Patriot War disabled veterans,
The Gentlemen Generals,
The Gentlemen Guard members, non-commissioned officers and officers,
The Gentlemen representatives of the civilian and church authority, representatives of International organizations, EUFOR and media,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I greet you all at this gathering of recollection, love and pride, and I congratulate all members of HVO their 14th anniversary.
This is an opportunity to use the celebration of the 14th anniversary of HVO to be reminded about everything we started from, what we have gone trough during the last 14 years, to talk about the current situation and to recognise our nearer and farther political future.
The glorious path that HVO units went trough in preserving lives, homes and the homeland, obliges us and demands from us not to forget those who made further fight possible for us, only by other means, in order to have a prettier and a more just B-H where Croats will be equal to other two peoples.
This kind of thinking gives us possibility to realistically recognise our political reality the Croatian people in B-H is going through, as well as are all previous institutions which are becoming the B-H institutions trough the reform transition, creating the legal supposition for B-H to join the Euro-Atlantic integration, at the same time preserving the identity of all three constituent peoples in B-H.
With these viewpoints, we have been building the defence system of HRHB, FB-H during the last 14 years, and today as well as in the future, we will be doing the same at the state level.
In all previous political processes, the defence structure of the Croatian component has had its organisational and structural changes, and it is why today we are in a position to have around 2.200-2.300 professional members of the B-H Armed Forces out of 10.000 professional members back in 1998.
These re-organisational processes have not diminished the political and military significance in the B-H Armed Forces because we have legally ensured the identity of the constituent peoples and the military heritage of HVO through the establishment of infantry regiment and recognisable symbols.
Besides the political significance of these reform processes, their social aspects are equally unavoidable, and the Croatian political leadership in B-H has attached a great importance to them, so I use this opportunity to ask the competent ones in the B-H Ministry of Defence to make additional efforts to take care of numerous members of the Armed Forces in a more quality manner, while the B-H Presidency will give them their full support.
After all these changes, we have a very important task in front of us, which is to build the defence system at the B-H State level.
During the system establishment, we will build a new work and relation quality within the Armed Forces, where the fundamental values in evaluating this quality will be the complete previous contribution, expertise and qualification for performing the duties and the showed degree of responsibility in performing the given tasks.
The strategic documents at the State level were made so far, which allowed B-H to create the legal basis for entry in the Partnership for Peace, and the NATO Alliance membership afterwards.
The defence institutions at the State level must primarily work on establishing the efficient command system in the Armed Forces, which is a key pre-requisite for achieving the strategically designated goals.
The B-H Presidency, as a Chief Commander, will give support to all these processes. For implementation of all these legal solutions, we also must have the most quality personal solutions in order to become an active factor in building these institutions. A very serious commitment that B-H has is participation of the B-H Armed Forces members in world peace missions.
This task is a task for the entire State leadership in B-H, and we must take this commitment responsibly and fully execute all given commitments.
For this purpose, all those that need to work in the Armed Forces must take up some general and military advancing in order to give their complete contribution to peace missions.
Our set goals in building the entirely professional armed forces bind the leadership of this country to ensure conditions for raising the entire living quality standard for soldiers, personnel education of non-commissioned officers and officers, equipment modernization, as fundamental pre-conditions for performing the defined mission of the Armed Forces to which they owe their existence.
I personally believe that upcoming commitments are also our chance, which we could use only by means of active participation in giving our contribution to complete international security. This way, B-H will ensure its active presence in the family of group security. Feeling proud of all members of all HVO units, I wish us to continue to celebrate our anniversaries that bear witness to a Croatian soldier in B-H.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Please allow me,
Once again, to express sincere congratulations and gratitude to all HVO members, who were in our joint formation during the difficult war and post-war times, and due to objective reasons, they could not be with us today.
To all killed HVO members, the Patriot war disabled veterans and their families, I wish to say one sincere and humane “thanks” for the sacrifice they made in fight for survival and freedom of Croats in B-H, because they completely fulfilled their task.
May we have a happy 14th anniversary of HVO.
I wish you a healthy life, may dear God bless you all.
T H A N K Y O U”

title: H Presidency at the opening of the Trade Fair “Mostar 2006”
content:
This year, the Republic of Hungary will present itself as a partner country of the B-H economy, and its experience as a young member of European Union can be of use to us in that area
Speech of Ivo Miro Jovic, the Member of the Presidency of Bosnia-Herzegovina
At the opening of the Trade Fair “Mostar 2006”
In Mostar, April 4, 2006
"Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is my pleasure to greet you today at the opening of the International Trade Fair “Mostar 2006”. This event has grown to a significant economic manifestation, not only within the limits of Bosnia-Herzegovina, but within the entire region as well.
This year also, through participation of over five hundred presenters from group of around 30 countries worldwide, this fair confirms the need for its organization and further enhancement, and economic and political institutions of Bosnia-Herzegovina must give its support to it.
This year, the Republic of Hungary will present itself as a partner country of the B-H economy, and its experience as a young member of European Union can be of use to us in that area.
We in Bosnia-Herzegovina find it clear that the economic growth is essential for ensuring the overall stability in the country. Achieving this goal demands us to define the economic perspective and to provide additional efforts to accelerate our European path. We in Bosnia-Herzegovina must believe that we can work, produce, export and open more job positions to a greater extent and with better quality than we are doing today.
For these effects, we must express our country’s willingness to step forward sufficiently good and fast in its transformation, accepting all transitional challenges. Therefore, economic and institutional reforms have no alternative. All of us called to do it by means of our position, must create pre-conditions for forming the unique economic space, which is also a task given to us by the European Commission. Unless we do it, we will miss our given chance for complete prosperity of our citizens.
The progress made by Bosnia-Herzegovina so far shows that we still have not achieved the necessary level of economic growth, however we can say that by acting, we could be an active participant of all economic processes in the region and wider.
We must see our chance in resources that Bosnia-Herzegovina unquestionably possesses. Along with natural resources and vast energetic potential, our greatest chance is our creative, innovative and hard-working people. Investing in knowledge and new technologies is a pre-condition for reaching the European Union standards that we aspire to. Knowledge is an important stimulus in development of the overall economy.
However, we still have to solve some basic development problems. The trade deficit of Bosnia-Herzegovina burdens its economy, so I am glad that this fair presents more and more production possibilities aimed at export. The Vine and Viticulture Equipment Fair is becoming a significant event for a successful promotion of traditional Herzegovina’s products and turning Herzegovina into a recognisable “brand”-BRAND in that area.
In today’s conditions, we need a combination of political breakthrough and aiming at development of good economic relations within development of favourable bilateral relations, which we will organize through a more active acting of the B-H economic diplomacy whose acting we need to turn into economic gains.
In the end of my greeting presentation, I want to thank, once again, the organizers for their invested efforts and express congratulations for organizing this significant event, and to all of you who recognised your economic interest I wish you much business success. With a great pleasure, I pronounce this International Trade Fair “Mostar 2006” open.
Thank you!”

title: H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech at the Congress of the European People’s Party
content:
B-H Presidency Chairman Sulejman Tihic’s speech at the Congress of the European People’s Party
Rome, March 30-31, 2006
“Mr. President of the European People’s Party,
Presidents and Prime Ministers,
Members of the European Parliament,
It is my pleasure to have an opportunity to address you today at the Congress of the European People’s Party, as a President of the B-H Presidency and the SDA President, which is the biggest party in Bosnia-Herzegovina.
I use this opportunity to say a few words about my country – Bosnia-Herzegovina, and SDA, for being its president.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Bosnia-Herzegovina is a place where we can see the most direct meeting and an intense permeation of the East and the West, different cultures and four world monotheistic religions. For hundreds of years, mostly in peace and tolerance, in our country live Bosniacs-Muslims, Serbs-the Orthodox, and Croats-Catholics, Jews and numerous other national and religious minorities. Only this kind of Bosnia-Herzegovina has perspective. In virtually all B-H cities stand mosques, catholic and orthodox churches, occasional synagogue, side by side for centuries.
A significant progress has been achieved in all domains. We are conducting comprehensive reforms in all areas. We have achieved a political agreement on reviewing the B-H Constitution. This means that our country will have a more functional and efficient structure, but also that it has finally stepped out of the Dayton into the Brussels phase. By the end of the year, we expect to sign the EU Stabilisation and Association Agreement, as well as to be accepted in the Partnership for peace.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Now, if you permit me, I would like to say something about the Democratic Action Party. As the strongest political party, SDA has given its considerable contribution to the achieved progress and it is a leading force in conducting reforms. Along with this, SDA continues with the process of internal transformation. Today, it is no longer exclusively a monotheistic party. In its leadership and membership, besides Bosniacs, there are now members of all B-H peoples. Such as is our today’s delegation, which includes Desnica Radivojevic, the B-H Federation Vice-president and the GO SDA Vice-president, and Dr Josip Jurisic, the President of the SDA Commission for International Cooperation and the Mayor of Sarajevo.
SDA has been defined and is becoming a people’s party of political centre, which accepts European values and standards, membership in EU and NATO, along with preservation of traditional values and the Bosnian identity. We stand for civil society and rule of law, and we cherish values of anti-fascism.
We find it crucial to establish the truth about deaths and the character of war in our country, 1992-2995. The role of the Hague Tribunal is very important in that matter, because based only on truth and justice, we can build trust between people, peoples and countries in the region and a better future for new generations.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
We need to continue with the historic process of enlarging the European Union. Such Europe will definitely become the oasis of peace, stability and prosperity, where all its citizens, regardless of ethnic, racial, religious and cultural membership, will feel at home and be proud of European unity of differences.
In Bosnia-Herzegovina, regardless of the difficulties we are going through, what is always winning is a vision of a modern, united Europe based on equal possibilities and rights for all its citizens. This is the only future, not just for B-H, but for our entire continent, and my party – SDA and I will continue to work on achieving it.
Thank you.”

title: H Presidency Member, Mr. Ivo Miro Jovic at the conference “Role of the Pan
content:
I thank you for invitation and having pleasure to greet you at today’s conference whose main subject is the role of the Pan-European Union in integration of Bosnia-Herzegovina into European Union
The speech of the B-H Presidency Member, Mr. Ivo Miro Jovic at the conference
“Role of the Pan-European Union in integration of Bosnia-Herzegovina into the European Union”,
Sarajevo, March 24, 2006
“Dear President and
The Presidency,
Your Excellencies,
Dear Ladies and Gentlemen,
Dear Guests,
I thank you for invitation and having pleasure to greet you at today’s conference whose main subject is the role of the Pan-European Union in integration of Bosnia-Herzegovina into European Union. I am extremely glad that the honorary president of the International Pan-European Union, a great European and a friend of Bosnia-Herzegovina, H.E. Otto von Habsburg is here with us today.
Upon his initiative, far back in 1979, an empty chair was placed in the plenary hall of the European Parliament as a European belonging symbol of the Central and Eastern European peoples, who were at the time under the communist regime. This gesture expressed his belief that that part of Europe, and Bosnia-Herzegovina within, would become a full-fledged member of the European Union some day. Your Excellency, we wish to thank you today for that belief and devotion.
After undergoing the catastrophic world wars, the European continent has faced the challenge of uniting Europe. The founder of the Pan-European Union, count Coudenhov-Kalergi (KUDENOV-KALERGI), far back in 1922 in one of his articles called “Pan-Europe – one proposal”, called for a political and economic unity of European countries and this envisaged events that marked the second half of the twentieth century – the creation of European Union.
Bosnia-Herzegovina has always belonged to the European political, cultural and economic space. However, the process of European integration is a process that seeks fundamental changes in society and demands comprehensive adjustment of the political, institutional frame and legal system in order to achieve European standards in all areas, which is our current priority.
The Pan-European Union, in its program exactly points to the fundamental principles demanding Europe as a community of peace, rights and liberty, based on the Christian image of man, without detriment to anybody and in benefit to all.
Europe as a community of peace must enhance friendship of all its peoples and fight against the disuniting of European peoples and deterring national and social conflicts. Only supporting the differences of the European peoples, cultures and traditions as an expression of a rich European heritage, we will be able to build the European patriotism, which supplements the national patriotism.
The legal state principle ensures a universal value of human rights and is a condition for a gradual construction of Europe, because only this provides the European guarantee as a community of values. Unfortunately, exile, refugees and ethnic cleansing in the past war bore massive negative consequences to our country, Bosnia-Herzegovina.
This is why with our choosing Europe, as a community of equal rights to all, we can prevent destiny, which peoples in Bosnia-Herzegovina have recently experienced. Besides this, legal state must naturally include the protection of human life from abortion, euthanasia and DNA-manipulation.
Europe, as a community of freedom, must resist every violence and totalitarianism such as were ideologies of communism and nationalism. Free and self-reliable development of man and strengthening family, support the awareness of protection and helping the weak and ill, as well as the responsibility to future generations. Respecting every difference, especially in language and culture, is one of the basic principles Europe is based on. Equality of peoples and citizens is what my country also stands for.
We strive for Europe of free men and peoples, which respects the dignity of every man and shows respect to God and its creation; Europe that supports the ideals of freedom and human rights all around the world; Europe that could be a role model to the entire world as a leading spiritual power.
This is the Europe we want,
This is the Europe that Bosnia-Herzegovina wants to belong to.
Thank you!”

title: H Presidency Sulejman Tihic at the European College in Bruges, Bruges, Belgium, March 8, 2006
content:
BOSNIA-HERZEGOVINA, TEN YEARS AFTER DAYTON, ON ITS PATH TO BRUSSELS
Mr. President of the European College,
Mr. Mayor,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Please allow me to express my pleasure with having this opportunity to address you today, here at the European College, the most prestigious European academic institution of the European studies.
I consider my today’s speech also as lobbying for Bosnia-Herzegovina to enter the European Union, since some of you will soon certainly be among those who will be deciding on our entry in next couple of years, when the time comes.
It has been ten years after the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina had ended and the Dayton Agreement was signed. During those ten years, Bosnia-Herzegovina has come a long way – from a completely destroyed country, ravaged by war, to a country that started the negotiations with the European Union on the Association and Stabilization Agreement couple of months ago, i.e. a country that is determinately going toward the European Union and NATO membership.
How difficult and complex this road was can best be seen by shortly looking back at my country and its society ten years ago, and compare it to how they look today.
Bosnia-Herzegovina, ten years ago, immediately after signing the Dayton Agreement
Cities, settlements, economy, infrastructure, communication, all devastated, damaged or destroyed. Bosnia-Herzegovina was divided by war, entity or other lines of separation. In the field, three conflicted and well-armed armies, with around 500 thousand soldiers and 70 thousand members of the international military forces. Three police departments, which were far from professional and democratic standards.
The State borders were porous. The freedom of movement restricted. Crossing the entity lines regarded as an act of bravery.
The legal system of Bosnia-Herzegovina divided and more connected with neighbouring countries then internally. An intensive presence and interference in the internal affairs by neighbouring countries.
Over 2.2 million (more then half of population) in exile and refugees. Their property destroyed, devastated and usurped. The return was unthinkable, and those who dared to come back were exposing their lives and health to danger. Many were killed or wounded in those attempts.
War criminals at large. The cooperation of a larger number of institutions (RS and so-called Herzeg-Bosnia) with the Hague Tribunal almost nonexistent.
Economic and social situation extremely difficult. Hundreds of thousands of pensioners, disabled veterans, families of shehits and demobilized fighters without proper compensations. Employees with paid salaries were rare.
State institutions almost nonexistent and those that were established did not function. At the same time, entities and other para-institutions were operating as a state in a state. Presence and interference of neighbouring countries in internal affairs of Bosnia-Herzegovina were at all levels and segments of a society and authority.
Bosnia-Herzegovina today, ten years after
Today, ten years after, Bosnia-Herzegovina is unquestionable as a state and there are no serious political forces, inside or outside, that could endanger its territorial integrity and sovereignty. Additional authorities and numerous institutions at the state level have been established.
A significant progress in returns of those in exile and refugees has been achieved. According to UNHCR data, over million (around 50%) of the exiled and refugees have returned. Almost all property has been restored, though often destroyed and devastated. Freedom of movement has been ensured, including securing the returnees. The returnees still have many problems, starting with unemployment, rights to health care, education, pensions, etc.
Besides that, returning means re-establishing the multi-ethnic structure of country, which, at the same time, strengthens the State of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
In the economic field, macro-economic stability has been ensured, with inflation like the one in the European Union. We have the strongest currency in the region. In regard to the post-war period, GDP has been tripled. Foreign exchange reserves have increased 15 times and last year they amounted to 3.3 billion EUR. We regularly paying off our foreign debt that amounts to 2.1 billion EUR. Our banking system has been consolidated. The industrial production is in constant growth. Foreign investments are increasing. We recorded a constant growth in public revenues. VAT has been successfully introduced. According to achieved results, exempting the period of 1992-1995 when the IC, unfortunately, had not reacted adequately, we can state that the post-war period in Bosnia-Herzegovina was a successful project of the International Community – the United Nations, NATO, European Union, etc.
Bosnia-Herzegovina on the path to Europe
Bosnia-Herzegovina has started negotiations with the European Union on signing the Stabilization and Association Agreement several months ago. The beginning of those negotiations represents the most significant political event in our country since signing the Dayton Agreement ten years ago, and it represents a definite transition of Bosnia-Herzegovina from the Dayton to the Brussels phase.
The beginning of the negotiations was preceded by the realization of a number of extremely difficult and complex reforms. Allow me to mention some of them: customs and fiscal system reform, establishment and development of the State Border Service, introduction of VAT, Public Broadcasting System reform, judicial system reform, etc.
We have also conducted a defence system reform. Immediately after signing the Dayton, ten years ago, there were 500.000 armed men in Bosnia-Herzegovina, who belonged to the three mutually conflicted armies. Defence was in the exclusive jurisdiction of an entity, who had its defence ministers and separate armies, mostly of mono-ethnic composition.
Today, after the conducted reform, the issue of defence is explicitly in the jurisdiction of the State! Entities no longer have any jurisdiction in that regard, and the State of Bosnia-Herzegovina has professional, united and multi-ethnic armed forces, organized according to the NATO standards. The Armed forces of Bosnia-Herzegovina today have 12 thousand soldiers.
Only ten years ago, the world was sending soldiers to our country, to help us in construction of peace and stability. Today, Bosnia-Herzegovina, naturally within its possibilities, is sending its own troops to the International peace missions. Our soldiers and police officers are today in Iraq, Liberia, Sierra Leone and a few more critical areas.
Association with the European Union and the NATO is the main priority of our foreign policy. At the same time, this is also the best way to establish peace and stability permanently, not only in Bosnia-Herzegovina, but also in the entire region of the Southeastern Europe.
This is why we are going to do everything possible so that Bosnia-Herzegovina would fulfil the necessary requirements on its path to Europe as soon as possible.
We hope that by the end of this year we will have completed the negotiations and signed the Stabilization and Association Agreement (by the end of the Finnish or at the beginning of the German Chairmanship of the European Union).
We are fully aware of the fact that meeting requirements for entering the European Union is primarily in our country’s and our citizens’ interest, in order to ensure prosperous future for our children and future generations.
It is why we support the EU’s insistence on meeting the set requirements strictly, when it comes to Bosnia-Herzegovina and the other candidate countries as well. This especially refers to the request for unconditional cooperation with the Hague Tribunal, i.e. arresting the war criminals still at large.
I’m primarily referring to Karadzic and Mladic, who are, along with Slobodan Milosevic, the personification of crime and death in our region.
The extradition of Karadzic and Mladic to the Hague Tribunal would finally close the war page of our history. It would enable hundreds of thousands of their direct or indirect victims to finally find peace and commit themselves to normal life. Besides this, this will prove that justice may be slow, but attainable as well. Their arrest would surely set loose the new amount of positive energy, as in Bosnia-Herzegovina and in the entire region as well.
How we regard the war crime and war criminals is the most important issue not just in Bosnia-Herzegovina, but in the entire region as well. It is not enough to arrest Karadzic, Mladic and others indicted by the Hague Tribunal! It is necessary that the local administration of justice processes several hundreds (perhaps even thousands!) of other criminals. However, an awareness of war crimes and a manner of how we treat criminals has gradually started to change. It is inadmissible in today’s Europe, and anywhere in the world for that matter, that war criminals are considered national heroes, and crime is being justified with the so-called ethnic interests! There is no excuse for that!
The recent example of arresting Ante Gotovina in Croatia concretely shows that such approach of the European Union and its strict insistence on meeting requirements is the only correct way that shows results.
In regard to association of Bosnia-Herzegovina with NATO, the adjustment of our armed forces with the standards of the North-Atlantic Alliance is going very well, and we think that B-H has a real chance of joining the group of countries, which will become the full-fledged members in 2008.
The process of meeting the requirements, however, could be going even faster. The problem is in the country’s existing constitutional structure. Today, Bosnia-Herzegovina has a non-functional and expensive political system, a weak State and strong Entities. During the last couple of months, we have been conducting negotiations on changing the constitutional structure. We have come to an agreement about the first phase giving the stronger mandate and the more efficient authority to the State.
Relations with neighbours and Bosnia-Herzegovina in the region
I would also like to say something about our relations with our neighbours and a situation in the region of the Southeastern Europe.
Bosnia-Herzegovina has entirely understood the message from Brussels that the regional cooperation is the key for institutionalisation of relations between countries of our region with the European Union.
Ten years after the end of the war, we have mostly normalised relations with both of our neighbours – Croatia and Serbia and Montenegro. Unfortunately, we still haven’t signed and verified all the necessary bilateral agreements (borders, property and legal relations).
We have full diplomatic relations with the both countries; we have signed a great deal of bilateral agreements in various domains, including agreements on free commerce. Citizens of our three countries can travel to Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Serbia and Montenegro having just identity cards.
As you can see, a lot has been done. However, I think that there is still a lot more to be done. Parallel with the further agreement regulation of relations, I find that it is necessary to intensify efforts to enhance the infrastructural connection of our three countries. This is especially because a unique infrastructure was being built within one joint country over the last 80 years.
That is why I will propose organizing a three-lateral meeting of our countries, where Heads of State of Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia and Serbia and Montenegro could emphasize the need for initiating the regional infrastructural projects in order to have a better connection between our countries and citizens. I believe that we should even try to set some concrete goals. One of them could be, for example, the reconstruction and modernisation of road and railroad connection of our three Capitals, which could shorten the distance between Sarajevo, Zagreb and Belgrade to less than a four-hour drive.
Our country is actively participating in all regional initiatives, which we find very important, as for returning trust and establishing permanent stability in our region, as well as for concretely preparing our country to enter the European Union.
Besides political cooperation and regular exchange of opinions with other member countries, the regional initiatives have been helping us to intensify our economic relations and to have better relations between our businessmen.
In that sense, I would like to emphasize that Bosnia-Herzegovina supports the recent initiative of the European Commission on establishing the free commerce zone in the area of the western Balkan.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Equality, tolerance and respecting differences are the foundations of the modern democratic world and the values the European Union is based on, but also they are multi-century tradition of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Bosnia-Herzegovina is a place where four great monotheistic religions have met, bringing to our country and its citizens all the splendour of their cultures and traditions, as one of the rare autochthonous European multi-ethnic societies.
In virtually every B-H city, a Catholic and an Orthodox church, a mosque and somewhere a synagogue, stood side by side for hundreds of years. Our peoples have learned to live together in peace and tolerance, and wars in our country were consequences of the world and (or) regional wars, bigger or minor interventions from neighbouring countries. Such was the case in the period of 1992-1995.
This is why we are very proud of our differences and our multi-ethnicity, which we consider our greatest wealth and comparative advantage.
Among else, it is due to our multi-ethnicity that Bosnia-Herzegovina is one of the rare countries that have good relations with the European Union and USA, as well as with China, the Russian Federation and the Islamic world.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I believe that you will agree that my short review of the path that Bosnia-Herzegovina has taken in last ten years, speaks volumes about the great importance of the current moment for my country.
Ten years after the war, Bosnia-Herzegovina has possibility to close one of the hardest chapters in its history definitely, and from an object to become an active subject of the International affairs, which will be apt to contribute constructively to permanent stability and prosperity establishment in the Southeastern Europe.
We, in Bosnia-Herzegovina, are trying everything possible to achieve it. However, we also need your help in order to cross the remaining part of the road to the European Union and NATO as quickly as possible.
Let us not forget that it was the permanent peace and stability establishment in previously completely destroyed and divided Europe, which was the main guiding idea of the fathers of what is the European Union now – Conrad ADENAUER, Jean MONET, Paul SPACK and Robert SCHUMAN.
I am convinced that Bosnia-Herzegovina’s entry in the European Union and NATO will once again show that those visionaries were right.
Thank you.

title: H Presidency Sulejman Tihic on Occasion of The Independence Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina (1st of March), Sarajevo, February 28th
content:
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I wish you welcome and thank you for coming tonight to celebrate with us The Bosnia and Herzegovina Independence Day.
Fourteen years ago, on the referendum that took place on February 29 and March the 1 1992, the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina declared themselves FOR the sovereign and independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, a state of equal peoples and citizens – Bosniacs, Serbs, Croats and all others living in this country.
This decision is a product of the historic and the other circumstances dealing with the dissolution of the former SFRY. Until that very point, Slovenia and Croatia have already declared their independences. Bosnia and Herzegovina then did the same, based on the recommendations of the International Arbitrary Commission for SFRY, which actually confirmed the rights of the SFRY’s former republics citizens to declare their independence.
Soon after that, there came the open aggression against our country, as a result of the greater states ambitions and deals to divide Bosnia and Herzegovina. Along with the aggression, there came our sufferings – about 150 thousand people were killed and the hundreds of thousands were wounded, tents of thousands of women were raped and the hundreds of thousands of BH citizens passed throughout incredible tortures and humiliations in the concentration camps. About 2 million of our citizens were expelled from their homes and displaced throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina and the whole world, the hundreds of thousands of houses were destroyed, as well as the infrastructure, and economy of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Throughout of the whole of its’ history, Bosnia and Herzegovina was never divided and it has never changed its’ name. Bosnia was never a part of the neighboring states, and its’ borders were defined even in the 17th century and have not been changed until today. There is no doubt that Bosnia and Herzegovina is a legacy created during its’ centuries long history but not the product of any kind of deal between the internal or external factors.
Continuity of the BH statehood has been never cut totally and its’ origins go back to the 10th century – The Medieval century and the Kulin ban of Bosnia, Stjepan Tomašević, the last Bosnian king until nowadays. Bosnia has, mostly within the same borders, always been a political and territorial whole, keeping a high-level autonomy same in the Ottoman and Austrian-Hungarian Empire, as well as in the Kingdom and Socialist Yugoslavia later on.
The documents and decisions of the Anti-Nazi Council of the national Liberation of Bosnia and Herzegovina have confirmed the historic and political continuity of Bosnia and Herzegovina, stressing that it is not a Serbian, Croatian or a Muslim, but equally a Serbian, a Croatian and a Muslim one. On that basis, we have declared the independence of Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. During the 1992-1995 aggression, the BH patriots resisted these attempts for achieving the greater state nationalistic projects and defended the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
