It is truth that Bosnia and Herzegovina is still not the one our citizens wanted it to be and declared for in 1992. It is still not the country many of our best country fellows gave their life for.
However, Bosnia and Herzegovina is on the right way. It is today not under question as state and there are no serious political force in or out of BH which could dispute its’ territorial integrity and sovereignty. We are moving forward. Our country became the full member of the Council of Europe and I do believe that we will sign the SAA with the EU and become the PfP member. We also expect top be invited to join the NATO in 2008.
We are implementing the overall reforms in administration, taxies, education, security and defense. Besides, we expect to reach the political agreement about the changes of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina. And this will be the result of the domestic political forces.
Although we are not quite happy yet, the economic trends are increasing. I know that it is not enough and we need to achieve more. This year is giving lot of chances and opportunities. It is also important to reestablish the confidence. And for confidence amongst the peoples it is necessary to find the truth and to please the justice. Only on the basis of truth and justice we can built a prosperous future and better relations between the peoples and states.
In spite of all problems, I am convinced that the forces of hatred and division are defeated so our peoples and citizens are more and more accepting Bosnia and Herzegovina as their only homeland.
With such the wish, I congratulate the Independence Day to the BH citizens home and abroad.
Thank you.

title: Address by the Chair of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Ivo Miro Jovic at the ceremony of the 60th anniversary of the Food and Agriculture Organization (UN FAO) in Rome
content:
Mr. Director General,
Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen, distinguished guests,
It is my privilege to attend the Ceremony on the occasion of the 60th Anniversary of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Allow me, on behalf of citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and my own, to extend sincere congratulations and best wishes for the prosperous future of the Organization. At the outset, I would also like to congratulate to H.E. Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, President of the Federative Republic of Brazil, on the FAO Agricola Medal award.
One month ago, I had another great privilege: to attend the High Level Plenary Meeting of the 60th General Assembly of the United Nations in New York. I was honored and humbled to be amongst 180 world leaders who adopted the Final Document that will set the course of the World for the next decade. Needless to say, major part of the Document was dedicated to the Millennium Development Goals and to the strategy for their accomplishment. Having determined that the Organization of the United Nations had approached the fork on its path, the pivotal moment in its existence, we decided to take the turn that will hopefully lead us to the future with less hunger, less poverty, less fear and grievances, more freedom, more stability and economic prosperity and more justice for all.
Just to remind you: in the Final Document we emphasized the responsibility of each and every country for its own development. Good governance, transparency, sound policies, mobilizing internal resources, attracting international flows, promoting international trade and tightening financial discipline is what each Government owes not only to its own people, but to the international community as well. For governments that cannot feed their own populations or create conditions for production of sufficient food supplies could only become a source of instability and lead their countries into all sorts of conflicts.
Fight against hunger and poverty can not be overemphasized. Rural and agricultural development play important role in that fight and Final Document stressed that role. In it, we reaffirmed that food security and rural and agricultural development must be urgently addressed in the context of national development and response strategies. We expressed our conviction that eradication of poverty, hunger and malnutrition, particularly as they affect children, is crucial for the achievement of the MDGs. Rural and agricultural development, says Paragraph 46. of the Final Document, should be an integral part of national and international development policies. We deemed it necessary to increase productive investment in rural and agricultural development to achieve food security. And we committed ourselves to increasing support for agricultural development and trade capacity building in the agricultural sector in development countries. It is decided that support for commodity development projects, especially market based projects should be encouraged.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is a relatively small country, the IC still deem us “post conflict society” and our economy is still heavily dependent on agriculture. Problems that we encounter in that area are many-fold. Systemic: until recently we did not even have one economic space in the country and we still do not have the Ministry for Agriculture on the state level; Economic: due to the opening of our market to the Free Market Economy, which was a precondition for our membership in the Euro-Atlantic integrations that we strive for, we are flooded with agricultural products from the countries with heavily subsidized agricultural production. Hence, we suffer a heavy deficit in our trade, since the agricultural products make two thirds of our overall trade. It will get worse before it gets any better, tells us the experience of other European countries in transition. And our farmers are still getting killed and mutilated by landmines left behind from the recent war we were involved in. One would bitterly say: we reap what we sow.
On a brighter side: Bosnia and Herzegovina is a proud member of FAO, we timely pay our contributions and we benefited from the membership a great deal. To mention but a few, we participated in the Project for prevention of corn pests in Central and Eastern Europe, total value of 2,260.000 US$, “Inventory of agricultural resources in Bosnia and Herzegovina”, financed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Italy, implemented by FAO, fish farms in Bosanska Krupa, assisted by Government of Norway in cooperation with FAO, regional program “Quality of Food in South East Europe”, total value of 386.000 US$ etc. Our food and agricultural experts benefited enormously from the training courses and programs organized by FAO over the past decade. We are also looking forward to reopening of the FAO office in Bosnia and Herzegovina that was closed in 2000. We remain committed to further strengthen our cooperation with FAO in all its fields and aspects.
Allow me to conclude by reiterating the importance we attach to the FAO, our gratitude for the assistance we received in the past and our best wishes for the future of the organization that has become, in the past 60 years, irreplaceable in its role of a fighter against hunger and poverty, the two major menaces of today’s World.
Thank you Mr. Director General

title: Address by the Chair of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina H. E. Mr. Ivo Miro Jovic Summit of Heads of Central European States Zagreb 13 - 15 October 2005
content:
Dear Presidents,
Excellencies, distinguished friends,
It is a great pleasure for me, as a chair of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, to greet you here and to, first of all, express my gratitude to our host for the effort made in organizing this meeting. The moment in which this meeting takes place has a historic meaning for Republic of Croatia. I would like to use this opportunity to congratulate President Mesić, Prime Minister Sanader and to the Government of the Republic of Croatia, as well as to all its citizens, on this outstanding accomplishment. Opening of negotiations for the EU membership is a big step and it will represent a motivating factor for the countries still making efforts to achieve such a status. This time, EU reconfirmed its indubitable openness and has shown how committed it is to enlarge the EU family, thus offering us a great encouragement.
Countries participating at this gathering are facing different challenges.
These differences derive from their very status within the EU. Fortunately, some of the countries participating in this event are the full EU members. Bosnia and Herzegovina expects that their support, we enjoyed so far, will continue. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, we have put special efforts in implementing reforms in all of the segments of our society – a precondition for the opening of negotiations on the Stabilization and Association Agreement. Unfortunately, reforms in our country are not always synhronized with the principles and standards that are applied in Europe, but the reform solutions, with the aim of democratization, offer to us non-democratic, unjust and unfair solution, and always at cost of one people the one smallest in number, Croats. Signing of this agreement will be a key moment for all of us in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The advantages that this agreement brings will be impetus for the further economic development with increase of foreign investments. We expect the political dialogue to continue and we expect to gradually start the process of harmonization of our own with the EU legislation, as well as the improvement of the economic cooperation and the gradual development of the free trade zone.
While giving the general evaluation of the success of the ongoing reforms, I would like to mention the difficulties and problems we are facing during that process. At present, I would like to point out the success that Bosnia and Herzegovina achieved by adopting the laws unifying the defence system and indications of a completed negotiations on police reforms. That gives hope and I excpect a policy that will stop controling crisis and solve it.
In December this year, we will mark the 10th anniversary of the unjust Dayton/Paris Agreement. It will be an opportunity for all of us in Bosnia and Herzegovina to review what has been done so far, where we are standing right now, and what is yet to be achieved. The experience gained in these ten years shows, without a doubt, that there is a need to find ways and modalities on how to change Dayton/Paris Agreement.
The solution offered in DPA has defined a nonfunctional state structure. Europe will not welcome such a structure, one state, two enteties and three peoples. With the given Constitution, that has not been translated yet in any of the languages of our peoples, Croats, Serbs and Bosniaks (perhaps it is easier to manipulate with it, like this), and with the Sovereign, called the High Representative, we are not respected country in EU, even though others are trying to present it differently. That is a huge challenge that the political leaders and peoples in Bosnia and Herzegovina are facing. By developing the state institutions, harmonizing them, first of all, with the European standards and by overtaking the responsibility for development and future we will ensure the preconditions for the full respect of human rights in all of the society’s segments.
Respect for diversity and especially, for differences in languages and culture is one of the principles that the Europe rests on. We are committed to equal rights for all the peoples and citizens in our country, and that is something that we are often being denied of. Understanding of the democratic values and the value of cultural diversity are the foundations for the promotion of tolerance and cooperation in Europe. The Croatian people, as the smallest in number in B-H, are deprived of the rights that are even guaranted to minorities in EU, such as the education curriculum and the right to have Televison and radio program in Croatian language.
Co-operation among the countries participating at this meeting in all the aspects is of exceptional importance, and has to be intensified even further. It has to be especially efficient in battling the global terrorism – a key task that the entire world community is faced with.
We are aware of how important is the accession to the European Union. Taking into consideration clearly defined conditions set out for the future members, we are aware of how complex and delicate political project this is, as the fullfilment of respect of EU principles and standards are primarily necessary.

title: H Presidency Ivo Miro Jovic at the 33rd General Conference of UNESCO
content:
Mr. President of the UNESCO General Assembly, Mr. General Director, Mr. President of the Executive council, ladies and gentlemen ministers, ladies and gentlemen,
This year UNESCO celebrates its 60th anniversary. To all of you I would like to congratulate this for us such important anniversary. This intellectual body of the UN, as some call it, during these 60 years has reached its full maturity and fulfilled the expectations of all countries members among them Bosnia and Herzegovina as a proud member. It has fulfilled expectations set long time ago, in 1945 when the world just deserted its tragic history, decided to form its moral nucleus, and form a place where the communication and dialog of diversity will replace language of violence. UNESCO has for years matured and searched for the models by which would help to young states and peoples whose cultures were endangered and languages faced disappearance, in order to replace the power of force by the power of arguments and to give the hope to those peoples that they are not alone in their searches.
By its mission of introducing literacy and making the education possible to the poorest, UNESCO has given the hope that the light even being so frail wins over the darkness of deprivation. Today in the world of information technology, when communication seems so easy to reach and the languages of big nations so well known, it is hard to imagine that someone feels ununderstood and frustrated. No wonder, when that knowledge and love is often just a one sided wish for cognition and understanding of the other and different, which disappears the moment the same message is not reciprocated. Relations of respect towards the culture in which one is borne, by which is fed and in which his ethical path got his guidelines, should be first of all respect.
The messages are sometimes lost in translation, and the communication between big and small languages is reduced to functioning of the telephone lines, as a Croat from Bosnia and Herzegovina well known Nobel prize winner Ivo Andrić, said it figuratively. “While I was a diplomat, I used to phone my mother from a large world centers to a small place in Bosnia and Herzegovina, she would hear my words well, but because of poor telephone lines I could not understand her at all.”
I believe that the next Convention on cultural differences, that will be a guaranty to small nations, their languages and cultures, that will be a mean by which those lines of communications will improve and never again small nations will be ununderstood. As in order to be open to the others in this world, which has no borders one has to be sure in his own identity. That identity is a prerequisite of cultural identity and is as important to people as to persons. On the contrary, denial of anybodies identity and difference leads to violence. This Convention is a precondition and confirmation of the basic human right. Defending the cultural difference and the difference of identities we raise our voices to defend universal values. Giving the right to every people to their own language in media and the education of their children as the future foundation of a healthy society in their mothers tongue in which they hear their first gentle words in their homes, we acknowledge to the person and the people right to the cultural identity, we are setting foundations to a more human society, to which my country is committed in its path to the EU membership, to which will, with its cultures, languages and historic heritage, contribute in building of one common European identity, that will be proud of its richness and multi-layerness.
Not like as it was until now, making it impossible for one people (Croatian) to have radio and TV channel, own curriculum in schools in own language, an to give that right to other two people, Bosniacs and Serbs. And interpreting it all like EU standard and principle.
The world today faces the risk of uniformisation and fears which that uniformisation imposes. The lack of money and economic unjustifiableness cannot be an excuse that children are not allowed to right to be educated in language of their parents. That is frequently used as an argument of imposing uniform education in our country. Unfortunately, during the last few years issues regarding the reforms of education are being subject of consideration of many to whom that is not a primary mission, but UNESCO-s.
After the war until 2003, UNESCO gave the best fruits in teacher training and reconstruction of primary and secondary school, and training of experts in ministries of education. We would like you to get actively involved in the most sensitive area that considers the foundations of a healthy society, in order to avoid any feelings of neglect and denial of rights to education in mother tongue.
Let us remember Holy Father Paul II, that peace envoy, who said the most beautiful words that each people exist because of its culture and for its culture. The culture has created feeling of belongingness to a community among people and because of it each community owns history that overcomes history of person that builds that community. With his own life the Pope was a witness of a history of a country that knows what owes to its culture. Without that culture defended so frantically, His country would not survive totalitarian regime through which has passed. And it would not be able to refer to its old history.
Without the culture which is strongly defended and kept in families through churches and religious communities, the cultural values in my countries would not have memories of rich historic and cultural, traditional and language heritage of our peoples. My country has unfortunately experienced a war in which the cultural differences because of its lack of knowledge were sometimes opposed to each other.
The consequence of war was that each culture and people in general chaos was searching for a shelter in well know and familiar. Just like in any trouble one looks for a shelter in own home, which has given him the security. Denial of history and culture has just intensified conflict facing the fear of repeated uniformization and replacement of one force by the other.
50 years of denial of the history and culture of small peoples that constituted former state of SFRJ, created myths prejudices and history that was not thought at school, as it was denied there, and some primeval fears have given up their place to dialogue and tolerance.
UNESCO has helped a lot in organizing Presidential regional forums from Ohrid to the last in Varna, where the regional heads of states have adopted common declaration about the dialogue between the cultures, peoples and religions as well as valuing the regional cultural heritage.
We firmly believe, that the denial of the personal and collective identity is part of the past and that will never again someone’s identity be denied and that the culture, language and history of each people will be studied at schools, in right manner without threatening the other and different, and that we will be close to each other by it. The history that is often written in centers far from our homes and by selective use of information was as well the cause of long-lasting frustrations. The truth remains saved in testimonies of people that are real witnesses of the times they live.
The history that does not take in consideration all truths and facts is a cause of conflict that are born from the frustrations and from impossibility to articulate own truth. The regional history was for many years a subject of discussions, often created on long-lasting prejudices because of the other and different and selective use of information, all familiar to single-party regimes that are based on one truth.
In all that chaos UNESCO was an avant-garde that instead of mere diplomacy and investigating missions, of which B&H has seen an infinite number, has sent the envoys of peace foundation building. One of those envoys UNESCO has sent in the middle of war to the first mission to Sarajevo and Mostar destroyed by war. Mr. Bouchanki was the first peace envoy with the first idea of reconstructing the destroyed Old Bridge in Mostar as a symbol of reconciliation of then warring peoples in Mostar.
From the symbol of war and division, by building the Old bridge, UNESCO has invited the most famous experts for the restauration, World bank and EBRD with the donations of governments members of UNESCO among which are Italy, Netherlands, Turkey, Croatia and Hungary, the restoration of the Old bridge has started the restoration of trust in a multiethnic town, which from the most beautiful city in the country has became a favorite place of war reporters. Day after day, stone after stone dignified history was coming back and the place of common memories and reconciliations was restored.
Peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bosniaks, Croats and Serbs again today proud of their Bridge. UNESCO gave them back that pride, UNESCO created a place of unity and true dialog. The old bridge is material proof that the language of dialogue can replace the language of dispute. The Old Bridge is today a meeting place of tourists from all over the world, as it has always been. That is the meeting place of young people of Mostar, which by the cold river Neretva during the hot summer days enjoy as the generations before them did.
Cultural tourists replaced war tourists and Bosnia and Herzegovina and Mostar are grateful to you for that. The restored Old Bridge and the old nucleus of Mostar are just the same a meeting place of the world experts for restorations and reconstruction who come to learn and admire the skills transferred to today’s masters by experience of their ancestors in identical renovation of monuments. Mostar will, I hope, become a place from which the other places in the region will draw experience of renovation and healing up of wounds made by conflict. For Bosnia and Herzegovina this is the start on healthy foundations. Recognition of its first monument opened the door to an extraordinary discussion, where each municipality and each community compete in emphasizing and valuing own monuments, which were unknown only yesterday to the wider public. Wonderful example is Blidinje lake on Čvrsnica Mountain, and Hutovo Blato as parks of nature and urban antiquity Travnik and Jajce.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is one virgin territory full of unexplored layers of history where each layer and foundation hides one another foundation just like peoples that live there. That is the country nucleus of identity and history that knew many dynasties and conquerors, all big European and Asian cultures, religions and civilizations. Their remains are visible in kings town of Jajce, and in well preserved custom of tattooing that can be seen on old women hands in Tomislavgrad and in Bobovac in their custom of wearing black as a symbol of bereavement after the last medieval Queen Katarina, who has found her refuge in Vatikan, where is her tomb, in picturesque houses built in ottoman style as remembrance on ottoman rule architecture that was preserved for centuries and in most beautiful gardens of the capitals in Austrian-Hungarian harmony built during the Austrian-Hungarian rule in our country and in Byzantine temples of Greek Orthodox churches that are ornaments to the cities next to ottoman minarets and catholic churches. Jewish synagogues are remembrance of Jews that found their refuge during their hundreds years of migrations. But the most beautiful of all that our country poses are the bridges as they connect people and river banks, peoples and cultures and we are continuing to build them with a good spirit of UNESCO. Our history is visible in buildings, country and people, in languages, dialects and living myths. In a way they talk and behave the different cultural codes are mixed as their ancestors lived through them, in the chests with national costumes that are on the first sight all so similar and only to them so different.
In songs and stories that are transferred from kin to kin, in the way they keep their tradition, and in the way they meet their neighbors for religious holidays, when they with pride present that difference. I would like to invite UNESCO to carry on with its noble mission, so that Bosnia and Herzegovina become an example of application of the Convention on cultural difference, where conditions will be formed for everyone to be proud and to all guaranty will be given that his language, tradition, historic heritage and culture will be safeguarded so that uniformisation of identity and culture is not allowed
at the expense of the history and tradition. From my side I can promise that we will know how to show the world by our own example that the other and different, language, people, culture and religion can be a bridge that connects. The world in the future will need an example from which can learn. You have that example just two hours away from Paris. Come to learn from us and help us to be an example of coexistence and respect among the cultures and religions. As the insecure world that we witness today is so desperate for such examples.
Thank you.

title: 60th General Assembly High Level Plenary Meeting; Statement by H.E. Ivo Miro Jovic Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Mr. President,
Mr. Secretary General,
Majesties, Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen, distinguished guests,
Allow me at the outset to express my gratitude and
appreciation to H.E Kofi Annan, to High-level Panel on Threats,
Challenges and Changes who provided us with the most
comprehensive document as a backbone of our discussions and
deliberations; to the President of the 59. General Assembly,
H.E. Mr. Jean Ping, who made outstanding effort in
coordinating the Open ended working group and preparing the
draft outcome document for consideration of this impressive
gathering of the world's leaders. I would also like to use this
opportunity to convey the assurances of all the peoples of
Bosnia and Herzegovina of their support for the United Nations,
and their preparedness to undertake their fair share of
obligations and tasks in order to reinvigorate the Organization
in the pivotal moment of its existence.
Mr. President,
Back in the early sixties, at the peak of the Cold War during the
Cuban Crisis, there was a discussion around a dinner table
amongst the Ambassadors accredited to the United Nations
here in New York. As the discussion got heated up over how
soon the world will face its imminent destruction and
disappearance, and the diplomats agreed that we were doomed
to perish but continued arguing who was to be blamed, a quiet
gentleman at the far end of the table raised his hand to get the
attention of his peers. "Sincerely, my dear friends," he said, "I
fail to understand what the real cause of your argument is,
when all this will be recorded in history as a mere fifty years of
turmoil."
Well, he was fortunately right, and those fifty years of turmoil
are behind us, as well as the Cold War, the silly armament race,
the imminent threat of nuclear catast rophe and the divided
world as we use to know it. Today, we are facing the new fifty
years of challenges and threats, and we are determined to do
something about it. In the meantime, our Organization has
grown three times in size, the colonialism got transferred to
2
the history books, the bricks from Berlin Wall have become
collectioner's items, and Brazil still rules the soccer field. The
world has become a better place.
Or has it?
The rich are getting richer and the poor are still poor. We had
the same number of inter-state wars in nineties as we had in
the fifties. Instead of tuberculosis we got ourselves the retroviruses
and chicken flue. Some women still cannot vote, and a
lot of children still do not go to school. I wish that the list of
problems we are dealing with is exhausted at the number .159.
of the Draft outcome report. But it is not.
Mr. President,
I come to you from a small, but brave and proud country. It is
among those that comprise almost half of the UN membership,
those under 5 million citizens. And one of those with under
1.500 US$ of GNP per capita. We are referred to as a "postconflict
society", we are still dressing the wounds from the
tragic war, we are still chasing the war criminals, and we are
still desperately seeking mutual forgiveness and reconciliation.
This year we will commemorate the tenth anniversary of the
Dayton Peace Accord, the agreement that indeed ended the
war, but failed to provide the foundations for sustainable
peace. The sound foundation of a lasting peace provides for the
equality of all the nations and citizens, and that is not what we
have now. One State, two entities and three nations is a nonfunctional
structure bequeathed to us by Dayton, so we
decided, through negotiations and consensus of all three
constituent nations, to change it for the better, and to adjust it
to our needs and wants.
Despite the complexity of our political and constitutional
structure, we are committed to improve, by consensus, the
constitution that was given to us as a gift, and to take the
ownership of the State from the Office of the High
Representative. We are committed to ensure to our citizens the
highest standards of human and civil rights based on the
European Convention, including the right of Croats, Bosniaks
and Serbs, as three constituent nations, to be informed and
educated in their native languages. Thus we intend to meet our
3
international obligations enshrined in the Millennium
Development Goals: stability, prosperity, good governance,
transparency and fulfillment of our international legal
obligations. We rightly believe that we belong to the European
family of nations, and even though we sometimes get
neglected, we feel that we ought to become a factor of stability
in the region of Balkans.
I am proud to inform you that our Foreign Minister has just
signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption. Prior
to coming here, the State Presidency that I am a Chairman of
has given the authority to our Permanent Representative here
in New York to sign the International Convention for the
Suppression of Acts of Nuclear Terrorism, and the House of
Representatives of the State Parliament approved the
ratification of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. We
regularly and timely pay our dues to the UN and affiliated
organizations, and we have our peacekeepers in Haiti, Ethiopia
and Eritrea, Cyprus, Liberia and DR of the Congo.
As far as the UN reform is concerned, Bosnia and Herzegovina
follows closely all the recent developments, we have regular
consultations with our neighbors, countries from the region
and the Eastern European Regional Group. We are committed
to support any and all solutions that stand a chance to get the
consensus from the majority of the member countries. That
goes for the Peace Building Committee, Human Rights Council
and the enlargement of the Security Council. Respecting
unreservedly the UN Charter, we support the principle that any
decision by the UN or its bodies that affects or in any way limits
the sovereignty of a member state, needs to be made
unanimously or by a consensus. We share the view of our
fellow developing countries that we need better representation
at the Security Council, but it would be a pity and the whole
reform process will lose its momentum if we exhaust ourselves
deliberating pros and contras of the Model A and Model B. The
bottom line is that we need a stronger, more efficient, better
financed, more agile, more alert Organization to address the
threats to the international peace and security of a XXI
Century.
We stand ready to take on our shoulders a fair share of that
load.

title: A speech of the Chairman of the Presidency Borislav Paravac at the send
content:
Excellencies,
Distinguished Officers and Soldiers,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
This ceremony is undoubtedly representing an important date and historic moment for Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In the year celebrating the 10th Anniversary of the signing the Dayton - Paris Peace Agreement for Bosnia and Herzegovina, I am honored of taking the opportunity to emphasize that the ever lasting and sustainable peace has been achieved in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is the greatest success and legacy in the implementation of the Peace Agreement.
It is a great pleasure to underline the present reality of Bosnia and Herzegovina articulated in its political maturity and capability to actively contribute to the peace keeping and support missions throughout the world, under the patronage of the United Nations Organization.
Up to now Bosnia and Herzegovina has been mostly sending to the peace keeping operations military and police monitoring missions, but with this Unit from the Armed Force of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a new phase in building our foreign policy was opened manifested in our readiness to fulfill our internationally taken obligations towards the significant achievements to the Euro-Atlantic integration.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has made a progress with the improving results in the foreign policy, primarily in the implementation of the main structural reforms in all aspects of our living and in particular in the defense and security sector.
The Unit for destruction of unexploded mine objects from the Armed Force of Bosnia and Herzegovina is going today to the very responsible and trustworthy military mission with the basic goal to help the Iraq people in the reconstruction of their country thus creating secure and safety living environment, creditably representing capabilities of our armed forces and reputation of our country in the world.
I would like to take the opportunity to express our gratitude to all our defense structures in Bosnia and Herzegovina, international organizations in BiH, and especially to the U.S. Embassy in Sarajevo, which has put a great effort in the training and equipping of this Unit for the very mission.
Dear Soldiers and Officers of this Unit,
Your decision to contribute to this Mission showing your personal courage, professional approach and skill for the most complex tasks, together with the high level of responsibility and patriotism.
On behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina I wish you to successfully carry out your duties within the framework of the mission, and to return healthy and enriched with the new knowledge and experience to your dearly loved ones, your families and to successfully continue your professional careers in the Armed Force of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Speech by H.E. Borislav Paravac, Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Regional Forum of the Heads of State and Government of South East Europe "Cultural Corridors of South East Europe
content:
Mr. President of the Republic of Bulgaria,
Honorable Presidents,
Mr. Director General of UNESCO,
Mr. Secretary General of the Council of Europe,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Allow me, at the very beginning to thank our host the President of the Republic of Bulgaria, Mr. Georgi Parvanov, for the warm hospitality and excellent organization of this Forum.
Bosnia and Herzegovina welcomes the organization of this meeting and I understand it as a continuation of the process of dialogue at the highest level of the South East European countries, to improving our relationships in the field of culture and cultural heritage, started under the auspices of UNESCO in 2003 in Ohrid.
Our specific geographic location, on the crossroads between the East and the West, Mediterranean and Black Sea, as well as very rich and boisterous history of our region made this region of South East Europe to become a true mosaic of varieties of religions, cultures, traditions and languages.
Therefore, we fully share UNESCO′s views that the very sphere of culture offered a great potentials for establishing closely cooperation in the South East Europe Region.
We believe that the further joint affirmation and promotion of our rich cultural heritage constitutes one of the best and the most efficient ways to changing the image the world had about our region.
Apart from crucial cultural and historic values, our cultural wealth characterize an important foundation for sustainable economic development. I would like to reiterate that there are 54 cultural monuments enlisted as the world cultural heritage of UNESCO. We do hope it will be 55 after forthcoming meeting of the World Committee for cultural heritage in Durban, South Africa, when the decision on enlisting of the ancient core of the City of Mostar in the world cultural heritage is supposed to be done. It would be the first monument in Bosnia and Herzegovina enlisted in the world heritage with universal value and symbolic of the mixture of diverse cultures and civilizations that have been passing through Bosnia and Herzegovina for ages thus leaving invaluable signs. The Old Bridge during its reconstruction done under the auspices and closely monitored by the UNESCO experts has drawn the attention of the world public with every stone symbolizing the strengthening of the broken links amongst people and regaining mutual trust. From the very beginning as well as the spectacular opening ceremony it represented the most prominent global event recognized in the UNESCO and Ohrid Declaration, as the multi ethnic project of reconciliation and dialogue amongst different religions and cultures. There is nothing more wonderful and more symbolic to show a real dialogue than it is the bridge, which only together with the reconstruction of the Congregation Church, by which Mostar was recognizable, unfortunately destroyed down to the ground, can express its complete real meaning, and therefore thoroughly enrich our cultural heritage.
I would like to take this opportunity to once again welcome the most recent organization of the Donor′s Conference for reconstruction and preservation of the cultural monuments in Kosovo, organized by UNESCO in cooperation with the Council of Europe, European Union Commission and the United Nations Mission.
We are convinced that the reconstruction and preservation of the monuments represent one of the very important steps towards the establishing of the dialogue and long-lasting stability in Kosovo.
Bosnia and Herzegovina institutions are just reviewing the forms and the ways Bosnia and Herzegovina could be included into the great project of the international community. We believe of possessing know-how based on our experience in reconstructing a great number of destroyed cultural monuments in our country. I would especially like to emphasize the great endeavor of the rehabilitation of the Old Bridge in Mostar, which could represent an archetypal for realization of the reconstruction of the most important cultural heritage in Kosovo.
In that context Bosnia and Herzegovina is ready in close cooperation with UNESCO to organize special seminars for training and exercise in our country for the experts from Kosovo, thus contributing the implementation of the assured donor resources.
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
That new period is to be noticeable by the affirmation of the opulence cultural heritage of the South East Europe, that has throughout its history given substantial contribution to the European cultural identity.
Bosnia and Herzegovina strongly support intensifying the cultural cooperation between our countries recognizing the contribution of a network of cultural corridors and cultural rotes could considerably contribute to that goal.
Therefore we support the initiative to setting up Regional Expert Network granting a mandate to develop the Strategy for the identification, protection and promotion of cultural corridors.
By establishing of the cultural corridors, together with affirmation and joint promotion of our cultural heritage we can create our region of the South East Europe again as the region which is going to attract, with its cultural lavishness and diversities, the visitors from all over the world, thus opening new developing perspective of our country.
In that way we convey a strong political message on our willingness to constructively involve our countries into all international processes and our commitment for the region of South East Europe to turn out to be an example of the good neighborly relationships and cooperation based on the regular dialogue and valuable cultural diversities.
Thank you!

title: Speech by H.E. Borislav Paravac, Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, 3rd Summit of the Council of Europe Heads of Member State and Government in Warsaw, 16
content:
Mr Chairman,
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I would like to thank the President and the Government of Poland for their hospitality and excellent organisation of this third Summit, for their initiative in bringing us together, in the historic city of Warsaw and affording us this opportunity to plan for the future of the Council of Europe.
We gathered here in times when the picture of Europe is changing, enlargement of the European Union is redrawing it, and our task is to reassert the Council of Europe’s role as guardian of the fundamental values common to the whole continent. I see it as a victory over the division of Europe, the opportunity to create a continent of shared, common conceptions of rights and values. Council of Europe is indeed the place we all consider our home, our family, responsible to watch over the preservation of our values, a true guardian of modern European civilisation.
***
The Warsaw Summit, is bringing together 46 countries of Europe, a family that was growing bigger on the fast track during two last decades. United under one roof, we are responsible to build the inside of the house with enough place for everyone.
Fundamental values are built in the foundation of our house and we share common sincere commitment to democracy, human rights and the rule of law, social cohesion, education and culture, as well as protecting and promoting long-term success, stability and overall prosperity of all Europeans.
As you know my country has become the member of this family only three years ago. Council of Europe remains the most important co-operation organisation on the European scene for Bosnia and Herzegovina.
On our path to achieving European standards and implement norms and conventions, CoE assisted to Bosnia and Herzegovina to promote a model of democratic culture, actively involving civil society and citizens and to combat all forms of exclusion and discrimination.
The importance we attach to our accession to the Council of Europe is proved by fulfilling of our post-accession commitments, showing that we are on a good track in respect to reaching the European standards of democratic societies and our further integration in Europe. There has been a strong political will and full determination of all political subjects in Bosnia and Herzegovina to embrace the highest democratic values, and on that path we were supported by this organisation and its considerable constructive contribution to the process.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, as other countries that still remain outside the Union, needs the CoE to upgrade its democracy and develop a self-sustainable society, rule of law and respect for human rights, in years to come, at the level needed for the membership in the Union. This means promoting the observance of human rights, producing legal instruments and encouraging intergovernmental cooperation, in order to help establishing and maintaining the stability of our Continent, the hope of enduring peace and the well-being of our citizens.
We expect the third Summit to provide the answer in which direction this organisation should go in the future having in mind the challenges we are facing.
I believe, Mr President, that Bosnia and Herzegovina is the example of the society based on the shared values. Its cultural diversity, melting pot of different religions, cultures, traditions, languages, dialects, folklores, architecture, historic heritage, natural resources, persevered throughout centuries, have been endangered during the years of dissolution of Yugoslavia. It is rightly said, building inclusive, stable, and peaceful societies based on shared values means that these values need to be reborn in the minds and hearts of every generation. That is what we are doing in Bosnia and Herzegovina right now, and with a welcomed assistance of our organisation.
Experience of the Western Balkans countries shows how too often were we told that our youngsters and young professionals have so many abilities and so few, or no at all opportunities. This is our historic chance to correct this injustice. To achieve real unity of our continent we should provide environment of equal opportunities for everyone. Every one of our 800 million fellow Europeans should have the same opportunities. Council of Europe is the place to be educated, and phenomena like extreme nationalism and xenophobia come from ignorance. We should let young people travel and learn from meeting each other and enriching their knowledge and experience.
The main challenges have important educational and cultural dimensions. The understanding of democratic values and the value of cultural diversity are fundamental elements in the promotion of peaceful co-existence and co-operation in Europe To strengthen the European identity we have to enhance our cooperation in the sphere of culture, education and intercultural dialogue, and that is the only way to successfully combat intolerance, xenophobia and signs of racism. We must teach our children that our diversity, our common and our individual cultural heritage are a gift to us all. That is the least we have to do.
***
What we are witnessing here today is the beginning of the century of a new, united Europe, undivided and united in its commitment to democracy and respect for human rights, Europe united in pledging a better future for its citizens, and making respect for human rights an integrated part of the daily lives of people living in Europe.
We believe that this Summit should reiterate the role of the CoE as a true Pan-European body which can create a framework for initiatives of our common interest and make the concrete steps in the fight against international terrorism, corruption and organised crime, and in combating trafficking in human beings. We all want to better the world today to provide our children with a healthy basis to develop stability and prosperity and promote European values beyond the borders of this continent. That is what we owe to our children, but to the founders of this organisation as well.
The fight against the corruption and organised crime is the field in which we still need the assistance from the international bodies, and especially through more efficient regional cooperation. In this regard we warmly welcome PACO and CARDS programmes aimed at strengthening of our own capabilities to fight corruption and organised crime.
Bosnia and Herzegovina therefore endorses the three conventions concerning the prevention of terrorism, actions against the trafficking in human beings as well as money laundering and the financing of terrorism.
Mr President, Bosnia and Herzegovina supports the proposed Action Plan for this Summit and will actively cooperate in its implementation, as well as we endorse all parts of the draft Declaration. We do so in the firm belief that the Council of Europe is and will continue to be indispensable to the peoples of Europe as the guardian of stability, democratic security and respect of human rights.
***
We are aware that the region of major attention for the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe is the Western Balkans. We appreciate their last decision in regard with the Monitoring reports on the compliance of post-accession obligations and cooperation programmes, which from now on are going to be issued twice a year. This represents a clear positive message from Strasbourg to Brussels, and we all know that the road to Brussels goes exclusively through Strasbourg.
We understand that full and unconditional cooperation with the ICTY remains an important task and obligation for the states in the region, and we continue with our efforts in proving our cooperation is full and sincere. This is a visible sign of our progress towards European Union structures and the all-European family of nations.
In the end, Mr President, let me conclude with expressing my firm belief that Europe should establish its unity exactly in our diversity, and that Europe should gather its wealth to produce well-being for all.
We must go beyond all narrow bounds and look forward to the exciting decades of our common prosperity in this century of the united Europe.
Thank you.

title: EAST EUROPEAN COOPERATION PROCESS THE EIGHT SUMMIT OF THE HEADS OF STATE AND GOVERNMENT OF THE SEECP PARTICIPATING COUNTRIES Bucharest, 11 May 2005
content:
Mr. Chairman,
Distinguished Heads of State and Government,
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
It is a great pleasure to participate today at this Summit of the Heads of State and Government of the South-East European Cooperation Process. First of all, let me be allowed to express my sincere gratitude to our host – Romania and personally to H.E. Traian Basescu, the President of Romania for a warm welcome and extraordinary organized event of the Eight Summit of the South-East European Cooperation Process.
Mr. Chairman,
Today′s Agenda is addressing the issues of the great importance for the general situation and the future of our countries in the region. Therefore this is yet another occasion to continue our practice of open exchange of our views and prospects regarding activities focused on further development of good neighboring relationship and the region as a whole.
Speaking in terms of the South-East Europe we must always keep in mind the challenges we may be facing on our road. Positive trends within the region have led to the stability and security that until recently had been the key issues in all negotiations on the South-East Europe have finally been replaced with the issues of development and European integration of our countries. With a sincere pleasure I can say that our daily experiences have confirmed a good will of our countries in the region to strengthen the good neighboring relationships, stability and cooperation. Dialogue and understanding have no alternative thus representing the only way to discussing the issues of mutual interests.
Nevertheless, the encouragement to the all regional efforts lies in the perspective of European integration. The countries of the region can be recognized for their continuous democratic reforms aimed to meet European standards. I believe we will all agree with the evaluation that there has been a true progress in the very context. Our countries are now much closer to Europe than they were just a year ago.
On this occasion I would like to emphasize that rapid European integration of our countries implies stable, democratic and progressive South-East Europe. Keeping in mind that these processes are very complex and ever-lasting, we need joint efforts and efficient cooperation in order to achieve the initiated activities. Permanent strengthening of bilateral relationships has a very important role to be a pillar for all regional efforts, mutual communication, intensive and friendly in all areas of mutual interests. It is a basic precondition for accomplishing many goals.
Dear Friends,
We have a specific task, and that is to promote the progress of our countries in the region based on solidarity and mutual affirmation. We, in Bosnia and Herzegovina are truly satisfied with the ways in which the process of cooperation in South-East Europe is being developed and getting larger importance. In that regard it is very important to keep a mature political dialogue that we held in SEECP on the occasion of negotiating many delicate issues. No less important is how to extend our cooperation and addressing the points of specific importance for all participating countries in the process. Allow me to express my sincere congratulations to our hosts for their very successful chairmanship during the last year. We have a high regard for valuable progress achieved in the implementation of the Charter on good neighboring relationships, further improvement of the SEECP and introducing diverse joint activities. New approach to the issues of permanent importance made it possible for us to transfer political support into operational one. There has been visible progress in the countries of the region in the fields of joint actions against organized crime and corruption, creation of energy supply community of South-East Europe, development of parliamentary dimension of SEECP, as well as the defense issue regarding conversion of military capacities. We would especially like to single out Regional MARRI Forum as practical reflection of our good will to, within the framework of the SEECP, reinforce such an important dimension of the ownership over the Process of regional cooperation.
Dear Friends,
At this moment I believe that certain issues deserve to be specially emphasized:
When we speak about the situation in the region, we must emphasize that solution for the status of Kosovo is still a very sensitive issue. Bosnia and Herzegovina is interested for further stabilization of conditions and relations in the region. Permanent solution for the issue of Kosovo can only be reached through negotiations and it must meet the requirements of all included parties. In that sense we would like to remind you to the principles of regional cooperation contained in the Bucharest Charter: firm determination to transfer the region into areas of peace, security, stability and cooperation; fully abiding by the territorial integrity and sovereignity of all the countres in the region; development of peaceful and good neighboring relations in the region through reconciliation, respecting inviolability of the existing international borders, and peaceful resolving of all disputes, all in accordance with the international law. In this context, we, the participating countries in SEECP need to avoid misunderstanding especially when it comes to the issues that no country can resolve on its own.
Regarding our joint fight against organized crime, we are very encouraged with the initial results achieved in the joint campaign of the SEECP countries. However, in the context of providing stronger regional response to this evil which has a regional character it is also necessary to emphasize the role of the Bucharest SECI Center. We believe that the SECI Center has fully justified its existence and therefore we fully support the change of its legal status in order to make it possible for the Center to cooperate with European institutions such as EUROPOL and EUROJUST. Thus we would enter a new phase with stronger operational capacity, and therefore the contribution of the Center in the joint fight against the organized crime in the South-East Europe would be more capable.
Dear Friends,
Bosnia and Herzegovina has made a noticeable progress in many fields. Great efforts have been invested to speed up a process of reforms. It is in our direct interest to as soon as possible start negotiations with the European Union in order to conclude the Agreement on Stabilization and Association. There is no doubt that such a status of the country would give greater encouragement to legal and institutional adjustments on our road towards EU.
We believe that further progress of BiH into the European integration will be of use to the region as a whole in the same way as it is the case with the other countries in the region.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is committed to, through active participation, contribute to strengthening of cooperation within the SEECP framework. Therefore, in the end I would like to express my sincere hope that the results of the today’s Summit, listed in the Conclusions of the Bucharest Declaration that we are adopting today will provide furter progress towards more efficient and more valuated process of cooperation in the South-East Europe. At the same time, I hope that the following Chairmanship of Greece will be marked by advancement of this process.
Thank you!

title: Speach delivered by the Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Mr. Dragan Čović on the ocassion of the Christmass Reception Sarajevo, Konak Presidency,Thursday, December 16, 2004, at 18:3
content:
Your eminences, excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends,
I would like to greet you all during this, very special part of the year, the time of Advent, awaiting of Christmas – the celebration of the Christ's birth. I would also like to thank you all for being here today.
For us, Catholics, the Christmas has an exceptional meaning: first of all, it reinforces our faith into the Lord Almighty and His Son. On the other hand, it provides us with strength and inspires the love towards every human being and the mercy towards the needy ones. Unfortunately, in our country, those in need are numerous.
I would like to use this opportunity to inspire us to contemplate for a moment the values we share: love towards the family, thankfulness to God, esteem for the religious freedoms and the sincere respect of our differences.
Human and the laws of God have to provide the equal treatment for all in this country that has been suffering for centuries – for all of its peoples and citizens. It is a primary requirement for a better and happier future. The complete constitutional and legislative equality of each of the three constitutional peoples in Bosnia and Herzegovina - something we all advocate, shall guarantee the right to existence and the right to own religion, culture and tradition, including the right to own holidays, the joy of which we would like to share with the others.
We live hoping for that more just society, a society of peoples that would be truly equal, and hoping that every man in this country will have a life that is worthy of human beings. We are hoping for the society in which we will be able to enjoy the fruits of our own labor, and in which we will be able to selflessly give our love and compassion to our fellow men.
I would like to remind you that in the past twelve months we have witnessed and participated in the events that in my opinion represent crucial tests, while at the same time, the key pillars for the development of our society. Another year of peace has passed, a year in which we have completed a high quality reform of the defense system and established the Ministry of Defense of BiH. We have established the state level Indirect Taxation Administration. For the first time ever, local authorities have, without the external assistance, organized and implemented local elections; without a single serious deficiency, I have to add. We have completed the reconstruction and officially opened the Old Bridge and the old part of Mostar. We have organized a high level International Investment Conference in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Stabilization Forces –SFOR have finished their mandate, and we are continuing the integration processes with the presence of the European Forces. Currently, we are active in implementing a whole line of other reforms in all of the society’s segments. To complete this is a necessity, and we have to finish them, for our own sake, but also in order to join the European Integrations.
We should believe and hope that during the year ahead, we will be able to make additional steps forward, towards bringing our country closer to the European Union and NATO; that we will be able to speed up the privatization process; to give a push to the foreign investments and enhance the social status of all our citizens, and especially to the most deprived and socially excluded ones. It is my firm belief that together, we have the will, strength, capability, determination and responsibility enough to go forward, to accept the European standards. In this country, we have a wide consensus to do so. It is our wish for all our citizens to have a better and a more dignifying life, and we wish for all the people in this country, young and old, to be able to rejoice life.
I would like to invite all of us to share the joy of Christmas with our loved ones and neighbors – I wish for other peoples in BiH to share the spirit of Christmas and a wish to spend these holly days in peace and kindness, prosperity, joy and happiness with us.
To all those celebrating Christmas, I wish a Marry Christmas, and to you all a very Happy New Year.
Thank you and cheers!

title: ADDRESS OF THE CHAIRMAN OF PRESIDENCY OF BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA MR. BORISLAV PARAVAC, Regional Summit On “The Development of Inter-religious and Inter- ethnic Dialogue – An Importanat Factor for the S
content:
Mr. Chairman,
Distinguished Presidents,
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Allow me to express my sincere gratitude to the President of Albania, H.E. Mr. Alfred Moisiu and the Director-General of UNESCO, Mr. Koichiro Matsuura, for the invitation to participate at this Summit.
I am truly confident that the dialogue among peoples and religions in this region is the key factor thus contributing the everlasting peace, stability and progress. The tragic event Bosnia and Herzegovina has experienced in the past decade is yet another proof for that.
Inter-ethnic and inter-religious dialogue has to be a permanent process which will be beyond the sphere of verbal, contemplations and adopted declarations acknowledged into the everyday living. Without an open dialogue there is no true reconciliation.
All the peoples and cultures want to enjoy the real freedom, equality and harmony. Cherishing protecting and safeguarding the cultural heritage, as well as the freedom to practice the religion, to speak the languages and respect the traditions are the basic rights of every human being.
Cultural diversities are enriching our reality. The more we accept and respect it the better it will be for our stability, happiness and prosperity.
There should not be created the sense or the atmosphere where any of the ethnicities or the religions will be put to the moral suspect or culpability.
We have to faster release ourselves of the disputes from the past and overcome it through a dialogue between the nations, religions and states, especially that we are all strongly committed to the peace, stability, progress and access the Euro-Atlantic integrations.
Our major determinant will be to show the readiness to uphold and sustain mutual dialogue across a range of issues resolving them we advance further to the road of peace, democracy, security and stabilization in the region.
We must build coexistence fully recognizing mutual diversities. We will better respect our culture and religion if we understand others.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
People of Bosnia and Herzegovina are really aware that there is no prosperous future without a true reconciliation, tolerance, mutual respect and understanding. It could only be achieved through a dialogue which will fully be recognizing the identities of all the peoples living in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The best example that the dialogue is possible is the nearly passing of the Law on freedom of religion and legitimacy of churches and religious societies in Bosnia and Herzegovina. For a country in the Balkans, which just a decade ago went out of the war it represented a tremendous progress. Every human being is guaranteed to the full enjoyment of freedom of expression and practicing a religion according to the best human rights standards encompassed in the international charters and conventions.
Theologians, religious dignitaries, believers and citizens, are the ones contributing in a legal manner to the spiritual background as a principle Bosnia and Herzegovina is functioning. Without the crucial background there is neither a vivid word, nor a proper dialogue such as Bosnia and Herzegovina.
As a fruit of the dialogue is the restoration of the cultural heritage, I would specially like to emphasize the reconstruction of the Old Bridge /Stari most/ in Mostar, with the immense support of UNESCO. I would also like to use the presence of the Director-General of UNESCO, Mr. Koichiro Matsuura to express on behalf of Bosnia and Herzegovina sincere gratitude.
We are aware that in the oncoming period we must work more decisively on promotion of the dialogue in order to prepare the young generations to live in tolerance fully recognizing all national and cultural identities.
Progress in information and communication technologies, network exchange, is crucial for building and contributing the greater understanding and respect of the different ethnic, cultural and religious knowledge and creativity especially amongst the young generations.
We are affirmative of building a praiseworthy society, with the highest ethical norms. Only in such a society we could create a genuine culture of living and dialogue.
Sincere and open dialogue between the people, national minorities and confessions, based on the equality, human rights protection and guarantees for freedom of expression beliefs, rule of law, recognition and respect for cultural diversity, will be the grounds on which we are going to build and develop true reconciliation and coexistence in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I am hopeful that the constructive exchange of views at the Tirana Summit will contribute to the better understanding between our peoples and cultures of this region and further improvement of the relationships between our countries.
I am optimistic in a belief that the results of the Summit will symbolize a clear signal to the international community about the readiness of the countries of South-East Europe, through an intensified dialogue, to further promote peace, stability and prosperity, not only in this part of Europe but much broadly.

title: Speech by H. E. dr. Dragan Covic, Croat Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina on the occasion of the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina
content:
Your Excellencies,
Ladies and gentlemen,
Dear friends,
It is my great pleasure to welcome you on behalf of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina and on my own behalf. I would like to sincerely thank you for your presence which lends solemnity to the Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Throughout its turbulent past, Bosnia and Herzegovina was experiencing numerous ordeals, mainly caused by global events, ordeals and historical events that were hurting, improving, changing and complementing… nevertheless, Bosnia and Herzegovina has always managed to survive, survive while carrying its basic feature… confirming the coexistence despite the differences.
Along with the tolerance and mutual respect, acknowledgment of others and those different, this shall be a main reference of our future.
By its internal structure, its historical, political, cultural, religious and ethnical diversity on one hand, and at the same time, the common coexistence on the other, Bosnia and Herzegovina should represent a formula that the modern Europe aspires to.
We are prepared to heal the consequences of our, often tragic past, while adhering to the principles that the modern Europe highly regards. Antifascism, fight against terrorism, organised crime, corruption and human trafficking still remain our primary mission, however, internally, we have to put additional efforts in regard to the return of refugees, protection of private property and return of dignity to the citizens deprived of their rights.
In that regard, respect for the differences, continuous dialogue and the establishing of mutual trust are a must.
Now, I would particularly like to emphasize that we have already fulfilled a significant part of tasks in the process of necessary reforms and that we have created a climate needed for the undergoing changes. Thus, we have opened the windows of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s future, and remain confident that we shall soon wide open the doors of the better future for all the peoples and citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, who after all, deserve it.
Past should not be forgotten. On the contrary, we must learn from it, however, today we must direct our efforts towards the future, in order to create conditions needed, so that one day, our citizens would be able to rejoice living in this country.
I am quite convinced that you share my opinion when I say that together, we can achieve that.
Ladies and gentlemen,
Nowadays, we are proud to say that there is a consensus present in Bosnia and Herzegovina regarding the issue of the utmost importance and that is the path of our future, the path towards the European integrations.
This is the path towards the establishment of a law-respecting society and the rule of law.
That project enjoys the undivided support not only of the current authorities but of the opposition as well.
An additional reason to be pleased by, and an additional motivation is the fact that all three constituent peoples as well as the all the citizens in Bosnia and Herzegovina unconditionally support the Euro-Atlantic integrations.
Nowadays, Bosnia and Herzegovina enjoys the support of International community; nevertheless, this relation is slowly changing, on day-to-day basis, converting from the tutorship into the partnership.
Regrettably, our country is still not completely fulfilling its international obligations, particularly regarding the cooperation with the Hague Tribunal.
We do hope that in the near future, after fulfilling the additional conditions needed for the start of negotiations on the accession to the European Community, we shall be able to achieve such a results, in the area of economy in particular, which will notably influence the quality of life of our citizens.
We simply expect, and will do our utmost, to achieve the economic growth that would ensure the use of our natural and human resources, increase the employment rate, and decrease the import and the economic inferiority present today.
It is my firm belief that we shall have the strength and will needed for such a transformation – after all, we have been intensively carrying out reforms needed, modernising army, police, customs, and financial flows, we are about to start building a highway that would provide for the increased use of our economic potentials: timber and wood industry, metal processing and chemical industry, power supply and tourism.
There is a merciless selection going on among those in power, to those committed to the reforms and their implementation on daily basis, and those who would still like to benefit from the tragic outcomes of our past and hinder, in every way possible, the progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a European country.
When talking about the political consensus regarding our common future, I have to add that we are facing a huge problem: a certain number of officials publicly claiming one thing, whereas on the other hand secretly acting in a completely opposite way.
There is also a still present influence of the individuals outside the institutions that are not in favour of the normalization of the relations in our country. In order to address this serious problem, we expect the understanding and support as well as the vigorous intervention of the International Community as a whole.
Finally, Your Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, please, allow me a personal notion.
Let us make progress, let us achieve results I was telling you about, then we will easily come to the agreement and understanding not only regarding the Statehood Day but the other national holidays as well.
That is the way we can achieve that the Statehood Day is not only respected, but also truly celebrated by all.
I sincerely hope that we will fulfil the responsibility we have towards our country and our future generations.
We can do it, and the most important is that we want it.

title: Speech of the chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Mr. Borislav Paravac on the occasion of the Dayton agreement anniversary
content:
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Your Excellencies
Today we are entering the tenth year since the moment when, due to the great efforts of the Dayton Agreement Signatories, a difficult and tragic war conflict in BiH was terminated and when the peoples of this country and their representatives were given chance and hope to build the democratic, tolerant and prosperous society.
It is absolutely clear that a nine-year period is not sufficient to complete a very complex task of building the civil and democratic society, and particularly, overcoming the difficult problems of our past.
It is also clear, though not affirmed enough, that the achieved results in implementation of the Dayton Peace Agreement and its eleven Annexes, representing the social reforms process, are obvious and present. They represent solid grounds for maintaining a self-sustainable state, thus being able to enter the Regional and European integration.
Allow me to briefly indicate the following facts, being the confirmation of what has been done according to the obligations from the Dayton Agreement:
- Military aspect of the Dayton Agreement has been completely realised and permanent peace achieved on this territory
- Annex 3 of the Dayton Agreement has been completely realised by having passed the Law on Elections and the elections, organised and conducted by the domestic institutions, which represented the first and probably most important step in building a self-sustainable democratic society
- Both local authorities and international community put efforts and energy in realisation of the Annex 7 concerning return of refugees and displaced persons and property repossession. The encouraging fact is that about 98% property issues have been resolved, being however insufficient for a sustainable return, which will be a priority for BiH authorities in the oncoming period.
- International Police Task Force Agreement from the Annex 11 has been successfully realised
- With the aim of ensuring the human rights and freedoms in accordance with the European Convention, many efforts have been put into realising the obligations from the Dayton Peace Agreement Annex 6. In that regard, Human Rights Ombudsman offices on the state level have been established for the respective Entities, as well as the Human Rights Chamber, whose competences have been transferred to the BiH Constitutional Court at later stage.
- The key segment of the Dayton Agreement, representing the institutional basis for our existence and development is the BiH Constitution, included in the Annex 4 of the Document. The Dayton Constitution has defined Bosnia and Herzegovina as a complex state, which, in order to exist, must be internally stable and functional, particularly in terms of the local, Entity and state authorities relationships. Allow me to remind you that we have made many practical steps to that aim, in spite of the obstructions, in order to create a functional society, which understood the transfer of authorities from the Entity to the State level. Important BiH institutions such as the State Border Service, SIPA, OSA, BiH Court, Prosecutor’s Office have been established. Defence reform has been successfully realised and the Police Reform is also ongoing. When it was established, the Council of Ministers had four ministries, and today there are nine. These and other examples show that the Dayton Agreement, as well as BiH Constitution, is a framework wide enough to ensure the building a functional state. It also shows that the agreement amongst the elected representatives always makes it possible to upgrade and improve the existing solutions.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
The whole process of building our society actually represents the Dayton Agreement Annex 10 implementation, with the key role of the international community in BiH headed by the High Representative. This is an opportunity to express our sincere gratitude to all the former High Representatives, from Mr. Bildt to Mr. Ashdown, who is to finalise the role of the international community in the post-war reconstruction and development of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Your Excellencies,
This is an opportunity to express our sincere gratitude to you and the governments of your countries, being the most powerful countries of the world: USA, Russia, Great Britain, France and Germany, for signing the peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Therefore, 21 November 1995, has taken the permanent place in Bosnia and Herzegovina history.
I would also like to express my appreciation to Serbia and Montenegro and Croatia, the countries which guaranteed the Dayton Agreement implementation with their signatures, which was of outmost importance, due to the their being our neighbours and the need for good cooperation in future, without which there is no stability and prosperity for either of them.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
There is still much to be done. First of all, we have to set impetus for economic development, attract foreign investments, and create conditions for better living of our citizens. Economic recovery is the most important task for Bosnia and Herzegovina. We certainly have to resolve the issue of cooperation with the ICTY in the Hague and bring to justice all the indictees, regardless of their nationality, since this is the precondition for our true and thorough reconciliation.
Finally, we are fully committed and absolutely agreed in passing the remaining our path towards the European Union and the Partnership for Peace as fast as possible. There is no alternative to this way. It is a path that ensures internal stability and chance to become an equal member of the great family of European countries.
Thank you!

title: Address of Mr. Borislav Paravac, member of The Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina from The Republic of Srpska, on the occasion of taking over the duty of The Chairman of The Presidency of Bosnia and
content:
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Your Excellencies,
Dear Colleagues, Members of the BH Presidency
Today, when I take over the chairmanship over this Institution, in this formal, but also symbolical and essentially important act for the internal Bosnia and Herzegovina relations, allow me to present briefly, the way I see them, the main priorities of the Presidency activities in the next eight months.
This is the institution at the very top of the pyramid of power in Bosnia and Herzegovina and this fact obliges us to perform the duty of the collective head of the state with full responsibility, professionally and in accordance with the existing standards of democracy and, in our circumstances, also mutual respect and tolerance.
